superEntry.entry:
alphabetical letter j j
The fifth letter of the alphabet: called jiymN, which is one of the names of letters of the fem. gender, but which it is allowable to make masc.: it is one of the letters termed majohuwrap [or vocal, i. e. pronounced with the voice, and not with the breath only]: and of the number of the letters termed maHoquwrap, and Huruwfu Alqaloqalapi, because it cannot be uttered in a case of pause without a strong compression, and a strong sound: and it is also one of those termed XajoriyRap, from AlXRajoru, which is the place of opening of the mouth. (TA.) ― -b2- It is sometimes substituted for I, when the latter letter is doubled, (K,) or is so substituted by some of the Arabs; (AA, S;) as in fuqayomijRN, for fuqayomiIRN; (AA, S, K;) and murRijRN, for murRiIRN. (AA, S.) An Arab of the desert recited to Khalaf El-Ahmar,
AlomuToEimaAni AlRaHoma biQloEaXijRi xaAliI EuwayofN waOabuw EalijRi
[My maternal uncle is 'Oweyf, and Aboo-'Alijj, who feed with flesh-meat at nightfall]; meaning EaliIR and EaXiIR. (S.) It is also sometimes substituted for a single I. (S, K.) AZ gives the following ex.:
yaA rabRi Uino kunota qabilota HujRatijo
falaA yazaAlu XaAHijN yaOotiyka bijo
[O my Lord, if Thou accept my plea, a brayer (or mule) shall not cease to bring me to Thee (i. e. to thy temple)]; (S;) meaning HujRatiI (K) [and biI]. Oamosajato and OamosajaA are also mentioned as occurring in a verse, for Oamosato and OamosaI [because originally Oamosayato and OamosaIa]. (S.) But all these substitutions are abominable, (S, Ibn-'Osfoor,) and only allowable in cases of poetical necessity. (Ibn- 'Osfoor.) It is further said that some of the Arabs, among whom were the tribe of Kudá'ah, changed I, when occurring immediately after E, into j; and said, for raAEK, [originally raAEiIN,] raAEijN: this is what is termed EajoEajapN: Fr attributes the substitution of j for I to the tribe of Teiyi, and some of the tribe of Asad. (TA.) ― -b3- Some of the Arabs also changed it into I; saying XayarapN for XajarapN, and javoyaAvN for javojaAvN, and yaSRaSa for jaSRaSa. (AZ, S in art. yS.) ＝ -A2- [As a numeral, j denotes Three; and, as such, is generally written without the dot, but thus H, or thus H, to distinguish it from H, which denotes eight.]

juWojuWN c
juWojuWN The breast (Sador, Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán, ” S, K, TA) of a human being, (TA,) and of a bird, and (tropical:) of a ship: (S, TA:) or the sternum, or breast-bone: or the middle of the breast: or the part where the heads of the bones of the breast come together; as in the Nh and M: (TA:) pl. jaMjiYu. (S, K.) An Arab is related to have said, maA OaToyaba juwcaAba AlOaruzRi bijaMjiYi AlUiwazRi [How delicious is jwcAb of rice (i. e. rice prepared with sugar and flesh-meat) with the breasts of geese!]. (TA.) And you say, XaqRati AlsRafiynapu bijuWojuWihaA (tropical:) [The ship clave the water with her breast]. (TA.)

1 jaOaba c
1. jaOaba, aor.
jaAa^a
, (S, K,) inf. n. jaOobN, (S,) He gained, earned, or acquired, (S, K,) wealth, or property: (K:) but [SM says,] I have not seen that any of the leading lexicologists has mentioned this addition of wealth, or property. (TA. [See, however, jaORLbN, below.]) The rájiz (Ru-beh Ibn-El-'Ajjáj, TA) says,
waQllRehu raAEiI EamaliI wajaOobiI
[And God is mindful of my work and my earning]. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also He sold jaOobi, i. e. magorap [red ochre]; (IAar, K;) and so jabaOa. (IAar, TA.)

jaOobN c
jaOobN Thick, gross, big, or bulky: (S, K:) or strong: (A:) applied to an ass, (A, K,) or to a wild ass: (S, K:) as also jaAbN, without C: (S:) pl. juWuwbN. (TA.) Accord. to the K [and the A], it signifies also Whatever is rude, or coarse; thick, gross, big, or bulky: (kulRu jaAfK galiyZK:) but in the L, we find kaAhilN jaOobN galiyZN [meaning that jaOobN applied to the part of the back termed kAhl signifies thick, or big]: and xaloqN jaOobN as meaning a thick, gross, big, or bulky, make. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AljaOobu The lion. (A, Sgh, K.) ― -b3- And jaOobapu AlmidoraI, (S, A, K,) or, accord. to AO (S) and the Mj (TA) and Sh, (TA in art. jwb q. v.,) without C, (S, TA,) A doe-gazelle having her horn just come forth; because the horn when it first comes forth is thick, and afterwards becomes slender; (S, K;) thus showing her to be young: (S:) or a doe-gazelle, and a cow, strong in the horn. (A.) [See also art. jwb.] ― -b4- You say also, fulaAnN Xaxotu AlMli jaOobu AlSRabori (assumed tropical:) Such a one is slender in body, or person, [but] great in patience. (S.) ＝ -A2- The navel. (K.) ＝ -A3- Red ochre; syn. magorap [read by Golius mEzp]; (Mj, K;) with and without C, (Mj, TA.)

jaOobapu AlbaToni c
jaOobapu AlbaToni, (Ibn-Buzurj, K,) as also jaboOapu AlbaToni, (Ibn-Buzurj, TA,) i. q. maOonapu AlbaToni, (K,) i. e. The part of the belly that is between the navel and the pubes. (TA.)

juWobapN c
juWobapN: see what next follows.

juWuwbapN c
juWuwbapN (K) and juWobapN↓ (K accord. to some copies, but not in others nor in the TA) A grinning, and frowning, or contracting, of the face; or looking sternly, austerely, or morosely. (K.)

jaORLbN c
jaORLbN A gainer, an earner, or an acquirer, of wealth, or property. (TA voce jawRaAbN.)

jaAvaliyqN jAvlyq jvlyq
jaAvaliyqN [an arabicized word, from the Greek καθολικὸς, The catholicos; i. e.] the primate of the Christians in the country of El- Islám, [residing] in the [chief] city of El-Islám: under him is the biToriyq [or biToriyk, or baTorak, i. e. patriarch] of Antioch: then, under him, is the maToraAn [or metropolitan]; under whom is the OusoqufR [or bishop], in every province: then, the qisRiys [or priest]: then, the XamRaAs [or deacon]: (K:) accord. to Sgh, a judge, or ruler: in the Tekmileh, a wise man, or sage. (TA.) j and q do not occur in any one word, unless it is arabicized or a word imitative of a sound: (S and K * at the beginning of the section in which this word is mentioned:) accord. to El-Jawáleekee, they do not occur in any Arabic word unless separated, as in jalawobaqN and jaranodaqN: accord. to Lth, they occur in many words, most of which are arabicized. (TA ib.)

1 jaOara c
1. jaOara, aor.
jaAa^a
, inf. n. juWaArN (S, A, K) and jaOor (K,) He, (a bull, S and K, or a calf, A,) and jaOorato she, (a cow, K,) lowed. (S, A, K.) juWaArN is like xuwaArN; and is substituted for the latter in a reading of the Kur vii. 146 and xx. 90. (Akh, S.) ― -b2- Also, (S, A, K,) inf. ns. as above, (K,) He (a man praying, A and TA) raised his voice in prayer, or supplication: (Th, K:) he cried out: (Es-Suddee, TA:) he cried out, calling for aid, or succour; humbled, or abased, himself, and raised his voice: (A:) he humbled, or abased, himself, with earnest supplication; (S, K;) AilaI QllRehi
to God; (S;) and cried out, or called, for aid, or succour. (K.) [Accord. to Katádeh, yajoOaruwna in the Kur xxiii. 66 signifies yaxoraEuwna, as written in the TA; but this is app. a mistranscription for yajozaEuwna, They manifest grief and agitation; &c.] ― -b3- Also (tropical:) It (a plant) grew tall; (A, K;) like as one says, SaAHati AlXRajarapu. (A.) And jaOarati AlOaroDu (tropical:) The plants, or herbage, of the land grew tall. (A, K.)

jaOorN c
jaOorN, applied to herbage, (Az, A, K,) (tropical:) Fresh, juicy, or sappy: (K, * TA:) or tall, and fullgrown: (Az, TA:) and abundant. (A, K.) ― -b2- gayovN jaOorN, (K,) and juWarN↓, (As, S, A, K,) and, accord. to As, juWaArN↓, (TA voce jawarRN,) as also jiwarRN, (K,) (tropical:) A copious rain; (As, S, A, K;) that makes the plants, or herbage, to grow tall: (A:) or the second, a rain that makes a sound, or noise. (TA.)

juWRrN c
juWRrN: see jaOorN.

juWaArN c
juWaArN: see jaOorN.

huwa jaORrN biAllRayoli c
huwa jaORrN biAllRayoli [He is one who cries out, calling for aid, or succour; who humbles, or abases, himself, and raises his voice; much, or often, by night]. (A, TA.)

1 jaOaXato nafosuhu c
1. jaOaXato nafosuhu, aor.
jaAa^a
, His soul rose, or heaved, by reason of grief or fear; (As, K;) a dial. var. of jaAXato, aor. tajiyXu. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, both of these, His (a coward's) soul purposed flight: or was frightened. (TA in art. jyX.) ― -b3- jaOaXa Uilayohi, aor.
jaAa^a
, He came, came forward, or advanced, towards him. (K.)

jaOoXo c
jaOoXo The return to its place, (ruwaAE, Lth, S, K,) or the fright, (rawoE, as in a copy of the A, [which latter is agreeable with explanations of the verb given above,]) of the heart, when in a state of commotion on an occasion of fright. (Lth, S, A, K.) ＝ -A2- The soul (nafos) of a man: (IDrd, A, K:) or his heart: or firmness, or constancy, of heart: or strength of heart when one hears a thing and knows not what it is: (TA:) sometimes, [jaAXN,] without C: (K:) pl. juWuwXN (K) and jiYaAXN. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN raAbiTu AljaOoXi Such a one restrains his soul, or himself, from flight, by reason of his courage; (S A; *) is strong in heart; as also rabiyTu AljaOoXi: (S in art. rbT:) or both signify is courageous. (K in art. rbT, q. v.) And waAhiI AljaOoXi [Infirm, or weak, in soul, or heart]. (A, TA.) And rabaTa licelika AlOamori jaOoXFA, (A,) or jaAXFA only, [without C,] (ISk, TA,) see art. rbT. And rabaTa jaOoXuhu His heart became strong. (K in art. rbT q. v.) ― -b2- See also juWoXuwXN.

juWoXN c
juWoXN: see what follows.

juWoXuwXN c
juWoXuwXN The breast, or chest; (S, A, K;) as also jaOoXN↓ and juWoXN↓: (A:) or its Hayozuwm, q. v. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b2- The forepart (Sador) of the night; accord. to which explanation it is tropical: or what is between the beginning and the third thereof: or a while thereof: (TA:) or a portion thereof; (Lh, K;) and of people. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also A thick, or gross, or coarse, man. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.)

jayoOalu c
jayoOalu The DabuE [or female hyena]; (S, K;) a name thereof, of the measure fayoEalu, determinate without Al (S,) imperfectly decl.; (K;) as also jayoOalapu↓, (S, K,) accord. to Ks; (S;) and jayalu, without C, (S, K,) the I not being changed into A as in naAbN and the like because the C, though literally suppressed, is considered as though meant to be retained, and because the I is considered as though meant to be quiescent; (Aboo-'Alee the grammarian, S, TA;) and AljayoOalu, (K,) like the first, but with Al. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, AljayoOalu, accord. to Ibn-Es-Seed, The wolf: but MF deems this strange. (TA.)

jayoOalapu c
jayoOalapu: see above.

jaAmN jAm
jaAmN: see art. jwm.

jaAmuwsN jAmws
jaAmuwsN: see art. jys.

juWonapN c
juWonapN A receptacle of the kind termed safaT, covered with skin, for the perfumes of the seller of perfumes; as also juwnapN: originally with C: pl. like SuradN [i. e. juwanN: thus in the TA, without C]. (K.) See also art. jwn.

jaAhN jAh jAp
jaAhN: see art. jwh.

jaAwarosN jAwrs
jaAwarosN: see art. jrs.

3 jaAMniI jAMnI jAMny
3. jaAMniI: see 3 in art. jyO.

1 jabRahu jb jbh jbp
1. jabRahu, aor.
jabuba
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. jabRN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and jibaAbN, (A, K, MF,) He cut it; or cut it off; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also Ajtbahu↓. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- jabRa xuSaAhu, inf. n. jabRN and jibaAbN, He cut off entirely, or extirpated, his testicles; (TA;) [as also AijotabRahaA↓; for] jabRN (A, K) and jibaAbN and AijotibaAbN (TA) signify the cutting off entirely, or extirpating, (A, K, TA,) of the testicle, (K, TA,) or of the genitals: (A:) [or] jibaAbN signifies [or signifies also, as inf. n. of jubRa,] the having the testicles, (S, TA,) or genitals, (Msb,) entirely cut off. (S, * Msb, TA.) You say also, jababotuhu, meaning I cut off entirely, or extirpated, his genitals; (Msb;) [or his testicles; or his penis; as is implied in the TA:] and jubRa, inf. n. jabRN, (Mgh, TA,) [or jibaAbN,] he had his penis and his testicles [or either of these] cut off entirely, or extirpated. (Mgh, TA. *) ― -b3- jabRa AlsRanaAma, aor.
jabuba
, inf. n. jabRN; and AjtbRhu↓; He cut off the hump of the camel: accord. to Lth, jabRN signifies the cutting off entirely, or extirpating, of the hump. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jabRa AlnRaxola, (As, S, Msb, TA,) [aor.
jabuba
,] inf. n. jabRN, (A, K,) or jibaAbN, (S, TA,) or jabaAbN, (A,) or both the second and last, (Msb, [the first is disallowed by MF,]) He fecundated the palmtrees [with the pollen of the male tree]. (As, S, A, Msb, TA.) You say, jaMCa zamanu AljibaAbi, (S,) or AljabaAbi, with fet-h, (A,) or both, (Msb,) [The time of the fecundating of the palm-trees came]. ＝ -A3- jabRa Alqawoma, (S,) aor.
jabuba
, (TA,) inf. n. jabRN, (K,) He surpassed, or overcome, the people, or company of men; (S, K, * TA;) accord. to some, in grounds of pretension to respect or honour, or in beauty, and in any or every manner. (TA.) And jabRati AlnRisaMCa She surpassed the [other] women in her beauty. (TA.) The saying
jabRato nisaMCa AlEaAlamiyna biAlsRababo
[She overcame the women of the whole world by means of the string] relates to a woman who measured round her hinder parts with a string, and then threw it to the women of the tribe, that they might do with it the like; but they found it to be much exceeding their measures. (TA.) See 3, in three places. ＝ -A4- See also 2.

2 tajobiybN tjbyb
2. tajobiybN The reaching of the [whiteness termed] taHojiyl, in a horse, to the knee and the hock: (S:) or the rising of the whiteness to [the extent of] what is termed Aljababu. (K.) You say of a horse, fiyhi tajobiybN [In him is a rising of the tHjyl to the knee and the hock]: and in this case, the horse is said to be mujabRabN: and the subst. is jababN↓ [meaning a whiteness of the legs rising to the knee and the hock]. (S.) [See mujabRabN.] ＝ -A2- The act of shrinking [from a thing]; or the being averse [from it]; or the act of withdrawing; (S, K, TA;) outwardly or inwardly. (TA.) You say of a man, jabRaba facahaba [He shrank, or was averse, or withdrew, and went away]. (S.) And jayRaba AlnRaAsu Eano TaAEapi QllRehi The people forsook, or relinquished, the obeying of God. (TA from a trad.) ― -b2- The act of fleeing. (K.) You say of a man, jbab He fled. (TA.) El-Hotei-ah says,
wanaHonu UicaA jabRabotumu Eano nisaAYikumo
kamaA jabRabato mino Einodi OawolaAdihaA AlHumuro
[And we, when ye flee from your women, like as the wild asses have fled from the presence of their young ones]. (TA.) And jabRa↓, said of a man, [if not a mistranscription for jabRaba,] signifies He went quickly, fleeing from a thing. (TA.) ＝ -A3- The act of satisfying with water (K, TA) the earth, (Aljabuwb, TA,) or cattle. (K, TA.)

3 jibaAb jb jbAb jbp
3. jibaAb The act of vying, or contending for superiority, in goodliness, or beauty, &c., (K,) as, for instance, in grounds of pretension to respect or honour, and in lineage: (TA:) and mujaAbRapN the vying, or contending for superiority, in goodliness, or beauty, (K,) &c., (TA,) and in food: (K:) but [SM says,] I know not whence this addition, respecting food, is derived. (TA. [See, however, what follows, from the A.]) You say, jaAbRaniI fajababotuhu↓ He vied with me, or contended with me for superiority, and I overcame him. (TA.) And jaAbRati AlmaroOapu SaAHibatahaA HusonFA fajabRatohaA↓ The woman vied, or contended for superiority, with her fellow, and surpassed her in beauty. (TA.) And jaAbRahu fiI AlqiraI fajabRahu↓ He vied with him, or contended with him for superiority, in the entertainment of guests, and he overcame him therein. (A.)

4 AjbR OjAb Ojb Ajb jAb jb jbI wjb
4. AjbR It (camels' milk) had, or produced, what is termed jubaAb [q. v.]. (K.)

5 tjbRb jb tjbb
5. tjbRb He clad himself with a jubRap [q. v.]. (MA.) [And so, app., AjtbR↓, explained by Golius, on the authority of Ibn-Maaroof, as signifying He put on a vest, or tunic.]

8 Uijotababa
8: see 1, in three places: ＝ -A2- and see also 5.

R. Q. 1 jabojaba jbjb
R. Q. 1. jabojaba He dealt, or trafficked, in jabaAjib [pl. of jubojubapN, q. v.]. (TA.)

R. Q. 2 tajabojaba tjbjb
R. Q. 2. tajabojaba i. q. AitRaXaqa; (S, TA;) i. e. He prepared what is called jubojubap: (TA:) or he put what is called xaloE into a jubojubap [q. v.]. (AZ, TA.)

jubRN jb
jubRN A well: (A, K:) or a well not cased with stone or the like: (S, A, Msb, K:) or a well containing much water: or a deep well: (A, K:) or of some other description: (A:) or a well in a good situation with respect to pasture: or one that people have found; not one that they have dug: (K:) or a well that is not deep: (Lth, TA:) or a well that is wide, or ample: (ElKilábeeyeh, TA:) or a well that is cut through rock, or smooth rock, or stones, or smooth stones, or hard and smooth and large stones: (Aboo- Habeeb, TA:) of the masc. gender; (Msb, TA;) [not fem. like biYorN;] or masc. and fem.: (Fr, Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] OajobaAbN (Msb, K.) and [of mult.] jibaAbN and jibabapN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- A well that is dug wherein a grape — vine is planted; like as one is dug for the shoot of a palm — tree: pl. jibaAbN. (ISh, TA.) ― -b3- The inside of a well, from its bottom to its top, whether cased with stone or the like or not. (Sh, TA.) ― -b4- The juron of a well [app. meaning A hollowed stone, or stone basin, for water, placed at the mouth of a well: or, perhaps, a hollowed stone placed over the mouth; for many a well has such a stone, forming a kind of parapet]. (Zeyd Ibn-Kuthweh, TA.) ＝ -A2- [A kind of leathern bag;] a mazaAdap of which one part is sewed to another, (K, TA,) wherein they used to prepare the beverage termed nabiyc, until, by use, it acquired strength for that purpose; mentioned in a trad., forbidding the use of it; and also called majobuwbapN↓. (TA.) ＝ -A3- The spathe, or envelope, of the spadix, or flowers, of the palmtree; also called jufRN: the former word was unknown to A'Obeyd: both occur, accord. to different readings, in a trad., where it is said that a charm contrived to bewitch Mohammad was put into the jubR, or jufR, of a TaloEap: accord. to Sh, (TA,) it means the inside of a TaloEap [which latter here app. signifies, as it does in some other instances, the spathe, not the spadix, of a palmtree]; (K, TA;) in like manner as the inside of a well, from its bottom to its top, is called jubR: the pl. is jibaAbN. (TA.) Hence the well-known prov., jibaAbN falaA taEanRa OaborFA [They are merely envelopes of the flowers of palm-trees; therefore weary not thyself to effect fecundation]; applied to a man in whom is little or no good; meaning he is like the spathes of the palm-tree in which are no flowers; therefore weary not thyself by attempting to make him good; laA taEanRa being for laA tataEanRa. (MF.)

jubRapN jb jbh jbp
jubRapN A well-known garment [or coat], (Msb, K, TA,) of the kind of those called muqaTRaEaAt: (TA:) accord. to ' Iyád, a garment cut out and sewed: accord. to Ibn-Hajar and others, a double garment quilted with cotton; or, sometimes, if of wool, a single garment, not quilted with anything: (MF:) [most probably not so much resembling the modern garment more generally known by the same name (for a description and representation of which see my “ Modern Egyptians, ” ch. i.,) as a kind of jubRap still worn in Northern Africa, described in this Lexicon voce midoraEapN: accord. to Golius, “ tunica ex panno gossipino, cui pallium seu toga imponitur, cum subductitio panno et intercedente gossipio punctim consuta: Italis consona voce giuppa: si ita cum gossipio consuta non sit, durRaAEapN tunica illa gossipina dicitur: ”] pl. jubabN (Msb, K) and jibaAbN. (S, K.) ― -b2- I. q. diroEN [A coat of mail; or any coat of defence]: (K:) pl. jubabN. (TA.) Er-Rá'ee says,
lanaA jubabN waOaromaAHN TiwaAlN
bihinRa numaArisu AlHaroba AlXRaTuwnaA
[We have coats of mail, or of defence, and long spears: with them we ply distant war]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- The part of a spear-head into which the shaft enters: (S, K:) and the vaEolab is the part of the spear-shaft that enters into the head. (TA.) ― -b2- [In the TA, jubRapu AlrRumoHi is also explained as meaning mA dxl mn AlsnAn fyh The part of the spearhead that enters into the shaft: but it seems that mn has been inserted here by a mistake of the copyist; and that the true meaning intended is the part of the spear-shaft into which the head enters; though in general the shaft enters into the head.] ― -b3- The part in which is the muXaAXap [q. v.] of a horn. (Zeyd Ibn-Kuthweh, TA.) ― -b4- The HijaAj [or bone that surrounds the cavity (see art. Hj)] of the eye. (K.) ― -b5- The contents (HaXow) of the solid hoof: or the horny box (qaron) of the solid hoof: or the joint between the sAq [which seems to mean here, as it does in many other instances, the hind shank,] and the thigh: (K:) or the shank-joint of a horse or the like (mawoSilu AlwaZiyfi [commonly applied, as in the S and K voce rusog, to the upper extremity of the pastern, i. e. the fetlock-joint, which seems to be the meaning intended in this instance,]) in the ciraAE [which here app. means the fore leg, not the arm]: or, accord. to As, the part where the wZyf [or shank] is set into the hoof: (S:) or the part of the rsg [or pastern], of a horse, where the wZyf [or shank] joins upon the HawoXab [which seems here to mean the upper pasternbone]: or, as AO says, the part where a horse's wZyf joins to the upper part of the HwXb: or, as he says in another place, the place where each tibia and hind shank, of a horse, meet; [the hockjoint;] expl. by mltqI sAqyh wwZyfI rjlyh: and the place of junction of any two bones, except in the back-bone. (TA.) ― -b6- Accord. to Lth, Whiteness of the bTAnyp [a word which I have not found anywhere but in this instance] of a horse or similar beast, extending to the hairs that surround the hoof. (TA.)

jababN jbb jbp
jababN A cutting off of the hump of a camel: (K:) or a cutting in the hump of a camel: (TA:) [or the state of having the hump cut off; as seems to be indicated in the S:] or an erosion of the hump of a camel, by the saddle, so that it does not grow large. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 2.

jubabN jbb jbp
jubabN Butter, or what is produced by churning, of camels' milk; like as zubod is what is produced by churning of cows' or sheep's or goats' milk: (Msb in art. zbd:) what rises upon the surface, (T, S,) or what has collected together [or coagulated], (K,) of the milk of camels, resembling zubod, (T, S, K,) which camels' milk has not: (S, K:) when a camel shakes about a skin of camels' milk, suspended to him, what is termed jbAb collects at the mouth of the skin. (T.)

jabuwbN jbwb
jabuwbN The earth, (Lh, K,) in general; (Lh;) sometimes written jabuwbu, as a proper name, without the article, and imperfectly decl., like XaEuwbu: (TA:) so called because it is cut, i. e. dug; or because it cuts, i. e. dissunders, the bodies of those buried in it: (Suh, TA:) and hence jabRaAnN↓ and jabRaAnapN↓, signifying a burial-ground; from AljabRu and Aljabuwbu; accord. to Kh; but others derive these two words from jbn: (TA:) or rugged land: (As, S, K:) or hard or rugged land, composed of rock, not of soil: (IAar, TA:) or earth, or dust: (Lh, K:) or the surface of the earth; (ISh, S, K;) whether plain or rugged or mountainous: (ISh:) a word without a pl.: (S:) also coarse, or big, lumps or clods of clay or mud; or of dry, or tough, or cohesive, clay or mud; plucked from the surface of the ground: (TA:) or crumbled clods of clay or mud; or of dry, or tough, or cohesive, clay or mud: (IAar, TA:) and with p, a lump, or clod, of clay or mud; or of dry, or tough, or cohesive, clay or mud. (K.)

jibaAbiIRN jb jbAbI jbAby jbp
jibaAbiIRN: see what next follows.

jubRiIRN jb jbI jby jbyy
jubRiIRN [app. a contraction of jubabiIRN], or jibaAbiIRN↓ A seller of jibaAb [pl. of jubRapN, q. v.]. (K.)

jabRaAnN jb jbAn
jabRaAnN: see jabuwbN; and see art. jbn.

jabRaAnapN jbAn jbAnh jbAnp
jabRaAnapN: see jabuwbN; and see art. jbn.

jabojabapN jbjbh jbjbp
jabojabapN: see what next follows, in two places.

jubojubapN jbjbh jbjbp
jubojubapN, (S,) or jabojabapN↓, (A,) or both, (K,) and jabaAjibu [which is the pl.], (L, TA,) The stomach of a ruminant animal * (S, A, K, TA) in which xaloE [q. v.] is put, (S, TA,) i. e., (TA,) in which is put flesh-meat cut in pieces; (K, TA;) or in which is put flesh-meat to be used as provision in travelling; (TA;) or in which melted grease (S, K) is collected (S) or put: (K:) or the skin of the side of a camel, cut out in a round form, in which is prepared flesh-meat, (K, TA,) such as is called waXiyqap, (TA,) which is flesh-meat that is boiled once, and then cut into strips, and dried, or salted and sun-dried; the most lasting of all provision [of the kind]: (S, TA:) or the first and second both signify tripe; in Persian, Xknbh or UiXokanobah. (MA.) A coward is likened to a jbjbp in which xlE is put; because of his turgidness and his little profitableness. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, the first, A vessel, or receptacle, made of skin, in which water is given to camels, and in which one macerates habiyd [i. e. colocynths, or the pulp thereof, or the seeds thereof]. (TA.) ― -b3- And A basket, (S, K, TA,) of small size, (TA,) made of skins, (S, K, TA,) in which dust, or earth, is removed: (S, TA:) or, accord. to Kt, it is [jabojabapN↓,] with fet-h: (TA:) pl. jabaAjibu. (S.) ― -b4- And A drum: pl. jabaAjibu [which is explained in the K as meaning “ a drum ” instead of “ drums ”]: as in the saying, Duribato EalaI baAbihi AljabaAjibu [The drums were beaten at his door]. (A.)

jubojubiIRN jbjbI jbjby
jubojubiIRN A tripe-seller. (Golius from Meyd. [See jubojubapN.])

jubojubiyRapN jbjbyh jbjbyp
jubojubiyRapN Food made with tripe; in Persian, Xikanobaho waA; (Golius from Meyd;) in Turkish, suxotuw XwrbAsI. (MA.)

OajabRu c
OajabRu A camel having his hump cut off: (S, K:) or having his hump cut off: (S, K:) or having his hump eroded by the saddle, so that it does not grow large: (K:) or having no hump: (A, TA:) fem. jabRaMCu. (A, K.) ― -b2- And [hence,] the fem., (tropical:) A woman not having [prominent] buttocks: (K:) or i. q. rasoHaMCu [i. e. having small buttocks sticking together; or having little flesh in her posteriors and things]: (ISh, TA:) or whose bosom and breasts have not become large: (K:) or whose breast has not become large: (Sh, TA:) or small in the breast; from the same epithet applied to a she-camel; (A;) for a woman having small breasts is like the camel that has no hump: (TA:) or having no thighs; (K;) i. e. having lean thighs; as though having no thighs. (TA.) Also, the masc., (assumed tropical:) A pubes having little flesh. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence, also,] AlOajabRu i. q. Alfaroju [as meaning The pudendum muliebre]; (K;) from the same word as applied to a camel [having no hump]. (TA.)

majabRapu mjbh mjbp
majabRapu The middle, or main part, (jaAdRp,) of a road. (S.)

mujabRabN mjbb
mujabRabN A horse in which the [whiteness termed] taHojiyl reaches to the knee and the hock; (S;) [i. e.] in which the whiteness [of the lower part of the leg] reaches to the knee and the hock or the knees and the hocks: (TA:) or in which the tHjyl reaches to his knees: (Lth, TA:) or in which the whiteness rises to [the extent of] what is termed Aljababu; (K, TA;) or more than this, [perhaps a mistake of a copyist for less than this,] so as not to reach to the knees: or in which the whiteness reaches to the hairs that surround his hoof. (TA.) ― -b2- biYorN mujabRabapN Aljawofi A well having in the middle a part wider than the rest, hollowed out like a cupola. (Fr, TA.)

majobuwbN mjbwb
majobuwbN Having the genitals, (Msb,) or the testicles (S, * Mgh, TA) and the penis, (Mgh,) cut off entirely, or extirpated: (S, * Mgh, Msb, TA:) or having the penis cut off. (TA.)

majobuwbapN 1
majobuwbapN: see jubRu.

1 jabaOa c and jabiYa
1. jabaOa jabiYa, aor.
jabaAa
, He restrained, or withheld, himself; refrained, forbore, or abstained; or turned back, or reverted. (K, TA.) You say, jabaOa Eanohu, and jabiYa, meaning He restrained, or withheld, himself, &c., from him, or it; and regarded him, or it, with reverence, veneration, dread, awe, or fear: (TA:) [or,] accord. to AZ, jabaOotu Eani AlrRajuli, inf. n. jaboCN and jubuwoCN, [to which Golius adds jubuWN and jibaMCN, but, I suspect, from incorrect MSS.,] means I drew, or held, or hung, back from the man; or remained behind him; or shrank from him; or shrank from him and hid myself: and he cites (from Nuseyb Ibn-Mihjen, TA)
fahalo Oana UilRa mivolu sayRiqapi AlEidaI
Uini Qsotaqodamato naHorN waUino jabaOato EaqorN
[And am I otherwise than like the beasts driven away by the enemy? If they go before, slaughter befalls them; and if they remain behind, hocking]. (S, TA.) You say also, maA jabaOa Eano XatomiI He did not draw back from reviling me; did not desist, or abstain, therefrom. (TA.) ― -b2- It (a sword) recoiled, or reverted, without penetrating, or without effect: (K:) or so the former verb [only]. (TA.) ― -b3- It (the sight, or the eye,) recoiled, or reverted: (K:) or so the former verb [only]; and disliked, or disapproved, or hated, the thing [that was before it]. (TA.) You say, jabaOato EayoniI Eani AlXRaIoCi My eye recoiled, or reverted, from the thing. (S.) And of a woman of displeasing aspect you say, UinRa AlEayoni latajobaOu EanohaA [Verily the eye recoils from her with dislike]. (As, TA.) ― -b4- He disliked, disapproved, or hated: (K:) or so the former verb [only]. (TA.) You say, jabaOa AlXRaIoCa He disliked, &c., the thing. (TA.) ― -b5- He inclined his neck: (K:) or so the former verb [only]. (TA.) ― -b6- He hid himself; (K, TA;) [app. from fear;] as, for instance, a DabR [q. v.] in its hole. (TA.) ― -b7- He, or it, came, or went, forth, or out: (K:) [or so the former verb only.] You say of a serpent, jabaOa Ealayohi It came forth upon him from its hole (S, TA) so as to frighten him; and in like manner one says of a hyena, and a DabR, and a jerboa. (TA.) And jabaOa EalaI Alqawomi He came forth unexpectedly upon the people, or company of men. (TA.) And jabaOa AljaraAdu The locusts invaded, or came suddenly upon, the country. (TA.)

4 OajobaOato c
4. OajobaOato said of a land, (S,) or AjbO said of a place, (K,) It abounded with [the kind of truffles called] kamoOap, (S,) or kamoC, (so in some copies of the K,) or [rather] jibaOap [a pl. or quasi-pl. n. of jaboC. (So in other copies of the K.) ＝ -A2- AjbO He hid a thing. (K.) And hence, He hid his camels from the collector of the poor-rate. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- He sold seed-produce before it showed itself to be in a good state, (S, K, TA,) or before it came to maturity. (TA.) Hence, in a trad., mano OajobaI faqado OarobaI [He who sells seed-produce before it shows itself to be in a good state, or before it has come to maturity, practices the like of usury]: (S, TA:) originally with C, (S,) which is suppressed for the purpose of assimilation [to ArbI]. (TA. [See 4 in art. jbw and jbI.] ＝ -A3- AjbO EalaI Alqawomi He overlooked the people, or company of men; or commanded, or had, a view of them; or came in sight of them; syn. OaXorafa. (K.)

jaboCN jbC
jaboCN sing. of jibaOapN, like as faqoEN is of fiqaEapN, and garodN of giradapN: (S:) or i. q. kamoOapN: (K:) or n. un. of jaboOapN↓, which is a coll. gen. n., like kamoOapN: (MF and TA, voce qaEobN:) [J says,] jibaOapN signifies Red kamoOap [or truffles]: or, accord. to El-Ahmar, those [truffles] that incline to redness; kamoOapN signifying those that incline to dust-colour and blackness; and fiqaEapN, the white; and banaAtu Oawobara, the small: (S:) accord. to AHn, jaboOapN↓ signifies a white thing resembling a kamoC, of which no use is made: but accord. to IAar, the black kamoOap; which, he says, are the best of kmOp: (TA:) the pl. of jaboCN is OajobuWN, (S, K,) a pl. of pauc., (S,) and jibaOapN, [as mentioned above,] or, accord. to Sb, this is a quasi-pl. n., (TA,) and jabaON↓, (K,) or this also is a quasi-pl. n. (TA.) ― -b2- I. q. OakamapN [q. v., i. e. A hill, or mound, &c.]: pls. as above. (K.) ― -b3- A hollow, or cavity, (T, K,) in a mountain, (TA,) in which the water (T, K) of the rain (TA) stagnates, (T,) or collects: (K:) pl. as above. (K.)

jabaON c
jabaON: see the next preceding paragraph.

jaboOapN c
jaboOapN: see jaboCN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also A shoemaker's board, (S, K,) on which he cuts his leather; also called qurozuwmN. (S.) ＝ -A3- And The place where the false ribs of the camel end, and thence as far as the navel and udder. (K.) ― -b2- And The part of the belly called the maOonapN thereof; as also jaOobapN; (Ibn-Buzurj, TA;) i. e. the part between the navel and the pubes. (TA in art. jOb.)

jubRaON c
jubRaON (S, K) and jubRaACNa↓ (Sb, K) Fearful, or cowardly: (S, K:) fem. with p: and therefore the pl. is formed by the addition of w and n.
(Sb, TA.) Mafrook Ibn-' Amr Esh-Sheybánee says,
famaA Oana mino rayobi Almanuwni bijubRaOK
walaA OanaA mino sayobi AlUilehi biMyisi
[But I am not fearful of the vicissitudes of fortune, nor despairing of the favour of God]. (S, TA.)

jubRaMCN jbMC
jubRaMCN: see what next precedes.

jaAbiYN c
jaAbiYN The locust, or locusts: (S, K:) so called because of the coming forth thereof [suddenly or unexpectedly: see 1, last two sentences]: (S, TA:) as also jaAbK [q. v.]. (TA.)

OaroDN majobaOapN c
OaroDN majobaOapN A land abounding with [the truffles called] jibaOap. (S.)

Aljibotu Aljbt
Aljibotu, not a pure Arabic word, because it comprises the letters j and t without any of the letters of the kind called cawolaqiIR [which are r and l and n]; (S;) The idol: (S, K:) or idols: (Ksh in iv. 54:) or the name of a certain idol, (Bd and Jel on that verse,) belonging to Kureysh; as also AlTRaAguwtu: (Jel:) and that which is worshipped instead, or to the exclusion, of God; whatever it be: (Ksh, Bd, K:) said to be originally Aljibosu, i. e., (Bd,) he, or that, wherein is no good: (Bd, K:) and the diviner: (S, K:) and the enchanter: (S, K, Kull:) and the like thereof: (S:) or the Devil; Satan: (Kull:) and enchantment. (Esh-Shaabee, K.) Accord. to Esh-Shaabee, yuWominuwna biAljiboti waAlTRaAguwti, in the Kur [iv. 54], means They believe in enchantment and the Devil: or, accord. to I' Ab, by Aljbt is meant Hoyeí Ibn-Akhtab; and by AlTAgwt, Kaab Ibn-El-Ashraf: (TA:) or the words relate to these two men, Jews, who, in order to induce Kureysh to join with them in a league against Mohammad, prostrated themselves to the gods of Kureysh: (Ksh, Bd:) or to certain Jews, who said that the worship of idols is more pleasing to God than that to which Mohammad invited. (Bd.) It is said in a trad. that what are termed AlTRiyarapu and AlEiyaAfapu and AlTRaroqu are mina Aljiboti [app. meaning of things wherein is no good: or kinds of divination: or from the Devil]. (S.)

1 jabacahu c
1. jabacahu, (S, A, Mgh, * L, Msb, K, *) aor.
jabica
, (Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. jabocN, (T, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) i. q. jacabahu (T, * S, A, Mgh, * L, Msb, K, * &c.) i. e. He drew it; &c.: (T, TA:) formed by transposition from the latter; (A 'Obeyd, S, A;) accord. to some: (Msb:) or it is a dial. var. of the latter; (M, L, K, &c.;) of the dial. of Temeem; (T, Msb;) not formed from the latter by transposition, (Ibn-Es-Sarráj, IJ, M, L, K,) for both are equally conjugated: (Ibn-EsSarráj, IJ, L, Msb:) and AijotibaAcN [inf. n. of Ajtbc↓] signifies the same as jabocN. (K.) jabacaniI rajulN mino xalofiI, meaning A man pulled me from behind me, occurs in a trad. (L.) ― -b2- You say also, jabacatohu and jacabatohu, meaning, (tropical:) She repelled him, or rejected him; namely, a man who sought her in marriage. (T and TA in art. jcb.)

7 AinojibaAcN c
7. AinojibaAcN [inf. n. of Anjbc] i. q. AinojicaAbN, (K,) meaning Quick going or journeying or travelling. (TA.)

8 Uijotabaca
8: see 1.

1 jabara jbr
1. jabara, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
jabura
, (Msb,) inf. n. jaborN (S, A, Msb, K, &c.) and jubuwrN, (M, K,) which latter, accord. to MF, is an inf. n. of the intrans. verb only, but it has been heard as an inf. n. of the trans. verb also, (TA,) and jibaArapN, (Lh, K,) He set a bone; reduced it from a fractured state; (S, A, Msb, K, &c.;) as also jbRr↓, (A, IAmb, K,) inf. n. tajobiyrN; (TA;) and Ajbr↓, (Ibn-Talhah, MF, TA,) but this is extremely strange, and not found in the lexicons of celebrity, (MF,) and not heard by AO; (TA;) [and Ajtbr↓.] One says also, yadahu jbRr↓, (A, IAmb,) or jabarahaA, (Msb,) He (a bone-setter) set his arm, or reduced it from a fractured state: (A:) or put upon it the jabiyrap [or splints]. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) jabara, (AAF, M, K, &c.,) inf. n. jaborN (S, A, K) and jubuwrN [but respecting this latter see above] and jibaArapN; (K;) and jbRr↓, (K,) inf. n. tajobiyrN; (TA;) and Ajbr↓; (Ibn- Talhah, MF, TA; [but respecting this form see above;]) and Ajtbr↓; (K;) (tropical:) He restored a man from a state of poverty to wealth, or competence, or sufficiency: (AAF, S, A, K, &c.:) or he benefited a poor man; conferred a benefit, or benefits, upon him: (M, K:) but the former is the more appropriate explanation: (AAF, TA:) and this signification is tropical; (IDrst, MF, TA;) the poor man being likened to one who has a broken bone, and his restoration to wealth, or competence, being likened to the setting of the bone; wherefore he is called faqiyrN, as though the vertebræ of his back were broken: (IDrst, TA:) in the A it is mentioned as proper, not tropical; but the author of the A afterwards mentions jabarotu fulaAnFA as tropical in the sense of naEaXotuhu (tropical:) [I recovered such a one from his embarrassment, &c.; repaired his broken fortune, or his condition]. (TA.) One says also, jabarotu faAqapa AlrRajuli (tropical:) [I repaired the broken fortune of the man;] I restored the man to wealth, or competence, or sufficiency. (A Heyth, TA.) And jabarotu Alyatiyma (assumed tropical:) [I put the affairs of the orphan into a right, or good, state: or] I gave to the orphan. (Msb.) And jabara (tropical:) He restored anything to a sound, right, or good, state. (IDrst, TA.) And jabarahu QllRehu (assumed tropical:) [May God render him sound, and strong]: said in relation to a child. (S and K in art. zrE.) And jabarotu niSaAba AlzRakaApi bikacaA (assumed tropical:) I made the amount of the property equal to that which renders it incumbent on the possessor to pay the poor-rate, by [adding] such a thing: the name of that thing is jbrAn [app. juboraAnN↓]: and the person who does this is termed jaAbirN↓. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- jabara also signifies He compelled, or constrained, another. (B.) You say, jabarahu EalaI AlOamori, (Lh, Az, Msb, K,) aor.
jabura
, inf. n. jaborN and jubuwrN, (Msb,) a chaste form of the verb, of the dial. of El- Hijáz, (Az, TA,) or of the Benoo-Temeem and of many of the people of El-Hijáz, (Msb,) or of Temeem alone; (Lh, TA;) [but said in the Mgh to be of weak authority;] and Ajbrhu↓; (Th, S, Msb, K, &c.;) both these forms of the verb mentioned by AZ, Fr, A 'Obeyd, and others, (Msb,) but the latter is the form used by the generality of the Arabs, (Lh, TA,) and by the grammarians [in general]; (TA;) He compelled him, against his will, to do the thing: (Lh, Th, Az, S, Msb, K:) UijobaArN↓ originally signifying the inciting, urging, or inducing, another to restore a thing to a sound, right, or good, state. (B.) And EalaI AlHukomi Ajbrhu↓ He (a judge) compelled him to submit to, or to perform, the sentence. (L.) ＝ -A3- Also jabara, [aor.
jabura
,] inf. n. jubuwrN (S, Msb, K) and jaborN, (Msb, K,) which latter, accord. to MF [and the Mgh], is an inf. n. of the trans. verb only, but it has been heard as an inf. n. of the intrans. verb also; (TA;) and Anjbr↓, (T, S, K,) and Ajtbr↓, (T, S,) and tjbRr↓; (K;) It (a bone) became set, or reduced from a fractured state. (T, S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And [hence,] the first of these verbs, with the same inf. ns.; (K;) and Ajtbr↓, (S, * K,) and Anjbr↓, and tjbRr↓, and Astjbr↓; (K;) (tropical:) He (a poor man, K, and an orphan, TA) became restored from a state of poverty to wealth, or competence, or sufficiency: (S, * K:) or received a benefit, or benefits: (K:) Ajtbr↓ is syn. with AntEX (tropical:) [he recovered, or became recovered, from his embarrassment, &c.]. (A.) [And (assumed tropical:) It (anything) became restored to a sound, right, or good, state.] El-' Ajjáj has used jabara transitively and intransitively in the same sentence, saying,
qado jabara AldRiyna AlUilaAhu fajabaro
[(assumed tropical:) God hath restored the religion to a sound, right, or good, state, and it hath become restored thereto]: (S:) or, accord. to some, the second verb is corroborative of the first; the meaning being, God hath desired, or purposed, to restore the religion, &c., and hath completed its restoration. (B.)

2 jabRara
2: see 1, in three places.

4 Oajobara
4: see 1, in five places. ＝ -A2- Ajbrhu also signifies He imputed to him [the tenet of] Aljabor; (S, * L, K; *) he called him a jabariIR: (L:) like as Akfrhu signifies “ he imputed to him infidelity. ” (S.)

5 tjbRr Ojbr jbr tjbr
5. tjbRr: see 1, latter part, in two places. Also (tropical:) What had gone from him (a man) returned to him: (K:) or some of his property that had gone from him returned to him. (T, TA.) (assumed tropical:) He (a sick man) became in a good state. (K.) (assumed tropical:) It (a plant, TA, and a tree, K) became green, and put forth leaves (K, TA) and fresh green twigs, when dry: produced fresh shoots in its dry parts: (TA:) it (herbage) became somewhat restored to a good state after having been eaten: (K, * TA:) or grew after having been eaten. (S.) ― -b2- He (a man, S) magnified himself; behaved proudly, haughtily, or insolently. (S, A, K.) ＝ -A2- (assumed tropical:) He (a man) obtained wealth, or property: (K:) but
Lh explains it as meaning, intransitively, he obtained wealth, or property. (TA.)

7 Uinojabara
7: see 1, latter part, in two places.

8 Uijotabara
8: see 1, in five places. You say also, OaSaAbatohu muSiybapN laA yajotabiruhaA [(assumed tropical:) A calamity befell him from which he will not recover]; i. e. minohaA laA majobara↓ [(assumed tropical:) there is no recovering from it]. (TA.)

10 Uisotajobara
10: see 1, latter part. ＝ -A2- Astjbrhu (tropical:) He exerted himself much, or exceedingly, or to the utmost, in paying frequent attention to him, taking care of him, or putting his affairs into a right, or proper, state. (A.)

jaborN jbr
jaborN, in computation, (assumed tropical:) The addition of something for the purpose of reparation. (TA.) [Hence, Aljaboru (assumed tropical:) Algebra; more commonly called Aljaboru waAlmuqaAbalapu perfective addition and compensative subtraction; or restoration and compensation; because of the frequency of these operations in the reduction of equations.] ＝ -A2- The contr. of qadarN: (S, Msb, K:) it is the assertion that God compels his servants, or mankind, to commit acts of disobedience; (Msb;) the virtual denial that actions proceed from man, and attributing them to God; the sect that hold the tenet thus termed asserting that man, with respect to his actions, is like the feather suspended in the air; whereas qadarN signifies the “ virtual attributing of optional, or voluntary, actions to man; asserting that man creates his own optional, or voluntary, actions: ” (IbrD:) A 'Obeyd says that it is a post-classical term. (S.) ＝ -A3- A king; (AA, T, M, K;) of uncertain derivation: (M:) and a slave, or servant: (A 'Obeyd, Kr, K, &c.:) thus bearing two contr. significations: (K:) and a man: (AA, A 'Obeyd, K, &c.:) [see jaboraYiylu:] and a young man: and [a] courageous [man]. (K.) ＝ -A4- [Also, app., Aloes-wood: Aljaboru is explained in the K as signifying AlEuwdu, which means wood in general, as well as aloes-wood in particular; and to this is added in the TA, AlcI yujobaru bihi, as though the meaning were the wood with which one sets bones; but I think that yujobaru is a mistranscription for yujamRaru; and that the meaning is aloes-wood with which one fumigates.]

jabariIRN jbr jbrI jbry
jabariIRN or jaboriIRN: see jabariyRapN.

jabaruwRapN jbr jbrwh jbrwp
jabaruwRapN and jaboruwRapN and jabaruwtN &c.: see what next follows.

jabariyRapN jbry jbryh jbryp
jabariyRapN (S, K) and jaboriyRapN and jiboriyRapN and jibiriyRapN and jiboriyaMCu↓ (K) and jabariyRaMCu↓ (Aboo-Nasr, TA) and jabaruwRapN↓ (S, K) and jaboruwRapN↓ (K) and jabaruwtN↓ (S, Msb, K, one of the forms most known, of the measure faEaluwtN, like malakuwtN and rahabuwtN and ragabuwtN and raHamuwtN, said to be the only other words of this measure, though, as MF says, this requires consideration, TA) and juboruwtN↓ (K) and jaboraWuwtN↓ (Et-Tedmuree, TA) and jabaruwtaI↓ (K, like raHamuwtaI, [&c.], TA) and jabRuwrapN↓ (S, K) and jabRuwrN↓ (Lh, Kr) and jubRuwrN↓ (Lh, TA) and jubuwrapN↓ and tajobaArN↓, (K,) all inf. ns., (TA,) [or simple substs.,] meaning The quality denoted by the epithet jabRaArN; (K;) i. e. self-magnification, pride, haughtiness, or insolence; or proud, haughty, or insolent, behaviour; (S, Msb, K;) &c. (K, TA.) Hence, maA kaAnato nubuwRapN UilRaA tanaAsaxahaA mulokN jabariyRapF [There has been no prophetic office but a kingly office has succeeded in its place through some one's selfmagnification, pride, haughtiness, or insolence]; i. e., but kings have magnified themselves, or behaved proudly or haughtily or insolently, after it. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- AljabariyRapu (S, K) and AljaboriyRapu, (Th, Msb,) or the latter is a mispronunciation, or is the correct form, (K,) and the former is so pronounced in order to assimilate it to AlqadariyRapu; (Msb, K; *) the latter is the pronunciation of the scholastic theologians of the persuasion of EshSháfi'ee (El-Háfidh in the “ Tabseer, ” B) in old times, but the term used in the conventional language of the modern scholastic theologians is Almujobarapu↓; (B;) and AljbryRp, also, is a postclassical term; (TA;) The contr. of AlqadariyRapu; (S, K;) the sect who hold the tenet termed jaborN [q. v.]; (Msb;) a sect of those who follow their own natural desires, whose founder was El- Hoseyn Ibn-Mohammad En-Nejjár El-Basree, who assert that man has no power; that [what are termed] voluntary motions are of the same predicament as a tremour; though this does not oblige them to deny the imposition of duties; (Lb, TA;) a sect who assert that God compels his servants, or mankind, to commit sins: (AHeyth, TA:) n. un. jabariIRN↓ or jaboriIRN. (Msb.)

jaboraAlu jbrAl
jaboraAlu and jiboraAlu: see jaboraYiylu.

juboraAnN jbrAn
juboraAnN: see 1.

jiboriylu jbrYyl jbryl
jiboriylu and jaboriylu &c.: see jaboraYiylu.

jiboriynu jbryn
jiboriynu and jaboriynu: see jaboraYiylu.

jiboriyaMCu jbryMC
jiboriyaMCu and jabariyRaMCu: see jabariyRapN.

jaboraYiylu c
jaboraYiylu, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) imperfectly decl., because having the quality of a proper name and that of a foreign word, or being a compound regarded as forming a single word, as some say, (TA,) originally Syriac, or Hebrew, [???,] (Esh-Shiháb [El-Khafájee],) A proper name of an angel; (TA;) [Gabriel: and also, of a man:] signifying the servant of God: (A 'Obeyd, S, Msb, K, TA:) or (rather, TA) the man of God: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) being said to be composed of jaborN, (S, Msb, TA,) signifying “ servant, ” or “ slave, ” (Msb, TA,) or rather “ man, ” (TA,) and UiylN, (S, Msb, TA,) signifying “ God: ” (Msb, TA:) or both together signify the servant of the Compassionate: or the servant of the Mighty, or Glorious: (TA:) this form of the word is of the dialects of Keys and Temeem: (TA:) and there are other dial. vars.; namely, jaborayiylu↓, without C , and jaboraAYiylu ↓, (S, K,) and jaboraAyiylu ↓, and jaboraYilu ↓, and jaboraAYiylu ↓, (K,) and jaboraAyiylu ↓, (Es-Suyootee, TA,) and jaboraAYilu ↓, (K,) and jaboraAyilu ↓, (Es-Suyootee, TA,) and jiboriylu↓, (S, Msb, K, which is the form most known and most chaste, and is of the dial. of El-Hijáz, TA,) and jaboriylu↓, (Msb, K, reckoned of weak authority by Fr, because the measure faERiyl [or faEoliyl] does not exist in the language, for as to samowiyl, mentioned by Esh-Shiháb as against the objection of Fr, it is of the measure faEowiyl, MF, TA,) and jaborayolu↓, and jaboraAlu↓, and jiboraAlu↓, (K,) and jiboriynu↓, and jaboriynu↓, (S, K,) and jaboraAYiynu↓. (Es-Suyootee, MF.)

jaborayiylu jbryyl
jaborayiylu: see jaboraYiylu.

jaboraAYilu c
jaboraAYilu and jaboraAyilu: see jaboraYiylu.

jaboraAYiylu c
jaboraAYiylu and jaboraAyiylu: see jaboraYiylu.

jaboraAYiyna c
jaboraAYiyna: see jaboraYiylu.

jubaArN jbAr
jubaArN A thing of which no account, or for which no revenge or retaliation or mulct, is taken. (S, A, Msb, K, TA.) You say, cahaba damahu jubaArFA His blood went unrevenged, unretaliated, or unexpiated by a mulct. (S, A.) And juroHN jubaArN A wound for which is no retaliation, nor any expiatory mulct. (A, TA.) And HarobN jubaArN A war in which is no retaliation, (K, TA,) nor any expiatory mulct. (TA.) And AlmaEodinu jubaArN [The mine is a thing for which no mulct is exacted]: i. e., if the mine fall in upon him who is working in it, and he perish, his hirer is not to be punished for it. (S and Msb from a trad.) And AlbiYoru jubaArN [The well is a thing for which no mulct is exacted]: i. e., if a man fall into an ancient well, and perish, his blood is not to be expiated by a mulct: (TA:) or, as some say, it relates to a hired man's descending into a well to cleanse it, or to take forth something from it, if he fall into it and die. (TA in art. bOr.) And jurHu AlEajumaMCi jubaArN The wound of the speechless beast, if it get loose and wound a man or other thing while loose, is a thing for which no retaliation or expiatory mulct is exacted. (T, A, * Msb. *) ― -b2- Clear, or quit, of a thing: so in the saying, OanaA minohu xalaAwapN wujubaArN [I am clear, or quit, of it]. (K. [See also faAlijN.]) ＝ -A2- A torrent. (K.) ― -b2- Anything that corrupts, or mars, and destroys; (so accord. to some copies of the K, and the TA;) as the torrent, &c.: (TA:) or anything that is corrupted, or marred, and destroyed. (So accord. to other copies of the K.) ＝ -A3- Tuesday; (S, K;) an ancient name thereof, (S,) used in the Time of Ignorance; (TA;) as also jibaArN↓. (K.)

jibaArN jbAr
jibaArN: see what next precedes.

jibaArapN jbAr jbArh jbArp
jibaArapN and jabiyrapN↓ Splints; pieces of wood with which bones are set, or reduced from a fractured state: (S, K:) or bones which are put upon a diseased part of the person, to reduce it to a sound state: pl. jabaAYiru. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also, both words, A wide bracelet; syn. yaAraqN: (S, K:) a bracelet (siwaAr) of gold or silver: pl. jabaAYirapN [or jabaAYiru, as above?]. (A 'Obeyd, TA.)

jubuwrapN jbwr jbwrh jbwrp
jubuwrapN: see jabariyRapN.

jabiyrapN jbyr jbyrh jbyrp
jabiyrapN: see jibaArapN.

jabRaArN jbAr
jabRaArN One who magnifies himself, or behaves
proudly or haughtily or insolently, and does not hold any one to have any claim upon him, or to deserve anything of him: (K:) one who slays when in anger: (S, A:) one who slays unjustly: (K:) imperious, or domineering, by absolute force and power; overbearing; tyrannical; a tyrant: (TA:) any one who exalts himself, or is insolent and audacious, in pride and in acts of rebellion or disobedience; who is bold, or audacious, and immoderate, inordinate, or exorbitant; or excessively, immoderately, or inordinately, proud, or corrupt, or unbelieving, or disobedient, or rebel-lious; or who exalts himself and is inordinate in infidelity; or who is extravagant in acts of disobedience and in wrongdoing; or who is refractory, or averse from obedience; (K, * TA;) as also jibRiyrN↓: (K:) or this latter signifies one who magnifies himself much, or behaves very proudly or haughtily or insolently: (S:) and the former, one who proudly, haughtily, or insolently, disdains the service of God: (Lh, TA:) fem. with p: pl. masc. jabRaAruwna and jabaAbirapN. (A, TA.) ― -b2- AljabRaArN [A name of] God; so called because of his magnifying Himself [above every other being], (K,) and his highness: (TA:) meaning the Compeller of his creatures to do whatsoever He willeth: (Bd and Jel in lix. 23:) or the Compeller of his creatures to obey the commands and prohibitions which He pleaseth to impose upon them: (Msb, TA:) accord. to Fr, from Oajobara, and the only instance known to him of an epithet of the measure faERaAlN from a verb of the measure OafoEala except darRaAkN [q. v.] from Oadoraka: (Az, TA:) or, accord. to Fr, from jabara as syn. with Oajobara: (Msb:) it is also explained as meaning the Supreme; the High above his creatures: (Az, TA:) or the Unattainable; and hence applied to the palm-tree [of which the branches cannot be reached by the hand]: (IAmb, TA:) or it may signify (tropical:) the Restorer of the poor to wealth or competence or sufficiency. (Az, TA.) [God is also called] jabRaAru Alquluwbi EalaI fiTaraAtihaA (assumed tropical:) The Establisher of hearts according to their natural constitutions which He hath given them in the mothers' wombs, disposing them to know Him and to confess Him, both the unfortunate of them and the fortunate. (TA from a trad. of 'Alee.) ― -b3- Also (tropical:) A name of AljawozaMCu [the constel-lation Orion]; (A, K;) because it is [represented] in the form of a crowned king upon a throne. (A.) ― -b4- ciraAEu AljabRaAri (assumed tropical:) The cubit of the king: (A, TA:) or the long cubit: or, as Kt thinks, by AljbRAr is here meant a certain foreign king whose fore arm was of full length. (TA.) ― -b5- qalobN jabRaArN (tropical:) A heart that receives not admonition: (A:) or that admits not compassion. (K.) ― -b6- jabRaArN, (Seer, K,) without p, (Seer, TA,) applied to a palm-tree (naxolapN), signifies (tropical:) Tall and young; (Seer, K, TA;) as also jubRaArN↓: (K:) or is applied to palmtrees collectively (naxolN), and signifies tall, and above the reach of the hand; (T, S;) and the epithet applied to a single palm-tree is with p; (S, A;) in this sense; meaning less than saHuwqN: (A:) or, with p, it signifies a young palm-tree, that has attained its utmost height and has borne fruit: (M:) or that has been ascended [for the purpose of cutting off its fruit], and retains its excellence, surpassing therein other palm-trees. (AHn, TA.) ― -b7- Also, hence, as Az thinks, (TA,) (tropical:) Huge, tall, and strong; a giant. (T, A, * K.) ― -b8- And, with p, (S, A,) and also without p, (A,) applied to a she-camel, (tropical:) Great (S, A) and fat. (S.)

jubRaArN jbAr
jubRaArN: see jabRaArN.

jabRuwrN jbwr
jabRuwrN and jubRuwrN: see jabariyRapN.

jibRiyrN jbyr
jibRiyrN: see jabRaArN.

jabRuwrapN jbwr jbwrh jbwrp
jabRuwrapN: see jabariyRapN.

jaAbirN jAbr
jaAbirN, (S,) and jaAbiru bonu HabRapa, (S, A, K,) names of (tropical:) Bread; (S, A, K;) and Oabuw jaAbirK is a surname thereof; (S, K;) and so OumRu jaAbirK: which last also signifies the ear of corn: (T in art. Am:) and i. q. Alhariysapu [grain, or wheat, bruised, or brayed, and then cooked]. (Har p. 227.) ― -b2- fulaAnN jaAbirN liI i. q. musotajobirN↓ (tropical:) [Such a one exerts himself much, or exceedingly, or to the utmost, in paying frequent attention to me, taking care of me, or putting my affairs into a right, or proper, state]. (A.) ― -b3- See also 1.

tajobaArN tjbAr
tajobaArN: see jabariyRapN.

majobarN mjbr
majobarN [an inf. n. of 1]: see 8.

Almujobarapu Almjbrh Almjbrp mjbr
Almujobarapu: see jabariyRapN.

mujabRirN mjbr
mujabRirN One who sets bones, or reduces them from a fractured state; a bone-setter. (S, A, K.)

majobuwrapN mjbwr mjbwrh mjbwrp
majobuwrapN A woman possessed by a jinnee, or genie; syn. majonuwnapN; but this is held to be of weak authority. (Mgh.)

AlmutajabRiru Almtjbr mtjbr
AlmutajabRiru The lion. (K.)

musotajobirN mstjbr
musotajobirN: see jaAbirN.

jaboraYiylu c
jaboraYiylu and its vars.: see art. jbr.

jibosN jbs
jibosN [Gypsum;] i. q. jiSRN, or jaSRN, (K,) with which one builds. (Kr, TA. *)

jabRaAsapN jbAsh jbAsp
jabRaAsapN The place of jibos; [i. e., in which gypsum is found, or prepared;] as also mjbRasp [i. e. mujabRasapN↓, or, more probably, it is a mistranscription, for majobasapN↓, like maHoSaApN (originally maHaSayapN) and maboqalapN &c.]. (TA.)

majobasapN mjbsh mjbsp
majobasapN or mujabRasapN: see jabRaAsapN.

1 jabalahu jbl jblh jblp
1. jabalahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jabula
(Msb, K) and
jabila
, (K,) inf. n. jabolN, (KL.) He (God) created him. (S, Msb, K, KL.) So in the phrase, jabalahu EalaI kacaA, (Msb,) or ElI AlXRaIoCi, (K,) He (God) created him with an adaptation, or a disposition, to such a thing, or to the thing; adapted him, or disposed him, by nature thereto. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., jubilati Alquluwbu EalaI HubRi mano OaHosana UilayohaA wabugoDi mano OasaMCa UilayohaA [Hearts are created with a disposition to the love of him who does good to them, and the hatred of him who does evil to them]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) i. q. jabarahu [evidently as meaning He compelled him, against his will, EalaI AlOamori to do the thing; for he who is created with a disposition to do a thing is as though he were compelled to do it]; and so Ajblhu↓, (K, TA,) inf. n. UijobaAlN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jabila (assumed tropical:) He (a man) became like a mountain (jabal) in bigness, thickness, coarseness, or roughness. (TA.) ― -b2- jabila Hadiyduhumo (K, TA; in the CK, jabala; and in a MS. copy of the K, without any vowels;) (assumed tropical:) Their iron was, or became, blunt, such as would not penetrate. (K, * TA.)

3 jAbl jAbl
3. jAbl He (a man) alighted, or descended and abode, or sojourned, or settled, in a mountain. (AA, TA.)

4 Ajbl Ojbl Ajbl jbl
4. Ajbl He came, or went, or betook himself, to the mountain. (ISk, S, K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He (a digger) reached a hard place, (S, K,) or stone, (Mgh,) in his digging. (TA. [AlHaAfir, meaning “ the digger, ” Golius seems to have misunderstood as meaning “ the hoof ” of a horse.]) ― -b3- [Hence,] (tropical:) He (a poet) experienced difficulty in diction, (K, TA,) so that he said nothing original, nor anything in the way of repetition. (TA.) ― -b4- And Talaba HaAjapF faOajobala (assumed tropical:) He sought a thing that he wanted, and failed of attaining it. (TA.) ― -b5- And saOalonaAhumo faOajobaluwA (tropical:) We asked them, and they refused, and did not give. (Ibn-'Abbád, Z, TA.) ― -b6- And OajobaluwA (tropical:) Their iron became blunt, so that it would not penetrate. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- Ajblhu (tropical:) He found him to be a jabal, i. e. a niggard: (K, TA:) it is considered as implying fixedness. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1.

5 tjbRlwA jbl tjblwA
5. tjbRlwA They entered a mountain: (K:) or, accord. to the O, you say, tjbRl Alqawomu AljibaAla, meaning, the people, or company of men, entered the mountains. (TA.)

jabolN jbl
jabolN (assumed tropical:) Big, thick, coarse, or rough; (TA;) as also jabilN ↓, applied to a thing (S, O, K) of any kind: (K:) or this latter is applied to an arrow, signifying (assumed tropical:) coarsely, roughly, or rudely, pared. (K.) You say rajulN jabolu AlrRaOosi , (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, jabalu AlrOs ,]) and Alwajohi, (TA,) (tropical:) A man having a big, thick, coarse, or rough, head, and face; (TA;) having little sweetness. (K, TA.) [See also jabiylN.] And rajulN mijobaAlN↓ (assumed tropical:) A big, thick, coarse, or rough, and heavy, man. (Ham p. 818.) And AimoraOapN jabolapN (K [in one place in the CK jabalapN and jibolapN, but only jabolapN accord. to the TA,]) and mijobaAlN↓ (S, K) (tropical:) A woman big, thick, coarse, or rough, (S, K, TA,) in make; (S;) large in make. (TA.) And xiloqapN jabolapN (assumed tropical:) A big, thick, coarse, or rough, make. (Ham p. 821.) And naAqapN jabolapu AlsRanaAmi (tropical:) A she-camel having an increasing hump. (TA.) And sayofN jabolN and mijobaAlN↓ (assumed tropical:) A sword not made thin. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also (K, TA, [in the CK, jabal,]) A court [of a house]; syn. saAHapN. (K.)

jubolN jbl
jubolN: see jibolN: ― -b2- and jibilRN. ＝ -A2- Also Dry trees. (K.)

jibolN jbl
jibolN Much; or numerous; (S, K;) as also jubolN↓ (K.) So in the phrases maAlN jibolN [Much property; or numerous cattle]; and HaIRN jibolN A numerous tribe. (S.) ― -b2- See also jibilRN, in two places.

jabalN jbl
jabalN [A mountain: or] any of the mountains (OawotaAd [lit. “pegs,” or “stakes,” a term applied to the mountains because they are supposed to make the earth firm, or fast,]) of the earth, that is great and long; (Mgh, K;) or, as some say, only such as is long; (Msb;) such as is isolated being called OakamapN, or qunRapN: (K:) [and also applied to a rocky tract; any rocky elevation, however little elevated:] and sometimes it means stone; [or rock;] such, for instance, as is reached by the digger: and hence it is applied to Es-Safà and El-Marweh: (Mgh:) pl. [of mult.] jibaAlN (S, Msb, K) and (of pauc., Msb) OajobulN (Msb, K) and OajobaAlN. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A man who does not remove from his place: you say of such a one, huwa jabalN. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A niggard. (K, TA.) [See 4.] ― -b4- (tropical:) The lord, or chief, of a people, or company of men: and their learned man. (Fr, K, TA.) ― -b5- Abonapu Aljabal (assumed tropical:) The serpent: (K:) because it keeps to the jabal. (TA.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) Calamity, or misfortune. (K.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) The bow that is made from the tree called naboE; (K, TA;) because this is one of the trees of the jabal. (TA.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) The echo. (Har p. 472.)

jabulN jbl
jabulN: see jibilRN.

jabilN jbl
jabilN: see jabolN. ― -b2- Also, applied to the iron head, or blade, of an arrow, or of a spear, or of a sword, &c., (tropical:) Blunt; that will not penetrate into a thing: (Ibn-' Abbád, K, * TA:) and so, with p, applied to a faOos. (TA.)

jubulN jbl
jubulN: see jibilRN.

jabolapN jbl jblh jblp
jabolapN (K, TA, [in the CK jabalapN,]) and jibolapN↓ The face: or the baXarap [or external skin] thereof: or the part thereof that is turned towards one. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also, (K,) or the former, (TA,) A vice, fault, defect, or blemish. (K.) ＝ -A3- And Strength. (K.) ― -b2- And Hardness of the earth, or ground. (Lth, K.) ＝ -A4- See also jubolapN: ＝ -A5- and see jibolaPN.

jubolapN jbl jblh jblp
jubolapN A camel's hump; (S, K;) as also jabolapN↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also jibilRN: ＝ -A3- and see jibilRapN, in two places.

jibolapN jbl jblh jblp
jibolapN: see jibilRapN. ― -b2- Also The origin, or stock, (K, TA,) of any created thing; (TA;) and so jubulRapN↓. (K, TA.) ― -b3- The fundamental nature, or composition, of a mountain. (TA.) ― -b4- vawobN jayRidu Aljibolapi (tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, good in respect of the thread (K, TA) and the weaving. (TA.) ― -b5- rajulN cuw jibolapK (assumed tropical:) A big, thick, coarse, or rough, man. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also jibilRN, in two places: ＝ -A3- and see jabolapN.

jabalapN jbl jblh jblp
jabalapN: see jibilRapN.

jubulRN jbl
jubulRN: see what next follows.

jibilRN jbl
jibilRN and jubulRN↓ and jibolN↓ [accord. to the CK like EadolN, but correctly like EidolN,] and jubolN↓ and jubulN↓, (S, K,) accord. to different readings of the instance occurring in the Kur xxxvi. 62, the first being the reading of the people of ElMedeeneh, (S,) [and the most common,] A great company of men; as also jibilRapN↓ and jabiylN↓: (K:) or [simply] a company of men; (S;) as also jabulN↓, accord. to Kh; (Sgh, TA;) and so jabolapN↓ and jubolapN↓ and jibilRapN↓: which last three signify also the same as OumRapN [a nation, or people, &c.]: (K:) it is said [by some] that jibilRN is pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of jibilRapN↓ meaning a numerous company: (TA:) jibalapN is pl. of jibolN↓: one says, qabaHa QllRehu jibalatakumo [May God remove far from prosperity, or success,] your companies: (Fr, TA:) and jibalN is pl. of jibolapN↓. (Bd in xxxvi. 62.)

jubulRapN jbl jblh jblp
jubulRapN Much, or an abundance, or a large quantity or number, or anything; as also jibilRapN↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also jibolapN: ＝ -A3- and see what next follows, in two places.

jibilRapN jbl jblh jblp
jibilRapN (S, Msb, K) and jubulRapN↓ and jabiylapN↓ (Sgh, MF) and jibolapN↓ (AA, S, K) and jubolapN↓ and jabolapN↓ and jabalapN↓, (K,) but this last, accord. to MF, is unknown, (TA,) Nature; or natural, native, innate, or original, constitution, disposition, temper, or other quality or property; idiosyncrasy; syn. xiloqapN (AA, S, Sgh, Msb, K) and TabiyEapN (Msb, K) and gariyzapN; all these signifying the same: (Msb:) pl. of the first jibilRaAtN. (S.) Hence, in the Kur [xxvi. 184], waAljibilRapa AlOawRaliyna, (S,) meaning Alxaliyqapa, (Jel,) or cawiy AljibilRapi, i. e. And the preceding created beings: (Bd:) El- Hasan read with damm [i. e. AljubulRapa↓ or Aljvbolapa↓]. (S.) ＝ -A2- See also jibilRN, in three places: ― -b2- and see jubulRapN.

jabaliIRN jbl jblI jbly jblyy
jabaliIRN Of, or relating to, a mountain or mountains; contr. of suholiIRN. (The Lexicons &c. passim.)

jibilRIRN jbl jblI jbly jblyy
jibilRIRN Natural; i. e. of, or relating to, the natural, native, innate, or original, constitution, disposition, temper, or other quality or property; like TabiyEiIRN; i. e. essential; resulting from the Creator's ordering of the natural disposition in the body. (Msb.)

jibaAlN jbAl jbl
jibaAlN (tropical:) The body, with, or without, the members; syn. jasadN and badanN; (K, TA;) as being likened to a mountain in bigness [?]. (TA.) One says, OaHosana QllRehu jibaAlahu, meaning, (tropical:) [May God render beautiful] his body (jasadahu): and [render good] his created xuluq [or mind, with its qualities and attributes: but I rather think that xuluq is here a mistranscription for xaloq, meaning make]. (Ibn-' Abbád, TA.)

jabiylN jbyl
jabiylN: see jibilRN. ＝ -A2- jabiylu Alwajohi (tropical:) A man having a bad, or an ugly, face. (K, TA.) [See also jabolN.]

jabiylapN jbyl jbylh jbylp
jabiylapN: see jibilRapN.

mijobaAlN mjbAl
mijobaAlN: see jabolN, in three places.

majobuwlN mjbwl
majobuwlN, applied to a man, (assumed tropical:) Great, large, or big, (K, TA,) in make; as though he were a mountain. (TA.)

1 jabuna jAb jbn jbnn
1. jabuna, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jabuna
, inf. n. jubonN (Msb, K) and jubunN (K) and jabaAnapN; (Msb, K;) and jabana, (S, ISd, Msb,) aor.
jabuna
; (Msb, TA;) He (a man) was, or became, such as is termed jabaAn (S, Msb, K) and jabiyn; (S, K;) i. e. cowardly, (K,) or weak hearted. (Msb.) And jabuna Eanohu He held back, or refrained, from him, or it, through cowardice. (TA in art. Ers.)

2 jbanhu jAb jbn jbnh jbnnh jbnp
2. jbanhu, inf. n. tajobiynN, He attributed to him cowardice (jubon). (S.) And huwa yujabRanu, inf. n. as above, He is accused of cowardice. (K.)

4 Ajbnhu OjAb Ojbn Ojbnh Ojbnp Ajbnh Ajbnp jbn
4. Ajbnhu He found him to be such as is termed jabaAn; (S, Msb, K;) i. e. a coward, or cowardly, (K,) or weak-hearted: (Msb:) or he reckoned him a coward; (M, K;) as also Ajtbnhu↓. (K.)

5 tjbRn OjAb jAb jbn tjbn tjbnn wjb
5. tjbRn It (milk) became like jubon [i. e. cheese]. (K.) ― -b2- And hence, perhaps, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man) became thick, gross, coarse, or big. (S, TA.)

8 Ajtbnhu Ajtbnh Ajtbnp
8. Ajtbnhu He made cheese of it; i. e. of milk. (T, K.) ＝ -A2- See also 4.

jubonN jAb jbn jbnn
jubonN and jubunN↓ and jubunRN↓, (S, Msb, K,) the first of which is the most approved, and the last the most rare, and said by some to be used only in a case of necessity in poetry, (Lth, Msb,) [Cheese;] a certain thing that is eaten, (S, Msb,) well known: (K:) n. un. jubonapN, (TA,) a word having a more particular signification than jubonN, (S,) meaning a qurS [or round, flattened, loaf] thereof, (Mgh,) [or a cheese, or piece of cheese,] as also jubunapN (TA) and jubunRapN. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also jubonN and jubunN↓, [inf. ns. of jabuna, used as simple substs.,] Cowardice; weak-heartedness;] the quality denoted by jabaAnN. (S.)

jubunN jAb jbn jbnn
jubunN: see jubonN, in two places.

jubunRN jAb jbn jbnn
jubunRN: see jubonN.

juboniIRN jb jbn jbnI jbny
juboniIRN A seller of jubon [i. e. cheese]. (TA.) ― -b2- And a rel. n. from suwqu Aljuboni [The cheesemarket] in Damascus. (K.)

jabaAnN jb jbAn
jabaAnN, (S, Msb, K,) an epithet from jabana, (S,) applied to a man and to a woman, (S, Msb, K,) in the latter case like HaSaAnN and razaAnN, (Ibn-EsSarráj, S,) and with p also applied to a woman; (M, Msb, K;) and jabynN↓, (S, K,) from jabuna, (S,) applied to a man and to a woman; and jabRaAnN↓; (K;) A coward; or cowardly; i. e. wont to dread things, so as not to venture upon them boldly, (K, TA,) by night or by day; (TA;) weak-hearted: (Msb:) jabaAnN is contr. of XujaAEN: (Msb in art. XjE:) pl. masc. jubanaMCu, (Msb, K,)
[properly of jabiynN] and fem. jabaAnaAtN. (Lth, Msb, TA.) huwa jabaAnu Alkalobi [He is one whose dog is cowardly,] means (tropical:) he is extremely generous: (K, TA:) because, by reason of guests' coming to him, his dog does not growl. (TA.) And you say, fulaAnN XujaAEu Alqalobi jabaAnu Alwajohi (tropical:) [app. meaning Such a one is courageous in heart, mild in face]. (TA. [Expl. by AjnI Alwjh, which seems to be a mistranscription.])

jabiynN jb jbI jbyn
jabiynN: see jabaAnN. ＝ -A2- Also The part above the temple, on the right of the forehead, and on the left thereof; the two being called jabiynaAni: (S:) the side of the forehead, [so Bd in xxxvii. 103,] from the part over against the place where the hair falls off, to the temple, on the right of the forehead, and on the left thereof: so say Az and IF and others: the forehead (Aljabotap) is between the jabiynaAni: (Msb:) or the jabiynaAni are the two borders of the forehead, on either side thereof, in the part between the two eyebrows (fiymaA bayona AlHaAjibayoni [so in the copies of the K, a mistake for fymA yaliI AlHAjbyn in the part next to the two eyebrows]), rising to the place where the growth of the hair terminates: (K:) or between the place where the growth of the hair terminates and the eyebrows: (TA:) or the jbyn is the borders (in the T, the border, TA) of the forehead, between the two temples, uniting with the naASiyap [or place where the hair grows in the fore part of the head, or the hair of that part]: (K, TA:) and it sometimes occurs as meaning the forehead: (MF, TA:) [see an ex. voce tariba, where it is used in this last sense, and is fem., perhaps because syn. with jabohap, for] Lh says that it is always masc.: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] jubunN and [of pauc.] OajobinapN (Msb, K) and OajobunN. (K.)

jabRaAnN jb jbAn
jabRaAnN: see jabaAnN. ＝ -A2- Also One who keeps, or guards, the produce of land in the desert. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also what next follows.

jabRaAnapN jbAn jbAnh jbAnp
jabRaAnapN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jabRaAnN↓, (S, Msb, K,) the former of which is the more common, (Msb,) A place of prayer, (Msb,) or common place of prayer, (Mgh,) in a SaHoraMC [or desert tract]. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- A burial-ground: (K:) this is sometimes called jbRAnp because the place of prayer is generally in the burial-ground: (Msb:) accord. to Kh, these two words, in this sense, are from AljabRu and Aljabuwbu; but others derive them from jbn. (TA in art. jb.) ― -b3- A [desert tract such as is termed] SaHoraMC. (S, K.) ― -b4- A place that produces much herbage: and level, elevated land: (AHn, K:) or the latter, level, elevated land, that produces much herbage: (Aboo-Kheyreh, TA:) accord. to ISh, it is smooth, without trees; but it may have in it hills, and a tract abounding with trees: and sometimes the jbRAnp is level, without hills and without any tract abounding with trees; but it is not in sand nor in mountains, though it may be in [high grounds such as are termed] qifaAf [pl. of qufRN] and in [what are termed] XaqaAYiq [pl. of XaqiyqapN]. (TA.)

jabRAniIRN jb jbAn jbAnI jbAny jbAnyy jbI
jabRAniIRN A dweller in the jabRaAn, meaning SaHoraMC. (TA.)

Oajobanu c
Oajobanu [More, and most, cowardly, or weakhearted]. (TA.) You say Oajobanu mino SaAfirK, i. e. [More cowardly] than a whistling bird: (S in art. Sfr:) or, as some say, than a thief. (TA in that art. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 326.])

majobanapN mjbnh mjbnp
majobanapN [A cause of cowardice, or weak-heartedness]. One says, Alwaladu majobanapN maboxalapN [Children are a cause of cowardice and a cause of niggardliness]; because one loves continuance of life, and property, on account of them. (S, TA.)

1 jabahahu jbh jbhh jbhp
1. jabahahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jabaha
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. jabohN, (Ham p. 355,) He slapped, (S,) or struck, (K,) or hit, (Msb,) or struck him on, (Ham ubi suprà,) his jabohap [or forehead]. (S, Msb, K, and Ham ubi suprà.) ― -b2- And [hence], (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He turned him back (K, TA) from the thing that he wanted: (TA:) or (tropical:) he met him, or encountered him, with, or he said to him, or did to him, a thing disliked, or hated: (K, TA, TK:) or (tropical:) he encountered him, or confronted him, with speech in which was roughness: (JK, M, TA:) or (tropical:) he encountered him with that which he disliked, or hated; or he accused him thereof to his face; (M, TA, and Ham ubi suprà;) or so jabahahu biAlmakoruwhi. (S, TA.) ― -b3- jabaha AlmaMCa, (JK, S, K,) inf. n. as above, (JK, S,) (tropical:) He came to the water, (JK, S, K,) when there was at it no apparatus for drawing, (S,) i. e. no pulley &c., (JK, TA,) or having no means of drawing, so that he only looked at the surface of the water. (Z, K.) [See also jabiyhapN.] ― -b4- jabaha Alqawoma (tropical:) It (winter) came upon the people unprepared for it. (A, K.)

2 tajobiyhN jb jbI tjbyh tjbyp
2. tajobiyhN The mounting a fornicator, or an adulterer, upon an ass, and turning his face towards the tail; whence the trad. of the Jews respecting the adulterer, yuHumRamu wayujabRahu wyujoladu [He shall have his face blackened with charcoal, and be mounted on an ass with his face towards the tail, and be flogged]: (Mgh:) or the mounting two fornicators, or adulterers, upon an ass, and turning the backs of their heads towards each other, (JK, Mgh,) and parading them round about; thus accord. to the Tekmileh: (Mgh:) or the blackening [with charcoal] the faces of two fornicators, or adulterers, (Oano yuHamRara in the K being a mistake for Oano yuHumRama, i. e. yusawRada, TA,) and mounting them upon a camel or an ass, and turning their faces in contrary directions: accord. to analogy, it should mean turning their faces towards each other; for it is from Aljabotapu: tajobiyhN also signifies the bending, inclining, lowering, or hanging down, the head towards the ground: and it may be hence; (i. e. it may be hence that it is applied to him who is mounted on a beast in the manner described above; TA;) because he to whom this is done bends down his head in shame and confusion: or it may be from jabahahu meaning "he did to him a thing disliked, or hated." (K.)

8 AijotibaAhN AjtbAh AjtbAp QjtbAh QjtbI
8. AijotibaAhN The deeming [one] rude, coarse, unkind, hard, or churlish. (JK.) ― -b2- And The fearing [a person or thing]. (JK.) ― -b3- And Ajtbhhu He disliked, or hated, and feared, it, or him; namely, a country, or town, and a man. (JK.) ― -b4- He disapproved it, or disliked it, and did not find it wholesome; namely, water, (En-Nawádir, K,) &c. (K.)

jabahN jb jbh jbp
jabahN Largeness, (S,) or width (JK, M, K) and beauty, (M, K,) of the jabohap [or forehead]: (JK, S, M, K:) or protuberance, or prominence, thereof. (M, K.)

waradonaA maMCF lahu jabiyhapN wrdnA mMC lh jbyhh wrdnA mMC lh jbyhp
waradonaA maMCF lahu jabiyhapN We came to a water that was salt, so that the drinking thereof did not take away the thirst of our cattle: (ISk, JK, S:) or that was altered for the worse in taste and colour, from some such cause as long standing, though still drinkable; or covered with the green substance called TuHolub and with leaves: or that was deep in the bottom, difficult to give to drink. (ISk, S.) [See also 1, last meaning but one.]

jubRahN jb jbh jbp
jubRahN i. q. jubRaON, (K,) i. e. A fearful, or cowardly, man. (TA.)

jaAbihN jAb jAbh jAbp
jaAbihN, applied to a gazelle, (JK,) or to a bird or a wild animal, (K,) That meets one with its face or forehead; and such is of evil omen: (K:) contr. of qaEiydN. (JK.) ― -b2- Coming to water: so in a saying cited and explained in art. Acn, conj. 2. (IAar, TA.)

Oajobahu c
Oajobahu, applied to a man, Large, (S,) or wide (JK, M, K) and beautiful, (M, K,) in the jabohap [or forehead]: (JK, S, M, K:) or protuberant, or prominent, therein: (M, K:) applied to a horse, having a protuberant, or prominent, forehead, rising beyond the bone of the nose: (TA:) fem. jabohaMCu; (S, K;) of which the dim. is jubayohaMCu. (S.) ― -b2- AlOajobahu The lion; (K;) because of the width of his jabohap. (TA.)

dictScrap.title: jbw & jbI [The words belonging to the former of these two arts. cannot well be classed by themselves, being intimately connected with those of the latter, which are the more numerous and common, and from which they are generally easily distinguishable.]
dictScrap.label:
jbw and jbI
[The words belonging to the former of these two arts. cannot well be classed by themselves, being intimately connected with those of the latter, which are the more numerous and common, and from which they are generally easily distinguishable.]

superEntry.entry:
1 jabaI jb jbI jby jbyy
1. jabaI, (K,) first pers. jabayotu, (Ks, S, Er-Rághib,) aor.
1a2i2a
; (K;) and jabaI, aor.
1a2a2a
, (K,) said by MF to be unknown, and also, because neither the second nor the third radical is a faucial letter, unreasonable, but mentioned by Sb, though held by him to be of weak authority, and mentioned also by IAar, as extr., like OabaI, aor. yaOobaI; (TA;) and jabaA, (TA,) first pers. jabawotu, (Ks, S, TA,) aor.
1a2u2a
; (TA;) inf. n. [of the first and second] jaboIN (Sh, K) and [probably of the last only] jabFA and jibFA and jubFA and [of the last, but whether in the first or the second of the senses here following is not shown,] jibowapN; (K; [or this last has a different application, explained below;]) He collected water in a trough or tank for beasts &c. [Ks, S, K, Er-Rághib.) ― -b2- And (hence, metaphorically, Er-Rághib, TA) the first of these verbs, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, Er-Rághib,) and the second, (K,) and the third; (S, Msb, TA;) inf. n. (of the first, S, Msb) jibaAyapN (S, Mgh, Msb, K, Er-Rághib) and (of the last, S, Msb) jibaAwapN (S, Msb, K) and jabowN (TA) [and probably jibowapN also, which see above]; (tropical:) He collected the [tax called] xaraAj, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, Er-Rághib,) and [other] property. (Msb, TA.) The last of these verbs is said in the S to be originally with C, though pronounced without C; but IB says that this is not the case, and that it has not been heard with C. (TA.) You say also, jabaAhu Alqawoma (assumed tropical:) [He collected it from the people, or company of men]; (M, K, * TA;) and jabaI minohumo (assumed tropical:) [He collected from them]. (M, K, TA.) ― -b3- Also jabaA [or jabaI], (TA,) first pers. jabayotu, (Zj, TA,) (assumed tropical:) He appropriated a thing purely to himself, exclusively of any partner; chose it, or took it in preference, for himself. (Zj, TA.) And hence, (Zj, TA,) AjtbAhu↓ (assumed tropical:) He chose it, or selected it, (Zj, S, K) linafosihi for himself. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And jabaI and jabaA, [originally jabaOa,] He returned, receded, retreated, or went back. (TA.)

2 jbRI jb jbI jby jbyy
2. jbRI, inf. n. tajobiyapN, He placed his hands upon his knees, (K, TA,) in prayer; (TA;) or upon the ground: or he fell prostrate; or fell upon his face: (K:) or he lowered his body and his hands, and raised his buttocks: (Ham p. 801:) [or] tjbyp signifies a man's standing [with the hands upon the knees] in the manner of the raAkiE: (S, K: *) accord. to A'Obeyd, what is thus termed is of two kinds: one is the placing the hands upon the knees, while standing: the other, the prostrating oneself, or falling upon the face, lying down; which is sujuwdN: (S:) or the bending down, and placing the hands upon the knees; because it is a bringing-together of the limbs. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- jbRAhu, inf. n. as above, meaning He gave to him, is vulgar. (TA.)

4 AjbI OjbI Ojby AjbI Ajby jbI
