It is said in a trad. of Aboo-Bekr, EiXoriyna wasoqFA nahala EaAYiXapa jidaAda↓, meaning He gave to 'Áïsheh palm-trees of which the quantity of the dates cut therefrom was a hundred camel-loads; but the phrase heard from the Arabs is jaAdRa EiXoriyna: the former is like the saying hecihi AldRaraAhimu Darobu AlOamiyri; and the latter, like EiyXapN raADiyapN. (Mgh.)

jaAdRapN jAd jAdh jAdp
jaAdRapN The main part of a road; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) its middle: (Mgh, Msb, and M voce jarajap:) or its even part: or the beaten track, or part along which one walks, or travels; the conspicuous part thereof: or a main road that comprises other roads, or tracks, and upon which one must pass: (TA:) or a road, or way, absolutely; as also judRapN↓: (Zj, MF:) or a road leading to water: (AHn, TA:) it is so called because it is marked with tracks, forming lines: (T, TA:) pl. jawaAdRN, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) occurring in poetry without teshdeed, but disapproved by As. (L.) fulaAnN EalaI AljaAdRapi means (assumed tropical:) Such a one is following the right course of action or the like. (Mgh.) You say also, huwa EalaI jaAdRapi AlHaqRi (assumed tropical:) [He is on the road, or main road, of truth]: not, however, EalaI jaAdRapi AlbaATili, but ElI mazalRapi AlbaATili, and mazolaqatihi, and maholakatihi. (MF.)

OajadRu c
OajadRu [Having some part, or parts, cut, or cut off: fem. jadRaMCu]. ― -b2- [Hence,] jadRaMCu A ewe, or she-goat, or she-camel, (TA,) having her ear cut off. (K, TA.) ― -b3- A ewe, or she-goat, having her teats cut off; (Sh, TA;) as also mujadRadapN↓ [q. v.], applied to a she-camel: (As, TA:) or having her udder cut off. (Khálid, TA.) ― -b4- [And hence,] (assumed tropical:) A milch animal (TA [in the S app. restricted to a ewe]) whose milk has passed away, (ISk, S, K,) by reason of some fault, or imperfection: (ISk, S:) see also jaduwdN: or a ewe, or she-camel, or she-ass, having little milk; having a dry udder: or having dry teats, being hurt by the SiraAr [q. v.]: (L:) and OajadRu (assumed tropical:) a breast that has become dry. (AHeyth.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) A woman small in the breast: (S, K:) or having short breasts. (TA from a trad.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A desert, (falaAp, S, K,) or land, (OaroD, A,) in which is no water: (S, A, K:) a desert (mafaAzap) that is dry. (TA.) ― -b7- EaAmN OajadRu and sanapN jadRaMCu (assumed tropical:) A year of drought, and of dryness o the earth. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AlOajadRaAni: see jadiydN, in two places. ＝ -A3- OajadRu also signifies More [and most] easy to walk or ride upon, and more [and most] plain or level; applied to a road. (TA.) ＝ -A4- And More [and most] fortunate; applied to a man. (ISd, A, L.)

mujadRadapN AlOaxolaAfi c
mujadRadapN AlOaxolaAfi A she-camel having her teats cut off in consequence of injury occasioned to her by the SiraAr [q. v.]. (S.) See also OajadRu. ＝ -A2- And mujadRadN A [garment of the kind called] kisaMC having stripes of different colours. (S.)

mujidRN mjd mjdy
mujidRN: see jaAdRN. ― -b2- UinRahaA lmjdRp biAlrRajuli, a phrase mentioned by As, said of a she-camel, meaning, Verily she is quick in her pace with the man: but Az says, I know not whether he said mijadRapN↓ or mujidRapN: the former would be from jadRa; and the latter, from OajadRa. (L.)

mijadRapN mjd mjdh mjdp
mijadRapN: see what next precedes.

majoduwdN mjdwd
majoduwdN: see jadiydN, in two places; and jaAdRN. ＝ -A2- See also jadRN, in two places.

1 jaduba jdb
1. jaduba, (A, Msb, K,) aor.
jaduba
, (K,) inf. n. juduwbapN, (S, A, Msb, K,) It (a place, S, A, K, or a country, or region, Msb,) was, or became, affected with drought, barrenness, or dearth; or with drought, and dryness of the earth; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also jadiba, (A,) inf. n. jadabN; (KL;) or jadaba; (K;) and Ajdb↓; (A, K;) or jadibat, aor.
jadaba
; and Oajodabat↓; both said of the earth or land (AlOaroD): (Msb:) and Oajodabati↓ AlbilaAdu the countries, or regions, were affected with drought, and the prices became high [therein]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jadabahu, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
jadiba
(M, Msb, K) and
jaduba
, (K,) inf. n. jadobN, (Msb,) He found fault with it; dispraised it; expressed disapprobation of it. (S, M, A, Msb, K.) So in the saying (S, A) relating to 'Omar, (A, TA,) in a trad., (S,) jadaba AlsRamara baEoda AlEiXaMCi (S) or baEoda AlEatamapi (A) [He expressed disapprobation of night-discourse after nightfall, or after the first third of the night reckoned from the disappearance of the redness of the twilight].

3 jaAdabati AlUibilu AlEaAma jAdbt AlAbl AlEAm
3. jaAdabati AlUibilu AlEaAma, (ISk, S, A, TA,) inf. n. mujaAdabapN, (TA,) The camels experienced, or have experienced, drought, and barrenness, or dryness
of the earth, this year, and have become in such a state as not to eat anything but dry and black herbage, dry vumaAm [or panic grass]: (ISk, S, TA:) or have not met with, or found, anything but what was bad, by reason of drought, and barrenness, or dryness of the earth, this year. (A.)

4 Oajodaba
4: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- Oajodabati AlsRanapu The year became one of drought, barrenness, or dearth; or drought, and dryness of the earth. (A, * TA.) ― -b3- Ajdb Alqawomu The people, or company of men, experienced drought, barrenness, or death; or drought, and dryness of the earth. (S, A, Msb, K.) ― -b4- [Hence,] nazalonaA bibaniI fulaAnK faOajodabonaA (tropical:) We alighted as guests at the abode of the sons of such a one, and found not entertainment with them, though they were in the enjoyment of plenty: (A:) [or] nazalonaA fulaAnFA faOajoabonaAhu (assumed tropical:) we alighted as guests at the abode of such a one, and [found that] he did not entertain us. (TA.) [The latter, if correct, is from what next follows.] ＝ -A2- Ajdb AlOaroDa He found the land to be affected with drought, barrenness, or dearth; or with drought, and dryness of the earth. (S, A, K.)

5 maA OatajadRabu Oano OaSoHabaka c
5. maA OatajadRabu Oano OaSoHabaka (assumed tropical:) I do not deem it disagreeable, or unsuitable, to accompany thee; syn. maA Oasotawoximu. (K.)

jadobN jdb
jadobN Drought, barrenness, or dearth; contr. of xiSobN; (S;) i. q. maHolN, (A, Msb, K,) i. e. drought, or suspension of rain, and dryness of the earth; (Msb;) dryness and barrenness of the earth: (Har p. 576:) and jidabRN↓ is a name, or subst., for AljadobN, (K, TA,) meaning AlmaHolu; as in the saying of the rájiz, cited by Sb,
laqado xaXiytu Oano OaraI jidabRaA
fiI EaAminaA baEoda maA OaxoSabRaA
[Verily I feared to see drought, or barrenness, &c., in this our year, after it had been abundant in herbage]; jidabRaA being used for AljadobaA; or, accord. to one reading, it is jadobabRaA↓, with a doubled b added; the change being made for the sake of the metre. (M, TA. [Respecting OaxoSabRaA, see 4 in art. xSb.]) ― -b2- Also A place, (S, A, K,) or a country, or region, (Msb,) affected with drought, barrenness, or dearth; or with drought, and dryness of the earth; and so jadiybN↓ (S, A, Msb, K) and jaduwbN↓ and majoduwbN↓, (K,) the last derived from judiba though this verb has not been used, (TA,) and mujodibN↓, (M, A,) of which the pl. is majaAdiybu. (A.) You say also OaroDN jadobN [in which jdb is an inf. n. (though app. obsolete as such) and therefore applicable to a fem. subst.] (ISd, TA) and jadobapN (S, A, Msb, K) and jadibapN↓ (A, Msb) and jadiybN↓ (Msb) and jaduwbN↓ (Lh, M, Msb) and mujodibapN↓, of which last the pl. is majaAdiybu, (Msb,) A land affected with drought, &c.: (S, M, A, &c.:) and OaroDuwna juduwbN, (S, K,) as though to each part were applied the term jadobN [used as a subst.] from which is formed the pl. juduwbN, (TA,) and jadobN, (K,) which is here an inf. n. used as an epithet [and therefore applicable to a pl. subst.], (TA,) lands affected with drought, &c. (S, K.) And falaApN jadobaMCu↓ [fem. of Oajodabu] (M, K) A desert affected with drought, &c.; (K;) in which is neither little nor much, neither pasture nor herbage. (M, TA.) And fulaAnN jadiybu↓ AljanaAbi Such a one is environed by a tract affected with drought, &c. (S. [But this phrase is generally used tropically, as meaning (assumed tropical:) Such a one is ungenerous or illiberal or inhospitable. See art. jnb.]) And sanapN jadobapN (K in art. jrz) and EaAmN jaduwbN↓ (M, TA) [A year of drought, &c.]. See also OajaAdibu, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also i. q. EayobN [A vice, fault, defect, &c.]; (S, A, K;) a signification which may be either proper or tropical. (Er-Rághib, MF.)

OaroDN jadibapN c
OaroDN jadibapN: see jadobN.

Oaxaca fiI waAdiI jadabaAtK c
Oaxaca fiI waAdiI jadabaAtK: see jacabaAt, in art. jcb.

jidabRN jdb
jidabRN and jadobabRN: see jadobN.

jaduwbN jdwb
jaduwbN: see jadobN, in three places.

jadiybN jdyb
jadiybN: see jadobN, in three places.

jaAdibN jAdb
jaAdibN Finding fault, dispraising, expressing disapprobation: whence the saying of Dhu-rRummeh,
fayaA laka mino xadRK OasiylK w manoTiqK
raxiymK wamino xaloqK taEalRala jaAdibuho
meaning [O thou smooth and even cheek, and gentle speech, and make] whereof he who dispraises it occupies himself vainly, finding no defect in it. (S, TA.) ― -b2- It is also said [as in the K &c.] to signify Lying; and the author of the 'Eyn says that it has no verb belonging to it [in this sense]; but this is a mistranscription [for xaAdibN]: AZ says that jaAdibN, with j, has the signification here first given. (M, TA.)

junodabN jndb
junodabN and junodubN (S, K, &c.) and jinodabN, like dirohamN, (Sb, M, K,) the last of which is of weakest authority, because of a rare measure, whereof it has been said that there are only four examples: (TA:) in all of them the n is said by some to be radical; but others, with more reason, hold it to be augmentative: (MF:) Sb says that it is augmentative: (S:) A species of locust, (S, K,) well known: (K:) or the male locust: or small locust: or, accord. to Seer, i. q. SadFI [a kind of cricket], that creaks by night, and hops and flies: [but see SadFI:] or, accord. to the M, it is smaller than the SdI, and is found in the deserts: pl. janaAdibu. (TA.) SrR Aljndb [i. e. SarRa Aljunodabu The jndb creaked] is a saying of the Arabs, used as a proverb; alluding to a difficult affair by which a person is troubled in mind; originating from the fact that the jndb, when its feet are scorched by the heated ground, does not keep them steadily upon it, and a creaking sound is consequently heard, produced by its legs. (TA.) ― -b2- OumRu junodabK The sand; because the locust [or jndb] deposits its eggs therein: and the walker therein falls into evil [or encounters difficulty]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence it signifies also] Misfortune: (S, M, K:) and perfidy, or faithlessness, or treachery: (M, K:) and wrong, or injury: (S, M, K:) and evil conduct, or ill treatment. (S.) You say, waqaEa fulaAnN fiI OumRi junodabK Such a one fell into misfortune: or into perfidy. (TA.) And waqaEuwA fiI OumRi junodabK They suffered wrong, or injury. (AZ, S, K.) And waqaEa Alqawomu junodabK The people, or company of men, committed wrong, or injury, and slew him who was not a slayer: (TA:) [as though they came with violence upon sand in which eggs of the jndb were deposited, and so destroyed the eggs, which had occasioned them no harm.] And rakiba OumRa junodabK He committed wrong, or injury. (TA.)

Oajodabu c
[Oajodabu i. q. jadobN as syn. with jadiybN: fem. jadoyaMCu. Hence,] falaApN jadoyaMCu: see jadobN. ― -b2- [Hence also,] sanapN jadobaMCu A year of much snow. (L in art. Xhb.) ― -b3- Oajodabu is [also] said in the M to be [used as] a subst. applied to what is termed mujodib [i. e. as syn. with the latter word used as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant; app. meaning A place, or the like, affected with drought, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b4- [Also, as a comparative and superlative epithet, meaning More, and most, affected with drought, &c.; contr. of OaxoSabu.]

OajaAdibu c
OajaAdibu, in a trad., where it is said, wakaAnato fiyhi OajaAdibu Oamosakati AlmaMCi, (K, * TA,) or wkAnt fiyhaA, (TA,) [And there were in it AjAdb that retained the water], is said to be pl. of OajodubN, which is pl. of jadobN↓, (K, TA,) like as OakaAlibu is pl. of OakolubN, which is pl. of kalobN; (TA;) and signifies hard parts of the ground, that retain water, and do not imbibe it quickly; or, as some say, land having no plants or herbage, from jadobN↓ meaning “ drought ” &c.: the word is thus written in the two Saheehs, of El-Bukháree and Muslim: (IAth, TA:) but some say that it is an anomalous pl. of jadobN, like as maHaAsinu is of HusonN: and there are other readings; namely, OajaAcibu and OaHaAdibu and OaHaAzibu and OajaAridu, pl. of Oajoradu, and UixaAcaAtN, pl. of UixaAcapN. (MF, TA.)

mujodibN mjdb
mujodibN, and its fem., with p: see jadobN.

mijodaAbN mjdAb
mijodaAbN Land scarely ever, or never, abundant in herbage, or in the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life; scarcely ever, or never, fruitful, or plentiful. (K.)

majoduwbN mjdwb
majoduwbN: see jadobN.

8 Ajtdv Ajtdv
8. Ajtdv He made, or prepared, a jadav, i. e., a grave, or sepulchre; or did so for himself. (S, K, TA.)

jadavN jdv
jadavN A grave; a sepulchre; pl. OajodaAvN (S, Msb, K) and OajoduvN; (S, K;) of which latter, J cites an ex., but in this instance it is the proper name of a place. (TA.) It is of the dial. of Tihámeh: the people of Nejd say jadafN: (Msb:) or [as some say] the f in the latter is a substitute for the v in the former; for AjdAv is used as a
pl. by common consent, and AjdAf is not used: (TA:) but Suh affirms, in the R, that the latter pl. is used by Ru-beh. (TA in art. jdf.)

1 jadaHa jdH
1. jadaHa, aor.
jadaHa
, inf. n. jadoHN, He mixed anything. (L.) jadaHa AlsRawiyqu, (S, A, Mgh, L, K,) wanaHowahu, aor. and inf. n. as above; and jdRHhu↓, inf. n. tajodiyHN; (L;) and AjtdHhu↓, (S, L, K,) and AjdHhu↓; (K;) He stirred about the swyq [or meal made of parched barley or wheat], and the like, with water, [or milk, (see what follows,) or clarified butter, or fat of a sheep's tail, &c., (see latRa,)] until the whole became of a uniform consistence: (L:) or he stirred it about with a mijodaH: (A, L:) or he stirred about the swyq in milk, and the like, with a mjdH, until it became mixed: (Lth, TA:) or he beat and mixed the swyq with a mjdH: (Mgh:) i. q. latRahu: (S, K:) and jdRHhu↓, inf. n. tajodiyHN, he mixed it; in the K, laTaxahu; but the right reading is xalaTahu, as in the L and other lexicons: (TA:) and AjtdHhu↓ he drank it (Xrbh [but this is perhaps a mistranscription for Darabahu he beat it]) with the mjdH. (L, TA.)

2 jadRaHa
2: see 1, in two places.

4 OajodaHa
4: see 1. ― -b2- AHdH AlUibila He branded the camels on their thighs with the mark called mijodaH. (K.)

8 UijotadaHa
8: see 1, in two places.

AlmujodaHu AlmjdH
AlmujodaHu: see the next paragraph.

mijodaHN mjdH
mijodaHN The instrument with which sawiyq is stirred about with water &c.; (S, A, K, &c.;) which is a piece of wood the end whereof has several sides; (S, L;) or a piece of wood at the head of which are two cross pieces of wood; (A, Mgh, L;) and sometimes having three prongs: (IAth, TA:) pl. majaAdiHu. (L.) ― -b2- It is sometimes used tropically, as relating to evil, or mischief. (L.) [Thus it means (tropical:) A stirrer-up of evil or mischief; or a thing that stirs up, or whereby one stirs up, evil or mischief.] ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Any one of the majaAdiyHu AlsRamaMCi [or stirrers-up of the sky, or of rain]; (L;) these being the OanowaMCN [or stars, or asterisms, which, by their auroral settings or risings, were believed by the Pagan Arabs to bring rain &c.]; (S, L, K;) of those AnwAC that seldom or never failed [to bring rain], accord. to the Arabs: (Mgh:) the I in the pl. is added to give fulness to the sound of the kesreh; for the regular pl. is majaAdiHu, and the sing. of mjAdyH should by rule be mijodaAHN. (A, IAth, Mgh.) One says, Arosalati AlsRamaMCa majaAdiyHuhaA (L) or majaAdiyHu Algayovi (A) (assumed tropical:) [Its stirrers-up, or the stirrers-up of rain, or the stars or asterisms which were the bringers of it, sent forth rain]. It is related of 'Omar, that he ascended the pulpit to pray for rain, and, having only offered a prayer for forgiveness, descended; whereupon it was said to him, “ Thou hast not prayed for rain; ” and he replied, laqadi Qsotasoqayotu bimajaAdiyHi AlsRamaMCi (assumed tropical:) [I have indeed prayed for rain by words which are the stirrers-up of rain]; making the prayer for forgiveness to be a prayer for rain, in allusion to a passage in the Kur, lxxi. 9 and 10; and meaning thereby to deny the efficacy of the AnwAC. (A, * Mgh, * L.) AlmijodaHu, also pronounced AlmujodaHu↓, (S, K,) thus pronounced by El-Umawee, (S,) is moreover the name of (assumed tropical:) A particular star or asterism, one of those which the Pagan Arabs asserted to be bringers of rain: (L:) said to be AldRabaraAnu [the Hyades; or the five chief stars thereof; or the brightest star thereof, a of Taurus]; (S, A, L, K;) [which is called by this name of AldbrAn] because it rises latterly [with respect to the Pleiades], (S,) or because it follows (yadoburu, i. e. yatobaEu,) the Pleiades: (T in art. dbr:) [whence] it is also called HaAdiI AlnRujuwmi [“ the urger of the stars, ” properly, “ with singing ”], (S,) or HaAdiI AlnRajomi [“ the urger of the asterism, ” meaning, “ of the Pleiades ”], and taAliI AlnRajomi [“ the follower of the asterism, ” or, “ of the Pleiades ”], (Kzw,) and AltRaAliI and AltRaAbiEu [“ the follower ”]: (Sh:) or it is a small star or asterism, between AldbrAn and AlvRurayRaA [or the Pleiades]: (IAar, K:) [perhaps meaning the four stars that are the chief stars of the Hyades exclusively of a Tauri:] or three stars, (Mgh, TA,) like the three stones upon which a cooking-pot rests, (TA,) likened to a three-pronged mijodaH; (Mgh, TA;) on the [auroral] rising of which, heat is expected: (TA:) the Arabs regarded it as one of the AnwAC which [by their auroral setting] foretokened rain. (IAth.) AlmijodaHaAni is a name by which some of the Arabs called (assumed tropical:) The two wings of AljawozaMC [or Orion]. (Sh, TA.) ― -b4- mijodaHN also signifies (assumed tropical:) A certain mark made with a hot iron upon the thighs of camels. (K.)

mujadRaHN mjdH
mujadRaHN Beverage, or wine, (XaraAb,) stirred about: (S, K:) and in like manner, blood, when it is stirred about in the body of a gored animal by the goring horn. (L.)

majoduwHN mjdwH
majoduwHN Blood drawn from a vein, used in times of dearth, or drought, (S, K,) in the Time of Ignorance: (S:) or blood which was mixed with something else, and eaten in times of dearth: (TA:) or a kind of food of the Pagan Arabs, being blood obtained by opening a vein of a she-camel, which blood was received in a vessel, and drunk. (T, TA.)

1 jadara jdr
1. jadara, (K,) aor.
jadura
, (TA,) He made a jidaAr [app. here meaning a wall of enclosure]; syn. HawRaTa: (K:) or he built a jdAr: and he founded it. (Ham p. 818.) ＝ -A2- He concealed himself by means of a jidAr [or wall]. (Th, K.) ＝ -A3- judira, (A, K,) inf. n. jadorN; (TA;) and jadara, (Lh, K,) aor.
jadura
, inf. n. jadorN; (Lh, TA;) and judRira↓, (S, (A, K,) which last some disallow, because this form denotes repetition, and the verb signifies the having a disease that befalls but once in a man's life; (MF;) He (a man, S, or a child, A) had, or became attacked by, judariIR [or small-pox]. (S, A, K.) [And jadara AljudariIRu The small-pox came forth, or broke out; as in the TK: for its inf. n.] jadorN signifies the coming forth, or breaking out, of the judariIR. (K.) ＝ -A4- jadura, aor.
jadura
, inf. n. jadaArapN, He, or it, was, or became, adapted, disposed, apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, competent, proper, or worthy. (K.) You say, jadura bihi [and lahu ] He was, or became, adapted, disposed, apt, &c., for it. (A.) [And jadura Oano yafoEala kacaA He was, or became, adapted, disposed, apt, &c., for doing such a thing. See jadiyrN .] ＝ -A5- jadarahu He made, or called, (jaEala,) him, or it, adapted, disposed, apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, competent, proper, or worthy. (K.)

2 jadRara binaMCahu jdr bnMCh jdr bnMCp
2. jadRara binaMCahu: see 8. ＝ -A2- judRira: see 1.

4 maA Oajodarahu biAlxayori c
4. maA Oajodarahu biAlxayori [and liloxayori] How well adapted or disposed, or how apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, competent, or proper, is he for what is good! or how worthy is he of what is good! (A.) And maA Oajodarahu Oano yafoEala celika, and Oajodiro bihi, How well adapted or disposed, or how apt, meet, &c., is he for doing that! or how worthy is he to do that! (TA.) The usage of jadura, signifying “ he was, or became, adapted, &c., ” refutes the assertion of certain grammarians that these two forms of the verb deviate from general rule. (MF.)

8 Ajtdr binaMCahu Ajtdr bnMCh Ajtdr bnMCp
8. Ajtdr binaMCahu; and jdRrhu↓, inf. n. tajodiyrN (K) and mujadRarN; (TA;) He raised his building high; or constructed it firmly and strongly, and raised it high; syn. XayRadahu. (K, TA.) [In the CK, we read Aijtadara binaAhu, as though the pronoun h referred to the word jidaAr, which precedes; and thus the verb signified “ he built a wall; ” but it is shown in the TA that the right reading is that given above.]

Q. Q. 1 janodara AlkitaAba jndr AlktAb
Q. Q. 1. janodara AlkitaAba He passed the pen over what had become obliterated, of the writing, (S, K,) in order that it might become distinct. (S.) And jndr AlvRawoba He renewed the variegated, or figured, work of the garment, or piece of cloth, after it had gone. (S, K.) [J says,] I think it to be an arabicized word. (S)

jadorN jdr
jadorN A wall; or a wall of enclosure; syn. HaAYiTN; as also jidaArN↓, [which is the more common]: (S, A, Msb, K:) pl. of the former, judurN, (S, Msb, K,) sometimes used as a pl. of pauc., (Sb, TA,) and judorN; (K;) and of the latter, judoraAnN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- The basis, or foundation, of a wall: (K:) and the side of a wall: (Lh, K:) pl., in both these senses, juduwrN. (TA.) Aljadoru is applied to The [wall called the] HaTiym (A, K) of the Kaabeh; (K;) because in it is a part of the [original] foundations of the house: (TA:) and it is also called AlHijoru. (A.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A fence, or dam, raised of branches, to retain water; likened to a wall: (Az, Msb:) or
a fence, or dam, to confine water: pl. juduwrN: (Suh, Msb:) and judurN, [which is also a pl.,] signifies fences, or dams, between houses, which retain water. (TA.) ― -b4- [The pl.] juduwrN also signifies Gardens, or walled gardens, (HawaAYiT,) of grapes. (TA.)

jadarapN jdr jdrh jdrp
jadarapN: see jadiyrapN

judariIRN jdrI jdry
judariIRN and jadariIRN (S, Msb, K) [Small-pox;] certain pustules (Msb, K) in the body, (K,) which break forth (Msb, K) from the skin, full of water, and afterwards opening, (Msb,) and generating thick purulent matter; (K;) a well-known disease, that attacks people once during life. (TA.) ― -b2- judariIRu AlOaroDi (tropical:) an appellation applied to Truffles (kamoOap), denoting disapprobation. (TA from a trad.)

jidaArN jdAr
jidaArN: see jadorN: and see also jadiyrapN.

jadiyrN jdyr
jadiyrN A place having a wall built around it; a walled place. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also mujadRarN. ＝ -A3- Also Adapted, disposed, apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, proper, competent, or worthy; syn. xaliyqN (S, A, Msb, K) and HaqiyqN: (Msb:) fem. with p: (TA:) pl. mase. jadiyruwna and judaraMCu: (S, K:) pl. fem. jadiyraAtN and jadaAYiru. (TA.) You say, huwa jadiyrN bikacaA (S, A, Msb) and likacaA (TA) He is adapted, disposed, apt, meet, &c., for such a thing; (S, A, Msb;) and [naturally] drawn to it. (Ham p. 707.) And Oanota jadiyrN Oano tafoEala kacaA Thou art adapted, disposed, apt, meet, &c., for doing such a thing; or worthy to do it. (S.) And Oano yafoEala UinRahu lamajodarapN↓, (K,) and in like manner you say of two persons, and of more, (TA,) and majoduwrN↓, (K.) Verily he is one who is adapted, disposed, apt, meet, &c., for doing [such a thing]; or worthy to do [it]; syn. maxolaqapN. (K.) [majodarapN↓ properly signifies A place, and hence a thing, an affair, and a person, adapted, disposed, apt, meet, &c.; like maxolaqapN and maHoraApN: and majoduwrN↓, Made, or called, adapted or disposed &c., though said by Aboo-Jaafar Er-Ru- ásee to be a pass. part. n. having no verb.] Also bicelika UinRahaA lamajodarapN↓ Verily she is one who is adapted, disposed, apt, &c., for that: and biOano tafoEala celika for doing that: and in like manner you say of two persons, and of more. (TA.) And licaAka hecaA AlOamoru majodarapN↓ This affair, or thing, is one that is adapted, apt, meet, &c., for that; syn. maHoraApN. (S.) And hecaA AlOamoru majodarapN↓ minohu This affair, or thing, is one that is adapted, apt, meet, &c., for him to do; i. e. he is adapted, apt, meet, &c., for doing it. (TA.)

jadiyrapN jdyr jdyrh jdyrp
jadiyrapN An enclosure for camels, (AZ, S, K,) and for lambs and kids and calves &c., (TA,) made of masses of stone; (AZ, S;) as also jadarapN↓: (TA:) if of mud, or clay, it is called jidaArN↓: (AZ, TA:) or an enclosure (zarob ) for sheep or goats. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Nature; or natural, or native, disposition, temper, or other property. (K)

huwa Oajodaru bihi c
huwa Oajodaru bihi He, or it, is more, or most, adapted, disposed, apt, meet, suited, suitable, fitted, fit, competent, or proper, for it, or him; or he is more, or most, worthy of it. (A.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce xuTRapN.]

OaroDN majodarapN c
OaroDN majodarapN A land in which is HudariIR [or small-pox]: (Lh, S:) or a land in which is much thereof. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also jadiyrN, in five places.

mujadRarN mjdr
mujadRarN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and majoduwrN↓ (Mgh, K) and jadiyrN↓ (Msb, TA) Having the judariIR [or small-pox]. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) And majoduwrN↓ Alwajohi [Having the face marked with the smallpox]. (A.)

majoduwrN mjdwr
majoduwrN: see mujadRarN: ＝ -A2- and see also jadiyrN, in two places.

1 jadaEa AlOanofa c
1. jadaEa AlOanofa, (S, * Msb, K, *) aor.
jadaEa
, (Msb,) inf. n. jadoEN, (S, Msb, K,) He cut off the nose; and in like manner, the ear; and the hand, or arm; and the lip; (S, Msb, K;) and a similar part: (TA:) and Oanofahu OajodaEotu↓ signifies the same as jadaEotu [I cut off his nose]: or jadoEN signifies [absolutely] the cutting off; or cutting so as to separate. (TA.) In the following saying of a poet, the verb is used metaphorically,
waOaSobaHa AldRahoru cuw AlEironiyni qado judiEaA
[lit. And nosed fortune became mutilated in the nose; meaning, (assumed tropical:) became marred]. (TA.) And in the following phrase, occurring in a verse, kaOanRa QllReha yajodaEu Oanofahu waEayonayohi, the poet means, [As though God cut off his nose] and put out his eyes: see a similar saying in art. qld, voce taqalRada. (TA.) ― -b2- jadaEahu, (S, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He mutilated him, or maimed him, by cutting off his nose, or his ear, or his hand or arm, or his lip, (S, K, TA,) or the like; (TA;) as also jdREhu↓ (S, TA.) [Hence the phrase,] lahu jadoEFA↓ (S, K) [(May God decree) to him mutilation, or maining, by the cutting off of his nose, or the like; or cause it to befall him: or] meaning Oalozamahu QllRehu AljadoEa [(assumed tropical:) may God make injury, or diminution of what is good, to cleave to him]: (K:) said in imprecating a curse upon a man: similar to EaqorFA lahu, q. v.: the first word being governed in the accus. case by a verb understood. (TA.) One says also, AijodaEohumo biAlOamori HatRaI yacilRuwA, a phrase mentioned by IAar, but not explained by him; thought by ISd to mean, (tropical:) Act thou, in commanding, as though thou mutilatedst them by cutting off their noses [until they become submissive]. (TA.) In the phrase Sawotu AlHimaAri AlyujadRaEu↓ [The voice of the ass that has his ear, or ears, cut off, (see mujadRaEN, below,)], occurring in a verse of Dhu-l-Khirak Et-Tuhawee, (S,) accord. to J, but not found by Sgh in the verses of that poet, and said to be in the Book [of Sb], though IB denies this, asserting it to be in the Nawádir of AZ, (TA,) Akh says, the poet means AlRaciI yujadRaEu, like as you say, huwaQloyaDoribuka, meaning AlRaciI yaDoribuka: Aboo-Bekr Ibn-es-Sarráj says, the poet, requiring refa for the rhyme, has changed the noun into a verb; and this is one of the worst of poetic licences. (S.) ― -b3- [Hence,] AlsRanapu tajodaEu AlnRabaAta (tropical:) [The year of drought cuts off, or destroys, the herbage]: (A, TA:) and tajodaEu biAlmaAli destroys the camels or the like. (S, O, K.) And AlqaHoTu AlnabRaAti jadRaEa↓ (tropical:) The drought prevented the growth, or increase, of the herbage. (K, TA.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] jadaEa EiyaAlahu, inf. n. jadRaEN, (assumed tropical:) He withheld good things from his family, or household. (TA.) And jadaEatohu OumRuhu, aor.
jadaEa
, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) His mother fed him with bad food; (Zj, K;) as also OajodaEatohu↓, (S, K,) inf. n. UijodaAEN; (TA;) and jadRaEatohu↓, (K,) inf. n. tajodiyEN: (TA:) and jdREhu↓ and AjdEhu↓ (tropical:) He (a pastor) confined him [a beast] to bad pasture. (TA.) jadaEotuhu, (S,) inf. n. as above, (K,) also signifies (assumed tropical:) I confined him, restricted him, or the like; syn. Habasotuhu: and (assumed tropical:) I imprisoned him: (S, K: *) and so with c: (S:) or jadoEN and jacoEN both signify (assumed tropical:) the confining, or restricting, a person with evil management, and with contemptuous treatment, and want of good care. (A Heyth.) ＝ -A2- jadiEa, aor.
jadaEa
, (Msb,) inf. n. jadaEN, (S, Msb, K,) He (a man) was, or became, mutilated, or maimed, by the cutting off of his nose, or his ear, (S, * Msb, K, *) or his hand or arm, or his lip, (S, K,) or the like: (TA:) or, accord. to some, you do not say jadiEa, but judiEa: (TA:) and jadiEati AlXRaApu The sheep, or goat, was, or became, mutilated by having its ears entirely cut off. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] also, (S, K,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (S,) [as though meaning (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, injured;] (tropical:) he (a child) had bad food: (S, K, TA:) and he (a young weaned camel) had bad food: or was ridden while [too] young, and in consequence became weak. (TA.)

2 jdREhu jdE jdEh jdEp
2. jdREhu, inf. n. tajodiyEN: see 1, in five places. ― -b2- jadRaEahu waXarRaAhu (tropical:) He made him to experience evil treatment, and derided him; as when one cuts off the ear of his slave, and sells him. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also He said to him jadoEFA laka [explained above; see 1]. (S, K. *) [See also EaqRarahu.]

3 jAdE jAdE
3. jAdE, inf. n. mujaAdaEapN (S, K) and jidaAEN (K,) (tropical:) He reviled, being reviled by another, (K, * TA,) saying jadoEFA laka; as though each of them cut off the nose of the other: (TA:) and, (K,) or accord. to some, (TA,) (tropical:) he contended in an altercation; as also tjAdE↓; (S, K, TA;) [but the latter is said of a number of persons &c.] You say, OafaAEiyhaA tarakotu AlbilaAda tajaAdaEu↓, (Th, S,) and tajadRaEu↓ also, (Th,) (tropical:) I left the countries with their vipers eating one another; (Th, S;) not meaning eating in reality, but rending in pieces, or mangling, one another: (Th:) and OafaAEiyhaA EaAmN tajadRaEu↓, and tajaAdaEu↓, (tropical:) A year in which the vipers eat one another, by reason of its severity. (Th.)

4 OajodaEa
4: see 1, in three places.

5 tajadRaEa
5: see 3, in two places.

6 tajaAodaEa
6: see 3, in three places.

jadoEN jdE
jadoEN What is cut off of the anterior parts of the nose, to its furthest, or uttermost, part: (As,
TA:) an inf. n. used as a [proper] subst. (TA.) ― -b2- jadoEFA lahu : see 1. ＝ -A2- (tropical:) Unwholesomeness in herbage. (K.)

jadiEN c
jadiEN (tropical:) A child having bad food; or fed on bad food: (S, K, TA:) pronounced by El-Mufaddal with c; but As repudiated to him this pronunciation; (S, TA:) and his objection was confirmed by a young man of the Benoo-Asad called in as an umpire. (TA.)

jadaEapN jdE jdEh jdEp
jadaEapN What remains, of the nose, ear, hand or arm, or lip, after the cutting off [of the rest]: (S, K:) the place of the cutting off thereof; like EarajapN from AlOaEoraju, and qaTaEapN from AlOaqoTaEu. (TA.)

jadaAEi jdAE
jadaAEi (S, A, K, &c.) and jadaAEN (K, TA) (tropical:) A year of drought; because it cuts off, or destroys, (tajodaEu,) the herbage, and abases men: (A, TA:) or a severe, or calamitous, year, that destroys the camels or the like; (S, O, K;) or that destroys everything; as though it cut off its nose or the like. (L.) ― -b2- See also judaAEN.

judaAEN jdAE
judaAEN (tropical:) Withered herbage: (S:) or herbage that is unwholesome to the feeder upon it: (K:) or tall, unwholesome, and withered. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, AljudaAEu signifies (tropical:) Death: (K, TA:) written by some AljadaAEu↓. (TA.)

OajodaEu c
OajodaEu Mutilated, or maimed, by having his nose cut off, or his ear, (S, Msb, K,) or his hand or arm, or his lip, (S, K,) or the like: (TA:) fem. jadoEaMCu: (S, Msb:) and the latter, applied to a she-camel, having the sixth part of her ear, or the fourth part of it, or more than that, to the half, cut off; and to a she-goat, having a third part, or more, of her ear cut off; or, accord. to IAmb, any ewe or she-goat having the ear lopped; (TA;) or a ewe or she-goat having her ear entirely cut off: (Mgh, Msb:) and mujadRaEN↓ an ass having the ear cut off, (S,) or having the ears cut off. (K.) It is said in a prov., Oanofuka minoka wa Uino kaAna OajodaEa [Thy nose is a part of thee though it be cut off]: applied with reference to him whose good and evil attaches to thee though he be not firmly connected with thee by relationship. (TA.) ― -b2- AlOajodaEu one of the appellations applied to The devil. (Fr, K. *)

mujadRaEN mjdE
mujadRaEN: see OajodaEN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A plant, or herbage, of which the upper part has been eaten: (S:) or of which the upper part and the sides have been partly cut off or eaten. (AHn.)

1 jadafahu jdf jdfh jdfp
1. jadafahu, aor.
jadifa
, (IDrd, K,) inf. n. jadofN, (TA,) He cut it; or cut it off: (IDrd, K:) and so jacafahu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jadafa, (Ks, S, K,) aor.
jadifa
, (Ks, IDrd, S,) inf. n. juduwfN, (Ks, S, K,) or jadofN, (L as on the authority of Ks,) He (a bird) flew [with his wings] clipped, appearing as though he turned his wings backward: (Ks, S, K:) or contracted his wing somewhat, in order to descend in his flight, and then inclined, or declined, in fear of the hawk: (TA:) and he (a bird) went quickly, (K in art. jcf,) with his wings; generally when one of the wings had been shortened; (TA;) as also Ajdf↓ and Anjdf↓: and so, all, with c. (K ib.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jadafa AlmalRaAHu biAlmijodaAfi [The sailor rowed, or paddled, with the oar, or paddle]. (AA, TA.) And jadafa biAlsRafiynapi, (TA,) or jadafa AlsRafiynapa, aor.
jadifa
, inf. n. jadofN, (Mgh,) [He rowed, or paddled, the ship, or boat;] he put the ship, or boat, in motion with the mijodaf [or mijodaAf]. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Also jadafa He (a man) swung the arms; (K, expl. by Daraba biAlyadayoni; in the O, biAlyadi, as is said in the TA;) as a man does in walking, moving them about: and the meaning seems to be, he walked quickly: (TA:) you say, jadafa fiI miXoyatihi he (a man) was quick in his manner of walking; (AAF, TA;) and so with c: (S in art. jcf:) or jadofN signifies a repeated interrupting of the voice (taqoTiyEu AlSRawoti) in singing to camels to urge or excite them. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- Also, (K,) inf. n. jadofN, (TA,) He (a gazelle) went, or walked, with short steps. (K, * TA.) And jadafato She (a woman) walked like those that are short: and she (a gazelle, and a woman, TA) went with short steps; as also Ajdft↓: and so, both, with c. (K in art. jcf.) ― -b5- jadafati AlsRamaMCu biAlvRaloji The sky cast down snow: (K:) and so with c. (TA.)

2 jdRf jdf
2. jdRf, (S,) inf. n. tajodiyfN, (S, K,) He denied, or disacknowledged, favours, or benefits; or was ungrateful, or unthankful, for them: (As, S, K:) or he deemed the gifts of God small: (ElUmawee, S, K:) or he said that he was in an evil state when he was in a good state: (TA:) or he said, layosa liI walayosa EinodiI [app. meaning There is nothing due to me nor by me]; (K;) thus explained by Mohammad on his saying that the worst of deeds is AltRajodiyf: (TA:) [accord. to Golius, he blasphemed; and identified by him, in this sense, with the Hebr. ???.] It is said in a trad., laA tujadRifuwA biniEomapi QllRehi (S, TA) Deny not ye, or disacknowledge not, or be not ungrateful or unthankful for, the bounty of God, and deem it not small. (TA.)

4 Oajodafa
4: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- AjdfwA They raised cries, shouts, noises, a clamour, or confused cries or shouts or noises. (K, TA.)

7 Uinojadafa
7: see 1.

jadafN jdf
jadafN A grave; a sepulchre; (S, Msb, K;) like jadavN; for the Arabs made f and v interchangeable: (Fr, S:) the former is of the dial. of Nejd; and the latter, of the dial. of Tihámeh: (Msb in art. jdv:) [accord. to some,] the former is formed from the latter by substitution [of f for v]: (S:) IJ argues that this is the case because the former has not OajodaAfN for pl.: (TA:) but it has this pl., (Fr, S, R, TA,) used by Ru-beh. (R, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, said in a trad. to be the beverage of the jinn, or genii, (S, TA,) Beverage that has not been covered [at night according to a precept of the Prophet]: (Katádeh, S, K:) or of which the mouth of the skin containing it has not been tied [at night]: (K:) or a certain plant of El-Yemen, the eater of which needs not to drink after it: (S, K:) or a certain plant of El-Yemen, eaten by camels, which thereby become in no need of water: (M, TA:) or the froth, or floating particles, cast up by beverage; (El-'Otbee, Hr, K;) as though it were cut off from the beverage. (El-'Otbee, Hr, TA.)

jadafapN jdf jdfh jdfp
jadafapN Cries, shouts, noises, clamour, or a confusion of cries or shouts or noises: and the sound made in running. (Sgh, K.)

jawaAdifu jwAdf
jawaAdifu [pl. of jaAdifapN,] Gazelles going with short steps. (Sgh, K.)

Oajodafu c
Oajodafu Short: (Lth, K:) applied to a man. (TA.) ― -b2- And [the fem.] jadofaMCu A ewe, or she-goat, having somewhat cut off from her ear. (K.)

mijodafN mjdf
mijodafN: see mijodaAfN.

mujadRafN mjdf
mujadRafN Straitened: so in the saying, UinRahu lamujadRafN Ealayohi AlEayoXu [Verily the means of living are rendered strait to him]: (K:) but in the L, lamajoduwfN↓. (TA.)

mijodaAfN mjdAf
mijodaAfN The wing of a bird: (S, Msb, K:) sometimes with c. (Msb.) ― -b2- And hence, (K,) [An oar; a paddle;] a certain appertenance of a ship or boat; (As, S, Msb, K;) a piece of wood at the head of which is a broad board, with which one propels a ship or boat; (M, TA;) and mijodafN↓ [signifies the same;] a certain thing with which a ship, or boat, is put in motion: (Mgh:) pl. majaAdiyfu: (Msb:) from jadafa said of a bird: (As, S, M:) also called mijocaAfN (IDrd, S, Msb) and miqocafN and miqocaAfN. (TA.) ― -b3- And hence, as being likened thereto, (tropical:) A whip: and so with c. (TA in this art, and in art. jcf.) ― -b4- And for a similar reason, (tropical:) The neck. (TA.)

majoduwfN mjdwf
majoduwfN A [skin of the kind called] ziqR having the legs cut off: and so with c. (K, * TA.) And majoduwfu Alyadayoni A man having the arms, or hands, cut off. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence,] the latter, (assumed tropical:) A niggardly man. (TA.) ― -b3- And majoduwfu AlkumRayoni, (K, TA,) and Alyadi, and AlqamiySi, and AlUizaAri, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) Short in respect of the sleeves, (K, TA,) and of the arm, and of the shirt, and of the waistwrapper. (TA.) ― -b4- See also mujadRafN.

1 jadalahu jdl jdlh jdlp
1. jadalahu, aor.
jadula
(S, K) and
jadila
, (K,) inf. n. jadolN, (S,) He twisted it firmly; (S, K;) namely, a rope. (S.) ― -b2- He made it firm, strong, or compact. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] jaAriyapN HasanapN Aljadoli (assumed tropical:) [A girl of beautiful compacture; of beautiful, compact make]. (S.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] Eamila EalaI XaAkilatihi AlRatiI judila EalayohaA (assumed tropical:) [He did according to his own particular way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, to which he was strongly disposed by nature]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 2. ＝ -A3- jadala, inf. n. juduwlN, It (a thing) was, or became, hard, and strong. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- jadala AlHabRu fiI AlsRunobuli The grain became strong in the ears: (S. O, TA:) or accord. to the K, it means waqaEa [i. e., came into the ears]. (TA.) ― -b3- jadala said of a
young gazelle, &c., He became strong, and followed his mother. (K.) [See also jaAdilN.] ＝ -A4- jadila, aor.
jadala
, inf. n. jadalN, [said in the S to be a subst. from 3, q. v.,] He contended in an altercation, disputed, or litigated, vehemently, or violently. (Msb.)

2 jdRlhu jdl jdlh jdlp
2. jdRlhu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. tajodiylN, (Msb,) He threw him down (S, Msb, K) upon the jadaAlap, (Msb, K,) i. e., (TA,) upon the ground; (S, TA;) as also jadalahu↓, (K,) inf. n. jadolN: (TA:) or the former signifies he did so much, or often. (TA.) You say, TaEanahu fajadRalahu [He thrust him, or pierced him, with a spear or the like, and threw him down &c.]. (S, Msb.) [See also 3.]

3 jAdlhu jAdl jAdlh jAdlp
3. jAdlhu, inf. n. mujaAdalapN and jidaAlN, (S, Mgh, K,) He contended in an altercation, or disputed, or litigated, with him: (S, TA:) or did so vehemently, or violently, (Mgh, K,) and ably, or powerfully: (K:) [or he did so obstinately, or merely for the purpose of convincing him; for] mjAdlp signifies the disputing respecting a question of science for the purpose of convincing the opponent, whether what he says be wrong in itself or not: (Kull p. 342:) [he wrangled with him:] or jAdl, inf. n. mjAdlp and jdAl, as above, signifies originally he contended in an altercation, or disputed, or litigated, by advancing what might divert the mind from the appearance of the truth and of what was right: and accord. to a later usage, of the lawyers, he compared evidences [in a discussion with another person, or other persons,] in order that it might appear which of those evidences was preponderant: and the doing this is commendable if for the purpose of ascertaining the truth; but otherwise it is blameable: (Msb:) accord. to Er-Rághib, jdAl signifies the competing in disputation or contention, and in striving to overcome [thereby]; from jadalotu AlHabola, meaning, “ I twisted the rope firmly; ” as though each of the two parties twisted the other from his opinion: or, as some say, it originally means the act of wrestling, and throwing down another upon the jadaAlap [or ground]: accord. to Ibn-El-Kemál, a disputing that has for its object the manifesting and establishing of tenets or opinions. (TA.) [See also jadila.]

4 Ajdlt Ajdlt
4. Ajdlt She (a gazelle) had her young one [sufficiently grown to be] walking with her. (Zj, K.)

5 tajadRala
5: see 7.

6 tjAdlwA jAdl tjAdl tjAdlwA
6. tjAdlwA The contended in an altercation, disputed, or litigated, [or did so vehemently, or violently, &c., (see 3,)] one with another. (KL, MA, &c.,)

7 Anjdl Anjdl
7. Anjdl He fell down upon the ground: (S:) he became thrown down upon the jadaAlap, i. e., the ground; and in like manner tjdRl↓, he became thrown down, &c., much, or often. (TA.)

8 AijotidaAlN AjtdAl
8. AijotidaAlN The act of building, or constructing. (TA.) El-Kumeyt says,
majaAdila XadRa AlrRaASifuwna QjotidaAlahaA
(S, TA) i. e. [Pavilions of which the masons have made strong] the building, or construction. (TA.)

[ Q. Q. 1 jadowala jdwl
Q. Q. 1. jadowala He ruled a book with lines; such as are ruled round a page, &c. See jadowalN.]

jadolN jdl
jadolN Hard, and strong; as also jadilN↓. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- Also, and jidolN↓, A strong, firm, or compact, penis. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) or the former, (S, TA,) Any member, or limb: (S, K:) pl. juduwlN. (S, TA.) ― -b4- Also, (K,) or the former, (TA,) Any complete bone, [app. with its flesh,] not broken, nor mixed with aught beside: pl. [of pauc.] OajodaAlN and [of mult.] juduwlN. (K, TA.) ― -b5- Also, (K,) or [the pl.] juduwlN , (Lth, TA,) The bones of the arms and legs (Lth, K, TA) of a man: (Lth, TA:) and of the fore and hind legs of the victim termed Eaqiyqap. (TA from a trad.)

jidolN jdl
jidolN: see jadolN.

jadalN jdl
jadalN Vehemence, or violence, in altercation or disputation or litigation; (S, K;) and ability, or power, to practise it: (K:) [or simply contention in an altercation; disputation; or litigation:] a subst. from jaAdalahu: (S:) or inf. n. of jadila [q. v.]. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, as a term of logic, A syllogism composed of things well known, or conceded; the object of which is to convince the opponent, and to make him to understand who fails to apprehend the premises of the demonstration. (TA.)

jadilN jdl
jadilN: see jadolN. ＝ -A2- Also One who contends in an altercation, disputes, or litigates, vehemently, or violently, (Msb, K,) and ably, or powerfully; and so mijodalN↓ and mijodaAlN↓. (K.)

jadolaMCu jdlMC
jadolaMCu fem. of Oajodalu. ＝ -A2- Also syn., in two senses, with jadiylapN, which see, in two places.

jadowalN jdwl
jadowalN A rivulet; a streamlet; (S, Msb, K;) [whether natural, or formed artificially for irrigation; being often applied to a streamlet for irrigation, in the form of a trench, or gutter;] it is less than a saAqiyap; and this is less than a nahor: (Mgh in art. saqI:) as also jidowalN: (K:) pl. jadaAwilu. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, AisotaqaAma jadowaluhumo (tropical:) Their affair, or case, was, or became, in a right, a regular, or an orderly, state; like the jdwl when its flow is uniform and uninterrupted. (TA.) And AisotaqaAma jadowalu AlHaAjRi (assumed tropical:) The caravan of the pilgrims formed an uninterrupted line. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also jadowalN as meaning (assumed tropical:) A kind of small vein. (Golius from Ibn-Seenà.)] ― -b4- Hence also jadowalu kitaAbK (assumed tropical:) [A ruled line, (such as is ruled round a page, &c.,) and a column, and a table, of a book]. (TA.)

jadiylN jdyl
jadiylN applied to a rope, Firmly twisted; as also majoduwlN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- A camel's nose-rein (S, K) of hide, or leather, (S,) firmly twisted: (S, K:) and a cord of hide, or leather, or of [goats'] hair, [that is put] upon the neck of the camel: (K:) and the [kind of women's ornament termed] wiXaAH (S, K) is sometimes thus called: (S:) pl. judulN. (K.)

jadaAlapN jdAl jdAlh jdAlp
jadaAlapN The ground: (S, Msb, K:) or hard ground: (TA:) or ground having fine sand. (K.)

jadiylapN jdylh jdylp
jadiylapN A rahoT, [q. v.,] i. e., (TA,) a thing like an Uitob, of hide, or leather, which boys, and menstruous women, wear round the waist in the manner of an UizaAr. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- A [tribe, such as is termed] qabiylap: and a region, quarter, or tract; syn. naAHiyapN: (S, K:) and so jadolaMCu↓, in both these senses, as used in the phrase, hecaA EalaI jadolaAYihi [This is according to the way of his region, and of his tribe]. (TA.) You say also, cahaba EalaI jadolaAYihi↓, in the K, erroneously, jadolaAnihi, (TA,) i. e., ElI wajohihi [He went his own way], (K, TA,) and naAHiyatihi [towards his region, or quarter, or tract]. (K.) ― -b2- A state, or condition. (K.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A particular way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct; syn. XaAkilapN, (S, K,) and TariyqapN. (K.) You say, Eamila EalaI jadiylatihi, i. e. [He did according to his own particular way, &c.; or] Eamila EalaI XaAkilatihi AlRatiI judila EalayohaA [explained above: see 1]. (TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A determination of the mind. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) The management, or ordering, of a people's affairs; the exercise of the office of Eariyf. (AA, TA.)

jaAdilN jAdl
jaAdilN A boy becoming, or become, strong; vigorous, or robust. (S.) ― -b2- A she-camel's young one above such as is termed raAXiH, which is such as has become strong, and walks with his mother- (As, S.) [See also jadala.]

janodalN jndl
janodalN: and junodalN: &c.: see art. jndl.

Oajodalu c
Oajodalu; fem. jadolaMCu: see majoduwlN, in three places ＝ -A2- Also, [accord. to most of the grammarians OajodalN, but accord. to some Oajodalu,] The hawk; syn. SaqorN; (S, K;) as also OajodaliIRN↓: (K:) or an epithet applied to the hawk [and therefore without tenween]: (TA:) pl. OajaAdilu. (K.)

OajodaliIRN c
OajodaliIRN: see what next precedes.

mijodalN mjdl
mijodalN A qaSor [or palace, or pavilion, &c.,] (S, K, TA [in the CK AlqaSiyru is erroneously put for AlqaSoru]) strongly constructed: (TA:) pl. majaAdilu. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also jadilN.

mijodaAlN mjdAl
mijodaAlN A piece of rock or stone: [an oblong roofing-stone, of those which, placed side by side, form the roof of a subterranean passage, &c.:] pl. majaAdiylu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jadilN.

majoduwlN mjdwl
majoduwlN: see jadiylN. [Hence,] diroEN majoduwlapN (tropical:) A compact coat of mail; (S, TA;) as also jadolaMCu↓: (S, K:) pl. [of the latter] judolN. (K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A man (K, TA) of slender make, (TA,) slender in the (bones called] qaSab, of firm, or compact, make (muHokamu Alfatoli [as though firmly twisted]): (K, TA:) or slender, slim, thin, spare, lean, or light of flesh; not from emaciation: (S:) and majoduwlu Alxaloqi, as some say, of firm, or compact, make. (TA.) And majoduwlapN (assumed tropical:) A woman small in the belly, and compact in flesh:
(A in art. fyD:) or majoduwlapu Alxaloqi a girl of beautiful compacture; of beautiful, compact make; syn. Hasanapu Aljadoli. (S.) Also saAEidN Oajodalu↓ (assumed tropical:) [A fore arm, or an upper arm,] of firm, or compact, make. (K, * TA.) And saAqN majoduwlapN and jadolaMCu↓ (tropical:) [A shank of beautiful compacture;] well rounded; well turned; syn. Hasanapu AlTRaIRi. (K, TA.)

1 jadaA Ealayohi jdA Elyh jdA Elyp
1. jadaA Ealayohi, (Msb, K,) and jadaAhu, first pers. jadawotu, (IB, TA,) aor.
jaduwa
, (K,) inf. n. jadowN (Msb, TA) and jadFA; (Msb;) and Ealayohi AjdI↓, (Msb, K,) and AjdAhu↓, (S,) the prep. in the former of these two being suppressed in the latter; (TA;) and AjtdAhu↓; (TA;) He gave him a gift. (S, IB, Msb, K, * TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jadaA Ealayohi XuWomahu (assumed tropical:) He drew his evil fortune, or ill luck, upon him: an ironical expression; [for it literally means he gave him, or bestowed upon him, his evil fortune.] (TA.) ― -b3- Hence also, Ealayoka AjdI↓ (tropical:) It (a thing) sufficed thee. (Msb.) fiEoluhu XayoYFA maA OajodaI↓ (tropical:) His deed, or act, did not profit him, or avail him, aught. (Msb.) And Eanoka hecaA maA yujodiI↓ (assumed tropical:) This does not stand thee in any stead; does not profit thee, or avail thee. (S.) ＝ -A2- jadawotuhu, (S, IB, Msb, K, *) [aor.
jaduwa
,] inf. n. jadowN; (K;) and jadayotuhu; (K in art. jdI;) and Aijotadayotuhu↓, (S, Msb, K, *) and Aisotajodayotuhu↓; I sought, or demanded, (S,) or asked, (IB, Msb, K,) of him (S, IB, Msb, K) a gift, (S,) or a thing wanted. (K.) [See an ex. of the last of these verbs in a verse cited in art. tA.] Hence, mujaAdaApN [inf. n. of jAdI↓]: whence, in a trad., waqado EarafuwA OanRahu layosa Einoda marowaAna maAlN yujaAduwnahu Ealayohi, meaning yasoOaluwnahu Ealayohi [i. e. And they knew that there was not, in the possession of Marwán, property for which they should ask as owed by him]. (TA.)

3 jaAodawa
3: see 1.

4 Oajodawa
4: see 1, in five places. ＝ -A2- Also AjdI, He obtained a gift. (S, Msb.)

8 Uijotadawa
8: see 1, in two places.

10 Uisotajodawa
10: see 1.

jadFA jd jdA
jadFA i. q. jadowaI, q. v. ― -b2- Hence, (Har p. 32,) jadFA, (K,) also written jadFI, (ISk, TA,) or maTarN jadFA, (S,) and, accord. to the K, jadowaI↓, but this latter is not known except as signifying “ a gift, ” (TA,) A common, or general, rain; (S, K, TA;) of wide extent: (TA:) or of which the uttermost is not known. (K.) One says also samaMCN jadFA, meaning A rain having a rain following it; making the latter word masc. because it has the force of an inf. n. (TA.) And AalRehumRa QsoqinaA gadaqFA wajadFA TabaqFA [O God, water us with a copious rain, and a rain that shall cover the land]: (S, TA:) occurring in a trad. respecting prayer for rain. (TA.) ― -b3- And xayorN jadFA Ample good; (K;) of wide extent to men. (TA.) ＝ -A2- laA Mtiyka jadaA AldRahori (S, * K, * TA) i. e. [I will not come to thee] ever, like yada AldRahori; (S, TA;) or to the end of time. (K, TA.)

jadowaI jdwI jdwy
jadowaI A gift; (S, Msb, K;) as also jadFA↓: (S, K:) dual (of the former, TA) jadowaAni and jadoyaAni; (Lh, M, K;) the former, regular; (M, TA;) the latter, anomalous, (M, K, TA,) formed by commutation. (M, TA.) You say, maA OaSabotu mino fulaAnK jadowaI qaTRu [I have not obtained from such a one a gift ever]. (TA.) And hence the prov., Xagalato XiEaAbiI jadowaAIa: see art. XEb. (S in that art.) ― -b2- See also jadFA.

jadaMCN c
jadaMCN profit, utility, or avail. (S, TA.) So in the saying, fulaAnN qaliylu AljadaMCi Eanoka [Such a one is of little profit, utility, or avail, to thee; will stand thee in little stead]. (S.)

jadiIRN jd jdI jdy jdyy
jadiIRN [originally jadiywN] Munificent, or bountiful. (TA.)

jaAdK jAd
jaAdK Asking, seeking, or demanding, (S, K,) a bounty, or benefit, (S,) or gift: (K:) pl. judaApN. (TA.)

OajodaI c
OajodaI [More, and most, profitable, useful, or availing]. It is said in a prov., OajodaI mina Algayovi fiI OawaAnihi [More profitable than rain in its season]. (Meyd.)

1 jadayotuhu jdy jdyp jdyth jdytp
1. jadayotuhu: see 1 in art. jdw. ― -b2- One says of the locust, yajodiI kulRa XaIoCK, meaning It eats everything. (TA.) ＝ -A2- lamo Oajodi mino celika budRFA I found no means of avoiding, or escaping, that, is sometimes said for lamo Oajido Alx The text appears to have a medial خ in the terminal position. . (Kz, TA in art. wjd.)

2 jdRI AlrRaHoli jdy AlrHl
2. jdRI AlrRaHoli, inf. n. tajodiyapN, He made, or put, to the camel's saddle a [jadoyap or] jadiyRap. (TA.)

4 AjdI Ojd OjdI Ojdy Ojdyy AjdI Ajdy jdA
4. AjdI It (a wound) flowed [with blood: see jadiyRapN]. (K.)

jadoIN jdy
jadoIN A kid: (S:) or a male kid; (IAmb, Msb, K;) the female being called EanaAqN: (IAmb, Msb:) or a kid in his first year; (Mgh, Msb;) not yet a year old: (TA:) one should not say jidoIN; (S;) this being a bad dial. var.: (Msb:) pl. (of pauc., TA, applied to three, S) OajodK (S, Msb, K) and (of mult., TA, applied to more than three, S) jidaMCN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jidoyaAnN: (K:) jadaAyaA [as pl. of jadoI] is not allowable. (S.) ― -b2- Hence, as being likened thereto, (M, TA,) AljadoIu (assumed tropical:) A certain star, (S, Msb, K,) [the star a of Ursa Minor, commonly called the pole-star,] that revolves with banaAtu naEoXK, (K,) by the side of the [north] pole, by which the kibleh is known, (S,) or according to which the kibleh is turned; (Msb;) the bright star at the extremity of the tail of the Lesser Bear; (Kzw;) the star of the kibleh; (Mgh;) also called jadoIu Alfaroqadi; (Mgh, Msb;) and called by the astronomers AljudaIRu↓, in the dim. form, to distinguish it from what next follows. (Mgh, MF.) [See also AlquTobu.] ― -b3- Hence also, (M, TA,) A certain sign of the Zodiac; (S, K;) [namely, Capricornus;] the tenth of the signs of the Zodiac; (Mgh;) that next to the dalow; unknown to the Arabs [of the classical times]. (K.) This and the former together are called [the] jadoyaAni. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jadoyaAni is also an anomalous dual of jadowaI, q. v. (Lh, M, K.) ＝ -A3- See also what next follows.

jadoyapN jd jdy jdyh jdyp
jadoyapN and jadiyRapN↓, (S, K,) but not jadiydapN, which is used by the vulgar, (S,) [A kind of pad, or] a stuffed thing, (S,) or a stuffed piece (K, TA) of a kisaMC, (TA,) that is put beneath a horse's saddle, (K,) or beneath the two boards (AldRafRataAni) of a horse's and of a camel's saddle; [one on either side; for] there are two of such stuffed things: (S:) the pl. of the former is jadayaAtN, (Sb, S,) which may be used as a pl. of mult., (TA,) or jadoyaAtN, so in [some of] the copies of the K, [but omitted in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K,] following the TS, as on the authority of A'Obeyd and AA and En-Nadr, (TA,) and jadoIN↓; (S, IB, [in some copies of the S jadFA, but the former (which I find in two copies of the S) is said by IB to be the right; or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,]) like as XaroIN is of XaroyapN: (IB, TA:) the pl. of jadiyRapN↓ is jadaAyaA. (S.) [See also jadiydapN, and rifaAdapN.]

judaMCN jdMC
judaMCN, (K in this art.,) or jucaMCN, (A in art. jcr, and K in art. brj,) [the latter is the term commonly known, An arithmetical square;] the product of multiplication [of a number by itself]; as when you say, the jdAC [or jcAC] of three [in some copies of the K, of three multiplied by three,] is nine; (K, * TA;) also called maAlN. (Msb in art. jcr.) [See jacorN.]

AljudayRu AljdI Aljdy jdy
AljudayRu: see jadoIN.

jadaAyapN jdAyh jdAyp
jadaAyapN and jidaAyapN A young gazelle; syn. gazaAlN: (K, and so in a copy of the S:) or a young doegazelle; syn. gazaAlapN: (so in another copy of the S:) said by As to be like the EanaAq of goats: (S:) or the male, and the female, of the young of gazelles, when it has attained the age of six months, or seven, and has run, and become strong: or, as some say, the male thereof: pl. jadaAyaA. (M, TA.)

jadiyRapN jd jdy jdyh jdyp
jadiyRapN: see jadoyapN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also Flowing blood; (Lh, K;) blood not flowing being termed baSiyrapN: (Lh, TA:) or the former, blood adhering to the body; and the latter, blood upon the ground: (AZ, S:) or the former, a streak of blood: (S:) or the first quantity that flows at once, of blood: (TA:) pl. jadaAyaA. (S.) ― -b2- A piece of musk. (K.) ― -b3- The colour of the face. (K, TA.) You say, AiSofarRato jadiyRapN wajohihi [The colour of his face became yellow]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- I. q. naAHiyapN [A side; a lateral, or an outward or adjacent, part or portion, region, quarter, or tract; &c.]. (K.) So in the saying, huwa EalaI jadiyRatihi [app. meaning He is keeping to his own side: he is following his own course; like the phrase huwa EalaI Tariyqatihi: or he is by himself; like huwa EalaI waHodihi and Hidatihi]. (TA.)

jaAdK jAd
jaAdK The locust; because it eats (yajodiI, i. e. yaOokulu) everything: but the appellation [more] commonly known is jaAbiYu. (TA.)

jaAdiIRN jAd jAdI jAdy jAdyy
jaAdiIRN [erroneously written in the CK, in this art. and in art. jwd, without the sheddeh to the I] Saffron; (Az, IF, K;) as also jaAdiyaMCu↓: (Sgh, K:) the former a rel. n. from AljaAdiyap, or jaAdiyap, a town of AlbaloqaMC, in Syria, said to produce saffron: it is mentioned by Az and IF in this art., being held by them to be of the measure faAEuwlN [originally jaAduwIN]: by J, in art. jwd, as being of the measure faEoliIRN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Wine; (K, TA;) as resembling saffron in colour. (TA.)

jaAdiyaMCu jAdyMC
jaAdiyaMCu: see what next precedes.

1 jacRahu c
1. jacRahu, (S, A, L, Msb,) aor.
jacuca
, (L, Msb,) inf. n. jacRN, (L, Msb, K,) He cut it, or cut it off; (S, A, L, Msb;) namely, a thing; (S, Msb;) as, for instance, a rope: (L:) or he cut it off utterly; (L, K;) and jacojacapN [inf. n. of jacojaca↓] signifies the same as jacRN, i. e. the cutting off utterly: (K:) and AijoticaAcN [inf. n. of AjtcR↓], the act of cutting: (KL:) or jacRahu signifies he cut it off utterly and quickly; and in like manner jcRchu↓ [applied to many objects, or as meaning he cut it, &c., repeatedly, or many times, or in many pieces, or much]. (L.) [Hence,] jacRa AlnRaxola, aor.
jacuca
, inf. n. jacRN and jacaAcN and jicaAcN, He cut off the fruit of the palm-trees; syn. Sarama: (Lh, L:) or, accord. to some, jcAc signifies the cutting off of all fruits, and jdAd relates particularly to palmtrees. (TA in art. jd.) [Hence also,] jucRuwhumo jacRFA, in a trad. relating to the battle of Honeyn, (assumed tropical:) Cut ye them off utterly; exterminate them by slaughter. (L.) ― -b2- Also, (S, A, L, Msb,) aor.
jacuca
, (L,) inf. n. jacRN, (L, K,) He broke it; (S, A, L, Msb, K;) namely, a thing, (S, Msb,) or a hard thing: (M, L:) and AijoticaAcN [inf. n. of AjtcR↓], also, signifies the act of breaking. (KL.) ― -b3- Also, (L,) inf. n. jacRN, (L, K,) He hastened it; or hastened to it. (L, K. *) It is said in a prov., respecting one who boldly ventures upon taking a false oath, jacRahaA jacRa AlEayori AlSRilRiyaAnapa He hastened to it as the ass hastens to the plant called SlRyAnp. (L.)

2 jacRaRa
2: see 1.

5 tajacRaRa
5: see 7.

7 AnjcR c
7. AnjcR It became cut, or cut off: (S, L, Msb, K:) or cut off utterly: or cut off utterly and quickly: and in like manner, tjcRc↓ [said of a number of things, or used in a frequentative or an intensive sense; being quasi-pass. of 2]. (L.)

8 Uijotacaca
8: see 1, in two places.

R. Q. 1 jacojaca c
R. Q. 1. jacojaca, inf. n. jacojacapN: see 1.

jacRN c
jacRN A piece broken off; a fragment: pl. OajocaAcN: so in the phrase, kasarotuhu OajocaAcFA [I broke it in pieces, or fragments]; occurring in a trad., relating to an idol. (L.) [See also jucaAcN.]

maA Ealayohi jucRapN c
maA Ealayohi jucRapN There is not upon him a piece of rag; i. e., any garment to cover him: (L:) or anything (S, L, K) of clothing: (S, L:) pl. jucacN. (Bd in xxi. 59.)

jicacN c
jicacN: see jucaAcN.

jacaAcN c
jacaAcN, with fet-h, The act of separating a thing from another thing (faSolu XaIoCK Eano XaIoCK, accord. to some copies of the K and the TA; [see 1;] accord. to other copies of the K, [probably by mistranscription,] the superiority of a thing over another thing, faDolu XICK EalaI XICK); as also jacaAcapN↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also what next follows.

jucaAcN c
jucaAcN and jicaAcN↓, (S, L, K,) the former of which is the more chaste, (S, L,) and jacaAcN↓, (L, K,) substs. from jacRN the act of “ breaking; “ (K;) What is broken, of, or from, a thing: (S, L:) or what is broken, or cut, in pieces: or broken pieces: so in the Kur xxi. 59, in which the word is read in these three different forms: (L:) some also read jucucFA, which is pl. of jaciycN↓; and some, jucacFA, pl. of jucRapN: (Bd:) or the first signifies fragments of a thing much broken; [as a coll. gen. n.;] and the n. un. is jucaAcapN↓: (Lth, L:) [or] it is an extr. pl. of jaciycN↓; (L;) or i. q. majocuwcN; and jicaAcN↓ is a dial. var.; or is pl. of jaciycN↓. (Bd.) [See also jacRN.] ― -b2- Also the first, Small pieces, or particles, of silver: and jucaAcaAtN↓, pieces of silver: (L:) or the latter, cuttings, or clippings, (S, L, K,) of silver. (M and L in art. qc.) ― -b3- Also Stones containing gold; (Ks, S, L, K;) so called because they are broken: (Ks, S, L:) or stones containing gold &c. which are broken; as also jicaAcN↓. (Msb.) ― -b4- And jcAc [app. jucaAcN or jicaAcN↓], (L,) or jicacN↓, (TA,) i. q. firaqN [Distinct parties, or portions, &c., of men or things]. (L, TA.)

jicaAcN c
jicaAcN: see jucaAcN, in four places.

jaciycN c
jaciycN and majocuwcN↓ Cut; or cut off: or cut off utterly: or cut off utterly and quickly: and also broken: (L:) pl. of the former, jucucN and jicaAcN (Bd in xxi. 59) and jucaAcN, which last is extr. (L. See the paragraph headed jucaAcN, in three places.) ― -b2- Also the former, (A, K,) and XaraAbN jaciycN, (A,) and jaciycapN↓, (S, L, K,) Meal of parched barley or wheat; syn. sawiyqN; (S, A, L, K;) so prepared [by being moistened with water or with clarified butter &c.] as to be drunk: (A:) and jcycp↓ is [a mess of the kind called] jaXiyXap made of coarse swyq; so called because it is broken and made into coarse particles: and a quantity of swyq, or the like, such as a man eats or drinks at one time. (L.)

jacaAcapN c
jacaAcapN: see jacaAcN.

jucaAcapN c
jucaAcapN and its pl. jucaAcatN: see jucaAcN, in two places.

jaciycapN c
jaciycapN: see jaciycN, in two places.

yado jacRaMCu c
yado jacRaMCu [fem. of OajacRu] (tropical:) An amputated arm or hand: used figuratively: see OaHacRu, in art. Hc. (L.) ― -b2- raHimN jacRaMCu (assumed tropical:) A bond of relationship [cut, or severed, or] not made close by affection; expl. by UicaA lamo tuwSalo [a well-known phrase: erroneously explained by Golius as meaning “ uterus infœcundus vel interruptæ conceptionis ”]: (Fr, S, L, K:) as also HacRaMCu. (Fr, S, L.) ― -b3- yamiynN jacRaMCu: see HacRaMCu. ― -b4- sinRN jacRaMCu A tooth much broken; or broken in pieces. (K, TA.)

jacRaAnN c
jacRaAnN (As, L, and so in some copies of the K: in other copies of the K, and in the TA, jucRaAnN:) Soft stones: (As, L, K:) as also kacRaAnN [q. v.]: (As, L:) n. un. (of both, As, L) with p. (As, L, K.)

majocuwcN c
majocuwcN: see jaciycN. ＝ -A2- EaTaMCN gayoru majocuwcK [A gift, or stipend,] not cut short, or not interrupted; syn. gayoru maqoTuwEK. (A'Obeyd, S, L.)

1 jacabahu c
1. jacabahu, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
jaciba
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. jacobN; (S, Msb;) as also jabacahu, (S, TA,) inf. n. jabocN, of the dial. of Temeem, (TA,) or formed by transposition; (S, TA; [but see art. jbc;]) and Ajtcbhu↓; (S, A, K;) He drew it; dragged it; pulled it; tugged it; strained it; extended it by drawing, or pulling or tugging; stretched it; extended, lengthened, or protracted, it; (S, A, K;) namely, a thing; and sometimes relating to an ideal object. (TA.) ― -b2- jacaba mina AlUinaMCi, (S,) or jacaba mina AlmaMCi, (K,) or jacaba AlmaMCa, (A, Msb,) nafasFA, (S, A, Msb, K,) or nafasayoni, (S, A, Msb,) (tropical:) He drank (S, K) from the vessel, (S,) or of the water, (K,) by putting his mouth into it, [a draught, or two draughts:] (S, K:) or he conveyed [or drew up] into the innermost parts of his nose [a draught, or two draughts, of the water]. (Msb.) And jacabato labanahaA (tropical:) She (a camel) drank her milk when she was milked. (A. [But see what next follows: and see also 5.]) ― -b3- jacabato, said of a she-camel, (S, K,) and of a she-ass also, aor.
jaciba
, inf. n. jicaAbN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) She became scant of milk; (S, K;) she drew her milk (jacabato labanahaA) from her udder so that it went away upwards. (TA.) ― -b4- jacabahu, (K,) or jacabahu Eano OumRihi, (S, A,) aor.
jaciba
, inf. n. jacobN, (TA,) (tropical:) He weaned him; namely, a colt, (S, A, K,) and a young camel, and a lamb. (TA.) And one says of a mother, jacabato waladahaA (tropical:) She weaned her young one: so accord. to Lh, who does not specify the kind. (ISd, TA.) And accord. to the T, juciba is said of a child, or of a lamb or kid, meaning (tropical:) He was weaned. (TA.) ― -b5- jacabahu and jaAcabahu↓ He transferred, or removed, it (a thing) from its place. (K.) ― -b6- jacabatohu (tropical:) She repelled him, or rejected him; namely, a man who sought her in marriage; (T, A, TA;) as though from the saying jaAcabotuhu fajacabotuhu [which see below]; (T, TA;) [i. e.] as though she contended with him and overcame him, and thus he became separated from her; (T, A, TA;) as also jabacatohu. (T, TA.) [Accord. to the TA, jaAcabatohu↓ has the same meaning; but I think that this is a mistake of a copyist.] ― -b7- jacaba fulaAnN Habola fulaAnihi (assumed tropical:) Such a one severed the bond of his union. (M, TA.) And jacaba fulaAnN AlHabola bayonanaA (tropical:) Such a one severed the bond of union between us. (A, TA.) ― -b8- jacaba AlnRaxolapa, aor.
jaciba
,
(AHn, K,) inf. n. jacobN, (AHn, TA,) He cut off the jacab [q. v.] of the palm-tree, (AHn, K,) to eat it. (AHn, TA.) ― -b9- jacaba AlEadowa (assumed tropical:) He ran quickly. (L in art. mEd.) See also 7. ― -b10- jacab AlXRahoru, (S, A, K,) aor.
jaciba
, inf. n. jacobN, (TA,) (tropical:) The greater part of the month (EaAmRatuhu, S, A, K, i. e. Oakovaruhu, TA) passed. (S, A, K.) ＝ -A2- jacabahu, aor.
jacuba
, He overcame him in AlmujaAcabap (K) [lit. drawing, dragging, pulling, &c.; (see 3;) but also] used figuratively [as meaning (tropical:) he overcame him in contention]. (TA.) You say, jaAcabotuhu↓ fajacabotuhu [I contended with him in drawing, dragging, &c., and I overcame him therein: and also] (tropical:) I contended with him and I overcame him. (T, A, * TA.)

3 jAcbhu c
3. jAcbhu He contended with him in drawing, dragging, pulling or tugging, straining, or stretching, &c. (L in art. md.) And jAcbhu AlHabola [He contended with him in pulling the rope]. (Mgh in art. nzE .) And jAcbhu AlvRawob He contended with him in pulling the garment, or piece of cloth. (A.) And jAcbwA AlXRaIoCa, inf. n. mujaAcabapN, They pulled the thing, every one of them to himself. (Msb.) And jaAcabotuhu fajacabotuhu: see 1, last sentence: [a phrase having two meanings: for] you say, jaAcabaA, (K, TA,) inf. n. mujaAcabapN (TA) and jicaAbN, (Har p. 636,) meaning (assumed tropical:) They two contended [in any manner], each with the other: (K, TA:) and [in like manner,] tjAcbA↓, (K,) inf. n. tajaAcabN, (S,) (assumed tropical:) They two contended together. (S, * K.) You say also, kaAnato bayonahumo mujaAcabaAtN vumRa QtRafaquwA (tropical:) [There were contentions between them: then they agreed]. (A, TA.) And jaAcabotuhu AlXRaIoCa (assumed tropical:) I contended with him for the thing. (S.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places, beside the instance in the last sentence.

5 tjcRbhu c
5. tjcRbhu (tropical:) He drank it; (A, K;) namely, milk: said of a pastor. (A.)

6 tjAcbwA AlvRawoba c
6. tjAcbwA AlvRawoba They contended together in pulling the garment, or piece of cloth. (A.) [Hence,] tjAcbwA OaToraAfa AlkalaAmi (tropical:) [They contended together in discourse, talk, or conversation]. (A.) See also 3. ― -b2- And see 7.

7 Anjcb c
7. Anjcb It (a thing) was, or became, drawn, dragged, pulled, tugged, strained, extended by drawing or pulling or tugging, or stretched, &c.; it dragged, or trailed along; syn. AnjrR. (S and K in art. jr.) ― -b2- It was, or became, transferred, or removed, from its place; and so tjAcb↓. (K.) ― -b3- AinojicaAbN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Quick going or journeying or travelling. (S.) [You say, Anjcb, and AlsRayora jacaba↓, (the latter occurring in the TA in art. xlj, &c., like jacaba AlEadowa, mentioned above, see 1,) (assumed tropical:) He went, or journeyed, or travelled, quickly.] And AnjcbwA fiI AlsRayori and Anjcb bihimu AlsRayoru (tropical:) They brought, or purveyed, wheat, or corn, or provisions, from afar. (A, TA.)

8 Ajtcbhu c
8. Ajtcbhu: see 1. ― -b2- Also He seized it, or took it, or carried it off, by force. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) He called, summoned, or invited, him. (Ham p. 645.)

jacobN c
jacobN (assumed tropical:) Quick journeying or travelling. (ISd, K.) ― -b2- And The stopping, or a stoppage, of the flow of saliva (AinoqiTaAEu AlrRiyqi). (S.)

jacabN c
jacabN The pith that is at the head of the palmtree, from which the [fibres called] liyf are pulled off, and which is then eaten; as though so called because pulled off [or cut] from the tree; (TA;) the heart, pith, or cerebrum, (jumRaAr,) of the palm-tree; (AHn, S, TA;) so in some copies of the K; (TA;) i. e. the XaHom of the palm-tree: (S:) or, as in some copies of the K, and in the M and L, only such as is coarse: (TA:) as also jicaAbN↓: (K:) n. un. jacabapN. (S, K.) [See also jacamapN.]

jacobapN mino gazolK c
jacobapN mino gazolK A portion that is drawn by a single pull of spun thread, or yarn. (S.) [Hence,] maA OaEoTaAhu jacobapa gazolK (tropical:) He gave him not aught. (A, TA.) ― -b2- bayoniI wabayona Almanozili jacobapN (assumed tropical:) Between me and the place of alighting is a piece [of land or country, or a tract], meaning a distance: (S:) or a far-extending piece [of land or country]. (K.) And bayonanaA wabayona baniI fulaAnK jacobapN, and nabocapN, (assumed tropical:) Between us and the sons of such a one is a small space, or short distance; i. e., they are near to us. (ISh, TA.)

Oaxaca fiI waAdiI jacabaAtK c
Oaxaca fiI waAdiI jacabaAtK [He took his way into the valley of Jedhebát]: (K:) or, as given by Meyd, [and in the A,] waqaEuwA [they fell into the valley of Jedhebát]: a celebrated prov.: (TA:) applied to a man who has missed the object of his aim or pursuit; (K, * TA;) jcbAt being said to be derived from jacaba AlSRabiIRa “ he weaned the boy; ” because, in weaning, a child sometimes dies: or from AinojacabuwA fiI AlsRayori, or Ainojacaba bihimu AlsRayoru, explained above: or, accord. to some, the right reading is jadabaAtK: or, as Az says, on the authority of As, the most correct reading is xadibaAtK, from xadabatohu AlHayRapu “ the serpent bit him; ” and the prov. is applied to him who falls into perdition, and to him who wanders in perplexity from the object of his aim or desire. (TA.) [See also another reading in art. xrb.]

jicibRaAnN c
jicibRaAnN The sandal-thong that is between the great and second toes. (K, TA.) You say, maA OagonaI EaniI jicibRaAnFA He did not stand me in stead of, or avail me as much as, a sandal-thong that is between the great and second toes. (AA, TA.)

jacaAbi c
jacaAbi, indecl., [as a proper name, changed in form from AljaAcibu,] (TA,) Death: (ISd, K:) so called because it draws away the soul. (ISd, TA.)

jicaAbN c
jicaAbN: see jacabN.

jacuwbN c
jacuwbN: see jaAcibN.

jacRaAbapN c
jacRaAbapN Hairs, (TA,) or coarse hairs, or a coarse hair, (K,) tied, and made into a snare, (TA,) for catching larks. (K, TA.)

jaAcibN c
jaAcibN (tropical:) A she-camel that has exceeded the usual time of pregnancy, and passed beyond the time [of the year] when she had been covered: (Lh, TA:) or a she-camel that has extended, or protracted, the period of her pregnancy to eleven months. (A, TA.) (assumed tropical:) A she-camel, (S, K,) and a she-ass, (TA,) scant of milk; (S, K, TA;) as also jaAcibapN and jacuwbN↓: (K:) pl. [of the first and second] jawaAcibu and jicaAbN. (S, K.)

juwcaAbN c
juwcaAbN (M, K) and cuwbaAjN, the latter formed by transposition, (L and TA in art. cbj,) A kind of food, prepared with sugar and rice and flesh-meat: (M, K:) [from the Persian kuwcaAbo, as observed by Golius:] it might be hastily imagined to be arabicized from juwzaho Mbo; but this is not the case: (TA:) [n. un. with p: or] juwcaAbapN is a cake of bread (xubozapN) put into the oven (tanRuwr), and having suspended over it a bird or some flesh-meat, the gravy of which flows upon it as long as it is cooking; also called OumRu Alfaraji, because it removes one's anxiety for seasoning, or condiment. (Har p. 227.)

1 jacara c
1. jacara, (A, TA,) aor.
jacura
, (TK,) inf. n. jacorN, (A, K,) He cut, or cut off, or severed, (K, TA,) a thing: (TA:) and (K) he extirpated, or cut off entirely, (A, K,) a thing; (A;) as also jcRr↓; (S;) and Ajcr↓, inf. n. UijocaArN. (AZ, K.)

2 jacRara
2: see 1.

4 Oajocara
4: see 1.

7 Anjcr c
7. Anjcr It became cut, or cut off, or severed. (K, TA.)

jacorN c
jacorN (As, IAar, S, A, Msb, K) and jicorN↓ (AA, S, K) The root, or lower part, (As, S, A, Msb, K,) of anything: (As, S, A:) or (so in the K, but in other lexicons “ and ”) particularly, of the tongue: (Sh, A, Msb, K:) and of the penis: (Sh, K:) and of a horn (S, * A) of a cow (S) or of a bull; (A;) or the horn [itself] of a cow: (TA:) and the latter word, the root, or foot, or lowest part, of a tree: (TA:) and the former word, the base of the neck: (El-Hejeree, K:) pl. jucuwrN. (K.) Hence, nazalati AlmaHabRapu fiI jacori qalobihi Love took up its abode in the bottom (OaSol) of his heart. (A.) And [hence] it is said in a trad., UinRa AlOamaAnapa nazalato fiI jacori quluwbi AlrRijaAli [app. meaning, Verily reason, or intellect, or rather conscience, each of which is a trust committed by God to man, and a faculty which renders him responsible for his faith and works, (see, in art. Amn, an explanation of OamaAnapN as used in the Kur xxxiii. 72,) hath taken up its abode in the bottom of the hearts of men]. (S.) ― -b2- Also, both words, The origin, or stock, from which one springs. (TA.) ― -b3- And the former, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and the latter, or the latter only, (K,) or the former only, (IAar, TA,) A root of a number; (A;) an arithmetical root; (Mgh, K;) [a square root;] a number that is multiplied by itself; (Msb;) as when you say that ten multiplied by ten is a hundred; (Mgh, Msb;) and three multiplied by three is nine; (A;) in the former of which cases, ten is the jcr, (Mgh, Msb,) i. e., the jcr of a hundred; (Mgh;) and in the latter, three; (A;) and in each case, the [square or] product of the multiplication is called the maAl, (Msb,) or the jucaMC, (A,)
or the majcuwr↓: (Mgh:) [pl. of pauc. OjocaArN, and of mult. jucuwrN.] It is of two kinds, naATiqN [i. e. rational], and OaSamRu [i. e. surd, or irrational]: the latter known only to God, accord. to a saying of 'Áïsheh. (Mgh.)

jicorN c
jicorN: see jacorN.

juWocarN c
juWocarN and juWocurN (S, K) and juwcarN and jawocarN and jaWocarN and jiycarN↓, (K, TA,) the last of which is written in some copies of the K [and in the CK] jayocarN, (TA,) The young one of a wild cow: (S, K:) pl. of the first and second, jaMciru. (S.) ISd thinks that jawodarN and jiycarN are Arabic, and that juWocarN and juWocurN are Persian. (TA.) See also mujocirN.

jiycarN c
jiycarN or jayocarN: see what next precedes.

mujocirN c
mujocirN A wild cow having a young one. (ISd, K.) Hence we decide that the C in jWcr↓ is augmentative; and because it often occurs as an augmentative in the second place. (ISd, TA.) [In the S it is regarded as a radical.]

majocuwrN c
majocuwrN: see HacorN.

4 AjcE c
4. AjcE, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. UijocaAEN, (Mgh, Msb,) He (a beast) became such as is denoted by the term jacaEN; (TA;) said of the offspring of the sheep or goat, he became in his second year; of that of the cow, and of a solidhoofed beast, he became in his third year; and of that of the camel, he became in his fifth year: (S, Msb, K:) but sometimes, when said of the offspring of the ewe, it means he became six months old, or nine months old; and such is allowable as a victim for sacrifice: (S:) IAar says, it denotes a time, not a tooth (Mgh, Msb) growing or falling out: (Msb:) and said of a she-goat, AjcEt means she became a year old, and sometimes, less than a year, by reason of plenty of food; and of a sheep, AjcE means, when from young parents, he became from six months old to seven; and when from very old parents, from eight months old to ten. (Mgh, Msb.) [See jacaEN, below.]

6 tjAcE c
6. tjAcE (tropical:) He (a man) pretended to be a jacaE [or youth]. (TA.)

jicoEN c
jicoEN The trunk of a palm-tree: (S, * Msb, K:) or, accord to some, only after it has become dry: or, accord. to some, only after it has been cut: (TA:) or the trunk of a tree when the head has gone: (Ham p. 656:) in the Kur, xix. 23, it is applied to the trunk of a palm-tree which had become dry and was without a head; (Bd;) therefore this does not indicate any restriction nor the contrary: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OjocaAEN (Msb) and [of mult.] jucuwEN. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- The beam of a roof. (Msb, TA.)

jacaEN c
jacaEN A beast (Lth, Mgh) before the vaniIR [q. v.], (Lth, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) by one year; when it may for the first time be ridden and used: (Lth:) fem. with p: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) pl. masc.
