[of pauc.] OjocaAEN (Yoo, O) and [of mult.] jucoEaAnN (Yoo, S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jicoEaAnN (L, Msb) and jicaAEN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jucaAEN; (Yoo, O;) and pl. fem. jacaEaAtN: (S, Msb:) it is a name applied to the beast in a particular time, not denoting a tooth growing or falling out: (S, K:) but it differs in its application to different kinds of beasts: (Az:) applied to a sheep or goat, it means a year old; (IAar;) in his second year: (Mgh:) or, applied to a sheep, a year old; and sometimes less than a year, by reason of plenty of food; (IAar;) or eight months old, (Az, Mgh, TA,) or nine; (TA;) or, when from young parents, from six months old to seven; and when from very old parents from eight months old to ten; (IAar, Mgh;) and the sheep thus called is a satisfactory victim for sacrifice: (Mgh, TA:) and applied to a goat, a year old; (Az, Mgh;) or in its second year; (AZ;) but the goat thus called is not a satisfactory victim for sacrifice: (Mgh:) applied to a bull, it means in like manner in his second year; (Mgh;) or in his third year; and the bull thus called is not a satisfactory victim for sacrifice: (TA:) applied to a horse, it means in his third year; (IAar;) or in his fourth year: (Mgh:) [but see qaAriHN:] and applied to a camel, in his fifth year; (Az, Mgh;) fem. with p; and this (a jcEp) is what must be given for the poor-rate when the camels are more than sixty. (Az, TA.) [See also XaSarN.] ― -b2- A youth, or young man. (K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) One who is light-witted, or weak and stupid, like a youth: opposed in this sense to baAzilN as meaning “ old: ” (IAar, TA:) or one whose teeth have fallen out, here and there, [as though likened to a beast thus termed that has shed some of his first teeth,] because he has drawn near to his appointed term of life. (TA: [but it is not quite clear whether this explanation relate to jcE or to bAzl.]) ― -b4- (tropical:) [A novice, or recent beginner.] You say, fulaAnN fiI hecaA AlOamori jacaEN (tropical:) [Such a one, in this affair, is a novice, or recent beginner,] when he has begun it recently. (S, Z.) ― -b5- AldRahoru jacaEN OabadFA (tropical:) Time, or fortune, is ever new, like a youth. (K, * TA.) ― -b6- Hence, (TA,) AlOazolamu AljacaEu (tropical:) Time, or fortune; (S, K;) as in the saying, Oaholakahumu AlOazolamu AljacaEu (tropical:) Time, or fortune, destroyed them; and laA Mtiyka AlOazolama AljacaEa (tropical:) I will not come to thee ever. (TA.) [See also art. zlm.] And accord. to some, (S,) The lion: (S, K:) but this is a mistake. (IB, L.) ― -b7- And hence, (TA,) OumRu AljacaEi (tropical:) Calamity, or misfortune. (K, TA.) ― -b8- OaEadotu AlOamora jacaEFA (tropical:) I renewed the thing, or affair, as it was at the first: as, for instance, a war which had been extinguished. (TA.) And farRa AlOamora jacaEFA [signifies, in like manner, (tropical:) He recommenced the thing: or] he commenced the thing. (TA.) And furRa AlOamoru jacaEFA (tropical:) The thing was commenced: (TA:) or the thing returned to its first state; it recommenced. (K in art. fr.) ― -b9- jucoEaAnu AljibaAli (assumed tropical:) Small mountains. (K.)

jucuwEapN c
jucuwEapN [The state of being what is denoted by the term jacaEN;] a subst. from UijocaAEN [inf. n. of AjcE]. (TA.)

jacoEamapN c
jacoEamapN Young; (S, K, * TA;) not arrived at puberty: (TA:) originally jacoEapN; (S, K;) the m being augmentative: (S:) the p is either to give intensiveness to the meaning, or to denote the fem. gender; the word being considered as implying the meaning of nafosN or juvRapN. (TA.)

xaruwfN mutajaAciEN c
xaruwfN mutajaAciEN [A lamb approaching the age in which the term jacaEN is applied to him: expl. in some copies of the K by daAnK: in others, by waAnK:] in the copies of the O, expl. by waAnK mina AlUijocaAEi: in the TS and in the A, by daAnK, which is probably the right reading. (TA.)

jacoEamapN c
jacoEamapN: see art. jcE.

1 jacafahu c
1. jacafahu, (AA, S, K,) aor.
jacifa
, (K,) inf. n. jacofN, (AA, S,) He cut it; or cut it off: (AA, S, K:) and so with d. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jadafa said of a bird, a dial. var. of jadafa: (S:) both signify He (a bird) went quickly (K, TA) with his wings; generally, when one of the wings had been shortened; (TA;) as also Ajcf↓ and Anjcf↓: and so, both of these, with d. (K.) ― -b2- [Hence, jacafa biAlmijocaAfi; and jacafa biAlsRafiynapi, or AlsRafiynapa; i. q. jadafa, q. v.] ― -b3- jacafa fiI miXoyatihi He (a man) was quick in his manner of walking: (AO, S:) and so with d: (AAF, TA in art. jdf:) as also tjcRf↓. (TA.) And jacafato She (a woman) walked like those that are short: and she (a gazelle, and a woman, TA) went with short steps; as also Ajcft↓: and so, both, with d. (K.) ― -b4- jacafati AlsRamaMCu biAlvRaloji The sky cast down snow: and so with d. (TA.) ＝ -A3- jacafa AlXRaIoCa i. q. jacabahu. (TA.)

4 Oajocafa
4: see 1, in two places.

5 tajacRafa
5: see 1.

7 Uinojacafa
7: see 1.

mijocaAfN c
mijocaAfN, (S, TA,) in the K mijocaAfapN↓, but the former is the more proper, (TA,) i. q. mijodaAfN; (S;) The wing of a bird: and so with d. (Msb in art. jdf.) ― -b2- And [hence, An oar; a paddle;] a certain thing with which a ship, or boat, is propelled. (S, * TA.) ― -b3- And hence, as being likened thereto, A whip: (Abu-l-Ghowth, S:) and so with d. (TA in art. jdf.)

majocuwfN c
majocuwfN A [skin of the kind called] ziqR having the legs cut off: and so with d. (K * and TA in this art. and in art. jdf.)

mijocaAfapN c
mijocaAfapN : see mijocaAfN.

1 jacala c
1. jacala, (aor.
jacula
, TK,) inf. n. jucuwlN, It stood erect, and was firm, (K, TA,) like the jicol of a tree. (TA.) And He set himself up as an antagonist to others, in fight. (TA in art. Hk.)
And said of a chameleon, It became erect; as also Astjc↓. (TA.) You say also, baAta yasotajocilu↓ EalaI Zahori daAbRatihi (tropical:) He slept [during the night] erect, without commotion, upon the back of his beast. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jacila, (S, K,) aor.
jacala
, (K,) inf. n. jacalN, (S,) He was, or became, joyful, glad, or happy; as also Ajtcl↓. (S, K.)

4 Ajclhu c
4. Ajclhu He made him joyful, glad, or happy. (S, K.)

8 Uijotacala
8: see 1.

10 Uisotajocala
10: see 1, in two places.

jacolN c
jacolN: see what next follows, in two places.

jicolN c
jicolN (S, K) and jacolN↓ (K) The trunk, stem, stump, or lower part, (OaSol) of a tree &c., after the branch or the like has gone; pl. [of pauc.] OajocaAlN and [of mult.] jicaAlN and jucuwlN and jucuwlapN, (K,) which last is pl. of jacolN: (TA:) or a large trunk, or lower portion, of a tree; (S, * K;) pl. OajocaAlN: (S:) and a branch, or piece of wood, like the fruit-stalk of the raceme of a palm-tree. (K.) [Hence,] EaAda UilaI jacolihi↓ [or jicolihi] (assumed tropical:) He returned to his original state, or condition. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, the former, A post, or piece of wood, that is set up (S, K) in the place where camels lie down, at their watering-place, (S,) for the mangy camels to rub themselves against it. (S, K. *) Hence, (S, K,) the saying of El- Hobáb Ibn-El-Mundhir, (S,) AlmuHakRaku OanaA jucayoluhaA↓ waEucayoquhaA AlmurajRabu (assumed tropical:) [I am their much-rubbed little rubbing-post, and their propped little palm-tree loaded with fruit, or their honoured little palmtree &c.: see art. rjb]: (S, * K, * TA:) i. e., I am of those by means of whose counsel, or advice, people seek relief, like as the mangy camels seek relief from their mange by rubbing themselves against the post above mentioned, (TA,) and one having a family that will aid and defend me: (TA in art. rjb:) the dim. is here used for the purpose of aggrandizement. (K. [See also art. Hk.]) And hence, (TA,) huwa jicolu maAlK (tropical:) He is a gentle manager of cattle: (S, * K, * TA:) likened to the jicol that is set up. (TA.) One says also, UinRahu jicolu rihaAnK, i. e., SaAHibuhu [app. meaning, (assumed tropical:) Verily he is one who is constantly engaged in contending for stakes, or wagers; rhAn being here an inf. n. of raAhana; not a pl. of rahonN; for if it were the latter, the explanation would be SaAHibuhaA]. (K.) ― -b3- A small quantum of property, or a small number of cattle; (K;) as though it were the original stock thereof. (TA.) ― -b4- The summit, or head, of a mountain; and a prominent portion thereof: pl. OjocaAlN. (K.) ― -b5- The side of a sandal. (K.)

jacilN c
jacilN: see what next follows.

jacolaAnu c
jacolaAnu [in copies of the K with tenween, but correctly without tenween, for the fem. is jacolaMCu,] Joyful, glad, or happy; (S, K;) as also jacilN↓; (K;) and jaAcilN↓ occurs in poetry: (IDrd, K:) pl. jucolaAnN. (K.) You say, nafosuhu jacolaMCu bicelika His soul is joyful, glad, or happy, by means of that. (TA.)

jucayolN c
jucayolN dim. of jicolN, q. v.

jaAcilN c
jaAcilN [part. n. of jacala] (assumed tropical:) Erect, in his place, not moving therefrom; likened to the jicol that is set up in the place where camels lie down, at their watering-place, for the mangy camels to rub themselves against it. (S.) You say, baAta jaAcilFA EalaI Zahori daAbRatihi (tropical:) He slept [during the night] erect, without commotion, upon the back of his beast. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jacolaAnu.

1 jacamahu c
1. jacamahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jacima
(Msb, K, TA) and
jacuma
also, (accord. to some copies of the K,) inf. n. jacomN, (S, Msb, K,) He cut it off; (S, Msb, K;) and so jcRmhu↓: (K:) or jcRm signifies he cut off many things; or cut off much, or frequently: and jacomN signifies also the cutting off quickly. (TA.) [It is like xacamahu.] You say, jacama yadahi, (Msb, K,) aor.
jacima
, inf. n. as above, (Msb,) He cut off, or amputated, his arm, or hand; (Msb, K;) as also AjicmihA↓, (K,) inf. n. UijocaAmN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jacama fulaAnN Habola wiSaAlihi (tropical:) Such a one severed the bond of his union; as also jacabahu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jacima, (S, Msb,) aor.
jacama
, (Msb,) inf. n. jacamN , He (a man) had his arm, or hand, cut off, or amputated; was maimed of it. (S, Msb.) You say, HatRaI maA AlRaciI Ojocamahu↓ jRcima [What is it that has maimed him of his arm, or hand, so that he has become maimed of it?] (TA.) ― -b2- And jacimiti Alyadu, aor.
jacama
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. jacamN, (Msb,) The arm, or hand, was cut off, or amputated. (Msb, K.) ＝ -A3- jucima He (a man, S, Msb) was, or became, affected, or smitten, with the disease termed jucaAm. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.)

2 jacRama
2: see 1.

4 Oajocama
4: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- UijocaAmN also signifies The being quick in pace, or going. (Lth, TA.) You say, Ajcm fiI sayorihi, (S,) or Ajcm AlsRayora, (K,) He (a camel, S) hastened, or was quick, in his pace, or going. (S, K.) And Ajcm said of a horse, (Lh, K,) and the like, of such as run, (Lh, TA,) He ran vehemently. (Lh, K.) ― -b2- Ajcm Eani AlXRaIoCi He abstained, or desisted, from the thing. (S, * K.) ― -b3- Ajcm He decided, determined, or resolved, upon it. (K.)

5 tajacRama
5: see 7.

7 Anjcm c
7. Anjcm It was, or became, cut off; (S, K;) as also tjcRm↓: (K:) [or the latter is said of a number of things; or implies muchness, or frequency:] the two verbs are syn. [respectively] with AinoqaTaEa and taqaTRaEa. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence] you say, Anjcm Eani AlrRakobi (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, cut off from the company of riders upon camels. (TA.) And En-Nábighah says,
SadRato sulayomaI waOamosaI HaboluhaA QnojacamaA
[Suleymà has turned away, and the bond of her union with me has become severed]. (S.)

jacomN c
jacomN: see the next paragraph. ＝ -A2- Also A cessation of the supply of corn or other provision. (TA.) ＝ -A3- A rope cut off, or severed. (TA.) ― -b2- A man whose extremities have fallen off in pieces, piece after piece, in consequence of the disease termed jucaAm. (TA; but in this last sense, the word is there written without any syll. signs.)

jicomN c
jicomN The root, source, origin, or original, or the fundamental or essential or principal part, syn. OaSol, (S, Msb, K,) of a thing, (S, Msb, TA,) whatever that thing be; (TA;) as also jacomN↓: (S, K:) pl. [of pauc.] OajocaAmN and [of mult.] jucuwmN. (K.) ― -b2- The family of a people; their kinsfolk: whence the saying, in a trad., lamo yakono rajulN mino qurayoXK UilRaA lahu jicomN bimakRapa [There was not a man of Kureysh but he had kinsfolk in Mekkeh]. (TA.) [And app. The main stock from which tribes are derived: for,] accord. to some, it ranks before XaEobN. (TA voce baTonN.) ― -b3- The places [or place] of growth of the teeth. (TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely, El-Hárith Ibn-Waaleh, (TA,)
AaloMna lamRaA QboyaDRa masorubatiI
waEaDiDotu mino naAbiI EalaI jicomi
(S, TA,) [Now, when the hair in the middle of my bosom, extending downwards to my navel, has become white, and I have bitten upon the place of growth of my canine tooth]: i. e., I have become old, and eaten upon the jcm of my nAb. (TA.) ― -b4- The lower, or lowest, part, or the foundation, of a wall: (Mgh from a trad.:) or the remains thereof: or a portion thereof. (TA.) ― -b5- See also jicomapN.

jacimN c
jacimN Quick; swift. (K.)

jacomapN c
jacomapN The place of the arm, or hand, where it is cut off, or amputated; as also jacamapN↓. (K.)

jucomapN c
jucomapN The defect, or deficiency, of him who has had his arm, or hand, amputated, or who has lost the end-joints of his fingers: so accord. to the copies of the K: but in the L, the defect, or deficiency [resulting] from the amputation of the arm or hand (mina AlUijocaAmi.) (TA.) ＝ -A2- maA samiEotu lahu jucomapF, with damm, meaning [I heard him not utter] a word, is not of established authority. (ISd, TA.)

jicomapN c
jicomapN A piece cut off (S, K) of a rope &c., (S,) or of a thing of which the extremity has been cut off, the lower, or principal, part remaining; (K;) as also jicomN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- A whip: (S, K:) because it becomes cut by that which is beaten with it. (TA.) ― -b3- The part of a whip of which the slender extremity has become much cut [by use], the lower, or principal, part remaining; pl. jicamN: (L, TA:) or the remaining part of a whip; its lower, or principal, portion. (As, TA.) ― -b4- A thick piece of wood, having fire at the end of it or not; [i. e. a brand, or fire-brand;] like jicowapN. (AO, S and TA in art. jcw.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) A company of men [as though cut off from others]. (TA.)

jacamapN c
jacamapN: see jacomahN. ― -b2- Also The uppermost pith of the palm-tree; which is the best; (K;) like jacabapN. (TA.) ― -b3- And Dates that come forth upon one base. (TA.)

jucaAmN c
jucaAmN [Elephantiasis; a species of leprosy; the leprosy that pervaded Europe in the latter part of the Middle Ages;] a certain disease, (S, K,) arising from the spreading of the black bile throughout the whole person, so that it corrupts the temperament of the members, and the external condition thereof; and sometimes ending in the dissundering, or corrosion, (so accord. to different copies of the K, TA,) of the members, and their falling off, in consequence of ulceration; (K, TA;) so called because it dissunders the flesh, and causes it to fall off; (Msb;) or because the fingers, or toes, become cut off: (TA:) it is a cracking of the skin, and a dissundering, and gradual falling off, of the flesh. (Mgh.)

nawFIjacuwmN c
nawFIjacuwmN A tract towards which one journeys separating lovers or objects of love. (TA.)

jaciwmN c
jaciwmN Cut off; amputated. (S, Msb, TA.) [See also Oajocamu.]

jucaAmapN c
jucaAmapN What remains, of seed-produce, after the reaping. (S.) ― -b2- [See also juraAmapN, in two places.]

jaAmN jAm
jaAmN [an epithet] of the measure faERaAlN from Aljacomu meaning AlqaToEu: so in the phrase jacRaAmu Haboli AlhawaI [Wont to sever the bond of love], in a verse of Ows Ibn-Thaalabeh. (Ham p. 334.)

Oajocamu c
Oajocamu Having his arm, or hand, cut off, or amputated: (S, Msb, K:) or having lost the endjoints of his fingers: (K:) fem. jacomaMCu: (Msb:) pl. jacomaI. (S.) It is said in a trad., mano taEalRama AlquroMna vumRa nasiyahu laqiIa QllReha yawoma AlqiyaAmapi wahuwa Oajocamu, (A 'Obeyd, S, *) i. e., [He who learns the Kur-án and then forgets it shall meet God on the day of resurrection] having his arm, or hand, cut off: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) or having lost all his limbs, or members: (Kt, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) having his plea cut off; having no tongue with which to speak, nor any plea in his hand: (IAth, TA:) or (assumed tropical:) having his means of access cut off: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) with his hand devoid of good and of recompense. (IAar, El-Khattábee, TA.) And in another trad., kulRu xuTobapK layosa fiyhaA XahaAdapN kaQloyadi AljacomaMCi [Every oration from the pulpit in which there is not an acknowledgment of the unity of God and of the mission of Mohammad is like the arm of which the hand is amputated]. (TA.) ― -b2- AlkRfRu AljacomaMCu [The amputated hand;] (assumed tropical:) a name of the star a of Cetus; (so in the Egyptian Almanacs;) [i. e.] the star that is in the head of Cetus: so called because it is less extended [from the Pleiades] than that called AlkafRa AlxaDiybu. (Kzw. [See AlkafRu AlxaDiybu in art.xDb.]) ― -b3- naEolN jacomaMCu (assumed tropical:) A sandal of which the [thong called] qibaAl [which is between two of the toes] is cut, or cut off, or severed. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also majocuwmN.

mujacRamN c
mujacRamN: see majocuwmN. ＝ -A2- Also A man tried, or proved, and strengthened by experience in affairs. (TA.)

rajulN mijocaAmN c
rajulN mijocaAmN and mijocaAmapN↓, [the latter of a very rare measure, (see miEozaAbapN,)] (assumed tropical:) A man who decides affairs. (K.) (tropical:) A man who, loving and being loved, when he is sensible of evil treatment quickly cuts the tie of affection: (A, TA:) or the latter, (tropical:) a man who quickly cuts the tie of love, or affection. (S, K, TA.) rajulN mijocaAmu AlrRakoDi fiI AlHarobi (assumed tropical:) A man quick in running, or fleeing, in war. (TA.) And rajulN mijocaAmapN↓ liloHarobi, and lilsRayori, and lilohawaI, (assumed tropical:) A man who desists from, and relinquishes, war, and journeying, and love, or natural desire. (Lh, TA.)

majocuwmN c
majocuwmN A man (S, Msb) affected, or smitten, with the disease termed jucaAm; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also mujacRamN↓ (K) and Oajocamu↓, (Kr, K,) which J erroneously disallows: (K:) J says, one does not say Ojocamu: (TA:) [and Fei,] they say that Oajocamu, of the measure of OaHomaru, is not said in this sense. (Msb.)

mijocaAmapN c
mijocaAmapN: see mijocaAmN, in two places.

jacomaArN c
jacomaArN or jidomaArN: see what follows, in two places.

jucomuwrN c
jucomuwrN The root, or lowest part, of a thing: or the first thereof; (K;) the beginning, or commencement, and fresh state, thereof; its first and fresh state. (TA.) ― -b2- A piece, or portion, (S, K,) of the lowest part (S) of a palm-branch, (S, K,) [i. e. a stump thereof,] remaining upon the trunk when the [rest of the] branch has been cut off; (S, K;) as also jacomaArN↓, (S,) or jicomaArN. (K.) [Accord. to the S, the m is an augmentative letter.] ― -b3- The stump of a [tree of the kind called] naboEap, remaining when the tree has been cut down. (TA.) ― -b4- The stump of a hand of which the greater part has been cut off; (TA;) what remains of a hand that has been amputated, at the extremity of the two bones of the fore arm. (T, TA.) One says, Darabahu bijucomuwrihi and biqaTaEatihi [He struck him with the stump of his amputated hand]. (TA.) ― -b5- What remains of anything that has been cut off. (IAar, TA.) ― -b6- [Pl. jacaAmiyru.] ― -b7- You say, Oxacahu bijucomuwrihi (assumed tropical:) He took it altogether; (K;) as also Axch bijacaAmiyrihi: (Ks, S, K:) or he took it in its first and fresh state: and Fr also mentions the phrases Axch bijicomiyrihi↓ and bijicomaArihi↓. (TA.)

Oaxacahu bijicomiyrihi c
Oaxacahu bijicomiyrihi: see what next precedes.

1 jacaA c
1. jacaA, (S, K,) aor.
jacuwa
, (TA,) inf. n. jacowN and jucuwRN, (K,) It (a thing, TA) stood firmly; as also AjcI↓. (S, K.) You say also, jacaA EalaI XaIoCK He [or it, for instance, a stone of those (three in number) upon which a cooking-pot is places, as is implied in the S, (see jaAcK,)] remained firm upon a thing. (S.) And jacaA AlquraAdu fiI janobi AlbaEiyr The ticks stuck, and clave, to the side of the camel: (ISd, K, TA:) and jcA biAljamali clung to the camel. (TA.) ― -b2- I. q. javFA [He sat upon his knees; &c.]; (AA, Fr, S, K;) as also AijocawaI↓, [in form] like AiroEawaI; (TA;) except that jcA is more indicative of keeping to a place: (Kh, TA:) or he stood upon the extremities of his toes: (As, K:) accord. to Th, jucuwRN is [the standing] upon the extremities of the toes; and juvuwRN is [the sitting] upon the knees: (TA:) and accord. to IAar, jaAcK↓ means [a man standing] upon his feet; and jaAvK, [one sitting] upon his knees. (S, TA.) Accord. to El-Hasan Ibn-'AbdAllah El-Kátib El-Isbahánee, jacaA, inf. n. jucuwRN, said of a bird, means He stood upon the extremities of his toes, and warbled, and went round in his warbling; which he does only when seeking the female: and said of a horse, it means he stood upon his toes; and in like manner when said of a man, whether for dancing or for some other purpose. (TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely, En-Noamán Ibn-Nadleh, (TA,)
UicaA XiYotu ganRatoniI dahaAqiynu qaroyapK
waSanRaAjapN tajocuw EalaI Harofi manosimi
[When I will, the husbandmen of a village sing to me, and a female player with the cymbals, standing upon the extremity of a toe]. (S, TA: but in the latter, EalaI kulRi manosimi [upon every toe].) ― -b3- Also, inf. n. jucuwRN, He, or it, was, or became, erect, and straight; (TA;) and so AijocawocaI↓, inf. n. AijociycaMCN. (Az, TA.) See jawaAci as applied to she-camels, in two places, voce jaAcK. ― -b4- It (a camel's hump) bore fat [so that it became elevated]. (K.) ― -b5- jacaA manoxiraAhu His nostrils were, or became, raised and extended. (TA.) ― -b6- Er-Rá'ee, describing a strong, or sturdy, she-camel, says,
lamo yajocu mirofaquhaA fiI AldRafi mino zawari
meaning Her elbow did not stand out far from the side by reason of [the distortion termed] zawar. (TA.)

4 AjcI c
4. AjcI: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also He (a young camel) bore fat in his hump. (Ks, S, K.) El-Khansà says,
yujociyna nayRFA walaA yjociyna qirodaAnaA
They bear fat [in their humps], and have not ticks clinging to them. (IB, TA.) ＝ -A2- He lifted a stone, (AA, S, TA,) in order that he might know thereby his strength. (TA.) One says, humo yujocuwna HajarFA wayatajaAcawonahu↓ [They lift a stone, in order to prove their strength, and vie, one with another, in lifting it, for that purpose]. (TA.) tajaAcK↓, in the lifting of a stone, is like tajaAv: (S, TA:) tajaAcawoA meaning taraAbaEuwA liyarofaEuwhu [They vied, one with another, to lift the stone, for trial of strength]. (TA.) ― -b2- AjcI Tarofahu [in the CK, erroneously, Tarafahu,] He raised his eye, or sight, and cast it before him. (K, TA.)

6 tajaAocawa
6: see 4, in two places.

9 AijocawaI c
9. AijocawaI: see 1.

12 AijocawocaI c
12. AijocawocaI: see 1.

jicowapN c
jicowapN and jucowapN and jacowapN (S, Msb, K) [A brand, or fire-brand;] i. q. jicomapN, (AO, S, K,)
i. e. a thick piece of wood, having fire at the end of it or not: (AO, S, in explanation of the first:) or a thick piece of fire-wood, not flaming: (AO, TA, in explanation of jicowapN mina AlnRaAri:) or a thick stick, one end of which is a live coal: (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA:) or a thick stick upon which fire is taken [by kindling one end]: (ISk, TA:) and a piece (qabosapN, K, or qiToEapN, Har p. 471) of fire: (K, Har:) or a portion of fire-wood that remains after flaming: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and a live coal: (S, K:) or a flaming live coal: (Msb:) or jicowapN mina AlnRaAri means a piece of live coal; so in the language of all the Arabs: (Mujáhid, S, TA:) pl. [of the first] jicFI and [of the second] jucFI (S, Msb, K) and (of the third, TA) jacFI (Msb, TA, and so in a copy of the S) and jicaMCN, (AAF, K,) which is held by ISd to be a pl. of the third. (TA.)

jucaMCN c
jucaMCN: see judaMCN, in art. jdI.

jaAcK c
jaAcK [part. n. of 1; fem. jaAciyapN: pl. masc. jicaMCN; pl. fem. jaAciyaAtN and jawaAcK]. A rájiz says, (S,) namely, 'Amr Ibn-Jebel-El-Asadee, (TA,)
lamo yuboqi minohaA sabalu AlrRacaAci
gayora OavaAfiI mirojalK jawaAciI
i. e. [The continual fine rain left not thereof save the three stones that were the supports of a cooking-pot] remaining firm. (S, TA.) ― -b2- I. q. jaAvK [Sitting upon his knees; &c.]: (Fr, TA:) or sitting upon his heels, with his feet upright, [resting] upon the extremities of his toes: (S:) or standing upon the extremities of the toes: (AA, S:) see also 1: pl. [masc.] jacaMCN. (S) Aboo-Duwád describes mares as jaAciyaAtN EalaI AlsRanaAbiki, i. e. Standing upon the toes. (AA, S, * TA.) ― -b3- jawaAcK, (K,) applied to she-camels, (TA,) means That bear themselves erect (tajocuw↓) in their course, or pace, as though they lifted their feet clear from the ground; (K, TA;) on the authority of Aboo-Leylà: (TA:) [the last words of the explanation in the K are kaOanRahaA taqolaEu: in the TA, kAnhA tqlE AlsRayora: I suppose that AlsRayora is for fiI AlsRayori; and that the pret. of the aor. here used is qaliEa; for qaliEN, which is of the regular form of a part. n. of such a verb as qaliEa, means “ raising the feet clear from the ground in walking &c.: ” but in one copy of the K, I find tuqalREu: and another reading in some work seems to be tuqoliEu; for] ISd says, I know not jacaA with the meaning of OasoraEa nor of OaqolaEa: and As says that jawaAcK means quick, or swift, camels, that do not stretch themselves forth in their course, or pace, but bear themselves erect (wayanotaSibona yajocuwna↓). (TA.)

mujocK c
mujocK [act. part. n. of 4]. mivolu AlOarozapi Almujociyapi EalaI AlOaroDi, (S,) or kaAlOarozapi Almjcyp ElI wajohi AlArD, (TA,) occurring in a trad., (S, TA,) describing the unbeliever, (TA,) means [Like the pine-tree] that is firm (S, TA) and erect [upon the ground]. (TA.)

mujocawocK c
mujocawocK [in the CK, erroneously, AlmajocuwociIRu,] Keeping constantly to the dwelling, or to the camel's saddle and the dwelling, (AlrRaHol and Almanozil, AA, S, K,) not quitting it: (AA, S:) like mujocawocK EalaI AlrRaHoli. (AA, S) ― -b2- And A man who lowers, or abases, himself; (El-Hejeree, ISd, TA;) as though he clave to the ground by reason of his abjectness; from jacaA AlquraAdu fiI janobi AlbaEiyri [q. v.]. (ISd, TA.)

1 jarRa jr
1. jarRa, aor.
jarura
, (S, A, Msb,) inf. n. jarRN; (S K;) and jrRr↓, inf. n. tajoriyrN (S K) [and app. tajirRapN, said in the TA to be of the measure tafoEilapN from AljarRu], with teshdeed to denote repetition or frequency of the action, or its relation to many objects, or intensiveness; (S;) and AjtrR↓, inf. n. AijotiraArN; (S, L, K;) and AijdrR↓, inf. n. AijodiraArN; (L, K;) in which the t is changed into d, though you do not say AijodaraOa for AijotaraOa, nor AijodaraHa for AijotaraHa; (L;) and AstjrR↓; (K;) He dragged, drew, pulled, tugged, strained, extended by drawing or pulling or tugging, or stretched, (A, L, Msb, K,) a thing, (A,) or a rope, (S, Msb,) and the like. (Msb.) You say, jarRuwA OacoyaAlahumo They dragged along their hinder skirts. (A.) And AlrRumoHa AjArR↓ He dragged, or drew along, the spear. (TA.) And AlHadiyva mino OabaAEidi OaToraAfihi fulaAnN yasotajirRu↓ (assumed tropical:) [Such a one draws forth talk, or discourse, or news, or the like, from its most remote sources]. (A in art. bEd.) And maA AlRaciI jarRaka UilaI hecaA AlOamori (assumed tropical:) [What drew thee, led thee, induced thee, or caused thee, to do this thing]. (TA in art. dEw.) ― -b2- Also jarRa, aor.
jarura
, (TA,) inf. n. jarRN, (K,) (tropical:) He drove (camels and sheep or goats, TA) gently, (K, TA,) letting them pasture as they went along. (TA.) And jarRa AlUibila EalaI OafowaAhihaA (tropical:) He drove the camels gently, they eating the while. (A.) ― -b3- [Hence,] halumRa jarRFA↓ (tropical:) At thine ease. (TA.) ElMundhiree explains halhmRa jurRuwA as meaning (tropical:) Come ye at your ease; from AljarRu in driving camels and sheep or goats, as rendered above. (TA.) You say also, kaAna caAka EaAma kacaA wahalumRa jarRFA UilaI Alyawomi (S, A, Msb, * TA) (tropical:) That was in such a year, and has continued to this day: (Msb, TA:) from AljarRu meaning the act of “ dragging, ” &c.: (TA:) or from Oajorarotuhu AldRayona, or from Oajorarotuhu AlrRumoHa. (Msb.) jrRA is here in the accus. case as an inf. n., or as a denotative of state: but it is disputed whether this expression be classical or postclassical. (TA.) [See also art. hlm] ― -b4- jarRa AlOavara, said of a numerous army, means (assumed tropical:) [It made a continuous track, so that] it left no distinct footprints, or intervening [untrodden] spaces. (TA.) ― -b5- jarRati Alxayolu AlOaroDa bisanaAbikihaA (tropical:) The horses furrowed the ground with their hoofs. (As, A, TA.) ― -b6- jarRa jariyrapF, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
jarura
and
jarara
, (K,) but the latter form is disallowed by MF as not authorised by usage nor by analogy, (TA,) inf. n. jarRN, (K,) He committed a crime, or an offence for which he should be punished, or an injurious action, (S, Msb, K, *) against (EaliI [and UilaI, as in the K voce janaI,]) another or others, (S, K,) or himself; (A, K;) [as though he drew it upon the object thereof;] syn. janaI jinaAyapF. (S, TA.) It is said in a trad., baAyaEahu EalaI Oano laA yajurRa Ealayohi UilRaA nafosahu [He promised, or swore, allegiance to him on the condition that he should not inflict an injury, meaning a punishment, upon him but for an offence committed by himself;] i. e., that he should not be punished for the crime of another, of his children or parent or family. (TA.) ― -b7- jarRa AlfaSiyla: see 4, in two places. ― -b8- [jarRa AlHarofa fiI AlUiEoraAbi, aor.
jarura
, inf. n. jarRN, (assumed tropical:) He made the final letter to have kesreh, in inflection; i. q. xafaDa, q. v.:] AljarRu is used in the conventional language of the Basrees; and AlxafoDu, in that of the Koofees. (Kull p. 145.) ＝ -A2- jarRN, (S, A,) inf. n. jaruwrN, (K,) (tropical:) She exceeded the [usual] time of pregnancy. (A.) (tropical:) She (a camel) arrived at the time [of the year] in which she had been covered, and then went beyond it some days without bringing forth: (S, TA:) or withheld her fœtus in her womb after the completion of the year, a month, or two months, or forty days only: (K, * TA:) Th says that she sometimes withholds her fœtus [beyond the usual time] a month. (TA. [See also jarRato.]) (tropical:) She (a mare) exceeded eleven months and did not foal: (K, TA:) the more she exceeds the usual term, the stronger is her foal; and the longest time of excess after eleven months is fifteen nights: accord. to AO, the time of a mare's gestation, after she has ceased to be covered, to the time of her foaling, is eleven months; and if she exceed that time at all, they say of her, AllRayolapu. (TA.) (tropical:) She (a woman) went beyond nine months without bringing forth, (K, TA,) exceeding that term by four days, or three. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) It (the night, kbd,) was, or became, long. (L in art. kbd.) ― -b3- jarRa, aor.
jarura
, (TA,) inf. n. jarRN; (K;) and AnjrR↓; (K;) (assumed tropical:) He (a camel) pastured as he went along: (IAar. K: [if so, the aor. is contr. to analogy:]) or he rode a she-camel and let her pasture [while going along]. (Kudot;.) ― -b4- jarRa AlnRawoCu biAlmakaAni (assumed tropical:) The nwC [or auroral setting or rising of a star or asterism supposed to occasion rain] caused lasting rain in the place. (TA.)

2 jarRaRa
2: see 1, first sentence.

3 jArahu jAr jArh jArp
3. jArahu, (S, K,) inf. n. mujaArarapN, (TA,) or mujaArRapN, (TK,) He delayed, or deferred, with him, or put him off, by promising him payment time after time; syn. TaAwalahu, (S,) or maA Tilahu: (K:) or he put off giving him his due, and drew him from his place to another: (TA:) or i. q. jaAnaAhu, (so in copies of the K,) meaning, he committed a crime against him: (TK:) or HaAbaAhu. (TA, as from the K. [But this seems to be a mistranscription.]) It is said in a trad., laA tujaArR OaxaAka walaA tuXaArRihi, i. e. Delay not, or defer not, with thy brother, &c.: [and do not act towards him in an evil, or inimical, manner; or do not evil to him, obliging him to do the like in return; or do not contend, or dispute, with him:] or bring not an injury upon him: but accord. to one reading, it is
laA tujaArihi, without teshdeed, from AljaroIu, and meaning, contend not with him for superiority. (TA.)

4 AjrRhu OjAr Ojr OjrI Ojrh Ojrp Ajrh Ajrp jAr jr jrI Mjr Mjrh
4. AjrRhu He pierced him with the spear and left it in him so that he dragged it along: (S, K:) or so AjrRhu AlrRumoHa: (A, Msb:) as though [meaning] he made him to drag along the spear. (TA.) ― -b2- He put the jariyr, i. e. the rope, upon his neck. (Har p. 308.) ― -b3- AjrRhu jariyrahu [lit. He made him to drag along his rope; meaning,] (tropical:) he left him to pasture by himself, where he pleased: a prov. (L.) And AjrRhu rasanahu [lit. He made him to drag along his halter; meaning,] (tropical:) he left him to do as he would: (S, K, TA:) he left him to his affair. (A, TA.) ― -b4- AjrRhu AldRayona (tropical:) He deferred for him the payment of the debt: (S, A, K:) he left the debt to remain owed by him. (Msb.) ― -b5- AjrRhu OagaAniIRa (tropical:) He sang songs to him consecutively, successively, or uninterruptedly; syn. taAbaEahaA: (S, K, TA:) or (tropical:) he sang to him a song and then followed it up with consecutive songs. (A, TA.) ― -b6- AjrR lisaAna AlfaSiyli, (S,) or AjrR AlfaSiyla, (As, K, *) inf. n. UijoraArN; (K;) and AlfaSiyla jarRa↓, (As K, *) inf. n. jarRN; (K;) (tropical:) He slit the tongue of the young weaned camel, that it might not suck the teat: (S, K, TA:) or UijoraAru AlfaSiyli signifies (tropical:) the slitting the tongue of the young weaned camel, and tying upon it a piece of stick, that it may not suck the teat; because it drags along the piece of stick with its tongue: or AlUijoraAru is like AltRafoliyku, signifying (assumed tropical:) a pastor's making, of coarse hair, a thing like the whirl, or hemispherical head, of a spindle, and then boring the tongue of the [young] camel, and inserting it therein, that it may not suck the teat: so say some: (ISk, TA:) the animal upon which the operation has been performed is said to be majoruwrN↓ and mujarRN↓. (TA.) [But sometimes jarRa↓ signifies merely He drew away a young camel from its mother: see xaliyRapN voce xaliIRN, in three places.] ― -b7- Hence, AjrR lisaAnahu (tropical:) He prevented him from speaking. (A.) 'Amr Ibn-MaadeeKerib Ez-Zubeydee says,
falawo OanRa qawomiI OanoTaqatoniI rimaAHuhumo
naTaqotu walekinRa AlrRimaAHa OjarRati
[And if the spears of my people had made me to speak, I had spoken; but the spears have prevented speech]: i. e., had they fought, and shown their valour, I had mentioned that, and gloried in it, (S,) or in them; (TA;) but their spears have prevented my tongue from speaking, by their flight. (S, * TA.) ＝ -A2- AjrR as an intrans. verb: see 8. ― -b2- AjrRt AlbiYoru (tropical:) The well was, or became, such as is termed jaruwr. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.)

7 AnjrR 8
7. AnjrR It (a thing, S) was, or became, dragged, drawn, pulled, tugged, strained, extended by drawing or pulling or tugging, or stretched; it dragged, or trailed along; syn. Ainojacaba. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also 1, last sentence but one.

8 AHtrR c and AjdrR
8. AHtrR AjdrR: see 1, in three places. ＝ -A2- AjtrR said of a camel, (S, Msb, K,) and any other animal having a kariX, (S, TA,) [i. e.] any clovenhoofed animal, (Msb,) He ejected the cud from his stomach and ate it again; ruminated; chewed the cud; (S, * Msb, * K * TA;) as also AjrR↓. (Lh, K.)

10 Uisotajorara
10: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- Aisotajorarotu lahu (tropical:) I made him to have authority and power over me, (K, TA,) and submitted myself, or became submissive or tractable, to him; (A, K, TA;) as though I became to him one that was dragged, or drawn along. (TA.) ― -b2- AstjrR Eani AlrRaDaAEi (assumed tropical:) He (a young camel) refrained from sucking in consequence of a purulent pustule, or an ulcer, in his mouth or some other part. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 jarojara Onjr Anjr njr Qnjr
R. Q. 1. jarojara, (S, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. jarojarapN, (S, * K, * TA,) He (a stallion-camel) reiterated his voice, or cry, (S, * Mgh, Msb, K, *) or his braying, (TA,) in his windpipe. (S, * Mgh, Msb, K. *) ― -b2- He, or it, made, or uttered, a noise, sound, cry, or cries; he cried out; vociferated; raised a cry, or clamour. (TA.) It (beverage, or wine,) sounded, or made a sound or sounds, (K, TA,) in the fauces. (TA.) And jarojarati AlnRaAru (assumed tropical:) The fire sounded, or made a sound or sounds. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- Also, (A, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He poured water down his throat; as also tajarojara↓: (K:) or he swallowed it in consecutive gulps, so that it sounded, or made a sound or sounds; (A, Msb, TA;) as also ↓the latter verb. (K, * TA.) It is said in a trad., (of him who drinks from a vessel of gold or silver, Mgh, TA,) yujarojiru fiI baTonihi naAra jahanRama He shall drink down into his belly the fire of Hell (Az, A, Mgh, Msb) in consecutive gulps, so that it shall make a sound or sounds: (A:) or he shall make the fire of Hell to gurgle reiteratedly in his belly; from jarojara said of a stallion-camel. (Mgh.) Most read AlnAra, as above; but accord. to one reading, it is AlnAru, (Z, Msb,) and the meaning is, (tropical:) The fire of Hell shall produce sounds in his belly like those which a camel makes in his windpipe: the verb is here tropically used; and is masc., with I, because of the separation between it and AlnAr: (Z, TA:) but this reading and explanation are not right. (Mgh.) ― -b2- You say also, jarojarahu AlmaMCa He poured water down his throat so that it made a sound or sounds. (K, * TA.)

R. Q. 2
R. Q. 2: see R. Q. 1, in two places.

laA jara lA jr
laA jara and laA caA jara, for laA jarama and laA caA jarama: see art. jrm.

jarRN jr
jarRN (tropical:) The foot, bottom, base, or lowest part, of a mountain; (S, A, K;) like cayolN: (A, TA:) or the place where it rises from the plain to the rugged part: (IDrd, TA:) or AljRrRu OaSolu Aljabali is a mistranscription of Fr, and is correctly AljuraASilu Aljabalu [i. e. jurASilN signifies “a mountain”]: (K:) but juraASilN is not mentioned [elsewhere] in the K, nor by any one of the writers on strange words; and [SM says,] there is evidently no mistranscription: jarRu Aljabali occurs in a trad., meaning the foot, &c., of the mountain: and its pl. is jiraArN. (TA.) ― -b2- halomRa jarRFA: see 1. ＝ -A2- See also jarRapN. ＝ -A3- laA jarRa i. q. laA jarama: see art. jrm. (TA.)

jarRapN jr jrh jrp
jarRapN [A jar;] a well-known vessel; (Msb;) an earthen vessel; a vessel made of potters' clay: (T, IDrd, * S, * K: *) or anything made of clay: (Mgh:) dim. jurayorapN: (TA:) pl. jiraArN (T, S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jarRaAtN (Msb) and jarRN↓, (T, S, Msb, K,) [or this last is rather a coll. gen. n., signifying pottery, or jars, &c.,] like tamorN in relation to tamorapN; or, accord. to some, this is a dial. var. of jarRapN. (Msb.) Beverage of the kind called nabiyc made in such a vessel is forbidden in a trad.: (Mgh, TA:) but accord. to IAth, the trad. means a vessel of this kind glazed within, because the beverage acquires strength, and ferments, more quickly in a glazed earthen vessel. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jirRapN: ＝ -A3- and see what here next follows.

jurRapN jr jrh jrp
jurRapN (S, K) and jarRapN↓ (K) A small piece of wood, (K,) or a piece of wood about a cubit long, (S,) having a snare at the head, (S, K,) and a cord at the middle, (S,) with which gazelles are caught: (S, K:) when the gazelle is caught in it, he strives with it awhile, and struggles in it, and labours at it, to escape; and when it has overcome him, and he is wearied by it, he becomes still, and remains in it; and this is what is termed [in a prov. mentioned below] his becoming at peace with it: (S, * TA:) or it is a staff, or stick, tied to a snare, which is hidden in the earth, for catching the gazelle; having cords of sinew; when his fore leg enters the snare, the cords of sinew become tied in knots upon that leg; and when he leaps to escape, and stretches out his fore leg, he strikes with that staff, or stick, his other fore leg and his hind leg, and breaks them. (AHeyth, TA.) naAwaSa AljurRapa vumRa saAlamahaA He struggled with the jrRp and then became at peace with it [see above] is a prov. applied to him who opposes the counsel, or opinion, of a people, and then is obliged to agree: (S, * TA:) or to him who falls into a case, and struggles in it, and then becomes still. (TA.) And it is said in another prov., huwa kaAlbaAHivi Eani AljurRapi [He is like him who searches in the earth for the]. (AHeyth, TA.) In the phrase UicaA Oafolatato mino jurRatayohaA , in a saying of Ibn-Lisán-el-Hummarah, referring to sheep, [app. meaning When they escape from their two states of danger,] by jrRtyhA he means their place of pasture (AlmajarR) in a severe season [when they are liable to perish], and when they are scattered, or dispersed, by night, and [liable to be] attacked, or destroyed, by the beasts of prey: so says ISk: Az says that he calls their mjr two snares, into which they might fall, and perish. (TA.)

jirRapN jr jrh jrp
jirRapN A mode, or manner, of dragging, drawing, pulling, tugging, straining, or stretching. (K.) ＝ -A2- The stomach of the camel, and of a clovenhoofed animal: this is the primary signification: by extension of its meaning, it has the signification next following. (Msb.) ― -b2- The cud which a camel [or cloven-hoofed animal] ejects from its stomach, (Az, S, * IAth, Mgh, Msb, K, *) and eats again, (K,) or chews, or ruminates, (Az, IAth, Msb,) or to chew, or ruminate; (S;) as also
jarRapN↓: (K:) it is said to belong to the same predicament as baEor. (Mgh.) Hence the saying, laA OafoEalu celika maA Qxotalafati AldRirRapu waAljirRapu I will not do that as long as the flow of milk and the cud go [the former] downwards and [the latter] upwards. (S, A. * [See also dirRapN.]) And Aujotulibati AldRirRapu biAljirRapi [The flow of milk was procured by the cud]: alluding to the beasts' becoming full of food, and then lying down and not ceasing to ruminate until the time of milking. (IAar, TA.) And laA yaHonaqu EalaI jirRatihi (assumed tropical:) He will not bear rancour, or malice, against his subjects:: or, as some say, cross he will not conceal a secret: (TA:) and maA yaHonaqu EalaI jirRapK and maA yakoZimu ElI jirRapK (assumed tropical:) he does not speak when affected with rancour, or malice: (TA in art. Hnq:) [or the last has the contr. signification: for] laA yakoZimu EalaI jirRatihi means (tropical:) he will not be silent respecting that which is in his bosom, but will speak of it. (TA in art. kZm.) ― -b3- Also The mouthful with which the camel diverts and occupies himself until the time when his fodder is brought to him. (K.)

jaruwrN jrwr
jaruwrN (tropical:) A female that exceeds the [usual] time of pregnancy. (A.) (tropical:) A she-camel that withholds her fœtus in her womb, after the completion of the year, a month, or two months, or forty days only; (K, * TA;) or, three months after the year: they are the most generous of camels that do so: none do so but those that usually bring forth in the season called AlrRabiyE (AlmaraAbiyE); not those that usually bring forth in the season called AlSRayof (AlmaSaAyiyf): and only those do so that are red [or brown], and such as are of a white hue intermixed with red (AlSRuhob), and such as are ash-coloured: never, or scarcely ever, such as are of a dark gray colour without any admixture of white, because of the thickness of their skins, and the narrowness of their insides, and the hardness of their flesh. (IAar, TA. [See also 1: and see xaSuwfN.]) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) A she-camel that is made to incline to, and to suckle, a young one not her own; her own being about to die, they bound its fore legs to its neck, and put upon it a piece of rag, in order that she might know this piece of rag, which they then put upon another young one; after which they stopped up her nostrils, and did not unclose them until the latter young one had sucked her, and she perceived from it the odour of her milk. (L.) ― -b3- Also, applied to a horse, (S, A, K,) and a camel, (K,) (tropical:) That refuses to be led; refractory: (S, A, K:) of the measure faEuwlN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN; or it may be in the sense of the measure faAEilN: (Az, TA:) or a slow horse, either from fatigue or from shortness of step: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) pl. jururN. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) A woman crippled; or affected by a disease that deprives her of the power of walking: (Sh, K:) because she is dragged upon the ground. (Sh, TA.) ― -b5- biYorN jaruwrN (tropical:) A deep well; (Sh, S, K;) from which the water is drawn by means of the saAniyap [q. v.], (S, A,) and by means of the pulley and the hands; like matuwHN and nazuwEN: (A:) or a well from which the water is drawn [by a man] upon a camel [to the saddle of which one end of the wellrope is attached]; so called because its bucket is drawn upon the edge of the mouth thereof, by reason of its depth. (As, L.)

jariyrN jryr
jariyrN A rope: pl. OajirRapN. (Sh, TA.) A rope for a camel, corresponding to the EicaAr of a horse, (S, K,) different from the zimaAm. (S.) Also The nose-rein of a camel; syn. zimaAmN: (K:) or a cord of leather, that is put upon the neck of a she-camel: (Msb:) or a cord of leather, like a zmAm: and applied also to one of other kinds of plaited cords: or, accord. to El-Hawázinee, [a string] of softened leather, folded over the nose of an excellent camel or a horse. (TA.) [See also xiTaAmN.]

jiraArapN jrAr jrArh jrArp jrp
jiraArapN The art of pottery: the art of making jars, or earthen vessels. (TA. [See jarRapN.])

jariyrapN jryrh jryrp
jariyrapN A crime; a sin; an offence which a man commits, and for which he should be punished; an injurious action: (S, * Msb, * K, * TA:) syn. canobN, (Msb, K,) and jinaAyapN: (S:) of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN: (Msb:) pl. jaraAYiru. (A.) See also what next follows.

faEalotu kacaA mino jarRaAka c
faEalotu kacaA mino jarRaAka, (S, A, * K, *) and mn jarRaAYika, (K,) and mn jaraAk, and mn jaraAYika, (S, K,) and mn jariyratika↓, (K,) means mn Oajolika, (S, A, K,) i. e., [originally, I did so] in consequence of thy committing it, namely, a crime: and then, by extension of its application, [because of thee, or of thine act &c.; on thine account; for thy sake;] indicating any causation. (Bd in v. 35, in explanation of mn jarRaAka and mn Oajolika.) One should not say mijoraAka, (S,) or bijoraAka. (A.)

jirRiIRN jr jrI jry
jirRiIRN (written in the Towsheeh with fet-h to the j also, TA,) [The eel;] a kind of fish, (S, K,) long and smooth, (K,) resembling the serpent, and called in Persian maAro maAhiI; said to be a dial. var. of jirRiyvN; (TA;) not eaten by the Jews, (K,) and forbidden to be eaten by 'Alee; (TA;) having no scales: (K:) or any fish having no scales. (Towsheeh, TA.)

jirRiyRapN jry jryh jryp
jirRiyRapN The stomach, or triple stomach, or the crop, or craw, of a bird; syn. HawoSalapN; (S, K;) as also jirRiyoYapN [q. v.] (K) and qirRiyRapN. (AZ, TA.) You say, OloqaAhu fiI jirRiyRatihi, meaning, (tropical:) He ate it. (A, TA.) See also art. jrI.

jarRaArN jrAr jrp
jarRaArN A man who leads a thousand. (T, end of art. Hfz.) ― -b2- jayoXN jarRaArN, (S, A,) and katiybapN jarRaArapN, (S, K,) (tropical:) An army, and a troop of horse or the like, that marches heavily, by reason of its numbers: (As, S, K:) or dragging along the apparatus of war: (A:) or numerous. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A potter; a maker of jars, or earthen vessels. (TA. [See jarRapN.])

jarRaArapN jrAr jrArh jrArp jrp
jarRaArapN A small, (S, A, K, TA,) yellow, (A, TA,) female (TA) scorpion, (S, A, K, TA,) like a piece of straw, (TA, [thus I render ElI Xkl Altbnp, but I think that there must be here some mistranscription, as the words seem to be descriptive of form,]) that drags its tail; (S, K;) for which reason it is thus called; one of the most deadly of scorpions to him whom it stings: (TA:) pl. jarRaAraAtN. (A, TA.)

jarRaAnu jrAn
jarRaAnu: see jaArRN, last sentence.

jarojarN jrjr
jarojarN The thing [or machine] of iron with which the reaped corn collected together is thrashed. (K.) [See naworajN and midowasN.] ＝ -A2- See also jirojirN.

jirojirN jrjr
jirojirN: see jarojaArN. ＝ -A2- Also The bean; or beans; syn. fuwlN; (S, K;) and so jarojarN: (K:) of the dial. of the people of El-'Irák. (TA.) ― -b2- See also jirojiyrN.

jarojarpN jrjr jrjrh jrjrp
jarojarpN, an onomatopœia: (Msb:) A sound which a camel reiterates in his windpipe: (S, K:) the sound made by a camel when disquieted, or vexed: (TA:) the sound of pouring water into the throat: (TA:) or the sound of the descent of water into the belly: (IAth, TA:) or the sound of water in the throat when drunk in consecutive gulps. (Msb.) [See R. Q. 1.]

jarojaArN jrjAr
jarojaArN A camel that reiterates sounds in his windpipe: (S:) or a camel that makes much noise [or braying]; as also jirojirN↓ and juraAjirN↓. (K.) ― -b2- The sound of thunder. (K.) ＝ -A2- A certain plant, (S, K,) of sweet odour; (S;) a certain herb having a yellow flower. (AHn, TA.)

jurojuwrN jrjwr
jurojuwrN A large, or bulky, camel: (K:) pl. jaraAjiru, (Kr, K,) without I [before the final letter], though by rule it should be with I, except in a case of poetic necessity. (TA.) And, as a pl., Large, or bulky, camels; as also [its pl.] jaraAjiru: (S:) or large-bellied camels: (TA:) and generous, or excellent, camels: (K, TA:) and a herd, or collected number, (K, TA,) of camels: (TA:) and maAYapN jurojuwrN a complete hundred (K, TA) of camels. (TA.)

jirojiyrN jrjyr
jirojiyrN (S, K) and jirojirN↓ (K) [The herb eruca, or rocket;] a certain leguminous plant, (S, K,) well known: (K;) a plant of which there are two kinds; namely, barRaIR [i. e. eruca sylvestris, or wild rocket], and busotaAniIR [i. e. eruca sativa, or garden-rocket]; whereof the latter is the better: its water, or juice, removes scars, and causes milk to flow, and digests food: (TA:) AHn says that the jirojiyr is the baAqilRaI [q. v.]; and that the jirjiyr miSoriIR is the turomus: [but see this last word.] (TA in art. trms.)

jarojaArapN jrjArh jrjArp
jarojaArapN A mill, or mill-stone; syn. raHFI: (K:) because of its sound. (TA.)

juraAjirN jrAjr
juraAjirN: see jarojaArN. ― -b2- Also That drinks much; (K; [in the CK misplaced;]) applied to a camel: you say UibilN juraAjirapN. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- And hence, (TA,) Water that makes a noise. (K.)

jaArRN jAr jAry
jaArRN [act. part. n. of 1; Dragging, drawing, &c.]. ― -b2- jaArRu AlDRabuEi (tropical:) Rain that draws the hyena from its hole by its violence: or the most violent rain; as though it left nothing without dragging it along: (TA:) or rain that leaves nothing without making it to flow, and dragging it along:
(IAar, TA:) or the torrent that draws forth the hyena from its hole: (A:) and in like manner, AlDRabuEi majarRu↓ the torrent that has torn up the ground; as though the hyena were dragged along in it. (IAar, Sh, TA.) You say also maTarN jaArRu AlDRabuEi, and maTorapN jaArRapu AlDRabuEi. (A.) ― -b3- UibilN jaArRapN (tropical:) Working camels; because they drag along burdens; (A, Mgh;) or tropically so called because they are dragged along by their nose-reins: (Mgh:) or camels that are dragged along by their nosereins: (S, K, TA: [but in the copies of the S, and in those of the K, in my possession, tajurRu is put for tujarRu, though the latter is evidently meant, as is shown by what here follows:]) jArRp is of the measure faAEilapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN: it is like as when you say EiyXapN raADayapN in the sense of maroDiyRapN, and maMCN daAfiqN in the sense of madofuwqN: (S:) or it means such as carry goods, or furniture and utensils, and wheat, or food. (AZ, TA voce HaAnRN, q. v.) It is said in a trad. that there is no poor-rate (Sadaqap) in the case of such camels, (S, Mgh,) because they are the ridingcamels of the people; for the poor-rate is in the case of pasturing camels, exclusively of the working. (S.) ― -b4- laA jaArRa liI fiI hecaA (tropical:) There is no profit for me in this to attract me to it. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- HaArRN jaArRN is an expression in which the latter word is an imitative sequent to the former; (S, K;) but accord. to A 'Obeyd, it was more common to say HaArRN yaArRN, with I: (S:) and one says also HarRaAnu yarRaAnu jarRaAnu↓. (TA in art. Hr.)

jiwarRN jwr jwrp
jiwarRN is mentioned by Az in this art., meaning Rain that draws along everything: and rain that occasions the herbage to grow tall: and a large and heavy [bucket of the kind called] garob; explained in this sense by AO: and a bulky camel; and, with p, in like manner applied to a ewe: Fr says that the w in this word may be considered as augmentative or as radical. (TA.) [See also art. w.]

jaArRapN jAr jArh jArp
jaArRapN [fem. of jaArRN, q. v.: and, as a subst.,] A road to water. (K.)

jaAruwrN jArwr
jaAruwrN A river, or rivulet, of which the bed is formed but a torrent. (S, * K, * TA.)

AlOajarRaAni c
AlOajarRaAni The jinn, or genii, and mankind. (IAar, K.)

majarRN mjr
majarRN [The place, or track, along which a thing is, or has been, dragged, or drawn]. You say, raOayotu majarRa cayolihi [I saw the track along which his hinder skirt had been dragged]. (A.) See also AlmajarRapu: and jaArRN. ― -b2- A place of pasture. (TA.) ― -b3- The jaAYiz [or beam] upon which are placed the extremities of the EawaAriD [or rafters]. (K)

mujarRN mjr
mujarRN: see 4, in the latter portion of the paragraph.

AlmajarRapu Almjrh Almjrp
AlmajarRapu (tropical:) [The Milky Way in the sky;] the Xaraj of the sky; (K;) the whiteness that lies across in the sky, by the two sides of which are the nasoraAni [or two constellations called AlnRasoru AlTRaAYiru and AlnRasoru AlwaAqiEu]: or [the tract called] AlTRariyqu AlmaHosuwspu [which is probably the same; or the tract], in the sky, along which (minohaA) the [wandering] stars [or planets] take their ways: (TA:) or the gate of Heaven: (K:) so called because it is like the trace of the majarR [or place along which a thing has been dragged, or drawn]. (S.) Hence the prov., turoTibo hajaro siTiI majaro↓ (tropical:) Reach the middle of the sky, O milky way, (mjr being for mjrRp,) and the palm-trees of Hejer will have ripe dates. (A, * TA.)

majoruwrN mjrwr
majoruwrN [pass. part. n. of 1]: see 4, latter portion.

1 jaruWa c
1. jaruWa, aor.
jaruAa
, inf. n. jaraMCapN (S, Msb, K) and jaraAYiyapN and jaraAyapN, with I [in the place of C], which is extr., (K,) and juroOapN and jurapN, (S, K,) thus sometimes, without C, like as one says maroOapN and juroOapN, (S,) [all mentioned as inf. ns. in the TK, and app. as such in the K, but only the first is explicitly mentioned as an inf. n. in the S and Msb, and AstjrO↓ is said in the Msb to be a simple subst.,] He was, or became, bold, daring, brave, or courageous; (S, Msb, * K, TA;) so as to attempt, or venture upon, a thing without consideration or hesitation: (TA:) [said of a brute and the like, as well as of a man:] and AstjrO↓ is syn. therewith. (IJ, W p. 146.)

2 jarRaOotuhu Ealayohi c
2. jarRaOotuhu Ealayohi, (inf. n. tajoriIoCN, K,) I emboldened him, or encouraged him, against him. (S, Msb, * K, TA.)

5 tajarRaAa
5: see 8.

8 AjtrO Ealayohi c
8. AjtrO Ealayohi, (S, K,) or tjrRO↓, (Msb,) He became emboldened or encouraged, or he emboldened or encouraged himself, against him. (S, Msb, * K, TA.) ― -b2- AjtrO EalaI Alqawoli He ventured upon the saying hastily and unhesitatingly. (Msb.)

10 UisotajoraAa
10: see 1.

juroOapN c
juroOapN Boldness, daringness, bravery, or courage; as also jurapN: (S: see 1:) the quality of venturing upon a saying [&c.] hastily and unhesitatingly. (Msb.)

jariIoCN jrIC jryC jrY
jariIoCN Bold, daring, brave, or courageous: (S, Msb, * K, TA:) pl. OajoraMCN, accord. to a MS. copy of the K; [and so in the CK;] but in the M, OajoriYaMCu, with two hemzehs, on the authority of Lh; and so in some copies of the K; and sometimes juraOLCu, like HulamaMCu, occurring in a trad., as some relate it; but the reading commonly known is HuraOLC, with the unpointed H. (TA.) ― -b2- jariIoCu Almuqodami Bold, daring, brave, or courageous, in venturing [against an adversary, or upon an undertaking]. (S.) ― -b3- AljariIoCu The lion; as also AlmujotariICu↓. (O, K.)

jariyoYapN c
jariyoYapN A chamber (K, TA) constructed of stones, with a stone placed over its entrance, (TA,) for the purpose of entrapping wild beasts: (K, TA:) the piece of flesh-meat for the wild beast is put in the hinder part of the chamber; and when he enters to take the piece of meat, the stone falls upon the entrance, and closes it: (TA:) pl. jaraAYiIu (accord. to some copies of the K,) or jaraAYiICu, (accord. to others,) mentioned by AZ as one of the forms of pl. repudiated by the Arabic grammarians except in some anomalous instances. (TA.)

AljirRiyoYapu c
AljirRiyoYapu The qaAniSap [here app. meaning the stomach, or triple stomach, or the crop, or craw, of a bird], and the Huloquwm [here app. meaning the gullet of a bird]; like AljirRiyRapu; (K;) i. e. the HawoSalap [meaning the stomach, or the crop, of a bird]: it is said in the T, on the authority of AZ, that AlqirRiyRapu and AljirRiyRapu and AlnRawoTapu signify the HawoSalap of a bird. (TA.)

AlmujotariICu AlmjtrIC AlmjtryC AlmjtrY mjtrY
AlmujotariICu: see jariIoCN.

1 jariba Ojrb jrAb jrb
1. jariba, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
jaraba
, (Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. jarabN, (Msb, TA,) He (a camel, S, A, Msb, K, and a man, S, or other animal, Msb,) was, or became, affected with what is termed jarab [i. e. the mange, or scab]. (S, Msb, K.) maA lahu jariba waHariba is a form of imprecation against a man [meaning What aileth him? may he have the scab, and be despoiled of all his wealth, or property: or may he have his camels affected with the mange, or scab, and be despoiled &c.: or may his camels be affected with the mange, or scab, &c.]: it may express a wish that he may be affected with jarab: or jariba may be put for Oajoraba, to assimilate it to Hariba: or it may be for jaribato Uibluhu. (L.) ― -b2- See 4. ― -b3- Also (tropical:) i. q. halakato OaroDuhu [meaning His land had its herbage dried up by drought; or became such as is termed jarobaMC, fem. of Oajorabu, q. v.]. (K.)

2 jrRbhu Ojrb jrAb jrb jrbh jrbp
2. jrRbhu, (A, Msb, K,) inf. n. tajoribapN, (M, A, K,) or tajoriybN, the former, which see also below, being a simple subst., (Msb,) or both, but the former is irreg., are inf. ns., (TA,) He tried, made trial of, made experiment of, tested, proved, assayed, proved by trial or experiment or experience, him, or it: (A, K:) or he tried it, made trial of it, &c., namely, a thing, time after time. (Msb.) [You say also jarRaba, for jarRaba AlOumuwra, meaning He tried affairs: and hence, i. q.] jurRiba fiI AlOumuwr [He became experienced, or expert, in affairs]. (T, TA.) And jarRabatohu AlOumuwru [Affairs, or events, tried him. &c.: and thus, rendered him experienced, or expert]. (S, TA.) And maA jurRibto Ealayohi faEolapN qabiyHapN qaTRu [A foul action was never found to be chargeable upon him]. (S voce nugobapN.)

4 Ajrb Ojrb Ajrb jrb
4. Ajrb He had his camels [or found them to be] affected with what is termed jarab [i. e. the mange, or scab]; (S, A, L, K;) as also jariba↓, (L, K,) which may be for jaribato Uibiluhu; or used for Oajoraba, to assimilate it to Hariba in a saying mentioned above; see 1. (L.)

Q. Q. 1 jaworabahu jwrb jwrbh jwrbp
Q. Q. 1. jaworabahu He put on him [i. e., on his
(another's) foot or feet,] jaworab [i. e. a sock or stocking, or a pair of socks or stockings]. (S, K.)

Q. Q. 2 tajaworaba tjwrb
Q. Q. 2. tajaworaba He put on [i. e., on his own foot or feet,] jaworab [i. e. a sock or stocking, or a pair of socks or stockings]. (S, K.) And in like manner, tjwrb jaworabayoni [He put on a pair of socks or stockings]. (TA.)

jirobN Ojrb jrAb jrb
jirobN: see jirobapN.

jarabN Ojrb jrAb jrb
jarabN [The mange, or scab;] a certain disease, (A,) well known; (S, A, K;) accord. to the medical books, (Msb,) a gross humour, arising beneath the skin, from the mixture of the salt phlegm, (Msb, MF,) or the phlegm of the flesh, (so in a copy of the Msb,) with the blood, accompanied with pustules, and sometimes with emaciation, in consequence of its abundance; (Msb, MF;) or [an eruption consisting of] pustules upon the bodies of men and camels. (M, TA.) You say, OEodaI mina Aljarabi Einoda AlEarabi [More transitive, or catching, than the mange, or scab, among the Arabs]: (A, TA:) a proverb. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Rust upon a sword. (K.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A resemblance of rust upon the inner side of the jafon [or eyelid], (M, K,) sometimes covering the whole of it, and sometimes part of it. (M.) You say, biOajofaAnihi jarabN (tropical:) [In his eyelids is] a resemblance of rust upon their inner sides. (A.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A vice, a fault, a defect, an imperfection, or a blemish. (IAar, K.)

jaribN Ojrb jrAb jrb
jaribN: see Oajorabu.

jirobapN Ojrb jrAb jrb jrbh jrbp
jirobapN A place of seed-produce; (S, K;) as also jariybN↓: (K:) and a tract of land such as is termed qaraAH [i. e. a field, or land, sown or for sowing, without any building or trees in it; or land cleared for sowing and planting; or a separate piece of land in which palm-trees &c. grow; &c.]: (K:) metaphorically applied by Imra-el-Keys to [a grove of] palm-trees, where he says
kajirobapi naxolK Oawo kajanRapi yavoriba
[Like a grove of palm-trees, or like the plantation of Yethrib]: (AHn, TA:) or land prepared for sowing or planting: (AHn, K:) or a piece of land differing in condition from the land adjoining it, [i. e. a patch of land,] producing good plants or herbage: (Lth, TA:) the pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] is jirobN↓, (Lth, AHn,) like as tibonN is of tibonapN, and sidorN of sidorapN: (AHn:) or jirobN signifies a qaraAH; and its pl. is jirabapN. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- A skin, or a mat, which is placed upon the brink of a well, lest the water should be scattered into the well [app. in falling from the bucket into the channel of the tank or cistern &c.]: or (a skin, TA,) that is placed in a rivulet or streamlet jadowal [which is applied in the present day to an artificial streamlet for irrigation, in the form of a trench or gutter,]) that the water may flow down over it [app. from the well to the tank or cistern &c.]. (M, K.)

jaribapu Ojrb jrAb jrb jrbh jrbp
jaribapu: see Oajorabu, last sentence but one.

jarobaAnu Ojrb jrb jrbAn
jarobaAnu or jarobaAnN: see Oajorabu: ＝ -A2- and for the latter, see jurubRaAnN.

jurobaAnN Ojrb jrb jrbAn
jurobaAnN and jirobaAnN: see jurubRaAnN, in five places.

jurubRaMC jrbMC
jurubRaMC and jiribRaMC: see what next follows.

jurubRaAnN Ojrb jrb jrbAn
jurubRaAnN (S, MF, TA) and jiribRaAnN, (Mj, MF, TA,) which are the two forms commonly known, (MF, TA,) or, accord. to the K, jirobaAnN↓ and jurobaAnN↓, or, accord. to the L, jarobaAnN↓, and sometimes jurobaAnN↓, or, accord. to some copies of the K, [and so in the CK,] jiribRaMC↓ and jurubRaMC↓, which are evident mistranscriptions, or, accord. to the 'Ináyeh of El-Khafájee, jaribRaAnN, which is more strange, (MF,) but this last accords [most nearly] with its original, (TA,) [for it is] a Persian word arabicized, (S, TA,) originally GariybaAno; (TA;) The jayob [or opening at the neck and bosom] of a shirt: (K, TA:) or the part around the neck, upon which are sewed the buttons: (IB and TA in art. bnq:) or the [part called] libonap [q. v.] of a shirt. (S, TA.) ― -b2- jurubRaAnu sayofK (Fr, S, K) and jurobaAnuhu↓, (K, TA,) or jirobAnhu↓, (CK,) The edge (HadR) of a sword: (K:) or a thing [i. e. a case] (K, TA) of sewed leather (TA) in which are put a sword and its scabbard with the cords or belts by which it is suspended: (K, TA;) i. q. qiraAbuhu: (S: [see also jiraAbN:]) or a large sword-case in which are a man's sword and his whip and what else he requires: (Fr, TA: [also called julubRaAn and jilibRaAn and julobaAn:]) in the L, the first is [also] said to signify the scabbard of a sword. (TA.)

jirobiyaMCu jrbyMC
jirobiyaMCu [a word of a very rare form, (see kiboriyaMCu,)] The north-west wind; a wind of the kind termed nakobaMCu, that blows in a direction between that of the [north wind, or northerly wind, called] XamaAl and that of the [west wind, or westerly wind, called] dabuwr, and that dispels the clouds: (S, TA:) it is a cold wind, and is sometimes attended by a little rain: (TA in art. nkb, q. v.:) or the [north wind, or northerly wind, called] XmAl: or the cold of that wind: (K, TA:) or, (K,) as also Oazoyabu, (TA,) the south east wind; the wind that blows in a direction between that of the [south wind, or southerly wind, called] januwb and that of the [east wind, or easterly wind, called] SabaA. (K, TA.) ― -b2- Also, with the article Al, a name of The seventh earth: corresponding to AlEirobiyaMCu, a name of “the seventh heaven.” (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A weak man. (K.)

jiraAbN jrAb
jiraAbN, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) not jaraAbN, (ISk, Msb, K,) or this latter is of weak authority, (K, TA,) or peculiar to the vulgar, (S, L,) A provisionbag for travellers: (K, Har p. 174:) or a bag, or receptacle, for travelling-provisions and for goods or utensils &c.,; syn. wiEaMCN: (K, TA:) or such a receptacle made of sheep-skin, in which nothing is kept but what is dry: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] jurubN (S, Msb, K) and jurobN, (S, K,) the latter a contraction of the former, (TA,) and [of pauc.] OajoribapN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A sword-case; or a case, or receptacle, in which a sword is put with its scabbard and its suspensory belt or cord; syn. qiraAbu sayofK. (TA. [See also jurubRaAnN.]) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) The scrotum. (K.) ― -b4- jiraAbu Alqalobi (assumed tropical:) [The pericardium, or heart-purse]. (K in art. vht, &c.) ― -b5- jiraAbu AlbiYori (assumed tropical:) The cavity of the well; (M, K;) or (tropical:) its interior, (Lth, S, M, A,) from top to bottom. (Lth, S, M.) You say, AiTowi jiraAbahaA biAlHijaArapi Case thou its interior with stones. (A.)

jariybN jryb
jariybN A certain measure, (M, A, Mgh, K,) or quantity, of wheat, (S, Msb,) consisting of four Oaqofizap [pl. of qafiyzN]: (M, A, Msb, K:) or ten Aqfzp; each qfyz thereof consisting of ten OaEoXiraMC [pl. of EaXiyrN]; so that the EXyr is the hundredth part of the whole: (TA:) or, as some say, a measure differing in different countries; as is the case of the rTol and mudR and ciraAE &c. (MF, TA.) For the pl., see what follows. ― -b2- Hence, (Mgh,) (assumed tropical:) A certain quantity of land; (S, Mgh, Msb;) as much as is sown with the measure of seed so called; (A, Mgh;) like as mules and the space that they travel are termed bariydN: (A, Mgh: *) it is sixty cubits by sixty cubits; accord. to Kudámeh, the extent termed OaXol multiplied by itself; the AXl being sixty cubits; the cubit being six qabaDaAt; and the qaboDap, four OaSaAbiE: the tenth part of the jryb is called qfyz, and the tenth of the qfyz is called EXyr; so that the qfyz is ten AEXrAC: (Mgh:) it is a distinct portion of land, differing according to the different conventional usages of the people of different provinces: it is said that the width of six moderate-sized barleycorns is called UiSobaEN; the qbDp is four ASAbE; the ciraAE is six qbDAt; ten OacoruE are called qaSabapN; ten qaSabaAt are called AXl; and the jryb is the extent termed AXl multiplied by itself: the AXl multiplied by the qSbp is called qfyz; and the AXl multiplied by the crAE is called EXyr: so the jiryb is ten thousand cubits: or, accord. to Kudámeh the Scribe, it is three thousand and six hundred cubits: (Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] OajoribapN and [of mult.] jurobaAnN (S, Msb, K) and juruwbN. (R, TA.) See also jirobapN. ― -b3- Also A valley; (Lth, Msb, K; [accord. to the second of which, this is the primary signification;]) i. e., in an absolute sense; and, with the article Al, the name of a particular valley in the territory of Keys: (TA:) pl. OajoribapN. (Lth, TA.)

jaworabN jwrb
jaworabN [A sock or stocking, or a pair of socks or stockings;] the wrapper of the foot or leg: (K:) or a pair of woollen envelopes for the feet, used for warmth: (TA:) an arabicized word, (S, Msb,) from the Persian Guwrabo, originally Guwro, i. e. “tomb of the foot:” (TA:) pl. jawaAribapN and jawaAribu; (S, A, Msb, K;) in the former of which, the p is added because it is originally a foreign word. (S, TA.) You say, huwa Oanotanu mino riyHi Aljaworabi [He, or it, is more stinking than the smell of socks, or stockings]. (A, TA.)

jawaAribiIRN jwArbI jwArby jwrb
jawaAribiIRN A maker of jawaArib [i. e. socks or stockings]. (TA.)

Ojorabu c
Ojorabu (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and jaribN↓ (A, Mgh, K) and jarobaAnu↓ or jarobaAnN (K accord. to different copies) [Mangy, or scabby;] affected with what is termed jarab: (S, A, Msb, K:) applied to a camel, (A, Msb,) and to a man: (S, A:) fem. (of the first, Msb) jarobaMCu (A, Msb) and [of the second] jaribapN: (A:) pl. (of the first, S, Msb) jurobN (S, A, Msb, K) and (of the first, S, Mgh, TA, or of the second, Mgh, or of the third agreeably with analogy, TA) jarobaI (S, Mgh, K) and [of the first] OajaAribu, which is like certain pls. of substantives, as OajaAdilu and OanaAmilu, (TA,) and (of the first contrary to rule, like EijaAfN and biTaAHN and EiSaAlN which are pls. of OaEojafu and OaboTaHu and OaEoSalu, Msb, or of the second, IB, K, or of jurobN, which is pl. of the first, S) jiraAbN: (S, IB, Msb, K:) this last occurs in the following verse [of ‘Amr, or’ Omeyr, Ibn-El-Hobáb, or El-Khabbáb; these variations being in different copies of the K; but in the TA art. nXr, and in a copy of the S in that art. and in the present one, ‘Omeyr Ibn-El-Khabbáb]:
wafiynaA waUino qiyla QSoTalaHonaA taDaAgunN
kamaA TarRa OawobaAru AljiraAbi EalaI AlnRaXori
(S, K *) Within us, though it be said that we have made peace, one with another, and we are on good terms outwardly, is mutual rancour: as the soft wool of the mangy camels (while disease lurks beneath, within them, TA) grows by reason of [eating] the nXr [or herbage] that becomes green at the and of summer (in consequence of rain falling upon it, TA) and is injurious to animals that pasture upon it: (K, TA:) and it is said by IB, and in the K, that jrAb, here, is pl. of jaribN, not, as J says, of jurobN: but MF observes that fiEaAlN is the pl. measure of several words of the measure fuEolN, as rumoHN and duhonN, and is even said by IHsh and Ibn-Málik and AHei to be regularly applicable to sings. of this latter measure; whereas no grammarian nor Arabic scholar asserts that a word of the measure faEilN assumes fiEaAlN as the measure of its pl. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] sayofN Oajorabu (tropical:) A sword reddened by much rust, which cannot be removed from it unless with a file. (A.) ― -b3- And OaroDN jarobaMCu (tropical:) Land affected with. drought: (S, A, Msb, K: *) or salt land, affected with drought, and containing nothing. (ISd, TA.) ― -b4- And AljarobaMCu (tropical:) The sky; (S, M, A, K;) so called because of the stars (S, TA) and the milky way, (TA,) as though it were scabbed with stars; (S, IF, ISd;) its stars being likened to the marks of jarab; (A;) like as the sea is called Oajoradu, and like as the sky is also called raqiyE because [as it were] patched with stars: (AAF, ISd:) or that tract of the sky in which the sun and moon revolve: (M, K:) or the lowest heaven: (AHeyth, TA:) and accord. to the M, jrbp [so in the TA, app. jaribapu↓,] is applied as a determinate [proper] name to the sky. (TA.) ― -b5- And jarobaMCu (assumed tropical:) A beautiful girl; (IAar, K;) so called because the women separate themselves from her, seeing that their goodly qualities are rendered foul by comparison with hers. (IAar, TA.)

tajoribapN jrb tjrbh tjrbp
tajoribapN is a subst. from jarRaba: (Msb:) or it is an inf. n. of that verb, (M, A, K,) and is one of the inf. ns. from which pls. are formed: (M, TA:) its pl. is tajaArbu (M, Msb, TA) and tajaAriybu, (M, TA.) En-Nábighah says,
UilaI Alyawomi qado jurRibona kulRa AltRajaAribi
[To this day, they (referring to females) have been tried with every kind of tryings]: and El-Aashà says,
kamo jarRabuwhu famaA zaAdato tajaAribuhumo
OabaA qudaAmapa UilRaA Almajoda waAlqanaEaA
[How often have they tried him, and their tryings of Aboo-Kudámeh have not increased aught save his glory and contentment!]; tjArb being here a pluralized inf. n. made to govern an objective complement; which is a strange fact. (M, TA.) [But in this latter instance, we may consider AbA qdAmp as a first objective complement of rAdt, and XayoYaA, understood before AlRA, as a second objective complement of the same verb.]

mujoribN mjrb
mujoribN A man who has his camels affected with what is termed jarab [i. e. the mange, or scab]: whence the prov., laA UilaAha limujoribK [There is no god to one who has his camels affected with the mange]; as though he renounced his god by frequently swearing falsely by him that he had no pitch when it was demanded of him [for the purpose of curing other camels]: (A:) or laA OaliyRapa limojoribK [There is no oath to one who has his camels affected with the mange; for the reason above mentioned, or because he is likely to deny that he has mangy camels lest his camels should be prevented from coming to water: and hence also,] Oakodabu mino mujoribK [More lying than one who has his camels affected with the mange]; another prov. (Meyd. [See Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 382.])

mujarRabN mjrb
mujarRabN One who has been tried, or proved, in affairs, and whose qualities have become known: (T, TA:) or one who has been tried, or proved, and strengthened by experience in affairs: (S:) [experienced, or expert, in affairs:] or one whose qualities have been tried, or proved. (K, TA.) And mujarRibN↓ One having experience in affairs. (K, TA.) In general, but not always, (MF,) the Arabs used the former of these two epithets [which are virtually synonymous]. (S, MF.) ― -b2- daraAhimu mujarRabapN Weighed money. (Kr, K.) ― -b3- AlmujarRabu The lion. (Sgh, K.) ＝ -A2- [It is also employed as an inf. n. of 2, in accordance with a usage of which there are many other instances; as in the saying,] Oanota EalaI AlmujarRabi [Thou art about to have the proof, or experience]: a prov., mentioned by AZ: said to him who asks respecting a thing which he is about to know of himself: originally said by a woman to a man who asked her an indecent question which he was himself about to resolve. (TA.)

mujarRibN mjrb
mujarRibN: see mujarRabN.

jirRiyvN jryv
jirRiyvN A kind of fish, (S, Mgh, K,) well known, (TA,) also called jirRiIRN and SilRaworN, (Mgh, TA,) resembling a serpent, called in Persian maAro maAhiI [snake-fish, or eel]; forbidden to be eaten by the Jews: whether it be lawful to the Muslims is disputed: (TA:) qirRiyvN is a dial. var. (S in art. qrv.)

Q. 2 tajarovama tjrvm
Q. 2. tajarovama: see 3, in two places. ＝ -A2- tjrvm AlXRaIoCa He took the greater, main, or chief, part of the thing. (K.)

Q. 3 Aijoranovama Ajrnvm
Q. 3. Aijoranovama He, or it, drew himself, or itself, together; contracted; or shrank: (TA, Har p. 297:) from jurovuwmapN signifying the “earth collected around a tree.” (Har ib.) Also, and tjrvm↓, It (a thing, S) collected itself together, or became collected, (S, K,) and kept to a place. (K.) Hence, in a trad., waEaAda lahaA AlnRiqAdu mujoranovimFA↓ And the lambs, by reason of it, namely, the vehement drought, became collected, or drawn, together [in one place, and kept to it]. (TA.) ― -b2- He (a man, TA) fell from a high, or higher, to a low, or lower, place; as also tjrvm↓. (K, TA.)

jurovumapN jrvmh jrvmp
jurovumapN: see what next follows.

jurovuwmapN jrvwm jrvwmh jrvwmp
jurovuwmapN [and accord. to Golius, as on the authority of the S, jurovuwmN, but this I have. not found in any Lexicon but his and that of Freytag,] The root, lowest part, base, stock, or source, syn. OaSolN, of a thing; (S, Mgh, K;) whatever the thing be; (Mgh;) as also jurovumapN↓: (TA:) and the place of collection thereof: (Mgh, TA:) or the earth that is collected at the roots, or lower parts, of trees: (K:) or the earth collected around a tree: (Har p. 297:) or the root of a tree to which the earth is collected: (Lth, TA:) pl. jaraAviymu. (Mgh.) One is related to have said, AlOasodu jurovuwmapu AlEarabi famano OaDalRa nasabahu faliyaOotihimo [ElAsd are those, of the Arabs, to whom most others congregate: therefore whoever loses his genealogy, let him come to them]: meaning AlOazodu. (TA.) And jaraAviymu jahanRama means The greater, main, or chief, degrees of the punishment of Hell. (Mgh.) ― -b2- The base (OaSol) of a sandhill overlooking what surrounds it. (Har p. 99.) And the pl. (jrAvym), Places elevated above the ground, composed of clay and earth collected together. (TA.) ― -b3- The earth collected by ants; (TA;) an ant-hill: (K:) or jurovuwmapu AlnRamoli signifies the ant-hill. (S.) ― -b4- The earth, or dust, that the wind raises, or sweeps up and scatters. (K.) ― -b5- The galoSamap [or epiglottis]. (K.)

mujoranovimN mjrnvm
mujoranovimN: see 3. ― -b2- rakabN mujoranovamN [in the CK, erroneously, rakobN mujoranovamN,] i. q. musotahodifN, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, musotahodafN,]) i. e., A wide, elevated pubes. (TA in art. hdf.)

1 jaraHahu jrH jrHh jrHp
1. jaraHahu, (S, A, K, &c.,) aor.
jaraHa
, (K, Msb, &c.,) inf. n. jaroHN, (S, Msb, &c.,) He wounded him;
produced an effect, or made an impression, upon him with a weapon: (L:) he cut him: (A, MF:) or clave, or rent, some part of his body: (MF:) syn. kalamahu: (K:) and jrRHhu↓, (S, K,) inf. n. tajoriyHN, (TA,) signifies the same (K) in an intensive sense, or as applying to several objects; (S;) or he wounded him much. (L.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or jaraHahu bilisaAnihi, (A, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (Msb,) [lit. He wounded him with his tongue; meaning] (tropical:) he reviled him, or vilified him; (A, K;) he imputed to him a vice, or fault, or the like; or spoke against him. (Msb.) And jaraHuwhu biOanoyaAb waOaDoraAsK [lit. They wounded him with dog-teeth and grinders; meaning] (tropical:) they reviled him, or vilified him, and imputed to him vices or the like. (A.) And hence, (Msb,) jaraHa AlXRiAhida (A, L, Msb, K) [and jrRHhu↓, as in many of the law-books,] said of a judge, (A, L,) or other person, (I.,) (tropical:) He annulled the witness's claim to be legally credible, (L, K,) by happening to discover in him a falsehood &c.; (L;) he evinced in the witness something that caused his testimony to be rejected: (Msb:) he censured the witness, and rejected what he said. (L.) And jaraHa AlrRajula (tropical:) He invalidated the man's testimony. (L.) And jaraHa AlXRahaAdapa (tropical:) [He, or it, invalidated the testimony; or annulled its claim to be legally credible]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Also jaraHa, and AjtrH↓, (tropical:) He gained, acquired, or earned; (S, Mgh, K, TA;) or applied himself with art and diligence to get, obtain, gain, acquire, or earn; (S, K, TA;) a thing: (TA:) he worked, or wrought, with his hand, and gained, acquired, or earned; &c.: (Msb:) from jiraAHapN. (Mgh.) You say, fulaAnN yajoraHu liEiyaAlihi, and yajotariHu↓, (tropical:) Such a one [works, and earns sustenance, or] gains, acquires, or earns, and collects, for his family, or household. (TA) And biYosa maA jaraHato yadaAka, and QjotaraHato↓, (tropical:) Very evil is that which thy hands have done, or wrought, or effected: a metaphor taken from the signification of “cutting,” or “wounding;” (A, TA;) accord. to El-Khafájee, a metaphorical meaning conventionally regarded as proper.
