(TA.) AlsRayRaMti QjotaraHuwA↓, in the Kur [xlv. 20], means (tropical:) Have committed crimes, sins, or evil actions. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jariHa, aor. as above, He (a man, TA) received a wound. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And (tropical:) He had his testimony rejected as not legally entitled to credit: (K, * TA:) and so his relation. (TA.)

2 jarRaHa
2: see 1, in two places.

8 UijotaraHa
8: see 1, in four places.

10 AstjrH AstjrH
10. AstjrH (tropical:) He deserved that his claim to be legally credible should be annulled. (A, TA.) And (tropical:) It (a tradition, or narrative, A, or a thing, Msb) deserved to be rejected [as unworthy of credit or regard]. (A, Msb.) AisotajoraHato hecihi AlOaHaAdiyvu means (tropical:) These traditions deserved to be rejected on account of their great number and the fewness of such as were true: (A:) or, by reason of their great number, obliged those who were acquainted with them to annul the claim of some one or other of their relaters to be credited, and to reject his relation: (L:) or were corrupt: (T, S, * TA:) [for] AisotijoraAHN signifies [also] the being faulty, defective, and corrupt. (S, K.) One says, qado waEaZotukumo falamo tazodaAduwA UilRaA QsotijoraAHFA: (S, A:) these words are from a xuTobap of ‘AbdEl-Melik; and the meaning is, [I have admonished you and ye have not increased save] in corrupt conduct: or in what gaineth for you censure. (TA.)

jaroHN jrH
jaroHN: see the next paragraph.

juroHN jrH
juroHN a subst. from jaraHa; (S, L, K;) A wound; (L;) and so jaroHN↓, in its original acceptation; but some of those skilled in the science of lexicology say that the former is employed to denote the effect produced upon bodies by iron instruments and the like; and the latter, that produced upon objects of the mind by the tongue: (MF:) the pl. of the former is juruwHN and OajoraAHN [which is a pl. of pauc.] (S, L, K) and jiraAHN; (T, A, L;) but the second of these is of rare occurrence, (K,) only used in poetry: (S, L:) [respecting the third, see what follows:] jiraAHapN↓ also signifies the same as juroHN; (Msb;) and its pl. is jiraAHN (S, Msb, K) and jiraAHaAtN (A, Msb) and jaraAYiHu; (A;) or jiraAHN is a coll. gen. n., of which jiraAHapN is the n. un.; or, accord. to Az, this last has not a sing. sense, as Lth asserts it to have, but is a pl. of juroHN, like as HijaArapN is of HajarN, and jimaAlapN of jamalN, and HibaAlapN of HabolN. (L.)

juroHapN jrH jrHh jrHp
juroHapN (tropical:) A thing whereby testimony is invalidated, or its claim to be legally credible annulled: as in the saying, halo laka juroHapN (tropical:) [Hast thou anything to adduce whereby to invalidate the testimony?]. (A, TA.) OaqoSaSotuka AljuroHapa faUino kaAna Einodaka maA tajoraHu bihi AlHujRapa fahalumRahaA, said by the judge of El-Medeeneh to one of the parties in a lawsuit, when about to give judgment against him, means (tropical:) I authorize thee to adduce anything whereby to invalidate the testimony: [therefore, if thou have anything whereby thou mayest invalidate the allegation, adduce it.] (A, * TA.)

jariyHN jryH
jariyHN; pl. jaroHaI; (S, A, Msb, K;) each of which is mase. and fem.; (S, K;) Wounded. (Msb.) The pl. is not formed by the addition of w and n because the fem. is not formed by the addition of p. (TA.)

jiraAHapN jrAH jrAHh jrAHp jrH
jiraAHapN: see juroHN.

jaraAYiHiIRN c
jaraAYiHiIRN: see what next follows.

jarRaAHN jrAH jrH
jarRaAHN A surgeon that dresses wounds. (Golius on the authority of Ibn-Maaroof; and so in the present day; as also jaraAYiHiIRN↓.)

jaAriHapN jArH jArHh jArHp
jaAriHapN sing. of jawaAriHu. (Mgh, L, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- The latter signifies (tropical:) Beasts, and birds, of prey; or that catch game; (S, A, * Mgh, L, Msb, K:) thus the falcon is a jArHp, and so is the dog trained for hunting, because it gains for its owner: (L:) and this appellation is applied alike to the male and the female, like raAHilapN and raAwiyapN. (Msb.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) The members, or limbs, of a man, with which things are gained or earned; (S, K, TA;) or with which one works; (A;) as the hands or arms, and the feet or legs: (S, A, K, TA:) because they gain, or earn, or do, good and evil. (TA.) ― -b4- [And (tropical:) The organs of the body: thus, for instance, jArHp is applied (in the Msb, art. bSr,) to the eye, which is termed (in the TA in that art.) the seeing jArHp (AljaAriHapu AlnRaAZirapu).] ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) Mares: [and the like:] because they bring gain to their owners by their breeding. (AA, T.) You say, maA lahu jaAriHapN (assumed tropical:) He possesses not a female beast that bears young: he possesses not that which makes gain. (TA.) And hecihi AlnRaAqapu mino jawaAriHi AlmaAli, and hch AlOataAnu, (K,) and hch Alfarasu, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) This she-camel, and this she-ass, and this mare, is young, unimpaired by age (muqobilapN [i. q. muqotabalapN]) in the womb, (K, TA,) and in youthful vigour, and one of which the offspring is wished for. (TA.)

1 jarada jrd
1. jarada, aor.
jaruda
, inf. n. jarodN: see 2, in nine places. ― -b2- jarada AljaraAdu AlOaroDa, (A, L, Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (L,) (tropical:) The locusts stripped the land of all its herbage; (A, * L;) ate what was upon the land. (Msb.) ― -b3- jaradahumu AljaAruwdu (tropical:) [The year of drought destroyed them]. (A.) ＝ -A2- juridati AlOaroDu (assumed tropical:) The land had its herbage eaten by locusts; (S;) was smitten by locusts. (Msb.) ― -b2- jurida said of seed-produce, (assumed tropical:) It was smitten [or eaten] by locusts. (K.) ― -b3- And said of a man, (S,) (assumed tropical:) He had a complaint of his belly from having eaten locusts. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- jarida, aor.
jarada
, (K,) inf. n. jaradN, (TA,) (tropical:) It (a place) was, or became, destitute of herbage. (K, TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He (a man) had no hair upon him [i. e. upon his body, or, except in certain parts: see Oajoradu]. (S: but only the inf. n. is there mentioned.) ― -b3- (tropical:) He (a horse, K, TA, or similar beast, TA) had short hair: (TA:) or had short and fine hair: as also Anjrd↓. (K, TA.) [See Oajoradu.] ― -b4- See also 7. ― -b5- Also, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man, S) became affected with the cutaneous eruption termed XarFI, from having eaten locusts. (S, K.)

2 jrRd jrd
2. jrRd, (A, L,) inf. n. tajoriydN, (S, A, L,) He stripped, divested, bared, or denuded, of garments, or clothes. (S, A, L.) You say, jrRdhu mino viyaAbihi, (A,) or mn vawobihi, (Th, L, K,) as also jaradahu↓, (K,) and jrRdhu vawobahu, (Th, L,) He stripped, divested, or denuded, him of his garments, or of his garment: (Th, A, L, K:) [this is the only signification of the verb given in the A as proper; its other significations given in that lexicon being there said to be tropical:] or jarRadotuhu mino viyaAbihi signifies I pulled off from him his garments: and AlXRaIoCa jaradotu↓, aor.
jaruda
, inf. n. jarodN, (assumed tropical:) I removed from the thing that which was upon it. (Msb.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He peeled, or pared, a thing; divested it of its peel, bark, coat, covering, or the like; as also jarada↓, (L, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above: (L:) and ↓the latter, (assumed tropical:) he peeled off anything,
Eano XaIoCK from a thing. (S, L.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He stripped skin of its hair; as also jarada↓. (L, K.) ― -b4- (tropical:) It (drought) rendered the earth, or land, bare of herbage: so in the L and other lexicons: in the K, jarada↓: but the former is the right. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) I. q. XcRb [generally signifying He pruned a tree or plant]. (S, TA.) ― -b6- (tropical:) [He bared a sword;] he drew forth a sword (S, A, K) from its scabbard; (A;) as also jarada↓ (TA, and so in some copies of the K in the place of the former verb,) aor. as above. (TA.) ― -b7- [(assumed tropical:) He detached a company from an army: see jariydapN.] ― -b8- [(assumed tropical:) He divested a thing of every accessory, adjunct, appendage, or adventitious thing; rendered it bare, shere, or mere.] ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) He made the writing, or book, (L, K,) and the copy of the Kur-án, (L,) free from syllabical signs, (L, K,) and from additions and prefaces: (L:) he divested the Kur-án of the diacritical points, and of the vowel-signs of desinential syntax, and the like: (Ibrá- heem [En-Nakha'ee]:) or he wrote it, or read it, or recited it, without connecting with it any of the stories, or traditions, related by the Jews or Christians. (Ibn'Oyeyneh, accord. to the L; or A'Obeyd, accord. to the TA.) ― -b10- jrRd AlquTona, and jaradahu↓, (assumed tropical:) He separated the cotton from its seeds, with a miHolaAj: or separated and loosened it by means of a bow and a kind of wooden mallet, by striking the string of the bow with the mallet: syn. Halajahu. (K.) ― -b11- jrRd AlHajRa, (ISb, K,) and biAlHajRi tjrRd↓, (TA,) which latter alone is mentioned by Z and Ibn-El-Jowzee, (MF,) (assumed tropical:) He performed the rites and ceremonies of the pilgrimage (AlHajR) separately from those of AlEumorap [q. v.]: (ISh, Z, Ibn-El-Jowzee, K:) or the former signifies he made the performance of the pilgrimage to be free from the vitiations of worldly desires and objects. (Har p. 392.) [See also 5.] ― -b12- jurRida liloqiyaAmi bikacaA: see 5. ― -b13- jrRd Alqawoma; (K;) and jaradahumo↓, (L, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (L;) (assumed tropical:) He asked, or begged, of the people, or company of men, and they refused him, or gave him against their will. (L, K.) ＝ -A2- Also, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He wore, or put on, juruwd, i. e., old and wornout garments. (K.)

5 tjrRd jrd tjrd
5. tjrRd He was, or became, stripped, divested, bared, or denuded, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) [and he stripped, divested, bared, or denuded, himself,] mino viyaAbihi of his clothes or garments, (A, * Msb,) or mn vawobihi of his garment; (L, K; *) as also Anjrd↓, (A, L, K,) which latter, accord. to Sb, is not a quasi-pass. verb, (L,) [but it seems that he did not know jarada, in a sense explained above, (see 2, second sentence,) of which it is the quasipass, like as tjrRd is of jrRd.] ― -b2- (tropical:) It (an ear of corn, A, K, and a flower, TA) came forth from its envelope, or calyx. (A, K, TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) It (expressed juice) ceased to boil, or estuate, (K,) [and so became divested of its froth, or foam.] ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) He (a man) was, or became, alone, by himself, apart from others; as though detached from the rest of men. (Har p. 430.) ― -b5- (tropical:) He (a horse) outstripped the other horses in a race; as also Anjrd↓, and Anjrd Eani Alxayoli; like naDaA Alxayola; as though he threw off the others from himself as a man throws off his garment. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) He (an ass) went forward from among the she-asses. (L.) ― -b6- tjrRd liloOamori (tropical:) [He devoted himself to the affair, as though throwing aside all other things; he applied himself exclusively and diligently to it;] he strove or laboured, exerted himself or his power or efforts or endeavours or ability, employed himself vigorously or diligently or with energy, or took pains or extraordinary pains, in the affair, (S, A, K, and Har p. 430,) not diverted therefrom by any other thing. (Har ib.) And tjrRd liloEibaAdapi (tropical:) [He devoted himself TO, applied himself exclusively and diligently to, or strove &c. in, religious service, or worship]. (A.) And liloqiyaAmi bikacaA jurRida↓ (tropical:) [He devoted himself to, applied himself exclusively and diligently to, or strove &c. in, the performance of such a thing]. (A.) And tjrRd fiI AlsRayori, and Anjrd↓, (tropical:) He strove or laboured, exerted himself or his power or efforts or endeavours or ability, in pace, or going; he hastened therein; like XamRara fiI sayorihi. (L, TA.) ― -b7- tjrRd biAlHajRi: see 2. Accord. to Ahmad, as related by Is-hák Ibn-Mansoor, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He affected to be like, or he imitated, the pilgrim of Mekkeh, or the man performing the pilgrimage of Mekkeh. (K, TA.)

7 Anjrd Anjrd
7. Anjrd: see 5, first sentence. [Hence,] Anjrdti AlUibilu mino OawobaArihaA (assumed tropical:) The camels cast, or let fall, their fur, or soft hair. (L.) ― -b2- See also 1. ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) became threadbare, or napless, (S, L, K,) and smooth; (S, L;) as also jarida↓. (L.) ― -b4- Said of a horse in a race: see 5. ― -b5- Anjrd fiI AlsRayori: see 5. ― -b6- Anjrd binaA AlsRayoru, (S, A, L,) in the K, erroneously, Anjrd bihi AlsRayolu, (TA,) (tropical:) The journey, or march, (S, A, L,) became extended, (S, A, L, K,) and of long duration, [with us,] (S, L, K,) without our pausing or waiting for anything. (A.)

8 AjtrAd AjtrAd
8. AjtrAd (assumed tropical:) The attacking one another with [drawn] swords. (KL.) [You say, AjtrdwA (assumed tropical:) They so attacked one another; like as you say, ADTrbwA.]

jarodN jrd
jarodN (tropical:) A garment old and worn out, (L, K, TA,) of which the nap has fallen off: or one between that which is new and that which is old and worn out: pl. juruwdN. (L, TA.) You say burodapN jarodN, (A,) and jarodapN↓ [alone], (S, L, TA,) (tropical:) A [garment of the kind called] brdp worn so that it has become smooth. (S, A, L, TA. *) And [the pl.] juruwdN, (K, TA, in the CK jaruwd,) as a subst., (TA,) (assumed tropical:) Old and worn-out garments. (K.) It is said in a trad. of Aboo-Bekr, layosa EinodanaA mino maAli Almusolimiyna UilRaA jarodu hecihi AlqaTiyfapi, meaning (assumed tropical:) There is not in our possession, of the property of the Muslims, save this threadbare and worn-out qTyfp. (TA.) ＝ -A2- (assumed tropical:) The pudendum, or pudenda; [app. because usually shaven, or depilated;] syn. farojN, (K,) i. e. EaworapN. (TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) The penis. (K.) ＝ -A3- (assumed tropical:) A shield. (K.) ＝ -A4- (assumed tropical:) A remnant of property, or of cattle. (K.) ＝ -A5- See also jariydapN.

jurodN jrd
jurodN: see jariydapN.

jaradN jrd
jaradN (assumed tropical:) A wide, or spacious, tract of land in which is no herbage: (S, A, K:) an inf. n. used as an appellative subst. (A.) ― -b2- rumiIa EalaI jaradihi and Oajoradihi↓ (assumed tropical:) He (a man, TA) was shot, or struck with a missile, on his back. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also what next follows.

jaridN jrd
jaridN, (K,) fem. with p; (S, K;) and Oajoradu↓, (S, A, K,) fem. jarodaMCu; (A, K;) and jaradN↓, (TA, as from the K,) which last is an inf. n. used as an epithet; (TA;) (tropical:) A place (A, K) destitute of herbage: (S, A, K:) you say OaroDN jaridapN (S, K) and jarodaMCu↓ (A, K) and jaradiyRapN↓, (TA,) and faDaMCN Oajoradu↓: of which last the pl. is [jurodN and] OajaAridu. (S.) ― -b2- Also, the first, (assumed tropical:) A man affected with the cutaneous eruption termed XarFI, from having eaten locusts. (TA.)

jarodapN jrd jrdh jrdp
jarodapN: see jarodN. ― -b2- . Also (assumed tropical:) An old worn piece of rag: dim. jurayodapN↓. (TA from a trad.)

jurodapN jrd jrdh jrdp
jurodapN [The denuded, or unclad, part, or parts, of the body]. You say AimoraOapN baDRapu Aljurodapi (A, * K) and AlmujarRadi↓ (A, K) and AlmutajarRadi↓, (T, A, K,) [A woman thin-skinned, or fine-skinned, and plump, in respect of the denuded, or unclad, part, or parts of the body: or] when divested of clothing: (T, A, * K:) the last of these words is here an inf. n.: if you say AlmutajarRidi↓, with kesr, you mean, [in] the [denuded] body: (K:) [and so when you say Aljurodapi, and AlmujarRadi; or this last may be regarded as an inf. n.:] AlmtjrRad is more common than AlmtjrRid. (TA.) [In like manner,] you say, fulaAnN Hasanu Aljurodapi and AlmujarRadi↓ and AlmutajarRad↓; like as you say, Hasanu AlEuroyapi and AlmuEarRaI, which signify the same. (S.) It is said of Mohammad, kaAna Oanowara AlmutajarRadi↓, i. e. He was bright in respect of what was unclad of his body, or person. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Plain, or level, and bare, land. (S.)

AljurodaAnu AljrdAn
AljurodaAnu (S, K) and AlmujarRadu↓ and AlOajoradu↓ (K) (assumed tropical:) The yard of a horse &c.: (S:) or of a solidhoofed animal: or it is of general application: (K:) or originally of a man; and metaphorically of any other animal: (TA:) pl. (of the first, TA) jaraAdiynu. (K.)

jaradiyRapN jrdyh jrdyp
jaradiyRapN: see jaridN.

jaraAdN jrAd
jaraAdN [a coll. gen. n., (tropical:) Locusts; the locust; a kind of insect] well known: (S, Msb, K:) so called from stripping the ground, (A, Msb,) i. e., eating what is upon it: (Msb:) n. un. with jrAd: (S, Msb:) applied alike to the male and the female: (S, Msb, K:) jrAdp is not the masc. of baqarN, but is a [coll.] gen. n.; these two words being like baqarN and baqarapN, andtamorN and tamorapN, and HamaAmN and HamaAmapN, &c.: it is therefore necessary that the masc. should be [in my copies of the S, “should not be,” but this is corrected in the margin of one of those copies,] of the same form as the fem., lest it should be confounded with the pl. [or rather the collective form]: (S:) but some say that jrAd is the masc.; and jrAdp, the fem.; and the saying raOayatu jaraAdFA EalaI jaraAdapK [as meaning I saw a male locust upon a female locust], like raOayotu naEaAmFA EalaI naEaAmapK, is cited: (TA:) it is first called sirowapN; then, dabFI; then, gawogaMCu; then,
xayofaAnN; then, kuitofaAnN; and then, jrAd: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) As says that when the males become yellow and the females become black, they cease to have any name but jrAd. (AHn, TA.) [Hence,] Aibonu AljaraAdi, (T in art. bnI) or Abn AljaraAdapi (TA in that art.,) (assumed tropical:) The egg of the locust. (T and TA ubi suprà.) ― -b2- maA OadoriI OaIRu jaraAdK EaArahu, (S, K,) or OaIRu AljaraAdi, (A, L,) (tropical:) I know not what man, (S, K,) or what thing, (A,) took him, or it, away. (S, A, K.)

jariydN jryd
jariydN [a coll. gen. n.], n. un. jariydapN↓: (S, Msb:) the latter is of the measure faEilaypN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN; (Msb;) signifying (tropical:) A palm-branch stripped of its leaves; (S, A, Msb, K;) as long as it has the leaves on it, it is not called thus, but is called saEafapN: (S:) or a palm-branch in whatever state it be; in the dial. of El-Hijáz: (TA:) or a dry palm-branch: (AAF, K:) or a long fresh palm-branch: (K:) pl. jaraAYidu. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also, jariydapN↓, (assumed tropical:) A tally, by which to keep accounts; because a palm-stick is used for this purpose; notches being cut in it. ― -b3- And hence, HisaAbK jariydapu↓ (assumed tropical:) An accountbook: and AlxaraAji jariydapu↓ (assumed tropical:) The register of the taxes, or of the land-tax.] ＝ -A2- UibilN jariydapN (tropical:) Choice, or excellent, (A, L,) and strong, (L,) camels. (A, L.) ― -b2- See also Oajoradu, in two places.

juraAdapN jrAd jrAdh jrAdp
juraAdapN (assumed tropical:) Anything that is peeled off, or pared, from another thing. (S.)

jariydapN jryd jrydh jrydp
jariydapN n. un. of jariydN as a coll. gen. n.: see the latter in four places. ― -b2- Also fem. of the latter as an epithet. ― -b3- Also (tropical:) A detachment of horsemen; a company of horsemen detached (jurRidato, S, A) from the rest of the force, (S,) or from the main body of the horsemen, (A,) in some direction, or for same object: (S, A:) or a company of horsemen among whom are no footsoldiers, nor any of the baser sort, or of those of whom no account is made: (A:) or horsemen among whom are no foot-soldiers; (K;) as also jurodN↓ [as though pl. of OajoradN], (K, TA,) with damm, (TA,) or jarodN↓. (So in the CK.) [See an ex. under the word bayotN, last sentence.]

jurayodapN jryd jrydh jrydp
jurayodapN dim. of jarodapN, q. v.

jurayodaMCu jrydMC
jurayodaMCu dim. of jarodaMCu [fem. of Oajoradu]: so in the phrase jurayodaMCu Almatoni (assumed tropical:) The middle of the back of the neck, which is free from flesh. (L.)

jarRaAdN jrAd
jarRaAdN (assumed tropical:) One who polishes brazen vessels. (K.)

jaAruwdN jArwd
jaAruwdN (tropical:) An unlucky man; (S, K;) one who strips off prosperity by his ill luck; (A;) or as though he stripped off prosperity by his ill luck. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, and jaAruwdapN↓, (A,) or sanapN jaAruwdN, (S, K,) (tropical:) A year of drought: (A, K:) or a year of severe drought and dryness of the earth; (S;) as though it destroyed men. (TA.)

jaAruwdapN jArwdh jArwdp
jaAruwdapN: see what next precedes.

AljaAruwdiyRapN AljArwdyh AljArwdyp
AljaAruwdiyRapN A sect of the Zeydeeyeh, (of the Shee'ah, TA,) so called in relation to Abu-lJárood Ziyád the son of Aboo-Ziyád: (S, K:) Abu-l-Járood being he who was named by the Imám El-Bákir “Surhoob,” explained by him as a devil inhabiting the sea: they held that Mo- hammad appointed 'Alee and his descendants to the office of Imám, describing them, though not naming them; and that the Companions were guilty of infidelity in not following the example of 'Alee, after the Prophet: also that the appointment to the office of Imám, after El-Hasan and El-Hoseyn, was to be determined by a council of their descendants; and that he among them who proved himself learned and courageous [above others] was Imám. (MF.)

Oajoradu c
Oajoradu (tropical:) A man having no hair upon him; (S, A, L, K;) i. e., upon his body; or except in certain parts, as the line along the middle of the bosom and downwards to the belly, and the arms from the elbows downwards, and the legs from the knees downwards; contr. of OaXoEaru, which signifies “having hair upon the whole of the body:” (IAth, L:) [fem. jarodaMCu: and] pl. jurodN. (A, TA.) The people of Paradise are said (in a trad., TA) to be jurodN murodN (tropical:) [Having no hair upon their bodies, and beardless]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Also applied to a horse, (S, A, K,) and any similar beast, (TA,) meaning (tropical:) Having short hair: (TA:) or having short and fine hair. (S, K.) This is approved, (S,) and is one of the signs of an excellent and a generous origin. (TA.) Pl. as above. (A.) In like manner, Oajoradu AlqawaAYimi means (tropical:) Having short, or short and fine, hair upon the legs. (TA.) ― -b3- Also (tropical:) A check upon which no hair has grown. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) A sandal upon which is no hair. (L from a trad.) ― -b4- Applied also to a place; and the fem., jarodaMCu, to land: see jaridN, in three places. ― -b5- Also (tropical:) Milk free from froth. (A.) And the fem., (assumed tropical:) Wine that is clear, (AHn, K,) free from dregs. (AHn, TA.) And (assumed tropical:) A sky free from clouds. (L.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) Smooth. (Ham p. 413.) ― -b7- (assumed tropical:) A heart free from concealed hatred, and from deceit, dishonesty, or dissimulation. (L.) ― -b8- (tropical:) Complete; (A, K;) free from deficiency; (A, TA;) as also jariydN↓; (S, A, K;) applied to a year (EaAmN), (S, A,) and to a month, (Th, TA,) and to a day: (K:) fem. as above, applied to a year (sanapN). (A.) Accord. to Ks, (S,) you say, maA raOayotuhu muco OajoradaAni and mc jariydaAni↓, meaning (tropical:) [I have not seen him, or it, for, or during,] two days, (S, A, K,) or two months, (S, K,) [or two years,] complete. (A, TA.) ― -b9- (tropical:) A horse wont to outstrip others; (K;) that outstrips others, and becomes separate from them by his swiftness. (IJ, TA.) ― -b10- And the fem., (tropical:) A voracious she-camel. (A.) ＝ -A2- It is also used as a subst.: see jaradN: ― -b2- and see AljurodaAnu. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) The sea. (AAF, M in art. jrb.) ― -b4- And the fem., (assumed tropical:) A smooth rock. (S, TA.)

UijoridRN Ojrd Ajrd jrd
UijoridRN, and sometimes without teshdeed, UijoridN, A certain plant which indicates the places where truffles (kamoOap) are to be found: a certain herb, or leguminous plant, said to have grains like pepper. (En-Nadr, TA.)

mujoradN mjrd
mujoradN (assumed tropical:) A man ejected from his property. (IAar, TA.)

mujarRadN mjrd
mujarRadN: see jurodapN, in two places. ― -b2- (tropical:) A bare, or naked, [or drawn,] sword. (A.) ― -b3- [ (assumed tropical:) Divested of every accessory, adjunct, appendage, or adventitious thing; rendered bare, shere, or mere; abstract. ― -b4- In philosophy, Bodiless; incorporeal; as though divested of body.] ＝ -A2- See also AljurodaAnu.

majoruwdN mjrwd
majoruwdN (assumed tropical:) Peeled, or pared; divested of its peel, bark, coat, covering, or the like. (S, L.) ― -b2- OaroDN majoruwdapN (assumed tropical:) Land of which the herbage has been eaten by locusts: (S:) or land smitten by locusts: (Msb:) or land abounding with locusts; (A'Obeyd, ISd, K;) a phrase similar to OaroDN mawoHuwXapN; the epithet having the form of a pass. part. n. without a verb unless it be one that is imaginary. (ISd, TA.) ― -b3- rajulN majoruwdN (assumed tropical:) A man having a complaint of his belly from having eaten locusts. (S.)

mutajarRadN mtjrd
mutajarRadN and mutajarRidN: see jurodapN, in four places: ― -b2- and see what follows.

munojaridN mnjrd
munojaridN (assumed tropical:) A horse having short, and little, hair: (EM pp. 39 and 40:) or sharp, or vigorous, in pace, [and] having little hair. (Har p. 455.) ― -b2- maA Oanota bimonojaridi AlsRiloki, (AZ, A, TA,) or bimotajRrRidi↓ AlsRiloki, (so in a copy of the A,) said to one who is shy, or bashful, [meaning (assumed tropical:) Thou art] not free from shyness in appearing [before others]: (AZ, TA:) or (tropical:) thou art not celebrated, or well-known. (A, TA.)

Q. 1 jarodaba jrdb
Q. 1. jarodaba [from jarodabaAnu] He put his hand upon the food (K, TA) that was before him on the table, (TA,) in order that no other person might take it: (K, TA:) or he ate with his right hand, and prevented [others from eating] with his left hand: (IAar, K:) also, (K,) or jrdb EalaI AlTRaEaAmi, (TA,) he ate greedily, gluttonously, or voraciously: (K, TA:) or jrdb fiI AlTRaEaAmi he put his left hand upon food that was before him on the table, in order that no other person might take it; as also jarodama: (Yaakoob, S:) or jrdb maA fiI AlUinaMCi he ate, and made an end of, devoured, or consumed, what was in the vessel; as also jrdm [q. v.]. (Sh, TA.)

jarodabiIRN jrdbI jrdby
jarodabiIRN: see what next follows, in two places.

jarodabaAnN jrdbAn
jarodabaAnN, an arabicized word, (S, K,) from the Persian, (S,) originally Girodaho baAno “guardian of the cake of bread,” (S, K,) and jurodubaAnN and jarodabiIRN↓ and mujarodibN↓, (K,) One who puts his hand, (K,) or who puts his left hand, (S,) upon food, (K,) or upon a thing that is before him on the table, (S,) in order that no other person may take it: (S, K:) or who eats with his right hand, and prevents [others from eating] with his left hand: and one who eats greedily, gluttonously, or voraciously: or the first and ↓third signify, (K, TA,) or signify also, (tropical:) a spunger; (K, TA;) because of his greediness, gluttony, or voraciousness, and his boldness. (TA.) A poet says, (namely, ElGhanawee, TA voce jarodabiylN,)
UicaA maA kunota fiI qawomK XahaAwaI
falaA tajoEalo XimaAlaka jarodabaAnaA
[When thou art among a greedy company of men, put not thy left hand upon the food as a jrdbAn]: (Fr, S:) or the last word is jarodabiylaA, meaning, (accord. to Sh, as also jarodabaAn, TA voce jrdbyl,) one that takes a fragment [of food] with his left hand, and eats with his right hand, and, when what the party have is consumed, eats what is in his left hand. (TA.)

mujarodibN mjrdb
mujarodibN: see jarodabaAnN.

jarodabiylN jrdbyl
jarodabiylN: i. q. jarodabaAnN, explained in art. jrdb.

jarodaqN jrdq
jarodaqN and jarocaqN, (T, JK, TA,) or jarodaqapN (S, K) and jarocaqapN, (IAar, K,) the last asserted by IAar to have been heard by him from a man of chaste speech, (TA,) A cake of bread: (JK, S, K:) arabicized words, (T, JK, S, K,) from Girodaho, (K, TA,) which is Persian, meaning “ round: ” (TA:) pl. jaraAdiqu and jaraAciqu. (JK.)

Q. 1 jarodamapN jrdmh jrdmp
Q. 1. jarodamapN, [inf. n. of jarodama,] (S, K,) in relation to food, (S,) i. q. jarodabapN; (S, K;) i. e., The covering the food that is before one with the left hand, [while eating with the right hand,] in order that no other person may take it: accord. to Yaakoob, the m is a substitute for the b. (TA.) And jarodama signifies He ate, made an end of, devoured, or consumed, what was in the bowl or vessel: (IAar, Sh, K, TA:) and he ate entirely the bread. (K.) ― -b2- Also jrdm, He talked much. (S, K.) ― -b3- And He hastened, made haste, sped, or was quick; (Kr, K;) as also jrcm. (K.) ― -b4- jrdm AlsRitRiyna He passed the [age of] sixty. (IAar, K.)

jarodamN jrdm
jarodamN [probably Voracious: see above: and hence, ― -b2- ] Black locusts, having green heads. (K.) ― -b3- Loquacious; or a great talker. (K.)

1 jaraca c
1. jaraca, inf. n. jarocN, (tropical:) He (a horse [or similar beast]) became affected with the kind of swelling termed jaracN [q. v. infrà]. (A.) ― -b2- jaracat AlqaroHapu (assumed tropical:) The wound, or ulcer, formed itself into a knot, or lump, (taEaqRadat,) like what is termed jaracN, or juracN. (K, accord. to different copies. [The former reading is app. the right.])

2 jrRc c
2. jrRc (tropical:) He trimmed a tree, as though by removing its jarac, meaning its faulty parts, or knots, which are likened to jirocaAn [pl. of juracN]: whence rajulN mujarRacN↓. (A.) ― -b2- [And hence,] jrRchu AldRahoru (tropical:) Time, or fortune, tried and strengthened him by means of experience in affairs. (T, L, TA.)

jaracN c
jaracN (tropical:) Any swelling, (A'Obeyd, S, Mgh, L, K,) and inflation of the sinews, (A'Obeyd, S, Mgh, L,) in the hock (A'Obeyd, S, Mgh, L, K) of a horse (A'Obeyd, Mgh, L) or similar beast; (S, K;) and in the side of the hock-joint, externally and internally; (A'Obeyd, Mgh, L;) derived from juracN, because resembling in form the rat (fOr) thus called: (Mgh:) or an inflation of the sinews of a horse's legs, occasioning swellings which are likened to [the rats called] jirocaAn: (A:) or a swelling in the side of a horse's hoof, and in his stifle-joint (vafinap), or in the hinder part of his hock, which grows so large as to prevent his walking and working; also written jaradN; (ISh, L in arts. jrc and jrd;) and likewise affecting the camel: (ISh, L in art. jrc:) the original word is with c. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (tropical:) The faulty parts, or knots, of a tree, which are pared off; likened to jirocaAn. (A.)

OaroDN jaricapN c
OaroDN jaricapN Land containing, (S, L,) or abounding with, (K,) [the large field-rats called] jirocaAn; (S, L, K;) like ArD faYirapN. (A.) ― -b2- daAbRapN jaricN, (M, L,) or farasN jaricN, (Mgh,) (tropical:) A beast, or horse, affected with the kind of swelling termed jaracN. (M, Mgh, L.) And rajulN jaricu AlrRijolayoni (tropical:) [A man whose legs are affected with similar swellings]. (M, L, TA.)

juracN c
juracN [The large field-rat; so in the present day;] a species of faOor [or rat]: (S, A, Mgh, L, K:) or the male fOr: (T, M, IAmb, L, Msb:) or the large male fOr; said to be larger than the jerboa, of a dusky colour, with a blackness in his tail: (L:) or the large fOr that is in the deserts, or uncultivated plains, and that does not frequent, or keep to, houses: (Msb:) pl. jirocaAnN, (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) or jurocaAnN. (TA.) Okovara QllRehu jirocaAna bayotika [lit. May God multiply the large rats of thy house, or tent,] means (tropical:) may God fill thy house, or tent, with wheat, or food. (A.) And tafarRaqato jircaAnu bayotihi [lit. The large rats of his house, or tent, became dispersed,] has a contr. meaning. (Har p. 274.) ― -b2- OumRu jirocaAnK A sort of dates, (L, Msb, K,) of a large size: before the fruit is cut [from the tree], rats collect beneath: so called when fresh and ripe: when dry, kabiysN: called in El-Koofeh muwXaAnN: (L:) and a sort of palm-tree, the last in the time of the ripening of its fruit in El-Hijáz: (As, AHn, L:) or [simply] the palm-tree. (T in art. Am.) Hence the saying, UicaA TalaEati AlxaraAtaAno Oukilato OumRu jirocaAno [When ElKharátán (the Eleventh Mansion of the Moon) rises aurorally (see manaAzilu Alqamari in art. nzl), the dates called AmR jrcAn are eaten]: for El-Khará- tán rises [aurorally] in the last part of the hot season, after the [auroral] rising of suhayol [or Canopus], and before the season called AlSRafariIF. (AHn, L.)

jirocaAnapN c
jirocaAnapN (in the CK jarocaAnapN) A sort of date: pl. jaraAciynu. (K.)

mujarRadN mjrd
mujarRadN (tropical:) A man freed from his faults by experience in affairs: see 2: (A:) or an intelligent, or a sagacious, man: (M, L:) one who has been tried and strengthened by experience in affairs. (T, S, M, L, K.)

jarocaqN c
jarocaqN and jarocaqapN: see jrdq.

Q. 1 jarocama c
Q. 1. jarocama, (K,) inf. n. jarocamapN, (L,) He hastened, made haste, sped, or was quick, (L, K,) in walking, or going, and in work; (L;) like jrdm. (K.)

1 jarazahu jrz jrzh jrzp
1. jarazahu, (S, K, * TA,) aor.
jaruza
, inf. n. jarozN, (S, Mgh, TA,) He cut it; or cut it off. (S, K, Mgh, TA.) You say also, jurizati AlOaroDu, meaning, The land had its herbage cut, or cut off: (A:) or became without herbage; its herbage having been consumed by the locusts or the sheep or goats or the camels or the like: (Fr, TA:) and jarizati AlOaroDu, aor.
jaraza
, signifies [the same, or] the land became what is termed juruz; as also Oajorazat↓. (TA.) ― -b2- It (time, or fortune, AlzRamaAnu,) destroyed, exterminated, or extirpated, him or it. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He slew him. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- Also jaraza (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He ate quickly. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- And jaruza, (K,) inf. n. jaraAzapN, (TA,) He ate much; was a great eater; (K, TA;) not leaving anything upon the table: (TA:) or (K and TA, but in the CK “ and ”) he ate quickly; was a quick eater. (K, TA.)

4 Ajrzt AlOaroDu c
4. Ajrzt AlOaroDu: see 1. ― -b2- Ajrz Alqawomu, from OaroDN juruzN, (S,) is a phrase similar to juruz, (S, TA,) and signifies The people journeyed in a land such as is termed juruz: (TA in art. ybs:) also (TA) they were, or became, afflicted with dearth, scarcity, drought, sterility, or barrenness. (K, TA.) ― -b3- [And hence, app.,] Ajrzt AlnRaAqapu The she-camel became lean, or emaciated. (K.)

jarozN jrz jrzp
jarozN: see juruzN; the former, in two places.

jurozN jrz jrzp
jurozN: see juruzN; the former, in two places.

jarazN jrz jrzp
jarazN: see juruzN. ― -b2- Also sanapN jarazN A year of dearth, scarcity, drought, or sterility: (S, * K, * TA:) pl. OajoraAzN. (S, TA.)

OaroDN juruzN c
OaroDN juruzN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and jurozN↓, and jarazN↓, and jarozN↓, (S, K,) and majoruwzapN↓, (K,) Land in which is no herbage; (Fr, S, Mgh;) as though the herbage or the rain were cut off from it: (S:) or from which the water is cut off, so that it is dried up and without herbage: (Msb, in explanation of the first:) or dried up, producing no herbage: (Jel in xviii. 7, in explanation of the first:) or of which the herbage has been cut: (Bd ibid., in explanation of the first; and A in explanation of the last:) or that produces no herbage: (K:) or of which the herbage has been eaten: (K: or this is the signification of the last [only] according to the S:) or not rained upon: (K:) or, accord. to some of the expositions of the Kur, by the first is meant the land of El-Yemen: and by the second, accord. to El-'Otbee, [land] that takes, or receives, much water, and does not dry it up: and as to jarozN↓, it may be an inf. n. used as an epithet, as though
meaning caAtu jarozK, i. e., of which the herbage has been eaten: also OaroDN majoruwzapN↓ is explained as signifying land of which the herbage has been consumed by the locusts or the sheep or goats or the camels or the like: (TA:) and mafaAzapN mijoraAzN↓ a barren desert: (A, * K:) [see also jaArizN:] the pl. of jurozN is jirazapN, like as jiHarapN is pl. of juHorN; and that of jarazN is OajoraAzN, like as OasobaAbN is pl. of sababN: (S:) and one says also OaroDN OajoraAzN, (K, TA,) as well as OaraDuwna OajoraAzN. (TA.)

jarozapN jrz jrzh jrzp
jarozapN, (S, A,) or jarazapN↓, with fet-h to the r, (K, TA,) Extirpation: (S, A:) or destruction. (K, TA.) Hence the saying, lano taroDaI XaAniYapN UilRaA bijarozapK A female that hates, by reason of the vehemence of her hatred, will not be content save with extirpation [of the object of her hatred]: (S:) or lamo yaroDa XaAniYuhu UilRaA bijarozapK, (A,) or bajarazapK↓, (TA,) His hater was not content save with extirpation of him whom he hated. (A, TA.) You say also, ramaAhu QllRehu biXarazapK wjarazapK↓, [or biXarozapK wajarozapK, thus, only, the former word is written in the K and TA in art. Xrz, and I think that the latter is correctly written in like manner, as in the S and A,] God smote him with destruction [and extirpation]. (TA.)

jurozapN jrz jrzh jrzp
jurozapN A bundle of [the kind of trefoil called] qatR (A, Mgh, Msb, K) or the like: (Mgh, Msb, K:) or a handful thereof: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. jurazN. (A, * Mgh, Msb.)

jarazapN jrz jrzh jrzp
jarazapN: see jarozapN, in three places.

juraAzN jrAz
juraAzN, applied to a sword, (S, K,) Cutting, or sharp: (K:) or cutting much, or very sharp: (S:) or penetrating: or that cuts off utterly, or entirely. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence you say of a she-camel, likening her to such a sword, UinRahaA lajuraAzN lilXRajari (assumed tropical:) Verily she is one that eats and breaks the trees. (TA.) See also jaruwzN.

jaruwzN jrwz
jaruwzN (tropical:) That eats much; (A, K;) [when applied to a man,] that leaves nothing upon the table when he eats: (S, A:) or that eats quickly: (K:) applied to a man, and to a camel; (TA;) and to a woman; and to a she-camel, as also juraAzN↓; (S;) or [any] female: (TA:) or, applied to a she-camel, that eats everything. (As, TA.)

jaArizN jArz
jaArizN, applied [to land, and hence,] to (tropical:) a woman, Barren: (S, A, K:) the woman is likened to land that produces no herbage. (TA.) [See also juruzN.] ― -b2- OaroDN jaArizapN Dry and rugged land encompassed by sands or by a [level tract such as is called] qaAE: (S, K:) pl. jawaArizu: (S, TA:) mostly applied to islands of the sea. (TA.)

mujorizapN mjrzh mjrzp
mujorizapN, applied to a she-camel, Lean, or emaciated. (K.)

mijoraAzN mjrAz
mijoraAzN: see juruzN; the latter, in two places.

majoruwzapN mjrwzh mjrwzp
majoruwzapN: see juruzN; the latter, in two places.

1 jarasa jrs
1. jarasa, [aor., app.,
jarusa
and
jarisa
, as seems to be implied in the K, inf. n. jarosN, which see below,] He, or it, made a sound; (TA;) as also Ajrs↓: (Mgh, TA:) [or both signify he, or it, made a low, gentle, slight, or soft, sound; as appears from what follows.] You say, jarasa biAlkalaAmi, (A,) or jarasa AlkalaAma, (Msb,) He spoke in a low, gentle, or soft, voice or tone; or with modulation, or melody; syn. nagama fiyhi, (A,) or nagama bihi. (Msb.) And jarasa, (S,) inf. n. jarosN; (K;) and tjrRK↓; (S, K;) He spoke: (K:) or he said a thing, and spoke in a low, gentle, or soft, voice or tone, or with modulation or melody; expl. by takalRama biXaIoCK watanagRama. (Lth, S.) And Ajrs↓ is also used in the senses here following. It (a bird) caused the sound of its passing to be heard: (S, A, * K:) and in like manner it is said of a man. (K, accord. to the TA; but not found by me in any copy of the K.) ↓And (tropical:) It (an ornament, HaloIN,) made a sound (S, A, * K) like that of a jaras [or bell]; (TA;) as also Anjrs↓. (A, TA.) ↓And It (a tribe, HaIRN,) made its sound (jaros) to be heard: or, accord. to the T, made the sound of the jaros of a thing to be heard. (TA.) ↓And He (a man) raised his voice. (TA.) ↓And He (a camel-driver) sang to camels for the purpose of urging or exciting: (S, K:) or raised his voice in doing so. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] jarasa, aor.
jarusa
(Lth, AO, S, K,) and
jarisa
, (K,) inf. n. jarosN, (Lth, AO, K,) He ate [a thing: because a slight sound is made in doing so]: (AO, TA:) or he licked [a thing] with his tongue. (K.) You say, jarasat AlnRaHolu AlEurofuTa The bees ate the [trees called] ErfT: (S) and jarasati AlnRawora, (Lth, A,) and AlEasala [put tropically for AlnRawora because honey is made from flowers or blossoms], (Lth, TA,) the bees ate the flowers, or blossoms, making a sound in so doing: (A:) or licked the flowers, or blossoms, and thence made honey. (Lth, TA.) And jarasati AlmaAXiyapu AlXRajara, and AlEuXoba, The beasts licked the trees, and the herbage. (TA.) And jarasati Albaqarapu waladahaA The cow licked her young one. (TA.)

2 jrRs biAlqawomi jrs bAlqwm
2. jrRs biAlqawomi, inf. n. tajoriysN, He rendered the persons notorious, or infamous; [as, for instance, by parading them, and making public proclamation before them; accord. to the usage of the verb in the present day;] syn. samRaEa bihimo, (K,) and nadRada, (Ibn-'Abbád, TA,) and SawRata. (A.) ＝ -A2- jarRasatohu AlOumuwru, (S,) and AldRuhuwru, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (tropical:) [Events, and misfortunes,] rendered him experienced, or expert, and sound, or firm, in judgment &c. (S, K, * TA)

4 Ajrs Ojrs Ajrs jrs
4. Ajrs: see 1, in six places. ― -b2- Ajrs biAlHaloIi (tropical:) [He made a sound with the ornament]: said of the owner [or wearer] of the ornament. (A.) ― -b3- Ajrs Aljarasa He struck [or sounded] the bell. (TA.) ― -b4- OajorasaniI AlsRabuEu The animal of prey heard my sound (jarosiI): (ISk, S, A, K:) or heard it from afar. (TA.)

5 tajarRasa
5: see 1.

7 Uinojarasa
7: see 1.

jarosN jrs
jarosN (S, A, Msb, K) and jirosN↓ (S, A, K) and jarasN↓ (Kr, ISd) A sound: (ISk, A, K:) or a low, faint, gentle, slight, or soft, sound: (IDrd, S A, K:) such, for instance, as the sound of the beaks of birds, (S, A, Msb,) pecking, (A,) upon a thing which they are eating: (S:) and that of bees eating flowers or blossoms: (A:) and of a tribe [or crowd of men, more particularly as heard from some distance; i. e., a hum]: (TA:) and of a camel-driver singing to his beasts to urge or excite them: (A:) and the slight sound of a letter of the alphabet: (TA:) and low, gentle, or soft, speech: (Msb:) or when the word is used alone, [i. e., not coupled with another noun as it is in the second of the two examples here following,] it is with fet-h: thus one says, maA samiEotu lahu jarosFA; (A, K;) i. e., I heard not any sound of him, or it: (TA:) but you say, maA samiEotu lahu HisRFA walaA jirosFA↓, with kesr; (A, K;) i. e., I heard not any motion, nor any sound, of him, or it: (TA in art. Hs:) pl. [app. of the third] OajoraAsN. (Ham p. 200.) [See also jaroXN.]

jirosN jrs
jirosN: see what next precedes, in two places.

jarasN jrs
jarasN [A bell;] a thing well known; (Msb;) the thing that is hung to the neck of the camel (S, Mgh, K) &c., and that makes a sound: (Mgh:) or, accord. to some, the [little round bell called] julojul: (TA:) and also that which is struck [to make it sound]: (Lth, S, K:) the thing that is struck by the Christians at the times of prayers: (Har p. 616:) pl. OjoraAsN. (Mgh, Msb.) It is said in a trad., laA taSoHabu AlmalaAYikapu rufoqapF fiyhaA jarasN [The angels will not accompany an assemblage of persons journeying together among whom is a bell]: (S, TA:) the reason is said to be, because it guides others to them; for Mo- hammad liked not to let the enemy know of his approach until he came upon them suddenly. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jarosN.

jurosapN jrs jrsh jrsp
jurosapN The act of rendering [a person or persons] notorious, or infamous. (TA.) [See 2.]

jaAruwsN jArws
jaAruwsN Voracious. (IAar, K.)

jawaArisu jwArs
jawaArisu [as though pl. of jaArisapN] Bees: (S:) or bees eating flowers, or blossoms, and making a sound in doing so: (A:) or jawaArisu AlnRaHoli signifies the males of bees. (TA.)

jaAwarosN jAwrs
jaAwarosN [A species of millet;] a kind of grain, (Msb, K,) well known, (K,) resembling curap, but smaller: (Msb:) or, accord. to some, a species of duxon: (Msb:) or i. q. duxonN: (S in art. dxn, and TA in art. dxl:) or a well-known grain, which is eaten, like duxon, of which there are three species, the best whereof is the yellow [AlSfr, or the word may be AlASgr, the smallest,] and weighty: it is likened to rice in its power, or virtue, is more astringent than duxon, promotes the flow of urine, and constringes: the word is arabicized, from [the Persian] GaAwiroso. (TA.)

mujarRasN mjrs
mujarRasN (S) and mujarRisN (TA) (tropical:) A man (TA) experienced, or expert, in affairs, (S, TA,) and rendered sound, or firm, in judgment &c. (TA.) And with p, (tropical:) A she-camel tried and proved by use, or practice, in pace and riding. (TA.)

majoruwsN mjrws
majoruwsN [Uttered with a sound: or with a low, gentle, slight, or soft, sound]. Every letter of the alphabet is majoruwsap, except the soft letters, (A, TA,) namely, wA, and I. (TA.)

1 jaraXahu c
1. jaraXahu, (S, A, K,) aor.
jaruXa
(MS, K) and
jariXa
, (K,) inf. n. jaroXN, (A, TA,) He bruised, brayed, or pounded, it, (S, A, K,) and he ground it, namely, salt, and grain, (A,) coarsely, not finely. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- He stripped off, scraped off, rubbed off, abraded, or otherwise removed, its superficial part; syn. qaXarahu. (K.) ― -b3- He scratched, scraped, rubbed, grated, chafed, or fretted, it; syn. HakRahu; (K, TA;) like as the viper does its fangs; when its folds rub, or grate, together, causing a sound to be head. (TA.) ― -b4- He scratched it (HakRahu, namely, his head,) with a comb, (S, A, K,) so as to raise its scurf; (S, K;) as also jarRaXahu↓. (TA.) ― -b5- He rubbed and pressed it (namely, the skin,) with the hand, in order that it might become smooth (K, TA) and soft. (TA.)

2 jarRaXa
2: see 1, last signification but one.

jaroXN c
jaroXN The sound of a viper's coming forth form the skin [or slough] when the former rubs, or grates, one part against another. (K.) ― -b2- And The sound of a viper's fangs, when they rub, or grate [together]. (TA.) ― -b3- And The sound arising from eating a rough thing: or this is with s. (TA.)

jariyXN c
jariyXN A thing, (S, K,) such as salt, (A,) bruised, brayed, or pounded, (S, A, K,) and ground, (A,) coarsely, not finely: (S, A, K:) or, applied to salt, it signifies maAlamo yuTayRabo [app. meaning such as has not been purified], (S, K, TA,) that crumbles; as though one part thereof were rubbed against another. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Coarse flour, such as is fit for [making the kind of food called] xabiyS muramRal. (TA.)

juraAXapu XaIoCK c
juraAXapu XaIoCK What falls, of, or from, a thing coarsely bruised or brayed or pounded, when what is bruised &c. thereof is taken. (S.) ― -b2- juraAXapN also signifies What falls from the head when it is combed: (A, TA:) and what falls and becomes scattered from wood: (A:) or cuttings, chips, parings, and the like. (TA.)

jawaAriXN c
jawaAriXN [from the Persian GuwaAriXo, A digestive stomachic;] a thing that causes food to digest; as also haADuwmN. (S in art. hDm.)

majoruwXN c
majoruwXN A thing having its superficial part stripped off, scraped off, rubbed off, abraded, or otherwise removed. (TA.) ― -b2- Skin rubbed and pressed with the hand in order that it may become smooth and soft. (TA.)

1 jariDa biriyqihi jrD bryqh jrD bryqp
1. jariDa biriyqihi, aor.
jaraDa
, (IDrd, A, K,) inf. n. jaraDN; (IDrd, K;) or jaraDa biriyqihi, aor.
jariDa
; (S;) but IKtt says that the former is the right; (IB;) His throat, or fauces, became choked by his spittle; he was choked with his spittle: (IDrd, A:) or, accord. to some, he suffered the chokings (guSaS) of death: (TA:) or the verb is sometimes used in a general manner, in the former of the senses explained above, and in the place of gaSRa and in that of Xariqa and in that of XajiIa: (MF in art. gS, q.v.:) and the above-mentioned phrase also signifies (A) he swallowed his spittle with difficulty, or trouble, or labour, contending against anxiety, or grief. (S, A, K.) You say also, huwa yajoriDu binafosihi, (S,) or yajoraDu bnfsh, (A, * TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He is near to dying; accord. to As: (S, TA:) or his soul reaches his fauces: (TA:) or he is at the point of death, his soul having reached his fauces. (A.) And yajoraDu EalaI nafosihi He dies. (TA.) And jariDati AlnRaAqapu bijirRatihaA [app. meaning The she-camel was choked with her cud: or swallowed her cud with difficulty]. (TA.) And jaraDa riyqahu He swallowed his spittle. (A, TA.) And fulaAnN yajoriDu Ealayoka riyqahu [app. meaning Such a one swallows his choler against thee]. (A.) ― -b2- jaraDahu He strangled him. (K.) You say, Oafolata minohumo waqado jaraDuwhu He escaped from them when they had strangled him [so as almost to kill him]. (TA.)

4 AjrDhu biriyqihi AjrDh bryqh AjrDh bryqp
4. AjrDhu biriyqihi He caused his throat, or fauces, to be choked by his spittle. (S, K.)

jaraDN jrD
jaraDN Spittle: (A, K:) or spittle by which one is choked. (S.) ― -b2- [The choking, or strangulation, or rattles, immediately preceding death. See 1: and see also jariyDN.] ― -b3- Difficulty, trouble, or labour; syn. jahodN. (TA.)

jariyDN jryD
jariyDN [A man having his throat, or fauces, choked by his spittle. ― -b2- And hence,] Having his soul reaching his fauces: or near to dying: (TA:) or at the point of death, his soul having reached his fauces, so that he is choked by it: (A, TA:) or dying: (TA:) or made, or suffered, to escape, after evil: (Lth:) or oppressed by grief or sorrow; (S, K;) as also jiroyaADN↓ and jiroMDN↓: (ADk, K:) or affected by intense anxiety or grief: (TA:) [see also jarRaADN:] pl. jaroDaI; (A, K;) like as maroDaI is pl. of mariyDN. (A, TA.) You say, Oafolata fulaAnN jariyDFA, or Oufolita, Such a one escaped, or was made to escape, being near to death; (TA;) or being at the point of death, his soul having reached his fauces, so that he was choked by it. (A, TA.) And maAta fulaAnN jariyDFA Such a one died oppressed by grief or sorrow. (S.) ＝ -A2- In the following prov., HaAla AljariyDu duwna AlqariyDi [The jryD interposed as an obstacle in the way of the qryD], AljryD signifies the thing choking the throat or fauces; (S, A;) and AlqryD signifies the cud: the meaning being, the thing choking the throat or fauces hindered from chewing the cud: (A:) or the former signifies the choking, or having the throat, or fauces, obstructed; and the latter, the poetry: (TA:) or the former, the swallowing of spittle in dying; and the latter, the sound, or voice, of a man in dying: (Er-Riyáshee:) or the former, spittle swallowed: (Har p. 150, q. v.:) and also, the chokings (guSaS) of death: [see also jaraDN:] and the moving to and fro of the two jaws at death: (TA:) the prov. relates to an affair which is hindered by some obstacle: (A, O, K:) or it is said on the occasion of any affair which was possible and which has been hindered by the intervention of some obstacle: and the first who said it was 'Obeyd Ibn-El-Abras, when El-Mundhir [on one of the days when it was his custom to slay whomsoever he met] desired him to recite some of his verses: (Zeyd Ibn-Kuthweh:) or the first who said it was Jowshan [in some copies of the K, Showshan, which, as is said in the TA, is a mistake,] El-Kilábee, when his father, having forbidden him to poetize, and seeing him sick of grief thereat, and at the point of death, gave him permission to do so: (K, TA:) whereupon, after saying these words, he recited some verses, and died. (TA.)

jarRaADN jrAD
jarRaADN A strangler. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Suffering intense, or violent, grief. (TA.) [See also jariyDN.]

jiroMDN jrMD
jiroMDN: see jariyDN.

jiroyaADN jryAD
jiroyaADN: see jariyDN.

1 jariEa AlmaMCa jrE AlmMC
1. jariEa AlmaMCa, aor.
jaraEa
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. jaroEN, (S, K, *) or HaraEN; (Msb;) and jaraEahu, aor.
jaraEa
, inf. n. jaroEN; (S, Msb, K;) but the latter is disallowed by As; (S;) He swallowed the water; (Msb, K;) as also AjtrEhu↓: (Msb:) or the latter signifies he swallowed it at once. (Sgh, K.) ― -b2- See also 5.

2 jarRaEa
2: [jrREhu AlmaMCa He made him to swallow the water.] tajoriyEN is The pouring beverage into the throat against one's will: but sometimes it is used of that which is not against one's will. (Har p. 115.) And jrREhu signifies He gave him to drink gulp after gulp, or sup after sup, or sip after sip. (Har p. 350.) ― -b2- [And hence,] jrREhu AlguSaSa, (K,) or jrREhu guSaSa AlgayoZi, (S,) inf. n. tajoriyEN, (K,) (tropical:) He made him to repress, or restrain, choking wrath, or rage. (S, TA.)

4 AjrEhu OjrEh AjrEh AjrEp jrE
4. AjrEhu He made it (a rope or a bow-string) to have one or more of its strands thick [or rather thicker than the others]. (TA.)

5 tjrRE jrE tjrE
5. tjrRE He swallowed in consecutive portions, one time after another, like him who acts against his own will: or, as IAth says, he drank in haste: or, accord. to some, he drank by little and little. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] tjrRE (S, Msb, K *) (tropical:) He repressed, or restrained, choking wrath, or rage; (S;) as though he swallowed it: (Msb:) and [in like manner] you say also, jariEa↓ AlgayoZa (tropical:) he repressed, or restrained, wrath, or rage. (TA.)

8 UijotaraEa
8: see 1.

jaraEN jrE
jaraEN A twisting in one of the strands of a rope, (S, K,) or of a bow-string, (K,) so that it appears above the other strands. (S, K.) [It is app. an inf. n., of which the verb, if it have one, is jariEa.] ＝ -A2- See also jaraEapN.

jariEN jrE
jariEN A rope, (K,) or a bow-string, (TA,) having the twisting termed jaraEN in one of its
strands; as also mujarRaEN↓: (K:) or, accord. to IAar, a bow-string that is even, except that there is a prominence in one part of it, wherefore it is rubbed and pulled with a piece of a kisaMC [q. v.] until that prominence disappears: and ↓the latter, accord. to ISh, a bow-string not uniformly nor well twisted, having in it prominences, so that one of its strands appears above the others, or some appear above others. (TA.)

jaroEapN jrE jrEh jrEp
jaroEapN: see what next follows, in three places: ＝ -A2- and see jaraEapN, in two places.

juroEapN jrE jrEh jrEp
juroEapN A gulp, or as much as is swallowed at once, of water; a juroEap of water being like a luqomap of food: (Msb:) or a sup, or sip; or as much as is supped, or sipped, at once; or a mouthful of what is supped, or sipped; (syn. HusowapN;) of water; (S, K;) as also jaroEapN↓ and jiroEapN↓: or juroEapN and jaroEapN↓ are substs. [signifying the act of swallowing water] from jariEa AlmaMCa “ he swallowed the water: ” (K:) or jaroEapN↓ signifies a single act of swallowing water: (IAth, L:) and juroEapN, what one swallows: (L, K:) or a mouthful which one swallows: (TA:) or a small draught: (IAth:) and its pl. is juraEN. (Msb, TA.) The dim. is jurayoEapN↓. (S, K.) And hence the prov., Oafolata fulaAnN jurayoEapa AlcRaqani, (Sgh, K,) the verb being intrans., and jryEp being in the accus. case as a denotative of state, as though the speaker said, Oafolata qaAcifFA jurayoEapa AlcRaqani; (Sgh;) or bijurayoEapi AlcRaqani; (S, K;) or bijurayoEaMYihaA↓; (K;) Such a one escaped [from destruction] when his spirit, or the remains thereof, had become in his mouth; (L, K;) or near thereto, (K,) as a sup [or little sup] of water to the chin [of a person drinking]; (TA;) or when death was as near to him as a little sup of water to the chin; (L;) or when at his last gasp: (Fr, S:) applied to one who has been at the point of destruction, and then escaped: (S:) or, accord. to AZ, it is thus; OafolataniI jurayoEapa AlcRaqani, which may mean he made me to escape &c., or he escaped from me &c.; in the latter case, AfltnI being for Oafolata minRiI; and [it is said that] jryEp is prefixed to Alcqn because the motion of the chin indicates the nearness of the departure of the soul: or the meaning of the words related by AZ may be, he made me, i. e. the remains of my soul, to escape; the last two words being a substitute for the pronoun affixed to the verb. (Sgh.) One says also, OafolatanaIi jurayoEapa AlrRiyqi, meaning He outwent me, [or escaped me,] and I swallowed my spittle in wrath, or rage, against him. (TA.) And maA mino juroEapK OaHomadu EuqobaAnFA mino juroEapi gayoZK nakoZimuhaA (tropical:) [There is nothing that is swallowed more praiseworthy in its result than what is swallowed of wrath, or rage, which we repress, or restrain]. (TA.)

jiroEapN jrE jrEh jrEp
jiroEapN: see juroEapN.

jaraEapN jrE jrEh jrEp
jaraEapN (S, K) and jaroEapN↓ (K) and jaroEaMCu↓ (S, K) and OajoraEu↓ (K) An even piece, (S,) or a round piece, or hill, or hillock, (K,) of sand, that produces no plants, or herbage; (S, K;) and, as some add, that retains no water: (TA:) or a piece, or tract, of sand, good for producing plants, or herbage, in which is no softness, or looseness: (Sgh, L, K:) or land in which is ruggedness, resembling sand: (L, K:) or a hill of which one side consists of sand, and one side of stones: (K:) or what is termed jrEAC↓ and AjrE↓ is larger than what is termed jaraEapN: jrEAC↓ is also explained as signifying sand of which the middle is elevated, and of which the sides are thin: and, accord. to IAth, AjrE↓ signifies a wide place, in which is ruggedness: (TA:) or this last, a plain, or soft, place, intermixed with sand: (Ham p. 574:) jaraEapN is sing., or n. un., of jaraEN↓: (S, K: *) or, accord. to some, this last word is a sing., like AjrE; and its pl. [of pauc.] is OajoraAEN and [of mult.] jiraAEN: the pl. of jaraEapN is jiroEaAnN: and the pl. of jaroEapN↓ is jiraAEN: and the pl. of jiriEAC↓ is jaroEaAwaAtN: and the pl. of AjrE↓ is OajaAriEu. (TA.)

jaroEaMCu jrEMC
jaroEaMCu: see jaraEapN, in four places.

jurayoEapN jryEh jryEp
jurayoEapN dim. of juroEapN, q. v.

jurayoEaMCu jryEMC
jurayoEaMCu: see juroEapN.

OajoraEu c
OajoraEu: see jaraEapN, in four places.

mujoriEN mjrE
mujoriEN A she-camel in which is not as much [milk] as will satisfy thirst, but only some sups: (K:) pl. majaAriyEu (L, K) and majaAriEu: (L:) J explains the former pl. as signifying she-camels having little milk; as though there were not in their udders more than some sups; and the sing. he does not mention. (TA.)

mujarRaEN mjrE
mujarRaEN: see jariEN, in two places.

1 jarafahu jrf jrfh jrfp
1. jarafahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jarufa
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. jarofN (S, Msb, K) and jarofapN, (Lh, K,) He took away, carried away, or removed, the whole of it, (S, Msb, K,) or the greater part of it, (S,) or much of it: (S, K:) and [in like manner jrRfhu↓; for its inf. n.] tajoriyfN signifies the act of carrying away wholly: (KL:) and Ajtrfhu↓ he took the whole of it. (TA in art. jft.) ― -b2- Also, (inf. n. jarofN, TA,) He swept it away, namely, mud, (S, K,) from the surface of the earth; (TA;) and so jrRfhu↓, (K,) inf. n. tajoriyfN; (TA;) and tjrRfhu↓: (K:) or tajoriyfN↓ signifies the act of clearing away mud or the like well; in Persian, nyk rndydn: (KL: [Golius, app. misled by a mistranscription, has explained the verb, jrRf, as on the authority of the KL, by “ bene effudit: ”]) and AlXRaIoCa Ajtrf↓ he swept away the thing (jarafahu) from the surface of the earth. (TA.) You say also, jarafatohu AlsRuyuwlu, (Msb,) or jrRfthu↓, inf. n. tajoriyfN; (S;) and tjrRfthu↓; (S, K;) The torrents swept it away; (TA;) [or swept it partially away; or wore it away;] namely, a portion of land. (S, Msb, K. See jurufN.) And, of a death commonly prevailing, jarafa AlnRaAsa kajarofi AlsRayoli (tropical:) [It swept away, or destroyed, men, like the sweeping away of the torrent]: (TA:) and yajotarifu↓ maAla Alqawomi [It sweeps away, or destroys, the cattle of the people]. (S, TA.) ― -b3- [He shovelled it, or scooped it, away, or up, or out.] You say, jarafahu bikilotaA yadayohi [He scooped it up, or out, with both his hands]; i. e. something dry, as flour, and sand, and the like. (S in art. Hfn.) ― -b4- jurifa It (herbage) was eaten up utterly. (TA.)

2 jrRfhu jrf jrfh jrfp
2. jrRfhu, inf. n. tajoriyfN: see 1, in four places. ― -b2- jrRfhu AldRahoru (assumed tropical:) Time, or fortune, or misfortune, destroyed, or exterminated, his property, or cattle, and reduced him to poverty. (TA.) A poet (of the Benoo-Teiyi, TA) says,
faUino takuni AlHawaAdivu jarRafatoniI
falamo Oara haAlikFA kaQbonaIo ziyaAdi
(assumed tropical:) [And if misfortunes have destroyed my property, or cattle, and reduced me to poverty, I have not seen any one in a state of perdition like the two sons of Ziyád]. (S, TA.)

4 Ajrf Ojrf Ajrf jrf
4. Ajrf It (a place) was invaded by a torrent such as is termed juraAf. (K.)

5 tajarRafa
5: see 1, in two places; and see jurufN.

8 Uijotarafa
8: see 1, in three places.

jurofN jrf
jurofN: see jurufN. ― -b2- Also A smooth side of a mountain. (A boo-Kheyreh, K.)

jirofN jrf
jirofN: see the next paragraph.

jurufN jrf
jurufN and jurofN↓, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) the latter a contraction of the former, (Msb,) [An abrupt, water-worn, bank or ridge;] a bank (jaAnibN Ksh and Jel in ix. 110) of a valley, the lower part of which is excavated by the water, and hollowed out by the torrents, so that it remains uncompact, unsound, or weak; (Ksh ib.;) a bank, or an acclivity, of a water-course of a valley and the like, when the water has carried away from its lower part, and undermined it, so that it has become like what is termed a daHol, with its upper part overhanging; (L;) a portion of land (or sand, S in art. thr) which the torrents have partially swept away, or worn away, (tajarRafatohu↓, S, K, or jarafatohu↓, Msb,) and eaten; (S, Msb, K;) a portion of the lower part of the side of a valley, and of a river, eaten by the torrent; (M, TA;) the side of the bank of a river, that has been eaten by the water, so that some part of it every little while falls: (Har p. 47:) and the latter, [or each,] a place which the torrent does not take away; as also jirofN↓; (K;) [i. e. a bank, or ridge, that remains rising abruptly by the bed of a torrent or stream:] pl. [of pauc.] (of jurufN, TA) OajoraAfN, (K,) like OaTonaAbN pl. of TunubN, (TA,) and [of mult.] (of jurofN, though it is implied in the K that it is of jurufN, TA) jirafapN, like jiHarapN (S, K) pl. of juHorN, (S,) and juruwfN. (ISd, TA.)

juraAfN jrAf
juraAfN A torrent that carries away everything; (S, Msb;) i. q. juHaAfN applied to a torrent; as also jaworafN↓; (K;) and jaAruwfN↓ a torrent that sweeps away that by which it passes, by reason of its copiousness, carrying away everything, and so jaArifN↓ applied to rain. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A very voracious man: (K, TA:) a man who devours all the food: (S:) one who eats vehemently,
leaving nothing remaining. (M, TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A man who marries much, or often, and is brisk, lively, sprightly, or active; as also jaAruwfN↓. (K, TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A sword that sweeps away everything. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) A sort of measure of capacity; as also jiraAfN↓: (S, K:) a certain large measure of capacity. (ISk, TA.)

jiraAfN jrAf
jiraAfN: see what next precedes.

nayoTalN jaruwfN nyTl jrwf
nayoTalN jaruwfN [A capacious bucket: see 3 in art. nhz]. (S in art. nhz.)

jurRaAfapN jrAfh jrAfp
jurRaAfapN: see mijorafapN.

jaArifN jArf
jaArifN: see juraAfN. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A death commonly, or generally, prevailing, (S, K, TA,) that sweeps away, or destroys, (yajotarifu,) the cattle of the people. (S, TA.) And (assumed tropical:) Plague, or pestilence. (K.) AljaArifu means (assumed tropical:) A plague, or pestilence, that happened in the time of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr; (S;) or, as Lth says, AlTRaAEuwnu AljaArifu means the plague, or pestilence, that befel the people of El- 'Irák [in the year of the Flight 69], spreading wide, and sweeping away the people like the sweeping away of the torrent. (TA.) And (tropical:) Evil fortune, or an affliction, that sweeps away, or destroys, (Lth, K, TA,) a people, (K,) or the cattle of a people. (Lth, TA.)

jaworafN jwrf
jaworafN: see juraAfN. ― -b2- Hence, as being likened to the torrent thus termed, (TA,) (tropical:) A quick, or swift, birocawn [or hack, &c.]. (K.) And (tropical:) An ass; [app. meaning a wild ass, because of his swiftness.] (Sgh, K.) And, accord. to some, A male ostrich: (as in the K:) but this is a mistranscription for jaworaqN, with q. (Abu-l-' Abbás, T, Sgh, L, TA.)

jaAruwfN jArwf
jaAruwfN: see juraAfN, in two places. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Greedy; having an inordinate desire, or appetite, for food. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And An (tropical:) unfortunate man. (K, * TA.)

mijorafN mjrf
mijorafN: see mijorafapN. ― -b2- [Hence,] banaAnN mijorafN [Fingers, or fingers' ends,] that take much food. (IAar, TA.)

mijorafapN mjrf mjrfh mjrfp
mijorafapN A broom, or besom; (K;) a thing with which mud is swept away from the surface of the ground: (S, * TA:) [applied in the present day to a shovel: and a hoe: and a rake:] as also mijorafN↓: vulgarly, jurRaAfapN↓; [now applied by many to a drag for dragging rivers &c.;] of which the pl. is jaraAriyfu. (TA.)

mujarRafN mjrf
mujarRafN (tropical:) A man who has had his property, or or cattle, destroyed, or exterminated, and who has been reduced to poverty, by time, or fortune, or misfortune. (TA.)

mujarRifN mjrf
mujarRifN (tropical:) Lean, or emaciated. (M, TA.) [See what next follows.]

mutajarRifN mtjrf
mutajarRifN (tropical:) A ram whose general fatness has gone; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) and so a camel. (TA.) ― -b2- Lean, or emaciated; as also mutajalRifN. (TA in art. jlf.) You say, jaMCa mutajarRifFA (tropical:) He (a man, Ibn-'Abbád, TA) came in a lean and lax state (haziylFA muDoTaribFA). (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

jiroyaAlN jryAl
jiroyaAlN A certain red dye. (As, S, K.) ― -b2- The redness of gold. (S, K.) ― -b3- Pure; applied to red and other colours. (K.) ― -b4- Also, (S, K,) and jiroyaAlapN↓, (K,) Wine; (S, K;) inferior in goodness to such as is termed sulaAfN: (S:) or the colour of wine. (S, K.) The phrase salabotuhaA jiroyaAlahaA, used by El-Aashà, [lit. I deprived it, namely, wine, of its colour,] means I drank it red, and discharged it in urine white. (S.)

jiroyaAlapN jryAlh jryAlp
jiroyaAlapN: see above.

1 jaramahu jrm jrmh jrmp
1. jaramahu, aor.
jarima
, (K,) inf. n. jaromN, (S,) [like jazamahu,] He cut it, or cut it off. (S, K.) ― -b2- jarama AlXRaApa, (K,) or jarama Suwfa AlXRaApi, (S,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He shore, or sheared, or cut off the wool of, the sheep. (S, K, * TA.) And jaramotu minohu I took [or clipped somewhat] from it; [namely, the wool;] like jalamotu. (S.) ― -b3- jarama AlnRaxola, (S, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. jaromN (K) and jaraAmN and jiraAmN, (S, * K,) He cut the palmtrees; (Msb;) [meaning] he cut off the fruit of the palm-trees; (S, K;) as also Ajtrmhu↓: (S:) and in like manner, jarama AltRamora he cut off the dates. (TA.) You say, hecaA zamanu AljaraAmi and AljiraAmi, (S,) i. e. [This is] the time of the cutting off of the fruit of the palm-trees. (TA.) ― -b4- And jarama AlnRaxola, inf. n. jaromN, He computed by conjecture the quantity of fruit upon the palm-trees; (K;) and so Ajtrmhu↓: (Lh, K:) [like jazamahu and Ajtzmhu.] ＝ -A2- jarama, (S, K,) aor.
jarima
, (S,) inf. n. jaromN, (TK,) also signifies He gained, acquired, or earned, [wealth, &c.,] (S, K,) liOaholihi for his family; and so Ajtrm↓. (K.) And you say, xaraja yajorimu liOaholihi and yajorimu Oaholahu, meaning He went forth seeking [sustenance], and practising skill, or artifice, for his family. (TA.) ― -b2- walaA yajorimanRakumo XanaMnu qawomK, in the Kur [v. 3 and 11], is explained by some as meaning And let not a people's hatred by any means occasion you. or cause you: or it means let not a people's hatred by any means induce you, or incite you. (S, TA.) Some read lA yujorimanRakumo↓, with damm to the I; and Zj says that jaramotu and Oajoramotu signify the same: but some say that the meaning is, let it not by any means lead you into crime, or sin; Oajoramotuhu being like Mvamotuhu, I led him into sin, &c. (TA.) ― -b3- Fr says that the asserting jaramotu to mean Haqaqotu [or rather Huqiqotu, for this is evidently, I think, the right reading, though I find Haqaqotu in the TA as well as in a copy of the S, in another copy of which I find jaramato and HaqRaqato, suggesting that the right reading may perhaps be jaramato and HuqRato,] is nought: they who so explain it having been confused in their judgment by the saying of the poet Aboo-Asmà, (S, TA,) or, as some say, El-Howfazán, (TA,) or, accord. to some, 'Ateeyeh Ibn-'Ofeyf, (IB, TA,)
walaqado TaEanotu OabaA Euyayonapa TaEonapF
jaramato fazaArapa baEodahaA Oano yagoDabuwA
in which they made fzArp to be in the nom. case, as though the meaning were HuqRa lahaA AlgaDabu [it was right, or fit, or proper, for it, (the tribe of Fezárah,) to be angry; nearly agreeing with an explanation of jarama given by Golius as on the authority of Ibn-Maaroof, namely, “ meritus, dignus fuit ”]: but, he says, fzArp is in the accus. case; the meaning being, jaramatohumu AlTRaEonapu Oano yagoDabuwA [which will be found explained, on the authority of IB, in what follows]: AO says that the meaning is, OaHaqRato Ealayohimu AlgaDaba, i. e., OaHaqRati AlTRaEonapu fazaArapa Oano yagoDabuwA, and HaqRat also, [both having the same signification, i. e., the thrust required Fezá- rah to be angry,] from laA jarama laOafoEalanRa kacaA meaning HaqRFA [Verily I will do thus]: (S, TA:) accord. to Fr, the meaning is, kasabato fazaArapa AlgaDaba Ealayoka, the right reading being, walaqado TaEanota, with fet-h to the t; [so that the verse means And verily thou didst thrust Aboo-'Oyeyneh with a thrust of thy spear that occasioned, or caused, Fezárah, after it, to be angry against thee:] for he is addressing Kurz El-'Okeylee, bewailing his death; and Kurz had thrust Aboo-'Oyeyneh, who was Hisn Ibn-Hudheyfeh Ibn-Bedr El-Fezáree. (IB, TA.) ― -b4- And jarama, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jarima
, inf. n. jaromN, (Msb,) He committed a sin, a crime, a fault, an offence, or an act of disobedience; (S, Msb, K;) syn. Oaconaba, (Msb, K,) and Aikotasaba AlUivoma; (Msb;) [perhaps because he who does so brings upon himself the consequence thereof; as though originally jarama nafosahu Awlinafosihi Oavara juromK he drew upon himself the effect of a sin, &c.; (compare kasaba and Aikotasaba;)] as also Ajrm↓, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. UijoraAmN; (Msb;) and Ajtrm↓; (S, K;) and tjrRm↓. (El-'Okberee, Har p. 207.) You say, jarama Ealayohimo jariymapF, and Uilayohimo, (K,) and bihimo, used by a poet for Elyhm or Alyhm, (IAar, TA,) He committed against them a crime, or an offence for which he should be punished; as also Ajzm↓. (K.) They said also, AlcRanoba Ajrm↓ [He committed the sin, or crime, amp;c.]; making the verb trans. (TA.) And a poet says,
wataraI AllRabiyba muHasRadFA lamo yajotarimo
EiroDa AlrRijaAli waEiroDuhu maXotuwmN
[And thou seest the intelligent envied, or much envied: he has not injured the honour of men, while his honour is reviled]. (Th, TA.) ＝ -A3- jarima, aor.
jarama
, (K,) inf. n. jaramN, (TK,) He (a man, TA) betook himself to eating the juraAmap [in the CK, erroneously, jarAmap,] of the palm-trees, (AA, K,) [i. e., the dates which had fallen in the cutting, and] which were among the branches. (AA, TA.) ＝ -A4- jarima, said of a man, also signifies EaZuma juromuhu [His sin, or crime, &c., was, or became, great]; and so jaruma, like karum: [both are thus explained, in different places in this art, by the author of the TA; and the explanation in the latter case is followed by AI Acnb, i. e., he committed a six, &c.; probably added by him to show that the reading found by him was juromuhu, not jiromuhu: but [think that the right reading is EaZuma jiromuhu his body became great; and this is confirmed by what
here follows:] Ajrm↓ explained in the copies of the K by EaZuma [in the TK EZm yEnI jrmh wjsdh] should be jarima, a triliteral; and the meaning is EaZuma juromuhu: and in like manner, the three significations here following, assigned in the K to Ajrm↓, belong to jarima. (TA.) ＝ -A5- It (his colour) was, or became, clear. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- He (a man, TA) was, or became, clear in his voice. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A6- jarima bihi It (blood) stuck to him, or it: (K, * TA, and so in a marginal note in a copy of the S:) and in like manner, tar to a camel. (The same marginal note.)

2 jarRama
2: [jrRm He cut off vehemently, or much. (Golius, on the authority of a gloss in the KL.)] ― -b2- jarRamonaA humo, inf. n. tajoriymN, We went forth from them. (Lth, K.) ― -b3- jarRamonaA AlXRitaMCa We completed the winter. (TA.) [See also 5.]

4 Ajrm AltRamoru Ajrm Altmr
4. Ajrm AltRamoru The dates attained to the time for their being cut off. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, in six places.

5 tjrRm Ojrm jrm tjrm
5. tjrRm [It became cut off. ― -b2- And hence,] (tropical:) It (a year, HawolN) became completed; (Az, K, TA;) as though it became cut off from the preceding year: (Az, TA:) it ended; (S;) and so the winter: (TA:) and it (a night) passed away, (S, K,) and became completed; (K;) it ended. (TA.) ＝ -A2- tjrRm vamaAniyFA, a phrase used by Sá'ideh Ibn-Ju-eiyeh, means He passed eight nights. (TA.) [See also 2] ＝ -A3- tjrRm Ealayohi He accused him of a sin, a crime, a fault, an offence, or an act of disobedience, (Abu-l-'Abbás, S, K,) which he had not committed, (Abu-l-'Abbás, S,) or though he had not committed any (K.) ― -b2- And tjrRm He guarded against the commission of sin, or crime, &c.; like tOvRm. (Har p. 207.) ― -b3- See also 1. ＝ -A4- Also He called, cried out, shouted, or vociferated; from jiromN meaning SawotN. (Har p. 207. [But see jiromN.])

8 Uijotarama
8: see 1, in five places.

jaromN jrm
jaromN Hot; syn. HarRN, (S,) or [rather] HaArRN; (K;) contr. of SarodN; (Lth, TA;) a Persian word, (S,) arabicized; (S, K;) originally Garom. (TA.) You say OaroDN jaromN A warm land: (AHn, TA:) or a hot land: (IDrd, TA:) or a vehemently hot land: (K:) pl. juruwmN, (AHn, TA,) which, applied to countries, or regions, means the contr. of SuruwdN. (S.) ＝ -A2- A boat (zaworaqN) of El-Yemen; (K;) also called naqiyrapN: (TA:) pl. as above. (K.) [In the dial. of Egypt, The largest kind of Egyptian boat used on the Nile for the conveyance of grain and merchandise in general, but used only when the river is high, and also in the coastingtrade, and generally carrying from 5,000 to 15,000 bushels of grain.]

juromN jrm
juromN A sin, a crime, a fault, an offence, or an act of disobedience, syn. canobN, (S, Msb, * K,) whether intentional or committed through inadvertence; (Kull voce UivomN;) as also jariymapN↓; (S, Msb, K;) and jarimapN↓: (K:) transgression: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OajoraAmN and [of mult.] juruwmN, (K,) both of juromN: the pl. of jariyampN is jaraAYimu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jaraAmN. ＝ -A3- laA juroma: see laA jarama.

jiromN jrm
jiromN The body; syn. jasadN; (S, Msb, K;) or badanN; (Th, TA;) as also jiromaAnN↓: (K:) or the OalowaAHi [pl. of lawoH q. v.] and juvomaAn [q. v.] of the jasad: (T, TA:) pl. (of pauc., TA) OjoraAmN, (Msb, K,) which is also used as a sing., (TA,) and (of mult., TA) juruwmN and jurumN. (K.) OaloqaI Ealayohi OajoraAmahu is a phrase mentioned, but not explained, by Lh: ISd thinks that it means He threw upon him the weight of his body; as though the term jiromN applied to each separate part of his body. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlOajoraAmu AlfalakiyRapu The [heavenly] bodies that are above the EanaASir, of the orbs and stars. (KT.) ＝ -A2- The throat, or fauces; syn. HaloqN. (K.) The phrase yaDiyqu bihi Aljiromu, used by the poet Maan Ibn-'Ows, means (assumed tropical:) It is a great, or formidable, thing, or matter: [properly,] the throat (AlHaloqu) will not easily swallow it. (TA.) ― -b2- The voice; (S, K;) mentioned by ISk and others; (S;) and so explained as used in the phrase UinRa fulaAnFA laHasanu Aljiromi [Verily such a one is good in respect of voice]: (TA:) or highness, or loudness, of the voice: (K, TA:) you say, maA Earafotuhu UilRaA bijiromihi [I knew him not save by his voice, or his highness, or loudness, of voice]: but some disapprove this: (TA:) AHát says that the vulgar are addicted to saying, fulaAnN SaAfiI Aljiromi Such a one is clear in voice, or in throat: but it is a mistake. (S, TA.) ＝ -A3- Colour. (IAar, S, Msb, K.) One may say, of najaAsap [or filth], laA jiroma lahaA, meaning It has no colour. (Msb.) ＝ -A4- AlOajoraAmu (app. as pl. of jiromN, TA) The utensils, or apparatus, of the pastor. (K.)

laA jarama lA jrm
laA jarama (S, Msb, K, &c.) and laA caA jarama, (IAar, K,) cA being here a redundant connective as in several other instances, (IAar, TA,) and laA Oano caA jarama and laA Eano caA jarama (K) and laA jara, (Ks, K, [in the CK lA jaroma,]) in which the m is elided in consequence of frequency of usage, as the I is in HaAXa lilRhi for HaAXaI lilRehi, and the I and C in OayoXa for OaIRu XaIoCK, (Ks, TA,) and laA caA jara (IAar, TA) and laA jaruma↓ and laA juroma↓, (K,) originally i. q. laA budRa and laAmaHaAlapN [There is no avoiding it; it is absolutely necessary; &c.]: then, by reason of frequency of usage, employed in the manner of an oath, as meaning HaqRFA [verily, or truly]; wherefore, as in the case of an oath, l is prefixed to its complement, (Fr, S, Msb, K, *) so that they say, laA jarama laMtiyanRka [Verily I will come to thee], (Fr, S, K,) and laA jarama laOafoEalanRa kacaA [Verily I will do thus], (S, Msb, *) and laA jarama laqado kaAna kacaA and laA caA jarama and laA caA jara [Verily it was thus, or verily such a thing happened]: (IAar, TA:) ISd says, Kh asserts that jarama [or laA jarama] is only a reply to something said before it; as when a man says, “ They did such a thing, ” and you say, laA jarama OanRahumo sayanodamuwna, or OanRahu sayakuwnu kacaA wakacaA; and Az says that lA in laA jarama is said to be a [mere] connective; and the meaning [of the former of the last two phrases] is kasaba lahumo Eamaluhumu AlnRadama [It (their deed) will earn for them, or occasion them, repentance; and that of the latter, it will occasion that such and such things shall happen]: and some say that jarama means wajaba, and HaqRa, and that lA is a contradiction to the words preceding it, and that a new proposition then begins; as in the Kur [xvi. 64] where it is said, laA jarama OanRa lahumu AlnRaAra, i. e., [Nay, or] the case is not as they have said: the fire [of Hell] is their due. (TA.)

laA jaruma lA jrm
laA jaruma: see the paragraph next preceding.

jiromapN jrm jrmh jrmp
jiromapN People cutting off the fruit of palmtrees. (S, K, TA.) [In this sense it is app. a pl. of pauc., or a quasi-pl. n., of jaArimN, q. v.] ― -b2- Also Ripening dates cut off from the trees: and this sense, not the former as is implied in the S, is meant by Imra-el-Keys, where he says,
Ealawona biOanoTaAkiyRapK fawoqa EiqomapK
kajiromapK naxolK Oawo kajanRapi yavoriba
[They mounted, at Antioch, upon a variegated cloth, like the ripening dates cut off from palmtrees, or like the garden of Yethrib]: he likens the variegated cloth and wool upon the hawodaj to red and yellow ripening dates, or to the garden of Yethrib because it abounded with palm-trees. (TA.)

jarimapN jrm jrmh jrmp
jarimapN: see juromN.

jiromaAnN jrm jrmAn
jiromaAnN: see jiromN.

jaraAmN jrAm
jaraAmN (erroneously said in the K to be [juraAmN] like guraAbN, TA) and jariymN↓ Dry dates: (AA, S, M, K:) mentioned by ISk among [syn.] words of the measures faEaAlN and faEiylN, like XaHaAHN and XaHiyHN, and bajaAlN and bajiylN, &c. (S.) ― -b2- Also, both these words, (AA, S, K, *) but the former not heard in this sense by ISd, (TA,) Datestones; (AA, S, K;) and so juromN↓: (mentioned in one copy of the S, but not in the TA, [probably an interpolation in the copy of the S above mentioned:]) and jariymapN↓ a date-stone; as in the saying of 'Ows Ibn-Háritheh, laA waQlRaciI Oaxoraja AlEacoqa mina Aljariymapi waAlnRaAra mina Alwaviymapi [No, by Him who has produced the palm-tree with its fruit from the date-stone, and fire from broken stones]. (TA.)

jariymN jrym
jariymN Dates (tamorN) cut off from the tree; (S, TA;) as also majoruwmN↓. (TA.) And XajarapN jariymapN A cut tree. (TA.) ― -b2- See also jaraAmN, with which it is syn. in two senses: in the latter sense having jariymapN for its n un. ― -b3- Also A thing with which date-stones are brayed, or crushed.
