(TA.) ＝ -A2- See also mujorimN. ＝ -A3- Also Large-bodied; (S, * K;) and so majoruwmN↓: (K:) pl. (of the former, S) jiraAmN. (S, K.) The fem. of the former is with p: (K:) [but] one says also jilRapN jariymN, meaning Largebodied camels advanced in age. (S.) ＝ -A4- In El- Hijáz, The [measure commonly termed] mudR is thus called; accord. to Z, the mudR of the Prophet. (TA.)

juraAmapN jrAm jrAmh jrAmp
juraAmapN i. q. jucaAmapN; (K;) i. e., (TA,) The dates that have fallen when they are cut off from the tree: (S, TA:) so says As: (TA:) [but see the latter word as explained on the authority of the S in art. jcm:] and, (K,) or as some say, (TA,) dates cut off from the tree: or what are gotten (yujoramu) thereof, after their being cut off, being picked up from the lower ends of the branches. (K, TA. [See jarima.]) And The qaSal of wheat and barley; i. e., the extremities thereof, which are bruised, and then cleared, or picked: (K, TA:) but the term more known is jucaAmapN, with cAl. (TA.)

jariymapN jrymh jrymp
jariymapN The last of one's offspring: (K:) as though there were a cutting off after it. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jaArimN: ＝ -A3- and see juromN: ＝ -A4- and jaraAmN.

jaArimN jArm
jaArimN Cutting off, or one who cuts off, the fruit of the palm-tree: pl. jurRamN and jurRaAmN. (S.) [See also jiromapN.] ＝ -A2- jaArimu Oaholihi (TA) and Oaholihi jariymapu↓ (S, K *) The gainer, acquirer, or earner, [of the sustenance] of his family. (S, K, TA.) ＝ -A3- See also mujorimN, in two places.

mujorimN mjrm
mujorimN A sinner; a criminal; committing, or a committer of, a sin, a crime, a fault, an offence, or an act of disobedience; as also jariymN↓ (K) and jaArimN↓: (TA:) and Almujorimuwna particularly signifies the unbelievers: (Zj, K:) so in the Kur vii. 38. (Zj, TA.) You say, EalaI nafosihi huwa jaArimN↓ waqawomihi, [as also mujorimN,] He is committing a crime, or an offence for which he should be punished, against himself and his people or party. (TA.)

mujarRamN mjrm
mujarRamN, (fem. with p, S,) A complete year (S, K) and month; (Ibn-Háni, TA;) a year past, completed. (AZ, TA.)

majoruwmN mjrwm
majoruwmN: see jariymN, in two places.

juromuwqN jrmwq
juromuwqN [A kind of galoche;] a thing that is worn over the [kind of boot called] xufR; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) called in Persian xarokaXo: (Mgh:) or a small xufR (JK, TA) which is worn over the [ordinary] xufR: (TA:) an arabicized word; (S;) [probably from the Persian Jarom “ leather, ” and muwq, which is said by some to be arabicized, but by ISd to be a genuine Arabic word, meaning “ a kind of xufR: ” or it may be from saromuwzaho, given as its Persian equivalent in the PS:] pl. jaraAmiyqu. (Msb.)

1 jarana jAr jrn
1. jarana, (S, K,) aor.
jaruna
, (S,) inf. n. juruwnN, (S, K,) said of a man, and of a beast, (ISk, S,) He became accustomed, habituated, or inured, to a thing, or an affair. (ISk, S, K.) And jaranato yadaAhu EalaI AlEamali, inf. n. as above, His hands became accustomed, or inured, to the work. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Also, said of a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, K,) and of a coat of mail, (K,) and of a skin for water or milk, (S,) It became threadbare, or worn, and soft, or smooth: (S, K:) or, said of a skin, and of a book, or writing, it became old and worn out. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- jarana, (K,) inf. n. jaronN, (TA,) He ground grain (K, TA) vehemently: (TA:) of the dial. of Hudheyl. (TA.)

4 Ajrn OjAr Ojr Ojrn Ajrn Mjr Mjrn
4. Ajrn He collected dates in the jariyn. (ISd, K.)

8 Ajtrn Ajtrn
8. Ajtrn He made, or prepared, a jariyn. (K.)

juronN jAr jrn
juronN A hollowed stone, [or stone basin,] from which the [ablution termed] wuDuwoC is performed; (K;) water being poured into it; called by the people of El-Medeeneh mhrs [app. mihoras, perhaps a dial. var. of mihoraAsN, or a mistranscription for this]: so in the M: in the Jm, the mihoraAs with which the wDwC is performed. (TA.) ― -b2- See also jubRN. ― -b3- [In the present day, applied also to A stone mortar in which things are pounded.] ― -b4- See also jariynN, in two places.

jironN jAr jrn
jironN The body, with the limbs or members; syn. jisomN; said to be a dial. var. of jiromN; or the n may be a substitute for the jrm of OajoraAnN; but the former is the more probable, as the word has a pl., namely, OaloqaI Ealayohi OajoraAnahu, and this is scarcely ever the case when a word is formed by substitution. (TA.) Hence the saying, OaloqaI Ealayohi OajoraAnahu, i. q. AlqI Elyh OajoraAmahu and XaraAXirahu [He threw upon him, or it, the weight of his body]: (Lh, TA: [see also XaroXarpN, under which other explanations are given:]) or he threw his weights [meaning his whole weight] upon him, or it; and so AlqI Elyh jiraAnahu↓: or, accord. to the A, he disposed, or subjected, his mind to it; or persuaded himself to do it; namely, an affair. (TA.)

jiraAnN jrAn
jiraAnN The anterior [or under] part of the neck of a camel, from his macobaH [or the part a little below the under jaw] to the place where he is stabbed: (S, Msb, K:) and in like manner, of a horse; (S, TA;) the inner [or under] part of the neck, from the pit of the uppermost part of the breast to the extremity of the neck at the head: and, metaphorically, of a man: (TA:) pl. [of mult.] jurunN (S, Msb, K) and [of pauc.] OajorinapN; (Msb, TA;) which last is used by Tarafeh as a sing. (TA, * and EM p. 68.) You say, of a camel, OaloqaI jiraAnahu biAlOaroDi [He threw the under part of his neck upon the ground]; meaning that he lay down, and stretched out his neck upon the ground. (Msb, TA.) See another ex. voce jironN. [And see a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. Hnw.] You say also, Daraba AlHaqRu bijiraAnihi, meaning (assumed tropical:) The truth, or right, or just claim, became established, or settled. (T, TA.) ― -b2- Also The inner [or under] part of the penis: pl. jurunN and OajorinapN, as above. (TA.)

jariynN jrI jryn
jariynN What one has ground [of grain]: (K, TA:) of the dial. of Hudheyl. (TA.) ― -b2- See also jaArinN. ― -b3- Also, and juronN↓ (T, S, M, K) and mijoranN↓, (K,) or majoranN↓, (so in a copy of the S, but in other copies not mentioned,) The place in which dates are dried: (S:) or a bayodar: (K:) or the jariyn is for grain; and the byd, for dates: (Towsheeh, TA:) or the place where dates are collected [and dried] when they are cut from the tree: or, accord. to Lth, the place of the byd in the dial. of the people of El-Yemen, the generality of whom pronounce the word [jiriyn,] with kesr to the j: (T, TA:) or the mirobad; i. e. the place in which fresh ripe dates are thrown to dry: (Mgh:) or the bydr in which wheat is trodden out; and also the place in which fruits are dried: (Msb:) the place of wheat; and sometimes [the place] for [drying] dates and grapes: (M, TA:) its pl. [of mult.] is jurunN, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) not jaraAYinu, (Mgh,) and [of pauc.] OajoraAnN and OajorinapN: (TA:) A 'Obeyd says that mirobadN and jariynN are of the dial. of El-Hijáz; and OanodarN, of that of Syria; and bayodarN, of El-'Irák: (TA in art. rbd:) juronN↓ is of the dial. of the people of Egypt, who use it as meaning the bydr of seed-produce, which is [sometimes] walled round; and its pl. is OajoraAnN. (TA.) [See also mirobadN.]

jiroyaAnN jryAn
jiroyaAnN a dial. var. of jiroyaAlN, (S, K, *) meaning A certain red dye. (ISd, TA.)

jaArinN jArn
jaArinN, applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (T, S, K,) and to a skin for water or milk, &c., (T, TA,) Old, and worn out: (T, TA:) or threadbare, or worn, and soft, or smooth: and in like manner applied to a coat of mail: (S, K:) as also jariynN↓: (TA:) or, applied to a coat of mail (diroE), in which case it is with p, that has become smooth from much use: (Ham p. 656:) pl. jawaArinu: (S, TA:) and, applied to a commodity, or utensil, or an article of furniture, used, and worn out: and to a skin for water or milk, dried up, and rough, or coarse, from use: (TA:) and to a road, worn, or effaced. (Abu-l-Jarráh, S, K.) ― -b2- Also The young one of a serpent: (S, K:) or of a viper, (Lth, M, TA,) such as is smooth. (Lth, TA.)

majoranN mjrn
majoranN: see jariynN.

mijoranN mjrn
mijoranN: see jariynN. ＝ -A2- Also Very voracious: (K:) of the dial. of Hudheyl. (TA.)

mujarRanN mjrn
mujarRanN A whip of which the thong has become soft, or smooth. (K.) Az says, I have seen them make their whips from the jurun [pl. of jiraAnN q. v.] of camels such as are termed buzol [i. e. in the ninth year, or nine years old], because of the thickness thereof. (TA.)

4 Oajorato c
4. Oajorato [in its primary sense app. signifies She (a bitch, and any female beast of prey,) whelped; or had a whelp, or whelps: see mujorK. (Accord. to Golius, as on the authority of J, Cum fœtu abiit vel asportavit eum fera: but I have not found it in any copy of the S, nor in any other lexicon.) ― -b2- And hence,] said of a tree (XajarapN), It had upon it [fruits such as are termed] jiraMC [pl. of jirowN]; (As, TA;) said [for instance] of a mawozap [or banana-tree]: (AHn, TA in art. mwz:) and [in like manner] said of a herb,
or leguminous plant, (baqolapN,) it had jiraMC; (K in art. jrI; [in the CK, erroneously, jarAC;]) belonging to the present art., not to art. jrI. (TA.)

jirowN jrw
jirowN and jurowN and jarowN (of which the first is the most chaste, Msb) The whelp, or young one, of the dog, (S, Msb, K,) [and so, app., jirowapN↓, q. v.,] and of the lion, (K,) and of any beast of prey: (S, Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] OajorK, (S, K,) originally OajoruwN, (S,) and OajoriyapN (Lh, K) and OajoraMCN (K) and [of mult.] jiraMCN; (S, K;) OajoriyapN, as pl. of jrw, being anomalous; (TA;) or it is pl. of jiraMCN [and therefore not anomalous]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- And the same, (K,) or the first of these, (S, El-Bári', Msb, TA,) only, (TA,) (tropical:) The small of anything, (El-Bári', Msb, K, TA,) as also jirowapN↓; (TA;) even, (K,) of the colocynth, (As, S, K,) and of the melon, and the like; (K;) as, for instance, (TA,) of the pomegranate, (S, TA,) and of the poppy, (AHn, TA in art. Etr,) and of the baAcanojaAn, (TA,) and of the cucumber, (S, TA,) as also jirowapN↓, (S, Msb,) likened to the whelps of dogs, because of their softness and smoothness: (Msb:) or what is round of the fruits of trees; as the colocynth and the like: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OjorK (Msb, K, TA [in the CK, erroneously, AajoruWN]) and [of mult.] jiraMCN. (As, Msb, K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Fruit when it first grows forth, (AHn, K,) in its fresh, juicy, state. (AHn, TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) The seeds, (M, TA,) or envelope, or receptacle, of the seeds, (K,) of the kaEaAbiyr [app. meaning the round and compact pericarps (in some of the copies of the K, erroneously, as is observed in the TA, EkAbyr,)] that are at the heads of branches. (M, K.) ― -b5- (tropical:) A tumour in a camel's hump; and in the withers; so called by way of comparison [to a whelp]: (TA:) and in the fauces. (K.) ― -b6- See also what next follows, last sentence.

jirowapN jr jrI jrwh jrwp
jirowapN: see jirowN, in three places. A huntsman beat, or disciplined, or trained, his dog for the purpose of the chase (Darabahu EalaI AlSRayodi); and thereupon it was said, Daraba jirowatahu [app. meaning He beat, or disciplined, or trained, his whelp]: and hence this phrase became proverbially used, in instances here following. (Z, TA.) ― -b2- I. q. nafosN [as meaning Self]. (TA.) You say, Daraba Ealayohi jirowatahu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He disposed and subjected himself to it; (S, TA;) namely, a thing, an affair, or a case: and he endured it with patience: and in like manner, Daraba jirowapa nafosihi: (TA:) and OaloqaI fulaAnN jrowatahu he endured the thing with patience. (S, TA.) Also Darabotu jirowatiI Eanohu (assumed tropical:) I endured with patience the want, or loss, of it: (TA:) or my mind became at ease [respecting it]. (AA, IB, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also (K, TA, [in the CK jirowN↓,]) (tropical:) A short she-camel. (K, TA.)

mujorK mjr
mujorK and mujoriyapN applied to a bitch, (S, K,) and a female beast of prey, (TA,) Having a whelp, or young one: (K:) or having with her her whelps, or young ones. (S.) El-Aalam says,
laHomiI UilaI OajorK HawaAXibo
watajurRu mujoriyapN lahaA
And a hyena having young ones shall drag for her my flesh to young ones with swollen bellies, and short. (Skr p. 57.)

1 jaraI jr jrI jry
1. jaraI, said of water (S, Mgh, Msb) &c., (S,) or of water and the like, (K,) more properly thus, as in the K, aor.
jariIa
, (TA,) inf. n. jaroIN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jarayaAnN (S, K) and jiroyapN, (S, * Msb, K,) [which last see below,] It ran, or passed along quickly; originally said of water: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or it flowed;; syn. saAla; contr. of waqafa and sakana. (Msb.) ― -b2- Said also of farina, in the phrase jaraI AldRaqiyqu fiI AlsRunobuli [The farina pervaded the ears of wheat]. (L in art. qmH.) ― -b3- And of a horse (Mgh, Msb, K) and the like, (Msb, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. jaroIN (Msb, K) and jarayaAnN (Msb) and jiraMCN (Lth, K) and majorFI, (S,) [He ran;] from the same verb said of water. (Mgh) ― -b4- And of a ship: you say, jarati AlsRafiynapN, (S, TA,) inf. n. jaroIN (TA) and majorFI, (S, K,) [The ship ran.] ― -b5- And of the sun, and a star: you say, jarati AlXRamosu, aor.
jariIa
, inf. n. jaroIN, [The sun pursued its course:] and jarati AlnRujuwmu The stars travelled, or passed along, from east to west. (TA.) ― -b6- jaraI UilaI kacaA, (Msb, and Har p. 152,) inf. n. jaroIN and jiraMCN; (Msb;) and Uilayohi AjrI↓, inf. n. UijoraMCN; (Ham p. 224, and Har p. 152;) He betook, or directed, himself to such a thing; made it his object; aimed at it; intended, or purposed, it: (Msb, and Har ubi suprà:) and he hastened to it: (Msb:) but in the latter phrase, an objective complement is understood; and it is used in relation to something disapproved, or disliked; (Ham and Har;) properly, AjrI fiEolahu Uilayoh, (Ham,) or AjrI fiEolahu biAlqaSodi Uilayohi. (Har.) ― -b7- Hence, perhaps, the saying, jaraI AlxilaAfu fiI kacaA (tropical:) [frequently used as meaning A controversy ran, or ran on, respecting such a thing between such and such persons]. (Msb.) ― -b8- jaraI lahu AlXRaIoCu, (Sh, TA,) and jaraI Ealayohi, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The thing was permanent, or continued, to him. (Sh, TA.) [And, more commonly, (assumed tropical:) The thing happened, or occurred, to him. Whence, maAjarayaAtN↓, as pl. of maAjaraI, used as a single word, by late writers, meaning (assumed tropical:) Events, or occurrences.] ― -b9- huwa yajoriI majoraAhu (assumed tropical:) It is like it, or similar to it, in state, condition, case, or predicament. (TA.) [It (a word or phrase) follows the same rule or rules, or occupies the same grammatical place, as it (another word or phrase). And similar to this is the saying,] mujaAraApa AlmabiyEi AldRayonu waAlrRahonu yatajaArayaAni↓ wAlvRamani (assumed tropical:) [The debt and the pledge are subject to the same laws as the thing sold and the price]. (Mgh.) ― -b10- [Also (assumed tropical:) It acts as, or in a similar manner to, it: and (assumed tropical:) he acts in his stead: see jariIRN. Hence the phrase, jaraI minohu majoraI kacaA (assumed tropical:) It acted upon him, or affected him, like, or in a similar manner to, such a thing: as in the prov.,] jaraI minohu majoraI AllRaduwdi (assumed tropical:) [It acted upon him, or affected him, like, or similarly to, the medicine, or draught, called ldwd: mnh here having the meaning of fiyhi]. (ISk, S in art. ld.) ― -b11- [One says, also, of an inf. n., and of a part. n., that is regularly formed, yajoriI EalaI AlfiEoli, meaning (assumed tropical:) It is conformable to the verb.]

2 jrRI jr jrI jry
2. jrRI He sent a deputy, or commissioned agent; as also AjirI↓. (K.) And jrRI jariyRFA He made, or appointed, a deputy, or commissioned agent; (ISk, S, * TA;) as also AstjrAhu↓. (S, * TA.) Hence the trad., (TA,) laA yasotajoriyanRakumu↓ AlXRayoTiAnu (S, TA) By no means let the Devil make you his followers and his commissioned agents. (TA.) You say also, fiI HaAjatihi AjrAhu↓ [He sent him to accomplish his needful affair]. (TA.)

3 jArAhu jAr jArAh jArAp jArI
3. jArAhu, inf. n. mujaAraApN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jiraMCN, (S, K,) He ran with him. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) You say, jaArayotuhu HatRaI futRuhu I ran with him until I passed beyond him, or outwent him. (TA in art. fwt.) ― -b2- [He vied, contended, or competed, with him in running: and hence, (assumed tropical:) in any affair; like saAyarahu.] You say, jArAhu fiI kacaA wafaEala mivola fiEolihi (assumed tropical:) [He vied, contended, or competed, with him in such an affair, and did like as he did]. (Mgh in art. fwD.) And jArAhu fiI AlHadiyvi (assumed tropical:) [He vied, contended, or competed, with him in discourse]. (S.) And jaArawoA fiI AlHadiyvi (TA) and tajaArawoA↓ fiyhi (S, TA) (assumed tropical:) [They vied, contended, or competed, one with another, in discourse]. And it is said in a trad., mano Talaba AlEiloma liyujaAriIa bihi AlEulamaMCa (assumed tropical:) He who seeks knowledge in order that he may run [i. e. vie] with the learned in discussion and disputation, to show his knowledge to others, to be seen and heard. (TA.) And in another trad., laA tujaAri OaxaAka walaA tuXaArihi walaA tumaArihi (assumed tropical:) [Contend not for superiority with thy brother, (so explained in the TA, voce jaArRa, in art. jr,) nor dispute with him, nor wrangle with him]: (El-Jámi'-es- Sagheer:) or, as some relate it, laA tujaArRi OaxaAka walaA tuXaArRihi. (TA in art. jr, q. v.)

4 AjrAhu Ojr OjrAh OjrI AjrAh AjrAp Mjr MjrAh
4. AjrAhu He made it to run; (S, K, * TA;) said of water &c., (S,) or of water and the like. (K, * TA.) [Hence, AjrI damoEFA, or dumuwEFA, He shed tears.] ― -b2- Also He made him to run; namely, a horse (Mgh, Msb, K *) and the like: (Msb, K: *) in which sense mujorFI [as well as UijoraMCN] is used as an inf. n. (S.) ― -b3- AjrI AlsRafiynapa [He made the ship to run]: (S:) in this sense, also, mujorFI [as well as UijoraMCN] is used as an inf. n. (S, K.) ― -b4- AjrI as syn. with jrRI; and AjrAhu fiI HaAjatihi: see 2. ― -b5- AjrI Uilayohi: see 1. ― -b6- Oajorayotu Ealayohi [and lahu] (assumed tropical:) I made a thing permanent, or continual, to him. (IAar, TA.) [And hence, both of these phrases, in the present day, (assumed tropical:) I made him, or appointed him, a permanent, or regular, allowance of bread &c.; I provided for him, or maintained him.] ― -b7- [AjrAhu mujoraI kacaA (assumed tropical:) He made it to be like, or similar to, such a thing in state, condition, case, or predicament. (assumed tropical:) He made it (a word or phrase) to follow the same rule or rules, or to occupy the same grammatical place, as such another. (assumed tropical:) He made it to act as, or in a
similar manner to, such a thing.] ― -b8- [Hence,] AisomN laA yajoraI i. q. laA yanoSarifu (assumed tropical:) [A noun that is imperfectly declinable]. (TA in art. Smt, &c.) ＝ -A2- Oajorato said of a herb, or leguminous plant, (baqolapN,) mentioned in this art. in the K: see art. jrw.

6 tajaArawoA fiI AlHadiyvi tjArwA fy AlHdyv
6. tajaArawoA fiI AlHadiyvi: see 3. Hence, in a trad., tatajaAraI bihimu AlOahowaMCu (assumed tropical:) [Natural desires, or blamable inclinations, or erroneous opinions, contend with them for the mastery: or] they vie, or compete, one with another, in natural desires, &c. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1.

10 AstjrAhu AstjrAh AstjrAp
10. AstjrAhu He demanded, or desired, that he should run. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 2, in two places.

laA jara lA jr
laA jara and laA caA jara, for laA jarama and laA caA jarama: see art. jrm.

jurapN jr jrh jrp
jurapN and jaraAyapN↓: see 1 in art. jrU.

jarFI jr jrI jry
jarFI: see jaraOCN ＝ -A2- faEalotuhu mino jaraAka, and mn jaraAYika↓, I did it because of thee, or of thine act; on thine account; or for thy sake; i. q. mn Oajolika; like mn jarRaAka [which see in art. jr]. (S, K.)

jiroyapN jry jryh jryp
jiroyapN i. q. jaroIN as inf. n. of jaraI said of water (Msb, K) and the like: (K:) and also A mode, or manner, of running [thereof]. (TA.) You say, maA OaXadRa jiroyapa hecaA AlmaMCi [How vehement is the running, or manner of running, of this water!]. (S.)

jaraMCN jrMC
jaraMCN and jiraMCN↓ (S, K) and jarFI↓ (K) and jaraAyapN↓ (S, K) and jaraAYiyapN↓ (IAar, K, TA, [in the CK jiraAyapN]) Girlhood; the state of a jaAriyap. (S, K.) One says, kaAna celika fiI OayRaAmi jaraAYihaA That was in the days of her girlhood. (S.) ＝ -A2- faEalotuhu mino jaraAYika: see jaraI.

jiraMCN jrMC
jiraMCN: see the next preceding paragraph.

jariIRN jr jrI jry
jariIRN A commissioned agent; a factor; a deputy: (S, Mgh, K:) because he runs in the affairs of him who appoints him, (Mgh,) or acts in his stead (yajoriI majoraAhu): (S, Mgh:) [in this and other senses following] used alike as sing. and pl., and also as [masc. and] fem.: (K:) but sometimes, though rarely, jariyRapN is used for the fem., accord. to AHát; and accord. to J [in the S, and Mtr in the Mgh], it has OajoriyaMCu for its pl. (TA.) And A messenger, or person sent, (S, K,) that runs in an affair. (TA.) But accord. to Er-Rághib, it is weaker [in signification, or in point of chasteness,] than rasuwlN and wakiylN [which are given as its syns. in the S and K]. (TA.) ― -b2- A servant. (TA.) ― -b3- A hired man; a hireling. (Kr, K.) ― -b4- A surety; a guarantee; one who is responsible, accountable, or answerable, for another. (IAar, K.) ＝ -A2- The word signifying “ bold, ” or “ daring, ” is jariIoCN, with C. (S.)

jaraAyapN jrAyh jrAyp
jaraAyapN: see jiraAyapN: ＝ -A2- and jaraMCN: ＝ -A3- and jurapN.

jiraAyapN jrAyh jrAyp
jiraAyapN The office of a jariIR, i. e. a commissioned agent, factor, or deputy; (S, K;) and of a messenger: (S:) as also jaraAyapN↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A running [or permanent] daily allowance of food or the like. (S, TA.) [Hence, in the present day, xubozu jiraAyapK Bread made of inferior flour, for servants and other dependants.]

jaraAYiyapN c
jaraAYiyapN: see jaraMCN

jiriyRaMCu jryMC
jiriyRaMCu: see UijoriyRaA

jirRiIRN jr jrI jry
jirRiIRN [The eel;] a certain fish, well known. (K: mentioned also in art. jr, q. v.)

jirRiyRapN jry jryh jryp
jirRiyRapN, like qirRiyRapN, (S,) The stomach, or triple stomach, or the crop, or craw, of a bird; syn. HawoSalapN: (S, K: mentioned also in art. jr, q. v.:) so called because the food at the last runs into it, or because it is the channel through which the food runs: (Er-Rághib, TA:) thus pronounced by Fr, and by Th on the authority of Ibn-Nejdeh, without C: by Ibn-Háni, [jirRiyoYapN,] with C, on the authority of AZ. (TA.)

jaArK jAr jAry
jaArK applied to water [and the like], [Running, or flowing, or] pressing forward, in a downward and in a level course. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also, [as meaning Running,] applied to a horse and the like. (Msb.) ― -b3- SadaqapN jaAriyapN (assumed tropical:) A permanent, continuous, charitable donation; such as the unalienable legacies provided for various benevolent purposes. (TA.)

jaAriyapN jAr jAry jAryh jAryp
jaAriyapN A ship; (S, Msb, K;) because of its running upon the sea: (Msb:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates: pl. jawaArK (TA.) ― -b2- The sun; (K;) because of its running from region to region: (TA:) or the sun's disk in the sky. (T, TA.) And AljawaAriI AlkunRasu The stars. (TA. [But see art. kns.]) ― -b3- The wind: pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b4- A girl, or young woman; (S, * Mgh, Msb, * K;) a female of which the male is termed gulaAmN; so called because of her activity and running; opposed to EajuwzN: (Mgh:) and (tropical:) a female slave; (Mgh voce gulaAmN;) [in this sense] applied even to one who is an old woman, unable to work, or to employ herself actively; alluding to what she was: (Msb:) pl. as above. (Msb, K.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) The eye of any animal. (TA.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A benefit, favour, boon, or blessing, bestowed by God (K, TA) upon his servants. (TA.)

UijoriIRN Ojr OjrI Ojrp Ojry Ojryy AjrI Ajry jrI
UijoriIRN A kind of running: pl. OajaAriIRu. (TA.) You say farasN cuwOajaAriIRa A horse that has several kinds of running. (TA.) ― -b2- See also UijoriyRaA.

UijoriyRapN Ojr OjrI Ojry Ojryh Ojryp Ajryh Ajryp jrI
UijoriyRapN: see what next follows.

UijoriyaAhu OjrI Ojry OjryAh AjryAh AjryAp
UijoriyaAhu: see what next follows.

UijoriyRaA OjrI Ojry OjryA AjryA
UijoriyRaA The act of running: (S, and so in some copies of the K: [in this sense, erroneously said in the TA to be btxfyf:]) or UijoriIRN↓. (So in this sense in some copies of the K.) ― -b2- Also, (S, K,) and UijoriyRaMCu↓, (K,) (assumed tropical:) A custom, or habit, (S,) or manner, (K,) that one adopts (S, K) and follows; (K;) [like hijoriyRaA &c.;] and so UijoriyaMCu↓ without teshdeed: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) nature, constitution, or natural disposition; [in the CK, Alxaloqu is erroneously put for Alxuluqu;] as also jiriyRaMCu↓ and UijoriyRapN↓. (K.) One says, Alkaramu mino UijriyRaAhu and mn UijoriyRaAYihi↓ (assumed tropical:) Generosity is [a quality] of his nature, &c. (Lh, TA.)

UijoriyRaMCu AjryMC
UijoriyRaMCu: see what next precedes, in two places.

majorFI mjr mjrI mjry mjryy
majorFI [A place, and a time, of running, &c.]. The channel of a river [and of a torrent &c.: a conduit; a duct; any passage through which a fluid runs: pl. majaArK]. (TA.) ― -b2- Also an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (S, K, &c.)

mujorK mjr
mujorK [Making to run]. It is said in a prov., kulRu mujorK fiI AlxalaMCi yusarRu [Every one who makes his horse to run in the solitary place rejoices, because no one can contradict his account of his horse's fleetness]. (Mgh.) [See Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 315 and 316, where two other readings are added: klR mjr bixalaMCK mujiydN, i. e., is possessor of a fleet horse; and klR mjr bixalaMCK saAbiqN, i. e., is one who outstrips.]

maAjarayaAtN mAjryAt
maAjarayaAtN: see 1.

1 jazRa jz
1. jazRa, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
jazuza
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. jazRN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and jazRapN↓, (K,) [but the latter seems to be an inf. n. of un.,] He cut (Mgh, Msb, K) wool, (IDrd, S, Mgh, Msb,) [see Halaqa,] and, as some say, other things, (Msb,) or a dense thing, (Mgh,) or hair, (A, K,) and dry herbage, (K,) and seed-produce, (A,) and wheat, (S,) and palm-trees, (S, ISd, A, Mgh,) meaning their fruit; (Mgh;) as also AjtzR↓. (K.) You say, AlXRiyHa wagayorahu Aijotazazotu↓, and Aijodazazotuhu↓, in the sense of jazazotuhu [I cut the sheeh, a species of wormwood, &c.]. (S.) You say also, jazazotu AlkaboXa wAlnRaEojapa, [I shore, or sheared, the ram and the ewe]; but of the she-goat and he-goat you say, HalaqotuhumaA. (TA.) And jazRa AlnRaxolapa, (Lh, A, Mgh,) aor.
jazuza
, inf. n. jazRN and jazaAzN and jizaAzN, (Lh, TA,) [like jacRa and jadRa,] He cut off the fruit of the palm-tree. (Mgh, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 4, in four places.

2 jzRr jzr jzyrp
2. jzRr, inf.n. tajoziyzN, He dried dates. (Msb.)

4 AjzR 8
4. AjzR It attained to the proper time for being cut; (S, Msb, TA;) said [app. of wool, and] of hair, and of herbage, (A,) and wheat, (AZ, S, Msb,) and barley; (AZ, Msb;) as also AstjzR↓, (S, Msb, K,) said of wool, (Msb,) and of wheat; (S, K;) and jazRa↓, [aor., app.,
jaziza
, as below,] said of wheat. (TA.) ― -b2- AjzR AliXRyHu The sheeh [a species of wormwood] attained to the proper time for being cut: (L, TA:) or AjzR AlXRayoxu (assumed tropical:) The old man attained to the proper time for dying. (K.) [SM says,] AlXRayoxu seems to be a mistranscription, for AlXRiyHu: if not, it is a tropical expression. (TA.) [But see 4 in art. jzr, and 8 in art. xDr.] ― -b3- AjzR Alganamu The sheep attained to the proper time for being shorn; (S, TA;) as also jazRa↓. (TA.) ― -b4- AjzR AlnRaxolu The palm-trees attained to the proper time for having their fruit cut off;
(S, K, TA;) as also jazRa↓. (K.) ― -b5- [Hence, app.,] AjzR AltRamoru The dates dried; (S, K;) as also jazRa↓, aor.
jaziza
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. juzuwzN, (S, K,) or jazRN: (Msb:) you say tamorN fiyhi juzuwzN Dates in which is dryness. (S, TA.) ― -b6- AjzR Alqawomu The people attained to the proper time for the shearing of their sheep: (K:) or had their sheep shorn: or had their seed-produce cut. (S, L.) ＝ -A2- AjzR AlrRajula He assigned to the man the jizRap [or wool, &c.,] of a sheep. (K.)

8 AjtzR c and AjczR
8. AjtzR AjczR: see 1, in three places.

10 Uisotajozaza
10: see 4.

juzRN OjAz Ojz OjzI Ajz jAz jz jzI wjz
juzRN i. q. juzoCN. (Bd in xv. 44.)

jazRapN jz jzh jzp
jazRapN [A single cutting, or shearing, or the like.]. (K.) See 1.

jizRapN jz jzh jzp
jizRapN [A mode, or manner, of cutting, or shearing, or the like]. You say, jazRahu jzRapF HasanapF [He cut it, or sheared it, &c., in a good manner]. (K, TA.) [in the CK, wajizRapF is omitted after wajazRapF; so that the reading there is jazRapF HasanapF.] ＝ -A2- Also, (S, K,) and jazazN↓ and juzaAzN↓ and juzaAzapN↓, (K,) What is cut, of dates: (K:) or [a fleece; i. e.,] the wool of a sheep [shorn] in one year: (S, K:) [and the hair of a goat, and of a camel, (see timRapN,) when shorn; a shorn crop of wool, and of goat's hair, and of camel's hair:] or the wool of a ewe, (K, TA,) or of a ram, (TA,) when shorn, and not mixed with any other: (K, TA:) so accord. to AHát: (TA:) or wool not used after being shorn; (K;) in which last sense you say also SuwfN jazazN↓: (TA:) pl. jizazN and jazaAYizu: (Lh, K:) the latter like DaraAYiru as pl. of OaqoriDoniI jizRapF, without regard to the difference of the vowels [in the sing.]. (TA.) One says to another, Oawo jizRatayoni kaOanRahu EaADRN EalaI jizRapK [Lend thou me the wool of a sheep, or of two sheep]; and the latter gives him the wool of a sheep, or of two sheep. (S.) And one says of a man with a large beard, EalaI jazRapK [As though he were biting] the wool of a shorn sheep. (K, TA: in the CK, jazazN.)

jazazN jzp jzz
jazazN: see jizRapN, in two places.

jazaAzN jzAz
jazaAzN and jizaAzN↓ The act of cutting, or shearing, wool, (Mgh, * Msb,) and hair; (Mgh;) and of reaping; (Fr, S, K;) and of cutting seed-produce (Mgh, K) before it has attained to maturity; (K;) and of cutting off the fruit of palm-trees: (Fr, S, Mgh:) and the time, or season, of shearing sheep [and the like]. (TA.) You say, hecaA zamanu AljazaAzi, and AljizaAzi, This is the time of cutting, or shearing, wool: (Msb:) and of reaping: and of cutting off the fruit of palm-trees. (S.)

juzaAzN jzAz
juzaAzN What one cuts, or cuts off, of anything; (K;) the cuttings of wool or any other thing: n. un. with p: (TA:) [as, for instance,] what is redundant of a skin or hide when it is cut: (K:) or juzaAzapN↓ signifies what falls from a skin or hide (S, A) or other thing (S) when it is cut. (S, A.) See also jizRapN.

jizaAzN jzAz
jizaAzN: see jazaAzN

jazuwzN jzwz
jazuwzN What is cut, or shorn; a masc. n.; and, as also jazuwzapN↓, fem.: (K:) or the latter signifies sheep of which the wool is shorn; (S, A;) and is similar to rakuwabpN, and HaluwbapN and EaluwfapN: (S:) Th says that a subst. of this class is only with p, like the three words just mentioned: Lh says that it may be with p and without p; and that the pl. in both cases is of the measures fuEulN and faEaAYilu: [in this instance, juzuzN and jazaAYizu:] but ISd says, I hold that fuEulN is the measure of the pl. of a subst. of this class without p, such as rakuwbN, of which the pl. is rukubN; and faEaAYilu, of that which is with rakaAYibu, such as rakuwbapN, of which the pl. is rakaAYibu. (TA.)

jaziyzN jzyz
jaziyzN and majozuwzN↓ Cut, or shorn. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also jaziyzapN.

juzaAzapN jzAz jzAzh jzAzp
juzaAzapN: see jizRapN: ― -b2- and juzaAzN.

jazuwzapN jzwzh jzwzp
jazuwzapN: see jazuwzN.

jaziyzapN jzyzh jzyzp
jaziyzapN A flock, or tuft, of wool; as also jizojizapN↓; (S, K;) which [latter] is a tuft of wool, or of wool dyed of various colours, (EihonapN,) that is hung upon a woman's camel-vehicle (hawodaj): (S:) or the latter signifies a tuft of wool tied with threads or strings, with which the woman's camel-vehicle (hwdj) is ornamented: and jazaAYizu [pl. of the former] and jazaAjizu [pl. of the latter] signify tufts of dyed wool which are hung upon the camel-vehicles (hawaAdij) of women on the day of going forth on a journey; also called vukanN: or jazaAYizu, (TA,) or jaziyzN↓, (L,) signifies a kind of beads (xaraz) with which the girls, or slave-girls, (jawaArK,) of the Arabs of the desert are adorned, resembling jazoE: or tufts of wool, or of wool dyed of various colours, (EihonN,) which were used in the place of anklets. (TA.)

jizojizapN jzjzh jzjzp
jizojizapN: see jaziyzapN.

mijazRN mjz
mijazRN An instrument for cutting or shearing. (S.)

majozuwzN mjzwz
majozuwzN: see jaziyzN.

1 jazaOahu c
1. jazaOahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jazaAa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. jazoCN, (S,) He divided it (a thing, S) into parts, or portions; (S, K;) made it to consist of parts, or portions; (S, Msb;) as also jzROhu↓, (S, * Msb, K,) inf. n. tajoziYapN, (S,) or tajoziIoCN: (Msb:) when that which is divided is property, as, for instance, slaves, only this latter form of the verb, with teshdeed, is used. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, aor. and inf.n. as above, He took a part, or portion, of it; namely, a thing. (Ham p. 117.) And jazaOa AlXRiEora, inf. n. as above; and jzROhu↓; He curtailed the poetry of two feet in each verse: or he made the poetry to consist of two feet in each verse. (TA. [See majozuwoCN.]) ＝ -A2- Also He made it firm, fast, or strong; or he bound it firmly, fast, or strongly; (XadRahu;) namely, a thing. (K.) ＝ -A3- jazaOa bihi, (S, K,) aor.
jazaAa
, (TA,) inf. n. jazoCN, (S,) [and app. juzoCN also,] He was, or became, satisfied, or content, with it; namely, a thing; (S, K;) as also jaziICa, a dial. var. mentioned by IAar; (TA;) and bh AjtzO↓, (S, Msb, K,) and bh tjzRO↓. (S, K.) A poet says,
waUinRa AlmaroCa yajozaOu biAlkuraAEi
[And verily the man is satisfied, or content, with the shank of the sheep or goat &c.]. (TA.) And you say TaEaAmN laA jazoCa lahu Food whereof one is not satisfied with a little. (TA.) And lahu fiI hecaA ganaMCN wajuzoCN [He has, in this, competence and] sufficiency. (Mgh.) And jazaOati AlUibilu biAlrRuTobi Eani AlmaMCi, (S, Mgh, K,) or [simply] jazaOati AlUibilu, (Har p. 475,) inf. n. juzoCN, with damm, (S, TA,) and juzuwoCN; (TA;) and jaziYat, (IAar, K,) and AjtzOt↓; (Mgh, and Har ubi suprà;) The camels were satisfied, or content, with green, or fresh, pasture or herbage [so as to be in no need of water]. (S, Mgh, K, TA.) And Eani QmoraOatihi AjtzO↓ [He was content to abstain from, or be without, conjugal intercourse with his wife]. (M in art. Abl.)

2 jazRaAa
2: see 1, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also 4.

4 AjzOhu c
4. AjzOhu It (a thing) satisfied, sufficed, or contented, him. (S, Mgh, K.) [Hence,] AjzO mujozaI gayorihi [or mujozaOa gayorihi] It (a thing) satisfied, sufficed, or contented, in lieu of another thing or other things; stood, or served, in stead thereof. (Msb.) And OajozaOotu Eanoka mujozaOa fulaAnK (S, Mgh, K) and majozaOa flAn and mujozaOapa flAn and majozaOapa flAn, (S, K,) as also mujozaI flAn and mujozaApa flAn without C and with damm, and majozaI flAn and majozaApa flAn, (K in art. jzI,) I satisfied, sufficed, or con tented, thee as such a one; I stood thee, or served thee, in stead of such a one. (S, Mgh, K.) And AjzO AlUibila biAlrRuTobi Eani AlmaMCi, (S, K,) inf. n. UijozaMCN; (TA;) and jzROhA↓, (S, K,) inf. n. tajoziYapN, (S,) or tajoziIoCN; (TA;) He satisfied, or contented, the camels with green, or fresh, pasture or hesrbage [so that they were in no need of water]. (S, K.) ― -b2- AjzO is also syn. with jazaI; the former being of the dial. of Temeem, and the latter of the dial. of El-Hijáz; (Akh, Msb;) and one may suppress the C, and say OajozaI: (Mgh, Msb:) this last is used by some of the lawyers in the sense of [jazaI, i. e.] qaDaI. (Az, Mgh, Msb.) One says, OajozaOatN Eanoka XaApN A sheep, or goat, made satisfaction for thee (S, Msb, * K, TA) as a sacrifice; (TA;) syn. qaDato; (S, Msb, K;) the verb being here a dial. var. of jazato. (S, K.) And Albadanapu tajoziYu Eano saboEapK The camel, or cow, makes satisfaction for seven: or serves in stead of seven. (Mgh.) And hecaA yujoziY uEano hecaA [This will make satisfaction, for this: or this will serve in stead of this]: and, accord. to 'Alee Ibn-'Eesà, yujoziI also, suppressing the C (Mgh.) ― -b3- Also, said of pasture, or herbage, (K, TA,) and of a meadow, (TA,) (tropical:) It was, or became, luxuriant: (K, TA:) because satisfying the beasts that feed upon it. (TA.) ― -b4- And, said of a company of men, They had their camels satisfied with green, or fresh, pasture or herbage [so that they were in no need of water]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- OajozaOato She (a woman) brought forth
females. (K. [But see juzoCN, from which it is derived.]) ＝ -A3- AjzO He furnished an awl (mixoSaf, S, K, or UiXofaI, S), (S, K,) or a knife, (Msb,) with a juzoOap, i. e. handle; (S, Msb, K;) as also AjzI. (Msb.) ― -b2- AjzO AlxaAtama fiIUiSobaEihi He put the ring upon his finger. (K.)

5 tjzRO c
5. tjzRO It became divided into parts, or portions. (Msb, KL.) ＝ -A2- See also 1.

8 UijotazaAa
8: see 1, in three places.

jazoCN jzC
jazoCN: see juzoCN. ＝ -A2- It is said by El-Khattábee to be a name for ruTb [app. meaning ruTobN, i. e. Green, or fresh, pasture or herbage, (see 1 and 4,)], with the people of El-Medeeneh; and occurs in a trad.; but the reading commonly known is jrw. (TA.)

juzoCN jzC
juzoCN A part, or portion, (Msb, K, TA,) or division, (TA,) of a thing; (Msb, TA;) properly and conventionally; (TA;) as also jazoCN↓; (K;) a constituent part of a thing, as of a ship, and of a house or tent, and of a sum in reckoning; (B, TA;) [an ingredient of any compound or mixture;] a share, or lot: (TA:) pl. OajozaMCN: (S, Msb, K, &c.:) it has no other pl. (Sb, TA.) ― -b2- [A volume of a book.] ― -b3- A foot of a verse. (TA.) ― -b4- In the Kur [xliii. 14], where it is said, wajaEaluwA lahu mino EibaAdihi juzoCFA, (K, TA,) or, as some read, juzuCFA, (Bd,) it means Females; (K, TA;;) i. e., they asserted the angels to be the daughters of God: so says Th: and Aboo-Is-hák says that it means, they asserted God's share of offspring to be the females; but that he had not found this in old poetry, nor had persons worthy of confidence related it on the authority of the Arabs [of the classical times]: Z disallows it, asserting it to be a lie against the Arabs; and Bd follows him: El-Khafájee says that the word may be used figuratively; for, as Eve was created of a part (juzoC) of Adam, the word jzC may be applied to denote the female. (MF, TA.)

juzoOapN c
juzoOapN The handle of the [kind of awl called] mixoSaf, (S, K,) and of the UiXofiI: (S:) AZ says that it is not [the handle, or hilt,] of the sword, nor of the dagger; but is the handle of the miYovarap with which camels' feet are branded. (TA.) [See also DabRapN.] ― -b2- A vine-prop; (K, TA;) a piece of wood with which a vine is raised from the ground. (TA.) ― -b3- In the dial. of the tribe of Sheybán, The hinder, or hindermost, XuqRap [or oblong piece of cloth] of a tent. (TA.)

juzoYiIRN c
[juzoYiIRN Relating to a part or portion or division; partial; particular; contr. of kulRiIRN. ― -b2- And, as a subst., A particular: pl. juzoYiyRaAtN.]

juzoYiyRapN c
[juzoYiyRapN The quality of relating to a part or portion or division; relation to a part &c.; particularity.]

jaziIoCN jzIC jzyC jzY
jaziIoCN Satisfying food; as also mujoziYN↓; (Fr, K;) like XabiyEN and muXobiEN. (Fr, TA.)

jaAziYN c
jaAziYN [act. part. n. of 1]. ― -b2- hecaA rajulN jaAziYuka mino rajulK This is a man sufficing thee as a man. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- ZaboyapN jaAziYapN A doe-gazelle that is satisfied with green, or fresh, pasture or herbage [so as to be in no need of water]: pl. jawaAziYu. (S.) The pl. is explained by IKt as meaning Gazelles: (TA:) [or] it signifies [or signifies also] Wild bulls or cows; (K, TA;) because they are satisfied with green, or fresh, pasture or herbage so as to be in no need of water. (TA.) Also, the pl., Palm-trees; as not needing irrigation. (TA.)

OajozaOu c
OajozaOu More [and most] satisfying or sufficing or satisfactory: hence, AlfaArisu OajozaOu mina AlrRaAjili [The horseman is more satisfactory than the footman]. (Mgh.)

majozaON c
majozaON and mujozaON are used as inf. ns. of 4 [q. v.]. (TA.)

mujoziYN c
mujoziYN: see jaziIoCN. ― -b2- Also A strong, fat, camel; because sufficing for the wants of the rider and carrier. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, and mujoziYapN, A woman who brings forth females. (TA. [But see juzoCN, from which the verb is derived.])

majozaOapN c
majozaOapN and mujozaOapN are used as inf. ns. of 4 [q. v.]. (TA.)

majozuwoCN mjz mjzwC
majozuwoCN Divided into parts, or portions. (TA.) ― -b2- [Having a part, or portion, taken from it: see 1.] ― -b3- A verse curtailed of two [of the original] feet: [like the hazaj and muDaAriE &c., which were originally of six feet each, but of which every known example is of four only:] or a verse consisting of two feet only: [as a kind of the rajaz, and two kinds of the munosariH: to each of which, or, accord. to some, to the former of which only, when thus consisting of only two feet, the term manohuwkN is also applied:] the former is said to be EalaI AlsRalobi; and the latter, EalaI Alwujuwbi. (TA.)

1 jazara jzr jzyrp
1. jazara, aor.
jazira
and sometimes
jazura
, (K,) inf. n. jazorN, (Mgh, K,) He cut, or cut off, (Mgh, K,) a thing. (TA.) ― -b2- jazara, (S, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
jazura
, (S, Msb,) [inf. n. as above,] He slaughtered a camel (S, Mgh, Msb) or other animal, (Msb,) and skinned it; (S;) as also Ajtzr↓. (S, TA.) You say also, jazara lahumo, meaning He slaughtered for them a camel. (A.) And Alqawoma jazuwrFA Ajtzr↓ He slaughtered and skinned for the people a camel. (TA.) ― -b3- jazara AlnRaxola, aor.
jazira
(S, K) and
jazura
, (K,) inf. n. jazorN (S, K) and jazaArN and jizaArN, (Lh, K,) He cut off the fruit of the palm-trees: (Lh, S, K:) or, as some say, he spoiled the palm-trees in fecundating them. (TA.) ― -b4- And jazara, (TA,) inf. n. jazorN, (K,) He gathered honey from the hive. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- jazara, aor.
jazira
and
jazura
, inf. n. jazorN, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) (tropical:) It (water) sank, and disappeared; became low; or became remote; (S, K;) decreased; went away; (TA;) flowed away, or retired, (A, Mgh, * Msb,) from the earth, or land: (A, Mgh:) it (the sea, and a river, Lth, ISd) ebbed; contr. of madRa; (S, ISd, K; [but in this last sense, only
jazira
is authorized by the K, and app. by ISd also, as the aor.;]) i. e., retreated, or went back; (S. Msb; *) as also Anjzr↓; (ISd, TA;) or ceased to increase. (Lth, Mgh.)

4 Ajzrhu Ojzrh Ajzrh Ajzrp jzr
4. Ajzrhu, (K,) or Ajzr Alqawoma, (ISk, S,) He gave to him, or to the people, a sheep or a goat, for him, or for them, to slaughter; (ISk, S, K;) meaning a ewe or a ram or a she-goat; (ISk, S;) or a sheep, or goat, fit for slaughter: (TA:) and Oajozarotuhu XaApF I gave to him a ewe or a ram or a she-goat, and he slaughtered it: (ISk, TA:) and Oajozarotuka baEiyrFA, or XaApF, I gave to thee a camel, or a sheep or goat, that thou mightest slaughter it: (A:) [but] accord. to ISk, one does not say Oajozarotuhumo naAqapF, because a she-camel is fit for other purposes than that of slaughter: (S:) and accord. to some, one should not say Ajzrhu jazuwrFA, but Ajzrhu jazarapF. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Ajzr He (a camel) attained to the fit time for his being slaughtered. (S, K.) ― -b2- Ajzr AlnRaxolu The palm-trees attained to the fit time for the cutting off of the fruit. (S, K.) ― -b3- [And hence,] Ajzr AlXayoxu (tropical:) The old man attained to the fit time for his dying; (K, TA;) being aged, and near to his perishing; like as the palm-tree attains to the fit time for having its fruit cut off. (TA.) Youths used to say to an old man Oajozarota yaA Xayoxu, meaning, Thou hast attained to the fit time for thy dying, O old man: and he would say, OaIo baniIRa watuHotaDaruwna, i. e., “ [O my sons, and] ye shall die youths: ” but accord. to one way of relation, it is Oajozazota; from OajazRa AlburRu “ the wheat attained to the proper time for being out. ” (S.) ― -b4- Ajzr Alqawomu The people attained to the fit time for the cutting off of the fruit of the palm-trees. (Yz, TA.)

5 tajazRara
5: see 8.

6 tajaAzaraA tjAzrA
6. tajaAzaraA (assumed tropical:) They reviled each other (K, TA) vehemently, or excessively. (TA.)

7 Uinojazara
7: see 1.

8 Ajtzr Ajtzr
8. Ajtzr: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- AjtzrwA fiI AlqitaAli and tjzRrwA↓ (K, TA) They fought one another [app. so that they cut one another in pieces]. (TA.) [In the K, this is immediately followed, as though for the purpose of explanation, by the words tarakuwhumo jazarFA lilsRibaAEi OaIo qiTaEFA: but there is evidently an omission in this place, at least of the conjunction wa.] ― -b3- And AjtzrwA They had a camel slaughtered for them. (A.)

jazorN jzr jzyrp
jazorN inf. n. of 1. (S, K, &c.) ＝ -A2- And also (assumed tropical:) The sea (K, TA) itself. (TA.)

jazarN jzr jzyrp
jazarN, (not jizarN↓, Fr, S, [but see what follows,]) [a coll. gen. n.,] Fat sheep or goats: (S, K, TA:) n. un. jazarapN: (S, K:) or sheep, or goats, that are slaughtered; (M;) as also jazuwrN↓: (K:) n. un. as above: (M: in the K jazorapN:) or jazarapN signifies a sheep, or goat, fit for slaughter: or a sheep, or goat, to which the owners betake themselves and which they slaughter: and anything that is lawful to be slaughtered; n. un. of jazarN, which is sometimes [written jizarN↓,] with fet-h to the z. (TA.) ― -b2- jazaru AlsRibaAEi The flesh which beasts or birds of prey eat. (S, Mgh.) One says, tarakuwhumo jazarFA (S, K) They slew them: (S:) or they left them cut
in pieces lilsRibaAEi [for the beasts or birds of prey]. (K.) And SaAruwA jazarFA liloEaduwRi [They became a prey to the enemy, cut in pieces]. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- See also jaziyrapN. ＝ -A3- Also, and jizRrN↓, (Fr, S, Msb, K,) the latter with kesr to the j, (Msb, K,) arabicized, (K,) from the Persian [Gazaro], (AHn,) [coll. gen. ns., meaning Carrots, or the carrot;] a certain root, (Oaruwmap,) which is eaten, (S, K,) well known: (TA:) n. un. with p; (K;) or jazarapN: (As, S, Msb:) the best kind is the red and sweet, which grows in winter: it is hot in the extreme of the second degree; moist in the first degree; (TA;) diuretic; (K, TA;) lenitive; emollient; (TA;) strengthening to the venereal faculty; emmenagogue: the putting of its pounded leaves upon festering ulcers is advantageous: (K, TA:) it is difficult of digestion; and engenders bad blood; but is made wholesome with vinegar and mustard. (TA.) ― -b2- [See also HinozaAbN, in art. Hzb.]

jizarN jzr jzyrp
jizarN: see jazarN, in three places.

jizaArN jzAr
jizaArN The time of the cutting off of the fruit of palm-trees. (Yz, TA.) [See also 1.]

jazuwrN jzwr
jazuwrN A camel [that is slaughtered, or to be slaughtered]; (K;) applied to the male and the female: (S, Msb:) or (as some say, Sgh, Msb) properly a she-camel that is slaughtered: (Sgh, Msb, K:) but the former is the correct assertion; (TA;) though the word is fem., (IAmb, S, Msb, TA,) on the authority of hearsay; (TA;) therefore you say, raEati AljazuwrC [the camel for slaughter pastured]: (IAmb, Msb:) or when used alone, it is fem., because what are slaughtered are mostly she-camels: (TA:) and when used as a common term, it implies the like of predominance [of the fem. gender]: (Háshiyeh of Esh-Shiháb, TA:) [the shares into which the jzwr is divided in the game called Almayosir are described voce badoCN:] pl. juzurN (S, Msb, K) and jazaAYiru and juzuraAtN, (Msb, K,) the last of which is pl. of juzurN, like as TuruqaAtN is of TuruqN. (TA.) ― -b2- See also jazarN.

juzaArapN jzAr jzArh jzArp
juzaArapN, of a camel, The extremities; (S, A;) namely, (S,) the fore and kind legs, (AlyadaAni waAlrRijolaAni, S, K,) and the head, (S,) or neck: (A, K:) because the slaughterer receives them; (S;) they being his hire, (S, K,) or right, (A,) not being included among the shares in the game called Almayosir. (TA.) But when a horse is said to be Eabolu AljuzaArapi, (S,) or Daxomu AljuzaArapi, (M,) what is meant is thickness of the fore and hind legs, and abundance of sinews; and the head is not included, because largeness of the head, in a horse, is a fault. (S, M.)

jizaArapN jzAr jzArh jzArp
jizaArapN The trade of him who slaughters camels (Mgh, Msb, K, * TA) and other animals. (Msb.)

jaziyrapN jzyrh jzyrp
jaziyrapN (tropical:) An island; land in the sea [or in a river], from which the water has flowed away, so that it appears; (Az, Mgh;) and in like manner, land which a torrent does not overflow, but which it surrounds; (Az, TA;) land from which the tide retires; as also jazarN↓: (K:) so called because cut off from the main land: (S:) or because of the retiring of the water from it: (Msb:) pl. jazaAYiru: (S, Mgh:) [also, a peninsula:] and a piece of ground or land. (Kr, TA.)

jazRaArN jzAr
jazRaArN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and jizRiyrN↓ (K) and jaAzirN↓ (A) One who slaughters camels (A, Mgh, Msb, K) and other animals. (Msb.)

jizRiyrN jzyr
jizRiyrN: see what next precedes.

jaAzirN jAzr
jaAzirN: see what next precedes.

majozarN mjzr
majozarN, (Msb, K,) or majozirN, with kesr to the z, (S, Ibn-Málik,) contr to rule, as the aor. of the verb is with damm, (Ibn-Málik, TA,) and sometimes majozarapN↓ [or majozirapN], (Msb,) A place where camels are slaughtered, (S, Msb, K,) and other animals, (Msb,) namely, bulls and cows and sheep and goats, and where their flesh is sold: pl. majaAziru. (TA.) In a trad. of 'Omar, persons are enjoined to avoid majaAzir, (S, TA,) meaning as above; because of their uncleanness; (TA;) or because the witnessing of the slaughter of animals hardens the heart and dispels mercy: (IAth, TA:) or the meaning is, places of assembly; because a camel is slaughtered only where people are collected together: (S, TA:) the majozarap↓ is one of the places in which it is forbidden to perform the usual prayers. (Mgh.)

majozarapN mjzr mjzrh mjzrp
majozarapN or majozirapN: see majozarN, in two places.

1 jazoEN jzE
1. jazoEN [inf. n. of jazaEa] signifies The act of cutting; or cutting off. (TA.) [See also 8.] ― -b2- [Hence,] jzaEa lahu jizoEapF mina AlmaAli He cut off for him a portion of the property. (S.) ― -b3- And jazaEa AlwaAdiI, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jazaEa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. jazoEN, (S, Msb, K,) He passed the valley to the other side: (Msb:) or he passed the valley [in any manner]: (K:) or he passed across it; i. e., crossed it: (S, K:) and in like manner, AlOaroDa the land: (K:) and AlmafaAzapa the desert: and AlmawoDiEa the place. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jaziEa, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jazaEa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. jazaEN (S, Msb, K) and juzwEN, (K,) He was, or became, impatient, (S, K,) mina AlXRaIoCi [of the thing]; (S;) and EalaI fulaAnK [on account of such a one]; (S and K in art. Alh, &c.;) jazaEN being the contr. of SaborN: (S, K:) or he had not sufficient strength to bear what befell him, (O, Msb,) and found not patience: (Msb:) or he manifested grief and agitation: (TK:) or he was, or became, affected with grief: or he was, or became, affected with most violent grief, such as prevented him and turned him from that to which he was directing himself, or from his object, and cut him off therefrom: this meaning of cutting off being said by 'Abd-el-Kádir El-Baghdádee to be the primary signification. (TA.)

2 jzRE jzE
2. jzRE, inf. n. tajoziyEN, It (a full-grown unripe date) became ripe to the extent of two thirds of it: (S:) or to the extent of half of it; (K, TA;) from the bottom: (TA:) or became partly ripe: and in like manner one says of a grape. (TA.) ― -b2- It (a watering-trough, or tank,) had but little remaining in it. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- He put a little water into a skin. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jzRE fulaAnFA, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He caused the impatience (jazaE) of such a one to cease: (K:) he said to him that which comforted him, or consoled him, and which caused his grief and fear to cease. (IAth.)

4 AjzE jizoEapF AjzE jzEh AjzE jzEp
4. AjzE jizoEapF, and juzoEapF, He left, or caused to remain, a remainder: (O, K:) or less than half. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AjzEhu He caused him to be impatient: (S, K:) or he caused him to want sufficient strength to bear what befell him, and to be impatient. (Msb.)

5 tajazRaEa
5: see 7, in two places. ＝ -A2- tjzREwA Alganiymapa They divided among themselves the spoil. (TA.)

7 AnjzE AnjzE
7. AnjzE It (a rope) broke, (K, TA,) in any manner: (TA:) or broke in halves; (K, TA;) but if it have broken at its extremity, one does not say AnjzE. (TA.) And AnjzEt AlEaSaA, and tjzREt↓, The staff, or stick, broke (K, TA) in halves. (TA.) tjzRE↓ is also said of a spear, and of an arrow, &c., meaning It broke in pieces. (TA.)

8 AjtzEhu AjtzEh AjtzEp
8. AjtzEhu He broke it, and cut it off: (K:) or he broke it off, and cut it off, for himself; namely, a branch, rod, or piece of wood, from a tree. (S.)

jazoEN jzE
jazoEN (S, Msb, K) and jizoEN↓, (Kr, K,) but IDrd ascribes the latter to the vulgar, (TA,) [The onyx; so called in the present day;] certain beads, or gems, (xarazN,) (Msb,) the beads, or gems, (xaraz, [here rendered by Golius “ Murœna seu concha Veneris, ” though he also gives what I regard as the only correct signification, namely “ onyx, ”]) of El-Yemen (S, K) [and] of China, (K) in which are whiteness and blackness, (S, Msb, K,) and to which eyes are likened, (S, K,) and in particular, by Imra-el-Keys, the eyes of wild animals, because their eyes, while they are alive, are black, but when they die, their whiteness appears; (TA;) a kind of stone having many colours, brought from El-Yemen and China; (Kzw;) so called because interrupted by various colours; its blackness being interrupted by its whiteness and its yellowness: (IB:) 'Áïsheh's necklace [which she lost on the occasion that subjected her to the accusation of adultery] was of jazoE of Dhafári: (TA:) the wearing it in a signet induces anxiety, or disquietude of mind, and grief, and terrifying dreams, and altercation with men; and if the hair of one who experiences difficulty in bringing forth be wound upon it, she brings forth at once: (K: [and Kzw says the like, and more of a similar kind:]) n. un. jazoEapN (Msb, K, * TA) and jizoEapN. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- See also what next follows.

jizoEN jzE
jizoEN, (S, O, L, Msb, K,) but AO says that it should be with fet-h, [jazoEN↓,] (K) The place of bending, or turning, (munoEaTaf, S, Msb, K, or munoHanFI, As, K,) of a valley: (As, S, Msb, K:) or the middle thereof: or the place where it ends: (IDrd, K:) or its side: (Msb:) or the place of
passing, or crossing, of a valley: or a widening part, of the narrow places, thereof, whether it produce plants &c. or do not produce them: (TA:) or it is not so called unless [it be a part] having width, and producing trees &c.: (Msb, K:) or it may be without plants, or herbage, or the like: (TA:) or a place, in a valley, in which are no trees: (IAar, K:) or a place, of a valley, taking a round and wide form: (TA:) pl. OajozaAEN. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- A place of alighting, or abiding, of a people. (K.) ― -b3- Elevated land, or ground, by the side of which is a low, or depressed, part. (K.) ＝ -A2- A bee-hive: pl. as above. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.) ＝ -A3- See also jazoEN.

jazuEN jzE
jazuEN: see what next follows.

jaziEN jzE
jaziEN (Msb, K) and jaAziEN↓ and jazuEN↓ (K) and jazuwEN↓ (Msb, K) and juzaAEN↓ (K) part. ns. of jaziEa; [Impatient; &c.;] (Msb, K;) but the last two have an intensive signification [very impatient, or having much impatience; &c.]. (IAar.)

juzoEapN jzE jzEh jzEp
juzoEapN: see what next follows, in two places.

jizoEapN jzE jzEh jzEp
jizoEapN A little, or small quantity, of property, or wealth; and of water, (S, K,) remaining in a skin, (Lh, IDrd,) and in a leathern bottle, or other vessel, (IDrd,) and in a pool left by a torrent, but not in a well, (TA,) as also juzoEapN↓ (IDrd, K) and [the dim.] juzayoEapN↓, (IDrd,) and of milk, in a skin; (Lh;) or a third part, or nearly that quantity, of water, in a trough, or tank; (ISh;) or a quantity of water, and of milk, less than the half of the skin or other vessel, and of the trough; (TA;) and, as also juzoEapN↓, somewhat remaining; (O, K;) or the latter, particularly, of milk; (IAar;) or both, accord. to some, [a remainder consisting of] less than half; (TA;) and the former, a portion [not defined] of property, or wealth; (S;) and particularly a portion of a flock of sheep or goats; (Aboo-Leylà, K;) as also juzayoEapN↓; (S;) thus in the handwriting of Aboo-Sahl El-Harawee; but in the Mj of IF, jaziyEapN↓, of the measure faEiylapN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlapN: (TA:) the pl. of jizoEapN is jizaEN. (ISh.) ― -b2- And [hence,] (tropical:) A part, or portion, of the night, (S, O, K,) past or to come, (TA,) less than half, (O, K,) of the former part thereof or of the latter part. (K.) ＝ -A2- A place in which is a collection of trees (K, TA) among which the camels or other beasts are made to rest at night from the cold, and are confined when they are hungry, or returning from water, or under rain. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also n. un. of jizoEN as syn. with jazoEN. (TA.)

juzaAEN jzAE
juzaAEN: see jaziEN.

jazuwEN jzE jzwE
jazuwEN: see jaziEN.

jaziyEapN jzyEh jzyEp
jaziyEapN and juzayoEapN: see jizoEapN, in three places.

jaAziEN jAzE
jaAziEN: see jaziEN. ＝ -A2- Also The piece of wood which is placed in the trellis of a grape-vine, crosswise, upon which are laid the branches of the vine; (S, K) not known to Aboo-Sa'eed; (S;) it is thus placed for the purpose of raising the branches from the ground; and this piece of wood is also called xaXabapN jaAziEapN; the latter word being thus used as an epithet. (TA.) Also Any piece of wood that is put crosswise between two things for a thing to be borne upon it (K, TA) is called its jAzE. (TA.)

mujazRaEN mjzE
mujazRaEN Interrupted by various colours [like the jazoE or onyx]: (IB:) or anything in which are blackness and whiteness; as also mujazRiEN↓: (K:) and flesh-meat in which are whiteness and redness. (TA.) [Hence,] nuwFI mujazRaEN and mujazRiEN↓ Datestones of which some, or some parts, have been scraped, or abraded, so as to have become white, the rest being left of their [original] colour: (K:) likened to the jazoE. (TA.) And busorN majazRiEN↓ (S, K) and mujazRaEN; (K;) the former, says Sh, accord. to El-Ma'arree, but he adds that he himself held the latter to be the right; Az says that he heard the former from the people of Hejer, and it has the authority of A' Obeyd; (TA;) Full-grown dates that have ripened to the half; (K, TA;) from the bottom: (TA:) or to the extent of two thirds: (S:) or that have become partly ripe: (TA:) fem. with p: (S, K:) and in like manner you say tamorN mutajazRiEN↓ dates that have ripened to the half. (TA.)

mujazRiEN mjzE
mujazRiEN: see mujazRaEN, in three places. ― -b2- HawoDN mujazRiEN A watering-trough, or tank, having but little water remaining in it. (K.)

mutajazRiEN mtjzE
mutajazRiEN: see mujazRiEN.

1 jazofN jzf
1. jazofN [inf. n. of jazafa] signifies The taking a thing [in the manner termed] majaAzafapF and jizaAfFA [i. e. by conjecture, not knowing the measure nor the weight]: (S, TA:) or the taking largely, or copiously: (IF, Msb, TA:) and it is [from] a Persian word. (Msb. [See juzaAfN, below.]) And you say, jazafa fiI Alkayoli, inf. n. jazofN, He gave large measure: (IKtt, Msb:) and jazafa lahu fiI Alkayoli He gave him large measure. (Jm, TA.)

3 jAzf jAzf
3. jAzf, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. mujaAzafapN (S, Msb, K, TA) and jizaAfN, (S, TA,) He sold, or bought, a thing not knowing its measure nor its weight: (Msb:) or he conjectured in selling and buying. (K.) ― -b2- He acted in an easy, or a facile, manner, (Msb, TA,) in selling or buying. (Msb.) ― -b3- And hence, jAzf binafosihi (tropical:) He perilled, endangered, jeoparded, hazarded, or risked, himself; as though he acted in an easy manner with himself. (TA.)

5 tjzRf fiyhi tjzf fyh tjzf fyp
5. tjzRf fiyhi He picked out, or selected, the good in it; syn. tanaqRada [in the CK, erroneously, tanafRaca]. (Sgh, K.)

8 Ajtrf Ojtrf Ajtrf Qjtrf
8. Ajtrf He bought a thing by conjecture, not knowing the measure nor the weight. (AA, K.)

jazofN jzf
jazofN Of unknown quantity, whether measured or weighed. (Nh, TA.)

jizofapN jzfh jzfp
jizofapN A portion of a number of cattle: (K:) and of hair. (TA)

jazaAfN jzAf
jazaAfN: see what next follows, in two places.

juzaAfN jzAf
juzaAfN, accord. to the 'Eyn, in selling and buying, is [The selling, and buying,] by conjecture, without measuring and without weighing; and by rule should be jizaAfN↓, with kesr; i. e., if formed in accordance to the verb [which is jaAzafa]: (Mgh:) or the selling or buying a thing not knowing its measure nor its weight: (Msb:) or conjecture in selling and buying; as also jizaAfN↓ and jazaAfN↓ and juzaAfapN↓ and jizaAfapN↓ and jazaAfapN↓: (K, TA:) arabicized, from GuzaAfo, (Msb, K, TA,) which is Persian: (Msb, TA:) they say laAfo wGazaAfo, meaning “ excess in speech, by conjecture: ” accord. to the Jm, its primary signification is muchness, or copiousness: (TA:) some say that the most chaste form of jzAf is jizaAfN↓, with kesr; [because this is a regular inf. n. of jaAzafa;] (MF, TA;) and some, that the triple vocalization of the j in jzAf is a kind of jzAf [i. e. conjecture], since all assert it to be a Persian word arabicized, and it cannot be so and be also an inf. n., conformable to the verb and to rule: it seems that, when they arabicized it, its original was gradually forgotten, so they formed from it a verb, and derived from it, and made it analogous. (TA.) ― -b2- bayoEN juzaAfN and jizaAfN↓ and jazaAfN↓ and jaziyfN↓ (K) and mujotazafN↓ (TA) A thing sold, or bought, of unknown quantity, whether measured or weighed. (TA.) [See also jazofN.]

jizaAfN jzAf
jizaAfN: see juzaAfN, in four places.

jazuwfN jzwf
jazuwfN A pregnant female exceeding the term of her bringing forth. (K.)

jaziyfN jzyf
jaziyfN: see juzaAfN.

jazaAfapN jzAfh jzAfp
jazaAfapN and juzaAfapN and jizaAfapN: see juzaAfN.

jazRaAfN jzAf
jazRaAfN A fisherman. (El-'Azeezee, K.)

jaAzifN fiI kalaAmihi jAzf fy klAmh jAzf fy klAmp
jaAzifN fiI kalaAmihi (assumed tropical:) One who pours forth his speech without rule. (Msb.)

mijozafapN mjzfh mjzfp
mijozafapN A fishing-net. (El-' Azeezee, K.)

bayoEN mujotazafN byE mjtzf
bayoEN mujotazafN: see juzaAfN.

1 jazalahu jzl jzlh jzlp
1. jazalahu, (K,) or jazaluwA naAqapF, (S,) aor.
jazila
, (K,) inf. n. jazolN, (S,) He cut it (a thing, S) in two pieces, (S, K,) with a sword. (K.) ― -b2- jazaluwA naAqapF They cut the base of the neck of a she-camel, that was slaughtered and dead, in the part between the two shoulder-joints, in order that the neck might become relaxed; not cutting the whole of it; previously to skinning. (Ham p. 689.) ― -b3- jazalahu Alqatabu, (K, * TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above; and Ajzlhu↓; The saddle cut it; namely, the withers of a camel. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- jazila, aor.
jazala
, (K.) inf. n. jazalN, (S, K,) He (a camel) had a gall, or sore, in the withers, in consequence of which a bone came forth from it, and the place thereof became depressed: (S, K:) or he had his withers cut by the saddle: (K:) or he had a gall, or sore, in the withers, penetrating into the interior, and killing him. (TA.) The epithet applied to a camel in this case is Oajozlu↓; (S, K;) fem. jazolaMCu: pl. juzolN (K.) See also Oaxozalu ＝ -A3- jazula,
aor.
jazula
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. jazaAlapN, (Msb,) said of firewood, (Msb, TA,) &c., (TA,) It was thick and large. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) (tropical:) He possessed good, (S, * K, TA,) strong, firm, (TA,) judgment, (S * K, TA,) [and natural disposition, and intelligence; for] jazaAlapN is used in relation to judgment and natural disposition and intelligence: (Ham p. 770:) and jazaAlapu AlrRaOoI signifies (assumed tropical:) firmness of judgment: (TA:) and AljazaAlapu fiI AlmanoTiqi, (assumed tropical:) chasteness, or clearness, or eloquence, and firmness, in speech. (Har p. 8.)

4 Oajozala
4: see 1. ＝ -A2- Ajzl EaTiyRatuhu (tropical:) He made his gift large. (TA.) And Ajzl lahu mina AlEaTaMCa, (S,) or fiI AlEaTaMCi, (Msb, TA,) (tropical:) He gave to him largely. (S, Msb, TA.)

10 Astjzl raOoyahu fiI hecaA c
10. Astjzl raOoyahu fiI hecaA (assumed tropical:) He esteemed his judgment, or opinion, good [and strong and firm (see jazula)] in this [matter]; syn. Aisotajowadahu (TA.)

jazolN jzl
jazolN Large and dry firewood: (S:) or dry firewood: (K:) or thick, large firewood. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Much of a thing; as also jaziylN↓: (K:) or the latter, great, or large; [and so the former:] you say EaTaMCN jazolN and jaziylN↓ (tropical:) [a great, or large, gift]: (S, TA:*) and vawaAbN jaziylN↓ (tropical:) [a great, or large, recompense]: (TA:) pl. jizaAlN; (S, K;) either of the former or of the latter. (TA.) And [the fem.] jazolapN (tropical:) [A woman] large in the posteriors. (K, TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Generous; munificent. (K, TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) Intelligent; firm, or sound, in judgment. (K, TA.) You say, fulaAnN jazolu AlrRaOoIi (tropical:) [Such a one is firm, or sound, in judgment]. (S, Msb.) And when this is said to you, and you desire to deny it, say, AlrRaOoIi balo jazilu↓(tropical:) Nay, unsound in judgment; from jazalN, [inf. n. of jazila,] relating to a gall, or sore, in the withers [of a camel]. (A, TA.) You say also AimoraOapN jazolapN (assumed tropical:) A woman possessing judgment: (S:) or intelligent; firm, or sound, in judgment; as also jazolaMCu↓: (K:) [but] IDrd says that jzAlMC, [app. a mistranscription for jazolaMCu,] as syn. with jazolapN, is not of established authority. (TA.) ― -b5- Applied to a word, or an expression, (S, K, &c.,) (tropical:) Strong, (PS,) sound, correct; (PS, TK;) contr. of rakiykN (S, K.) And applied to language, (assumed tropical:) Chaste, clear, or eloquent, and comprehensive. (TA.)

jizolN jzl
jizolN: see jizolapN

jazilu AlrRaOoIi c
jazilu AlrRaOoIi: see jazol

jizolapN jzl jzlh jzlp
jizolapN A piece, or portion cut off. (S, K.*) ― -b2- A large portion of dates; (S, K;) as also jizolN↓ (K)

zamanN AljizaAlu zmn AljzAl
zamanN AljizaAlu (S, K) and AljazaAli (K) The time of the cutting off of the fruit of the palm-trees. (S, K.)

jaziylN jzl jzyl
jaziylN: see jazolN, in three places.

Oajozalu c
Oajozalu; fem. jazolaMCu; pl. juzolN: see jazila: ＝ -A2- and for the fem., see also jazolN.

1 jazamahu jzm jzmh jzmp
1. jazamahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor
jazima
(Msb, K,) inf. n. jazomN, (Msb,) He cut it, or cut it off; (S, Msb, K) namely, a thing: (Msb:) [like jaramahu &c.] ― -b2- jazama AlnRaxola He cut off the fruit of the palmtrees: (Msb:) [like jarama Alnxl: but see another explanation, below.] And jazama mina AlnRaxolapi jizomFA [He cut off a portion of the fruit from the palmtree]. (TA.) ― -b3- jazama AlHarofa, (S, ISd, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (S,) He made the letter quiescent; (S, ISd, Msb, K;) i.e., the final letter of a declinable word; (S, ISd, Msb;) he cut it off from motion: (Msb:) or as though he cut off from it declinability: (Mbr, TA:) from jazama in the first of the senses explained above: jazomN in a declinable word being like sukuwnN in an indeclinable word. (S.) It is said in a trad. of En-Nakha'ee, AltRakobiyru jazomN wAltRasoliymu jazomN, meaning that neither should be prolonged in utterance, and that the last letter in each should be without a case-ending, i.e., be quiescent; so that one should not say [in prayer] AallRehu Oakobaru [nor AlsRalaAmu Ealayokumo waraHomapu QllRehi, but Oakobaro in the former instance, and QllReho in the latter]: or, accord. to Z, that one should not exceed the due bounds in the pronunciation of the hemzeh and the medd: (TA:) or that one should abstain from giving fulness and depth to the sound of the vowel, and should elide it entirely in the places of pausing, and avoid excess in the pronunciation of the hemzeh and the medd. (Mgh.) ― -b4- jazama EalaI fulaAnK kacaA wakacaA, He made such and such things to be binding, or obligatory, on such a one. (K.) And jazama Alyamiyna, (K,) inf.n. as above, (TA,) i. q. OamoDaAhaA; (K) i. e., He made the oath to be unconditional, without exception, absolutely or decidedly or irreversibly binding; (TK;) OamoDaAhaA AlbatRapa. (TA.) One says also, Halafa yamiynFA HatomFA jazomFA [He swore an oath in an absolute, a decided, or an irreversible, manner]. (TA.) And jazama AlOamora, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He decided the affair irreversibly. (K.) And jazamotu maA bayoniI wabayonahu I decided the matter between me and him. (TA.) And OafoEalu celika jazomFA I will do that decidedly; without any indulgence therein. (Msb.) And jazama bihi [He asserted it decisively]. (TA passim.) And jazama EalaI AlOamori He decided, or determined, upon, or upon doing, the thing, or affair. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, this last phrase, He was silent respecting the affair; and so jzRm↓. (K,* TA.) ― -b6- And jazama Eanohu He held back, or refrained, from it through cowardice; and was unable to do it; and so jzRm↓: (K:) or Alqawomu jzRm↓ the people lacked power or ability. (S) ― -b7- jazama AlbaEiyru famaA yaboraHu [app., The camel stopped, and would not quit his place]. (TA: but the verb jzm is there without any syll. sign.) ＝ -A2- jazama AlnRaxola, (A'Obeyd, S, K,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) and Ajtzmhu↓; (K; and the act. part. n. of the latter is also mentioned in the S;) like jaramahu (S) [and Ajtrmhu]; He computed by conjecture the quantity of fruit upon the palm-trees. (A'Obeyd, S, K.) ― -b2- And jazomN also signifies The selling, or buying, fruit [by conjecture, while yet in a rudimental state,] in its calyxes, for money. (IAar, TA.) ＝ -A3- Also jazama (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He filled a skin; (S, K;) and so jzRm↓, (S, *K,) inf. n. tajoziymN (S.) ― -b2- jazamati AlUibilu, (Fr, K,) inf. n. as above, (Fr, TA,) The camels satisfied their thirst [as though they filled themselves] with water. (Fr, K.) ― -b3- And jazama, (IAar, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (IAar, TA,) He ate one meal and was filled thereby: (IAar, K) or he ate one meal in every day and night. (Th, K.) ＝ -A4- jazama AlqiraMCapa, (Lth, K,) inf. n. as above, (Lth, TA,) He performed the reading, or recitation, so as to put the letters in their proper places, in a distinct, or perspicuous, and leisurely, manner. (Lth, K.) ― -b2- And jazomN in writing means The making the letters even. (K.) ＝ -A5- jazama bisaloHihi He voided part of his excrement, part thereof remaining: or he cast forth his excrement. (K.)

2 jazRama
2: see 1, in four places.

4 Ajzm naxolahu Ajzm nxlh Ajzm nxlp
4. Ajzm naxolahu He sold his palm-trees. (TA.)

5 tjzRmti AlEaSaA tjzmt AlESA
5. tjzRmti AlEaSaA The staff became split or cracked. (K.)

7 Anjzm Anjzm
7. Anjzm [It became cut, or cut off. ― -b2- And hence,] It (the final letter of a declinable word) became, or was made, quiescent. (S, TA.) ― -b3- It (a bone) broke, or became broken. (K.)

8 Uijotazama
8: see 1. ― -b2- Ajtzm jizomapF mina AlmaAli He took a portion of the cattle, or property, and left a portion. (K.) ― -b3- Ajtzm HaZiyratahu He bought his HZyrp [or enclosure for camels &c.]: (AHn, K:) of the dial. of El-Yemámeh. (AHn, TA.) ― -b4- Ajtzm AlnRaxolapa He bought the fruit, only, of the palm-tree: and Ajtzm naxola fulaAnK he bought the palm-trees of such a one. (TA.)

jazomN jzm
jazomN [an inf.n. (see 1) used as an epithet]. You say HukomN jazomN An indissoluble and irreversible decree or ordinance, or sentence; like qaDaMCN HatomN. (Msb.) ― -b2- A reed-pen (qalamN) having the nib evenly, not obliquely, cut. (S,* K, TA.) ― -b3- The modern Arabic character, (S, K,) composed of the letters of the alphabet: (K:) accord. to AHát, (TA,) so called because it was cut off from the character of Himyer, (K, TA,) i.e., the musonad, which they have still in El-Yemen. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A thing that is stuffed into a she-camel's vulva, (El-Umawee, S, K,) that she may think it to be her young one, [when it is taken forth,] and incline to it, [and therefore yield her milk;] like the durojap [q. v.]. (El-Umawee, S.) ＝ -A3- A thing, or an event, that comes before its time, or season: (K:) that which comes in its time, or season, is termed wazomN. (TA.)

jizomN jzm
jizomN A portion, share, or lot, (K,) of palmtrees (TA) [and app. of the fruit of a palm-tree, &c.: see 1, third sentence].

jazomapN jzm jzmh jzmp
jazomapN [The sign that is written over the final letter of a declinable word when it is quiescent]. ＝ -A2- A single act of eating. (S.)

jizomapN jzm jzmh jzmp
jizomapN A hundred [head] of cattle, and upwards: or from ten to forty: (K:) or it is peculiarly of
camels; like SiromapN: (TA:) or such a portion as is termed Siromap of camels; and such as is termed firoqap of sheep. (S, K.) [See also 8.]

jaAzimN jAzm
jaAzimN A full water-skin or milk-skin; as also mijozamN↓: (K,* TA:) and [the pl.] jawaAzimu filled milk-skins. (K.) ― -b2- Also, applied to a camel, and jawaAzimu applied to camels, Satisfied with water. (K.)

mijozamN mjzm
mijozamN: see jaAzimN

majozuwmN mjzwm
majozuwmN [Cut, or cut off. ― -b2- And hence,] applied to the final letter of a declinable word, Made quiescent. (TA.)

1 jazaI jzI jzy jzyp
1. jazaI, aor
jaziIa
(Msb, K,) inf. n. jazaMCN, (Msb,) It (a thing) paid; gave, or rendered, as a satisfaction; or made, gave, or rendered, satisfaction: (Msb:) or satisfied; sufficed; or contented. (K.) And jazayotu AldRayona I paid the debt. (Msb.) And jazayotu fulaAnFA HaqRahu I paid such a one his right, or due. (TA.) And maA yajoziyniI hecaA AlvRawobu This garment does not suffice me. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (TA,) jazaI Eanohu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (Mgh,) It (a thing) paid for him; gave, or rendered, [a thing] as a satisfaction for him; made, gave, or rendered, satisfaction for him; (S, Mgh, Msb,* K;) and some of the lawyers use AjzI↓ in this sense, like AjzO: (Az, Mgh, Msb:) jazaI is of the dial. of El-Hijáz, and AjzO of the dial. of Temeem. (Akh, Msb.) Hence, in the Kur [ii. 45], laA tajoziI nafosN Eano nafosK XayoYFA [A soul shall not give anything as a satisfaction for a soul, i. e. for another soul: or a soul shall not make satisfaction for a soul at all; accord. to the latter rendering, XyYA being put in the accus. case after the manner of an inf. n.]. (S, Msb.) You say also, jazato Eanoka XaApN A sheep, or goat, made satisfaction for thee [as a sacrifice]; (S, TA;) as also Oajozato↓: (TA:) Benoo-Temeem say OajozaOato, with C: (S, TA:) this last, thus explained, is a dial, var. mentioned by IKtt (Msb.) And kacaA Eano kacaA AjzI↓ Such a thing stood, or served, in lieu, in the place, or in stead, of such a thing, without sufficing. (Zj, K.) And qaliylN mino kaviyrKyujoziI↓; and hecaAmino hecaA; A little stands, or serves, in lieu of much; and this, of this. (IAar, TA.) And Eanohu mujozaI AjzI↓ fulaAnK and mujozaApa fulaAnK and (as though the augmentative letter [A in AjzI] were imagined to be rejected, TA) majozaI flAn and majozaApa flAn He satisfied, sufficed, or contented, him as such a one; he stood, or served, him in stead of such a one; a dial. var. of AjzO. (K.) And AjzI↓ mujozaI gayorihi It (a thing) satisfied, sufficed, or contented, as another thing; it stood, or served, in stead of another thing. (Msb.) And AjzAka↓, with the [second] objective complement suppressed, It was sufficient for thee. (Mgh.) ― -b3- jazaAha kacaA (Msb,* TA,) and jazaAhu bihi (K,) or bimaA SanaEa, (S,) and Ealayohi, (K,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (S, K,) He repaid, requited, compensated, or recompensed, him (Msb, K TA) [for such a thing, for it, or for what he had done]; as also jAzAhu↓, (S, K,) inf. n. mujaAzaApN and jizaMCN: (K:) or, accord. to Fr, [contr. to many instances in the Kur,] the former verb relates only to good; and the latter, to good and to evil: but accord. to others, the former may relate to good and to evil; and the latter, to evil. (TA.) [See also jazaMCN, below.] One says, in praying for another, jazaAhu QllRehu xayorFA May God repay him good: and requite, or recompense, him for good [that he has done]. (Msb.) And bicanobihi jaAzayotuhu↓ I punished him for his crime, or sin, or act of disobedience. (Msb.) And jazaI Eanohu fulaAnFA He requited, compensated, or recompensed, for him, such a one. (TA.) ― -b4- jaAzayotuhu fajazayotuhu: see 3.

3 jaAozaIa
3: see 1, latter part, in two places. ― -b2- [jAzAhu xayorFA He prayed for a reward for him from God: or said to him, May God reward thee. (Golius, on the authority of Z.) ― -b3- jAzI biHarofK and biZarofK, He employed a particle, and an adverbial noun, as conditional; to denote that, with what follows, it expresses a condition with its complement. For instance, in the S, voce Hayovu, it is said,Hayovu mina AlZRuruwfi AlRatiI laA yujaAzaI bihaA UilRaA maEa maA, i. e. Hyv is one of the adverbial nouns that are not employed conditionally, or to denote that, with what follows, they express a condition with its complement, unless with mA affixed thereto. See jazaMCN, below.] ― -b4- jaAzayotuhu fajazayotuhu↓ [I vied, or contended, with him in repaying, requiting, compensating, or recompensing, and] I overcame him [therein]. (S.)

4 AjzI OjzI Ojzy AjzI Ajzy jzI
4. AjzI: see 1, in seven places. ＝ -A2- Also He furnished a knife with a handle; a dial. var. of AjzO: (Msb, K:) but ISd doubts its being so. (TA.)

6 tjAzI dayonahu tjAzy dynh tjAzy dynp
6. tjAzI dayonahu, and bidayonihi, He demanded payment of his debt. (K.) You say, tajaAzayotu dayoniI EalaI fulaAnK I demanded payment of my debt [owed by such a one]. (S.) ― -b2- tajaAzayA [They two repaid, requited, compensated, or recompensed, each other]. (TA in art. qrD.)

8 AjtzAhu AjtzAh AjtzAp Qjtz QjtzAh
8. AjtzAhu He sought, or demanded, of him repayment, requital, compensation, or recompense. (K.)

jizoIN jzI jzy jzyp
jizoIN [a coll. gen. n., of which the n. un. is with p]: see what next follows.

jizoyapN jzyh jzyp
jizoyapN The tax that is taken from the free nonMuslim subjects of a Muslim government; (S, IAth, Mgh,* Msb, K;) whereby they ratify the compact that ensures them protection: (IAth:) [from jazaI;] as though it were a compensation for their not being slain: (IAth, Mgh:) [or from the Persian Gizoyaho:] and also, (metaphorically, Mgh,) (tropical:) a land-tax; (Mgh, K;) a tax that is paid by the owner of land: (TA:) pl. jizFI (S,) or jizoIN↓, (Msb,) or both, (K,) [but the latter is, properly speaking, a coll. gen. n.,] and jizaMCN, (K, [in the CK, erroneously, jazACN,]) like kitaAbN. (TA.)

jazaMCN jzMC
jazaMCN Repayment, requital, compensation, or recompense, for a thing; as also ↓; jaAziyapN(K;) a satisfaction, good for good, and evil for evil; (Er-Rághib, TA;) sometimes a reward, and sometimes a punishment: (AHeyth, TA:) [the former word is an inf. n.; see 1;] the latter, a quasi-inf. n.: jawaAzK is pl. of the latter, or of the former, or of jaAzK↓, accord. to different writers explaining the saying of El-Hoteí-ah,
mano yafoEali Alxayora laA yaEodamo jawaAziyahu
[Whoso doth good, he will not want his rewards, or his rewarders]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jazaMCa AlEuTaAsi In the time between the complimentary prayer addressed to a sneezer (called AltRaXomiyt) and the sneeze; [or as soon as one can compliment a sneezer by repeating the usual prayer of yaroHamuka QllRehu (God have mercy on thee).] (TA voce muEaAqibN) ― -b3- [And jazaMCu XaroTK An apodosis; the complement, or correlative, of a condition; also called jawaAbu XaroTK, q.v. in art. jwb ― -b4- And Harofu jazaMCK A particle denoting compensation, or the complement of a condition. And A conditional particle; as Uino; also termed HarofN lilojazaMCi, and jazaMCN alone, and Harofu XaroTK.] ― -b5- huwa cuw jazaMCK He is possessed of sufficiency, or competence, or wealth. (TA.)

jaAzK jAz
jaAzK [act. part. n. of 1, q. v.]: see jazaMCN ― -b2- hecaA rajulN jaAziyka mino rajulK This is a man sufficient for thee as a man. (S.)

jaAziyapN jAzyh jAzyp
