jaAziyapN: see jazaMCN. ＝ -A2- Also Wild bulls, or cows. (TA.) [See jaAziYN.]

majozFI mjz mjzI mjzy
majozFI and mujozFI are used as inf. ns. of 4. [See 1.] (K.)

mujozK mjz
mujozK [act. part. n. of 4. It is said in the TA that mjzI, applied to a camel, signifies Sufficing for a load or burden; and its pl. is mjAzI. And that mjzI liOamorihi, applied to a man, signifies Sufficing for his affair. But mjzI in these instances is evidently a mistranscription, for mujozK; and mjAzI, for majaAzK, Mistranscriptions of this Kind are of frequent occurrence in Lexicons.]

majozaApN mjzAh mjzAp
majozaApN and mujozaApN are used as inf. ns. of 4. [See 1.] (K.)

1 jasRahu js jsh jsp
1. jasRahu, (A, Mgh, K,*) or jasRahu biyadihi, (S Msb,) aor
jasusa
, (Mgh, Msb,) inf.n. jasRN, (A, Mgh, Msb, K,) He felt it with his hand (S, A, Mgh, K) for the purpose of testing it, that he might form a judgment of it; (Mgh, Msb;) as also AjtsRhu↓. (S, Msb, K.) You say, jasRahu AlTRabiybu, (Mgh,) and jasRa yadahu, (A,) The physician felt him, (Mgh,) and felt his arm, or hand, (A,) to know if he were hot or cold. (Mgh.) And jasRa AlXRaApa He felt the sheep, or goat, to know if it were fat or lean. (A, Mgh.) ― -b2- jasRN is also, sometimes, with the eye. (IDrd, S, Msb. *) You say, jasRahu biEayonihi (IDrd, S, A, K) (tropical:) He looked sharply, or intently, or attentively, at him, or it, for the purpose of investigation and clear perception. (K, TA.) IDrd cites as an ex. a verse (of 'Obeyd, or 'Abeed, [for I find it written without any syll. signs,] the son of Eiyoob El-'Amberee, TA,) in which occurs
the expression jasRuwhu biOaEoyunihimo: (S:) but Sgh says that the right reading is HasRuwhu. (TA.) ― -b3- jasRa AlOaroDa (assumed tropical:) He traversed the land. (Aboo-Sa'eed El-Yeshkuree, TA.) ― -b4- jasRa AlOaxobaAra, (S, Msb, K,) and tajasRasahaA↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) (tropical:) He searched, or sought, for, or after, news or tidings; inquired, or sought for information, respecting news or tidings; searched or inquired or spied into, investigated, scrutinized, or examined, news or tidings: (S, K:) he searched, or sought, repeatedly, or leisurely and by degrees, for news or tidings. (Msb.) You say also, fulaAnFA tjsRs↓, and mino fulaAnK (tropical:) He inquired, or sought for information, respecting such a one; as also tHsRs, which latter verb occurs in an extr. reading of verse 87 of ch. xii. of the Kur: or the former signifies he sought after him for another; and the latter, "he sought after him for himself:" or tjsRs↓ signifies [he acted as a spy;] he inquired respecting, or searched or inquired or spied into, things which others veiled or concealed by reason of disdainful pride or of shame or pudency; and tHsRs, "he listened:" (TA:) in the last of the senses here assigned to it, the former verb is used in the Kur, xlix. 12, where it is said, walaA tajasRasuwA↓, for tatajasRasuwA; (Mujáhid, Bd, K;) ↓or the meaning here is, and do not ye inquire respecting, or search or inquire or spy into, private circumstances: or take ye what appeareth, and leave ye what God hath concealed. (Mujáhid, K.) You also say, lahumo Oamori Alqawomi AjtsR↓ He examined or spied into, and sought out, for them, the circumstances of the people. (Mgh.)

5 tajasRaRa
5: see 1, in five places.

8 Uijotasasa
8: see 1, first and last sentences. ― -b2- AjtRst AlUibilu AlbaAriDu, (A,) or AlkalaOa, (K,) (tropical:) The camels sought out the first sprouts of the herbage with their mouths: (A:) or cropped the herbage with their majaAsR, (K,) i. e., their mouths. (TA.)

jasiysN jsys
jasiysN: see jaAsuwsN

jasRaAsN jsAs
jasRaAsN: see jaAsuwsN ― -b2- (tropical:) The lion that marks his prey with his claws: (K, TA:) or one that traverses a land. (Aboo-Sa'eed El-Yeshkuree, TA.) ― -b3- AljasRaAsapN A certain beast, that will be in the islands, that will search after news, or tidings, and bring them to Ed-Dejjál [or Antichrist]. (Lth, L, K.)

jaAsRapN jAs jAsh jAsp
jaAsRapN a dial. var. of HaAsRapN, (Msb,) and sing. of jawaAsRN, (Msb, TA,) which is syn. with HawaAsRN, (Kh, S, A, K,) signifying The five senses. (TA.) See HaAsRapN.

jaAsuwsN jAsws
jaAsuwsN (tropical:) A spy, who searches for, and brings, information, news, or tidings: (S, * Msb, * TA:) or one who is acquainted with private affairs of an evil nature: as also jasiysN↓ (K) [and jasRaAsN↓:] and naAmuwsN signifies one who is acquainted with private affairs of a good nature: (TA:) pl. jawaAsiysu. (A.)

majasRN mjs
majasRN (A, TA) and majasRapN↓ (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) The place which one feels with his hand, (A,* Mgh, K, TA,) for the purpose of testing it, that he may form a judgment of it: (Mgh:) and ↓the latter, the place which the physician feels [to know if a patient be hot or cold]: (S, Msb:) pl. majaAsRu. (S, A, Msb, K.) You say, majasRatuhu↓ HaArRapN [The place in which one feels him is hot]. (A, TA.) And kayofa taraI majasRahaA [How dost thou find the place in which one feels her?]; referring to a sheep or goat; to which one answers, "Indicative of fatness." (A.) ― -b2- [Hence, (assumed tropical:) Anything external which indicates the internal condition.] It is said in a prov., (S, A, Msb, K,) relating to camels, (Msb,) OafowaAhuhaA majaAsRuhaA, (S, A, K,) or majaAsRuhaA OafowaAhuhaA, (Msb,) or OaHonaAkuhaA majaAsRuhaA, (A, K,) (assumed tropical:) [Their mouths, or their palates, are the things which indicate their internal condition:] for if they eat well, he who looks at them sufficiently knows their fatness, (S, Msb, K,) without feeling them: (S, K:) if one see them eat well, it is as though he felt them: (A, TA:) or, accord. to AZ, they feel the herbage, to test it, with their heads [or mouths] and their palates: so that, accord. to his explanation, the term mjAsR is tropically applied to these parts. (TA.) The prov. relates to external evidences of things explaining their internal qualities. (K) [And hence,] raEati AlUibilu AlkalaOa bimajaAsRihaA, (K) (tropical:) The camels cropped the herbage with their mouths. (TA.) ― -b3- You say also, fulaAnN waAsiEu AlmajasRi, like as you say raHobu AlcRiraAEi (tropical:) [app. meaning Such a one is liberal, munificent, or generous]: and in the contrary case, DayRiqu AlmajasRi, (A,) or AlmajasRapi↓, (K,) or both, (TA,) signifying gayoru raHobi AlSRadori (tropical:) [app., not liberal]; (K, TA;) and not waAsiEu AlsRarobi [which is explained as meaning of ample bosom, and judgment, and love; and of ample way, or course of proceeding: but I rather incline to think that the right reading is waAsiEu AlsRirobi, and the meaning, of ample, or large, mind, or heart]. (TA.) You also say, laDiyqFA UinRa fiI majasRatika↓ (A) or majasRika (TA) (tropical:) [app,. Verily in thy bosom, or mind, or heart, is narrowness; or in thee is illiberality.]

majasRahu mjs mjsh mjsp
majasRahu: see, majasRN, throughout. ― -b2- It may also be used as an inf. n. of jasRahu in the first of the senses assigned to it above. (Mgh.)

1 jasaOa c
1. jasaOa, aor
jasaAa
inf. n. jusuwoCN and jusoOapN, (K,) thus in the corrected copies of the K, but in some copies the latter inf. n. is written jusaMCapN, (TA,) It (a thing, TA) was, or became, hard, tough, rigid, or stiff; (K, TA;) as also jasaA, aor
jasuAa
(Msb and K in art. jsw.) ― -b2- jasaOato yaduhu, aor
jasaAa
inf. n. jasoCN, His hand became hard, tough, callous, (S, TA,) coarse, or rough, (TA,) from work. (S, TA.) ― -b3- jasaOato mafaASiluhu His joints became rigid, or stiff. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jusiYati AlOaroDu The ground became hard, or hard and level, and rough: from jasoCN, explained below. (Ks, K.)

HasoCN HsC
HasoCN Hard, or hard and level, and rough, ground, (jaladN xaXinN, Ks, K, TA,) resembling small pebbles. (TA.) [Accord. to some copies of the K, Rough skin (jilodN xaXinN).] ― -b2- Frozen water, (K, TA,) resembling hail [strewed on the ground], (TA.)

jusoOapN c
jusoOapN Hardness, toughness, callousness, [coarseness, or roughness,] of the hand, from work. (S.) ― -b2- Rigidity, or stiffness, of the neck, (S, K, TA,) in a horse or the like. (S, TA.)

yadN jasoMCN yd jsMC
yadN jasoMCN A hard, tough, callous, coarse, or rough, hand. (K, TA.)

jaAsiYN c
jaAsiYN [Hard, tough, rigid, or stiff: see 1]. You say jabalN jaAsiYN [A hard, or hard and rugged, mountain]. (TA.) And SxuwrN jaAsiYapN [Hard, or hard and rugged, rocks]. (TA.) And nabotN jaAsiYN A rigid, or tough, plant. (TA.) And OaroDN jaAsiYapN Hard, or hard and level, and rough, ground; (TA;) as also majosuwoCapN↓. (Ks, K.) And makaAnN jaAsiYN A rugged place; as also XaAsiYN. (TA.) And daAbRapN jaAsiYapN AlqawaAYimi A beast, or horse or the like, having rigid, or stiff, legs, that will hardly bend. (TA.)

jaAsiYaMCu c
jaAsiYaMCu [in the CKjA siyAC] Hardness, toughness, rigidness, or stiffness; and ruggedness, or roughness. (K,* TA.)

majosuwoCapN mjsh mjsp mjswCh mjswCp
majosuwoCapN: see jaAsiYN

1 jasida jsd
1. jasida, aor
jasada
(S, K,) inf.n. jasadN. (S, KL,) It (blood) stuck, or adhere, (S K, KL,) bihi [to him, or it]: (S, K:) and it (blood) became dry. (KL.)

4 Oujosida c
4. Oujosida It (a garment) was made to stick, or adhere, to the jasad [or body]. (Fr, S.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. UijosaAdN, It (a garment) was dyed so that it stood up by reason of [the thickness of] the dye. (ISK, S.) [See mujosadN.]

5 tjsRd jsd tjsd
5. tjsRd from Aljasadu is like tjsRm from Aljisomu: (S:) [apparently signifying He became, or assumed, a jasad, or body; or became corporeal, or incarnate; and thus it is used by late writers, and in the present day: but tjsRm generally signifies he became corpulent: accord. to the TA, tjsRd, said of a man, is like tjsRm: accord, to the KL, the former signifies he became possessed of a body: accord. to the PS, he became corporeal, or corpulent.]

jasadN jsd
jasadN The body, with the limbs or members, [or whole person,] of a human being, and of a jinnee (or genie), and of an angel: (El-Bári', L, Msb, K:) it is thus applied only to the body of a rational animal; (El-Bári', Msb;) to no body that is nourished with food except that of a human being; but to the body of every rational creature that neither eats nor drinks, such as the genii and the angels: (L:) [the genii, however, are commonly believed to eat and drink:] or, accord. to ISd, it seems to be applied to a body other than that of a human being tropically: (TA:) the [golden] calf of the Children of Israel cried, but did not eat nor drink; [wherefore it is termed
jsd;] and in the Kur [vii. 146 and xx. 90], jasadFA is a substitute for EijolFA, or it may be meant for caA jasadK: (L:) [but see another explanation of jsdA, as there used, below:] or jasadN is syn. with badanN [which is generally held to signify the body without the head and arms and legs]: (S, A:) the pl. is OajosaAdN. (Lh, Msb, TA.) Lh mentions the saying, UinRahaA laHasanapu AlOajosaAdi [Verily she is beautiful in respect of body]; as though the sing. of which the pl. is thus used were applied to every separate part. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Saffron; (S, Msb, K) as also jisaAdN↓: (Lth, IAar, ISk, S, A, Msb, K:) or a similar dye: (S:) and ↓the latter signifies also a similar dye; (Lth, Msb,) red, or intensely yellow: (Lth, TA:) or bastard saffron; syn. EuSofurN; (Msb;) and so the former word. (L.) ― -b2- Also, (S, L, Msb, K,) and jasidN↓ (L, K) and jaAsidN↓ (L, Msb, K) and jasiydN↓ (L, K) and jisaAdN↓, (R,) (assumed tropical:) Blood; (S;) as also mujosadN↓, as being likened to saffron: (Ham p. 215:) or dry blood: (R, L, Msb, K:) pl. of the first as above. (Ham p. 127.) ― -b3- Some say that EijolFA jasadFA, in the Kur, [in two verses referred to above,] means A red golden calf. (S.)

jasidN jsd
jasidN: see jasadN: ＝ -A2- and see also jaAsidN.

jisaAdN jsAd
jisaAdN: see jasadN, in three places.

jasiydN jsyd
jasiydN: see jasadN.

jaAsidN jAsd
jaAsidN Blood sticking to (bi) a person; as also ↓. (S.) ＝ -A2- See also jasadN.

jalosadN jlsd
jalosadN (L, K in art. jlsd) and Aljalosadu (S, L, K, TA, in the CK AljalRasadu) the name of A certain idol, (S, L, K,) which was worshipped in the time of paganism: (L:) the l is an augmentative letter accord. to J and most of the leading lexicologists; but F disapproves of the mention of the word in this art. (TA.)

mujosadN mjsd
mujosadN Red. (S.) ― -b2- Also, (S, Msb, K,) and sometimes mijosadN↓, (IF, Msb,) and mujasRadN↓, (K,) A garment dyed with saffron: (K:) or with bastard saffron: (IAth, TA:) dyed with jisaAd: (IF, Msb:) or saturated with dye: (S:) or one says, EalaI fulaAnK vawobN muXobaEN mina AlSibogi [Upon such a one is a garment saturated with dye]; and Ealayohi vawobN mufodamN [Upon him is a garment saturated with red dye]; and when it is standing up by reason of [the thickness of] the dye, it is termed mujosadN: (ISK, S:) the pl. of this word is majaAsidu. (S.) ― -b3- See also what next follows: ― -b4- and see jasadN.

mijosadN mjsd
mijosadN, (S, A, K,) or mujosadN↓, (A,) the latter is the original form, because it is from Oujosida, meaning, "it was made to stick, or adhere, to the body,” (Fr, S,) like miTorafN and muTorafN, and miSoHafN and muSoHafN, (Fr, TA,) A garment worn next the body (IAar, S, A, K) by a woman, so that she sweats in it: (TA:) and a garment worn next the body dyed with saffron: (A:) pl. majaAsidu. (IAar, A.) [Hence,] laA yaxorujanRa UilaI AlmasaAjidi fiI AlmajaAsidi (IAar, A) They (women) shall by no means go forth to the mosques in the shirts that are next the body. (IAar.) ― -b2- See also mujosadN.

mujasRadN mjsd
mujasRadN: see mujosadN.

1 jasara jsr
1. jasara, (K,) aor.
jasura
, (TA,) inf. n. jasaArapN (A, K, KL) and jusuwrN, said of a man, (K,) He was daring, courageous, or bold: (A, KL:) he acted with penetrating energy, or sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness; syn. maDaI and nafaca. (K.) You say, jasara EalaI kacaA, aor.
jasura
, inf. n. jasaArapN, He ventured upon such a thing daringly, courageously, or boldly; (S, A;) as also tjAsr↓: (S:) and Ealayohi tjAsr↓ he emboldened himself against it, or him. (A, K.) And jasara EalaI EaduwRihi, (A, Msb,) aor.
jasura
, inf. n. jusuwrN and jasaArapN, (Msb,) He acted daringly, conrageously, or boldly, against his enemy. (A.) And laA yajosuru Oano yafoEala kacaA He dares not to do such a thing. (A.) ＝ -A2- jasara, (K,) inf. n. jasorN, (TA,) He (a man) arched, or vaulted, a jisor [or bridge]. (K.) ― -b2- It is said of [the giant] 'Ooj (Euwj), in a trad., waqaEa EalaI niyli miSora fajasarahumo sanapF, i. e., (tropical:) [He fell down upon the Nile of Egypt, and] became a bridge to them [for the space of a year]. (A.) ― -b3- And one says, jasarati AlrRikaAbu AlmafaAzapa, and AijotasaratohaA↓, (tropical:) The travellingcamels crossed, or passed over, the desert, (A, K,) as by a bridge: (A:) and AlsRafiynapu AlbaHora Ajtsrti↓ (tropical:) The ship crossed, or passed over, the sea: (A:) or rode upon, and passed through, the sea. (K.)

2 jsRrhu jsr jsrh jsrp
2. jsRrhu, (A, K,) inf. n. tajosiyrN; (K;) [and Ajsrhu↓; (see OagarRahu;)] He encouraged him; emboldened him. (A, K.)

4 Oajosara
4: see 2.

6 tjAsr tjAsr
6. tjAsr: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Also He stretched himself up, and raised his head. (K.) ― -b3- tjAsr lahu biAlEaSaA He put himself in motion to him (En-Nawádir, K) with the staff, or stick. (K.) ― -b4- tjAsrwA They acted with mutual daring or courage or boldness. (KL.) ― -b5- They journeyed [app. with boldness, or emulating one another in boldness]. (TA.) ― -b6- Alxayolu tajaAsaru biAlkumaApi [for tatajaAsaru] (tropical:) The horses convey the brave armed men away, or along, or across. (A.)

8 Uijotasara
8: see 1, last sentence, in two places.

jasorN jsr
jasorN: see jasuwrN, in two places. ― -b2- Also, applied to a he-camel, Sharp, spirited, or vigorous; syn. maADK [as contr. of baliydN]; as also jasorapN and mutajaAsirapN↓ applied to a she-camel: or (so in the K accord. to the TA; but in the CK, “ and ”) tall: (K:) or tall and bulky: and with p, applied to a she-camel, it has this last signification; (TA;) or signifies strong, and bold to endure travel: (A, TA:) the masc. epithet applied to a he-camel is rare. (Lth, TA.) ― -b3- Also Large, or bulky; applied to a camel, (S, K,) &c., (S,) or to anything, (K,) or to any limb, or member: (TA:) fem. with p. (S, K.) ― -b4- jasorapu AlsRawaAEidi, and AlmuxadRami, Full or plump [in the fore arms, and in the place of the anklet]; applied to a girl, or young woman. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also what next follows.

jisorN jsr
jisorN and jasorN↓ [A bridge; and a dyke, or causeway:] that on which one crosses over a river or the like; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as a qanoTarap and the like; (TA;) whether built or not built: (Mgh, Msb:) and a bridge of boats; boats bound together, and tied to stakes in the bank, being over a river; see qanoTarapN: (TA:) pl. (of pauc., TA) OajosurN (K) and (of mult., TA) jusuwrN. (S, Msb, K.) [Hence,] Almawotu jisorN yuwaSRilu AlHabiyba UilaI AlHabiybi (tropical:) [Death is a bridge that conveys the friend to the friend]. (TA.) And jaEala TaAEatahu jisorFA UilaI najaAtihi (tropical:) [He made his obedience a bridge to his safety]. (A, TA.)

jasuwrN jsr jswr
jasuwrN Daring, courageous, or bold: (S, A:) or courageous and tall; as also jasorN↓: (K:) or courageous; and also tall and bulky; applied to a man; and so jasorN↓: (TA:) fem. of the former without, and sometimes with, p: (Msb:) and of the latter with p: (TA:) pl. of the former jusurN and jusorN. (K, TA.) It is not applied to a hecamel; but with p is applied to a she-camel, meaning Bold to traverse rugged, or difficult, tracts. (Msb.)

jasRaArN jsAr
jasRaArN Very daring or courageous or bold. (TA.)

mutajaAsirapN mtjAsr mtjAsrh mtjAsrp
mutajaAsirapN: see jasorN.

1 jasuma jsm
1. jasuma, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
jasuma
, (K,) inf. n. jasaAmapN, (Msb, TA,) He, or it, (a thing, S,) was, or became, great, or large: (S, K:) or so jasima, aor.
jasama
, inf. n. jasamN: and the former, it (a thing) was, or it, was, or became, great, big, or bulky: (Msb:) or he, or it, was, or became, great, or large, in body: (KL:) or he, or it, was, or became, corpulent; or corporeal, or bodied; as also tjsRm↓. (MA, PS.)

2 jsRm jsm
2. jsRm, inf. n. tajosiymN, He, or it, made, or rendered, corporeal; or great, large, big, or bulky. (KL.) ― -b2- [He made to be solid, or to have length and breadth and thickness.]

5 tajasRama
5: see 1. ― -b2- [Hence,] tjsRm fiI EayoniI kacaA (tropical:) Such a thing assumed a form, or shape, [or an embodiment,] in my eye. (TA.) And tjsRm fulaAnN mina Alkarami (tropical:) [app. Such a one was, or became, an embodiment of generosity]. (TA.) And kaOanRahu karamN qado tajasRama (tropical:) [app. As though he were generosity embodied]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- tjsRm fulaAnFA (tropical:) He chose such a one (S, K, TA) mino bayoni Alqawomi [from among the people, or party], (S,) or mina AlEaXiyrapi faOarosalahu [from the kinsfolk, or tribe, &c., and sent him]: (TA:) as though he directed his course, or aim, to, or towards, his jisom [or body]; like as you say, taOayRayotuhu, meaning “ I directed my course, or aim, to, or towards, his Myap, and his XaxoS. ” (S.) [See also 5 in art. jXm.] One says also, tajasRamohaA naAqapF mina AlUibili qaQnoHarohaA [Choose thou her, a she-camel from among the camels, and stick her]. (TA.) ― -b2- tjsRm AlOaroDa (assumed tropical:) He betook himself towards the land, or country, (S, K,) desiring
to go thither. (S.) ― -b3- tjsRm AlrRamola, (S, K,) and Aljabala, (S,) (assumed tropical:) He mounted, or ascended, the greater part of the sand, (S, K,) and of the mountain. (S.) [See also 5 in art. jXm.] ― -b4- tjsRm AlOamora (tropical:) i. q. rakiba muEoZamahu; (S, K, TA;) i. e., He ventured upon, embarked in, or undertook, the main part, or bulk, of the affair: (TK:) or he constrained himself to do it, or perform it; as also tjXRmhu: (Aboo-Mihjen, Aboo-Turáb, TA:) or both these verbs signify he took it, or imposed it, upon himself, or he undertook it, in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience. (Aboo-Turáb, TA in art. jXm.) You say also, fulaAnN yatajasRama AlmajaAsima↓ and yatajaXRamu AlmajaAXima (tropical:) [app. meaning Such a one undertakes, in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience, those things, or affairs, that are causes of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience; i. e., difficult, or troublesome, or inconvenient things or affairs: supposing the two nouns to be pls. of which the sings. are majosamapN and majoXamapN, of the measure mafoEalapN, like maboxalapN and majobanapN and maXRaqapN (originally maXoqaqapN) &c.]. (TA.)

jisomN jsm
jisomN The body, with the limbs or members; syn. jasadN; (AZ, S, Msb;) as also jusomaAnN↓ and juvomaAnN: (AZ, S, Msb: *) or jisomN and jusomaAnN↓ are syn. with jasadN; (As, S;) or signify the whole body and limbs or members of a man, (K, and T and Msb in explanation of jsm,) and of a beast, a camel, and the like, (T, Msb,) and of any other species, (K,) of large make; (T, Msb, K;) and juvomaAnN is syn. with XaxoSN [app. as meaning “ a person ”]; and jusomaAnN↓ signifies the whole jisom of a man: (As, S:) or jisomN signifies [a body, or material substance; a solid;] a thing having length and breadth and thickness; so that, when it is cut and divided, no portion thereof ceases to be a jisom; whereas a XaxoS [meaning “ a person ”] ceases to be a XaxoS by its being divided: (Er-Rághib, TA:) a thing that is capable of being divided in length and breadth and thickness is called jisomN TabiyEiIRN, and also, because it is a subject of investigation, or inquiry, in instruction in the mathematical studies, jisomN taEoliymiIRN: (KT:) pl. [of pauc.] OajosaAmN and [of mult] jusuwmN. (K.) You say, vaAba jisomuhu, (M, A, K, in art. vwb,) and OavaAba jisomuhu, (IKt, M, ib.,) and vaAba Uilayohi jisomuhu, (T, M, A, ib.,) (tropical:) He became fat, after leanness; (A;) his good state of body returned to him; (M, K; *) his condition of body became good, after extenuation; and health, or soundness, thereof returned to him. (T.) And UinRahu laHaniyfu AljusomaAni↓ [Verily he is slender, spare, or lean, of body]. (TA.) ― -b2- AlOajosaAmu Almuxotalifapu AlTRabaAYiEi [The material substances of different natures; also called AlOajosaAmu AlsRaboEapu the seven material substances, and AlfilicaAtu; namely,] the EanaASir [which are the four elements, fire, air, earth, and water,] and the three products composed of these, (KT,) which are minerals, vegetables, and animals. (Note in a copy of the KT.) AlOajosaAmu AlTRabiyEiyRahu, as used by those who study to discover occult things, signifies The EaroX and the kurosiIR: and AlOajosaAmu AlEunoSuriyRapu, everything beside these two, of the heavens and the [elements termed] OusoTuqusaAt therein. (KT.)

jisomiIRN jsm jsmI jsmy jsmyy
[jisomiIRN Bodily, or corporeal.]

jisomiyRapN jsm jsmy jsmyh jsmyp
[jisomiyRapN Bodiliness, or corporeity.]

jusomaAnN jsm jsmAn
jusomaAnN: see jisomN, in four places.

jusomaAniIRN jsm jsmAn jsmAnI jsmAny
jusomaAniIRN: see jasiymN.

jusaAmN jsAm jsym
jusaAmN: see what next follows

jasiymN jsym
jasiymN Great; large; (S, Msb, K;) as also jusaAmN↓: (S, K:) big; bulky: (Msb:) fem. with p: (K:) pl. jisaAmN (S, Msb) [and jusumN also, like as jududN is pl. of jadiydN]: and corpulent, large in body, or big-bodied; (K, * TA;) as also jusomaAniIRN↓, applied to a man. (TA.) You say, huwa mino jisaAmi AlOumuwri [It is one of great affairs or events]: and mino jasiymaAti AlxuTuwbi [meaning the same, or of great afflictions or calamities]. (TA.) And jusumN [likewise, or OumuwrN jusumN,] signifies Great affairs or events. (TA.) jasiymu AlOamori signifies [also] The bulk, or the greater, main, principal, or chief, part, of the affair; and so AlOamori Oajosamu↓. (S.) ― -b2- [The pl.] jusumN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Intelligent men. (TA.) ― -b3- jasiymu AlOaroDi Elevated land over which water has risen: (K, * TA:) pl. jisaAmN. (K.)

Oajosamu c
Oajosamu Greater, larger, bigger, or bulkier; or greatest, largest, biggest, or bulkiest. (S, K.) See also jasiymN.

majaAsimu mjAsm
majaAsimu: see 5, last sentence.

jsw jsw
jsw: omitted in some copies of the S.

1 jasaA js jsA
1. jasaA, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor.
jasuma
, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. jasowN (M, K) and jusuwRN, (M, TA,) He, or it, (a man, M, TA, or a thing, Msb,) was, or became, hard, tough, rigid, or stiff: (M, Msb, K:) [see also jasaOa: or, said of a man,] he was, or became, hard, rough, harsh, or ungentle; contr. of laTufa. (S.) And jasati Alyadu, inf. n. jusuwRN and jasFA, The hand, or arm, was, or became, dry, or tough, or hard, (S, TA,) in the bones, with little flesh; (TA;) and in the same sense the verb is said of other things. (S.) ― -b2- It (water) congealed, or froze. (S, TA.) ― -b3- Also, inf. n. jusuwRN, He (an old man) attained the utmost age [so that his limbs became rigid]. (S, TA.)

3 jAsAhu jAs jAsAh jAsAp
3. jAsAhu, (K,) inf. n. mujaAsaApN, (TA.) He treated him, or regarded him, with enmity, or hostility. (K, TA.)

yadN jaAsiyapN yd jAsyh yd jAsyp
yadN jaAsiyapN A hand, or an arm, dry, or tough, or hard, in the bones, with little flesh. (TA.) And daAbRapN jaAsiyapN AlqawaAYimi A beast having tough, or hard, legs. (TA.) And rimaAHN jaAsiyapN Stiff, rigid, or tough, and hard, spears. (TA.) [See also jaAsiYN, in art. jsO.]

1 jaXRahu c
1. jaXRahu, (S, A, K,) aor.
jaXuXa
, inf. n. jaXRN, (S,) He ground it (namely wheat, S, or grain, A) coarsely; (S, A;) as also OajaXRahu↓. (S.) ― -b2- He bruised, brayed, or pounded, it: and he broke it: (S, K:) as also OajaXRahu↓. (K) ― -b3- He beat him, or struck him, with a staff or stick. (S, K.)

4 OajoXaXa
4: see 1, in two places.

juXRapN c
juXRapN (A, K, TA) and jaXaXN↓ (TA) Loudness, or vehemence, of voice or sound: (A, K, TA:) and a rough sound coming forth from the xayaAXiym [or air-passages in the nose], in which is a hoarseness. (K, TA.) You say, fiI Sahiyli Alfarasi jaXaXN↓ In the neighing of the horse is a rough sound: (TA:) which is one of the qualities approved in horses. (IDrd.) And fiI Sawoti Alqawosi juXRapN Einoda AlrRamoIi In the sound of the bow is a roughness of twanging on the occasion of shooting. (AHn TA.)

jaXaXN c
jaXaXN: see juXRapN, in two places.

jaXiyXN c
jaXiyXN Wheat coarsely ground; as also majoXuwXN↓. (S.) ― -b2- And, [as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates,] (TA,) as also jaXiyXapN↓, (S, K, TA,) What is coarsely ground, (S, K, TA,) of wheat &c., (S,) or of wheat and the like: (K, TA:) or the former, grain when bruised, brayed, or pounded, before it is cooked: and ↓the latter, such as is cooked: but ISd says that this distinction is not of valid authority. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, the former, i. q. sawiyqN [Meal of parched barley or wheat, coarsely ground, which is made into a kind of gruel]; (El-Fárisee, S, K;) and so ↓the latter: (A:) or ↓the latter is the n. un. (El-Fárisee.) You say, AisoqiniI jaXiyXapN↓ Give thou me to drink [some] swyq. (A.) Or swyq is not called jXyXp↓, but is called jaciycapN, q. v. (TA.) ― -b4- And the former, (Sh, K,) or jaXiyXapN↓, (TA in art. dX,) Wheat coarsely ground, and put into a cooking-pot, into which some flesh-meat is thrown, or some dates, and then cooked: (Sh, K:) also called daXiyXapN: (TA:) or a soup made of coarsely bruised wheat. (TA in art. dX.)

jaXiyXapN c
jaXiyXapN: see jaXiyXN, in seven places.

OajaXRu c
OajaXRu Having a rough, (S, K,) or loud, or vehement, (A,) voice, or sound: (S, A, K:) applied to a man, and a horse, and thunder, (A, K,) &c. (K.) You say, rajulN OajaXRu AlSRawoti A man having a [rough, or] loud, or vehement, voice. (A.) And farasN OajaXRu, (A,) or OajRaXu AlSawoti, (S, TA,) A horse in whose neighing is a roughness. (TA.) And saHaAbN OajaXRu, (As,) or OajaXRu AlrRaEodi, (S,) Clouds that thunder vehemently. (As.) And qawosN jaXRaMCu, [jXRMC being the fem. of AjXR,] A bow having a rough twanging, (AHn, K,) when one shoots with it. (AHn.) ― -b2- AlOajaXRu is also the name of One of the sounds of which musical modulations are formed, (Kh, K,) which are three in number; [app. meaning the treble, tenor, and bass, clefs; the last being that to which this
term is applied;] the sound thus called being from the head, (Kh,) issuing from the xayaAXiym [or air-passages in the nose], having in it a roughness and hoarseness, (Kh, K,) and followed by a gradual fall (taHadRur) [of the voice] modulated in accordance to that same sound, and then followed by a sound [in my original biwaXoIK, but I think it probable that this is a mistranscription for biwaHoIK, or biwaHFI, or the like, for, though waXoIN might perhaps, by straining a metaphor, be applied to denote a varied sound, its being understood in this sense seems to be forbidden by its being here added] like the first. (Kh, TA.) [This explanation is perhaps illustrated by the fact that the bass in the music of the Arabs is often formed of one prolonged note, falling and rising.] ― -b3- Also jaXRaMCu, [OaroDN being understood,] A pebbly plain, fit for palm-trees. (K, TA.)

mijaXRN c
mijaXRN, (S,) or mijaXRapN↓, (A,) or both, (K,) A mill (S, K) with which jaXiyX is ground: (S:) or a small mill with which one grinds coarsely. (A.)

mijaXRapN c
mijaXRapN: see what next precedes.

majoXuwXN c
majoXuwXN: see jaXiyXN.

1 jaXaOato nafosuhu c
1. jaXaOato nafosuhu, (S, K,) aor.
jaXaAa
, (K,) inf. n. juXuwoCN, (S, K, KL,) like quEuwdN, (TA,) and jaXaMCN, (KL, [or jaXaON, so Golius on the authority of the KL,]) [like jaOaXato nafosuhu, and jaAXato,] His soul [or stomach] heaved, by reason of grief or fright: (S, K; and so in the O; but in one copy of the K, by reason of grief or joy: TA:) or [simply] heaved, or rose: (T in art. vwr:) and heaved, or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; (K;) i. q. xabuvato and laqisato: (Sh, TA:) and jaXaOato UilaIRa nafosiI My soul [or stomach] heaved, or became agitated by a tendency to vomit, or became heavy, (xabovato,) in consequence of pain from something that it disliked. (ISh, TA.) ― -b2- jaXaOa Eani AlTRaEaAmi He nauseated food, in consequence of indigestion. (TA.) ― -b3- jaXaOati Alganamu The sheep emitted a sound from their throats. (Lth, K.) ― -b4- jaXaOati AlOaroDu (tropical:) The earth put forth all its plants, or herbage: like as they say, qaMCati AlOaroDu OukolahaA [lit. “ the earth vomited her victuals ”]. (TA.) ― -b5- jaXaOati AlrRiyaADu birubRaAhaA (tropical:) [The meadows, or gardens,] put forth [their good things]. (TA.) ― -b6- jaXaOati AlbilaAdu biOaholihaA (tropical:) [The countries, or towns, &c.,] cast forth [their inhabitants]. (TA.) ― -b7- jaXaOati AlbiHaAru biOamowaAjihaA (tropical:) [The seas] cast forth [their waves]. (TA.) ― -b8- Also jaXaOa said of the sea, (tropical:) It rushed on, (TA,) grew dark, (K, TA,) and was tumultuous with its waves; (TA;) and [in the CK “ or ”] impended over one. (K, TA.) And in like manner said of the night, (tropical:) It came on suddenly, (TA,) grew dark; (K, TA;) and [in the CK “ or ”] impended over one. (K, TA.) ― -b9- jaXaOati AlwaHoXu (assumed tropical:) The wild animals made a single leap, or spring. (TA.) ― -b10- jaXaOa Alqawomu (assumed tropical:) The people, or company of men, went forth from one country, or town, to another. (S, K, TA.) It is said in a trad., jaXaOati AlrRuwma EalaI Eahodi Eumara (assumed tropical:) The Greeks rose, and advanced from their country [in the time of 'Omar]. (TA.)

2 jaXRaAa
2: see 5.

5 tjXRO c
5. tjXRO, (S,) inf. n. tajaXRuWN; (S, Mgh, K; [in the CK, AltRajaXRu is erroneously put for AltRajaXRuWu;]) or tajaXRaI, inf. n. tajaXRK; (Msb;) and jXRO↓, (S,) inf. n. tajoXiYapN; (S, K;) both signify alike; (S;) He eructed, or belched; i. e., emitted a sound accompanied with wind, from his mouth, on an occasion of satiation of the stomach, (Mgh, Msb,) intentionally: (Mgh:) or it (the stomach) emitted wind (K, TA) on an occasion of its impletion with food or drink. (TA.)

8 AjtXO AlbilaAda c
8. AjtXO AlbilaAda, and AijotaXaOa AlbilaAdu (assumed tropical:) [He found the country to disagree with him, and] the country disagreed with him. (S, K.)

jaXoCN c
jaXoCN A light bow: (S, K:) or a bow that makes a ringing sound: (Lth, TA:) or a light rod of the tree called naboE: (As, S:) pl. OajoXaMCu, (K,) anomalous, and asserted by IHsh to be rare, (TA,) and jaXaMtN. (K: in the CK, jaXoMtN.) ― -b2- sahomN jaXoCN A light arrow. (Yaakoob, TA.) ＝ -A2- A large number (IAar, K, TA) of men, and of cattle. (IAar, TA.)

juXoOapN c
juXoOapN: see juXaMCN. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Daybreak: [or,] accord. to 'Alee Ibn-Hamzeh, the blowing of the wind at daybreak. (TA.)

juXaOapN c
juXaOapN: see juXaMCN, in two places.

qawosN jaXoOaI c
qawosN jaXoOaI A ringing bow. (TA. [See also jaXRaMCu, voce OajaXRu, in art. jX.])

juXaMCN c
juXaMCN A belch; i. e., a sound accompanied with wind, from the mouth, on an occasion of satiation of the stomach; (Mgh, Msb;) a subst. from 5; (As, S, Msb, K;) as also juXaOapN↓ (S, K) and juXoOapN↓: (K: but the first and last of these three words are omitted in some copies of the K:) or ↓the second of these three words, accord. to some, is a superlative epithet, signifying a great, or frequent, belcher. (MF.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) An invasion of the night, and of the sea. (K, TA.) The torrent and the night (AlsRayolu waAllRayolu) are called AlOaEomayaAni [the two blind things] because their invasion is vehement. (TA.)

1 jaXaba c
1. jaXaba, aor.
jaXuba
; and jaXiba, aor.
jaXaba
; (K;) and jaXuba, aor.
jaXuba
, inf. n. jaXaAbapN; (TA;) said of wheat, or food, (TaEaAm,) It was gross, or coarse: (K, TA:) it was badly and coarsely ground: (TA:) or it was without seasoning, or condiment, or anything to render it savoury. (K.) ― -b2- And the first, It (a thing) was thick, gross, big, coarse, or rough. (TA.) ― -b3- And jaXuba, aor.
jaXuba
, inf. n. juXuwbapN, He (a man, TA) was a foul, or bad, eater. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- jaXabahu He ground it coarsely; namely, wheat. (K, TA.) ― -b2- jaXaba QllRehu XabaAbahu God caused his youth, or youthful vigour, to pass away: or rendered him vile and despicable (radRaOahu waOaqomaOahu): or may God cause &c. (K.)

12 AijoXawoXibuw c
12. AijoXawoXibuw accord. to some, or AixoXawoXibuwA accord. to others, occurs in a trad. of 'Omar; (TA in art. xXb;) [and J says, and so Az accord. to the TA,] the former, if used like the latter, is not improbably correct; but I have not heard it. (S.) [See art. xXb.]

jaXobN c
jaXobN: see jaXibN

juXobN c
juXobN The rinds of pomegranates: (K:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

jaXibN c
jaXibN (S, K) and jaXobN↓ and jaXiybN↓ and mijoXaAbN↓ (K) and majoXuwbN↓ (S, K,) applied to wheat, or food, Gross, or coarse: (S, K, TA:) badly and coarsely ground: (TA:) or without seasoning, or condiment, or anything to render it savoury: (K, TA:) jXb [probably jaXibN] signifies also anything disagreeable in taste, and choking: (TA:) and gross, or coarse, and dry, or tough: (IAth, TA:) and what is dry, or tough, of herbage. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, the first, A bulky and strong camel: (ISk, TA:) a thickboned horse. (Ham p. 207.)

jaXuwbN c
jaXuwbN A rough, or coarse, (or, as some say, TA,) short woman. (K, TA.)

jaXiybN c
jaXiybN: see jaXibu. ― -b2- Also Anything rough, gross or coarse, disagreeable to the taste, and choking. (K.) ― -b3- A thick, rough, or coarse, garment, or piece of cloth. (S.) ― -b4- A rough, or coarse, and old, worn-out, skin for water or milk. (TA.) ― -b5- Rude, uncivil, unkind, rough, speech or language. (TA.) ― -b6- And (applied to a man, TA) A foul, or bad, eater. (K, TA.)

mijoXabN c
mijoXabN Big, or bulky, and courageous, brave, or bold. (IAar, K.) ＝ -A2- [Also, accord. to Golius, as on the authority of Ibn-Maaroof, but in this case probably a mistranscription for miXojabN, A wooden thing upon which clothes are put.]

mujaXRabN c
mujaXRabN A man (Sh) coarse in his means of subsistence. (Sh, K.)

mijoXaAbN c
mijoXaAbN: see jaXibN ― -b2- Thick, gross, big, coarse, or rough, (S, and Ham p. 207,) and short. (Ham ib.) ― -b3- mijoXaAbu Albadani Thick, gross, or big, in body. (T, TA.)

majoXuwbN c
majoXuwbN: see jaXibN.

1 jaXara c
1. jaXara, aor.
jaXura
, (As, A, Mgh,) inf. n. jaXorN; (As, S, K;) and jXRr↓, (A,) inf. n. tajoXiyrN; (K;) He took, or sent, forth his beasts to pasture, (As, S, Mgh, K,) not to return in the evening: (As, S Mgh:) [or] he pastured his beast near to the tents or houses: (A:) [or] jaXorN signifies also one's pasturing his horse before his tent or house, after their covering: (K:) or a people's taking forth their horses and pasturing them before their tents or houses. (L.) ― -b2- And jaXorN and tajoXiyrN↓ also signify The leaving or neglecting [a thing]:(K, TA:) and dismissing [it]. (TA.) jaXara AlquroMna, meaning He estranged himself from
the Kur-aacute;n, is said of him who has neglected the reading or reciting of it for two months. (L from a trad.) ＝ -A2- jaXara AlmaAlu Eano Oaholihi The cattle went forth to the places of pasturage from their owners. (A.) ― -b2- jaXara AlrRajulu Eano Oaholihi (tropical:) The man journeyed away from his family, or wife. (A.) ― -b3- jaXara AlSRuboHu (aor.
jaXura
, S,) inf. n. juXuwrN, (S, A, K,) (tropical:) The dawn broke, (S,) or rose, (K,) or came forth. (A.)

2 jaXRara
2: see 1, in two places.

jaXorN c
jaXorN: see jaXarN, in three places.

jaXarN c
jaXarN Camels or sheep or goats pasturing in their place, not returning to their owners (As, S, K) at night: (K:) or [simply] not returning to their owners. (As, TA.) [See also mujaXRarN.] ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A people who pass the night with the camels, (As, S, K,) in their place, not returning to their tents or houses: (As, S:) who go forth with their beasts to the place of pasturage, and remain in their place, not returning to the tents or houses: the doing this is not considered as travelling, and therefore is not a legal reason for shortening the ordinary prayers: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) and jaXorN↓ signifies the same. (TA, as on the authority of A 'Obeyed. [But perhaps this latter is a mistranscription for juXRarN: see what follows.]) (tropical:) A man who is away (EazabN, K, TA) from his family, or wife, with his camels; (TA;) as also jaXiyrN↓: (K, TA:) and in like manner the former is applied to a company of men; and so juXRarN [a pl. of jaAXirN↓, q. v.]: you say qawomN jaXarN and juXRarN. (L, TA.) ＝ -A2- The herbs, or leguminous plants, of [the season, or rain, called] the rabiyE; (L, K;) as also jaXorN↓. (L.) And jXr [app. jaXarN or jaXorN↓] also signifies A pasture-land in which horses feed. (TA.)

jaXiyrN c
jaXiyrN: see jaXarN ＝ -A2- Also A [quiver of the kind called] wafoDap; (S, K;) i. e., a kinaAnap; and so jafiyrN; accord. to ISd, a [quiver of the kind called] jaEobap, of skins, slit in the side in order that the wind may enter it and the feathers may therefore not be eaten: (TA:) or, accord. to Z, i. q. jiraAbN (IAth, TA.) ― -b2- And A large juwaAliq [or sack]: (S, K:) pl. [of pauc.] OajoXirapN and [of mult.] juXurN. (TA.)

jaXRaArN c
jaXRaArN The owner (SaAHib) of a pasture-land in which horses feed. (K.) You say, "He is the jaXRaAr of our camels." (A, TA. [But it seems to be implied in the A that it signifies the same as jaAXirN as explained below.])

jaAXirN c
jaAXirN One who takes forth horses and camels to the pasture-land, and remains there: [see also jaXRaArN:] pl.juXRaArN: (TA:) [and juXRarN is another pl. of the same:] see jaXarN ― -b2- Also [the pl.] juXRarN Camels, and asses, going whithersoever they will. (TA.)

jaAXiriyRapN c
jaAXiriyRapN (tropical:) A drink that is taken at daybreak: (S, A, K:) you say, AiSoTabaHonaA AljaAXiriyRapa We drank the morning-draught that is taken at daybreak: (S, A:) and it has no verb: (S:) or it is only of camels' milk: (K:) or it is correctly of general application: or is properly of wine; for this is what is most frequently mentioned: and it is also used as an epithet: thus you say XarobapN jaAXiriyRapN (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A certain kind of food: (K, TA:) or a kind of food eaten at daybreak. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) The [last part of the night, called the] saHar: (K:) because near to daybreak. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) Midday: (K:) because of the appearance and spreading of its light. (TA.)

mujaXRarN c
mujaXRarN [A beast] made to pass the night in the pasture, away from its owner, not brought back in the evening: (K, * TA: [see also jaXarN:]) or not pastured near the water: (IAar, TA:) or that is pastured near to the water. (El-Mundhiree, TA.) And xayolN mujaXRarapN Horses pastured (S, K) biAlHimaI [in the place of pasturage that is prohibited to the public]. (S.)

1 jaXiEa c
1. jaXiEa, aor.
jaXaEa
, inf. n. jaXaEN, He was, or became, affected with the most vehement desire, eagerness, avidity, cupidity, or hankering, (S, O, K,) and, (O, K,) as explained by an Arab of the desert to As, (IDrd,) with the worst kind thereof, (IDrd, O, K,) for eating &c.: (TA:) or, as ex plained by another Arab of the desert to As, (IDrd,) he took his own share, and coveted the share of another: (IDrd, K:) and tjXRE↓ sig nifies the like; (S;) or i. q. taHarRaSa, q. v. (K.) ― -b2- jaXaEN also signifies The being impatient on account of separation from an associate. (TA.) ― -b3- And The being frightened, terrified, or afraid. (TA.)

5 tajaXRaEa
5: see 1.

6 tajaAXaEaA AlmaMCa c
6. tajaAXaEaA AlmaMCa They straitened each other in pressing to the water, and [so I render taEaATaXaA] vied, each with the other, in endeavouring to satisfy their thirst; (K;) on the authority of an Arab of the desert. (TA.)

jaXiEN c
jaXiEN part. n. of jaXiEa, Affected with the most vehement desire, &c.: pl. jaXiEuwna, (S, K,) and jaXaAEaI and juXaEaMCa and jiXaAEN are also pls. [of the same]. (TA.) ― -b2- AljaXiEu The lion. (TA.) ― -b3- rajulN jaXiEN baXiEN, A man in whom are combined impatience and fright and a heavy, or a heaving, state of the soul. (TA.)

jaXiyEN c
jaXiyEN One who assumes a false disposition, and that which is not in him. (TA.)

OajoXaEu c
OajoXaEu [comparative and superlative of jaXiEN; More, and most, affected with most vehement desire, &c.]. (TA.)

1 jaXima AlOamora c
1. jaXima AlOamora aor.
jaXama
, inf. n. jaXomN (S, Msb, K) and jaXaAmapN, (Msb, K,) He took, or imposed, upon himself the affair, or he undertook it, as a task, or in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience; (S, Msb, K;) as also tjXRmhu↓, (S, Msb, * K,) and tjsRmhu: (Aboo-Turáb, TA:) or ↓the second and third signify he constrained himself to do it, or perform it: (Aboo-Mihjen, Aboo-Turáb, TA in art. jsm:) and kacaA wakacaA tjXRm↓ He did such and such things against his will, and in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience. (TA.) [See also an ex. of tjXRm↓ in art. jsm;conj. 5, last sentence.] jaXimotu Uilayoka Earaqa Alqirobapi is said to mean [I have imposed upon myself difficulty or trouble or inconvenience, in coming to thee,] so that I have journeyed, and become in want of the water of the water-skin in the journey: or the meaning is, I have suffered, and imposed upon myself, difficulty or trouble or inconvenience, so that I have sweated like the water-skin: or by the Earaq of the qirobap is meant its Ealaq, i. e., its miEolaAq, by which it is carried; and the phrase means Uilayoka tajaXRamotu↓ Hamola Alqirbapi [I have impose upon myself, in spite of difficulty &c., in coming to thee, the carrying of the water-skin]; alluding to journeying and its difficulties: (Har p. 511:) [and in like manner,] one says, laka Earaqa Alqirobapa tajaXRamotu↓ (S in art. Erq.) The sportsman, when he has not taken any game, and has returned disappointed, says, maA jaXimotu Uilayoka ZilofFA [app. meaning I have not had the trouble of bringing to thee so much as a hoof of a gazelle or the like]. (AZ, TA.) And maA jaXimotu Alyawoma TaEaAmFA i. e., I have not eaten, to-day, food, is said on the occasion of the disappointment of any one seeking a thing. (AZ, TA.)

2 jXRmhu AlOamora c
2. jXRmhu AlOamora (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. tajoXiymN; (S;) and AjXmhu↓; (S, Msb, K;) He imposed upon him, or made him to undertake, the affair, as a task, or in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience; or he ordered, required, or constrained, him to do the thing, it being difficult or troublesome or inconvenient. (S, Msb, K.) Hence, (S, TA,) in a trad. of Zeyd Ibn-'Amr Ibn-Nufeyl, (TA,)
mahomaA tujaXRimoniI faUinRiI jaAXimu↓
[Whatever thou impose upon me, in spite of difficulty &c., I undertake it, in spite of difficulty &c.]. (S, TA.)

4 OajoXama
4: see 2.

5 tajaXRama
5: see 1, in six places. ― -b2- tajaXRamotu AlrRamola I mounted, or ascended, the greater part of the sand: some say thus; and some say tajasRamotu (TA.) ― -b3- tajaXRamotu fulaAnFA mino bayoni Alqawomi I directed my course, or aim, towards such a one, [and chose him, (like tajasRamotuhu q. v.,)] from among the people, or party. (Abu-n-Nadr, TA.)

jaXomN c
jaXomN A state of destruction, perdition, or death. (AA, TA.) ― -b2- See also juXamN.

juXomN c
juXomN: see juXamN ＝ -A2- Also Bad money: pl. juXuwmN (IKh, TA.)

jaXamN c
jaXamN: see juXamN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also Fatness. (AA, K.)

jaXimN c
jaXimN: see jaXiymN

juXamN c
juXamN Weight, or heaviness; (S, K;) as also jaXamN↓ (K,) and jaXomN↓ accord. to the K, but correctly juXomN↓, as in the A and L: (TA:) [and
and unpleasing, and a difficult or troublesome or an inconvenient, affair:] a subst. from tajaXRama kacaA wakacaA. explained above: see 1. (TA.) You say, OaloqaI fulaAnN EalaIRa juXamahu, (S,) or jaXamahu↓, (TA,) Such a one threw upon me his weight, or heavi ness: (S, TA:) to which Z adds, or his difficult, or troublesome, or inconvenient, affair, that he had imposed upon himself, or that was imposed upon him. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The jawof [i. e., the belly; or the chest; &c.]: or the breast, with the ribs that contain it: (K:) or the breast of a camel: (S, TA:) and the part [of the skin] of the camel's breast, and of the rest of the body thereof, with which the [kind of quiver called] qrn [i. e. qaranN] is covered. (TA.) You say, gatRahu bijuXamihi meaning He threw his breast upon him. (TA.)

juXumN c
juXumN [app. pl. of jaXiymN↓, like as jududN is pl. of jadiydN] Fat men: (IAar, K:*) and tall, crafty or cunning, and wicked or malignant, men. (IAar, TA.)

jaXuwmN c
jaXuwmN A man who takes, or imposes, upon him self, or who undertakes, affairs, with energy or vigour, or in an extraordinary degree, in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience. (Msb.)

jaXiymN c
jaXiymN (K.) or, as in the book of Kr. jaXimN↓, (TA,) Thick, gross, coarse, rough, rugged, rude, big, or bulky. (K.) See also juXumN

jaAXimN c
jaAXimN A man taking, or imposing, upon himself, or undertaking, an affair, in spite of difficulty or trouble or inconvenience. (Msb.) See 2.

AlmujoXimu c
AlmujoXimu The lion. (K.)

majaAXimu c
majaAXimu: see 5 in art. jsm

jawoXanN c
jawoXanN and jawoXaniIRN: see art. jwXn

2 jSRS jSS
2. jSRS He plastered a building with jiSR [or gypsum]: (Mgh, K:) or he made a house therewith: (Msb:) i. q. qaSRaSa, (S, TA,) which is of the dial. of El-Hijáz. (TA.)

jiSRN jS
jiSRN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jaSRN (S, Mgh, K,) but the former is the more chaste: (TA, from an Expos. of the Fs:) the latter is disapproved by IDrd, and disallowed by ISk; (TA;) and it is said in the Bári', on the authority of AHát, that the latter is the form used by the vulgar, and the former is that which is correct: (Msb:) [Gypsum; a certain substance] with which one builds, (S,) or plasters; (Mgh;) well known: (Msb, K:) arabicized; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) because j and S do not occur in any Arabic word; (Msb;) or, accord. to AZ, there are some [Arabic] words in which they both occur, as has been mentioned in art. AjS: from kajo (Mgh, K, [in the CK kaJo]) or, as some say, GaJo; which are Persian: (TA:) in the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz, qSR [i. e.qiSRN or qaSRN]. (Lth, TA.) [The n. un. is with p: see art. qS.]

jaSRaASN jSAS
jaSRaASN A preparer of jiSR [or gypsum]. (S, K.)

jaSRaASaAtN jSAS jSASAt
jaSRaASaAtN [pl. of jaSRaASapN] Places in which jiSR [or gypsum] is made. (K.)

1 jaZRa jZ
1. jaZRa, [aor., accord. to rule,
jaZiZa
, and inf. n., probably, jaZRN,] He was short and fat. (IAar, K.)

4 AjZR AjZ
4. AjZR He was, or became, proud; or excessively proud, corrupt, unbelieving, or disobedient. (Sgh, K.)

jaZRN jZ
jaZRN [probably an inf. n. used as an epithet,] applied to a man, (S,) Large; big; bulky; or large in body, corpulent, and fleshy: (S, K, TA:) or tall, large in body, a great eater and drinker, who exults, and behaves insolently and ungratefully to God: (Fr, TA:) occurring in a trad. describing the people of Hell. (S.)

1 jaEabahu jEb jEbh jEbp
1. jaEabahu (S, K,) aor.
jaEaba
, (K,) inf. n. jaEobN, (TA,) He prostrated him; he threw him down upon the ground; (S, K, TA;) like jaEafahu; (S;) as also jERbhu↓, (K,) ing. n. taEojiybN; (TA;) and jaEomaAhu↓ (S, K, [in the CK erroneously written jaEobaOah,]) like saloqaAhu from salaqahu, (S,) inf. n. jiEobaMCN. (S, TA [in the latter, in one place, probably by a mistake of a copyist, written jEbAp].) ― -b2- He in verted it, or him; he turned it, or him, upside down, or over, or inside out; syn. qalabahu. (K.) ― -b3- He collected it; (K;) mostly used in relation to that which is small in quantity, paltry, or inconsiderable. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jaEaba, (A, K,) and jaEaba jaEobapN, (A,) He made a quiver of the kind called jEbp. (A, K.)

2 jaERaba
2: see 1.

5 tajaERaba
5: see 7.

7 AnjEb AnjEb
7. AnjEb and tjERb↓ (K) and tajaEobaI↓ (S, K) He became prostrated, or thrown down upon the ground. (S, K.)

Q. Q. 1 jaEobaAhu jEb jEbAh jEbAp
Q. Q. 1. jaEobaAhu: see 1.

Q. Q. 2 tajaEobaI jEb tjEbI tjEby
Q. Q. 2. tajaEobaI: see 7.

jaEobapN jEb jEbh jEbp
jaEobapN A kinaAnap [or quiver] (A, K) for arrows (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) of the kind called nuXRaAb (S, A, Msb, K) and for those that are called nabol also: (Ham p. 154:) but some make a distinction between jaEobapN and kinaAnapN: the former, they say, is for nXRAb; and the latter, for nbl: (Mz, MF:) accord. to IDrd, the knAnp is only for nbl, and is of leather: that which is of wood is called jafiyr: and that which is of two pieces [of wood] joined together is called qrn [i. e. qaranN]: (Ham ubi suprà:) accord. to ISh, the jEbp is round and wide, with a cover on the top, over its mouth: the wafoDap is smaller, and its upper and lower parts are of equal size; whereas the jEbp is wide in its upper part, and contracted in its lower part; wide in its upper part that the feathers of the arrows [having ample room] may not become detached; for the arrows are put in the quiver with the points downwards: each of these two kinds is made of two corresponding pieces of wood: (TA:) the pl. is jiEaAbN (S, A, Msb, K) and jaEabaAtN. (Msb.) You say, nakabuwA AljiEaAba wasakabuwA AlnRuXRaAba [They inverted, or inclined, the quivers, and poured forth the arrows]. (A, TA.) And maEahu jaEobapN fiyhaA banaAtu Almawoti [With him is a quiver in which are the daughters of death; i. e., deadly arrows]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Also The largest of drinking-vessels. (MF, TA.)

juEobuwbN jEbwb
juEobuwbN A man (S) short, and ugly, or contemptible; or ugly, and small in body: (S, K:) or weak, and destitute of good: or vile, or mean, and despicable: (K:) or a low, mean, or sordid, and weak man: pl. jaEaAbiybu. (TA.)

jiEaAbapN jEAbh jEAbp jEbp
jiEaAbapN The art of making quivers of the kind called jiEaAb, pl. of jaEobapN. (A, K.)

jiEaAbiIRN jEAbI jEAby jEbp
jiEaAbiIRN: see what next follows.

jaERaAbN jEAb jEbp
jaERaAbN [and app. jiEaAbiIRN↓ also, as seems to be indicated in the K, where it is mentioned as a surname, but in the CK written jaERAbIR,] A maker of quivers of the kind called jiEaAb. (A, K.)

mijoEabN mjEb
mijoEabN One who often prostrates, or throws down, others, (SirRiyEN, [in some copies of the K, erroneously, SariyE,]) but is not himself prostrated, or thrown down. (K, TA.)

munojaEibN mnjEb
munojaEibN or mutajaERibN (accord. to different copies of the K) Dead, or dying; syn. mayRitN. (K.)

1 jaEuda jEd
1. jaEuda, aor.
jaEuda
, inf. n. juEuwdapN (S, A, Msb, K) and jaEaAdapN, (K,) said of hair, (S, A, Msb, K,) It was, or became, crisp, or curly, or twisted, and contracted; (Msb;) was, or became, the contr. of saboT, (K,) or of musotarosil: (Msb:) or was, or became, short: (Kr, K:) and jaEida, [aor.
jaEada
,] (Msb, TA,) inf. n. jaEadN, (TA,) signifies the same; (Msb, TA;) as also tjERd↓. (K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) It became contracted, and compacted in lumps; (L;) as also tjERd↓; (L, K; *) said of earth, (K,) or of moist earth. (L.) [The inf. n.] juEuwdapN is also sometimes used in describing the state of the froth, or foam, of a camel's mouth, when it is accumulated. (S.[See jaEodN.]) ― -b3- Also, said of a cheek, inf. n. juEuwdapN, (assumed tropical:) It was rough, or coarse, and short; contr. of Oasula. (L.)

2 jERdhu jEd jEdh jEdp
2. jERdhu, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. tajoEiydN, (S, A, Msb,) He crisped, or curled, or twisted, and contracted, it; (Msb;) made it the contr. of saboT, (K,) or of musotarosil; (Msb:) or made it short: (K:) namely, hair. (S, A, Msb, K.)

5 tajaERada
5: see 1, in two places.

jaEodN jEd
jaEodN, applied to hair, (S, A, Msb, K,) Crisp, or curly, or twisted, and contracted; (Msb;) contr. of saboTN (K,) or of musotarosilN: (Msb:) or short. (Kr, K.) ― -b2- Applied to a man, (S,) Having hair such as is termed jaEod: (S, Msb, K:) [or]
so jaEodu AlXRaEari: (A, TA:) fem. with p: (S, Msb, K:) pl. jiEaAdN. (A, Msb.) ― -b3- As an epithet of praise, it has two meanings; namely, (assumed tropical:) Compact in limbs, and strong in make; not flabby, nor of slack, or incongruous, make; (L;) or big, or bulky, and compact; (Ham p. 238;) or, as some say, light, or active: (TA:) and having crisp, or curly, not lank, hair; because lankness is the prevalent characteristic of the hair of the Greeks and Persians; and crispness, or curliness, is the prevalent characteristic of the hair of the Arabs: but very crisp, or frizzled, or woolly, hair, like that of the Zenj and the Nubians, is disapproved. (L.) ― -b4- [Hence,] (tropical:) Generous; bountiful; munificent; (T, S, A, K;) alluding to a man's being an Arab of generous disposition, because the Arabs are characterized by crisp, or curly, hair. (A.) As did not know jEd in this sense; but it occurs in many verses of the Ansár. (T, TA.) ― -b5- As an epithet of dispraise, it has also two meanings; namely, (assumed tropical:) Short, and incongruous in make: (L:) [contr. of saboTN:] ― -b6- and (tropical:) Niggardly; (As, T, S, L, K;) as also jaEodu Alyadayoni, (S, K,) and jaEodu AlOanaAmilu, (S,) and jaEodu AlOaSaAbiEu, (A,) or this signifies (assumed tropical:) having short fingers, (K,) and jaEodu AlbanaAni, and jaEodu AlkafRi, (Har p. 96,) and jaEodu AljanaAni; (A;) contr. of [saboTu Alyadayoni, and] sbTu Alyadi and sbTu AlbanaAni [&c.]: (Har ubi suprà:) and mean; ungenerous; base: (L:) and jaEodu AlqafaA (tropical:) mean, or ignoble, in respect of rank, quality, reputation, or the like. (A, K.) ― -b7- A camel having much fur: (K:) or having crisp, or curly, and abundant, fur. (S.) [Hence,] Oabuw AljaEodi a surname of The camel. (L.) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) Soft moist earth; as also vaEodN: (S:) or moist earth. (K.) ― -b9- (assumed tropical:) A mess of the kind called Hayos that is thick, (L, K,) not flowing; (L;) as also mujaERadN↓. (L, K.) IAar cites the following words of a poet, accusing a woman of foul conduct:
wataxoliTu biAlmaOoquwTi HayosFA mujaERadFA↓
[And she mixes thick Hys with the food prepared with OaqiT]; meaning, she confounds men together, and does not select him who is to have intercourse with her. (L.) ― -b10- (assumed tropical:) Froth, or foam, accumulated upon the fore part of the mouth of a camel. (S, * L.) And jaEodu AllRugaAmi (assumed tropical:) A camel having froth, or foam, accumulated upon the fore part of his mouth. (S, * L, K. *) ― -b11- (assumed tropical:) A cheek rough, or coarse, and short; not Oasiyl. (L, K.) And (assumed tropical:) A round face, with little miloH [or beauty], (K, TA,) or, as in some copies of the K, laHom [or flesh]. (TA.) And qadamN jaEodapN (tropical:) A short foot; (A, TA;) characteristic of low origin. (TA.) ― -b12- It is also applied, in the manner of an intensive epithet, to the plant called SilRiyaAn; and in like manner, with p, to the plant called buhomaI. (TA.) ― -b13- naAqapN jaEodapN (assumed tropical:) A she-camel compact in make, and strong. (TA.)

mujaERadN mjEd
mujaERadN: see jaEodN, in two places.

mutajaERidN mtjEd
mutajaERidN Moist earth contracted, and compacted in lumps. (L in art. Eqd.)

1 jaEara jEr
1. jaEara, aor.
jaEara
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. jaEorN; (Msb;) and AnjEr↓; (K;) said of a beast or bird of prey (S, Msb, K *) having claws, or talons, (S, K, *) or a hyena, and a dog, and a cat, (TA,) and metaphorically of a rat or mouse, (Msb,) He voided his dung. (S, Msb, K.)

5 tjERr jEr tjEr
5. tjERr, (S, K,) or tjERr bijiEaArK, (TA,) He bound upon his (i. e. his own) waist a rope of the kind called jiEaAr. (S, K, TA.)

7 UinojaEara
7: see 1.

jaEorN jEr
jaEorN, originally an inf. n., (Msb,) The dung of a beast or bird of prey (S, Msb, K) having claws, or talons; (S, K;) as also jaAEirapN↓; (K;) which is like rawovN in relation to a horse: (TA:) or the dung of the hyena: (A:) [and of the dog, and cat: see 1:] or dry dung upon the majoEar, q. v.: (K:) or dung that comes forth dry: (IAth, TA:) and (tropical:) that of the rat or mouse: (Msb:) pl. juEuwrN. (K.) ― -b2- See also juEoruwrN. ＝ -A2- Also Costiveness. (TA.)

juEorapN jEr jErh jErp
juEorapN A mark left by the rope called jiEaAr (Th, K) upon the waist of a man. (Th, TA.)

jaEoraMCu jErMC
jaEoraMCu: see majoEarN.

Oabuw jiEoraAna c
Oabuw jiEoraAna [in which the latter word is imperfectly decl. because it is a proper name ending with the augment An] The [black beetle called] juEal, (Kr, K, TA,) in a general sense: or, as some say, a certain species thereof. (TA.) ― -b2- And OumRu jiEoraAna, (K, TA,) or OumRu jiEoraAnapa, (so in a copy of the K,) The raxamap [or female of the vultur percnopterus]. (Kr, K.)

juEoruwrN jErwr
juEoruwrN A bad kind of dates; (Msb, K;) also metaphorically called AlfaOorapi jaEoru↓ [the rat's, or mouse's, dung], because of the bad smell, and the diminutiveness, thereof: (Msb:) and you also say juEoruwrN: (TA:) or a species of the daqal, which is the worst kind of dates: (S:) or a species of the [kind of palm-tree called] daqal that bears small things [or dates] in which is no good. (As, TA.) [See Eacoqu Aljubayoqi, in art. Hbq.]

jiEirRaI jErI jEry
jiEirRaI: see majoEarN.

jaEAri jEAr
jaEAri, (S, A, K,) like qaTaAmi, (K,) indecl., with kesr for its termination, because it deviates from its original form, which is jaAEirapN, and is of the fem. gender, and has the quality of an epithet in which that of a subst. is predominant, so that the thing to which it applies is known by it like as it is known by its proper name; and as it is prevented from being perfectly decl. by two causes, it must be indecl. by reason of three; as we also say with respect to HalaAqi, a proper name of death; (S;) The she-hyena; (S, A, K;) a name of that animal (S) because of the abundance of its dung; (S, A;) as also OumRu jaEaAri, and jayoEarN↓, and OumRu jaEowarK↓. (K.) Hence, OaEoyavu mino jaEaAri [More mischievous than the she-hyena]: a prov. (A, TA.) And tiysiI jaEaAri (K) Be thou like the he-goat in stupidity, O she-hyena; a prov. applied to a stupid man: (A and TA in art. tys, q. v.:) or EiyviI jaEaAri [Do mischief, O she-hyena]; a prov. used in declaring a thing to be vain, or false. (K.) And
ruwEiI jaEaAri waQnoZuriI Oayona Almafori
[for AlmafirRu, Be afraid, O she-hyena, and look where is a place to which to flee]: (K, * TA:) or ruwgiI [i. e. turn aside, this way and that]: (S and TA in art. rwg:) a prov. applied to him who seeks to escape, and cannot: (TA:) or with reference to a coward, and his submissiveness. (K.) And quwmiI jaEaAri [Rise, O she-hyena]: said to a woman, in reviling her; likening her to a she-hyena. (ISk, TA.)

jiEaArN jEAr
jiEaArN A certain mark made with a hot iron upon [the part called] the jaAEarataAni: (K:) accord. to the Tedhkireh of Aboo-'Alee, one of the marks, so made, of camels. (Ibn-Habeeb, TA.) ＝ -A2- A rope which a man who waters ties to a stake, and then binds upon his waist, when he descends into a well, lest he should fall into it: (S:) or a rope which a drawer of water binds upon his waist, (K, TA,) when he descends into a well, (TA,) lest he should fall into the well; (K, TA;) the end being in the hand of another man, who, if he falls, pulls him up with it. (TA.)

OumRu jaEowarN c
OumRu jaEowarN: see jaEaAri.

jayoEarN jyEr
jayoEarN: see jaEaAri.

jaAEirapN jAErh jAErp
jaAEirapN: see majoEarN. ― -b2- AljaAEirataAni The place of the [two marks made by cauterization which are called the] raqomataAni, in the buttocks (Aisot) of an ass: (S, K:) or the places of cauterization in the hinder part, upon the [two portions of the thighs called the] kaAcataAni, of an ass: (TA:) and the part, (S, K,) or two parts, (A,) which the tail strikes, (S, A, K,) upon the two thighs of a horse, (S, K,) or of a beast, where he is cauterized: (A:) or the two edges of the haunches projecting over the thighs [behind]; (As, S, K;) i. e., the two places which the farrier marks, making lines upon them [with a hot iron] (yaroquhumuaA): or the heads of the upper parts of the two thighs: or the depressed part of the haunch and thigh, in the place of the joint. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jaEorN.

majoEarN mjEr
majoEarN The rump, or podex; or the anus; [in the present day, the latter;] syn. duburN; (S, K;) and jaEoraMCu↓ and jiEirRaI↓ and jaAEirapN↓ the same; syn. AisotN; (K;) or the last (jAErp), as some say, i. q. Haloqapu AldRuburi. (S, K.)

mijoEaArN mjEAr
mijoEaArN A man very, or often, costive; (K;) as also mijoEaAru AlbaToni. (TA.)

Q. Q. 1 jaEomasa jEms
Q. Q. 1. jaEomasa He (a man, TA) deposited his ordure, or excrement, at once: (K, TA:) or in a dry, or tough, state. (TA.) The m is augmentative. (Sgh, TA.)

jEosN jEs
jEosN, (S, K,) and jiEosN↓, (TA,) and juEomuwsN↓; (AZ, S, and K in art. jEms,) the first of which
is post-classical; (S, K;) and the last, the term used by the Arabs [of the classical ages]; (S;) Human ordure, or excrement; (AZ, TA in art. jEms;) syn. rajiyEN: (S, K:) or the first signifies the place in which the juEomuws falls: (IDrd, K:) the m in the last word is augmentative; and its pl. is jaEaAmiysu. (S.) You say, ramaI bijaEaAmiysi↓ baTonihi [He cast forth the excrements of his belly]. (S.)

jiEosN jEs
jiEosN: see the next preceding paragraph.

juEomuwsN jEmws
juEomuwsN; pl. jaEaAmiysu: see jaEosN.

juEaAmisN jEAms
juEaAmisN A man (TA) who deposits his ordure, or excrement, at once: (K:) or in a dry, or tough, state: as also mujaEomisN↓. (TA.)

mujaEomisN mjEms
mujaEomisN: see what next precedes.

1 jaEafahu jEfh jEfp
1. jaEafahu, (S, K,) aor.
jaEafa
, (K,) inf. n. jaEofN, (TA,) He prostrated him; threw him down upon the ground; (S, K;) cast him upon the gronnd; like jaEabahu; (TA;) namely, a man; (S;) as also AjEfhu↓. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b2- He pulled it, or plucked it, out, or up; (S, K;) namely, a thing, (S,) or a tree; (K, TA;) and turned it over, or upside down; (TA;) as also AjtEfhu↓. (K, TA.)

4 OajoEafa
4: see 1.

7 AnjEf AnjEf
7. AnjEf [He became prostrated, thrown down upon the ground, or cast upon the ground: see its part. n., below]. ― -b2- It (a thing, S, or a tree, K) became pulled, or pluckt, out, or up. (S, K.)

8 UijotaEafa
8: see 1.

juEaAfN jEAf
juEaAfN: see what next follows.

jaAEifN jAEf
jaAEifN, applied to a torrent, i. q. juHaAfN [That carries away everything]; as also juEaAfN↓: (K:) and that overturns everything upon which it comes. (TA.)

majoEafN mjEf
majoEafN A place where one is prostrated, or thrown down upon the ground. (TA.)

majoEuwfN mjEwf
majoEuwfN Prostrated, or thrown down upon the ground; as also munojaEifN↓. (TA.)

munojaEifN mnjEf
munojaEifN: see what next precedes.

Q. 1 jaEofadapN jEfdh jEfdp
Q. 1. jaEofadapN [inf. n. of jaEofada] a compound word from the phrase jaEalaniI QllRehu fidaAka [May God make me thy ransom]. (Ibn-Dihyeh, TA.) [You say, jaEofadahu, meaning He said to him jElnI AllReh fdAk.]

jaEofarN jEfr
jaEofarN A small river; a rivulet, streamlet, or brook; (IAar, S, K;) or one that is larger than a jadowalN: (K:) or, as in the Nawádir, a small river, larger than a jdwl: (TA:) or a river, IDrd, IJ, TA,) absolutely: (TA:) if small, it is a falaj: (IDrd, TA:) or (TA, but in the K “ and ”) a large, wide river: (Ibn-El-Ajdábee, K:) [if so,] bearing two contr. significations: (K:) or (in some copies of the K “ and ”) a full river. (K.) ― -b2- Also (from the last of these significations, TA) (tropical:) A she-camel abounding with milk. (K, TA.)

1 jaEala jEl
1. jaEala, aor.
jaEala
, inf. n. jaEolN (S, Msb, K) and juEolN and jaEaAlapN and jiEaAlapN (K) and majoEalN, (S, TA,) He made a thing; syn. SanaEa; (Msb, K;) but having a more general signification than faEala and SanaEa and their equivalents [as will be shown by what follows]; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and so AjtEl↓: (K:) both these verbs signify the same. (S.) ― -b2- He made a thing of, or from, a thing; as in the saying [in the Kur xvi. 74 and xlii. 9], jaEala lakumo mino Oanofusikumo OazowaAjFA [He hath made for you, of, or from, yourselves, wives]; and [in the Kur xvi. 83] wajaEala lakumo mina AljibaAli OakonaAnFA [And He hath made for you, of the mountains, places of retreat; as caves, and excavated houses or chambers: so explained by Bd]. (TA.) ― -b3- He created; (K, TA;) brought into being, or existence; (TA;) as in the saying [in the Kur vi. 1], waJaEala AlZRulumaAti waAlnRuwri [And hath created, or brought into being, the darknesses and the light]; (K, TA;) and [in the Kur xxi. 31] wajaEalonaA mina AlmaMCi kulRa XaIoCK HaIRK [And We have created of water, or the seminal fluid, everything living]; and [in the Kur xvi. 80, &c.,] wajaEala lakumu AlsRamoEa wa AlOaboSaAra waAlOafoYidapa [And He created for you the ears and the eyes and the hearts]. (TA.) ― -b4- He made, or prepared; as in the saying [in the Kur lxv. 2], yajoEalu lahu maxorajFA [He will make, or prepare, for him a way of escape, or safety]; and [in the Kur lxv. 4] yajoEalu lahu mino Oamorihi yusorFA [He will make, or prepare, for him an easy state of his circumstances; i. e., will make his circumstances, or case, easy to him]. (TA.) ― -b5- He made; meaning he made to be, or become; he constituted; he appointed; [in which sense it is doubly trans.;] (S, K;) as in the saying in the Kur [xix. 31], wajaEaloniI nabiyRFA [And He hath made me a prophet]; (S;) [and in the elliptical phrase, jaEalahu Ealayohi He made him to be superintendant, or the like, over it; set him, or appointed him, over it:] and in the phrase, jaEala AlqabiyHa HasanFA [He made that which was bad to be, or become, good]. (K.) ― -b6- He made a thing to be in a particular state or condition; as in the saying [in the Kur ii. 20], AlRaci jaEala lakumu AlOaroDa firaAXFA [Who hath made for you the earth to be as a bed]; and [in the Kur lxxi. 15] wajaEala Alqamara fiyhinRa nuwrFA [And hath made the moon, in them (the heavens), to be as a light]; and so, as some say, in the saying [in the Kur xliii. 2], UinRaA jaEalonaAhu quroMnFA EarabiyRFA [Verily we have made it an Arabic Kur-án]. (TA.) ― -b7- [He made a thing to be in an altered, or changed, state or condition; i. e.,] the verb signifies also the changing a thing from its state or condition; as in the saying [in the Kur xi. 84 and xv. 74], jaEalonaA EaAliyahaA saAfilahaA [We made their upper part to be their lower part]; (K;) and in the words of the Kur [lvi. 81], watajoEaluwna rizoqakumo OanRakumo tukacRibuwna [And do ye make the thanks that ye should render for your sustenance to be that ye charge with falsehood the Giver thereof by attributing it to the stars called OanowaMC as expl. by Bd and Jel]. (TA.) ― -b8- He pronounced (Er-Rághib, K) a thing by a true judgment or decision, (Er-Rághib,) or as a legal ordinance; (K;) as in the saying (of the Legislator, TA), jaEala QllRehu AlSRalawaAti AlmaforuwDaAti xamosFA [God hath pronounced the prayers that are made obligatory to be five] (K.) And He pronounce (Er-Rághib, K *) a thing by a false judgment or decision, (Er-Rághib,) or according to his own judgment, heretically; (K;) as in the saying [in the Kur xv. 91], AlRaciyna jaEaluwA AlquroMna EiDiyna [Who pronounced the Kur-án to be lies, or enchantment, &c.]. (Er-Rághib, K.) ― -b9- He called, or named, (S, Msb, K,) a thing; (Msb;) as in the saying [in the Kur xliii. 18], wajaEaluwA AlmalaAYikapa AlRaciyna humo EibaAdu AlrRaHomeni UinaAvFA [And they have called the angels, who are the servants of the Compassionate, females]: (S, K:) or, as some say, the meaning is, have described them as, and pronounced them to be, females; like as one says, jaEala fulaAnN zayodFA OaEolama AlnRaAsi [Such a one described Zeyd as, and pronounced him to be, the most learned of men]: or have held, or believed, them to be females; like as the verb signifies in the saying in the Kur [xvi. 59], wayajoEaluwna lilRehi AlbanaAti [And they hold, or believe, God to have daughters: or this may be rendered and they attribute to God daughters]. (TA.) You say also, jaEalotu zayodFA OaxaAka, meaning I asserted Zeyd to be related to thee [as a brother; or I called Zeyd thy brother]. (K.) ― -b10- He thought; as in the saying, jaEala AlbaSorapa bagodaAda [He thought El-Basrah to be Baghdád]; (K;) and so in the saying, jaEalotuhu EabodFA faXatamotuhu [I thought him to be a slave, and consequently I reviled him]. (Ham p. 31.) ― -b11- He made known, or plain, or perspicuous; as in the saying [in the Kur xliii. 2, of which one explanation has been given above], UinRaA jaEalonaAhu quroMnFA EarabiyRFA [Verily we have made it known, &c., as an Arabic Kur-án]: (K:) or the meaning is, we have revealed it [as such]. (TA.) ― -b12- He exalted, or ennobled; as in the saying [in the Kur ii. 137], jaEalonaAkumo OumRapF wasaTFA [We have exalted you, or ennobled you, as a nation conforming to the just mean; or just, or equitable, or good]: (K:) [or it may be rendered, we have made you a nation &c.:] or, as some say, the meaning is, we have called you, or named you, a nation &c. (TA.) ― -b13- Also, inf. n. jaEolN, He put, or laid, a thing; or put it, or laid it, down. (K.) And jaEala baEoDahu fuwoqa baEoDK He put, or threw, one part of it upon another. (K.) ― -b14- He inserted a thing into a thing; as in the Kur [ii. 18], yajoEaluwna OaSaAbiEahumo fiI McaAnihimo [They insert, or put, their fingers into their ears]. (TA.) ― -b15- He put into the heart, or mind; as in the Kur [lvii. 27], wajalonaA fiI quluwbi QlRaciyna QtRabaEuwhu raOofapF waraHomapF [And we put into the hearts of those who followed him pity and com-
passion]. (TA.) ― -b16- [He appointed, or assigned, or stipulated to give, or gave, wages, pay, or a stipend, &c.]. You say, jaEalotu lahu juEolFA [I appointed him, &c., wages, pay, or a stipend]. (Msb.) And jaEala lahu kacaA EalaI kacaA He stipulated with him to give him such a thing for [doing] such a thing. (K.) And jaEala [alone] He gave wages, pay, or a stipend, to another to serve for him in war, i. e., in his stead. (Mgh.) And lahu OajoEalotu↓ I gave to him wages, pay, or a stipend. (S, * Mgh.) And juEolFA OajoEalahu↓ and lahu OajoEalahu↓, He gave to him wages, pay, or a stipend. (K, TA.) And it is said in a trad., jaEala liqawomihi miAYapF mina AlUibili EalaI Oano yusalRimuwA [He gave, or stipulated to give, to his people, or party, a hundred camels on the condition that they should surrender]. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- jaEala yafoEalu kacaA He set about, began, commenced, took to, or betook himself to, doing such a thing; (K, * TA;) he became occupied in doing such a thing. (TA.) ― -b2- jaEala is also, sometimes, an intrans. verb included among the verbs of appropinquation (OafoEaAlu AlmuqaArabapi); as in the saying,
waqado jaEalotu UicaA maA qumotu yuvoqiluniI
vawobiI faOanohaDu nahoDa AlXRaAribi AlvRRamili
[And I was beginning to be, or at the point of being, in such a state that, when I rose, my garment heavily burdened me, so that I stood up as stands up the intoxicated drinker]. (K.) ＝ -A3- jaEila, (S, K,) aor.
jaEala
, (K,) inf. n. jaEalN; (S;) and AjEl↓; (K;) It (water) had in it many jiEolaAn, pl. of juEalN: (S, K:) or had in it dead jiEolaAn. (K.) ― -b2- And jaEila, (TK,) inf. n. jaEalN, (IAar, K, TK,) He (a boy, TK) was, or became, short and fat. (IAar, K. [In the explanation of AljaEalu in the CK, AlqaSiyru is erroneously put for AlqiSaru.]) ― -b3- And He (a man, TK) persisted; or persisted obstinately; or persisted in contention, or litigation; or contended, or litigated; jaEalN being syn. with lajaAjN. (IAar, K.)

3 jAElhu jAEl jAElh jAElp
3. jAElhu, (A, K,) inf. n. mujaAEalapN and jiEaAlN, (TA,) He endeavoured to conciliate him by means of a bribe. (A, K. * [In the CK, raXRAhu is erroneously put for raAXaAhu.])

4 OajoEala
4: see jaEala, above, in three places: ＝ -A2- and see jaEila, above. ＝ -A3- AjEl Alqidora He put down the cooking-pot (S, K) from the fire (S) with the piece of rag called jiEaAl. (S, K,) ＝ -A4- OajoEalato and AstjElt↓ said of a bitch, (S, K,) and of other animals, (K,) of any beasts of prey, (S,) She desired, (S, K, Er-Rághib,) or loved, (K,) copulation: (S, K, Er-Rághib:) metonymically used in this sense. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

6 tjAElwA AlXRaIoCa c
6. tjAElwA AlXRaIoCa They stipulated among themselves to give the thing as wages, pay, or stipend: (K:) from juEolN. (TA.) You say also, tjAEl AlnRaAsu bayonahumo Einoda AlbaEovi [The people stipulated among themselves to give wages, or pay, to such of them as should serve as substitutes, on the occasion of being ordered forth to war]. (TA.)

8 AjtEl AjtEl
8. AjtEl: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- Also He took, or received, wages, pay, or a stipend. (Mgh, TA.)

10 UisotajoEala
10: see 4.

jaEolN jEl
jaEolN Short palm-trees: (S, K:) or shoots, or offsets, of palm-trees, cut off from the mothertrees, or plucked forth from the ground, and planted: or bad palm-trees: or palm-trees that rise beyond the reach of the hand: (K:) n. un. with p: (S: [in the K, not so correctly, pl. of jaEolapN:]) and palm-trees such as are called baEolN [q. v.]. (K.)

juEolN jEl
juEolN Wages; pay; a stipend; or a thing that is appointed, or stipulated, to be given to a man for work, or service; (S, Mgh, Msb, * K;) of more general import than OujorapN and vawaAbN; (TA;) as also jiEaAlapN↓ (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and (as some say, Msb) jaEaAlapN↓ (As, Mgh, Msb, K) and juEaAlapN↓ (Mgh, Msb, K) and jaEiylapN↓ (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jiEaAlN↓ (K) and jaEalN↓: (Har p. 134:) pl. juEulN (TA) and (of jEylp or jEAlp, Mgh) jaEaAYilu. (Mgh, TA.) Afterwards, (Mgh,) or jaEaAlapN↓ and jiEaAlapN↓ and juEaAlapN↓, (K, TA,) Wages, or pay, or the like, which one gives to a man who goes to war (Mgh, K, TA) as a substitute for the giver, (K, TA,) that he may aid himself thereby to serve in the war: (Mgh:) pl. of the last three words jaEaAYilu (TA.) And juEolN, (TA in art. rXw,) or jaEaAlapN↓, (K,) A bribe. (K, TA.) And jaEiylapN↓ Algaraqi What is given, or stipulated to be given, to him who dives for goods or for a man drowned. (TA.)

jiEolN jEl
jiEolN and jaEilN↓ and mujoEilN↓ Water having in it many jiEolaAn, pl. of juEalN: or having in it dead jiEolaAn. (K.) And OaroDN mujoEilapN↓ A land abounding with jiEolaAn. (K.)

jaEalN jEl
jaEalN: see juEolN.

jaEilN jEl
jaEilN: see jiEolN.

juEalN jEl
juEalN [The species of black beetle called cantharus;] a certain insect (duwayobRap); (S, K;) a certain black insect, found in moist places, (TA,) that rolls along a little ball [of dung] called duHoruwjap [in which it deposits its eggs]: (S and K in art. dHrj:) [see also xunofasaMCu: it is strangely explained in the Msb as the HirobaMC, which is the male of the OumRu Hubayon:] pl. jiEolaAnN. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Hence, as being likened thereto, (TA,) A black and ugly and small man: or one who is wont to persist, or to persist obstinately, or to persist in contention or litigation, or to contend or litigate: and (as some say, TA) i. q. raqiybN [a watcher, an observer, &c.]. (K, TA.)

jiEaAlN jEAl
jiEaAlN A piece of rag with which a cooking-pot is put down (S, K) from the fire; (S;) as also jiEaAlapN↓ and juEaAlapN↓: (K:) pl. juEulN (S, TA) and jaEaAYilu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also juEolN.

jaEowalN jEwl
jaEowalN The young of the ostrich. (IDrd, K.)

jaEaAlapN jEAl jEAlh jEAlp
jaEaAlapN: see juEolN, in three places.

juEaAlapN jEAl jEAlh jEAlp
juEaAlapN: see juEolN, for each in two places: ＝ -A2-

jiEaAlapN jEAl jEAlh jEAlp
jiEaAlapN: and jiEaAlN.

jaEiylapN jEylh jEylp
jaEiylapN: see juEolN, in two places.

jaAEilN jAEl
jaAEilN [act. part. n. of jaEala] Giving [wages, pay, or a stipend: &c.]. (K.)

mujoEilN mjEl
mujoEilN applied to a bitch, (S, K,) and to any animal (S, K) or beast of prey, (S,) Desiring, (S,) or loving, (K,) copulation. (S, K. [See 4]) ＝ -A2- Also, fem. with p: see jiEolN, in two places.

mujotaEilN mjtEl
mujotaEilN Taking, or receiving, [wages, pay, or a stipend.] (K.)

dictScrap.label: Q. accord. to the K, but Q. Q. accord. to Sgh, jaEomasa: see art. jEs.

superEntry.entry:
juEomuwsN jEmws
juEomuwsN: see art. jEs.

juEaAmisN jEAms
juEaAmisN: see art. jEs.

mujaEomisN mjEms
mujaEomisN: see art. jEs.

1 jafRa jf
1. jafRa, (S, Mgh, Msb,) sec. pers. jafafota, (K,) aor. yajifRu (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and yajafRu, (S, K,) the latter aor. mentioned by AZ, but rejected by Ks; (S;) and sec. pers. jaffota, aor. yajafRu, (Sgh, Msb, K,) of the dial. of Benoo-Asad; (Msb;) inf. n. jafaAfN and jufuwfN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) which are assigned by J and Sgh to jafRa aor. yajifRN; (TA;) It (a thing, Mgh, or a garment, S, Msb, K, and also said of other things, S) was, or became, dry; it dried, or dried up. (Mgh, Msb.) Hence the saying, mani QHotalama vumRa OaSobaHa EalaI jafaAfK He who experiences an emission of semen in sleep, then rises in the morning with what is on his garment, of the semen, dry. (Mgh.) And jafRa AlnRahoru, an elliptical phrase, for jafRa maMCu AlnRahori [The water of the river dried up]. (Msb.) And fulaAnN laA yajifRu liboduhu Such a one does not remit, or become remiss, in his work, or labour: (TA:) or does not cease to go to and fro. (Har p. 589.) ― -b2- jafRa, inf. n. jufuwfN, said of a man, He was, or became, silent; he did not speak. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- jafafotu AlXRaIoCa UilaIRa, aor. OajufRu, inf. n. jafRN, I collected the thing to me. (Nawádir of AZ, TA.) ― -b2- jafRuwA OamowaAlahumo They collected together their camels, and took them away. (Sgh, * K, * TA.)

2 jfRfhu jffh jffp
2. jfRfhu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. tajofiyfN (S, Msb, K) and tajofaAfN, (K,) He dried it. (Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- jfRf Alfarasa, (K,) inf. n. tajofiyfN, (S,) He clad, or attired, the horse with a tijofaAf. (S, K.)

5 tajafRaRa
5: see R. Q. 2.

8 Uijotafafa
8: AjtfR maA fiI AlUinaMCi He consumed what was in the vessel; (K;) i. e., drank up all of it; as also AXtfR. (TA.)

R. Q. 2 tajafojafa tjfjf
R. Q. 2. tajafojafa It (a garment, or piece of cloth), having been moist, dried so far as to retain
some moisture: (S, K:) if it has dried entirely, you say of it, qado qafRa: (S:) the verb is originally tjfRf↓; the medial f being changed into j: it is like tabaXobaXa, originally tbXRX. (Lth, S.)

jafRN jf
jafRN: see jafRapN.

jufRN jf
jufRN The spathe of the palm-tree; the envelope of the TaloE; (AA, A'Obeyd, S, K;) as also jubRN; (AA, TA;) or [in other words] the qiyqaMC of the TlE; (K;) i. e., the envelope that is with the waliyE: (Lth, K:) or, as some say, the envelope of the TlE when it has become dry: (TA:) pl. jufuwfN. (A' Obeyd, TA.) [See jubRN.] ― -b2- A receptacle such as is termed wiEaMC that is not to be tied round at its mouth.
