(K, TA.) ― -b3- An old, worn-out water-skin or milk-skin, of which half is cut off and made into a bucket: (S, K:) and sometimes it is made of the lower part of a palm-tree hollowed out: (Lth, S, K: *) or a thing that is hollowed out in (fiI [probably a mistranscription for min, i. e. of]) the trunks of palm-trees: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or a worn-out milk-skin or butter-skin: (IAar, TA:) or a water-skin, or milk-skin, of which part is cut off at the fore legs, and in which the beverage called nabiyc is prepared: (Kt, TA:) or the lower half of a water-skin or milk-skin, made into a bucket: (IDrd, TA:) or a thing of camel's skin, like a vessel, or like a bucket, in which the rainwater is taken, holding half the quantity of a water-skin or the like. (TA.) ― -b4- An old man; (K;) as being likened to an old, worn-out water-skin or milk-skin: mentioned in the L from ElHejeree, and by Sgh from Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.) ― -b5- Anything hollow, such as has something within it, like the nut, and the magodap [or fruit of the tanoDub, &c.: in the CK, the maEidap]. (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA.) ― -b6- The body, or substance, (XaxoS,) of a thing. (TA.) ― -b7- An obstruction that one sees between him and the kibleh. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ＝ -A2- huwa jufRu maAlK He is a good manager of cattle, (K,) acquainted with the art of pasturing them, and of collecting them at their proper time in the place of pasture. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also what next follows.

jafRapN jf jfh jfp
jafRapN (S, K) and jufRapN↓, (Sgh, K,) but the latter is rare, (Sgh,) and jufRN↓ (S, K) and jafRN↓, (K,) A company of men or people; a collective body thereof: (Ks, S, K:) or a great number (K) thereof. (TA.) You say, duEiytu fiI jafRapi AlnRaAsi [I was summoned, or invited, among the collective body of people]. (S.) And jaAWuwA jafRpF waAHidapF (S, K) They came in one collective body. (K.) laA nafala fiI ganiymapK HatRaI tuqosama jafRapF, (S, Mgh,) or jufRapF↓, (K,) means [There shall be no gift of spoil] until it is divided altogether: (S, Mgh, K:) a saying of Ibn-'Abbás: (S, Mgh:) accord. to one reading, EalaI jufRatihi↓, i. e., [until it is divided] among the collective body of the army first. (K. [Golius (here copied by Freytag) appears to have read, laA taqulo fiI ganamK; and hence to have said, of jafRapN, erroneously, " de pecore non dicitur nisi totus grex sit."])

jufRapN jf jfh jfp
jufRapN: see what next precedes, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also A great dalow [or bucket]. (K.)

jufaAfN jfAf
jufaAfN What is dry of a thing that one has dried. (K.) You say, AiEozilo jufaAfahu mino raTobihi [Put thou apart what is dry thereof from what is fresh and moist thereof]. (TA.)

jafiyfN jfyf
jafiyfN Dry herbs or herbage: (S, K:) or dry leguminous plants or herbs, of the kind that are eaten without being cooked: (TA:) or of this kind and of such as are thick and inclining to bitterness; as also qafiyfN: (TA in art. qf:) or, as some say, mA Dmnt mn AlryH. (TA in the present art. [But what this means I know not; the verb being evidently mistranscribed.])

jufaAfapN jfAf jfAfh jfAfp
jufaAfapN What has become scattered, or strewed, of dry herbage (HaXiyX) and of [the kind of trefoil called] qatR, (S, K, TA,) and the like. (TA.)

tijofaAfN tjfAf
tijofaAfN A thing, (S, Mgh, Msb,) i. e. a kind of armour, (IAth, K,) [a cataphract,] with which a horse is clad, (S, IAth, Mgh, Msb, K,) in war, in the manner of a coat of mail, (Mgh, Msb,) to defend him from being wounded; (IAth;) and sometimes worn by a man, to defend him in war: (K:) of the measure tifoEaAlN, (Mgh, Msb,) the t being augmentative, (Aboo-'Alee the Grammarian, S, IJ,) to render the word quasi-coordinate to the class of qiroTaAsN; (IJ;) from jafRa, because of its hardness and toughness: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. tajaAfiyfu (S, Mgh, Msb.) It is said in a trad., OaEidRa lilofaqori tijofaAfFA; and one says, Ailobaso lilofaqori tijofaAfFA; [both] meaning, Make thou preparation for poverty. (TA.)

mutajafRifN mtjff
mutajafRifN Having a tijofaAf upon his horse. (Mgh.)

jafaOa c
jafaOa, (S, K,) aor.
jafaAa
, (K,) inf. n. jafoCN, (S,) It (a valley [flowing with water]) cast forth froth, or foam, (S, K,) and particles of rubbish or refuse; (S;) as also AjfO↓; (K;) but this latter is said in the O to be of weak authority. (TA.) And jafaOati Alqidoru, and AjfOt↓, The cooking-pot cast forth its froth, or foam, (S, K,) in boiling: (S:) or jfOt bizabadihaA it cast forth its froth, or foam: (Ham p. 132:) originally jafat and Ajft, without C. (Er-Rághib, TA in art. jfw.) ＝ -A2- jafaOa AlwaAdiI, (K,) or jafaOa AlguvaMCa Eani AlwaAdiI, (IAar, O,) He (a man, IAar, O) swept off the scum and rubbish of the valley [after it had flowed, or while it was flowing, with water]. (IAar, O, K.) And jafaOa Alqidora He cleared off the froth, or foam, of the cooking-pot. (K, TA.) ― -b2- Also jafaOa Alqidora, (S, Z in the Fáïk, TA,) inf. n. as above; (S, TA;) and OajofaOahaAs↓; (Z ubi suprà, TA;) but the former is that which is commonly known; (ISd, TA;) the latter is rare; (IAth, TA:) or the latter should not be said, though it occurs in a trad., (S, TA, *) accord. to one relation; (TA;) He turned the cooking-pot upsidedown, or inclined it, (S, Z ubi suprà, TA,) and poured out what was in it: (S:) or he emptied the cooking-pot, and turned it upside-down: (TA:) and jafaOa Alburomapa fiI AlqaSoEapi He turned the cookingpot upside-down upon the bowl. (K.) ― -b3- jafaOahu, (S, K,) [like HafaOahu,] and jafaOa bihi AlOaroDa, (TA,) He threw him down, or prostrated him, on the ground: (S, K, TA;) namely, a man: (S:) and bihi AjfO↓ [signifies the same; or] he threw him, or it, (K, TA,) on the ground. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 8.

4 OajofaAa
4: see 1, in four places.

8 AjtfO c
8. AjtfO He pulled, or plucked, up, or out, or he uprooted, (S, K,) and threw down, or away, a thing, (S,) or plants, or herbs, such as are termed baqol, (K,) and trees; (TA;) [but see AHtfI;] as also jafaOa↓, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above: (TA:) [or] both signify he cut a plant, or herb. (IAar, Nh.)

jufaMCN jfMC
jufaMCN What is cast forth [of froth, or foam, and particles of rubbish or refuse, (see 1,)] by a torrent: (ISk, S:) the froth, or foam, cast forth by a valley [flowing with water]; and by a cooking-pot, (K, TA,) in boiling. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, as being likened to the froth, or foam, of the cooking-pot, of which no use is made, (Fr, TA,) i. q. baATilN [meaning A thing that is worthless, useless, or unprofitable]. (Fr, K, TA.) It is said in the Kur [xiii. 18], faOamRaA AlzRabadu fayacohabu jufaMCF, meaning baATilFA [i. e. Now as to the froth, or scum, it passeth away as a thing that is worthless, or useless, or unprofitable], (Fr, S, Jel, TA,) and thrown away. (Jel.) You say also, cahaba AlzRabadu jufaMCF, meaning [The froth, or scum, passed away] driven from its water. (TA.) ― -b3- jufaMCN mina AlnRaAsi, occurring in a trad., is explained by IAth as meaning The first, or foremost, of the men or people (saraEaAnuhumo): but Bkh and Muslim read (instead of jfAC) OaxifRaMCu, pl. of xafiyfN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, [like jufaAyapN,] An empty ship. (O, K.)

1 jafara jfr jfrp
1. jafara He, or it, became wide: (K:) or became inflated, or swollen. (A.) And jafara janobaAhu His (a kid's, S and Msb, or lamb's, Msb) sides became widened, or distended: (S, Msb:) and janobaAhu Ajfr↓ [and Anjfr↓ (K in art. hDm)] his (a horse's) sides became inflated, or swollen. (A.) ― -b2- He (a lamb, K, and a kid, TA) became what is termed jaforN; as also tjfRr↓ and Astjfr↓: (K:) and tjfRrt↓ and Astjfrt↓ she (a kid) became a jaforap. (ISh, TA.) And He (a boy) became what is termed jaforN; as also tjfRr↓ (TA) and Astjfr↓: (A:) and this last verb, he became large in the sides. (L.) ＝ -A2- jafara (S, A) Eani AlDRiraAbi, (S,) or Eani AlUibili, (A,) aor.
jafura
, (S,) inf. n. jufuwrN; (S, K;) and Ajtfr↓; and Ajfr↓, inf. n. UijofaArN; and jfRr↓, inf. n. tajofiyrN; (K;) He (a stallioncamel) ceased, (S, K,) or abstained, (A,) from covering, (S, A, K,) and avoided it; having indulged in it so much that he was wearied; (S;) and his seminal fluid became little: (TA:) you say of a ram, rabaDa, (S, A,) not jafara. (S.) And
jafara Eani AlmaroOapi, (IAar, TA,) and EanohaA Ajfr↓, (IAar, K,) and Ajtfr↓, and jfRr↓, (IAar, TA,) He (a man) abstained from the woman; (K;) he abstained from sexual intercourse with her. (IAar, TA.) ― -b2- jafara mina AlmaraDi He recovered from the disease. (K, TA.)

2 jafRara
2: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- jfRrhu AlOamoru Eanohu The thing, or affair, cut him off from him, or it. (IAar, L.)

4 Oajofara
4: see 1, in three places. ＝ -A2- Ajfr also signifies He cut, abandoned, or forsook, (S, K,) another, (S,) or his companion, or friend, (K,) and left off visiting him. (S, K.) And Oajofarotu maA kunotu fiyhi I left, or relinquished, that in which I was occupied. (S.) ＝ -A3- Also It (a thing, TA) was, or became, absent, or hidden, or concealed, (K, TA,) from one. (TA.)

5 tajafRara
5: see 1, in three places.

7 Uinojafara
7: see 1.

8 Uijotafara
8: see 1, in two places.

10 Uisotajofara
10: see 1, in three places.

jaforN jfr jfrp
jaforN A lamb, or kid, whose sides have become widened, or distended: (Msb:) or a lamb, (IAmb, Msb, K,) and a kid, (K, * TA,) that has become large, and begun to pasture, (K, TA,) and whose sides have become widened, or distended: (TA:) or a lamb, (K,) or a kid, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, * TA,) that is four months old, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and whose sides have become widened, and that is weaned, (A'Obeyd, S,) and has taken to pasture: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or this is sometimes four months, and sometimes five months, after the birth: or a young lamb, and a kid, after it has been weaned, when six months old: (IAar, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OajofaArN (K) and [of mult.] jifaArN (Msb, K) and jafarapN: (K) fem. with p: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) or jaforapN signifies a female kid that has become satiated with leguminous herbs and with shrubs, and is independent of its mother: (ISh, TA:) IAmb applies it to a female lamb and a female kid; and this is correct, though some say that it is applied to the latter only. (TA.) ― -b2- A boy when his belly has become widened, (A,) or when his flesh has become swollen out, (K,) and he has begun to eat: (A, K:) fem. with p (K.) [See XaAdixN; and see also muTabRixN.] ＝ -A2- A well, (Msb, K,) or a wide well, (S, A,) not cased, or walled round, within; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also jaforapN↓: (R, TA:) or, of which a portion is cased, or walled round, within, (K, TA,) and a portion is not: (TA:) the former of the masc. gender: pl. jifaArN. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] fulaAnN munohadimu Aljafori (A, K *) [Such a one's well is in a state of demolition; meaning,] such a one has no judgment: (A:) or has no intelligence. (K.) And UinRa jaforaka EalaIRa lahaArK [Verily thy well is falling in upon me; meaning] thy mischief is coming quickly upon me. (A, TA.) ― -b3- [The pl.] jafaArN also signifies [simply] Wells. (K.) ― -b4- And hence, (TA,) She-camels abounding with milk. (K, TA.)

jaforapN jfr jfrh jfrp
jaforapN: see jaforN.

juforapN jfr jfrh jfrp
juforapN A round space in the ground: (S, K:) or a round and wide cavity in the ground: (L:) pl. jifaArN. (S.) ― -b2- Hence, (S,) The belly, or interior of the body: (S:) or the cavity of the chest: or what comprises the belly [in the TA the chest] and the two sides: (K:) or the place where the ribs curve; and so in a horse &c.: (TA:) the middle of a horse, (S, Msb, K,) and of a camel: and, as some say, the middle, and main part, of anything: and thus, the main part of the sea: (TA:) pl. jufarN and jifaArN, accord. to the K; but the latter is pl. of juforapN in the sense of "a round cavity." (TA.) ― -b3- Also [the pl.] jufarN signifies The holes that are dug in the ground for props. (TA.)

jafiyrN jfyr
jafiyrN A kind of quiver like the kinaAnap, but wider, (Lth, S, TA,) in which are put many arrows: (Lth, TA:) or a [quiver of the kind called] jaEobap [q. v.], of skins, in which is no wood: or of wood, in which are no skins; (K;) or in which is no skin; as in some good lexicons: (TA:) or of skins, and slit in its side, that the wind may enter it, and the feathers in consequence may not be eaten: (TA: [see also jaXiyrN:]) or the same as the jEbp and the knAnp: (El-Ahmar, TA:) or a quiver for nabol, wide, of wood. (Ham p. 358.) Hence, layosa fiI jafiyrihi gayoru zanodayoni [There is not in his quiver aught save two pieces of wood for producing fire]: a prov. applied to him in whom is no good. (Meyd.)

majofarN mjfr
majofarN: see majofarapN.

mujofarN mjfr
mujofarN, applied to a horse, (S, Msb, K,) and with p applied to a she-camel, (S,) Large in the middle: (S, Msb, K:) and mujofaru Aljanobayoni a horse inflated, or swollen, in the sides. (A.)

majofarapN mjfrh mjfrp
majofarapN (S, A, K) and majofarN↓ (Lh, K) An impediment to venery; (Lh, A'Obeyd, S, A, K;) and a cause of diminishing the seminal fluid: (A'Obeyd, TA:) applied to food: (Lh, K:) and such is fasting said to be; (A'Obeyd, S, K;) and the sun, (A, * TA,) i. e., sitting in the sun; and such, also, the sleeping between daybreak and sunrise, or in the first part of the day. (TA.)

1 jafala jfl
1. jafala, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jafila
and
jafula
, inf. n. jafolN (Msb) and jufuwlN, (Msb, K,) He (a camel) took fright, or shied, and fled, or ran away at random; or became refractory, and went away at random; or ran away, or broke loose, and went hither and thither by reason of his sprightliness: and Ajfl↓ he (a bird) took fright, and flew away; or became scared away: (Msb:) or the former, he (an ostrich, K) hastened, or sped, (S, K,) in his pace, (TA,) and went away in the land, or country; as also Ajfl↓; (IDrd, K;) both, said of an ostrich, mean he spread his wings, running; (Ham p. 555;) or spread his wings, and ran quickly, or went away at random and swiftly: (TA:) or jafalati AlnRaEaAmapu means the ostrich fled: (Msb:) and Eanohu Ajfl↓, said of anything, he fled from it: (TA, Ham p. 555:) and jafaluwA, aor.
jafula
, inf. n. jafolN; (Msb;) and AjflwA↓ (S, Msb) and AnjflwA↓ and tjfRlwA↓; (Msb;) they (a company of men) fled quickly; (S, Msb;) or the second (K) and third (S, K) signify they became displaced, (S, K, TA,) and quickly defeated, (TA,) and went away; (S, K, TA;) or these two and the fourth, (TA,) or all the four, (Har p. 373,) they hastened in defeat and flight: (TA, and Har ubi suprà:) and jafalati AlrRiyHu, (K,) and Ajflt↓, (S, K,) the wind was swift (S, K, TA) in blowing. (TA.) ― -b2- jafala, inf. n. jufuwlN, (tropical:) It (hair) became shaggy, or dishevelled, and frouzy, or altered in smell, in consequence of its being seldom dressed; or dusty and matted, by reason of its being seldom anointed; (K, TA;) and became raised and spread. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jafala is also trans., signifying He made a bird to take fright, and fly away; or he scared it away: its quasi-pass. is Ajfl↓ [explained above]; the reverse of the rule commonly obtaining: (Msb:) or the former verb, as in the O; not the latter, as in the K; he made a male ostrich to hasten, or speed, in his pace, and to go away in the land, or country; or made him to spread his wings, and run quickly, or go away at random and swiftly: (TA:) and jfRl↓ he, or it, made an animal, or animals, to take fright, and flee, or run away at random; or scared away it, or them: (TA:) [and, app., he frightened; tajofiylN being also said in the TA to be syn. with taforiyEN, which, I think, is evidently a mistranscription for tafoziyEN.] You say, AlqanRaASu AlwaHoXa jfRl↓ [The sportsman scared away the wild animals]. (TA.) And Eano maraAkizihimo Oatawohumo fajafRaluwhumo↓ [They came to them, and scared them, or frightened them, or made them to flee, away from their stations]. (TA.) And jafalati AlrRiyHu AlZRaliyma The wind put in motion the male ostrich, and drove him away, or along: (K:) and [in like manner] AlsRafiynapa [(assumed tropical:) the ship]. (TA.) And jafalati AlrRiyHu AlsRaHaAba (tropical:) The wind smote the clouds, and put them into a state of commotion, (K, TA,) and made them to speed along. (TA.) And AlrRiyHu tajofilu AljahaAma (assumed tropical:) The wind carries away the rainless clouds. (Mgh. [See also 4.]) Whence, app., (Mgh,) jafala AlbaHoru samakFA (assumed tropical:) The sea cast fish upon the shore; (Lth, Mgh, K;) a verb like Daraba; occurring in a trad., in which it is erroneously said to be Oajofala. (Mgh.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) aor.
jafila
, inf. n. jafolN, (TA,) He prostrated a man; threw him down upon the ground. (K.) You say, TaEanahu fajafalahu, meaning He thrust him, or pierced him, [with a spear or the like,] and displaced and prostrated him. (Mgh.) ― -b3- He threw goods one upon another. (IDrd, Msb, TA.) ― -b4- He, or it, overturned, or turned upside-down. (TA.) ― -b5- Also, aor.
jafila
, (K,) inf. n. jafolN, (TA,) He peeled, pared, stripped, or scraped off, a thing; (AZ, K, TA;) as, for instance, flesh from the bone, and fat from the skin; (AZ, TA;) and so jfRl↓, (K,) inf. n. tajofiylN: (TA:) he removed flesh from the bone: (K:) app. formed by transposition from jalafa. (TA.) ― -b6- Also, (Msb, K,) aor.
jafula
, (Msb,) or
jafila
, (K,) He swept away mud (Msb, K, TA) from the ground; (TA;) and so jfRl↓. (K.) [It seems that Golius found, in a copy of the K, AltRibona erroneously put for AlTRiyna;
and Haraqahu for jarafahu; for he has explained the former verb as meaning “ combussit stramen. ”]

2 jafRala
2: see 1, in five places.

4 Oajofala
4: see 1, in six places. ― -b2- You say also, Oajofalati AlrRiyHu biAltRuraAbi (assumed tropical:) The wind carried away the dust; made it to fly away. (S.) And Ajfl Algayomu The clouds, or mist, became removed, or cleared off. (TA.)

5 tajafRala
5: see 1. ― -b2- You say of a cock, tjfRl, meaning nafaXa buraAYilahu [i. e., (assumed tropical:) He ruffled the feathers around his neck]. (Ibn-' Abbád, K, TA.)

7 Uinojafala
7: see 1. ― -b2- Anjfl also signifies (tropical:) It went away, or departed; said of the shade, (K, TA,) and of the night. (TA.) ― -b3- He, or it, became overturned, or turned upside-down. (TA.) ― -b4- Anjflti AlXRajarapu The tree, blown upon by a violent wind, became uprooted. (TA.)

jafolN jfl
jafolN: see AjofiylN. It is an inf. n. used as an epithet; and means A people, or party, fleeing quickly; as also jafaAlapN↓. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also A cloud that has poured forth its mater and gone away (S, K) quickly; (S;) because it is then lighter and quicker. (Har p. 373.) ― -b3- A ship; (K;) because the wind drives it along (tajofiluhaA): (TA:) pl. jufuwlN. (K.) ＝ -A2- Ants: black ants: (K:) large black ants: (TA:) a dial. var. of javolN. (K.)

waqaEato fiI AlnRaAsi jafolapN wqEt fy AlnAs jflh wqEt fy AlnAs jflp
waqaEato fiI AlnRaAsi jafolapN [Fear fell upon the people;] the people feared. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jafolapN XajarapN A leafy tree; a tree having many leaves. (K.) ＝ -A3- See also what next follows.

jufolapN jfl jflh jflp
jufolapN (S, K) and jafolapN↓ (TA [there said in one place to be bAlftH, but this is most probably a mistranscription for bAlDmR,]) A fleece of wool: (S, K) [a word used in the sense of] a pass. part. n., like gurofap in the phrase Aigotarafa gurofapF. (S.)

daEawotuhumu AljafalaI dEwthm AljflI dEwthm Aljfly
daEawotuhumu AljafalaI, (AZ, S, Msb, * K, *) and AlOajofalaI↓, (AZ, S, K, *) which latter was unknown to As, (S,) I invited them to my feast, or food, (AZ, S, Msb, K, *) in common, (AZ, S, Msb,) without distinction, (Msb,) or with their company and commonalty. (K.) And duEiIa fulaAnN fiI AlnRaqaraI laA fiI AljafalaI, (Akh, S, Msb, *) and AlOajofalaI↓, Such a one was invited among the distinguished persons, not among the commonalty. (Akh, S.) And daEowapN jafalaI A general invitation; contr. of daEowapN naqaraI. (Msb.) And jaMCa Alqawomu, OajofalapF↓, and OazofalapF, (Fr, S, K, *) The people came in a company; (Fr, S;) and biOajofalatihimo↓, and Oazofalatihimo, with their company. (Fr, S, K.) Accord. to some, (S,) OajofalaI↓ signifies A collection, or an assemblage, of any things; (S, K;) as also OazofalaI: (S:) and jufRaAlapN↓, (S, Sgh, TA,) or jufaAlapN↓, (K,) a company, or an assembly, (S, Sgh, K,) of men, (S, TA,) going along quickly. (TA.)

jafolaAnu jflAn
jafolaAnu, or jafolaAnN, [whether with or without tenween is not shown,] Fearful; wont, or apt, to take fright and flee, or run away at random. (TA.) [See also jafRaAlN.]

jafaAlN jfAl
jafaAlN: see what next follows.

jufaAlN jfAl
jufaAlN What is cast forth by a torrent, (S, K, TA,) of rubbish and scum, or of rotten leaves mixed with scum; (TA;) as also jafaAlN↓, like saHaAbN; (TA;) and jufaAlapN↓. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- The froth of milk. (K.) ＝ -A2- Much (K) of anything: (TA:) or of wool; as also jafiylN↓: (K:) or much wool. (S.) The ewe is represented as saying, OuwalRadu ruxaAlFA waOujazRu jufaAlFA waOuHolabu kuvabFA viqaAlFA walamo tara mivoliI maAlFA [I am delivered of lambs, and I am shorn of much wool, and I am milked of heavy bowlfuls, and thou hast not seen cattle the like of me]: by OujazRu jufaAlFA is meant I am shorn [of much wool] at once; for nought of her wool falls to the ground until all of it is shorn. (S.) jfAl is applied, by Dhu-r-Rummeh, as an epithet to hair; [meaning Much, or abundant;] and it is not applied as an epithet to anything save what is much, or abundant. (S.) Ed-Dejjál [or Antichrist] is described, in a trad., as jufaAlu AlXRaEari Having much hair: (TA:) and AlrRaOosi jaAfilu↓ [also] has this meaning. (Ham p. 469.)

jafuwlN jfwl
jafuwlN A wind (riyH) that smites the clouds, and puts them into a state of commotion; (K;) or that makes them to speed along: (TA:) a swift wind; (TA;) as also jaAfilapN↓ and mujofilN↓: (S, K:) pl. of the first, (i. e., of jfwl,) jufolN. (K.) ― -b2- Great, or large: so in the phrase jumRapN jafuwlN [A great, or large, quantity of hair extending beyond the ears]. (K.) ― -b3- An aged woman; (K, * TA;) as also UijofiylN↓: (K:) pl. of the former as above. (K.)

jafiylN jfyl
jafiylN: see jufaAlN.

jafaAlapN jfAl jfAlh jfAlp
jafaAlapN: see jafolN.

jufaAlapN jfAl jfAlh jfAlp
jufaAlapN: see AljafalaI: ― -b2- and jufaAlN. ― -b3- Also AljufaAlapu, (K,) or jufaAlapu Alqidori, (S,) What one takes from the head [of the contents] of the cookingpot with the ladle. (S, K.)

jafRaAlN jfAl
jafRaAlN an intensive epithet from jafala in the first of the senses explained above; i.e., A camel that takes fright, or shies, and flees, &c., much, or often. (Msb.) [See also jafolaAnu.]

jufRaAlapN jfAl jfAlh jfAlp
jufRaAlapN: see AljafalaI.

jaAfilN jAfl
jaAfilN part. n. of jafala in the first of the senses explained above: (Msb:) [and in other senses.] ― -b2- Hastening, or speeding. (TA.) See jafuwlN. ― -b3- Disquieted, disturbed, agitated, or flurried. (S, K, TA.) ― -b4- See also jufaAlN.

jayofalN jyfl
jayofalN a name of [The month] cuw AlqaEodapi, (K, TA,) in the time of paganism. (TA.)

OajofalapN c
OajofalapN: see AljafalaI, in two places.

OajofalaI c
OajofalaI: see AljafalaI, in three places.

UijofiylN Ajfyl
UijofiylN Cowardly, or a coward, (S, K, TA,) that is frightened at everything. (TA.) A heostrich (S, K) that takes fright, (K,) and flees from everything (S, K, TA) that he sees; (TA;) as also jafolN↓. (K.) ― -b2- A bow of which the arrow goes far. (K.) ― -b3- See also jafuwlN.

mujofilN mjfl
mujofilN Turning away, or going back, or retreating; going away. (TA.) ― -b2- See also jafuwlN.

mijofalN mjfl
mijofalN applied to a camel's hump, Heavy: [properly, an instrument of overturning:] applied as an epithet to a camel's hump that is so heavy as to overturn the animal when, after rolling on the ground, he desires to rise. (TA.)

1 jafana naAqapF jfn nAqh jfn nAqp
1. jafana naAqapF, (K,) inf. n. jafonN, (TA,) He slaughtered a she-camel, and gave her flesh for food (K, TA) to the people, (TA,) in bowls (jifaAn). (K, TA.)

2 jfRnwA jfnwA
2. jfRnwA They made bowls (jifaAn [probably meaning they prepared bowls of food: accord. to Freytag's Lex., jfRn means “ apposuit scutellam; but he does not name his authority]). (TA.) ＝ -A2- jfRn and tjfRn↓ It (a grape-vine) attained to the state of having an OaSol [i. e., app., a stock]. (TA.)

5 tajafRana
5: see 2.

jafonN jfn
jafonN The eyelid; both the upper and the lower: (S, Msb, K:) of the mase. gender: (Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] OajofaAnN and OajofunN and [of mult.] jufuwnN. (K.) ― -b2- The upper surface, and the lower, of a cake of bread: both together being called jafonaA AlrRagiyfi. (Lh, TA.) ― -b3- The scabbard, or sheath, (gimod, S, K, or gilaAf, Msb,) of a sword: (S, Msb, K:) [or] the case, or receptacle, in which is [put] the sword together with its gmd and suspensory belt or cord: (S voce qiraAbN:) [but the former signification only is commonly known:] and [it is said that] jifonN↓ signifies the same; (K;) but this is doubted by IDrd: (M, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OajofaAnN and [of mult.] jufuwnN. (Msb.) ― -b4- The OaSol [app. here meaning stock] of a grape-vine: (K:) or a grape-vine itself, in the dial. of El-Yemen; (T, TA;) so called as being imagined to be the receptacle of the grapes: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or a species of grape: (ISd, K:) or the skin of the grape, in which is the juice: (IAar, TA:) or a climbing shoot of a grape-vine: (AHn, TA:) or the shoots of the grape-vine: (T, S, M, K:) n. un. with p: (T S, M:) or, accord. to IAar, jafonapN is syn. with krEp [app. a mistranscription for karomapN a single grape-vine]: or, accord. to some, as ISd says, the leaves of the grape-vine. (TA.) [Hence,] maMCu Aljafoni The juice of the vine; (A, TA;) wine: (TA:) [or it may originally mean tears; then, rain; and then, wine: for] wine is also called maMCu AlsRaHaAbi: and jafonu AlmaMCi means the clouds. (TA.) ― -b5- A kind of tree, of sweet odour. (AHn, K.) ― -b6- A certain plant, of the kind called OaHoraAr, that grows in a spreading manner, and, when it dries up, contracts; having grains like the Hulobap [or fenugreek]. (AHn, TA.)

jifonN jfn
jifonN: see jafonN.

jafonapN jfn jfnh jfnp
jafonapN A [bowl of the kind called] qaSoEap: (K:) or like a qSEp: (S:) the largest kind of qSEp; (Ks, S in art. SHf, M;) next to which is the
qSEp [properly so called], which satisfies the hunger of ten [men]; then, the SaHofap, which satisfies five; then, the miYokalap, which satisfies two men, and three; then, the SuHayofap, which satisfies one man: (Ks, S in art. SHf:) it is peculiarly applied to a receptacle for kinds of food: (Er-Rághib, TA:) pl. [of mult.] jafaAnN (S, Msb, K) and jifanN (Sb, TA) and (of pauc., TA) jafanaAtN (S, Msb, K.) [Hence,] kufiYato jafonatuhu [His bowl was turned upside-down; meaning] (tropical:) he was slain; a phrase similar to huriyqa rifoduhu. (A in art. rfd.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A small well; (K;) as being likened to the jfnp for food. (Er- Rághib, TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A generous man: (K:) jafonapN garRaMCu is an appellation applied to a generous man who entertains many guests and feeds many: (IAar, TA:) he is called jfnp because people are fed in the jfnp, and the epithet grRMC is added because of the whiteness of the camel's hump in the jfnp. (TA.) ― -b4- Also i. q. xamorapN [meaning Some wine, or a kind of wine: see also maMCu Aljafoni, voce jafonN]. (IAar, TA.)

1 jafaA jf jfA
1. jafaA, (K,) aor.
jafuwa
, (TA,) inf. n. jafaMCN; and tjAfI↓; It did not keep, or cleave, to its place. (K.) You say, jafaA janobuhu Eani AlfiraAXi, (Mgh,) and Eanohu tjAfI↓, (S, Mgh,) His side did not rest, or was restless, or uneasy, upon the bed; or shrank from it; (S, Mgh;) and heaved, or rose, from it: (Mgh:) or the former, his side did not keep, or cleave, to its place upon the bed: and the latter, it became withdrawn, or removed, from it. (TA.) And jafaA AlsRaroju Eano Zahori Alfarasi, (S Msb, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (Msb;) and tjAfI↓; (S, Msb;) The saddle heaved, or rose, from the back of the horse: (S, Msb:) or did not keep, or cleave, to its place upon his back. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] it is said in a trad. of 'Omar, UinRiI Oajofuw Eano OaXoyaMCa mina AlEilomi Verily I recoil, shrink, or am averse, from some matters of knowledge, or science, and ignore them, or neglect them. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Also jafaA, (Msb, TA,) aor. as above, (Msb,) [and so the inf. n.,] said of a garment, or piece of cloth, It was thick, coarse, or rough: (Msb, TA:) and in like manner said of a reed-pen, it was thick, coarse, or rough, in its nib. (TA.) ― -b4- [And hence, (see jafaMCN, below, and jaAfK,) He was, or became, thick, gross, coarse, rough, or rude, of make: and, more commonly, coarse, rough, or rude, of nature or disposition, or in his intercourse and dealings with others; unkind, hard, churlish, uncivil, or surly. (See also 10.)] It is said in a trad., mano badaA jafaA, i. e. [He who abides in the desert] becomes coarse, rough, or rude, of nature or disposition; [or unkind, hard, churlish, &c.;] by reason of mixing little with men. (TA.) ― -b5- jafaA Ealayohi kacaA Such a thing was, or became, heavy, onerous, burdensome, or oppressive, to him. (K.) ＝ -A2- jafaA janobahu Eani AlfiraAXi: and jafaA AlsRaroja: see 3. ― -b2- jafati Alqidoru zabadahaA The cooking-pot cast forth its froth, or foam; as also Ajft↓; (TA;) [like jafaOat and AjfOt;] originally without C. (Er- Rághib, TA.) And jafaA AlsRayolu The torrent drove away [things in its course]. (Msb.) ― -b3- jafaA AlrRajula, aor. as above, He turned away from the man; avoided him; or shunned him: or he drove away the man; from jfA AlsRayolu, explained above: sometimes meaning, with hatred. (Msb.) And jafaAhu He withdrew, or removed, far, or to a distance, from him: whence the saying of Mohammad Ibn-Sookah, lamRaA qalRa maAliI jafaAniI UixowaAniI [When my property became little, my brethren withdrew far from me]. (TA) ― -b4- And jafaA maAlahu He did not keep, or cleave, or hold fast, to his property. (K.) ― -b5- And jafaAhu, (S, K,) aor.
jafuwa
, (S,) inf. n. jafaMCN (S, K) and jafowN, (K,) He treated him, or behaved towards him, coarsely, roughly, rudely, unkindly, hardly, churlishly, uncivilly, or surlily: (S, K:) you should not say jafayotu. (S.) The pass. part. n. is majofuwRN↓ and majofiIRN↓: (S, and K in art. jfI:) the latter formed in accordance with jufiIa, in which the w is changed into I. (Fr, S.) ― -b6- He did to him what displeased, grieved, or vexed, him; did to him what he disliked, or hated; did evil to him. (TA.) So in the trad., mano HajRa walamo yazuroniI faqado jafaA [He who performs the pilgrimage to Mekkeh and does not visit me, i.e. does not visit my tomb afterwards, either on his homeward journey or by journeying to ElMedeeneh for that special purpose, does what displeases me]. (TA.) ― -b7- jafati AlmaroOupu waladahaA The woman neglected to take care of her child, or to pay frequent attention to it. (TA.)

2 tajofiyapN jf jfA tjfyh tjfyp
2. tajofiyapN [inf. n. of jfRI] signifies, in Persian, jfAC frmwdn [app. as meaning The ordering one to act, or to treat another, coarsely, roughly, rudely, &c.]. (KL. [Accord. to Golius, as on this authority, “ i. q. jafaA, sign. injuria affecit; duriter et inique tractavit: seu transit. ejus. ”])

3 jAfI janobahu Eani AlfiraAXi c
3. jAfI janobahu Eani AlfiraAXi, and jafaAhu↓, He caused his side not to rest, or caused it to be restless, or uneasy, upon the bed; or caused it to shrink therefrom: and he heaved it, drew it up, or raised it, [making it to be separated by some space or interval] from the bed. (Mgh.) And hence, (Mgh,) jAfI EaDudayohi (Mgh, TA) Eano janobyohi (TA) He put, or set, his upper arms apart, or remote, from his sides. (Mgh, TA.) [Thus the Muslim is enjoined to do in prostrating himself in prayer.] And jAfI AlsRaroja Eano Zahori Alfarasi, (S, * Msb,) and AjfAhu↓, (S, K,) and jafaAhu↓, (K, [said in the TA to be a mistake, but a similar usage of this verb has been mentioned above on the authority of the Mgh,]) He raised the saddle from the back of the horse: (S, Msb, K:) and in like manner, Alqataba Eano Zahori AlbaEiyri Oajofayotu↓ [I raised the saddle from the back of the. camel]. (M, TA.)

4 AjfAhu OjfAh OjfI AjfAh AjfAp
4. AjfAhu He made, or caused, him, or it, to be, or become, distant, remote, far off, or aloof. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 3, in two places. ― -b3- AjfI AlmaAXiyapa He fatigued the cattle, [in some copies of the S, tabiEahaA is put for OatoEabahaA,] and did not let them eat, (AZ, S, K, TA,) nor fed them previously, driving them vehemently. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Oajofati Alqidoru: see 1. ― -b2- Ojofati AlOaroDu The land became like the jufaMC, or rubbish and scum cast forth by the torrent of a valley, or by a cooking-pot, in respect of the departure of the good thereof. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

6 tjAfI jAfI tjAfI tjAfy
6. tjAfI: see 1, in three places. [Said of a person prostrating himself, or lying down, it means He drew up his body from that on which he rested. And tjAfI Eanohu generally signifies He, or it, receded, withdrew, removed, or became remote or aloof or separated by some space or interval, from him, or it: and he drew away, shrank, or flinched, from him, or it.] It is said, of the difference between AlcRaboH and Alqatol, that the former is by cutting the external jugular veins; and the latter, biUiyqaAEi AlfiEili fiI AlmaHalRi maEa AltRajaAfiI [By causing the act to take effect upon the place thereof while standing aloof]; meaning that the qaAtil strikes from a distance, not knowing whether he will hit the place or not. (Mgh.) And [hence] you say, tjAfI lahu Eano HaqRihi (assumed tropical:) [He relinquished, i. e.] he gave, to him, his right, or due. (TA in art. xmS.) ― -b2- He inclined, or declined, or turned, from side to side: and from right to wrong. (Har p. 125.) [See 6 in art. dfw.]

8 AjtfAhu AjtfAh AjtfAp
8. AjtfAhu He removed him, or it, from his, or its, place. (K.)

10 AstjfAhu AstjfAh AstjfAp
10. AstjfAhu He esteemed it (namely, a bed, &c., K) jaAfK (S, K) i. e. thick, coarse, or rough. (TA.) ― -b2- He demanded, or required, of him that he should do what was displeasing, grievous, vexatious, or evil. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AstjfI He became coarse, rough, rude, unkind, hard, churlish, uncivil, or surly. (KL. [See also 1.])

jafFA jfA
jafFA: see jafaMCN.

jafowapN jf jfw jfwh jfwp
jafowapN A single act of coarse, rough, rude, unkind, hard, churlish, uncivil, or surly, treatment, or behaviour. (TA.) ― -b2- See also jafaMCN, in three places.

jifowapN jf jfw jfwh jfwp
jifowapN: see jafaMCN.

jafaMCN jfMC
jafaMCN is in make; [signifying Thickness, grossness, coarseness, roughness, or rudeness:] and in nature, or disposition; (TA;) signifying coarseness, roughness, or rudeness, (Mgh, Msb,) in one's intercourse and dealings with others; (Mgh;) unkindness, hardness, churlishness, incivility, or surliness; a predominant quality of the people of the desert; (Mgh, Msb;) from jafaA said of a garment, or piece of cloth; (Msb;) contr. of birRN (S,) or of SilapN; (K;) as also jafFA↓, (K,) accord. to Lth; but Az says that he knew not any one who allowed this latter: (TA:) so, too, jifowapN↓ and jafowapN↓, in the sayings fiyhi jifowapN and jafowapN [In him is coarseness, roughness, or rudeness, &c.]: (K:) and fulaAnN ZaAhiru Aljifowapi Such a one is a person in whom coarseness, roughness, or rudeness, &c., is apparent: (S:) but accord. to Lth, jfwp [whether jafowapN or jafowapN is not shown] denotes a more constant quality than jafaMCN (TA.) You
say also, bihi jafowapN↓, meaning He is suffering coarseness, roughness, or rudeness, &c. (K.) And AlzRamani OaSaAbatohu jafowapu↓ (tropical:) [The roughness, or rudeness, &c., of time, or fortune, smote him]; and jafawaAtuhu [its roughnesses, or rudenesses, &c.]. (TA.)

jufaMCN jfMC
jufaMCN The rubbish and scum cast forth by the torrent of a valley, and by a cooking-pot. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [See also art. jfO.] ― -b2- And hence, as being likened to the jufaMC of the torrent, (tropical:) The first, or foremost, of men, or people. (TA.) [But see art. jfO.]

jaAfK jAf jAfy
jaAfK [act. part. n. of 1:] applied to a garment, or piece of cloth, (Mgh, Msb,) and to a bed, &c., (S, * K, TA,) Thick, coarse, or rough. (Mgh, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- And [hence] applied to a man, (S, TA,) meaning Thick, gross, coarse, rough, or rude, of make; and coarse, rough, or rude, of nature or disposition; coarse, rough, rude, unkind, hard, churlish, uncivil, or surly, in his treatment of, or behaviour towards, his companions: pl. jufaApN. (TA.) You say also, rajulN jaAfiI Alxiloqapi [A man thick, gross, coarse, rough, or rude, of make]: and jaAfiIAlxuluqi niggardly and incompliant; coarse, rough, or rude, (K, TA,) in his intercourse and dealings with others; oppressive when angry and irritated against his companion with whom he sits. (TA.) And jaAfK Eani AlmawoEiZapi [Obdurate against admonition]. (TA in art. jEZr.)

majofuwRN mjfw
majofuwRN: see 1.

majofiIRN mjfI mjfy
majofiIRN: see 1.

1 jalRRa jl
1. jalRRa, aor. yajilRu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. jalaAlapN, (S,) or jalaAlN, (K, [in the CK, erroneously, julAlFA is put for jalaAlFA,]) or both, (TA, [but see what follows,]) and julRaI, (Ham p. 218, see this word below, under jalalN,) [in its primary sense, It was, or became, thick, gross, coarse, rough, rugged, rude, big, or bulky: (see jaliylN:) and then,] it, (a thing, Msb,) or he (a man, S) was, or became, great; (S, Msb, K, TA;) [said of a thing, meaning in size; and] said of a man, meaning in estimation, rank, or dignity: (S, TA:) or jalaAlapN signifies greatness of estimation or rank or dignity: but jalaAlN, supreme greatness thereof: (Er-Rághib, TA:) the latter is an attribute of God only; (As in Ham p. 607, Er-Rághib, TA;) except in few instances: (As ubi suprà:) or it means the greatness, or majesty, of God: (S, Msb:) or his absolute independence. (Bd in lv. 27.) [EazRa wa jalRa, referring to the name of God expressed or understood, is a phrase of frequent occurrence, meaning, To Him, or to Whom, belong might and majesty, or glory and greatness] ― -b2- yajilPu Eani AlUiHaATapi bihi [He is too great to be comprehended within limits] and yajilRu Oano yudoraka biAlHawaAsRi [He is too great to be perceived by the senses] are phrases used in speaking of God. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b3- The saying of El-Ahmar,
yaA jalRa maA baEudato Ealayoka bilaAdunaA
faQboruqo biOaroDika maA badaA laka waQroEudi
[O, how greatly distant to thee is our country! therefore threaten in thy land as long as it seems fit to thee, and menace], means mA bEdt maA OajalRa↓ [&c.]. (S.) ― -b4- Also jalRa, (S, K,) aor.
jalila
, inf. n. jalaAlapN and jalaAlN, (K,) said of a man, (S,) He became old, or advanced in age, (S, K,) and firm, or sound, in judgment. (K.) And jalRato said of a she-camel, She was, or became, old, or advanced in age: (Abu-n-Nasr, S:) and so tjAlRt↓ said of a woman. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jalRati AlhaAjinu Eani Alawladi [The girl married before she had arrived at puberty, or the beast covered before she was of fit age,] was too young [to bear offspring]: (S:) a prov. (TA.) [Thus the verb bears two contr. significations. See also haAjinN.] ＝ -A3- jalRa Alqawomu, (S, Msb, * K, *) Eani Albaladi, (S,) or Eano manaAzilihimo, (K,) aor.
jalila
, (Msb, K,) or
jalula
[contr. to rule], (S, Sgh,) or both, accord. to Ibn-Málik and others, (TA,) inf. n. juluwlN, (S, K,) [and jalaMCN accord. to the K, but this is an inf. n. of jalaA], The people, or company of men, went forth, or emigrated, (S, Msb, K,) like jalaA, (S, K,) from a country, or town, (Msb,) [or from their places of abode,] to another country, or town. (S, Msb.) ＝ -A4- jalRuwA AlOaqiTa, (K,) [aor., accord. to rule,
jalula
,] inf. n. jalRN, (TA,) They took the main part, or portion, of the [preparation of milk termed] AqT. (K.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- jalalota hecaA EalaI nafosika Thou hast brought this as an injury (janayotahu) upon thyself. (K.) ＝ -A5- jalRa AlbaEara, (S, K,) aor.
jalula
, (S,) inf. n. jalRN (S, K) and jalRapN, (K,) He picked up, (S,) or collected with his hand, (K,) the camels', or similar, dung; (S, K;) and AjtlRpu↓ signifies the same, (S,) or he picked it up for fuel. (K.) [See jalRapN.] ＝ -A6- See also 2.

2 jlRl jlI jll
2. jlRl, inf. n. tajoliylN, said of a thing, i. q. EamRa [as meaning It included persons, or things, &c., in common, or generally, or universally, within the compass of its influence, or effects]. (S, TA.) So in the phrase saHaAbN yujalRilu AlOaroDa biAlmaTari [Clouds that include the land in common, or generally, or universally, within the compass of their rain; i. e., that rain upon the land throughout its general, or universal, extent]: (S, TA:) or, as in the A, thundering clouds, covering the land with rain. (TA.) And so in the phrase, jalRala AlmaTaru AlOaroDa The rain included the general, or universal, extent of the land within the compass of its fall; and covered the land so as not to leave anything uncovered. (IF, Msb.) ― -b2- And hence, [in a general sense,] He covered a thing. (Msb.) It [or he] ascended, rose, mounted, got, was, or became, upon, or over, a thing; (Ham p. 45;) as also tajlRl↓. (S, K.) ― -b3- He clad a horse (S, K) or beast (K) with a julR [or covering for protection from the cold]; (S, K;) as also jalRa↓. (K.)

4 AjlRhu OjAl Ojl OjlI Ojlh Ajlh Ajlp jAl jlA jlI Mjl Mjlh Mjlp
4. AjlRhu, (S, K,) inf. n. UijolaAlN, (TA,) [He made it jaliyl, i. e., thick, &c.: contr. of OadaqRahu: see Ham p. 546. ― -b2- And hence,] He magnified him; honoured him; (K, TA;) as also tjAlRhu↓: (TA:) he exalted him (TA) in rank, or station. (S.) It is said in a trad., OajilRuwA QllReha yagofiro lakumo, meaning [Magnify ye God, and He will forgive you: or] say ye, yaA caA AljalaAli wa AlUikoraAmi [O Thou who art possessed of greatness, or majesty, and bounty], and believe in his greatness, or majesty: it is also recited otherwise, with H; (TA in the present art.;) i. e. OaHilRuwA QllReha, meaning “Resign yourselves to God; ” or “ quit ye the danger and straitness of belief in a plurality of Gods, to avail yourselves of the freedom of El-Islám; ” (TA in art. Hl;) but the former recital is confirmed by another trad., namely, OaliZRuwA biyaAcaA AljalaAli wa AlUikoraAmi [see art. lZ]. (TA in the present art.) [Hence,] faEalotu mino UijolaAlika, and mn Oajoli UijolaAlika: see jalalN. ― -b3- He gave him much. (S.) You say, maA OajalRaniy walaA OadaqRaniI (S, TA) He gave me not much, nor gave he me little: (S:) or (assumed tropical:) he gave me not a camel, nor gave he me a sheep, or goat. (TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely, El-Marrár ElFak'asee, describing his eye, (TA,)
bakato faOadaqRato fiI AlbukaI waOajalRati
(assumed tropical:) It wept, and shed few tears, and shed many. (S, TA.) You say also, OajalRa farasahu firoqFA mino curapK He gave his horse a large feed of millet. (TA.) ― -b4- He gave him a jaliylap, i. e., a she-camel that had brought forth once. (S, K.) You say, maA OajalRaniI walaA OaHoXaAniI He gave me not a she-camel that had brought forth once, (S, K, *) nor gave he me a young, or small, camel. (S.) ＝ -A2- maA OajalRa: see 1. [You say, maA OajalRahu How great, &c., is he, or it!] ＝ -A3- AjlR He was, or became, strong: ― -b2- and He was, or became, weak: thus bearing two contr. significations. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

5 tjllRehu tjlleh tjllep
5. tjllRehu He took the greater, main, principal, or chief, part of it; the main, gross, mass, or bulk, of it; (S, K;) as also AjtlRhu↓ (K) and tjAlRhu↓. (Ibn-'Abbád, K. [In the CK, in the explanation of the second and third of these verbs, jilaAlahu is erroneously put for julaAlahu.]) ― -b2- See also 2. ― -b3- [Hence,] He sat upon him; namely, a horse. (K,) And tjlRl AlfaHolu AlnRaAqapa (S and K in art. dOm) The stallion-camel mounted the she-camel. (TA in that art.)

6 tjAlR OjAl tjAl
6. tjAlR i. q. taEaAZama (S, K) and tarafRaEa. (S.) You say, fulaAnN yatajaAlRu Eano celka (S, K *) Such a one exalts himself above that; holds himself above it; disdains it; or is disdainful of it; syn. yatarafRaEu Eanohu, (S,) or yataEaAZamu; (K;) as also ytjAlR Ealayohi. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1. ＝ -A2- tjAlRhu: see 4: ― -b2- and 5.

8 Uijotalala
8: see 5: ＝ -A2- and see also 1.

R. Q. 1 jalojala jljl
R. Q. 1. jalojala [app. It sounded; or made a sound, or sounds; said of a little bell, such as is called julojul: said also of thunder: and it sounded vehemently; or made a vehement sound, or vehement sounds: and he threatened: (see jalojalapN, which seems to be the inf. n. of the verb in these senses:) and,] said of a horse, he neighed clearly; or had a clear neigh. (K.) ＝ -A2- jalojalahu,
(S,) inf. n. jalojalapN, (K,) He put it (a thing, S) in motion (S, K) with his hand. (S.) And jljl AlqidaAHa He (a player at the game called Almayosir) moved about [or shuffled] the gaming-arrows. (TA.) ― -b2- He mixed it. (K.) ― -b3- He twisted it vehemently, or strongly; namely, the string of a bow or the like. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

R. Q. 2 tajalojala jljl tjljl
R. Q. 2. tajalojala It was, or became, in a state of motion; or was put in motion. (K.) ― -b2- It was, or became, agitated in the mind. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- He sank into the ground. (S, K.) It sank, or became depressed; syn. taDaEoDaEa. (K.) One says, tajalojalato qawaAEidu Albayoti The foundations of the house sank, or became depressed; syn. taDaEoDaEato. (S.)

jalRN jl
jalRN The sail of a ship: pl. juluwlRN. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also julRN, in two places: ＝ -A3- and jilRN: ＝ -A4- and jaliylN. ― -b2- Also Contemptible, mean, or paltry: thus bearing two contr. significations. (K.)

julRN jl
julRN The greater, main, principal, or chief, part of a thing; the most thereof; the main, gross, mass, or bulk, of it; (S, Msb, K;) as also julaAlN↓. (K.) You say, Oaxaca julRahu (K, TA) and julaAlahu↓ (S, Sgh, K) [He took the greater part of it]. ＝ -A2- A horse-cloth, or covering (Msb, K,) of a horse or similar beast, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) for protection (Msb, K) from the cold; (Msb;) as also jalRN↓: (K:) [in Persian jalo:] pl. [of mult.] jilaAlN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and [of pauc.] OajolaAlN, (Msb, K,) and OajilRapN is pl. of jilaAlN. (S, TA.) ― -b2- The cover of, or a thing with which one covers, a book, or volume; which latter is hence called majalRapN↓. (Er-Rághib in TA; but, in this sense, written without any vowel-sign.) ＝ -A3- The place of the pitching and constructing of a tent or house. (K.) ＝ -A4- Also, (S, K,) and jalRN↓, (K,) The rose, (AHn, S, K,) the white and the red and the yellow; (AHn, K;) plentiful in the countries of the Arabs, both cultivated and wild: (AHn, TA:) a Persian word, arabicized; (AHn, * S, Sgh;) from kulo: (Sgh, TA:) and the jasmine: n. un. with p. (K.) ＝ -A5- See also jilRN: ＝ -A6- and jalalN.

jilRN jl
jilRN: see jaliylN, in six places ＝ -A2- Also The stalks of seed-produce [or corn] when it has been reaped; (S, O, Mgh, K;) as also julRN↓ and jalRN↓: (K:) when it has been removed to the place where the grain is trodden out, and has been trodden, and cut by means of the midowas, it is called tibonN. (AHn, Mgh.) And, by amplification, applied to The stalks remaining upon the field after the reaping. (Mgh in the present art. and in art. HSd.)

jalRapN jl jlh jlp
jalRapN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jilRapN↓ and julRapN↓, (K,) the second whereof is that which is most known [in the present day], and next the first [which seems to be the most chaste], (TA,) Camels', or sheep's, or goats', or similar, dung; syn. baEarN: (S, K:) or a single lump thereof: (Mgh, Msb, K:) or such as has not been broken. (K.) [Commonly applied in the present day to Such dung kneaded with chopped straw and formed into round flat cakes, which are dried in the sun, for fuel.] You say, UinRa baniI fulaAnK wa quwduhumu AljalRapu [Verily the sons of such a one, their fuel is the dung of camels or sheep &c.]. (S.) ― -b2- Also (metonymically, Mgh) applied to Human ordure. (Mgh, Msb.)

julRapN jl jlh jlp
julRapN A large [receptacle made of palm-leaves woven together, such as is called] qufRap, for dates; (K;) a receptacle (S, Mgh, Msb, K) for dates, (S, Mgh, Msb,) made of palm-leaves; (K;) [a thing made of palm-leaves woven together, generally used as a receptacle for dates, but also employed for other purposes, as, for instance, to lay upon the mouth of a watering-trough, where the water is poured in, by way of protection; see UizaMCN:] pl. jilaAlN (Mgh, Msb, K) and julalN. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also jalRahN.

jilRapN jl jlh jlp
jilRapN: see jalRapN: ＝ -A2- and jaliylN; of which it is in most instances a pl.

jalalN jlI jll
jalalN A great, momentous, or formidable, thing, affair, matter, case, or event; as also julRaI↓ (S, K, TA) and julRaMCu↓: (TA:) or julaI↓ [as also jalalN and julRaMCu↓] signifies a hard, difficult, severe, or distressing, and a great, momentous, or formidable, thing, or affair, &c.: (Msb:) pl. [of jalalN,] OajolaAlN; (TA;) and of julalN julRaI↓; (S, K.) El-Hárith Ibn-Waaleh says,
qawomiI humu qataluwA Oumayoma OaxiI
faUicaA ramayotu yuSiybuniI sahomiI
falaYino Eafawotu laOaEofuwano jalalFA
walaYino saTwotu laOuwohinano EaZomiI
[My people, they have slain, O Umeymeh, (Oumayoma being apocopated, for Oumayomapu,) my brother; so, if I shoot, my arrow will strike me; and verily, if I forgive, I shall indeed forgive a great thing; but verily, if I assault, I shall indeed weaken my bone: see Ham p. 97]. (S.) And Beshámeh Ibn-Hazn says,
wamakorumapF waUino daEawota UilaI julRaI↓
yawomFA saraApF kiraAma AlnRaAsi faQdoEiynaA
[And if thou invite to a great affair, and a generous act, any day, manly and noble persons, the generous of mankind, invite us]: (TA:) or julRaI is here an inf. n. in the place of jalaAlN and jalaAlapN, like rujoEaI, &c. (Ham p. 218.) ― -b2- Also, i. e., jalalN, A small, (K,) an easy, or a mean, paltry, or contemptible, thing, affair, matter, case, or event: (S, K, TA:) thus bearing two contr. significations. (S, K.) Imra-el-Keys says, on the occasion of his father's having been slain,
OalaA kulRu XaIoCK siwaAhu jalalo
bi qatoli baniI OasadK rabRahumN
meaning [By Benoo-Asad's slaying their lord: now surely everything beside it is] a mean, paltry, or small, matter. (S, * TA.) ― -b3- faEalotu celika mino jalalika I did that on account of thee, for thy sake, or because of thee; syn. mino Oajolika; (S, K *) as also mn julRika↓, (K,) and mn jalaAlika↓, (S, K,) and mn tajilRatika↓, and mn UijolaAlika↓, and mn Oajoli UijolaAlika↓. (K.) Jemeel says,
rasomu daArK waqafotu fiI Talaliho
kidotu OaqoDiI AlgidApa mino jalalipo
meaning [The remains marking the site of a house, I paused at the relic thereof that was still standing: I almost died, in the early morning,] on account of it (mino Oajolihi), or, as some say, because of its greatness in my eye. (S.) ＝ -A2- Accord. to Zj, jalalo is a particle syn. with naEamo. (Mughnee.)

jalaAlN jlAl
jalaAlN an inf. n. of jalRa. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] faEalotu celika mino jalaAlika: see jalalN.

julaAlN jlAl
julaAlN: see julRN, in two places: ― -b2- also, and its fem., with p, see jaliylN, in three places: ― -b3- and see julaAjilN.

jilaAlN jlAl
jilaAlN The deck, or part resembling a roof, of a ship: a sing. word. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [See julRN and julRapN, of each of which it is a pl.]

jaliylN jlyl
jaliylN, in its primary acceptation, signifies Thick, gross, coarse, rough, rugged, rude, big, or bulky; applied to a material substance; (Er-Rághib, TA;) opposed to daqiyqN; (S, Er-Rághib, TA;) as also jilRN↓, (S,) opposed to diqRN: (S, K:) [and then,] great; (Msb, K;) as also jilRN↓ and jalRN↓ (K) and julaAlN↓, (S, K,) which is also explained as signifying large, big, bulky, or large in body, (K,) and julRaAlN↓: fem. jaliylapN and julaAlapN↓: (K:) [also] great in respect of estimation, rank, or dignity: (S, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OajilRapN and jilRapN and [of mult.] OajilRaMCu. (TA.) You say, maA lahu diqRN YalaA jilRN↓, i. e., daqiyqN walaA jaliylN [He has neither slender, or fine, or small, nor thick, or gross, or coarse, &c., or great]. (S.) And XajarN jilRN↓ [Large trees; or trees as] opposed to XajarN diqRN [or shrubs, or bushes]. (Lth, Mgh in art. bql.) And Hulalu jilRK↓ Thick, or coarse, [garments, or dresses, of the kind called] Hulal; opposed to Hulalu diqRN: (Mgh in art. dq:) or the things termed jilRN, of commodities, are carpets, and [the garments called] Oakosiyap [pl. of kisaMC], and the like; (K;) contr. of diqRN; such as the [cloth called] Hilos, and the mat, and the like. (TA.) And julaAlapN↓ signifies A great she-camel; (S, K;) big-bodied. (TA.) You say also, TaHatapu TaHonFA jaliylFA [He ground it coarsely]. (S in art. jX.) Aljaliylu, meaning The great in dignity, is not applied peculiarly to God: when it is applied to Him, it is because of his creating the great things that are indicative of Him, or because He is too great to be comprehended within limits or to be perceived by the senses. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And qawomN jilRapN means A great people; lords, chiefs, or people of rank or quality; (K;) a good people; (TA;) a people of eminence, nobility, dignity, or high rank. (K.) ― -b2- Also Old, or advanced in age, and firm, or sound, in judgment:
pl. jilRapN: (K:) which pl., as meaning old, or advanced in age, is applied to camels, (S, Sgh, K,) as well as to men. (K.) Hence, in a trad., faQEotaraDa lahumo Uiboliysu fiI Suwarpi XayoxK jaliylK [And Iblees presented himself to them in the form of an old man advanced in age]. (TA.) jilRapN↓ in the sense last explained above, is also used as a sing., and is applied to the male and the female [of camels]: or signifies such as is termed vaniyRap, [i. e., a she-camel that has entered her sixth year,] until she has become a baAzil [in her ninth year]: or a male camel that has become a vaniIR: or it is applied to a she-camel, and jilRN↓ to a he-camel. (K.) And [the fem.] jaliylapN↓ [used as a subst.] signifies A she-camel that has brought forth once: (S, O, K:) and [simply] a she-camel; as in the saying, maA lahu jaliylapN walaA daqiyqapN He has neither a she-camel nor a ewe, or she-goat: (S:) or camels. (JK and TA in art. dq [q. v., voce daqiyqN].) Also (i. e. jlylp↓) A great palm-tree having much fruit: pl. jaliylN; (K;) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.;] or, accord. to some copies of the K, the pl. is jilaAlN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. vumaAmN [Panicum, or panic grass]; (S, K;) a weak plant, with which the interstices of houses are stopped up: n. un. with p: (S:) or jaliylapN↓ signifies a species of vumaAm: (TA in art. vm:) pl. jalaAYilu. (S, K.)

jaliylapN jlyl jlylh jlylp
jaliylapN [used as a subst.]: see the latter part of the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

julRaI jl jlI jly jlyy
julRaI: see jalalN, in four places.

julRaMCu jlMC
julRaMCu: see jalalN, in two places.

julRiIRN jl jlI jly jlyy
julRiIRN a rel. n. from jul; A seller of jilaAl [pl. of julRN] for horses or similar beasts. (TA.)

julRalN jlI jll
julRalN: see jaliylN

jalRaAlapN jlAl jlAlh jlAlp
jalRaAlapN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jaAlRapN↓ (Mgh, Msb) A cow that repeatedly seeks after filths [to eat them]; (S, K;) the milk of which is forbidden: (S:) a beast that eats jalRap, meaning human ordure; (S, Mgh, Msb;) the flesh of which is forbidden: (Mgh:) pl. [of the former] jalRaAlaAtN; (Msb) and of the latter jawaAlRu; (Mgh, Msb;) the latter pl. occurring in a trad., in which some erroneously substitute for it jawRaAlaAt. (Mgh.)

julojulN jljl
julojulN [A little bell, consisting of a hollow ball of copper or brass or other metal, perforated, and containing a loose solid ball;] a small jaras [or bell]; (Msb, K;) a thing that is hung to the neck of a horse or similar beast, or to the leg of a hawk: (Mgh:) pl. jalaAjilu. (S, Mgh, Msb.) You say, fulaAnN yuEalRiqu Aljulojula fiI Eunuqihi [Such a one hangs the little bell upon his neck;] meaning, (tropical:) such a one imperils, or endangers, himself. (TA.) Abu-n-Nejm says,
UilRaA QmoraON yaEoqidu xayoTa Aljulojuli
[Except a man who ties the string of the little bell;] meaning, (tropical:) except a bold man, who imperils himself: AA says that it is a prov., meaning, except a man who makes himself notorious, so that no one precedes him except a courageous man who cares not for him, and who is stubborn and notorious. (TA.) ― -b2- See also julaAjilN.

jalojalapN jljl jljlh jljlp
jalojalapN [app. inf. n. of jalojala, q. v.;] The sound, or sounding, of a julojul, (S,) or of a jaras [or bell]; (TA;) and of thunder: (S, K:) and vehemence of sound: and a threatening (K, TA) from behind a thing covering or concealing. (TA.)

julojulaAnN jljl jljlAn
julojulaAnN What is jaliyl [app. meaning great in estimation] of a thing. (Ibn-' Abbád, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The fruit of the kuzoburap [or coriander]: (S, Mgh, K:) and, (Mgh,) accord, to Abu-1-Ghowth, (S,) sesame, or sesamum, (S, Z, Mgh, TA,) in its husks, before it is reaped: (S:) or it signifies also the grain of sesame or sesamum. (K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The heart's core (HabRapu Alqalobi). (S, Z, K, TA.) You say, OaSabotu julojulaAna qalbihi (tropical:) [I hit his heart's core]. (S.) And AisotaqarRa celika fiI julojulaAna qalobihi (tropical:) [That rested, or remained, in his heart's core]. (Z, TA.) And kalaAmN xaraja mino julojulaAni Alqalobi UilaI qimaEi AlOucuni (tropical:) [Speech that came forth from the core of the heart to the meatus of the ear]. (Z, TA.)

jalojaAlN jljAl
jalojaAlN: see mujalojilN

julaAjilN jlAjl jljl
julaAjilN An ass that brays clearly; (S, K;) as also julaAlN↓; (El-Moheet, K) which is in like manner applied to a she-camel. (El-Moheet, TA.) ― -b2- A boy light in spirit; brisk, lively, or sprightly, in his work; (K;) as also julojulN↓ (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ＝ -A2- Oabovavotuhu julaAjila nafosiI I revealed to him what was agitated in my mind. (Ibn-' Abbád, K, * TA.)

jaAlRN jAl
jaAlRN Going forth, or emigrating, from a country, or town, to another country, or town; (Msb;) [as also jaAlK; (see art. jlw;)] and so jaAlRapN, (S, Msb, K,) its pl., (Msb,) applied to a people, or company of men; (S, Msb, K;) originally applied to the Jews who were expelled from El-Hijáz; as also jaAliyapN. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, jaAlRapN↓, as a subst., meaning The poll-tax; (Msb;) as also jaAliyapN, (S and Msb in art jlw.) You say, AusotuEomila ifulaAnN EalaI AljaAlRap [Such a one was employed as collector of the poll-tax]; like as you say, ElI AljaAliyapi. (S, Msb.) ＝ -A2- jaAlRapN as a fem. epithet used as a subst.: see jalRaAlapN.

jaAlRapN jAl jAlh jAlp
jaAlRapN (as a subst.): see jaAlRN; of which it is also pl. and fem.

OajalRu c
OajalRu [Thicker &c., and thickest &c.; see jaliylN: and] i. q. OaEoZamu [more, and most, great &c.]: (S, TA:) fem. julRaI. (Ham. p. 45.) With the article, [as a superlative epithet,] it is applied to God; (S, TA;) and so, by poetic license, AlOajolalu. (TA.)

tajilRapN OjAl Ojl OjlI jAl jlA jlI tjlh tjlp
tajilRapN a subst. [signifying The act of magnifying, or honouring]; (K, TA;) like takorimapN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] faEalotu celika mino tajilRatika, like mn UijolaAlika &c.: see jalalN

majalRapN mjlh mjlp
majalRapN A SaHiyfap [or book, volume, writing, or written paper or the like;] in which is science: (S, K:) and any book, or writing, (A' Obeyd, S, K,) is thus called by the Arabs; (A 'Obeyd, S;) as, for instance, that of Lukmán, and one of poetry: (TA:) and so in the phrase used by En-Nábighah (Edh-Dhubyánee, TA) majalRatuhumo caAtu AlUilehi [Their book is that of God]: or, as some recite it, he said maHalRatuhumo, with HAC, meaning, their abode is one of pilgrimage and of sacred sites. (S, TA.) See julRN ― -b2- [Hence,] Science; and the doctrine, or science, of practical law. (AA, TA.)

mujalRalN mjll
mujalRalN A horse clad with a julR; as also majoluwlN↓; (TA;) which latter is likewise applied to a camel. (Ibn-Abbád, TA.)

saHaAbN mujalRilN sHAb mjll
saHaAbN mujalRilN Clouds that include the land in common, or generally, or universally, within the compass of their rain; i. e., that rain upon the land throughout its general, or universal extent: (S, TA:) or thundering clouds, covering the land with rain: (A, TA:) or clouds in which are thunder and lightning. (As, TA in art. qSb.) [See also mujalojilN.]

majoluwlN mjlwl
majoluwlN: see mujalRalN. ＝ -A2- Also Water into which jalRap [q. v.] has fallen. (TA.)

mujalojalN mjljl
mujalojalN A man very excellent, or elegant, in mind, manners, address, speech, person, or the like; in whom is no fault, or vice. (K.) ― -b2- A camel that has attained his full strength. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- UibilN mujalojalapN Camels having small bells, of the kind called julojulo, hung upon them. (K.)

mujalojilN mjljl
mujalojilN Clouds (saHaAbN) in which is the sound of thunder: (S, K: * [in the CK, in this instance, erroneously written mujalojalN:]) or sounding: (TA:) [see also mujalRilN:] and in like manner jalojaAlN↓ applied to rain. (K, TA.) ― -b2- A strong chief: or [in the CK, "and,"] one whose voice, or fame, (Sawot,) reaches far: and bold, vehement in repelling or defending, eloquent, or able in speech, (K,) who subjects himself to peril, or danger. (TA.)

1 jalaba jlb
1. jalaba, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
jaliba
and
jaluba
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. jalobN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jalabN, (S, K,) He drove, (A, K,) or brought, conveyed, or transported, (Mgh,) a thing, (S, A, * Mgh, Msb, K, *) or things, such as camels, sheep, goats, horses, captives, or slaves, or any merchandise, (TA,) from one place to another, (A, K,) or from one country or town to another, for the purpose of traffic; (Mgh;) as also Ajtlb↓, (A, K, KL,) and Astjlb↓. (KL.) And jalabotu AlXRaIoCa Uilay nafosiI and Aijotalabotuhu↓ signify the same; (S;) i. e. (assumed tropical:) I brought, drew, attracted, or procured, the thing to myself. (PS.) [Hence,] caA mimRaA yajolibu AlUixowaAna (tropical:) [This is of the things that bring, draw, attract, or procure, brothers, or friends]. (A, TA.) And AldRahori jalabatuhu jawaAlibu↓ (tropical:) [The calamities of time, or of fortune, or of fate, brought, drew, or attracted, him, or it]. (A, TA.)
[Hence also, accord. to some,] laA jalaba wa laA janaba, a trad., explained as meaning, The owner of cattle shall not be required to drive them, or bring them, to the town, or country, in order that the collector may take from them the portion appointed for the poor-rate, but this shall be taken at the waters; and when the cattle are in the yards, they shall be left therein, and not brought forth to the place of pasture, for the collector to take that portion: or, as some say, wlA jnb means, nor shall one have a horse led by his side, in a race, in order that, when he draws near to the goal, he may tranfser himself to it, and so outstrip his fellow: and other explanations have been given: (Msb:) [accord. to some,] lA jlb here means, they shall not drive, or bring, their cattle to the collector of the portions appointed for the poor-rate in the place where he alights, but he shall himself come to their yards and take those portions: or [jlb here is from the verb jalaba in a sense which will be explained below, and] the trad. relates to horse-racing, and means, one shall not cause his horse to be followed by a man crying out at it and chiding it; nor shall he have a horse without a rider led by his own horse, in order that, when he draws near to the goal, he may transfer himself to it, and outstrip upon it: (Mgh:) or Aljalabu, which is forbidden, means the collector's not coming to the people at their waters to take the portions appointed for the poor-rate, but ordering them to drive, or bring, their cattle to him: or it relates to contending for a stake, or wager, and means the mounting a man upon one's horse, and, when he has drawn near to the goal, following his horse and crying out at it, in order that it may outstrip; which is a kind of fraud: (S:) or it is used in both these cases: (A 'Obeyd: [his explanations are virtually the same as those in the S:]) or the meaning of the trad. [so far as the former clause of it is concerned] is, that the contributions to the poor-rate shall not be driven, or brought, to the waters nor to the great towns, but shall be given in their places of pasture: or it means, [or rather Aljlb means,] the collector's alighting in a place, and then sending a person, or persons, to drive, or bring, to him the cattle from their places, that he may take the portion thereof appointed for the poor-rate: or it [relates to horse-racing, and] means the sending forth a horse in the racecourse, and a number of persons' congregating, and crying out at it, in order that it may be turned from its course: or a man's following his horse, and spurring on behind it, and chiding it, and crying out at it: (K, TA:) or the shaking a thing behind a horse that is backward in a race, that it may be urged on thereby, and outstrip: or one's riding a horse, and leading behind him another, to urge it on, in contending for a stake, or wager: or the crying out at a horse from behind, and urging it to outstrip. (TA. See also 1 in art. jnb.) ― -b2- jalaba lOaholihi He gained or earned; sought or sought after or sought to gain [provisions &c.; generally meaning he purveyed]; and exercised art or cunning or skill, in the management of his affairs; for his family; as also Ajlb↓. (Lh, K.) ＝ -A2- jalabuwA, aor.
jaliba
and
jaluba
, (K,) [inf. n. jalabN, and perhaps jalabapN also;] and jlRbwA↓; (S, K;) and AjlbwA↓, (K,) inf. n. UijolaAbN; (Mgh;) [the second of which is the most common;] They raised cries, shouts, noises, a clamour, (S, Mgh, TA,) or confused cries or shouts or noises. (Mgh, K. *) And jalaba Ealay farasihi, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jaluba
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. jalabN, (S,) or jalobN, (Msb,) He chid, or urged on, his horse; as also jlRb↓ and Ajlb↓; (K;) the first, rare; the second and third, usual: (TA:) he cried out at his horse, (S, K,) from behind him, and urged him to outstrip [in a race], (S,) aor.
jaluba
and
jaliba
; (K; but this explanation is erased in the copy of the K in its author's handwriting, as being a repetition; and rightly, accord. to MF; though this requires consideration; TA;) as also Ajlb↓: (S:) he urged his horse to run, by striking, or goading, or by crying out, or the like; as also Ajlb↓: or, as some say, he led behind his horse that he was riding another horse to urge on the former, in contending [in a race] for a stake, or wager; as is shown in an explanation of the tradition cited above, laA jalaba walaA janaba. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [xvii. 66], Ealayohimo bixayolika warajolika waOajolibo↓ And raise thou confused cries against them, (Mgh,) or cry out against them, with thy forces riding and on foot. (Bd. But see another explanation in what follows.) And it is said in a wellknown prov., jalabato jalobapF vumRa Oamosakato It, i. e. a cloud (saHaAbap), thundered, then refrained from raining: applied to a coward, who threatens, and then is silent: but accord. to some, it is with H in the place of j (MF. See art. Hlb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jalaba, aor.
jaliba
and
jaluba
; and Ajlb↓; He threatened with evil; (K, TA;) followed by an accus. (TA) [or, app., by EalaI before the object]: or (so in the TA, but in some copies of the K “ and, ”) he collected a company, a troop, or an army. (K, TA.) [It is said that] Ealayohimo waOajolibo↓, in the Kur [xvii. 66], means And collect thou against them [thy forces], and threaten them with evil. (TA. But see another explanation above.) And Ealayohi Ajlbw↓ signifies also They collected themselves together against him, (S, K, *) and aided one another; like AHlbwA. (S.) ― -b3- jalaba Ealayohi, aor.
jaluba
, inf. n. jalobN, He committed a crime against him; or an offence for which he should be punished. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A3- jalaba, aor.
jaliba
and
jaluba
, (S, K,) It (a wound) healed: (K:) or it (an ulcer, As, or a wound, S) became covered with a skin in healing: (As, S:) as also Ajlb↓. (S, L.) ― -b2- And It (blood) dried; became dry; as also Ajlb↓. (Lh, K.) ＝ -A4- jaliba, aor.
jalaba
, It [app. a company or troop] assembled, or became collected together. (K.)

2 jalRaba
2: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- The inf. n. tajoliybN also signifies The act of bringing together: or collecting. (KL.)

3 jaAolaba
3: [jAlb is explained by Golius, as on the authority of the KL, as meaning He helped, or assisted: but this is a mistake for HAlb; for I find muHaAlabapN explained by yArI krdn in a copy of the KL, and the order of the words there shows that it is not a mistranscriptiou for mjAlbp.]

4 Ajlb Ojlb Ajlb jlb
4. Ajlb: see 1, in eleven places, in the latter half of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- Also His camels brought forth males; (S, K;) because the males that they produce are driven, or brought, from one place to another, and sold; opposed to AHlb “ his camels brought forth females: ” (S:) and his camel brought forth a male. (TA.) Oajolabota walaA OaHolabota May thy camels bring forth males, and may they not bring forth females, is a form of imprecation against a man, implying a wish that he may lose the milk [that he would have otherwise]. (TA.) ＝ -A3- He aided, helped, or assisted, another. (S, K.) [So, too, AHlb.] ＝ -A4- He put an amulet into a julobap [which must therefore signify the piece of skin in which an amulet is enclosed, as well as an amulet enclosed in a piece of skin: see mujolibN]. (K.) ― -b2- Ajlb qatabahu, (S, K,) inf. n. UijolAbN, (T,) He covered his qtb [or camel's saddle] (S, K) with a julobap, i. e., (S,) with a piece of fresh, moist skin, which he left upon it until it became dry [and tight]: (S, K: *) or he covered the head of his qtb with a piece of kid's, or lamb's, skin, and left it to dry upon it. (T.)

5 tajalRaba
5: [tjlRb rendered by Golius Clamorem ac murmur excitavit, as on the authority of the K, I do not find in that lexicon nor in any other.]

7 Anjlb Onjlb Anjlb Qnjlb
7. Anjlb It [a camel, sheep, goat, horse, captive, or slave, or a number of camels &c., or any merchandise, (see 1, first sentence,)] was driven [or brought] from one place to another [or from one country or town to another, for the purpose of traffic]. (K.)

8 Ajtlb Ojtlb Ajtlb Qjtlb
8. Ajtlb: see 1, first and second sentences. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) He (a poet) took, or borrowed, from the poetry of another. (TA.) ― -b3- And He sought or demanded [a thing]. (Har p. 44.)

10 Astjlbhu Ostjlbh Astjlbh Astjlbp Qstjlb Qstjlbh
10. Astjlbhu He sought, or demanded, or desired, that it [a camel, sheep, goat, horse, captive, or slave, or a number of camels &c., or any merchandise, (see 1, first sentence,)] should be driven [or brought] from one place to another [in which he was, or from one country or town to another, for sale]. (K.) ― -b2- See also 1, first sentence.

R. Q. 1 jalobabahu jlbbh jlbbp
R. Q. 1. jalobabahu, (K,) or jlbbhu jilobaAbFA, (TA,) inf. n. jalobabapN, the second b not being incorporated into the first because the word is quasi-coordinate to the class of daHorajapN, (S,) He put on him a garment of the kind called jilobaAb. (S, K.) Accord. to Kh, the first b in jlbb is [augmentative] like the w in jahowara and dahowara: accord. to Yoo, the second is [augmentative] like the I in saloqaI and jaEobaI. (IJ, TA.)

R. Q. 2 tajalobaba tjlbb
R. Q. 2. tajalobaba, (K,) and tajalobabato, (A, Msb,) He, and she, put on a garment of the kind called jilobaAb; or clad himself, and herself, therewith. (A, Msb, K.) And tjlbb bivawobaha He covered himself with his garment. (Har p. 162.)

julobN jlb
julobN: see jilobN ― -b2- Also The blackness of night; (K, TA;) and so jilobaAbN↓. (Har p. 480. [The latter evidently tropical in this sense, and perhaps the former also.])

jilobN jlb
jilobN (S, K) and julobN↓ (S, L) A camel's saddle of the kind called raHol, with what it
contains, or comprises: (K:) or its cover: (Th, K:) or its pieces of wood: (S:) or its curved pieces of wood: (TA:) or its wood, without [the thongs called] OanosaAE and other apparatus. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, both words, Clouds, (K,) or thin clouds, (S,) in which is no water: (S, K:) or clouds appearing, or extending sideways, (muEotariDN,) [in the horizon,] like a mountain [or mountainrange]: (K, TA:) or a cloud like that which is termed EaAriDN [q. v.], but narrower, and more distant, and inclining to blackness: (AZ, TA in art. ErD:) pl. OajolaAbN. (TA.) [See also julobapN.]

jalabN jlb
jalabN A thing, or things, driven, or brought, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) from one country or town to another, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or from one place to another, (A, K,) for the purpose of traffic; (Mgh;) as horses, &c., (K,) camels, (TA,) sheep or goats, captives or slaves, (Lth, TA,) or any merchandise: (TA:) and so jalabapN↓, thus in the handwriting of the author of the K in his last copy of that work, and mentioned by more than one, (MF, [who adds that it is correct, but SM thinks it a mistake,]) and jaliybapN↓ and juluwbapN↓: (K:) [see this last, below:] pl. [of the first] OajolaAbN. (K.) Hence the prov., AlnRufaADu yuqaTRiru Aljalaba The failure of provisions causes the camels, driven, or brought, from one place to another, to be disposed in files for sale. (TA.) ― -b2- [And, app., Male camels; like jaluwbapN; because they are driven, or brought, from one place to another, and sold; (see 4;) opposed to HalabN, q. v.] ― -b3- Also Persons who drive, or bring, camels and sheep or goats [&c.] from one place or country or town to another, for sale; and so [its pl.] OajolaAbN. (S.) [In the present day, jalRaAbN↓ signifies One who brings slaves from foreign countries, particularly from African countries, for sale.] ＝ -A2- Also, (S, A, K,) and jalabapN↓, (S, A, * Mgh, K,) [the former an inf. n., and so, perhaps, the latter, but often used as simple substs., the latter more commonly, meaning] Cries, shouts, noises, or clamour: (S, TA:) or a confusion, or mixture, (A, Mgh, K,) of cries or shouts or noises, (A, Mgh,) or of crying or shouting or noise. (K.) ― -b2- And the former, An assembly of men. (TA.)

julobapN jlb jlbh jlbp
julobapN The small piece of skin, (S,) or the crust, or scab, (A, K,) that forms over a wound (S, A, K) when it heals: (S, K:) pl. julabN. (A.) ― -b2- A piece of skin that is put upon the [kind of camel's saddle called] qatab. (S, K.) [See 4.] ― -b3- [A piece of skin in which an amulet is enclosed: see 4.] ― -b4- An amulet upon which is sewed a piece of skin: (K:) pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b5- A detached portion of cloud: (K:) [or] a cloud covering the sky. (IAar, TA.) [See also jilobN.] ― -b6- A piece of land differing from that which adjoins it; a patch of ground; syn. buqoEapN. (K.) One says, UinRahu lafiI julobapi SidoqK i. e. fI buqoEapi SidoqK [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) Verily he is in a good station or position: see art. bqE]. (TA.) ― -b7- A detached portion of herbage or pasture. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- Also Severity, or pressure, of time or fortune; (S, K;) like kulobapN: (S:) and hunger: (so in some copies of the K:) or vehemence of hunger: (so in other copies of the K:) or severity; adversity; difficulty; trouble: (TA:) and a hard, distressful, or calamitous, year. (K.)

jalabapN jlb jlbh jlbp
jalabapN: see jalabN, in two places.

jilibRaAtN jlbAt
jilibRaAtN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and jilobaAbN↓; (K;) the latter mentioned as an ex. of form by Sb, and thought by Seer to be syn. with the former, but not explained by any one except the author of the K; masc. and fem.; (TA;) A [woman's outer wrapping garment called] miloHafap: (S:) or this is its primary signification; but it is metaphorically applied to other kinds of garments: (El-Khafájee, TA:) or a shirt, (K, TA,) absolutely: or one that envelopes the whole body: (TA:) and a wide garment for a woman, less than the mlHfp: or one with which a woman covers over her other garments, like the mlHfp: or the [kind of head-covering called], ximaAr: (K:) so in the M: (TA:) or a garment wider than the xmAr, but less than the ridaMC (Mgh, L, Msb,) with which a woman covers her head and bosom: (L:) or a garment shorter, but wider, than the xmAr; the same as the miqonaEap: (En-Nadr, TA:) or a woman's head-covering: (TA:) or the [kind of wrapper called] UizaAr: (IAar, TA:) or a garment with which the person is entirely enveloped, so that not even a hand is left exposed, (Har p. 162, and TA,) of the kind called mulaMCap, worn by a woman: (TA:) or a garment, or other thing, that one uses as a covering: (IF, Msb:) pl. jalaAbiybu. (S, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- See also julobN. ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Dominion, sovereignty, or rule [with which a person is invested]. (K.)

julobaAnN jlbAn
julobaAnN and julabaAnN: see julubRaAnN, in three places.

jilibRaAbN jlbAb
jilibRaAbN: see jilobaAbN.

jalabRaAnN jlbAn
jalabRaAnN: see the next paragraph, last sentence.

julubRaAnN jlbAn
julubRaAnN, (K, TA, in the CK julRabAn, and so in the TA in art. xrf,) and without teshdeed, (K,) [i. e.] julobaAnN↓, (S, Msb,) and, accord. to some, julabaAnN↓ also, (Msb,) not heard by AHn from the Arabs of the desert but with teshdeed, though many others pronounce it without tesh-deed, and pronounced in the latter manner, he says, it may be a dial. var.; (TA;) [a coll. gen. n.;] A certain plant; (K;) or a certain grain, or seed, of the kind called qaTaAniIR [i. e. pulse]; (Msb;) the [grain, or seed, called] xulRar, which is a thing resembling the maAX: (S:) or a dust-coloured, dusky hind of grain or seed, which is cooked; of the colour of the mAX, except in its being of a more dusky shade; but larger: (T, TA:) a certain kind of grain or seed, resembling the mAX, of the kind called qaTaAniIR, well known: (TA:) [a common kind of vetch, or pea, the common lathyrus, or blue chickling vetch, the lathyrus sativus of Linn., is called in Upper Egypt, and by some of the people of Lower Egypt also, jilobaAn:] n. un. with p. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also the first, (K,) and p↓, (TA,) and julobaAnN↓, (MF, on the authority of Ibn-ElJowzee,) [like jurubRaAnN and jurobaAnN or jirobaAnN,] A thing like a jiraAb [or sword-case], of skin, or leather, (K, TA,) in which is put the sword sheathed, and in which the rider puts his whip and implements &c., and which he hangs upon the Mxirap or the waAsiT [see these two words] of the camel's saddle; derived from julobapN meaning “ a piece of skin that is put upon a qatab: ” (TA:) or the case (qiraAb) of the sword-sheath, or scabbard: (K:) or jlbRAnu AlsRilAHi, occurring in a trad., signifies the case (qrAb) with its contents: or the sword and bow and the like, which require some trouble to draw forth and use in fight; not such a weapon as the lance. (L, TA.) ＝ -A3- Also the first, and jalabRaAnN↓, (K, TA,) or jilibRaAnN↓, (so in the CK,) A clamorous man; or one who makes a confused crying or shouting or noise. (K, TA.)

jilibRaAnN jlbAn
jilibRaAnN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

julubRaAnapN jlbAn jlbAnh jlbAnp
julubRaAnapN and jilibRaAnapN: see jalRaAbapN.

julubonaAnapN jlbnAnh jlbnAnp
julubonaAnapN and jilibonaAnapN: see jalRaAbapN.

jaliybN jlyb
jaliybN, applied to a male slave, (A, Mgh, K,) One who is brought from one place or country or town to another [for sale]: (S, K:) or one who is brought to the country of the Muslims [for sale]: (Mgh:) pl. jalobaI and julabMCu. (K.) It is also applied [in like manner] to a woman: pl. jalobaI and jalaAYibu. (Lh, K.)

jaluwbapN jlwbh jlwbp
jaluwbapN A thing that is driven or brought from one place or country or town to another for sale; (T, S, TA;) such as an aged she-camel, and a he-camel, and a young she-camel such as is called qaluwS, and any other thing; but not applied to stallion-camels of generous race, that are used for procreation: pl. jalaAYibu: or the pl. signifies camels that are brought to a man sojourning at a water, who has not means of carriage; wherefore they put him [and his companions or goods &c.] thereon: (TA:) or jlwbp signifies male camels: [see also jalabN:] or camels that are laden with the goods or utensils &c. of the people: and it is used alike as pl. and sing. (K.) See jalabN, with which it is syn. (K.)

jaliybapN jlyb jlybh jlybp
jaliybapN: see jalabN. ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) An affected habit or disposition. (Ibn-Abi-l-Hadeed, MF.)

jalRaAbN jlAb
jalRaAbN: see jalabN.

julRaAbN jlAb
julRaAbN Rose-water: an arabicized word, (K,) from the Persian [Gulo Mbo]. (TA.)

jalRaAbapN jlAb jlAbh jlAbp
