jalRaAbapN and mujalRibapN↓ and jilibRaAnapN↓ (K, TA) and julubRaAnapN↓ (CK) and jilibonaAnapN↓ and julubonaAnapN↓, (K, TA,) applied to a woman, Clamorous, noisy, very loquacious or garrulous, and of evil disposition: (K, TA:) or jlbRAnp signifies, thus applied, rude and coarse: (TA:) the l in this word is not a substitute for the r in jiribRaAnapN [which has a similar meaning]: for it is from Aljalabapu. (IJ, TA.)

jaAliabN jAlb
jaAliabN (A) and jaAlibapN↓ (L) and majolabapN↓ (Har p. 194 &c.) [all signify] (assumed tropical:) A cause of bringing or drawing or attracting or procuring of a thing: (Har p. 194, in explanation of the last:) thus majolabapu AldRamoEi means (assumed tropical:) the cause of drawing tears:
(1d p. 15:) pl. of the second, jawaAlibu; as in the phrase jawaAlibu Alqadari (assumed tropical:) [the drawing, or procuring, causes of destiny]: (L, TA:) pl. of the third, majaAlibu. (Har p. 430.) You say, likulRi qaDaMCK jaAlibN walikulRi darRK HaAlibN (tropical:) [For every decree of fate there is a drawing, or procuring, cause; and for every flow of milk there is a milker]. (A, TA.) And [hence] the pl. jawaAlibu signifies (assumed tropical:) Calamities, misfortunes, evil accidents, adversities, or difficulties. (TA.) See an ex. in the first paragraph, near the beginning. ― -b2- quruwHN jawaAlibu and julRabN Wounds, or ulcers, healing, or becoming covered with skin in healing. (As, TA.)

jaAlibapN jAlb jAlbh jAlbp
jaAlibapN: see the paragraph next preceding.

mujolibN mjlb
mujolibN A person who puts an amulet into a case of skin: after which it is sewed upon [the headstall, or some other part of the trappings, of] a horse. (TA.)

majolabapN mjlbh mjlbp
majolabapN: see jaAlibN.

mujalRibN mjlb
mujalRibN, applied to thunder, (K,) and to rain, (TA,) Boisterous. (K, TA.) ― -b2- mujalRibapN: see jalRaAbapN.

yanojalibN ynjlb Qnjlb
yanojalibN A xazarap [i. e. bead, or gem, or similar stone] (T, K, TA) used by the Arabs of the desert, (T, TA,) [or by the women of the desert, as a charm,] for captivating, or fascinating, men; (K, * TA;) or for bringing back after flight; (T, K;) or for procuring affection after hatred: (T, TA:) Az mentions it as a quadriliteral-radical word. (TA.) The Arab women used to say,
falaA yarumo walaA yagibo
OaxRacotuhu biAlyanojalibo
walaA yazilo Einoda AlTRanabo
[I have fascinated him with the yenjelib, and he shall not seek another, nor absent himself, nor cease to remain at the tent-rope]. (Lh, TA.)

1 jaliHa OjlH jlH
1. jaliHa, aor.
jalaHa
, inf. n. jalaHN, He (a man, S, L, &c.) was, or became, bald in the two sides of his head: (S, K:) or in the two sides of the fore part of his head: (Msb:) or in the fore part of his head: or a little more bald than he who is termed OanozaEu. (L.) [See also jalaHN and OajolaHu.] ― -b2- jaliHati AlOaroDu, inf. n. as above, The herbage of the land was eaten; as also juliHat. (TA.) And juliHati AlXRajarapu The branches of the tree were eaten, and it became reduced to its stem, or root. (AHn, TA.) ＝ -A2- jalaHa AlmaAlu AlXRajara, aor.
jalaHa
, (S, K,) inf. n. jaloHN; (S;) and jlRHhu↓, inf. n. tajoliyHN; (TA;) The cattle ate the trees: or ate the upper parts thereof: (TA:) or fed upon the upper parts thereof, and peeled them. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- See also 3.

2 jalRaHa
2: see 1. ＝ -A2- tajoliyHN [the inf. n.] signifies also the acting, or advancing, boldly, (K,) or very boldly: (S:) or being bold to do evil or mischief; and showing open enmity or hostility: (A:) and acting with penetrating energy, vigour, or effectiveness, (S, K, TA,) in an affair: (TA:) and going, or journeying, vehemently: (TA:) and the assaulting, or attacking, (AZ, K, TA,) of a man, (AZ, TA,) and of an animal of prey. (K.) See also 3. You say, lat tujalRiHo EalayonaA yaA fulaAnu [Be not bold to do evil or mischief, or to show open enmity or hostility, to us, O such a one]. (A.) And fiI wajohihi tajoliyHN In his face is [apparent] boldness to do evil or mischief, and a show of open enmity or hostility. (A.) And jlRH EalaI Alqawomi He charged, or made an assault or attack, upon the people or party. (AZ, TA.) And jlRH tajoliyHa AlcRiYobi [He assaulted with the assaulting of the wolf]. (A.) And jlRH EalayonaA He came upon us; or came down upon us and overcame us; or destroyed us; syn. OataI EalayonaA. (ISh, TA.) And jlRH fiI AlOamori He went at random, heedlessly, without any certain aim or object, or without consideration, in the affair; or pursued a headlong, or rash, course therein. (TA.)

3 mujaAlaHapN mjAlHh mjAlHp
3. mujaAlaHapN [the inf. n.] signifies the acting openly with another in an affair: (As, K:) and the showing open enmity or hostility with another. (S, K.) You say, jaAlaHotu AlrRajula biAlOamori I acted openly with the man in the affair. (S.) And jaAlaHaniI fulaAnN Such a one showed open enmity or hostility with me; as also jlRH EalaIRa↓. (A.) ― -b2- Also The contending with another for superiority in strength; syn. muXaAdRapN (S) and mukaAlaHapN. (S, K.) You say, jaAlaHaniI fulaAnN wajalaHaniI↓ [app. meaning Such a one contended with me for superiority in strength, and overcame me therein]. (TA.) ― -b3- And i. q. mukaAbarapN [The contending with another for superiority in greatness; &c.]. (K.)

Q. Q. 1 jalomaHa jlmH
Q. Q. 1. jalomaHa He shaved his head: (Fr, S, K:) the m is augmentative. (S.)

jalaHN OjlH jlH
jalaHN Baldness in the two sides of the head: (S, K:) or in the two sides of the fore part of the head: (Msb:) it is more than nazaEN, and less than SalaEN, (S, Msb,) which is less than jalahN: (Msb:) or baldness in the fore part of the head: or baldness that is a little more than what is termed nazaEN. (L.)

jalaHapN OjlH jlHh jlHp
jalaHapN A part, or place, in which is baldness such as is termed jalaHN. (S, Msb.)

OaroDN jilaHaMCapN c
OaroDN jilaHaMCapN Land that produces no herbage. (K.)

julaAHN jlAH
julaAHN A torrent that carries away everything in its course. (S, K.)

jilowaAHN jlwAH
jilowaAHN Wide (K, TA) and bare, or open, (TA,) land. (K, TA.)

julRaHN OjlH jlH
julRaHN: see OajolaHu.

jaAliHapN jAlHh jAlHp
jaAliHapN (TA) and jawaAliHu (S, K [the latter being pl. of the former]) What flies about in successive portions from the heads of reeds and papyrusplants (S, K, TA) and other plants, in the wind, (TA,) resembling cotton; (S, TA;) and spiders' webs so flying about. (TA.) And the latter, Flakes of snow falling quickly and continuously. (TA.)

OajolaHu c
OajolaHu A man bald in the two sides of his head: (S:) or in the two sides of the fore part of his head: (Msb:) or in the fore part of his head: (Mgh, L:) or a little more bald than he who is termed OanozaEu: (L:) it signifies more than AnzE, and less than OajolaI and Oajolahu: (Mgh:) when a man is bald in the sides of his forehead, he is termed AnzE; when the baldness is a little more, AjlH; when it extends to the half, or the like, AjlI; and then, Ajlh: (A 'Obeyd, TA:) the fem. is jaloHaMCu: and the pl. juloHN (L, Msb) and juloHaAnN. (L.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Having no horn; applied to a bull and a he-goat: (A:) and in this sense the fem. is applied to a ewe (T, M, Msb) or she-goat, (T, M, A, Msb,) and to a cow: (T, M, A:) and in like manner [the pl.] juloHN is applied to cows or bulls having no horns; (S, TA;) erroneously said in the K to be julRaHN, like sukRarN. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A [woman's camel-vehicle of the kind called] hawodaj that has not a high head or top: (Ibn-Kulthoom, IJ, S, K:) or without a top: (T:) or one that is of a square form: (As, IJ:) pl. OajolaAHN↓, (S, IJ,) like as OaEozaAlN is pl. of OaEozalu; a very rare form of pl. of a sing. of the measure OafoEalu. (IJ.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A flat roof not surrounded by a wall or anything else to prevent persons' falling from it. (IAth, K.) ― -b5- qaroyapN jaloHaMCu (tropical:) A town having no fortress: (A, TA:) pl. qurFI juloHN: the fortresses being likened to horns. (TA.) ― -b6- OakamapN jaloHaMCu (assumed tropical:) [A hill] not having a pointed summit. (TA.) And haDobapN jaloHaMCu (assumed tropical:) [A] smooth [hill]. (A.) ― -b7- OaroDN jaloHaMCu (assumed tropical:) A land in which are no trees. (TA.) ― -b8- yawomN OajolaHu (assumed tropical:) A hard, distressing, or calamitous, day; as also OaSolaEu. (A, TA.)

OajolaAHN c
OajolaAHN: see OajolaHu.

UijoliyHN AjlyH
UijoliyHN A plant of which the upper parts have been eaten. (TA.)

mujalRaHN mjlH
mujalRaHN Eaten: (S, K:) eaten until nothing of it is left: (S:) herbage so eaten. (TA.)

mujalRiHN mjlH
mujalRiHN A man (S) who eats much; a great eater; voracious. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also mijolaAHN. ― -b3- sanapN mujalRiHapN A year of drought, barrenness, or death. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Insolent and audacious. (L.) You say, fulaAnN waqiHN mujalRiHN [Such a one is impudent, insolent, and audacious]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- A bold wolf. (TA.)

mijolaAHN mjlAH
mijolaAHN A she-camel (S) that bears with hardiness a severe year, preserving her milk; (S, K;) as also mujalRiHapN↓. (L.) ― -b2- See also mujaAliHN.

majoluwHN mjlwH
majoluwHN A tree having the head, or upper part, eaten. (L.) ― -b2- A plant, or tree, that has been eaten and has grown again. (TA.)

mujaAliHN mjAlH
mujaAliHN i. q. mukaAbirN [Contending with another for superiority in greatness; &c.: see its verb, 3]. (S.) ― -b2- The lion. (K.) ― -b3- A she-camel that yields
milk abundantly in winter: (S, K:) or that crops the twigs of the dry trees in winter, in a year of drought, and becomes fat upon them, and so preserves her milk: (IAar, TA:) pl. majaAliyHu↓: (S, K:) or this is pl. of mujaAliHN and mijolaAHN↓ as epithets applied to a palm-tree and a she-camel that cares not for the want of rain. (AHn, TA.) And mujaAlaHapN A she-camel that eats the samur and EurofuT, whether they have leaves upon them or not. (TA.)

majaAliyHu mjAlyH
majaAliyHu: see mujaAliHN. ― -b2- Also Years of drought that carry off, or destroy, the cattle. (S, K.)

1 jaladahu jld jldh jldp
1. jaladahu, (S, A, Mgh, &c.,) aor.
jalida
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. jalodN, (S, Mgh, Msb,) He hit, or hurt, his skin; (S, K;) like as you say, raOasahu, and baTanahu: (S:) he beat his skin: (Mgh:) he beat him; namely, a criminal: (Msb:) he struck him with a whip, and with a sword: (TA:) he flogged him (A, K) with a whip, (K,) or with whips: (A:) jaladotu is sometimes written and pronounced jaladRu. (MF on the letter d.) You say, jaladahu AlHadRa, inf. n. as above, He inflicted upon him the flogging ordained by the law. (S, L.) ― -b2- jaladati AlHayRapu The serpent bit: (K:) or, accord. to some, one says of the serpent called Oasowadu, specially, yajolidu bicanabihi [it strikes with its tail]. (TA.) ― -b3- jalada jaAriyatahu, (K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) (tropical:) He lay with his young woman, or female slave. (K, TA.) [Hence,] jalada Eumayorapa [(assumed tropical:) i. q. nakaHa Alyada], a metonymical phrase: jalodu Eumayorapa meaning AlxaDoxaDapu, and AlAisotimonaMCu biAlyadi, also termed AltRadoliylu, and AlAiEotimaAru: the similar act of a woman is termed AlUiloTaAfu. (Har p. 572.) ― -b4- jalada bihi AlOaroDa He smote the ground with him; (TA;) he threw him down prostrate on the ground. (A, TA.) And julida bihi He fell down (K, TA) upon the ground by reason of much sleepiness; as also julida bihi nuwomFA. (TA.) kunotu OataXadRadu fayujoladu biI, in a trad., means [I used to exert my strength, or energy, but] sleep would overcome me so that I fell down. (L.) ― -b5- jaladahu EalaI AlOamori (tropical:) He compelled him against his will to do the thing. (A, K.) ― -b6- yujoladu bikulRi xayorK (or, as related by AHát, yjlc, with c, TA) (tropical:) He is imagined to possess every good quality. (A, K.) But the saying of EshSháfi'ee kaAna mujaAlidN yujoladu means (assumed tropical:) Mujálid used to be pronounced a liar, (K, TA,) or suspected and accused of lying. (TA.) ＝ -A2- julidati AlOaroDu, (S, L, Msb,) the verb being in the pass. form, (Msb,) or jalidat, (A, K,) a verb of the same form as fariHa; (K;) [or both may be correct, like Duribat and Daribat in the same sense;] and Oajoladat↓; (K;) [but this last I believe to be a mistake for Oujolidat, like OuDoribat;] The land was, or became, affected or smitten, by hoar-frost, or rime. (S, A, L, Msb, K.) And jld Albaqolu [in the TA jalida] The herbs, or leguminous plants, were, or became, affected, or smitten, thereby. (L, TA.) And OujoliduwA↓ They (men) were, or became, affected, or smitten, thereby. (L, K.) ＝ -A3- jaluda, aor.
jaluda
, inf. n. jalaAdapN and juluwdapN and jaladN (or this last is a simple subst., L) and majoluwdN, (an inf. n. like maHoluwfN and maEoquwlN, (S, or from tajalRada, M in art. Esr,) He (a man, S, L) was, or became, hardy, strong, sturdy, (S, * L, K, *) and enduring, or patient. (L.)

2 jlRd jld
2. jlRd, (IAar, T, S, Mgh,) inf. n. tajoliydN, (T, S, Mgh, K,) He skinned a camel (IAar, T, S, Mgh, K) that had been slaughtered: (S, K:) one seldom uses salaxa thus [in relation to a camel]. (S.) ― -b2- Also He covered a thing with skin; as, for instance, a pair of socks, or stockings: (Mgh:) and in like manner, [he bound] a book: (A, K: *) and he clad a young camel in the skin of another young camel: (L: [see jaladN:]) thus the verb bears two contr. significations. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- [He ordered to be flogged. (Freytag's Lex.: but without any indication of an authority.)] ＝ -A3- [He, or it, rendered a man hardy, strong, sturdy, and enduring, or patient: so in the present day.]

3 jAldhu jAld jAldh jAldp
3. jAldhu He contended with him in fight, whether the fight were with swords or not. (A in art. Trd.) You say, jAldhu biAlsRayofi, (L,) inf. n. mujaAladapN (S, A, L) and jilaAdN, (A, L,) He contended with him in fight with the sword. (S, * A, L.) And jaAladuwhumo biAlsRuyuwfi They contended with them in fight with swords. (A.) And jAldwA biAlsRuyuwfi, (K, TA,) and tjAldwA↓ (S, A, L, and so in the CK instead of jAldwA) bAlsywf, (S,) and AjtldwA↓, (S, A, L,) They contended, one with another, in fight with swords. (S, A, * L, K.) ― -b2- [See also HaADarahu.]

4 Ajldhu Uilayohi Ajldh Alyh Ajldh Alyp
4. Ajldhu Uilayohi (assumed tropical:) He constrained, compelled, or necessitated, him to have recourse to, or betake himself to, him, or it: (so in some copies of the K:) or he made him to stand in need of, or to want, him, or it. (AA, L, and so in some copies of the K and in the TA.) ＝ -A2- Oajoladati AlOaroDu [or Oujolidat]: and OujoliduwA: see 1.

5 tjlRd Ojld jld tjld
5. tjlRd He affected hardiness, strength, sturdiness, and endurance, or patience; constrained himself to behave with hardiness, &c. (S, * A, * L, K. *) So in the phrase tjlRd lilXRaAmitiyna [He constrained himself to behave with hardiness, &c., to those who rejoiced at his misfortune]. (A, TA.) In the phrase tjlRd Eanohu [He constrained himself to endure with hardiness and patience the loss, or want, of him, or it], the verb is made trans. by means of En because it implies the meaning of taSabRara. (L.) ― -b2- Also He feigned, or made a show of, hardiness, strength, sturdiness, and endurance, or patience. (L.)

6 tajaAolada
6: see 3.

8 Uijotalada
8: see 3. ＝ -A2- Ajtld AlUinaMCa, (AZ, TA,) or maAfiI AlUinaMCi, (K,) He drank all that was in the vessel; (AZ, K, TA;) as also AHtld. (AZ, TA.)

jalodN jld
jalodN (sometimes pronounced jaDodN, S) and jaliydN↓, (applied to a man, S, A, Mgh,) Hardy, strong, sturdy, (S, * A, * L, K, *) and enduring, or patient: (L:) not baliyd [q. v.]: (Mgh:) pl. [of either] julodN, (S, L, K,) or juludN, (so in some copies of the K,) and juladaMCu and OajolaAdN [a pl. of pauc.] (S, L, K) and jilaAdN. (K.) And [the fem.] jalodapN A hardy and strong she-camel; strong to labour and to journey; that heeds not the cold: and also swift: pl. jalodaAtN: (L:) and a she-camel that yields a copious flow of milk: (Th, TA:) sing. of jilaAdN, (S,) which signifies she-camels abounding with milk; as also majaAliydu, (K,) pl. of mijolaAdN↓; (TA;) or she-camels having neither milk nor young: (K:) [see also jaladN:] or she-camels that yield the most greasy, or unctuous, sort of milk: and so the sing., jldp, applied to a ewe or a she-goat. (S.) jilaAdN (pl. of jalodapN, TA) is also applied to palm-trees, meaning Large, hard, hardy, or strong: (S, K, TA:) or such as are not affected by drought. (TA.) And tamorapN jalodapN signifies A tough-skinned, excellent, date; as also jilodapN↓: and a hard, compact, date. (L.)

jilodN jld
jilodN, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) the only form of the word mentioned by the generality of the lexicographers; (TA;) occurring at the end of a verse with kesr to the second as well as the first letter, jilidN↓, agreeably with a license allowed to a poet in such a case, to give to a quiescent letter in a rhyme the same vowel as that which the preceding letter has; (S;) and jaladN↓, (IAar, S, K,) like XibohN and XabahN, and mivolN and mavalN; but this is said by ISk to be unknown; (S;) The skin of any animal; (K;) the integument of the body and limbs of an animal: (Az, Msb:) or the exterior of the baXarapN [or upper skin] of an animal: (Msb: [but this is a strange explanation:]) pl. juluwdN (S, Msb, K) and (sometimes, Msb) OajolaAdN [a pl. of pauc.]. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- [The pl.] OajolaAdN signifies also, and tajaAliydu↓ likewise, The body and limbs (S, A, L) of a man; (S;) the whole person, or body and limbs, of a human being; (L, K;) and his self: (L:) so called because enclosed by the skin: pl. of the former, OajaAlidu. (L.) You say, maA OaXobaha OajolaAdahu biOajolaAdi Oabiyhi How like are his person and body to the person and body of his father! (L.) And fulaAnN EaZiymu AlOajolaAdi and AltRajaAliydi↓ (A, L) Such a one is large and strong (L) in respect of the body and limbs. (A, L.) And rudRuwA AlOayomaAna EalaI OajolaAdihimo Repeat ye the oaths to the persons, themselves: occurring in a trad.: said on the occasion of a man's entering among others of whom an oath had been demanded. (L.) ― -b3- Aljilodu also signifies (assumed tropical:) The penis. (Fr, L, K: but in the CK, in this sense, it is written Aljalodu.) Agreeably with this explanation, its pl. juluwd is said by Fr to be used in the Kur xli. 20: (L:) or as meaning the pudenda: (L, K:) but ISd holds that this word there means the skins, with which, as in manual operations, acts of disobedience are performed. (L.)

jaladN jld
jaladN: see jilodN. ― -b2- Also The skin of a camel,
or other beast, with which another beast is clothed: (L:) the skin of a young camel, which (being stripped off, S) is put over the body of another young camel, in order that the mother of the skinned young one (smelling it, S) may conceive an affection for it [and suckle it]: (S, K:) or the skin of a young camel, which is stuffed with panic grass (vumaAm), (K, TA,) or some other plant, (TA,) and put before a she-camel, in order that she may be induced thereby to affect that which is not her young one [and so yield her milk], (K, TA,) or, to affect the young one of another. (L, TA.) ＝ -A2- A ewe or she-goat whose young one dies at the time of her bringing it forth; as also jaladapN↓: pl. [of the former] jilaAdN and [of the latter] jaladaAtN. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, [as a coll. gen. n.,] Great she-camels, having neither young ones nor milk; n. un. with p: (S:) [see also jalodN:] or great camels, among which are no little ones; (K;) n. un. with p: (TA:) and (app. as a quasipl. n., TA) sheep or goats, and camels, having neither young ones nor milk; (K;) app. meaning having no little ones to which they give such: (Mohammad Ibn-El-Mukarram, TA:) or she-camels having no young ones with them, so that they endure patiently the heat and cold: (Fr, TA:) or she-camels having no milk, and the young ones of which have gone away from them; including what are called banaAtu AllRabuwni, and such as are above these in age; and also such as are called maxaASN, and EiXaArN, and HiyaAlN; but when they have given birth to their young, they cease to be termed jaladN, and are called EiXaArN, and liqaAHN: the pl. is OajolaAdN and [pl. pl.] OajaAliydu. (Az, TA.) ＝ -A3- Hard ground; as also Oajoladu↓: (S:) or hard and level ground; as also jaladapN↓: (K:) or level but rough ground; (L;) as also Oajoladu↓: (TA:) pl. (of the former, TA) OajolaAdN and (of the latter, TA) OajaAlidu. (S, TA.) You also say OaroDN jaladN, with fet-h to the l; (AHn, TA;) and jalodapN↓, with a quiescent l; (Lth, AHn, TA;) and ArD jaladapN↓ also; and makaAnN jaladN. (Lth, TA.) ＝ -A4- Also, as a subst. or an inf. n., (L, [see jaluda,]) Hardiness, strength, sturdiness, (S, * A, * L, K, *) and endurance, or patience. (T.)

jilidN jld
jilidN: see jilodN.

jalodapN jld jldh jldp
jalodapN: see jaladN.

jilodapN jld jldh jldp
jilodapN a more particular term than jilodN; (S, L;) signifying A piece, or portion, of skin. (L.) ― -b2- One says also jilodapu AlEayoni [app. meaning The eyelid]. (TA.) ― -b3- And qawomN mino jilodatinaA A people, or company of men, of ourselves, and of our kinsfolk. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jalodN.

jaladapN jld jldh jldp
jaladapN: see jaladN, in three places.

jaliydN jlyd
jaliydN A woman flogged with a whip; as also with p: pl. jalodaI and jalaAYidu: (Lh, L:) the former pl. thought by ISd to be of the former sing.; and the latter, of the latter. (L.) ＝ -A2- Hoarfrost, or rime; i. e. dew that falls (S, A, K) from the sky (S) upon the ground (S, A, K) and congeals; (S, K;) also called DariybN and saqiyTN; (S;) like SaqiyEN. (Msb.) ― -b2- Congealed, or frozen, water; ice. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also jalodN.

julayodapN jlyd jlydh jlydp
julayodapN [dim. of jilodapN] One of the TabaqaAt [coats, or tunics,] of the eye. (TA.)

juluwdiIRN jlwd jlwdI jlwdy jlwdyy
juluwdiIRN [A dealer in skins;] a rel. n. from juluwdN, pl. of jilodN. (TA.)

jalRaAdN jlAd
jalRaAdN One whose office it is to flog others with a whip. (Mgh.) [In the present day, An executioner, in a general sense.]

Oajoladu c
Oajoladu: see jaladN, in two places.

tajaAliydu tjAlyd
tajaAliydu: see jilodN, in two places.

mijoladN mjld
mijoladN A piece of skin which a wailing woman holds in her hand, and with which she slaps (S, K) her face (S) or her cheek: (K:) pl. majaAliydu; (Kr, K;) or, as ISd thinks, this is pl. of mijolaAdN↓ [as syn. with mijoladN], for mifoEalN and mifoEaAlN are often interchangeable as measures of words of this kind. (TA.)

mujalRadN mjld
mujalRadN Covered with skin: thus applied to a pair of socks, or stockings, meaning having skin put upon the upper and lower parts. (Mgh.) [A book, or portion of a book, bound: ― -b2- and hence, A volume: pl. mujalRadaAtN.] ― -b3- A bone covered only by the skin; having nothing remaining on it but the skin. (K.) ＝ -A2- A horse [rendered hardy and enduring;] that is not frightened by, (K,) or not impatient at, (S, and so in some copies of the K,) being beaten (S, K) with the whip. (TA.) ＝ -A3- A certain quantity of a burden, or load, of known measure and weight; (K;) six hundred pounds' weight. (IAar, TA in art. bhr.)

mujalRidN mjld
mujalRidN One who binds books, or covers them with skin. (K.)

mijolaAdN mjlAd
mijolaAdN: see mijoladN: ＝ -A2- and see also jalodN.

majoluwdN mjlwd
majoluwdN [Having his skin hit, hurt, or beaten: flogged: &c.: see also jaliydN]. ＝ -A2- OaroDN majoluwdapN Land affected, or smitten, by hoar-frost, or rime. (S, A, L, Msb, K.) ＝ -A3- majoluwdN is also an inf. n. of jaluda [q. v.]. (S, L, K.)

mujotaladN mjtld
mujotaladN A place of contending in fight with swords. (L from a trad.)

1 jalasa jls
1. jalasa, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
jalisa
, (A, K,) inf. n. juluwsN (S, A, Msb, K) and majolasN↓, (S, A, K,) He placed his seat, or posteriors, upon rugged [or rather elevated] ground, such as is termed jalosN: this is the primary signification: (TA:) [and hence,] He sat; i. q. qaEada [when the latter is used in its largest sense]: (Msb, and so S and L and A and K in art. qEd:) you say, jalasa mutarabRiEFA and qaEada mutarabRiEFA [He sat cross-legged]: (Msb:) accord. to El-Fárábee and others, contr. of qaAma; and thus it has a more common application than qaEada [when the latter is used in its most proper and restricted sense]: (Msb:) but qaEada also signifies the contr. of qaAma: ('Orweh Ibn-Zubeyr, L in art. qEd:) properly speaking, jalasa differs from qaEada; the former signifying he sat up; or sat after sleeping, or prostration, (Msb,) or after lying on his side; (B, TA;) and the latter, he sat down; or sat after standing: (Msb, B, TA: and see other authorities to the same effect in art. qEd:) for juluwsN is a change of place from low to high, and quEuwdN is a change of place from high to low: and one says, jalasa mutRakiYFA, but not qaEada mutRakiYFA, meaning [He sat] leaning, or reclining, upon one side: (Msb:) but both these verbs sometimes signify he was, or became: and thus, [it is said,] jalasa mutarabRiEFA and faEada mutarabRiEFA signify he was, or became, cross-legged: and jalasa bayona XuEabihaA AlOarobaEi in like manner signifies he was, or became, [between her four limbs,] (El-Fárábee, Msb,) because the man, in this case, is resting upon his own four limbs. (Msb.) [jalasa maEahu and jalasa Uilayohi, like xalaA mEh and xlA Alyh, signify the same; i. e. He sat with him: or the latter, he sat by him; like “ assedit ei. ”] An instance of the inf. n. majolasN is found in a trad., in which it is said, faUicaA Oatayotumo UilaI Almajolisi faOaEoTuwA AlTRariyqa HaqRahu [But when ye come to sitting, perform ye the duties relating to the road]. (TA.) [The trad. commences thus: UiyRaAkumo waAljuluwsa EalaI AlTRuruqaAti Beware ye of sitting on the roads: and then, after the words before cited, (in which, however, in my copy of the Jámi' es-Sagheer, instead of Almjls, I find AlmajaAlisi, which is pl. of Almajolisu,) it is added that the duties thus alluded to are the lowering of the eyes, the putting away or aside what is hurtful or annoying, the returning of salutations, the enjoining of that which is good, and the forbidding of that which is evil.] ― -b2- jalasati AlrRaxamapu (tropical:) The aquiline vulture lay upon its breast on the ground; syn. javamat: a saying applied to him who is of the seceders. (A, TA.) [See also qaEada.] ― -b3- jalasa also signifies (assumed tropical:) It (a thing, as, for instance, a plant,) remained, or continued. (AHn, TA.) ― -b4- Also, (aor.
jalisa
, inf. n. jalosN, TA,) He came to Aljalos, (TA,) or [the high country called] Nejd: (T, S, A, TA:) and in like manner said of a cloud; it came to Nejd. (TA.)

3 jAlshu jAls jAlsh jAlsp
3. jAlshu, inf. n. mujaAlasapN and jilaAsN, [He sat with him.] (TA.) You say, laA tujaAliso mano laA tujaAniso [Sit not with him with whom thou wilt not be congenial]. (A, TA.) And kariymu AlnRiHaAsi TayRiybu AljilaAsi [Generous in origin, or disposition; pleasant to sit with;] is said of a man. (TA.)

4 Ajlshu Ojls Ojlsh Ajlsh Ajlsp
4. Ajlshu [He seated him; made him to sit: or he made him to sit up]: (S, K, TA:) he gave him place, or settled him, (makRanahu,) in sitting. (TA.)

6 tjAslwA tjAslwA
6. tjAslwA [They sat together; one with another;] (S, A, TA;) fiI AlmajaAlisi [in the sittingplaces]. (S.)

10 Astjlshu Astjlsh Astjlsp
10. Astjlshu [He asked him, or desired him, to sit: or to sit up.]. You say, raMniI qaAYimFA faQsotajolasaniI [He saw me standing, and he asked me, or desired me, to sit]: (A, TA:) but this is at variance with what we have mentioned in the beginning of the art., respecting the distinction [between jalasa and qaEada]. (TA.)

jalosN jls
jalosN Rugged ground or land: (S, K:) this is the primary signification. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also, app., Elevated ground or land:] a place elevated and hard: or, as some say, a tract of land extending widely. (Ham p. 688.) ― -b3- [And hence,] Aljalosu What is elevated above the gawor [or low country]: (TA:) applied especially to the country of Nejd. (T, S, M, K.) ＝ -A2- [Persons sitting: or sitting up:] a quasi-pl. n., accord. to Sb, or a pl., accord. to Akh, of jaAlisN↓: said to be used as sing. and pl. and fem. and masc.; but this assertion is of no account: (ISd, L:) or the people of a majolis: (Lh, ISd, L, K:) [juluwsN↓ is also a pl. of jaAlisN↓; like as bukiIRN, originally bukuwIN, is of baAki: or it is an inf. n. used as an epithet: see jaAvK:)] you say qawomN juluwsN [a company of men sitting: or sitting up]. (S.) [See also majolisN.] ― -b2- Also A woman who sits in the finaMC [or court of the house], not quitting it: (K:) or she who is of noble rank (K, TA) among her people. (TA.)

jilosN jls
jilosN: see jaliysN, in two places.

jalosapN jlsh jlsp
jalosapN A single sitting: or sitting up. (Msb.)

jilosapN jlsh jlsp
jilosapN A mode or manner, (TA,) kind, (Msb,) or state, (S, A, Msb,) of sitting: or of sitting up. (S, * A, * Msb, K. *) You say, huwa Hasanu Aljilosapi [He has a good mode, &c., of sitting]. (A, Msb, K.)

julasapN jlsh jlsp
julasapN A man (S) who sits much; sedentary. (S, K.)

juluwsN jlws
juluwsN: see jalosN.

jaliysN jlys
jaliysN (S, A, Msb, K) and jilRiysN↓ (TA, as found in a copy of the K, [but this is an intensive form,]) and jilosN↓ (S, A, K) A companion with whom one sits: (A, Msb, K:) fem. of the first with p: (TA:) and pl. [of the same] julasaMCu (A, K) and [irreg., being by rule pl. of jaAlisN,] julRaAsN. (K.) You say, huwa jilosiI↓ and jaliysiI [He is my companion with whom I sit]; like as you say, huwa xidoniI and xadiyniI. (S.)

jilRiysN jlys
jilRiysN: see jaliysN.

jaAlisN jAls
jaAlisN: see jalosN, in two places. ― -b2- Also A man, and a cloud, coming to [the high country called] Nejd. (TA.) You say, raOayotuhumo yaEoduwna jaAlisiyna I saw them running, coming to Nejd. (A, TA.)

majolasN mjls
majolasN: see 1: ― -b2- and see majolisN.

majolisN mjls
majolisN A sitting-place; (S, Msb, K;) as also ↓with p; (Fr, Lh, Sgh, K;) similar to makaAnN and makaAnapN: (Sgh, TA:) [a place where persons sit together and converse; a sitting-room:] a thing upon which one sits: (MF:) some make a strange distinction between majolisN and majolasN↓, asserting the former to be applied to the chamber or house (bayot) [in which people sit]; and the latter, to a place of honour upon which it is forbidden to sit without permission; but the former is the only correct form of the two: (MF, TA:) pl. majaAlisu. (S, Msb.) You say, Aurozuno fiI majolisika and majolisatika↓ [Be thou grave] in thy sitting-place. (Fr, Sgh.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The people of a majolis; (Msb, TA;) elliptical, for Oaholu majolisK: (TA:) an assembly, or a company of men, sitting [together]: (Th, TA:) not well explained as being, with the article Al, syn. with AlnRaAsu: (TA:) persons sitting, or sitting up. (A, TA.) [See also jalosN.] You say, AinofaDRa Almajolisu (assumed tropical:) [The assembly of persons sitting together broke up]. (Msb.) And raOayotuhumo majolisFA I saw them sitting. (A, TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) An oration or a discourse, or an exhortation, (xuTobapN Oawo EiZapN,) delivered in a majolis; like maqaAmapN. (Mtr, in the Preface to Har.) ― -b4- It is also used in the same manner as HaDorap and janaAb: you say majolisu fulaAnK [meaning (assumed tropical:) The object of resort, with whom others sit and converse, such a one]; like HaDorapu fulaAnK. (Kull p. 146.) [See arts. HDr and jnb. But this usage I believe to be post-classical.] ― -b5- [Also (assumed tropical:) A stool; meaning, an evacuation. So in medical books.]

majolisapN mjls mjlsh mjlsp
majolisapN: see majolisN, in two places.

jalosadN jlsd
jalosadN and Aljalosadu: see art. jsd

1 jalafahu jlf jlfh jlfp
1. jalafahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jalufa
, inf. n. jalofN, (S, Msb,) He peeled, pared, stripped, or scraped, it off; (S, Msb, K, TA;) namely, a thing; (TA;) as, for instance, (S, TA,) the mud, or clay, (S, Msb, TA,) from the head of a [jar of the kind called] danR. (S, TA.) You say also, jalafa Zuforahu Eano UiSobaEihi He stripped off his nail from his finger. (Lth, TA.) And accord. to some, jalofN signifies The scraping off, or stripping off, the skin with somewhat of the flesh: and the act of pulling, or drawing, out, or up, or off; or displacing. (TA.) ― -b2- Also i. q. jarafahu [He took away, carried away, or removed, the whole of it, or the greater part of it, or much of it; or he swept it away]: (K:) or, as some say, jalofN signifies a more intensive and more exterminating action than jarofN. (TA.) ― -b3- And He cut it off; (S;) or pulled it, or plucked it, out, or up; or eradicated, or uprooted, it; (K;) and exterminated it; (S, K;) as also Ajtlfhu↓. (K.) ― -b4- jalafahu biAlsRayofi He struck him with the sword: (K:) or he cut, or cut a piece from, or cut in pieces, his flesh [with the sword]. (A, TA.) ― -b5- julifa AlnRabaAtu The herbage was eaten to the uttermost. (TA.) ― -b6- julifa fiI maAlihi jalofapF He suffered the loss of somewhat of his property, or cattle. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jalifa, aor.
jalafa
, inf. n. jalafN and jalaAfapN, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, rude in disposition, or in make; coarse, or churlish. (K.)

2 jalRafatohu AlsRinuwna jlfth Alsnwn
2. jalRafatohu AlsRinuwna The years of drought, or barrenness, or dearth, destroyed his cattle. (S.) And jalRafato kaHolu, (S,) or kaHolN, (K,) The year of drought, or barrenness, or dearth, exterminated the cattle. (K.) And OamowaAlahumo Ajtlfto↓ [It destroyed their cattle] is also said of a year of great drought, or barrenness, or dearth. (S.) And AldRahoru Ajtlfhu↓ Time, or fortune, or misfortune, destroyed his property, or cattle. (TA.)

4 Ajlf Ojlf Ajlf jlf
4. Ajlf He (a man) removed the julaAf [or clay] from the head of the [jar called] xunobujap [i. q. danR]. (IAar, K.)

8 Uijotalafa
8: see 1; and see also 2, in two places.

jilofN jlf
jilofN A [jar of the kind called] danR: (M, K:) or an empty danR: (AO, S, Msb, K:) this is said (S, Msb) by AO (S) to be the primary signification of the word: (S, Msb:) or the lower part of a danR when it is broken: (ISd, Sgh, K:) and a [receptacle such as is called] Zarof, (AA, S, Hr, Msb, K, [in the CK, erroneously, Tarof,]) and wiEaMC, (AA, S, Msb, K,) of any kind, (AA, S, Msb,) such as a saddle-bag, or pair of saddlebags, and a sack, in which bread or other food is kept: (Hr, TA:) pl. [of mult.] juluwfN (S, M, Msb) and [of pauc.] OajolaAfN and OajolufN, which last is rare. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also A [skin of the kind called] ziqR without head and without legs. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- And A skinned animal, (AO, S,) or a skinned sheep or goat, (K,) of which the belly has been taken forth, (AO, S, K,) and the head and legs of which have been cut off; (K;) the body of a skinned sheep or goat, without head and without belly and without legs: or, as some say, a body of any kind without a head upon it: (L:) or a beast without fat, and without back [to bear], and without belly to conceive: (IAth, TA:) or the skin of a sheep or goat, and of a camel: (As, Msb:) pl. OajolaAfN (Sb, L) and sometimes OajolufN: (Sb, TA:) and [it is also said that] OajolaAfu AlXRaApi signifies the shinned sheep or goat that is without head and without legs and without belly. (S, Msb.) ― -b4- Hence, i. e., from AjlAf AlXAp, (S, Msb,) (tropical:) Rude in disposition or in make; coarse, or churlish; (S, M, Msb, K;) as also jaliyfN↓; (K;) meaning that the person so termed is empty, without intellect: (M, TA:) applied to a DesertArab, (S,) or to an Arab: (so in a copy of the Msb:) or it is so applied as though meaning one with his skin; not having assumed the gentle and soft habits of the people of the towns or villages or cultivated lands; for when one does this, it is as though he pulled off his skin and clad himself with another: (Msb:) or (tropical:) stupid, foolish, or unsound in intellect; likened to a skinned sheep or goat because of the weakness of his intellect. (IAth, TA.) ― -b5- Also Thick, or coarse, dry bread: or bread not rendered savoury by anything eaten therewith: or the edge [of a cake] of bread. (K.) [See also jilofapN.] ＝ -A2- A male palm-tree, (Lth, K,) with the spadix of which the female palm-tree is fecundated: (Lth, TA:) pl. juluwfN. (TA.) ＝ -A3- A certain well-known bird. (K.)

jalofapN jlf jlfh jlfp
jalofapN [inf. n. of un. of julifa, q. v.]. ＝ -A2- See also jilofapN.

julofapN jlf jlfh jlfp
julofapN A part of a skin that is peeled, pared, stripped, or scraped, off. (L, K.)

jilofapN jlf jlfh jlfp
jilofapN A broken piece of dry bread, (K, TA,) thick, or coarse, (TA,) and without anything to
render it savoury: (K, TA:) pl. jilafN. (TA.) [See jilofN, of which it may be regarded as the n. un.] ― -b2- A piece of anything: (Sgh, K:) pl. as above. (TA.) ― -b3- The portion of a reed for writing that is between its maboraI [or place where the paring is commenced] and its point; as also jalofapN↓. (K.)

julaAfN jlAf
julaAfN Clay; such as is put upon the head of the [jar called] xunobujap. [See 4.] (IAar, K.)

jaliyfN jlyf
jaliyfN Peeled, pared, stripped, or scraped, off; as also majoluwfN↓. (K.) It is said by some that the last word in the following saying of Keys Ibn-El-Khateem,
hazolaI jaraAdi OajowaAfuhu julofu
kaOanRa labRaAtihaA tabadRadahaA
is pl. of the former in this sense: but accord. to ISk, [the meaning of the verse is, As though emaciated locusts without heads and without legs occupied the two sides, or the whole, of the part of her breast where the necklace lay; for he says that] the poet likens the ornaments upon her labRap to locusts without heads and without legs. (TA.) rijolN jaliyfapN [An excoriated leg]. (TA.) ― -b2- jaliyfapN [or sanapN jaliyfapN] A year that destroys the cattle; (S, * K;) as also jaAlifapN↓: (S, K:) any bane, or calamity, that destroys the cattle: pl. jalaAYifu and julufN and julofN. (TA.) You say, OaSaAbatohumo jaliyfapN EaZiymapN A great destruction of their cattle befell them. (S, TA.) And sinuwna jalaAYifu and julufN and julofN Years that destroy the cattle. (K.) And jalaAYifu also signifies Torrents. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jilofN.

jaAlifN jAlf
jaAlifN [act. part. n. of jalafa]. ― -b2- jaAlifapN [or XajRapN jaAlifapN] A wound of the head that peels off the skin with the flesh: (S, K:) or that peels off the skin but does not penetrate into the interior. (Msb.) And TaEonapN jaAlifapN A spear-wound, or the like, that does not penetrate into the interior; (S, K;) opposed to jaAYifapN. (S.) ― -b3- zamaAnN jaAYifN i. q. jaArifN [A time, or season, that sweeps away, or destroys, the cattle]. (TA.) See also jaliyfN.

mujalRafN mjlf
mujalRafN Having a portion, or portions, taken from its sides. (S, K.) ― -b2- Having somewhat thereof remaining. (S, K.) So explained by Abu-l-Ghowth as occurring in the saying of ElFarezdak,
waEaDRu zamaAna yaA Qbona marowaAna lamo yadaEo
mina AlmaAli UilRaA musoHatFA Oawo mujalRafu
i. e., [And a biting of fortune, O Ibn-Marwán, left not, of the cattle, save] such as were destroyed, or they were such as had only a remnant remaining. (S.) ― -b3- A man (S) whose cattle have been destroyed by years of drought, or barrenness, or dearth. (S, K.) And qawomN mujotalafuwna↓ A people, or party, whose cattle have been destroyed by a year of drought or the like. (S, TA.)

majoluwfN mjlwf
majoluwfN: see jaliyfN. ― -b2- Also A skinned sheep or goat. (L.) ― -b3- xubozN majoluwfN Bread burnt by the oven, (K, TA,) so that its outer parts stick to it. (TA.)

qawomN mujotalafuwna qwm mjtlfwn
qawomN mujotalafuwna: see mujalRafN.

mutajalRifN mtjlf
mutajalRifN Lean, or emaciated; (K;) as also mutajarRifN. (TA.)

jawaAliqu jwAlq
jawaAliqu (S, M, MA, Mgh, K) and juwaAliqN (IAar, M, K) and jiwaAliqN (K) A sack; in Pers. juwaAlo; (MA, PS;) [not so well rendered in the KL by xurojiyno, which means a saddle-bag or a pair of saddle-bags, like the Arabic xurojN;] a certain kind of wiEaMCi [or receptacle], (S, M, K,) [for corn &c.,] well known: (M, K:) it has a loop, into which is inserted a stick, or piece of wood, called XiZaAZN, (S and K in art. XZ,) this being also inserted into the loop of another jwAlq, when they are bound upon the camel: (K * and TA in that art.:) or it has two loops, one of which is inserted into the other, (S and K voce qaTaba,) [and then the stick is put through,] on the occasion of putting it on a camel: (TA ibid.:) the word is arabicized; (M, TA;) said to be from kwAlh, (TA,) or kwAlk, (KL,) but correctly from JwAlh, which is Pers.: (TA:) the pl. is jawaAliqu (S, MA, Mgh, K) and jawaAliyqu, (Sb, S, MA, Mgh, K,) the latter occurring in poetry, (TA,) and juwaAliqaAtN (S, K) was sometimes used, (S,) but this is disallowed by Sb. (S, M.) The saying [of a rájiz], cited by Th,
OuHibRu maAwiyRapa HubRFA SaAdiqaA
HubRa OabiI AljuwaAliqi AljuwaAliqaA
[I love Máweeyeh with a true love; with the love of the owner (lit. father) of the sack for the sack;] means that the speaker had a vehement love for the food, or wheat, that was in his jwAlq. (M.) Another says,
yaA HabRacaA maA fiI AljawaAliyqi AlsRuwdo
mino xuXokanaAni wasawiyqK maqonuwdo
[O, lovely is what is in the black sacks, of biscuit and meal of parched barley sweetened with sugarcandy!]. (S.)

1 jalamahu jlm jlmh jlmp
1. jalamahu, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
jalima
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. jalomN, (S, Msb,) He cut it, or cut it off; (S, Msb, K;) [like jaramahu.] ― -b2- He shore it, or sheared it; namely, wool, (Msb, K,) and hair, with the jalamaAni, (Msb,) or jalam. (TA.) And jalamotu minohu I took [or clipped somewhat] from it; namely, wool; like jaramotu. (S in art. jrm.) And jalama AlXRaApa He shore, or sheared, the sheep or goat. (Har p. 190.) ― -b3- jalama Aljazuwra, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He took the flesh that was on the bones of the slaughtered camel; (S, K;) as also Ajtlmhu↓. (K.)

8 Uijotalama
8: see what precedes.

jilomN jlm
jilomN The fat of the varob [or thin integument that covers the stomach and bowels or intestines] of a sheep or goat. (K.)

jalamN jlm
jalamN The instrument with which one shears (S, K, TA) wool and hair: (TA:) and jalamaAni signifies a pair thereof; a pair of shears: (S:) or jalamN and jalamaAni signify alike, i. q. miqoraADN; like as one says miqoraADN and miqoraADaAni, and qalamN and qalamaAni: and jalamaAnN↓ is also allowable, as a sing.; (Msb;) authorized by Ks; (TA;) and in like manner, qalamaAnN. (Msb. [But see miqoraADN.]) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The moon; (Az, K;) as also jayolamN↓: (K:) or the [new moon, or moon when it is termed] hilaAl: (K:) likened to the jalam [as meaning the blade of a pair of shears]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also, probably,] (assumed tropical:) A certain mark of camels, made with a hot iron. (Ibn-Habeeb, K.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] (assumed tropical:) The tick, or ticks. (K.) ― -b5- And, accord. to some, as being likened to these, because of their smallness, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The sheep of Mekkeh: (A'Obeyd, TA:) or certain sheep with long and hairless legs, found at Et-Táïf. (K.) And (assumed tropical:) The male of the gazelle, and of the sheep: pl. jilaAmN. (K.) And (assumed tropical:) A kid: (Kr, K:) pl. as above. (S, TA.)

jalomapN jlm jlmh jlmp
jalomapN The whole of a thing; (S, K;) as also julomapN↓ and jalamapN↓. (K.) You say, Oaxacotu AlXRaIoCa bijalomatihi I took the thing wholly. (S.)

julomapN jlm jlmh jlmp
julomapN: see what next precedes.

jalamapN jlm jlmh jlmp
jalamapN A skinned sheep or goat (S, K) without the intestines and without the legs, (S,) [or] when the shanks and the redundant parts have gone. (K.) And the whole flesh of a slaughtered camel. (S.) ― -b2- See also jalomapN.

jalamaAnN jlmAn
jalamaAnN: see jalamN.

julaAmapN jlAmh jlAmp
julaAmapN Shorn wool. (K.)

julRaAmN jlAm
julRaAmN Shorn he-goats. (K.)

jayolamN jylm
jayolamN: see jalamN.

majoluwmN mjlwm
majoluwmN Cut, or cut off. (Msb.) ― -b2- A shorn sheep or goat. (K, * TA.)

mujotalamN mjtlm
mujotalamN A bone having the flesh cut off with the jalam (TA in art. knt.) Quasi

jalomaHa jlmH
jalomaHa: see Q. Q. 1. in art. jlH.

jalomadN jlmd
jalomadN and julomuwdN↓ Rock: (S, K:) or a rock; or mass, or piece, of rock: (M:) or a round stone: (Mgh, Msb:) or [a stone] smaller than what is termed janodal, of such a size as that which is thrown with a ballista: (L:) or a great stone: (Har p. 95:) or the latter word, [a stone] like the head of a kid; or less, such as may be carried in the hand by grasping its side but over which the two hands will not meet, with which date-stones &c. are bruised, or brayed: (ISh:) [pl. of the former, jalaAmida; and of the latter, jalaAmiydu. Accord. to the Mgh and Msb, the m is an augmentative letter; but most of the lexicographers regard it as radical.] ― -b2- [Hence,] raXaHa jalomaduhu, said of one known to be a niggard, meaning, (assumed tropical:) He gave something. (Har p. 95.) ― -b3- And OaloqaI Ealayohi jalaAmiydahu (assumed tropical:) He threw his weight (viqalahu)
upon him. (K. [See AlqI Elyh mavaAqiylahu, voce mivoqaAlN.]) ― -b4- Also jalomadN, (L,) or jilomidN↓, (K,) A mass of rock rising out of shallow water. (IAar, L, K.) ― -b5- And the former, (assumed tropical:) A strong man; and so jalomadapN↓: (K:) or a man having a strong voice; and so julomudN↓. (L.) ＝ -A2- Also, jalomadN, Many camels: (S:) or camels composing a large herd: or camels advanced in years; as also julomuwdN↓: (K:) and sheep exceeding in number a hundred: (L, K:) you say DaOonN jalomadN. (L.) ― -b2- And Oxen, or cows: (L:) and the same word, (K,) or jalomadapN↓, (AA, L,) a single ox or cow. (AA, L, K.)

julomadN jlmd
julomadN: see above.

jilomidN jlmd
jilomidN: see above.

jalomadapN jlmd jlmdh jlmdp
jalomadapN applied to land (OaroDN) Stony: (K:) and jalaAmidu is [its pl.,] like jaraAwilu. (TA.) ― -b2- See also jalomadN, in two places.

julomuwdN jlmwd
julomuwdN: see jalomadN, in two places.

julRanaArN jlnAr
julRanaArN The flower of the pomegranate: an arabicized word, from GulonaAro, (K,) which is Persian, composed of Gulo “ a flower, ” and naAro “ a pomegranate. ” (MF.) It is said that whoever swallows three grains of it, of the smallest that may be, (K,) on the condition of his taking them with his mouth from the tree, before their opening, at sunrise, on a Wednesday, (Tedhkiret Dáwood, TA,) will not have ophthalmia in that year. (K.)

1 jaliha jl jlh jlp
1. jaliha, aor.
jalaha
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. jalahN, (Sudot;, * Msb, TA,) He was, or became, bald in the fore part of the head: (S, K:) or in the greater part of his head. (Msb.) [The latter seems to be the correct meaning: see jalahN below.] ― -b2- jalihato saAHatuhu His court, or yard, was, or became, vacant, or void. (JK.) ＝ -A2- jalaha, (S, K,) aor.
jalaha
, (K,) inf. n. jalohN, (TA,) He uncovered a thing; or removed it [from a thing that it covered or concealed]. (K, TA.) ― -b2- He raised the turban, while folding it, from the side of his forehead (Eano jabiynihi), (K, TA,) [like AijotalaI,] and from the fore part of his head. (TA.) ― -b3- He removed the pebbles from a place. (S, K.) ― -b4- He turned back a person from a difficult, or hard, thing or affair. (K.)

jalahN jl jlh jlp
jalahN, (JK, S,) or jalohapN↓, (K,) Baldness in the fore part of the head; (S, K;) which is the beginning of SalaEN; like jalaHN: (S:) or baldness of the greater part of the head; (Msb;) more than jalaHN, (JK,) and more than SalaEN, which is more than jalaHN. (Msb in art. jlH.)

jalohapN jlhh jlhp
jalohapN: see jalahu. ＝ -A2- Also The part that faces one of the brows, or brinks, or edges, of a valley: (S:) or the side of a valley; (K, TA;) the bank, or border, thereof: (TA:) or elevated parts in the interior, or lower part, of a valley, rising above the water-course, so that, when the valley flows with water, the water does not reach them: (ISh, TA:) and, some say, the mouth of a valley: and some, a part of a valley uncovered by the torrents, and so made apparent: (TA:) and [the dual] jalohataAni, (JK, M, TA,) or jalohataA waAdK, (S,) the two sides, or borders, of a valley, (S, M, TA,) when there is in them hardness: (JK, M, TA:) occurring in a trad., or, as some relate it, jalohamataAni↓, with an augmentative m: (TA:) pl. jilaAhN. (S.) ― -b2- A great round rock. (JK, K.) ― -b3- A large [hill, or the like, such as is called] qaArapN; as also jalohamapN↓, with an augmentative m. (TA.) ― -b4- The place of alighting and abiding of a people, or company of men: (JK, K, TA:) and a yard, or wide space, in front, or extending from the sides, of their dwelling. (JK.) ― -b5- And A meadow in which water collects and stagnates: pl. as above. (JK.) ＝ -A3- Dates, (K, TA,) of which the stones have been picked out, (TA,) macerated and mashed with milk, (K, * TA,) then given to drink to women; (TA;) having a fattening property; (K, TA;) as also jaliyhapN↓. (K.)

jalohamapN jlhmh jlhmp
jalohamapN: see jalohapN, in two places.

jalahiyRapN jlhyh jlhyp
jalahiyRapN A mode of wearing the turban, in which the jabiyn [or side of the forehead] is uncovered, so that the part where the hair grows is seen. (JK, Sgh.)

jaliyhapN jlyhh jlyhp
jaliyhapN A place from which the pebbles have been removed. (JK, S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also jalohapN, last sentence.

Oajolahu c
Oajolahu Bald in the fore part of the head; (S;) i. q. OajolaHu: (TA:) or [it denotes more than the latter; meaning] bald in the greater part of the head: fem. jalohaMCu: pl. julohN. (Msb.) [See jalahN.] ― -b2- Large in the forehead, having the places of growth of the hair receding. (K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A bull having no horn; (Ks, JK, S, K;) like OajolaHu. (Ks, S.)

majoluwhN mjlwh mjlwp mjly
majoluwhN A tent, or house, or chamber, (bayotN,) in which is neither door nor curtain. (JK, K.)

julaAhiqN jlAhq
julaAhiqN Bullets, syn. bunoduqN, (S, Msb, K,) or rounded things, (En-Nadr, TA,) made of clay, (En-Nadr, Msb, TA,) which one shoots [from a cross-bow]: (K:) n. un. with p: (En-Nadr, Msb, TA:) a Persian word, arabicized; (Msb;) in Persian julaho, meaning “ a ball of thread; ” pl. julahaA; applied also to “ a weaver; ” (S K;) i. e., jlhA is so applied. (TA.) Hence, qawosu AljulaAhiqi [The cross-bow for shooting bullets]. (S, Msb.)

jalohamapN jlhmh jlhmp
jalohamapN: see art. jlh.

1 jalaA jl jlA
1. jalaA, (S, Mgh, Msb,) [aor.
jaluwa
,] inf. n. jalaMCN, (Msb,) It (a thing, and (assumed tropical:) an affair, or a case, Mgh, or (assumed tropical:) information, or tidings, Msb,) was, or became, clear, unobscured, exposed to view, displayed, laid open, disclosed, or uncovered, (Mgh, Msb,) llinRaAsi to men, or the people; (Msb;) as also tjlRI↓, said of a thing: (S, Mgh, Msb:) it ((assumed tropical:) information, or tidings, S, Msb, or (assumed tropical:) an affair, or a case, Mgh,) was, or became, apparent, or plainly apparent, overt, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, plain, obvious, or evident, (S, Mgh, Msb,) liI to me, (S,) or lilnRaAsi to men, or the people. (Msb.) One says, AlXRamosu tjlRt↓ The sun became unobscured, or exposed to view, and ceased to be eclipsed. (TA from a trad.) Er-Rághib says that waAlnRahaAri UicaA tajalRaI↓ is sometimes by the thing itself; as in the phrase [in the Kur xcii. 2], falamRaA tajalRaI rabRuhu lilojabali [By the day when it becometh clear, &c.]: and sometimes, by the case, and the action; as in the saying [in the Kur vii. 139], falamRaA tajalRaI rabRuhu lilojabali [And when his Lord became manifested to the mountain]: Zj says that the meaning in this instance is, appeared, and so say the Sunnees; El-Hasan says that the meaning is, tjlRI biAlnRuwri AlEaroXi [became manifested by light, the light of the empyrean]. (TA.) ― -b2- jalaA, [aor.
jaluwa
,] inf. n. jalaMCN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jalowN; (K;) and AjlI↓; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) He, (a man, Msb,) or they, (a company of men, Mgh, Msb,) went forth, or emigrated, (S, Mgh, Msb,) Eani Albaladi from the country, or town, (S, Msb,) and Eano OawoTaAnihimo from their homes: (S, Mgh:) [like jalRa:] or they (a company of men) dispersed themselves, or became dispersed, Eani AlmawoDiEi, and minohu, from the place: (K:) or jlA means, in consequence of fear: and AjlI↓, in consequence of drought: (AZ, K:) or manozilahumo OajolawoA↓ signifies they left their place of abode in consequence of fear; the verb in this case being trans. by itself: but if they have left for some other reason than fear, you say, Eano manozilihimo: (Msb:) accord. to IAar, jalaA signifies he fled, being driven away, from his home. (TA.) [See also 12.] ― -b3- jaliIa, aor.
jalawa
, inf. n. jalFA, He had that degree of baldness which is termed jalFA↓; (K;) i. e. baldness of the fore part of the head; (S, K;) like jalahN: (S:) or baldness of half of the head; (S, K;) which is the beginning of SalaEN: (S:) or baldness less than what is termed SalaEN. (K.) And jalA Aljabiyni, inf. n. jalFA, signifies the same as jaliIa [The part above the temple became bald]. (A'Obeyd, TA.) ＝ -A2- jalaAhu, [aor.
jaluwa
, inf. n., app., jilaMCN, or perhaps jalaMCN, but the former seems to be indicated by what follows;] (S, Mgh, Msb;) and jlRAhu↓; (MA;) He made it, or rendered it, clear, or unobscured; exposed it to view, displayed it, laid it open, disclosed it, or uncovered it; (S, Mgh, MA;) namely, a thing: (S, Mgh:) he made it, or rendered it, apparent, or plainly apparent, overt, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, plain, obvious, or evident; (S, Mgh, Msb, MA;) namely, (assumed tropical:) an affair, (Mgh,) or (assumed tropical:) information, or tidings. (Msb.) You say, jalaA AlEaruwsa, inf. n. jilaMCN and jilowapN (S, Msb, K) and jalowapN (Msb, K) and julowapN; (K;) and AjtlAhA↓; (S, Msb, K;) He displayed the bride, EalaI baEolihaA to her husband: (K:) or he looked at the bride
displayed: (S:) and you say also, juliyato EalaI zawojihaA (TA) She mas shown to her husband, and he looked at her displayed: (Har p. 30:) and jalaAhaA zawojuhaA Her husband presented, or gave, to her a female slave (S, K) or some other thing at the time of her being displayed to him; as also jlRAhA↓: (K:) and jalati AlmaAXiTapu AlEaruwsa The female hairdresser adorned the bride [to display her to her husband]. (TA.) You also say, jalaA fulaAnN AlOamora (tropical:) Such a one displayed, discovered, disclosed, revealed, or manifested, the affair, or case; as also jlRAhu↓, and jalaA Eanohu: (K, * TA:) or jalaA fulaAnFA AlOamori he displayed, discovered, &c., to such a one the affair, or case; as also jlRAh↓ [i. e. jlRAhu AlOamora], and jalaA Eanohu [i. e. jlA Enh AlOamora or jlA fulaAnFA Eani AlOamori]. (So accord. to the CK and my MS. copy of the K. [The reading in the TA is, in my opinion, preferable to the latter.]) And AlsRaAEapa AallRehu yujalRiI↓ (assumed tropical:) God will make manifest the hour, or time of the resurrection; or will make it to appear. (K in art. jlI: [but it belongs to the present art.:]) so in the Kur vii. 186. (TA.) And Eano nafosihi huwa yujalRiI↓ (assumed tropical:) He declares, or explains, his mind. (S.) ― -b2- jalawotu AlsRayofa, inf. n. jilaMCN, (S, Msb, K, [in the CK jalAC, but it is]) with kesr, (S, Msb,) and jalowN, (K,) I removed, or cleared off, the rust from the sword; (Msb;) I polished, or furbished, the sword; (S, K;) and AlmiroMpa the mirror; (K;) and the like; (TA;) [as, for instance,] AlfiDRapa the silver; and so jalayotuhaA. (K in art. jlI.) And jalawotu baSariI biAlkuHoli [I cleared my sight with collyrium]: (S:) [whence,] jalaA He applied collyrium to his eye or eyes. (IAar, TA.) And jalawotu hamRiI EanRiI (tropical:) I removed my anxiety, or caused it to depart, from me: (S, K, * TA: *) and Eanohu AlhamRa AjlI↓ (assumed tropical:) He removed, or cleared away, from him anxiety. (Lth, TA.) And jalaA QllRehu Eanohu AlmaraDa (assumed tropical:) God removed from him the disease. (TA.) ― -b3- jalaAhumo, and AjlAhm↓, (S, Mgh,) or jalaAhu, and AjlAhu↓, (Msb, K,) and AjtlAhu↓, (K,) He, (a man, S, Msb, or the Sultán, Mgh,) or it, (drought, K,) caused them, or him, to go forth, or emigrate; or expelled them, or him; or drove them, or him, forth; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) [from their homes, or from his home.] And jalaA AlnRaHoli, inf. n. jilaMCN, or jalaMCN, (accord. to different copies of the K,) and jlwp [thus written without any syll. signs]; and AjtlAhA↓; (TA;) He smoked [out] the bees, in order to collect the honey; (K;) he drove away the bees by means of smoke. (TA.)

2 jlRI jl jlI jly jlyy
2. jlRI: see 1, in six places. ＝ -A2- Also, inf. n. tajoliyapN and tajoliIRN, He (a hawk, or falcon,) raised his head, and looked, (K, TA,) seeing the prey: (TA:) or he (a hawk) closed his eyes, and then opened them, in order to see more clearly. (Ibn- Hamzeh, TA.) ― -b2- And [hence,] jlRI bibaSarihi, inf. n. tajoliyapN, He cast his eyes (S, K) like the hawk looking at the prey. (S.) ＝ -A3- [jlRI is also mentioned (in Har p. 161), on the authority of Mtr, as signifying He, or it, outstripped; from AlmujalRiI meaning “ the first of the horses in a race; ” but as being not known in this sense on any other authority.]

3 jaAlayotuhu biAlOamori c
3. jaAlayotuhu biAlOamori, inf. n. mujaAlaApN, I acted openly with him in the affair; as also jaAlaHotuhu. (S.)

4 AjlI Ojl OjlI Ojly Ojlyy AjlI Ajly jlA jlI Mjl Mjly Mjlyy
4. AjlI as an intrans. v.: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Oajolawo Eani Alqatiyli They cleared themselves away, or removed, from the slain person. (S, Mgh, Msb, TA.) ― -b3- AjlI yaEoduw He hastened, running: (K:) or hastened somewhat, running: (TA:) or AjlI signifies he became distant, or remote, and hastened. (So accord. to some copies of the K, where we find waOajolaI baEuda wa OasoraEa instead of wa OajolaI yaEoduw OasoraEa.) ＝ -A2- As a trans. v.: see 1, in four places.

5 tjlRI Ojl OjlI jl jlA jlI tjlI tjly
5. tjlRI: see 1, in three places: ― -b2- and see also 7. ＝ -A2- tjlRI AlXRaIoCa He looked at the thing, (K in art. jlI,) standing upon a higher position. (TA.) [See also 8.]

6 tajaAlayonaA tjAlynA
6. tajaAlayonaA Our states, or conditions, became disclosed to each other; the state, or condition, of each of us to the other. (S.)

7 AnjlI Onjl Onjly Onjlyy AnjlI Anjly QnjlI
7. AnjlI It became removed, or cleared away; said of anxiety, (S, K, * TA,) and of an affair [&c.]; as also tjlRI↓. (K, * TA.) You say, AnjlI Eanohu AlhamRu Anxiety became removed, or cleared away, from him, (S,) kamaA tanojaliI AlZRulomapu like as the darkness becomes removed, or cleared away. (TA.)

8 AjtlAhu AjtlAh AjtlAp QjtlAh QjtlI
8. AjtlAhu He looked at him, or it. (K.) [See also 5.] Hence, AjtlI AlEaruwsa, explained above: see 1. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1 in two other places, last two sentences. ― -b3- Aijotalayotu AlEimaAmapa Eano raOosiI I raised the turban, while folding it, from the side of my forehead (Eano jabiyniI): (S:) [like jalahotuhaA.] ＝ -A2- AjtlI It became polished, or furbished; said of a sword [&c.]. (TA.)

12 AjlwlI AjlwlI Ajlwly
12. AjlwlI He went forth, or emigrated, from one country, or town, to another. (IAar, K.) [See also 1.]

Aibonu jalaA Abn jlA
Aibonu jalaA (tropical:) A man who is well known, celebrated, or notable; (Mgh;) of whom it is said, jalaA AlOumuwra, i. e. he has made affairs clear, unobscured, or manifest; (S, Mgh;) or jalaA Oamoruhu, i. e. his case has become clear, unobscured, or manifest: (Mgh:) or one whose case is clear, apparent, plainly apparent, or manifest; (K, TA;) as also Aibonu OajolaI↓: (K:) applied to a man who is upon an elevated and conspicuous place; and applied by El-Hajjáj to himself, as meaning that he was one whom every one knew: (TA:) and also, (K,) for this reason, (TA,) the name of a certain man, (S, K,) well known, (K,) of the Benoo-Leyth, who was a person of great daring. (TA.) A poet says, (S,) namely, Soheym Ibn-Wetheel Er-Riyáhee, (TA,)
OanaA Qbonu jalaA waTalRaAEu AlvRanaAyaA
mataI OaDiEa AlEimaAmapa taEorifuwniI
[I am a man well known, celebrated, or notable, &c.; and he who rises to eminences, or who is accustomed to embark in, or surmount, lofty and difficult things: when I put down the turban, ye will know me]. (S, TA.) Sb says, (TA,) jlA in this case is a verb in the pret. tense: 'Eesà Ibn- 'Omar says that when a man is named qatala or Daraba or the like, the word is imperfectly decl.; and he adduces, in evidence, this verse: others say that jlA may be here without tenween because it is imitative of a phrase, as though the poet said, OanaA Qbonu AlRaciI yuqaAlu lahu jalaA AlOumuwri: (S, TA:) accord. to IB, it is without tenween because it is a verb with its agent [implied in it]. (TA.) ― -b2- Accord. to some, it signifies (assumed tropical:) The daybreak, or dawn; (Har p. 498;) and so Aibonu OajolaI↓: (TA:) accord. to Hamzeh, (assumed tropical:) the beginning of day: and accord. to some, (assumed tropical:) the moon. (Har ubi suprà)

jalFA jl jlA
jalFA: see 1, voce jaliIa: ＝ -A2- and see jilaMCN.

jilFA jl jlA
jilFA: see jilaMCN.

jilowapN jlA jlI jlwh jlwp
jilowapN A female slave, (S, K,) or some other thing, (K,) that is presented, or given, by the husband to his bride at the time of her being displayed to him. (S, * K.) One says, maA jilowatuhaA [What is her bridal present?]; and is answered, “ Such a thing. ” (S.)

jalaMCN jlMC
jalaMCN A thing, an affair, or a case, that is apparent, manifest, plain, or evident. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- And Acknowledgment, or confession: so in the saying of Zuheyr:
faUinRa AlHaqRa maqoTaEuhu valaAvN
yamiynN Oawo nifaArN Oawo jalaMCN
[For verily the means of deciding the truth are three: an oath, and incongruity of circumstances, and acknowledgment, or confession]: (S:) but Az writes the last word jilaMC↓, with kesr to the j, as meaning an evidence, or a proof, and witnesses; from mujaAlaApN [inf. n. of 3, q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b3- Oaqamotu Einodahu jalaMCayawomiI, (K, TA,) or jalaMCa yawomK, (so in some copies of the K,) [I remained with him, or at his abode,] during the whiteness of my, or a, day. (Zj, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph.

jilaMCN jlMC
jilaMCN: see the paragraph next preceding. ＝ -A2- Also, (S, Mgh, K,) written by El-Muhellebee jalaMCN↓, (TA,) and jalFA↓, which is more correct than the first, (Mgh,) or it is allowable, as also jilFA↓, the former of the last two mentioned on the authority of En-Nahhás, (TA,) Collyrium: (S, K:) or a particular kind thereof, (K, TA,) that clears the sight; (TA;) [i. e.] i. q. UivomidN [antimony, or an ore of antimony]; (Mgh, TA;) so called because it clears the sight. (Mgh.) ＝ -A3- maAjilaAWuhu What is his honourable name, or surname, (S,) or his good surname, (K,) by which he is addressed? (S, K.)

jaliIRN jl jlI jly jlyy
jaliIRN Clear, unobscured, exposed to view, displayed, laid open, disclosed, or uncovered: apparent, or plainly apparent, overt, conspicuous, manifest, notorious, plain, obvious, or evident: (S, Msb, K, TA:) jaAlK thus used has not been heard. (Er-Rághib, TA.) It is applied as an epithet to information, or tidings, (Msb, TA,)
and to analogy, or rule. (TA.) ― -b2- EayonN jaliyRapN A seeing eye. (IB, TA.)

jaliyRapN jl jly jlyh jlyp
jaliyRapN Sure information or tidings. (S.) ― -b2- OaxobaraniI Eano jaliyRapN AlOamori He informed me of the true, or real, state of the affair, or case. (TA.)

dawaMCN jalRaMCN dwMC jlMC
dawaMCN jalRaMCN [A medicine that clears the complexion or skin]. (K voce fuwRapN, &c.)

jiliyRaAnN jly jlyAn
jiliyRaAnN The act of rendering apparent, open, manifest, plain, or evident: rendering clear, or unobscured; exposing to view, displaying, laying open, disclosing, or uncovering. (TA.)

jaAlK jAl
jaAlK Going forth, or emigrating, from his country, or town: [like jaAlRN:] and so jaAliyapN, applied to a company of people; [as also jaAlRapN;] (Msb;) or to people who have gone forth, or emigrated, from their homes; (S;) and particularly to those tributaries, (Mgh, Msb,) namely, certain Jews, (Mgh,) whom 'Omar expelled from the country of the Arabs; (Mgh, Msb;) and afterwards, to such as have the poll-tax imposed upon them, of the people of the Bible, and of the Magians, though not having emigrated from their homes; (Mgh;) [i. e.] the free non-Muslim subjects of a Muslim government; because they were expelled by 'Omar from Arabia; (K;) the word being fem. because denoting a jamaAEap; (Mgh;) and its pl. is jawaAlK. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, (Msb,) jaAliyapN↓ [as a subst.] is applied to The poll-tax that is exacted from the persons last mentioned above; (S, Mgh, Msb;) as also jaAlRapN: (S:) first, in this sense, applied to that which was exacted from the people expelled from Arabia by 'Omar. (Msb.) You say, AusotuEomila fulaAnN EalaI AljaAliyapi [Such a one was employed as collector of the poll-tax]. (S, Mgh, Msb.) ＝ -A2- See also jaAYilN, in art. jwl.

jaAliyapN jAlyh jAlyp
jaAliyapN (as a subst.): see what next precedes.

OajolaI c
OajolaI Having that degree of baldness which is termed jalFA; i. e. baldness of the fore part of the head: or baldness of half of the head; (S, K;) which is the beginning of SalaEN: (S:) or baldness less than what is termed SalaEN: (K:) or baldness of half of the head, and the like: (A'Obeyd, TA:) fem. jalowaMCN. (K.) [See OajolaHu.] ― -b2- Beautiful, or handsome, in face, bald in the sides of the forehead. (K.) ― -b3- jabohapN jalowaMCu A wide forehead. (K.) ― -b4- samaMCN jalowaMCN (assumed tropical:) A cloudless sky: (Ks, S, K:) and layolapN jalowaMCu (assumed tropical:) a cloudless, bright, night. (TA.) ― -b5- Aibonu OajolaI: see Aibonu jalaA, in two places. ― -b6- Also (i. e. Abn AjlI) (assumed tropical:) The lion. (TA.) ＝ -A2- faEalotuhu mino OajolaAka, and UijolaAka↓, I did it on account of thee, for thy sake, or because of thee; syn. mino Oajolika. (K.)

faEalotuhu mino UijolaAka fElth mn AjlAk
faEalotuhu mino UijolaAka: see what next precedes.

majolFI mjlI mjly mjlyy
majolFI sing. of majaAlK, which signifies The fore parts of the head, which are the [first] places of baldness: (Fr, S:) or what is seen of the head when one fronts the face. (TA.)

mujolK mjl mjly
mujolK [act. part. n. of 4. Hence,] faUimRaA HarobN mujoliyapN wa UimRaA silomN muxoziyapN And either war that shall cause you to emigrate, or abasing peace. (TA.)

AlmujolRiI AlmjlI Almjly mjly
AlmujolRiI The first of the horses in a race. (K in art. jlI.)

dictScrap.label: jlI: Some words are mentioned in the K under this head belonging to art. jlw, q. v.

superEntry.entry:
1 jamRa jm
1. jamRa, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
jamima
, inf. n. jamRN, (Msb,) said of water, (S,) &c., (S, Msb,) It became much, or abundant; (S, Msb;) as also Astjm↓; said of a thing: (TA:) and, said of water, aor.
jamuma
(S, K) and
jamima
, (K,) the former of which is of the higher authority, (TA,) inf. n. jumuwmN, (S, Mgh, K,) it became much, or abundant, (S, Mgh, K,) in the well, (S,) and collected (S, K) after it had been drawn from; (S;) as also AstjmR↓. (K.) And jamRuwA They became many. (TA.) ― -b2- jamRati AlbiYoru, (K,) aor.
jamuma
and
jamima
, inf. n. jumuwmN, (TA,) The water of the well returned by degrees, (K, TA,) and became much, or abundant, and collected; (TA;) and AstjmRt↓ signifies the same. (S.) ― -b3- [Hence, jamRato mavaAbapN jaholihi, a tropical phrase, explained in art. vwb.] ― -b4- jamRa Alkayolu, inf. n. jumaAmN, with damm, The measure became full or filled. (KL. [But only the inf. n. is there mentioned: so that the verb may be jumRa, which see below.]) ― -b5- jamRa Alfarasu, (S, K,) aor.
jamuma
and
jamima
, (S, TA,) inf. n. jamaAmN (S, K) and jamRN; (S;) and AstjmR↓; (S;) The horse abstained from covering, (S, K,) so that his seminal fluid (maAWuhu) collected. (K.) ― -b6- Also, (aor. of the former verb as above, TA, and inf. n. jamRN and jamaAmN, S, K,) The fatigue of the horse went away; (S;) [he recovered his strength after fatigue;] he recovered from his fatigue, being left unridden; (K, TA;) and so OajamRa↓ [of which see also the pass. form, below]. (M, K.) ― -b7- [And hence,] jamRa, [inf. n. jamaAmN, q. v. infrà,] He rested; said of a man [as well as of a horse]; (TA;) and so AstjmR↓. (Har p. 324.) ― -b8- Also, said of a bone, (K,) inf. n. jamRN, (TA,) It had much flesh; its flesh became much, or abundant. (K.) ― -b9- Also i. q. EalaA [He, or it, became high, &c.: perhaps said of water in a well]. (T, TA.) ― -b10- Also, inf. n. jumuwmN, He rose (AirotafaEa) in his pace, or going. (TA.) ― -b11- Also, (S, K,) inf. n. jamRN (TA) and jumuwmN, (S, TA,) said of an event, (K,) of the arrival of a person, (S,) It drew near; (S, K;) it came to pass: (S:) and AjmR↓ signifies the same, (S, Msb, K,) said of an event, of separation from another, (S, TA,) and of an object of want: (TA:) AHmR, [q. v.,] with the unpointed H, in this sense, was not known to As. (TA.) ― -b12- And, said of the naSiIR, and the SilRiyaAn, [two plants, inf. n. not mentioned,] It attained to the state of having a jumRap [app. meaning tuft, or flower-bud]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jamRa AlkaboXi, (TA,) or jamimati AlXRaApu, [perhaps a mistranscription for jamRat,] aor.
jamama
, (Msb,) inf. n. jamamN, (S, Msb, TA,) The ram, (TA,) or sheep or goat, (S, Msb,) was hornless. (S, Msb, TA.) ＝ -A3- jamRahu, (K,) [aor.
jamuma
, accord. to rule,] inf. n. jamRN, (TA,) He left it (namely, water [in a well],) to collect; as also AjmRhu↓. (K.) And jumRati AlbiYoru [The well was left for its water to collect]. (TA.) And AlbiYora AstjmR↓ He left the well for some days until its water should collect: whence the metaphorical phrase, mavaAbapu safahihi kaAna yasotajimRu↓, [explained in art. vwb,] occurring in a trad. (Har p. 68.) ― -b2- Also He filled it (namely, a measure, S, such as is called makRuwk, K) so that it had what is termed jumaAmN; and so AjmRhu↓; (S, K;) and jmRmhu↓. (K.) And jumRa It was filled. (T, TA.) See also jamRN, last sentence.

2 jmRmt AlOaroDu c
2. jmRmt AlOaroDu The jamiym [q. v.] of the land became full, or abundant. (ISh, TA.) ― -b2- jmRm [in the CK jamama] It (herbage) became such as is termed jamiym; as also tjmRm↓. (K, TA.) ― -b3- He made a jumRap [q. v.] of his hair. (Z, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, last sentence but two.

4 AjmR Ojm Ojmp Ajm jm wjm
4. AjmR, as an intrans. verb: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- AjmRhu: see 1, near the end of the paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- He left him unridden, so that he recovered from his fatigue; namely, a horse. (K.) And OujimRa He (a horse) was left unridden. (S.) ― -b3- [Hence, He rested him, or gave him rest.] You say, Oajomimo nafosaka yawomFA Oawo yawomayoni [Rest thyself a day, or two days]. (S.) And hence, in a trad. respecting the safarojalap [or quince], tujimRu AlfuWaAda, i. e. It rests the heart, and consolidates it, and completes its soundness and liveliness. (TA.) One says also, UinRiI laOasotajimRu↓ qalobiI biXRaIoCK mina AllRahowi liOaqowaI bihi EalaI AlHaqRi [Verily I relieve my heart with somewhat of diversion, in order that I may become strong thereby for that which is substantial, or solid, not vain or frivolous]. (S.) And AjmR AlOaroDa He gave the land rest from tilling. (TA in art. bxE.) ― -b4- He gave him the jamRap [or supply of water, that had collected after drawing,] of the well. (Th. TA.) ― -b5- OujimRa AlEinabu The grape-vine had all its branches that were above the ground cut off. (AHn, TA.)

5 tajamRaRa
5: see 2.

10 AstjRm Ostjm Astjm Qstjm
10. AstjRm, as an intrans. verb: see 1, in five places. ― -b2- It is said in a trad., mano yuHibRu Oano yasotajimRa lahu AlnRaAsu qiyaAmFA faloyatabawRaOo maqoEadahu mina AlnRaAri, i. e. [Whoso loveth that men] should collect themselves to him, standing in his presence, and confining themselves to him, [let him take his sitting-place in the fire of Hell:] or, accord. as some relate it, ystxmR; see art. xm; (TA;) and, as some, yasotaxiyma. (TA in art. xym, q. v.) ― -b3- AstjmRt AlOaroDu The land put forth its plants, or herbage, (K, TA,) so that it became like the [hair termed] jmRp [i. e. jumRap]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- As a trans. verb: see 1, near the end of the paragraph, in two
places: ― -b2- and see 4. ― -b3- AusotujimRato jamRapu AlmaMCi [The supply of water that had collected after drawing] was drunk. (TA.)

R. Q. 1 jamojama jmjm
R. Q. 1. jamojama, (S, TA,) inf. n. jamojamapN, (K,) He spoke indistinctly, (S, K,) not from impotence, or, accord. to the T, from impotence; (TA;) and tajamojama↓ signifies the same. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (Mgh, K,) with which majomajapN is syn., accord. to Ez-Zowzanee, (Mgh,) He concealed (Mgh, K, TA) speech, (Mgh,) or a thing, (K, TA,) in his bosom. (Mgh, K, TA.) You say, jmjm XayoYFA fiI Sadorihi He concealed a thing in his bosom; did not reveal it. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (Kr, K,) He destroyed, or killed, (Kr, K, TA,) another or others. (TA.)

R. Q. 2 tajamojama jmjm tjmjm
R. Q. 2. tajamojama: see R. Q. 1. ― -b2- Hence, tjmjm Eani AlOamori (tropical:) [He held back from the thing, not daring to do it;] he did not dare to do the thing. (Ham p. 240.)

jamRN jm
jamRN, an inf. n. used as an epithet, (Msb,) Much, or many; (S, Msb, K;) as also jamiymN↓ accord. to the copies of the K, but correctly jamama↓, as in the L. (TA.) You say maAlN jamRN (Msb, TA) and jamama↓ (TA) Muck property, or many cattle. (Msb.) And it is said in the Kur [lxxxix. 21], wa yuHibRuwna AlmaAla HubRFA jamRFA (S) And they love property with much love. (A'Obeyd, TA.) Aboo-Khirásh El-Hudhalee says,
Uino tagofiri QlRelhuma tagofiro jamRaA
(TA) i. c. [If thou forgive, O God, Thou forgivest] much sin. (Mgh.) jamRe AlbuEaAqi, in a trad. respecting prayer for rain, means Copious, abundant, extensive rain. (TA in art. bEq.) ― -b2- The greater, or main, portion of the Zahiyrap [i. e. midday, or mid-day in summer, &c.]: and of water; as also jamRapN↓, (as in some copies of the K,) or jumRapN↓: (so in other copies of the K, and accord. to the TA: [the former app. the right: if it were the latter, the author of the K, accord. to a rule which he has seldom neglected, would have added biAlDRamRi; as SM has here done, unless his transcriber have thus written by mistake for biAlfatoHi:] or jamRN signifies the water, of a well, that has collected [after it has been drawn from]: and jamRapN↓, the place in which the water collects: (S:) and also, this last, the water itself: (TA: [i. e. the supply of water that has collected after drawing: see 4, last sentence but one; and see 10, last sentence:]) the pl. (of jamRapN S [or of this and of jamRN also]) is jimaAmN (S, K) and jumuwmN. (K.) ― -b3- biYorN jamRapN: see jamuwmN. ― -b4- jaAWuwA jamRFA gafiyrFA, and AljamRa Algafiyra, &c.; see OajamRu, and art. gfr. ― -b5- jamRN also signifies People of the lowest, or basest, or meanest sort. (T, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The measuring to the head of the measure; [app. an inf. n., of which the verb is jamRa↓; see 1, last sentence but two; and so jamaAmN↓ and jumaAmN↓ and jimaAmN↓. (K.)

jamRapN jm jmh jmp
jamRapN: see jamRN, in two places. ― -b2- Also The part, or place, of a ship, in which collects the water that leaks from its xuruwz [or seams: in the CK xuruwr]: (K:) a genuine Arabic word. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (S, K,) and jumRapN↓, (S, K, and Ham p. 746,) A company demanding a bloodwit (S, K) or an obligation that must be discharged, (TA, and Ham ubi suprà,) or peace; or coming for some other purpose: (Ham:) pl. jmm [probably jumamN, pl. of the latter, or perhaps of both; or it may be jimamN, as pl. of both]. (TA.) You say, jaMCa fiI jamRapK EaZiymapK and EZymp jumRapK↓ He came in a great company &c. (S, K.)

jumRapN jm jmh jmp
jumRapN: see jamRN: ― -b2- and see also jamRapN, in two places. ― -b3- Also The collective mass of the hair of the head, or the head of hair, (mujotamaEa XaEori AlrRaOosi S, Mgh, K,) when more in quantity than what is termed waforap: (S, Mgh:) or the collective mass of the hair (mujotamaEu AlXRaEori) when it hangs down from the head to the lobe of the ear, and to the two shoulder-joints, and more than that; what does not extend beyond the ears being termed wfrp: (TA:) or the collective mass (mujotamaEa) of the hair of the naASiyap [or anterior part of the head]: accord. to some, what reaches to the two shoulder-joints: (Msb:) in the M it is said to signify the hair; and in like manner in the Deewán el-Adab: but ISd adds that it is also said to mean hair more in quantity than that which is termed limRap: accord. to IAth, the hair of the head that falls upon the two shoulder-joints: in the Muhedhdhib, what extends beyond the ears: in the Mukaddameh of Z, what extends to the lobe of the ear: accord. to IDrd, much hair: (TA:) [see also limRapN and waforapN:] pl. jumamN (Msb, TA) and jimaAmN: (TA:) dim. jumayomapN↓. (TA.) Hence, raOaI lumoEapF fagasalahaA bijumRatihi, meaning [He saw a spot, and washed it] by a moistening of his jmRp: or with the water of his jmRp: the prefixed noun being suppressed. (Mgh.) ― -b4- Also [app. (assumed tropical:) A flower-bud;] the qbp [rendered by Golius “ nodosior pars ”] of a plant, from which the flower comes forth. (KL.) [See an ex. above, voce jamRa. If from jumRapN applied to hair, it would seem rather to mean A tuft.] ― -b5- One says also, Hacafa jumRapu Aljawozapi vumRa OakalahaA (tropical:) [app. meaning He threw away the husk of the walnut: then ate it]. (TA.)

jamamN jmm
jamamN: see jamRN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also jumaAmN.

jamaAmN jmAm
jamaAmN A state of resting; (Fr, S, Msb, K;) as also jamaAmapN↓: (TA:) particularly of a horse. (Fr, S, Msb.) [See jamRa, of which it is an inf. n.] ― -b2- See also jamRN, last sentence: and see what next follows.

jumaAmN jmAm
jumaAmN What has collected of the seminal fluid of a horse [after his resting from covering]; as also jimaAmN↓. (K.) ― -b2- Also, and jimaAmN↓ and jamaAmN↓, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) [but see what follows,] The quantity [of flour or the like] that rises above the head of the [measure termed] makRuwk, (S, Mgh, K,) after the filling, (Mgh,) exceeding the TafaAf thereof; (S, Mgh, K;) as also jamamN↓: (K:) or the fill of a bowl, without a head: accord. to ISk, only said of flour and the like: one says, OaEoTaAniI jmAma AlqadaHi daqiyqFA [He gave me the bowlful of flour]: but jmAm meaning the “ resting ” of a horse is with fet-h only: (Msb:) or, accord. to Fr, one says AlqadaHi AlmaMCF jimaAmN↓, with kesr, meaning the bowlful of water; and jumaAmu AlmakRuwki daqiyqFA, with damm; and jamaAmN Alfarasi, with fet-h only; and one does not say jumaAmN, with damm, except in relation to flour and the like, meaning the quantity that rises above the head of the mkRwk, after the being filled: one says, OaEoTiniI jumaAma AlmakRuwki when one puts what the head of the mkRwk will bear, and gives it: (S, TA:) in the T, it is said that OaEoTihi jmAma AlmakRuwki means Give thou him [the quantity of] a mkRwk without a head: but [SM says,] I have seen in its margin written that the right meaning is, the quantity borne by the head of the mkRwk. (TA.) ― -b3- See also jamRN, last sentence.

jimaAmN jmAm
jimaAmN: see jumaAmN, in three places: ― -b2- and jamRN, last sentence: ＝ -A2- and see also jumojumapN. ＝ -A3- It is also a pl. of jamRapN (S) [and perhaps of jamRN likewise: (see this latter:)] and of jumRapN. (TA.)

biYorN jamuwmN c
biYorN jamuwmN (S, K) and jamRapN↓ (K) A well of much water. (S, K.) ― -b2- farasN jamuwmN A horse that, after any run, runs again; (T, S, K;) applied to the female as well as the male: (T, TA:) a horse that goes much. (KL.)

jamiymN jmym
jamiymN A plant, or herbage, that has grown somewhat, but not attained its full height: (S:) or much, or abundant, herbage: (K:) or herbage standing up and spreading: (AHn, K:) or that has grown up until it has become like the jumRap of hair: (TA:) a plant, or herbage, when it first appears in the ground is termed baAriDN; then, jamiymN; then, busorapN; then, SamoEaMCu; and then, [when it is dry,] HaXiyXN: (S in art. bsr:) pl. OajimRaMCu. (K.) And, with p, A [plant of the kind termed] naSiyRap that has become half a month old, so that it fills the mouth. (K.) ― -b2- See also jamRN.

jamaAmapN jmAm jmAmh jmAmp
jamaAmapN: see jamaAmN. ― -b2- Also The state of being satiated, or satisfied, with food, and with drink. (TA.)

jumayomapN jmymh jmymp
jumayomapN dim. of jumRapN, q. v. (TA.)

jumRaI jm jmI jmy jmyy
jumRaI The bean, or beans; syn. baAqilRaI. (AHn, K.)

jumRiI jm jmI jmy jmyy
jumRiI: see jumRaAniIRN.

jamRaAmN jmAm
jamRaAmN: see what next follows.

jamRaAnN jm jmAn
