jamRaAnN A measure, (S,) such as is called makRuwk, (K,) filled so as to have what is termed jumaAm; (S, K;) as also jamRaAmN↓: (K:) [fem. of the former jamRaI. Hence,] jumojumapN jamRaI [A] full [bowl]. (K. In the CK jamojamapN.)

jumRaAniIRN jm jmAn jmAnI jmAny
jumRaAniIRN, with n, (S,) an irreg. rel. n., applied to a man, (Sb, S,) Having a long jumRap: (S, K:) or having a great and long jumRap: (Sb, TA:) but if you name a person jumRap, the rel. n. formed from it is jumRiIRN↓ (Sb, S) only. (Sb, TA.)

jumojumN jmjm
jumojumN: see what next follows.

jumojumapN jmjm jmjmh jmjmp
jumojumapN The skull; i. e. the bone that contains the brain: (S, Msb, K: *) or i. q. qiHofN [i. e. the bone above the brain, or a separate portion of the skull, or a distinct bone of the skull]: (K:) or the bones of the head; (IAar, Mgh, TA;) all of them; the uppermost of them being the haAmap; (IAar, TA;) or the hAmp is the jmjmp altogether; (ISh, TA;) and the qHf is said to be a piece of the jmjmp: (TA:) pl. jumojumN↓, (K,) [or this (in the CK, erroneously, jamojamN) is a coll. gen. n.,] and jamaAjimu [is the pl. properly so called, and that which is more commonly known]. (TA.) ― -b2- Sometimes it is used to signify A man; so that one says, xucuwA mino kulRi jumojumapK dirohamFA [Take ye from every man, or head, a dirhem]; like as one says, mino kulRi raOosK: (Msb:) and waDaEa AlUimaAmu AlxaraAja EalaI AljamaAjimi EalaI kulRi jumojumapK kacaA [The Imám imposed the tax, or land-tax, upon the heads; upon every head so much]. (Mgh.) ― -b3- A wooden bowl: (S, K:) a bowl of glass; as also qiHofN. (Az, TA.) ― -b4- A kind of measure for corn or the like. (K.) ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) Chiefs, or lords, of the Arabs; because the jmjmp is the head, which is the most noble of the members: (TA:) also, (TA,) [the pl.] jamaAjimu has this meaning. (T, K, TA.) And (assumed tropical:) Any sons of a father that are persons of might, or power, and eminence, or nobility: (T, TA:) and [the pl.] jamaAjimu the tribes (qabaAYil) of the Arabs which comprise buTuwn, and in relation to which persons are called; as Kelb Ibn-Webreh; for when you say kalobiIRN, you do not need to call the person in relation to any of the bTwn: (S:) or the tribes (qbAYl) in relation to which the bTwn are called; as also jimaAmN↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- A well that is dug in salt ground. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- Sixty head of camels. (IF, IB, TA.) ＝ -A4- jamaAjimu AlHaArivi The piece of wood at the head of which is the ploughshare. (TA.)

OajamRu c
OajamRu [Greater, and greatest, in quantity, and in number, &c.: fem. jamRaMCu. Hence,] waAlwaHoIu OajamRu maA kaAna, in a trad. of Anas, means The revelation being the most that it used to be. (Sh, TA.) ― -b2- A bone having much flesh. (K.) You say also AimoraOapN jamRaMCu AlEiZaAmi A woman having much flesh (K, TA) on the bones. (TA.) And AimoraOapN jamRaMCu AlmaraAfiqi [A woman having much flesh on the elbows: or, as seems to be indicated by J, having no prominence of the elbows; and if so, from jamRaMCu applied to a ewe, in a sense explained in what follows]. (S.) ― -b3- jaAWuwA AljamRaMCa Algafiyra, (S, * Msb, K,) [and jamRaMCa gafiyrFA &c.,] and gafiyrFA jamRFA↓, (K,) [and Algafiyra AljamRa↓, &c.,] They came all together, (S, * Msb, K,) high and low, none of them remaining behind, and they being many: (S, K, in art. gfr:) see art. gfr. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- Hornless, applied to a ram (Mgh, Msb, K) or he-goat; (Msb;) and so jamRaMCu applied to a ewe (S, Mgh, Msb) or she-goat: (S, Msb:) pl. jumRN. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- And [hence,] (tropical:) A man having no spear (S, K, TA) in war or battle: (S, TA:) pl. as above. (TA.) The pl. is also applied to horses, (S,) meaning (assumed tropical:) whose owners have no spears; the spears being regarded as the horses' horns. (Ham, p. 90.) ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) A building having no [acroterial ornaments such as are termed] Xuraf: (S:) and the pl., (assumed tropical:) Mosques having no Xuraf (Mgh, TA) upon them, (TA,) [i. e.] upon their walls. (Mgh.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A flat house-top having no parapet, or surrounding wall. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Short; having no elevation. (TA.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) A woman's anterior pudendum. (K.) ― -b7- And, as being likened thereto, or the reverse may be the case, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) A bowl. (K.) ― -b8- Also, the fem., (assumed tropical:) Smooth. (IAar, K.) ― -b9- And hence, because of its smoothness, (IAar, TA,) (assumed tropical:) A helmet: (IAar, K:) to which the epithet gafiyrN [q. v.] is applied because it covers the head: but this meaning of “ a helmet ” was not known to ISd on any other authority than that of IAar. (TA.)

majamRN mjm
majamRN A place where water remains: or to which it reaches, and where it ends. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The breast, or bosom, or mind: (K, TA:) because it is the place in which are collected the knowledge &c. that it retains. (TA.) You say, huwa waAsiEu AlmajamRi, i. e. raHobu AlcRiraAEi waAsiEu AlSRadori (tropical:) [He is possessed of ample power and might, and free from distress of mind or from narrowness of mind]. (IAar, K, TA.) And UinRahu laDayRiqu AlmajamRi (tropical:) Verily he is contracted, or straitened, in mind by affairs, or events. (IAar, TA.)

majamRapN mjm mjmh mjmp
majamRapN A thing in which resting is usually known to take place. (TA.)

mujamRamN mjmm
mujamRamN A boy (IDrd, TA) having a head of hair such as is termed a jumRap. (IDrd, K, TA.)

mujamRimapN mjmmh mjmmp
mujamRimapN A woman who makes her hair to form a jumRap, to make herself like a man: the doing of which is forbidden. (TA.)

1 jamaHa jmH
1. jamaHa, aor.
jamaHa
, inf. n. jimaAHN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and jumuwHN (S, A, Msb, K) and jamoHN, (K,) or this last has not been heard, (Mgh,) He (a horse) overcame his rider, or gained the mastery over him, (S, L, K,) running away with him: (L:) or broke loose, or ran away, (Msb,) and went at random, without any certain aim, so as not to be turned by anything: (Mgh, Msb:) or ran so as to have the mastery over his rider: (Ham p. 568:) and jamaHa biraAkibihi (A, Mgh, Msb) he overcame his rider, (A, Mgh,) and ran away so that he could not govern him: (A:) or became refractory, so that he overcame his rider: (Msb:) and sometimes, (Msb,) this verb also signifies he was quick, or swift, (A, Msb,) and brisk, lively, or sprightly; denoting in this case a quality that is approved; whereas in the senses before explained it denotes a quality that is disapproved: but in the last sense it is obsolete [unless tropically applied to a man]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) He (said of anything [i. e. of a man or any animal]) went at random, or heedlessly, without consideration or certain aim, not obeying a guide to the right course. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) He (said of a man, S, L) hastened, or went quickly, (S, L, K,) Uilayohi to him, or it, so that his course was not turned for anything. (L, TA.) wahumo yajomaHuwna, in the Kur [ix. 57], means (assumed tropical:) They hastening, or going quickly: (AO, S, L:) or hastening so that nothing turns them back, like the horse that is termed jamuwH: (Bd, Jel:) or running like horses that overcome their riders and run away so as to be ungovernable by them. (A.) And jamaHa fiI Uivorihi, occurring in a trad., (assumed tropical:) He hastened after him, or it, so that nothing turned him back. (L.) ― -b3- jamaHati AlmaroOapu (tropical:) The woman went forth from the place where she used to pass the night, in anger, without the permission of her husband. (Msb.) And jamaHato mino zawojihaA, so in the S and L &c., but in the K jamaHato zawojahaA, [which is evidently a mistake,] (TA,) (tropical:) She went forth from the house, or tent, of her husband, to her own family, before he divorced her; (S, L, K;) inf. n. jimaAHN. (L, TA.) And jamaHato UilaI OaholihaA (tropical:) She went to her family without the permission of her husband. (A.) ― -b4- jamaHati AlsRafiynapu (tropical:) The ship quitted her course, (A, TA,) and became ungovernable by the sailors; inf. n. jumuwHN. (TA.) ― -b5- jamaHati AlmafaAzapu biAlqawomi (tropical:) The desert led the people, or party, far away, by reason of its great extent. (A, TA.) ― -b6- jamaHa bihi muraAduhu (tropical:) The object of his desire baffled his efforts to attain it. (A, TA.)

jamoHapu jmHh jmHp
jamoHapu [A trick of overcoming the rider, and running away with him]. You say, daAbRapN samoHapN maA bihaA jamoHapN wa laA ramoHapN [A beast submissive, or easy, or gentle: there is not in her a trick of overcoming the rider, and running away with him, nor a trick of kicking]. (A.)

jamuwHN jmwH
jamuwHN (T, S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K) and jaAmiHN↓ (Mgh, Msb) A horse that overcomes his rider, or gains the mastery over him, (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) being refractory, (Msb,) and runs away with him, (L,) or runs away so that his rider cannot govern him, (A,) or goes away at random, without any certain aim, so as not to be turned by anything: (Mgh:) or that will not bend his head: (TA:) the former epithet, (T, Mgh, TA,) and the latter, (Mgh, Msb,) applied alike to the horse and the mare: (T, Mgh, Msb, TA:) and the former has two meanings; one denoting what is a fault, for which the horse may be returned; (T, Mgh, TA;) i. e., that habitually takes his own way, so that his rider cannot turn him from it; (T, TA;) or as explained before; (Mgh;) the other meaning being quick, or swift, and brisk, lively, and sprightly; and this does not imply a fault (T, Mgh, TA) for which he may be returned. (T, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) Anything [i. e. a man or any animal] that goes at random, or heedlessly, without consideration or certain aim, not obeying a guide to the right course: (TA:) and the former epithet, (Msb, K,) or each of the two, (S, * A,) (tropical:) a man who follows his own natural desire, without consideration, not obeying a guide to the right course of conduct, (S, A, Msb, K,)
so that he cannot be turned back. (S, K.) And jumRaAHN↓ [is pl. of jaAmiHN↓, accord. to analogy, and] signifies (assumed tropical:) Men routed, defeated, or put to flight, in war. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- mafaAzapN jamuwHN (assumed tropical:) [A desert that leads one far away, by reason of its great extent: see 1, last sentence but one: likened to a horse that is termed jamuwH]: occurring in a poem of Dhu-r-Rummeh. (TA in art. nHb.)

jumRaAHN jmAH
jumRaAHN An arrow, (S, K,) or a small arrow, (L,) without an iron point, having a round head, with which the art of shooting is learned (S, L, K) by a boy: (S, L:) or one with which boys play, putting upon its head a date or some clay, in order that it may not wound: (L:) or it signifies also a date put upon the head of a piece of wood, with which boys play: (K:) birds are shot at with it, and knocked down, without being killed, so that the shooter takes them: and it is also called jubRaAHN: (T, TA:) or a boy's arrow, upon the end of which he puts a lump of chewed dates of the size of the EifaAD [here meaning stopper] of a bottle, in order that it (the end) may go more directly, and be smooth; without feathers, and sometimes without a notch. (AHn, L.) ＝ -A2- Also That [kind of plant] at the extremities of which come forth what resemble ears of wheat, soft, (L, K,) like foxes' tails, or (L) resembling the heads of the HaliIR and the SilRiyaAn and the like: (L, K:) a coll. gen. n.: n. un. with p: (L:) pl. jamaAmiyHu; and in poetry jamaAmiHu; (L, K;) the latter allowable only in cases of necessity. (L.) ＝ -A3- See also jamuwHN.

jaAmiHN jAmH
jaAmiHN: see jamuwHN, in two places.

1 jamada jmd
1. jamada, aor.
jamuda
, inf. n. jamodN and jumuwdN, said of water, (S, M, L, Msb, K,) &c., (Msb,) [i. e.,] of anything fluid, or liquid, (K,) It congealed; concreted; became solid, or contr. of fluid or liquid; froze; syn. qaAma; (S, M;) contr. of caAba; (Msb, K;) as also jamuda. (L, K.) And said of blood, &c., (S, M,) It congealed, or concreted; syn. qAm: (M:) or became dry; dried. (S.) See also 2. ― -b2- Also, inf. n. jumuwdN, (assumed tropical:) He, or it, remained fixed, or stationary. (KL.) You say, maA zilotu OaDoribuhu HatRaI jamada (tropical:) [I ceased not to beat him until he became motionless]. (A.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) [He, or it, was, or became, incapable of growth or increase; lifeless, or dead: see jaAmidN. ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, stupid, dull, wanting in intelligence; inert; not sharp, penetrating, vigorous, or effective, in the performing of affairs; or soft, without strength or sturdiness, and without endurance: see, again, jaAmidN.] ― -b5- Also, inf. n. jumuwdN, (tropical:) said of a man's state or condition [as meaning, It was, or became, stagnant, or unimproving]. (A.) ― -b6- Also jamadato, aor.
jamuda
, inf. n. jumuwdN, (tropical:) She [a camel, &c.,] had little milk. (T, TA.) And jamadato Eayonuhu (tropical:) His eye shed few tears: a phrase alluding to hardness of the heart. (Msb.) ― -b7- Also jamada, (L, K,) aor.
jamuda
, (L,) [inf. n. jumuwdN;] and Oajomada↓; (A, TA; [in a copy of the A, Anjmd, but this is doubtless a mistranscription; see mujomidN;]) (tropical:) He was, or became, niggardly, penurious, or avaricious; (L, A, K;) as also jamada kafRuhu [or jamadato]; (Msb;) or jamadato yaduhu: (A:) and Ajmd↓ he possessed little good: (A, TA:) or jumuwdN signifies the refraining, or holding back, from beneficence. (Har p. 149.) ― -b8- jamada liI Ealayohi HaqRiI (tropical:) My right, or due, was, or became, incumbent, or obligatory, on him; or established against him; (A, K, * TA;) as also caAba. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- jamadahu He cut it, or cut it off. (K.)

2 jmRd jmd
2. jmRd, inf. n. tajomiydN; (K;) or jamada↓; (so in the L;) It (water, and expressed juice, L) was about to congeal, concrete, become solid, or freeze; was at the point of congealing, &c.; expl. by HaAwala Oano yajomuda. (L, K.) ＝ -A2- [And the former, It caused water &c. to congeal.]

4 Ajmd Ojmd Ajmd jmd
4. Ajmd: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Also, inf. n. UijomaAdN, He was entrusted with the management of affairs among a people or party [in the game called Almayosir: see mujomidN]. (T, TA.) ＝ -A2- Oajomadotu Ealayohi HaqRiI (tropical:) I made my right, or due, incumbent, or obligatory, on him; or established it against him. (A, K, * TA.)

jamodN jmd
jamodN: see jaAmidN, in two places.

jumodN jmd
jumodN: see jumudN.

jamadN jmd
jamadN pl. [or rather quasi-pl. n.] of jaAmidN, q. v. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- Also Congealed, or frozen, water; ice: [see also jamodN, mentioned with jaAmidN:] and snow. (K.) ― -b3- See also what next follows.

jumudN jmd
jumudN and jumodN↓ Elevated ground; as also jamadN↓: (M, K:) or a hard, elevated place: (S, TA:) or jumudN signifies rugged ground: (TA:) or an elevated, rugged place: (As, TA:) or a small isolated mountain, not high, sometimes rugged and sometimes soft, and producing trees, only found in rugged land; so called because of its dryness; it is the smallest kind of Oakamap, round and small, not extending along the ground, rugged at the top, and producing herbs, or leguminous plants, as well as trees; differing from jumuwdN [q. v.]: (ISh, L, TA:) pl. [of mult.] jimaAdN (ISh, S, M, K) and [of pauc.] OajomaAdN. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- Also, the first, A stone: pl. jimaAdN. (Fr, TA.)

jamaAdN jmAd
jamaAdN (assumed tropical:) [A thing that does not grow, or increase; that is incapable of growth, or increase; an inorganic thing; as a mineral and the like:] an inanimate thing; a thing that has no soul: [an epithet used as a subst.; or an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant:] pl. jamaAdaAtN. (Har p. 13.) [See also jaAmidN.] ― -b2- (tropical:) Land (OaroDN) upon which rain has not fallen: (T, S, K:) or dry land, upon which no rain has fallen, and in which is nothing: (T, TA:) or land in which is no produce: (A:) or, as some say, rugged land: (L:) or sterile, barren, or unfruitful, land, in which is nothing; as also jahaAdN: pl. jumudN. (AA, L in art. jhd.) ― -b3- (tropical:) A year (sanapN) in which is no rain: (S, K:) or in which is no produce of the earth: (A:) and, in like manner, jaAmidapN↓ a year in which is no herbage, or pasture, no plenty, or fruitfulness, and no rain. (T, TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A she-camel having no milk; (S, M, K;) and so a ewe or a she-goat: (L:) or having little milk: (T, TA:) and [accord. to some,] a slow she-camel; syn. baTiyoYapN; (L, K;) but [this is app. a mistranscription for bakiyoYapN “ having little milk, ” and] ISd says that the explanation bTyYp does not please him. (TA.) ― -b5- See also jaAmidN, in two places. ＝ -A2- A kind of cloth or garment; as also jimaAdN↓. (K.)

jamaAdi jmAd
jamaAdi, like qaTaAmi, (K,) or jamaAdi lahu, (S, A, L,) said with reference to a niggard, (S, A, L, K,) in dispraise, (K,) as an imprecation, meaning (tropical:) May a stagnant, or an unimproving, state or condition (jumuwdu AlHaAli) be his lot [or his constant lot]: (A:) or may he not cease to be in a stagnant, or an unimproving, state or condition (laA zaAla jaAmida AlHaAli). (S, L.) jamaAdi is [a proper name,] indecl., with kesr for its termination, because it is transformed from the inf. n., namely, Aljumuwdu, like fajaAri, which means Alfajorapu: (S:) and the contr. of jamaAdi lahu is jamaAdi lahu, (S, * A,) which denotes praise. (S.) El-Mutalemmis says,
jamaAdi lahaA walaA taquwliI
lahaA OabadFA UicaA cukirato HamaAdi
i. e., Say thou jumuwdFA to her, [jumuwdFA,] and say not to her [ever, when she is mentioned,] HamodFA and XukorFA. (S.)

jimaAdN jmAd
jimaAdN: see jamaAdN, last meaning.

jamuwdN jmwd
jamuwdN: see jaAmidN.

jumuwdN jmwd
jumuwdN [app. Elevated tracts,] softer, or more plain, than what is termed jumudN, and more intermixed with soft, or plain, tracts, sometimes in, or by, that [kind of high ground] which is termed qufRN, and sometimes in, or by, soft, or plain, tracts. (ISh, L, TA.)

jamiydu AlEayoni jmyd AlEyn
jamiydu AlEayoni: see jaAmidN.

jumaAdaI jmAd jmAdI jmAdy
jumaAdaI One of the names of the months, (Msb, K,) applied to two of the Arabian months, together called jumaAdayaAni, (TA,) and distinguished by the appellations of jumaAdaI AlOuwlaI and jumaAdaI AlMxirapu [the fifth and sixth months of the Arabian year]: (S, K:) it is of the measure fuEaAlaI, from Aljamodu; (S;) the two months to which it is applied being [said to be] so called because, when the months were named, these two fell in the season of the freezing of water: (ISd, L, Msb:) [but this derivation seems to have been invented when the two months thus named had fallen back, into, or beyond, the winter; for when they received this appellation, the former of them evidently commenced in March, and the latter ended in May; therefore I hold the opinion of M. Caussin de Perceval, that they were thus called because falling in a period when the earth had become dry and hard by reason of paucity of rain, from jamaAdN, an epithet applied to land upon which rain has not fallen, or from jumaAdaI, an
epithet applied to an eye that sheds few tears; which opinion is confirmed by the obvious derivations of the names of other months, SafarN and rabiyEN and ramaDaAnu and XawRaAlN:] afterwards, when the lunar months superseded the solar, the same names were retained: (Msb:) [see zamanN, and Alhijorapu:] jmAdI is determinate, (K,) being a proper name, (TA,) and of the fem. gender: (Msb, K:) if you find it masc., it is because it is made to accord to AlXRahoru: all the other names of the months are masc.: (Fr, IAmb, Msb:) the pl. is jumaAdayaAtN, (Fr, L, K,) agreeably with analogy; and if the form jimaAdN [a mistranscription for jamaAYidu, like HabaAYiru, pl. of HubaAraI,] were used, it would also be agreeable with analogy. (Fr, L.) The former of these two months is also called jumaAdaI xamosapK; and the latter, jumaAdaI sitRapK; (K;) which mean, respectively, Jumádà the fifth month and Jumádà the sixth month, from the commencement of the year. (TA.) Lebeed says, [describing a pair of wild asses,]
HatRaI UicaA salaxaA jumaAdaI sitRapF
jazaM faTaAla SiyaAmuhu waSiyaAmuhaA
[Until, when they both pass, and come to the end of, Jumádà, completing six months, they satisfy themselves with green pasture so as to be in no need of water, and his and her abstinence from water becomes of long continuance]: thus cited by Bundár; stRp being in the accus. case as a denotative of state, and by jmAdI being meant jmAdI AlMxrp: or, accord. to IAar, the poet said stRpK, meaning the six months of winter, which are the months of dew; and Aboo-'Amr Esh-Sheybánee says the like. (MF.) AHn says that the Arabs applied the name of jmAdI to The whole of the winter; [see above;] whether the winter were at the same time as the months so called or not: and Aboo-Sa'eed says the like. (L.) ― -b2- See also jaAmidN.

layolapN jumaAdiyRapN lylp jmAdyh lylp jmAdyp
layolapN jumaAdiyRapN A wintry night. (Aboo-Sa'eed, L.) [See jumaAdaI.]

jamRaAdN jmAd
jamRaAdN (tropical:) A sword such that he who is struck with it becomes motionless (yajomudu): (A, TA:) or a sharp, cutting, sword. (AA, K.)

jaAmidN jAmd
jaAmidN, applied to water, (Msb, K,) &c., (Msb,) [i. e.] anything fluid, or liquid, (K,) In a state of congelation, concretion, or solidity; freezing; as also jamodN↓; contr. of caAYibN: (Msb, K:) you say maMCN jamodN [as well as maMCN jaAmidN]: (Msb:) or jamodN↓ signifies what is congealed, or frozen, of water [&c.]; ice; (S, A;) contr. of cawobN: (S:) [see also jamadN:] it is originally an inf. n.: (S, Msb, K:) [or it is an epithet from jamuda, like DaxomN from Daxuma:] and jamadN↓ is a pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of jaAmidN, (S, Msb, K,) like as xadamN is of xaAdimN: (S, Msb:) you say, qado kavura Aljamadu [The frozen waters have become many]. (S.) [Hence,] muxRapN jaAmidapN A hard piece of marrow. (L.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Remaining fixed, stationary, or motionless. (Bd and Jel in xxvii. 90.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A thing that does not grow, or increase; [incapable of growth, or increase; inanimate;] as stone, in contradistinction to a tree [and an animal]. (Kull.) [See also jamaAdN.] You say, laka jaAmidu hecaA AlmaAli wacaAYibuhu (A, L, K *) (tropical:) To thee belongs, or shall belong, what consists of gold and silver [or the like inanimate things], of this property, and what consists of live stock, thereof: (L, K:) or what consists of stones, thereof, and what consists of trees, thereof: or what is solid, thereof, and what is fluid, or liquid, thereof. (L.) ― -b4- [Hence its application in lexicology and grammar to (assumed tropical:) A noun that is not an inf. n. nor derived from an inf. n.; a noun having the quality of a real substantive (Aisomi EayonK), opposed to that which has the quality of an ideal substantive (Aisomu maEonFI): and (assumed tropical:) a verb that has but one tense and no inf. n., as layosa and niEoma &c., opposed (as is said in the TA voce qado) to mutaSarRifN: it may be rendered (and so I have rendered it), in these cases, aplastic.] ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) Lifeless; dead. (Kull p. 147.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) Stupid, dull, wanting in intelligence; inert; not sharp, penetrating, vigorous, or effective, in the performing of affairs; or soft, without strength or sturdiness, and without endurance. (TA.) ― -b7- It is also applied to a man's state, or condition: you say rajulN jaAmidu AlHaAli (assumed tropical:) [A man in a stagnant, or unimproving, state or condition]. (S, L.) ― -b8- And to the eye: you say EayonN jaAmidapN (assumed tropical:) An eye that sheds no tears; (Ks, K;) as also jumaAdaI↓, (Ks, K,) and jamuwdN↓; (S, K;) or this last signifies (tropical:) an eye that sheds few tears. (A.) And rajulN jaAmidu AlEayoni, (A, K,) and AlEyn jamiydu↓, and AlEyn jamaAdu↓, (A,) (tropical:) A man whose eye sheds few tears; (A;) or whose eye sheds no tears. (K.) ― -b9- See also jamaAdN. ― -b10- Also, (L,) and mujomidN↓, (M, A, K,) and AlkafRi jamaAdu↓, (A, K,) (tropical:) Niggardly, penurious, or avaricious; (M, A, K;) niggardly of that which it is incumbent on him to give: (L:) and mujomidN↓, also, a man of little, or no, good; possessing little, or no, good. (K.) ＝ -A2- jawaAmidu, (as its pl., IAar, L,) Limits, or boundaries, or boundary-marks, between lands, (IAar, L, K, *) and between two dwellings. (L.)

mujomidN mjmd
mujomidN: see jaAmidN, last sentence but one, in two places. ― -b2- The person who is entrusted with the management of affairs in a game of chance (qimaAr [here meaning the game called Almayosir]): (K:) [i. q. DariybN:] or the person entrusted with the management of affairs among a people or party, (T, K, TA,) who does not take part in the game called Almayosir, except that he shuffles the arrows (yaDoribu bihaA) for the players, and has them placed in his hands, and is confided in with respect to them, and compels him who has incurred an obligation to fulfil it: (L, TA:) or one who takes no part in the game called Almayosir, (who is called baramN,) but who sometimes shuffles, or deals forth, the arrows, (yufiyDu bihaA,) for the players; so in the following verse of Tarafeh:
waOaSofara maDobuwHK naZarotu Hawiyrahu
EalaI AlnRaAri waQsotawodaEotuhu kafRa mujomidi
[And of many a yellow arrow, changed in colour by fire, I have awaited the sound over the fire, and I have deposited it in the hand of one taking no part in the game but only shuffling, or dealing forth, the arrows for the players]; meaning, I have awaited its sound, which was like an answer proceeding from it, when I straightened it and marked it, over the fire: (S:) [or, accord. to the EM (p. 105), where we find HiwaArahu in the place of Hawiyrahu, the meaning is, and of many a yellow arrow, &c., I have awaited the returning and gaining, while we were assembled at the fire, &c.:] or mjmd here means a man taking with both his hands so as not to let anything go forth from them: (AA, TA:) or, accord. to As, it here means a man entering upon Jumádà, which was in that [the poet's] time a month of cold: (S, K: *) or one whose arrow does not gain anything in the game called Almayosir: (L:) or a person in whom one confides, and who is tenacious of that which is in his hand or possession, and not to be deceived. (A 'Obeyd, TA.)

majomadapN mjmd mjmdh mjmdp
majomadapN A place in which ice is kept. (MA.)

huwa mujaAmidiI hw mjAmdI hw mjAmdy
huwa mujaAmidiI He is my neighbour, his house, or tent, adjoining mine. (K.)

1 jamVra
1: see 2, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also 4: ― -b2- and 5. ＝ -A3- Also jamarahu He gave him jamor [live, or burning, coals]. (K.) ＝ -A4- He put him aside, apart, away, or at a distance. (Th, K.) ― -b2- jamarti AlXRamosu Alqamari, aor.
jamura
, The sun concealed [or as it were put out] the moon [by its proximity thereto: see Aibonu jamiyrK]. (IAar, TA.) ＝ -A5- jamara [said of the moon, It became concealed by its proximity to the sun: see an ex. voce jamiyrN: and see also 4]. ＝ -A6- Also, (K,) aor.
jamira
, (TA,) He (a horse) leaped while shackled; and so Ajmr↓. (K.)

2 jmRr jmr
2. jmRr, inf. n. tajomiyrN; (K;) and jamara↓; (Msb;) He collected together (Msb, K) a people, and anything. (Msb.) ― -b2- jamRarato XaEarahaA, inf. n. tajomiyrN; (S, A, K;) and jamaratohu↓, (Msb,) and Oajomaratohu↓; (K;) She (a woman) collected together her hair, (S, A, Msb, K,) and tied it in knots, or made it knotted and crisp, (Eaqadatohu, S, A, Msb,) at the back of her neck; (S, A, Msb, K;) not letting it hang down loosely: (S:) or plaited it: (T, TA:) and jmRr XaEarahu he collected together his hair at the back of his head: (Mgh:) and raOosahaA Ajmrt↓ she collected together the hair of her head, and plaited it: and XaEarahu Ajmr↓ he disposed his hair in cawaAYib [or locks hanging down loosely from the middle of the head to the back, or plaits hanging down]. (TA.) ― -b3- And jmRr It (a thing) necessitated a people to unite together. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, (inf. n. as above, S,) He (a commander, As, A) detained the army in the territory of the enemy, (S, K,) or on the frontier of the enemy's country, (A,) and did not bring them back (S, A, K) from the frontier: (S:) the doing of which is forbidden: (TA:) or he detained them long on the frontier of the enemy, and did not give them permission to return to their families: (As, TA:) or he collected them on the frontiers of the enemy, and kept them from returning to their families.
(TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 4: ― -b2- and 5. ＝ -A3- jmRr AlvRawoba, (A, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. as above, (Mgh, Msb,) He fumigated the garment with perfume; (A, * Mgh, Msb;) as also Ajmrhu↓: (Mgh, Msb, K:) but the former is the more common. (Mgh.) And jmRr Almasojida, (Mgh, TA,) or Ajmrhu↓, accord. to different modes of writing the surname of a certain No'eym, i. e., AlmujamRiru or Almujomiru, (TA,) [and accord. to different copies of the K,] He fumigated the mosque with perfume: (Mgh:) [or perhaps it may mean he strewed the ground of the mosque with pebbles; from jamorapN; like HaSRabahu, from HaSabapN or HaSobaMCu or HaSobapN.] ― -b2- And jmRr [for jmRr laHomFA] He put flesh-meat upon live coals [to roast]. (A.) ＝ -A4- Also, (A,) inf. n. as above, (S, A,) He (a pilgrim, A) threw the pebbles [in the valley of Minè]; (S;) and so Astjmr↓. (TA in art. tw.) Hence, yawomu AltRajomiyr [The day of the throwing of the pebbles, by the pilgrims, in the valley of Minè]. (A.) [See jamorapN.] ＝ -A5- jmRr AlnRaxolapa, (inf. n. as above, A,) He cut off the heart, or pith, (jumRaAr,) of the palmtree. (S, A. K. *)

4 Oajomarato XaEarahaA c
4. Oajomarato XaEarahaA, and raOosahaA; and Ajmr XaEarahu: see 2. ― -b2- Ajmr AlOamoru baniI fulaAnK The thing, or affair, included the common mass, (K,) or the whole mass, (TA,) of the sons of such a one within the compass of its relation or relations, or its effect or effects, &c. (K, TA.) ― -b3- Ajmr AlnRaxolu He computed by conjecture the quantity of the fruit upon the palm-trees, and then reckoned, and summed up the quantity so computed. (K.) He who does so is termed mujomirN↓. (TA.) ― -b4- Ajmr Alxayolu He prepared the horses for racing &c. by feeding them with food barely sufficient to sustain them, after they had become fat, (OaDomarahaA,) and collected them together. (K.) ＝ -A2- Ajmr Alqawomu EalaI AlXRaIoCi, (S,) or ElI AlOamori; (K;) and jmRr↓, (K,) inf. n. tajomiyrN; (TA;) and jamara↓, and Astjmr↓; (K;) The people, or party, agreed together to do the thing, (S, K,) and united for it. (K.) [See also 5.] ＝ -A3- Ajmr AlvRawoba, and Almasojida: see 2. ― -b2- Ajmr AlnRaAra, inf. n. mujomarN, He prepared the fire [app. in a mijomarap]. (S, * K.) ＝ -A4- Ajmr said of a camel, He had his foot rendered even, so that there was no line between its phalanges, (K, TA,) in consequence of its having been wounded by the pebbles, and become hard. (TA.) ＝ -A5- Also, said of a camel, (S,) and of a man, (TA,) He hastened, or was quick, in his pace, or going; (S, K;) and ran: (TA:) you should not say Ajmz. (S.) ― -b2- See also 1. ＝ -A6- Oajomarati AllRayolapu The night had its moon concealed by its proximity to the sun. (K, * TA.) [See also 1.]

5 tjmRr jmr tjmr
5. tjmRr It (a people, or party,) collected together; (A, Mgh, TA;) [and] so jamara↓; this verb being intrans. as well as trans.: (Msb: [see 2:]) and jmRr↓ it (a tribe) collected together, and became one band. (As, TA.) ― -b2- It (an army) became detained in the territory of the enemy, and was not brought back (S, K) from the frontier; (S;) as also Astjmr↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also 10.

8 Ajtmr biAlmijomari Ajtmr bAlmjmr
8. Ajtmr biAlmijomari, (K,) and Astjmr↓, (AHn, A, Mgh,) He fumigated, or perfumed, himself with aloes-wood [or the like]. (AHn, A, Mgh, K.)

10 Astjmr Astjmr
10. Astjmr: see 4: ― -b2- and 5: ＝ -A2- and 8: ＝ -A3- and 2. ― -b2- Also, [and vulgarly tjmRr↓,] He performed the purification termed AisotinojaMC with jimaAr, (Mgh, Msb, K,) i. e., with stones, (AZ, S, Msb,) or small stones. (Mgh, TA.)

jamorN jmr
jamorN: see what next follows, in two places.

jamorapN jmr jmrh jmrp
jamorapN A live, or burning, coal; a piece of smokeless burning fire: (Msb:) or burning fire: (K:) [but the former is the correct explanation:] when cold, [before it is kindled,] it is called faHomN (TA) [or HaTabN &c.]: and when reduced to powder by burning, ramaAdN: (L in art. rmd:) from jamRara “ he collected together: ” (Mgh:) pl. jamorN↓ (S, Msb, K) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.] and jamaraAtN and jimaArN. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence,] fiI Aljamoru↓ kabidiI (tropical:) [Live coals are in my liver]. (A.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] AljamaraAtu AlvRalaAvu (assumed tropical:) [The three live coals; meaning the first three degrees of heat]: the first is in the air; the second, in the earth, or dust; and the third, in the water: [or, accord. to the modern Egyptian almanacs, the first is in the air, and is cold, or cool; the second, in the water, and is lukewarm; and the third, in the earth, or dust, and is hot: the first falling exactly a zodiacal month before the vernal equinox; and each lasting seven days:] whence the saying, kaAna celika Einoda suquwTi Aljamorapi (assumed tropical:) [That was at the time of the falling of the live coal]; i. e., when the heat had acquired strength. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Any body of men that have united together, and become one band, and that do not form a confederacy with any others: (S:) or a body of men that congregate by themselves, because of their strength and their great valour; [said to be] from the same word signifying “ a live coal: ” (Msb:) or any people that endure patiently fighting with those who fight them, not forming a confederacy with any others, nor uniting themselves to any others: (Lth, TA:) or a tribe that does not unite itself to any other: (K:) or that comprises three hundred horsemen, (K,) or the like thereof: (TA:) or a tribe that fights with a company of tribes: (TA:) pl. jamaraAtN. (S, Msb, K.) You say, banuw fulaAnK jamorapN The sons of such a one are a people able to defend themselves, and strong. (TA.) jamaraAtu AlEarabi is an appellation especially applied to three tribes; namely, Benoo-Dabbeh Ibn-Udd, and Benu-l-Hárith Ibn-Kaab, and Benoo-Numeyr Ibn-' Ámir; (S, A, K;) the first of which became extinguished by confederating with Er-Ribáb, and the second by confederating with Medhhij; the third only remaining [a jmrp] because it formed no confederacy: (S:) or it is applied to 'Abs and El-Hárith and Dabbeh; all the offspring of a woman who dreamt that three live coals issued from her faroj. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also A thousand horsemen. (S, K.) One says jamorapN kaAljamorapi [A troop of a thousand horsemen like the live coal]. (S, TA.) ＝ -A3- A pebble: (S, K:) or a stone: (Msb:) or a small stone or pebble: pl. jimaArN (Mgh, Msb, Et-Towsheeh, TA) and jamaraAtN. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- Also sing. of jamaraAtN (S, Msb, K) and of jimaArN (TA) in the appellations jamaraAtu minFI (Msb) or jamaraAtu AlmanaAsiki (S, K) and jimaAru AlmanaAsiki, (TA,) which were three in number, (S, Msb, K,) called Aljamorapu AlOuwlaI and Aljamorapu AlwusoTaI and jamorapu AlEaqabapi, (K,) at which jamaraAt (i. e. small pebbles, TA) were cast; (S, K;) each of these being a heap of pebbles, at Minè, and each two heaps [or rather each heap and that next to it] being about a bow-shot apart: (Msb:) accord. to Th, from jamarahu “ he put him aside, apart, away, or at a distance: ” or from Oajomara “ he hastened; ” because Adam pelted Iblees in Minè, and he hastened away before him: (K, * TA:) or from tjmRrwA “ they collected together: ” (Mgh:) or from jamarahu “ he collected it together. ” (Msb.) ＝ -A4- See also jamiyrapN.

jamaArN jmAr
jamaArN An assembly; an assemblage; a collection: (K:) a people assembled together. (TA.) ― -b2- EadRa Uibilahu jamaArFA He counted, or numbered, his camels in one herd, (As, TA,) by looking at their aggregate. (As, T voce naZiyrN, q. v.) ― -b3- jaAWuwA jamaAraI↓, and with tenween, [i. e., app., jamaArFA, not, as might be thought at first sight, jamaArFI, a form which MF disapproves, though it is said in the TA that his disapproval requires consideration,] They came all together, or all of them. (K.)

jamiyrN jmyr
jamiyrN A place of assembly of a people. (S, K.) ― -b2- AibonaA jamiyrK The night and the day: (S, K:) so called because of the assembling [of people therein]; like as they are called AibonaA samiyrK because people held conversation therein: (S:) or the two nights during which the moon becomes concealed by its proximity to the sun. (TA.) And Aibonu jamiyrK, (IAar, S,) or Aibonu jumayorK↓, (Lh, Th,) The moon in the night when it is concealed by its proximity to the sun: (TA:) or the moon in the end of the [lunar] month; because the sun conceals it (tajomuruhu, i. e. tuwaAriyhi): (IAar, TA:) or the dark night: (S:) or the night in which the moon does not rise, either in the first part thereof or in the last: (TA:) or the last night of the [lunar] month. (Aboo-'Amr Ez-Záhid, TA.) You say, jaMCanaA faHomapa Qbonu jumayorK↓ [He came to us in the darkest part of the moonless night, or of the night in which the moon did not rise]. (Th, TA.) And laA OafoEalu celika maA jamara Qbonu jumayorK↓ [I will not do that as long as the moon in the end of the lunar month becomes concealed by its proximity to the sun; i. e., I will never do it]. (Lh, TA.) ― -b3- jamiyru AlXRaEari What is collected together, of the hair, and tied in knots, or made knotted and crisp. (TA. [See 2.])

Aibonu jumayorK Abn jmyr
Aibonu jumayorK: see jamiyrN, in three places.

jamiyrapN jmyrh jmyrp
jamiyrapN A plait of hair: (T, Msb, K:) and i. q. cuWaAbapN [app. here meaning a plait of hair hanging down; or a lock of hair hanging down loosely from the middle of the head to the back]: (TA:) and jamorapN↓ a lock of hair: (TA:) pl. of the former jamaAYiru. (T, Msb.)

jaAWuwA jamaAraI c
jaAWuwA jamaAraI: see jamaArN.

jumRaArN jmAr
jumRaArN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and jaAmuwrN↓ (K) [each a coll. gen. n.] The heart, or pith, [or cerebrum,] of the palm-tree, (S, A, Msb, K, TA,) that is in the summit of its head, which part is cut off, and its outer portion is stripped off from the pith within it, which is a white substance, like a piece of the hump of a camel, large and soft: it is eaten with honey: (TA:) from it come forth the fruit and the branches; and when it is cut off, the tree dies: (Msb:) the spathe comes forth from it, amid the part whence two branches divide: (TA:) the head of the palmtree; a soft, white substance: from jamRara “ he collected together; ” for a similar reason termed kavarN: (Mgh:) n. un. jumRaArapN. (A, TA.) [See also qalobN.] You say, lahu saAqN kaAljumRaArapi He has a shank like a piece of the heart of the palm-tree. (A.) And AljumRaAru fiI xalaAxilihinRa (tropical:) [Legs like the heart of the palm-tree are within their anklets]. (A.) Sakhr El-Hudhalee says, using a double trope, likening the fresh juicy stalks of the barodiIR to the pith of the palm-tree, and then applying this expression to the legs of a woman,
UicaA EuTifato xalaAxuluhunRa gaSRabo
bijumRaAraAti barodiIRK xidaAli
(tropical:) [When their anklets are bent, (for the anklet of the Arab woman is formed of a piece of silver, or other metal, which is bent round so that the two ends nearly meet,) they are choked, or entirely filled up, with plump legs like the pith of the papyrus]. (A, TA.)

jaAmirN jAmr
jaAmirN: see mujamRirN.

jaAmuwrN jAmwr
jaAmuwrN: see jumRaArN. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A well-known appertenance of a ship or boat; [i. e., the head of the mast; a kind of truck, which is made of harder wood than the mast itself.] (TA.) ― -b3- And hence, (tropical:) The head [absolutely]: but accord. to Kr, only the vulgar call it so. (TA.)

Oajomaru c
Oajomaru occurs in a trad., where it is said, daxalotu Almasojida waAlnRaAsu Oajomaru maA kaAnuwA, meaning I entered the mosque when the people were in their most collected state. (TA.)

mujomarN mjmr
mujomarN: see mijomarN: ― -b2- and see also mijomarapN, in two places. ― -b3- Also, (S, K,) and mujomirN↓, (K,) A hard solid hoof: (AA, S, K:) and a hard, strong, compact camel's foot: or one that has been wounded by the stones, and become hard. (TA.)

mujomirN mjmr
mujomirN: see mujamRirN, in two places: ― -b2- and OaJomara AlnRaxola: ＝ -A2- and see also mujomarN.

mijomaro mjmr
mijomaro: see mijomarapN. ― -b2- Also, (Mgh, Msb, K,) and mujomarN↓, (K,) Aloes-wood, (AHn, Mgh, Msb, K,) and the like, (Mgh,) or other substance, (Msb,) with which clothes are fumigated, (Mgh,) or with which one perfumes himself by burning it: (Msb:) pl. majaAmiru. (Mgh.)

mijomarapN mjmrh mjmrp
mijomarapN and mijomarN↓, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) which latter is sometimes fem. [like the former], (K,) or fem. when by it is meant the fire (AlnRaAr), and masc. when meaning the place [of the fire], (TA,) and mujomarN↓, (K,) A vessel for fumigation; a censer; (Msb;) a vessel in which live coals are put, (S, K,) with incense, or some odoriferous substance for fumigation; (K;) a vessel in which aloes-wood is burned: it is disapproved, because generally of silver; but not so what is termed midoxanapN: (Mgh:) or mujomarN↓ signifies the thing for which the live coals are prepared: (S:) [and mijomarapN also signifies a blacksmith's fire-place: (K in art. kwr:)] pl. majaAmiru. (S.)

mujamRarN mjmr
mujamRarN Flesh-meat put upon live coals [to roast]. (A.)

mujamRirN mjmr
mujamRirN (S, Z) and mujomirN↓ (TA) One who collects together his hair, and ties it in knots, or makes it knotted and crisp, at the back of his neck, not letting it hang down loosely: (S:) or who plaits the hair of his head. (TA.) He who does so (while he is a muHorim, TA) is commanded to shave his head. (S and TA from a trad.) ＝ -A2- Also, both the former and jaAmirN↓, which is a possessive epithet, without a verb, One whose business is to fumigate garments [&c.] with perfume. (TA.)

1 jamaza jmz
1. jamaza, (S, A, &c.,) aor.
jamiza
, inf. n. jamozN (S, Msb, K) and jamazaI, (K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) said of a camel, (S, K,) and of a man, (A, K,) [He went at a gentle trot or run;] he went a pace quicker than that termed EanaqN, (S, A, Msb, K,) but not so quick as that termed HuDorN, (K,) or not so quick as a vehement HuDor; (TA;) he went the pace with which corpses are conveyed [to the tomb; which, according to the practice prescribed by Mohammad, is a quick pace]: (TA:) or simply, he went, or went along: (Msb:) and he ran; syn. EadaA: (Mgh, Msb:) and he went quickly. (Mgh, Msb, TA.) You say, jamaza biQlojinaAzapi He went a pace quicker than that termed EanaqN [with the corpse upon its bier]. (A.) And jamaza AlrRajulu fiI AlOaroDa The man went away into, or in, the country or land. (Kr, K.)

2 jmRz jmz
2. jmRz, if used, He rode a camel such as is called jamRaAzN or jamRaAzapN. See the act. part. n., below.]

jamazaI jmzI jmzy
jamazaI a subst. from jamaza; [signifying A gentle trot or run; a pace quicker than that termed EanaqN, but not so quick as that termed HuDorN, or not so quick as a vehement HuDor; &c.] (Msb.) You say, huwa yaEoduw AljamazaI, (A,) and AlnRaAqapu taEoduw AljamazaI, and in like manner Alfarasu, (Ks, S,) [He, and the she-camel, and the mare or horse, runs at the pace termed jamazaI.] ― -b2- See also jamRaAzN, in two places.

jamRaAzN jmAz
jamRaAzN, applied to a he-camel, (S, K,) and jamRaAzapN, applied to a she-camel, (K,) That is ridden by the mujamRiz; (S;) that goes the pace described above, [voce jamazaI and] voce jamaza: (K, TA:) [the latter is also said in the TA to be mn MlaAt AlmHAml; but the correct reading seems to be mino OuwlaAt AlmaHaAmili; and the meaning, of those that carry the vehicles called mHAml, pl. of maHomil.] ― -b2- HimaArN jamRaAzN An ass that leaps, jumps, springs, or bounds, quickly: (K:) and HimaArN jamazaI↓ a quick ass; (S, K;) or an ass that leaps, jumps, springs, or bounds, quickly, and is swift; (TA;) the latter word in this phrase used as a masc. and fem. epithet, though its final letter is a denotative of the fem. gender. (Ham p. 277. [See below; and see also HayadaI.]) Umeiyeh Ibn-Abee-'Áïdh (S, TA) El-Hudhalee (TA) says,
kaOanRiI waraHoliI UicaA ruEotuhaA
jaAziYK biAlrRimaAli EalaI jamazaI↓
[As though I and my she-camel's saddle, when I frightened her, were upon a swift wild ass satisfied with green pasture, so as to be in no need of water, in the sands]. (S, TA.) He likens his she-camel to a wild ass, to which he applies the epithet jmzI, that is, swift; meaning, EalaI HimaArK jamazaI. (TA.) As says that this is the only epithet of the measure faEalaI heard by him applied to a male; and that IAar cited the verse above to him saying HayRidK biAldRiHaAli, meaning Eani AldRiHaAli, [i. e., “ shying and turning aside from the hollows, narrow at the top but wide below, in the ground: ” but this is probably a reading of some in the place of HayadaI biAldRiHaAli, which ends the next verse, agreeably with what is said in the L in art. Hyd:] Az says that EalaI jamazaI may be explained as for EalaI EayorK ciI jamazaI, i. e., upon an ass having the mode of pace termed jamazaI; and naAqapN wakaraI has a similar meaning. (TA.) ― -b3- See also mujamRizN.

jumRayozN jmyz
jumRayozN (S, K) and jumRayozaI↓ (K) [The sycamorefig: and the sycamore fig-tree: ficus sycomorus; also called the Egyptian fig:] the male fig; (K, TA;) which is found in the Ghowr, or Ghór, [here meaning the Valley of the Jordan,] (TA,) and is sweet: (K, TA:) this is the yellow: the black makes the mouth bleed: (TA:) it is of various colours, or kinds, (OalowaAn,) (K, * TA;) abundant in Syria and in Egypt: n. un. jumRayozapN: (TA:) [a fruit] resembling the tiyn [or common fig]: (S:) AHn says, of the kinds of fig is the fig of the jumRayoz, a sweet, moist fig, which has long fruit-stalks, and which is dried in the sun: and there is another species of the jmRyz, the fruit of which is like the fig in make, but its leaves are smaller than those of the fig, and its figs are yellow, of a small size, and black: it is found in the Ghowr, or Ghór, and is called the male fig: the yellow is sweet: the black makes the mouth bleed: and its fig has no stalk, but cleaves to the wood. ('Abd-el-Lateef, Account of Egypt: White's ed., entitled Abdollatiphi Historiæ Aegypti Compendium: p. 22. See also De Sacy's notes to his transl. of that work, pp. 82—86.) ― -b2- [AljumRayozapu also signifies (assumed tropical:) The pudendum muliebre: opposed to AltRiynapu as meaning “ the anus. ”]

jumRayozaI jmyz jmyzI jmyzy
jumRayozaI: see jumRayozN.

jumRayoziIRN jmyz jmyzI jmyzy
jumRayoziIRN A seller of jumRayoz. (TA.)

mujamRizN mjmz
mujamRizN One who rides the camel called jamRaAz, (S, * TA,) or who rides the she-camel called jamRaAzap; (K, * TA;) as also jamRaAzN↓. (TA.)

1 jamasa jms
1. jamasa, (A, Msb, K,) aor.
jamusa
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. jumuwsN (S, Msb, K) and jamosN; (TA;) and jamusa, aor.
jamusa
; (TA;) It (grease, As, S, A, Msb, K, and clarified butter, and water, A, K, but jamada is more commonly said of the last, K, or jamasa is incorrect when said of water, As, TA) congealed. (As, S, A, Msb, K.)

jumosapN jmsh jmsp
jumosapN A tough date: (IDrd, * M, K, * TA:) a date ripening (As, S, Z, K) altogether, (As, Z, K, TA,) but as yet hard, not mellow, or digestible, or easy of digestion: (As, S, Z, K:) pl. jumasN. (As, TA.) [See busorN.] ＝ -A2- Also A distinct number, or herd, of camels. (O, K.)

jaAmisN jAms
jaAmisN Grease, (A,) and clarified butter, (TA,) and water, (S,) or it is improperly applied to the last, (As, TA,) in a state of congelation. (S, A, Mgh, TA.) ― -b2- A plant that has lost its freshness, or juiciness, (AHn, K,) and become old, and hard, or tough. (AHn, TA.) ― -b3- SaxorapN jaAmisapN A tough rock, (TA,) firm in its place. (K, TA.) [In the TA is added muqoXaEirRapN: but this is evidently a mistranscription, for musotaqirRapN, which adds nothing to the explanation.]

jaAmuwsN jAmws
jaAmuwsN [The buffalo;] a kind of baqar; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) well known: (K:) n. un. with p: (K:) and pl. jawaAmiysu: (S, Msb, K:) an arabicized word, (T, S, K,) from the Persian; (T, S;) originally GaAwo miyXo. (T, K.)

1 jamaXahu c
1. jamaXahu, (S, A, K,) aor.
jamiXa
and
jamuXa
, (TA,) inf. n. jamoXN, (S,) He shaved it, or removed its hair; (S, A, K;) namely, his pubes; (S;) or his head. (A, K.) And jamaXatohu She shaved it; namely, her pudendum; or removed its hair: and it (nuwrap, q. v.) removed it; namely, hair. (A.)

jamuwXN c
jamuwXN, applied to nuwrap [q. v.], That removes hair; (S, K;) as also jamiyXN↓. (K.) ― -b2- Applied to a year (sanapN), (assumed tropical:) That shaves off, (S,) or nips, shrinks, shrivels, or blasts, [lit., burns, see OaHoraqa,] (K,) the plants, or herbage. (S, K.)

jamiyXN c
jamiyXN, applied to the pubes, Shaven, or having its hair removed, (S, A, K, TA,) by means of nuwrap [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- Applied to a place, (assumed tropical:) [Shorn of its plants, or herbage; or] having in it no plants, or herbage. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also jamuwXN.

1 jamaEa jmE
1. jamaEa, (S, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
jamaEa
, (Mgh, TA,) inf. n. jamoEN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He collected; brought, or gathered, together; gathered up; assembled; congregated; mustered; drew together; or contracted; (Mgh, Er-Rághib, B, K; *) a thing; (Er-Rághib, Msb, B;) so that the several parts or portions became near together; (Er-Rághib, B;) or a thing in a scattered, or dispersed, state; (Fr, S;) and a number of men; (Fr;) as also jmRE↓; [or this has only an intensive signification;] and AjmE↓. (TA.) [See also the inf. n., jamoEN, below; and] see 2; and 10. ― -b2- [jamaEa bayonahumaA He brought them two together, into a state of union, after separation; and particularly, reconciled them; conciliated them: and he, or it, united, connected, or formed a connexion between, them two: see 3 (last sentence) in art. dnw.] ― -b3- jamaEa Ealayohi viyaAbahu He put on, or attired himself with, his clothes. (TA.) ― -b4- jamaEati AljaAriyapu The girl put on the diroE and the ximaAr and the miloHafap; (S, TA;) i. e., (tropical:) became a young woman; (S, K, TA;) became full-grown. (TA.) ― -b5- maA jamaEotu biQmoraOapK qaTRu, and Eani QmoraOapK, (assumed tropical:) I have never gone in to a woman; or I have never had a woman conducted to me as my bride. (Ks, K.) ― -b6- faQjomaEuwA kayodakumo, and fajamaEa kayodahu: see 4. ― -b7- jamaEa Oamorahu: see 4. ― -b8- [jamaEa also signifies He composed, arranged, or settled, a thing, or an affair; as in the phrase jamaEa QllRehu Xamolahu: see art. Xml. ― -b9- Also It comprised, comprehended, or contained.] ― -b10- Also He pluralized a word; made it to have a plural, or plurals. (The Lexicons passim.)

2 jmRE jmE
2. jmRE, (Fr, Msb,) inf. n. tajomiyEN, (K,) He collected; brought, or gathered, together; gathered up; assembled; congregated; mustered; drew together; or contracted; [thus I render jamaEa, as explained above;] much; with much, or extraordinary, energy, or effectiveness, or the like; vigorously; or well. (Bd in civ. 2; Msb, K.) Thus in the Kur [civ. 2], AlRaciI jamRaEa maAlFA waEadRadahu (S, * Bd) Who hath collected much wealth, and hath made it a provision for the casualties of fortune, or reckoned it time after time: (Bd:) [or who hath amassed, or accumulated, wealth, &c.:] or who hath gained, acquired, or earned, wealth, &c.; thus differing from jamaEa, explained above: but it is allowable to say maAlFA jamaEa↓, without teshdeed; (Fr;) and thus it is [generally] read in this passage of the Kur. (Bd.) See also 1. ― -b2- HamRaEato, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) She (a hen) collected her eggs in her belly. (K, TA.) ― -b3- jamRaEuwA, (inf. n. as above, S,) They were present on the Friday, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or with the congregation [then collected], (Mgh,) and performed the prayers [with the congregation] on that day. (S, Mgh.) ― -b4- Hence the saying, OawRalu jumoEapK jumRiEato fiI AlUisolaAmu baEoda Almadiynapi bijuWaAviI [The first Friday that was observed by the performance of congregational prayer in the time of El-Islám, after the observance thereof in El-Medeeneh, was in Ju-áthà]. (TA.)

3 jAmEhu EalaI Oamori kacaA c
3. jAmEhu EalaI Oamori kacaA, (S, K,) inf. n. mujaAmaEapN (TK) [and jimaAEN], He combined with him, (maEahu AjtmE↓, S, K, TA,) and aided him, (TA,) to do such a thing. (S, * K, * TA.) It is said in a trad. of Aboo-Dharr, walaA jimaAEa lanaA fiymaA baEodu i. e. lanaA laAQjotimaAEa↓ [which may mean Nor any combining, or nor any coming together, for us afterwards: see 8]. (TA.) ― -b2- jAmE QmoraOatahu, (Msb,) inf. n. mujaAmaEapN (S, Msb, K) and jimaAEN, (Mgh, Msb,) (tropical:) He lay with his wife; compressed her. (S, * Mgh, * Msb, K. *) [The latter inf. n. is the more common as meaning Coïtus conjugalis, or the act of compressing]. ＝ -A2- AisotaOojara AlOajiyra mujaAmaEpF, and jimaAEFA, He hired the hireling for a certain pay every week. (Lh, * TA.)

4 AjmE OjmE AjmE jmE
4. AjmE: see 1. OajomaEotu AlXRaIoCa signifies I put the thing together; such, for instance, as spoil, or plunder. (S.) You say, OajomaEotu AlnRahobi, meaning I collected together from every quarter the camels taken as spoil from the people to whom they belonged, and drove them away: (AHeyth:) or UijomaAEN signifies [simply] the driving of camels together, or collectively. (K.) ― -b2- AlUijomaAEu also signifies The composing and settling a thing which has been discomposed [and unsettled]; as an opinion upon which one determines, resolves, or decides: (TA:) or jaEolu AlOamori jamiyEFA baEoda tafarRuqihi, (AHeyth, K,) i. e. the determining, resolving, or deciding, upon an affair, so as to make it firmly settled, [after it had been unsettled in the mind, or] after considering what might be its issues, or results, and saying at one time, I will do thus, and at another time, I will do thus. (AHeyth.) You say, OajomaEotu AlOamora, (Ks, S, Mgh, * Msb, K,) and EalaI AlOamori, (Mgh, * Msb, K,) I determined, resolved, or decided, upon the affair; (Ks, S, Mgh, * Msb, K;) as though I collected myself, or my mind, for it; (TA;) as, for instance, a journeying, and a fasting, (Mgh, Msb,) and a going forth, and a tarrying or an abiding; (TA;) and in like manner, Oamorahu jamaEa↓ He determined, resolved, or decided, upon his affair; as, for instance, a fasting: (TA:) and OajomaEotu AlrRaOoIi I determined, or settled, the opinion. (TA.) You say also, OajomiEo Oamoraka walaA tadaEohu munotaXirFA [Determine thou, or decide, upon thine affair, and do not leave it unsettled]. (S.) The saying, in the Kur [x. 72], faOajomaEuwA Oamorakumo waXurakaMCa kumo means Then determine ye, or resolve, or decide, upon your affair, (Fr, Ibn-'Arafeh, Bd,) and prepare for it, (Fr,) or AijoEaluwhu jamiyEFA, [which has the former of these meanings, as shown above,] (AHeyth,) and call ye your companions, (Fr, S, Bd, K,) XrkACkm being governed in the accus. case by the verb understood, (Bd, TA,) becanse the verb in the text is not used with XrkAC for its object, (S, K,) but only the unaugmented verb: (S:) or the meaning is then determine ye, with your companions, upon your affair; (Bd, K;) so says Aboo-Is-hák, adding that what Fr says is erroneous: (TA:) or then determine ye upon your affair and the affair of your companions, for waOamora XurakaAYikumo. (Bd.) It is also said that the phrase, in the Kur [xx. 67], faOajomiEuwA kayodakumo means Therefore determine ye, or resolve, or decide, upon your artifice, or stratagem: (TA:) but some read kayodakumo faQjomaEuwA↓, (Bd, TA,) meaning therefore combine ye all your artifice; leave nothing thereof unexerted; (TA;) and this latter reading is favoured by the phrase kayodahu fajamaE↓ [in verse 62 of the same ch.]. (Bd.) ― -b3- Also The agreeing, or uniting, in opinion. (K, * TA.) You say, OajomaEuwA EalaI AlOamori meaning They agreed, or were of one mind or opinion, upon, or respecting, the affair; (Mgh, Msb;) [and so Ealayohi AjtmEwA↓;
and Elyh tjmREwA↓.] ― -b4- Also The preparing [a thing], or making [it] ready; syn. AlUiEodaAdu. (K, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, AlAaEodaAdu.]) You say, OajomaEotu kacaA I prepared, or made ready, such a thing. (TA.) And OajomiEuwA Oamorakumo Prepare ye for your affair. (Fr.) ― -b5- Also The binding the teats of a she-camel all together with the SiraAr, q. v. (K.) You say, AjmE biAlnRaAqapi, (S, TA,) and AjmE AlnRaAqapi, (TA,) He so bound the teats of the she-camel; (S, TA;) and so OakomaXa bihaA. (TA.) ― -b6- Also The drying [a thing]; drying [it] up; making [it] dry; syn. AltRajofiyfu waAlUiybaAsu. (K TA. [In the CK, erroneously, Altaxofuyfu wAlAiyonAsu.]) Hence the saying of Aboo-Wejzeh Es-Saadee,
waOajomaEati AlhawaAjiru kulRa rajoEK
mina AlOajomaAdi waAldRamivi AlbavaMCi
i.e. [And the vehement mid-day-heats] dried up every pool left by a torrent [of the hard and elevated grounds and of the soft and even ground]. (TA.) ― -b7- AjmE AlmaTaru AlOaroDi The rain made the whole of the land, both its soft tracts and its hard tracts, to flow: (K:) and in like manner you say, OajomaEati AlOaroDu saAYilapF The land flowed in its soft tracts [as well as in its hard tracts; i. e., in every part]. (TA.) [See also 10.]

5 tajamRaEa
5: see 8, in three places: and see also 4, latter half.

7 AnjmE Eani AlnRaAsi AnjmE En AlnAs
7. AnjmE Eani AlnRaAsi [He withdrew himself from men]. (TA in art. qbD.)

8 AjtmE OjtmE AjtmE QjtmE
8. AjtmE It (a thing in a scattered or dispersed state, S, and a number of men, Msb, [and a number of things,]) became collected, brought together, gathered together, gathered up, assembled, congregated, mustered, drawn together, or contracted; or it collected, collected itself together, gathered itself together, came together, assembled, congregated, drew itself together, contracted itself; coalesced; combined; (K, TA;) so that the several parts or portions became near [or close] together; (TA;) as also AijodamaEa, (K,) with d [substituted for the t]; (TA;) and tjmRE↓ and AstjmE↓ signify the same: (Msb, K:) and tjmREwA↓ signifies they became collected, &c., [from several places, or] hence and thence. (S, K:) [See also 10.] You say also, AjtmE maEahu (Mgh) and bihi (Msb) [meaning He was, or became, in company with him; came together with him; met with him; met him; had a meeting, or an interview, with him]. And AjtmE maEahu EalaI Oamori kacaA: (S, K:) see 3, first sentence: and see the sentence there next following. And in like manner, EalaI tjmREwA↓ fulaAnK They combined, conspired, or leagued, together against such a one. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA in art. Dfr.) [See also AjtmEwA EalaI AlOamori in 4, latter half.] You also say, AijotamaEati MraAWuhumo EalaI AlOamori [Their opinions agreed together, or were in unison, upon, or respecting, the affair]. (Er-Rághib.) And AijotamaEato XaraAYiTu AlUimaAmapi The conditions of the office of Imám occurred together [or were combined, or they coexisted, in such a case]; as also AisotajomaEato↓. (Msb: [but it is implied in the Mgh that the latter verb in this sense is not of established authority.]) [See a similar ex. voce ArtfE.] ― -b2- [He, or it, was, or became, compact in make or frame, compressed, contracted, or the like. ― -b3- And hence,] He (a man) attained to his full state of manly vigour, and his beard became fullgrown. (K, TA.) The verb is not thus used in speaking of a woman. (S, TA.) ― -b4- [Hence also,] AjtmE fiI AlHaAjapi [He was quick and vigorous in executing the needful affair, or in accomplishing that which was wanted; as though he compacted his frame, and collected all his energy: see maXaI mujotamiEFA, below: and see also 10]. (TA in art. kmX.) ― -b5- [Hence also,] AijotamaEati Alqidoru The cooking-pot boiled. (Z, TA.) ― -b6- [Hence also, AjtmE said of a thing, or an affair, It was, or became, composed, arranged, or settled.]

10 UisotajomaEa
10: AstjmE kulRa majomaEK↓ [He desired, or demanded, the collecting together of every body of soldiers; or he summoned together every body of soldiers]: said of him who demands, or summons, armies, or military forces. (S, TA.) [But this usage of the verb is perhaps post-classical: for Mtr says,] With respect to the saying of ElAbeewardee,
XaMmiyRapN tasotajomiEu AlXRawola Harojafu
[A north wind, cold and vehement, inviting to collect themselves together the she-camels whose milk has dried up, they having passed seven or eight months since bringing forth, or since pregnancy], it seems that he has compared this verb with the generality of others of the same class, [and so derived the meaning in which he has here used it,] or that he heard it [in that sense] from the people of the cities, or towns, or villages, and cultivated lands. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- AstjmE used intransitively is syn. with AjtmE, which see in two places, and tjmRE. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- AstjmE AlsRayolu The torrent collected itself together from every place. (S, Mgh, K.) ― -b3- AstjmE AlwaAdiI The valley flowed in every place thereof. (TA.) [See also 4, last signification.] ― -b4- AisotajomaEato lahu Oumuwruhu His affairs, or circumstances, all combined in a manner pleasing to him. (Mgh, K.) ― -b5- AstjmE Alfarasu jaroyFA (S, Mgh, K) The horse exerted all his force, or energy, in running: (K, TA:) the last word is here in the accus. case as a specificative. (Mgh.) You say also, AisotajomaEuwA lahumo, meaning They exerted [all] their strength, force, or energy, for fighting them: and hence, lakumo UinRa AlnRaAsi qado jamaEuwA↓ [app. meaning Verily the men, or people, have exerted all their strength for fighting you]. (A, TA.) ― -b6- AstjmE Alqawomu The people, or company of men, all went away, not one of them remaining; like as one says of a valley flowing in every place thereof. (TA.) ― -b7- AstjmE Albaqolu The herbs, or leguminous plants, all dried up. (TA.)

jamoEN jmE
jamoEN inf. n. of 1. (S, &c.) [Hence,] yawomu AljamoEi The day of resurrection [when all mankind will be collected together]. (IDrd, K.) ― -b2- Also, without the article Al, A name of El-Muzdelifeh [between 'Arafát and Minè]; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) determinate, like EarafaAtu: (TA:) so called because people collect themselves there; (S, Msb;) or because Adam there met with Eve (Mgh, Msb) after they had fallen [from Paradise]: (TA:) [or, app., a name of the tract from 'Arafát to Minè inclusive of these two places: and hence,] yawomu jamoEK the day of 'Arafeh [when the pilgrims halt at Mount 'Arafát]: and OayRaAmu jamoEK the days of Minè. (IDrd, K.) ― -b3- As an inf. n. used as a subst., properly so termed, (S, * Mgh, Msb,) it also signifies A collection; a number together; an assembly; a company, troop, congregated or collective body, party, or group; a mass; syn. jamaAEapN↓, (S, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) of men; (S, L, K;) as also majomaEN↓ (L, Msb, TA) and majomiEN↓ (Msb) and majomaEapN↓ (L, TA) and jamiyEN↓: (O, K:) but jamaAEapN↓ is also used as signifying a collection, a number together, or an assemblage, of other things than men; [of beasts, as camels, horses and the like, bulls and cows, and antelopes, gazelles, &c., i. e. a herd, troop, or drove; of dogs, i. e. a pack; of sheep and goats, i. e. a flock; of birds, i. e. a flock or bevy; of bees, and locusts, &c., i. e. a swarm;] and even of trees, and of plants; (L, TA;) it signifies a collection, or an assemblage, or aggregate, of any things, consisting of many and of few; (Msb;) [as also majomuwEN↓ and majomaEN↓;] a number, a plurality, and a multitude, of any things: (TA:) the pl. of jamoEN is jumuwEN. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b4- And particularly, An army; a military force; (TA;) as also jamiyEN↓. (S, K.) Whence the phrase, in a trad., lahu sahomN jamoEN, [or, more probably, sahomu jamoEK,] meaning For him or shall be, the like of an army's share of the spoil. (TA.) ― -b5- Also The plural of a thing [or word; i. e. a proper plural, according to the grammarians; and also applied by the lexicologists to a quasi-plural noun, which the grammarians distinguish by the terms Aisomu jamoEK and jamoEN lugawiIRN]; and so jimaAEN↓, (S, K,) and jamiyEN↓, except that this last is what is termed AisomN laAzimN [app. meaning a subst. which does not govern another as its complement in the gen. case like as jamoEN and jimaAEN do, being thus likened to what is termed fiEolN laAzimN, i. e. an intransitive verb; so that you say of AlxibaMCu, for instance, AljamiyEu AlOaxobiyapu the plural is AlAxbyp; for in this manner I always find it used when it has this signification, which is frequently the case in several of the older lexicons, and in some others; not jamiyEu AlxibaMCi AlOaxobiyapu]; (TA;) [whereas] you say, [jamoEu AlxibaMCi AlOaxobiyapu and] jimaAEu↓ AlxibaMCi AlOaxobiyapu, (S, K,) i. e. the jamoE [or plural] of AlxbAC is AlxibaMCi; (K) for AljimaAEu↓ is what comprises a number [of things]. (S, K.) See also this last word below. ― -b6- And see also the next paragraph, in three places. ― -b7- The worst sort of dates; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) because they are collected together and mixed, (Mgh, Msb,) from among the dates of fifty palm-trees: (Mgh:) and afterwards, by predominant usage,
[any] bad dates: (Mgh, * Msb:) or a certain kind of dates (K, TA) mixed together, of several sorts, not in request, and not mixed but for their badness: (TA:) or it signifies, (Mgh, K,) or signifies also, (S, Msb,) palm-trees (As, S, Mgh, Msb, K) of any kind, (As, Mgh, Msb,) growing from the date-stones, (S, K,) of which the name is unknown. (As, S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b8- Red gum; (Ibn-'Abbád, K;) [app. because collected and mixed with gum of lighter colour.] ― -b9- The milk of any camel having her udder bound with the SiraAr [q. v.]; ([i. e. the milk that collects in the udder so bound;] that of any camel not having her udder bound therewith is called fuwaAqN;) as also jamiyEN↓. (K.)

AljumoEu AljmE jmE
AljumoEu, (TA, and EM p. 102,) and jumoEu AlkafRi, (S, Msb, K,) and AlkafRi jimoEu↓, (Msb, K, and so in the margin of a copy of the S, as mentioned in the TA,) and AlkafRi jamoEu↓, (Msb,) The fist; the hand clinched; (S, Msb, K;) the hand with the fingers put together and contracted in the palm: (TA, * and EM ubi suprà:) pl. OajomaAEN. (K.) You say, Darabotuhu bijumoEi kafRiI I beat him, or struck him, with my fist. (S, Msb. *) And Darabuwhu biOajomaAEihimo They beat him, or struck him, with their [clinched] hands. (TA.) And jaMCa fulaAnN biquboDapK miloCK jumoEihi Such a one came with a quantity in his grasp as much as filled his clinched hand. (S, TA.) And jumoEu AlkafRi signifies [also] The quantity that a hand grasps, of money &c. (Ham p. 778.) ― -b2- Oaxacotu fulaAnFA bijumoEi viyaAbihi, (S, Msb, *) and bijamoEi↓ viyaAbihi, (Msb,) i. e. [I took, or seized, such a one] by the part where his garments met together. (Msb.) ― -b3- Oamoruhumo bijumoEi, and bijimoEK↓, (tropical:) Their affair, or case, is concealed, (S, K,) undivulged by them, and unknown by any one [beside them]. (S, TA.) ― -b4- cahaba AlXRahoru bijumoEK, and bijimoEK↓, The month passed away wholly; all of it. (K, TA.) ― -b5- hiIa mino zawojihaA bijumoEK, (S, Mgh, K,) and bijimoEK↓, (S, K,) She is as yet undevirginated, or undeflowered, (S, Mgh, K,) by her husband. (S, Mgh.) And TulRiqato bijumoEK, or bijimoEK↓, She was divorced being yet a virgin. (TA.) And maAtato bijumoEK, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and bijimoEK↓, (Ks, S, Msb, K,) and bijamoEK↓, (K,) She died a virgin: (Mgh, Msb, K:) or it signifies, (S, K,) or signifies also, (Mgh, Msb,) she died being with child; (AZ, S, Mgh, Msb, K;) whether suffering the pains of parturition or not: (AZ:) or heavy with child: (K:) occurring in the first sense, (Mgh, TA,) or, as some say, in the last, (TA,) in a trad., in which it is said that a woman who so dies is a martyr: (Mgh, TA:) it properly signifies she died with something comprised in her, not separated from her, whether it were a burden in the womb, or her maidenhead: (Sgh:) [the pl. is OajomaAEN; for] you say, maAtati AlnRisaMCu biOajomaAEK The women died [being virgins: or] being with child. (AZ.) You say also, naAqapN jumoEN A she-camel with young. (TA.) And AimoraOapN jaAmiEN↓ A woman with child. (TA.)

jimoEN jmE
jimoEN: see the next preceding paragraph, in six places.

jumaEN jmE
jumaEN pl. of jamoEaMCu, fem. of OajomaEu [q. v.].

jumoEapN jmE jmEh jmEp
jumoEapN is [a subst.] from AlAijotimaAEu, like as [its contr.] furoqapN is [ a subst.] from AlAAifotiraAqu: (Mgh:) and signifies A state of union, agreement, congruity, or congregation: or sociableness, socialness, familiarity, companionableness, companionship, fellowship, friendship, and amity: syn. OulofapN: as in the saying, OadaAma QllRehu jumoEapa maA bayonakumaA [May God make permanent the state of union, &c., subsisting between you two]. (Aboo-Sa'eed, K.) ― -b2- Hence, (Mgh,) yawomu AljumoEapi, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) the original form, (TA,) of the dial. of 'Okeyl; (Msb, TA;) and yawomu AljumuEapi, (S, Msb, K,) the most chaste form, (TA,) of the dial. of El-Hijáz; (Msb, TA;) and yawomu AljumaEapi, (Msb, K,) of the dial. of Benoo-Temeem; (Msb, TA;) and, in consequence of frequency of usage, AljumaEapu alone; (Mgh;) A well-known day; (K;) [the day of the congregation; i. e. Friday;] formerly called (TA) the day of AlEaruwbap: (S, TA:) called ywm AljmEp because of the congregating of the people thereon: (Msb:) Th asserts that the first who named it thus was Kaab Ibn-Lu-eí; and he is related to have said that it was thus called because Kureysh used to gather themselves together to Kuseí, [on that day,] in [the building called] daAru AlnRadowapi: (TA:) accord. to the R, Kaab Ibn-Lu-eí was the first who collected a congregation on the day of AlErwbp, which was not called AljmEp save since the coming of El-Islám; [or it was not generally thus called before El-Islám; for it is added,] and he was the first who named it AljmEp; for Kureysh used to congregate to him on this day, and he used to preach to them, and to put them in mind of the mission of the apostle of God, informing them that he should be of his descendants, and bidding them to follow him and to believe in him: (TA:) or, as some say, it was thus called in the time of El-Islám because of their congregating [thereon] in the mosque: accord. to a trad., the Ansár named it thus, because of their congregating thereon: (TA:) or it was thus named because God collected thereon the materials of which Adam was created: (I 'Ab:) those who say AljumaEapu regard it as an epithet, meaning that this day collects men much; comparing it to humazapN and lumazapN and DuHakapN: (TA:) the pl. is jumaEN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jumoEaAtN (Msb, K) and jumuEaAtN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jumaEaAtN; (Msb, K;) of which the last is pl. of jumaEapN, [as well as of jumoEapN, accord. to analogy,] but not so jumaEN (AHát) [nor either of the other pls. mentioned above]. ― -b3- In like manner you say SalaApN AljumoEapi [The prayer of Friday], and, in consequence of the frequency of usage, AljumoEapu alone. (Mgh.) ― -b4- AljumoEapu, with the m quiescent, is also a name for [The week; i. e.] the days of the week [collectively]; of which the Arabs are said, by IAar, to have reckoned the Sabbath (AlsRabot [i. e. Saturday]) as the first, though they called Sunday the first of the days. (Msb.) ― -b5- jumoEapN is also syn. with majomuwEapN [meaning Things collected together; or a collection of things]; (K;) as in the phrase jumoEapN mino HaSFI [a collection of pebbles]. (TA.) ― -b6- You say also jumoEapN mino tamorK, meaning A handful of dates. (S, K.)

jamoEiIRN jmE jmEI jmEy
[jamoEiIRN Of, or relating to, a plural.]

jumaEiIRN jmE jmEI jmEy
jumaEiIRN One who fasts on Friday by himself. (IAar, Th.)

jimaAEN jmAE
jimaAEN: see jamoEN as signifying “ a plural, ” in three places. [The primary signification seems to be the last there mentioned; where it is said,] AljimaAEu is What comprises a number [of things]: (S, K:) one says, Alxamoru jimaAEu AlUivomi (S, TA) [i. e. Wine is what comprises a number of sins: or] that in which sin is comprised, and known to be: the saying is a trad.: (TA:) or jimaAEu AlUivomi signifies the plurality (jamoE) of sins. (Msb.) Hence also the saying of El-Hasan El-Basree, AitRaquwA hecihi AlOahowaMCa faUinRa jimaAEahaA AlDRalaAlapu wamaEaAdahaA AlnRaAru [Beware ye of these natural desires; for what they involve is error, and the place to which they lead is the fire of Hell]. (TA: in the L, wmyEAdhA.) And it is said in a trad., HadRivoniI bikalimapK takuwnu jimaAEFA i. e. Tell me a saying comprising [virtually] a plurality of sayings. (TA.) [See a similar phrase below, voce jaAmiEN.] ― -b2- [Hence also,] buromapN jimaAEN A stonecooking-pot of the largest size: (Ks, L:) or qidorN jimaAEN, and jaAmiEapN↓, (S, K, TA,) a cooking-pot that comprises a slaughtered camel; or, accord. to the A, that comprises a sheep or goat: (TA:) or a great cooking-pot; (S, K;) as also jaAmiEN↓: (Sgh, K:) pl. [most probably of this last] jumoEN [like as buzolN is pl. of baAzilN, &c.]. (K.) ― -b3- You say also, fulaAnN jimaAEN libaniI fulaAnK Such a one is an object of resort for his counsel and authority to the sons of such a one. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [See also 3.]

jamuwEN jmwE
jamuwEN: see jamRaAEN.

jamiyEN jmyE
jamiyEN In a state of collection, congregation, or union; being together; met together; [as also mujotamiEN↓;] contr. of mutafarRiqN. (S, K.) You say qawomN jamiyEN A people, or number of men, in a state of collection, &c.; being together; met together; syn. mujotamiEuwna↓: (TA:) and in like manner, UibilN jamRaAEapN↓ Camels in a state of collection; &c. (TA.) ― -b2- [All, or the whole, of any things or thing.] See OajomaEu, last sentence. ― -b3- [As an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant,] A tribe [or any number of men] in a state of collection, congregation, or union; being together; met together; syn. HaIRN mujotamiEN↓. (S, K.) See also jamoEN, in four places. ― -b4- A man compact, or compressed, or contracted, in make, or frame: (Alxaloqi mujotamiEu↓;) strong; who has not become decrepit nor infirm. (TA.) ― -b5- rajulN jamiyEN AllRaOomapi A man having his arms, or weapons, collected together. (TA.) ― -b6- rajulN jamiyEu AlrRaOoIi, and mujotamiEuhu↓, A man of right, not disordered or unsettled, opinion, or judgment, or counsel. (TA.) ― -b7- jaEala
AlOamora jamiyEFA baEoda tafarRuqihi (AHeyth, K) He determined, resolved, or decided, upon the affair, so as to make it firmly settled, [after it had been unsettled in his mind, or] after considering what might be its issues, or results, and saying at one time, I will do thus, and at another time, I will do thus. (AHeyth.)

jamaAEapN jmAE jmAEh jmAEp
jamaAEapN: see jamoEN, in two places.

jamRaAEN jmAE
jamRaAEN and mijomaEN↓ [are mentioned together, but not explained, in the TA: the former signifies, and probably, judging from analogy, the latter likewise, as also jamuwEN↓, One who collects much; or who collects many things]. ― -b2- UibilN jamRaAEapN: see jamiyEN

jumRaAEN jmAE
jumRaAEN Anything of which the several component parts are collected, brought, gathered, or drawn, together. (IDrd, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] as an epithet, applied to a woman, it means Short. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] jumRaAEN AlvRurayRaA The cluster of the Pleiades: (IDrd:) or persons who collect together for the rain of the Pleiades, which is the rain called AlwasomiIR, looking for the fruitfulness and herbage resulting from it. (IAar.) ― -b4- And jumRaAEu AlnRaAsi A medley, or mixed or promiscuous multitude or collection, of men, or people, (S, Msb, K,) of various tribes; (S, K;) as also jumRaAEN alone: (TA:) or the latter, people scattered, or in a state of dispersion. (Ham p. 302.) ― -b5- jumRaAEN also signifies The place [either properly or tropically] which comprises the origin of anything; (K, TA;) the source of descent or extraction of people; and hence applied by I 'Ab to main tribes from which other tribes are derived; or, as some say, used by him as meaning various classes of men, such as are termed OawozaAE and OawoXaAb. (TA.) ― -b6- [And The main, or most essential, part of a thing. Thus,] jumRaAEu jasadi AlUinosaAni means The head of the man. (TA.) ― -b7- jumRaAEu AltRamori The contraction (tajamRuE) of the envelopes of the flowers of dates, in one place, upon [the germs of] the fruit, or produce, thereof. (TA.)

jaAmiEN jAmE
jaAmiEN [act. part. n. of 1; Collecting; &c.] ― -b2- AljaAmiEu one of the names of God; meaning The Collector of the created beings for the day of reckoning: or, as some say, the Combiner of things of similar natures and of things of contrary natures, in existence. (IAth.) ― -b3- The belly; [because it collects what passes from the stomach;] of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, (Msb,) or Almasojidu AljaAmiEu, (S, K,) [The congregational mosque;] the mosque in which the [congregational] prayers of Friday are performed; because it collects the people for a certain time; (Msb;) and you may also say, masojidu AljaAmiEi, meaning masojidu Alyawomi AljaAmiEi, (S, K,) like as you say AlHaqRu Alyaqiynu and HaqRu Alyaqiyni, [the latter] as meaning HaqRu AlXRaIoCi Alyaqiyni; for it is not allowable to prefix a noun to another of the same meaning except with this kind of subaudition; or, accord. to Fr, the Arabs used to do so because of the difference of the two words themselves: (S:) or msjd AljAmE is a mistake: (K:) so says Lth; but all others allow it; for the Arabs prefix a subst. to another signifying the same thing, and also to its epithet, as in the phrases in the Kur diynu AlqayRimapi [ch. xcviii. v. 4] and waEoda AlSRidoqi [ch. xlvi. v. 15]: (Az, TA:) [pl. jawaAmiEu.] ― -b5- miSorN jaAmiEN [A great town comprising a large population; a comprehensive great town]. (Msb in art. mdn [where it is given as the explanation of madiynapN]; and K in art. qrI [where it is less properly given as the explanation of qaroyapN].) ― -b6- qidorN jaAmiEN and jaAmiEapN: see jimaAEN ― -b7- AimoraOapN jAmiEN: see the paragraph commencing with AljumoEu; last signification. ― -b8- OataAnN jaAmiEN A she-ass pregnant when beginning to be so. (S, O, K.) ― -b9- jaAmiEapN↓ A [collar of the kind called] gulR; (S, K;) because it collects together the two hands to the neck: (S:) pl. jawaAmiEu. (TA.) ― -b10- OamorN jaAmiEN An affair that collects people together: or, as Er-Rághib says, a momentous affair, on account of which people collect themselves together; as though the affair itself collected them. (TA.) [Similar to this is the saying,] AlSRalaApu jaAmiEapN likulRi AlnRaAsi Prayer is a collector of all people. (Msb.) ― -b11- It is said of Mohammad, (Msb,) kaAna yatakalRamu bijawaAmiEi Alkalimi He used to speak comprehensive but concise language; language conveying many meanings in few words. (Msb, K. [In the CK, Alklm is omitted.]) And hence the saying of 'Omar Ibn-'Abd-el-'Azeez, Eajibotu limano laAHana AlnRaAsa kayofa laA yaEorifu jawaAmiEa Alkalimi, meaning [I wonder at him who vies with men in endeavouring to show his superiority of intelligence,] how it is that he does not [know the way to] confine himself to conciseness, and abstain from superfluity, of speech. (TA.) In like manner, (TA,) it is said in a trad., Ouwtiytu jawaAmiEa Alkalimi, meaning I have had communicated to me the Kur-án, (K, TA,) in which many meanings are comprised in a few words. (TA.) AljawaAmiEu mina AldRuEaMCi, also, signifies Prayers, or supplications, combining petitions for good and right objects of desire with praise of God and with the general prescribed observances proper to the case. (TA.) You say also, AlmaHaAmidi Hamidotu QllReha bimajaAmiEi↓ I praised God with words comprising various forms of praise. (Msb.) [See also jimaAEN.] ― -b12- rajulN jaAmiEN A man who combines such qualities that he is suited to hardship and to easiness of circumstances. (As. T in art. Adm.) And rajulN jaAmiEN liloxayori (T and M and K in art. Am) A man combining all kinds of good qualities. (TK in that art.) ― -b13- daAbRapN jaAmiEN A beast fit for the UikaAf and the saroj [i. e. for the saddle of either of the kinds thus called].
