(Sgh, K.) ― -b14- jamalN jaAmiEN, and naAqapN jaAmiEapN, (K,) accord. to ISh, (TA,) A hecamel, and a she-camel, that fails of putting forth the tooth called nAb at the time expected; expl. by OaxolafaA buzuwlFA: but this is not said except after four years: (K:) so in the copies of the K; but correctly, accord. to the O and TS, this is not said after four years, [app. reckoned from the usual time of bzwl, for this is in the ninth year, or, sometimes, in the eighth,] without the exceptive particle. (TA.)

jaAmiEapN jAmE jAmEh jAmEp
jaAmiEapN used as a subst.: see the next preceding paragraph.

OajomaEu c
OajomaEu [Collecting, comprising, or containing, a greater, or the greatest, number or quantity; more, or most, comprehensive. Of its usage in a superlative sense, the following are exs.]. UicaA Oaxaca XaAhida zuwrK baEava bihi UilaI AlsRuwqi OajomaEa maA kaAna [When he took a false witness, he sent him to the market when it comprised, or contained, the greatest number of people]: AjmE being here in the accus. case as a denotative of state with respect to the swq: and the reason why kAnt is not here said [instead of kAn] is that swq is sometimes masc. (Mgh.) And AifoEalo maA huwa OajomaEu liOuSuwli AlOaHokaAmi [Do thou that which is most comprehensive in relation to the principles of the ordinances applying to the case]. (Msb in art. HwT.) ＝ -A2- [As a simple epithet, Entire, complete, or whole: fem. jamoEaMCu. You say,] bahiymapN jamoEaMCu A beast free from defects, entire in all its limbs or members, without mutilation, and without cauterization; (TA;) a beast from the body of which nothing has gone. (S, K.) ― -b2- naAqapN jamoEaMCu [may sometimes have the like meaning: or,] accord. to IAar, (TA,) A she-camel extremely aged, (K, TA,) so that her teeth have become short, and almost gone. (TA.) ＝ -A3- It is also a sing. having the meaning of a pl., (S, K,) without any proper sing. of its own: (S:) its pl. is OajomaEuwna: and its fem. is jamoEaMCu: (S, K:) and the pl. of this last is jumaEu, though by rule it should be formed by the addition of A and t to the sing., like as the pl. of OajomaEu is formed by the addition of w and n; (S;) the original form from which jumaEu is changed being jamoEaAwaAtN; or it is jamaAEaI; it is not jumoEN, because OajomaEu is not an epithet, like as OaHomaru is, of which the pl. is HumorN; (L;) for it is determinate, though of the measure of an epithet, which is indeterminate; (AAF;) and though it is in concordance with the noun which precedes it, like an epithet, it is shown to be not an epithet by its not having a broken pl.: (L:) it is a simple corroborative; (S, K;) and so are OajomaEuwna and jamoEaMCu and jumaEu; not used as an inchoative nor as an enunciative nor as the agent of a verb nor as the objective complement of a verb, like as are some other corroboratives, such as nafosuhu and Eayonuhu and kulRuhu. (S.) You say, Oaxacotu HaqRiI OajomaEa [I took my right, or due, all of it, or altogether]: and rOayotu AlnRisowapa jumaEa [I saw the women, all of them, or all together]: the last word in this and similar cases being imperfectly declinable, and determinate word: (Sudot;, TA:) and jaAWuwA OajomaEuwna [They came, all of them, or all together]: and raOayotuhumo OajomaEiyna [I saw them, all of them, or all together]: and mararotu bihimo OajomaEiyna [I passed by them, all of them, or all together]. (Msb.) Fr mentions the phrases, OaEojabaniI AlqaSoru OajomaEa [The palace pleased me, all of it, or altogether], and AldRaAru jamoEaMCa [The house,
all of it, or altogether], with the accus. case, as denotative of state; but does not allow OajomaEuwna nor jumaEu to be used otherwise than as corroboratives: IDrst, however, allows OajomaEiyna to be used as a denotative of state; and this is correct; and accord. to both these ways is related the trad., faSalRuwA juluwsFA OajomaEiyna and OajomaEuwna [And pray ye sitting, all of you, or all together]; though some make AjmEyn [here] to be a corroborative of a pronoun understood in the accus. case, as though the speaker said, OaEoniykumo OajomaEiyna [I mean you, all of you, or all together]: (K in art. btE:) or AjmEyn in this case is a corruption committed by the relaters in the first age; and he is in error who says that it is in the accus. case as a denotative of state, for corroboratives are determinate, and the denotative of state is literally or virtually indeterminate. (Msb.) [Respecting the usage of this corroborative together with others similar to it, see OabotaEu.] You say also, jaAWuwA biOajomaEihimo, and biOajomuEihimo, with damm to the m, [They came, all of them, or all together,] (S, Msb, K,) the latter mentioned by ISk. (Msb.) And you say, qabaDotu AlmaAla OajomaEahu [I took, or received, the property, all of it, or altogether]. (Msb.) And jamiyEN↓, also, is used as a corroborative: (S, Msb:) as in the saying jaAWuwA jamiyEFA, meaning They came, all of them: (S:) and qabaDotu AlmaAla jamiyEahu, like OajomaEahu [explained above]: (Msb:) and jamiyEapF occurs as its fem.; but this is extr. (TA.)

majomaEN mjmE
majomaEN and majomiEN, (S, Msb, K,) the latter anomalous, like maXoriqN and magoribN &c., (TA,) A place of collecting, and the like: (S, Msb, * K:) [pl. majaAmiEu] [Hence,] majomaEu AlbaHorayoni, in the Kur [xviii. 59], means The place where the two seas meet. (Bd.) And in like manner, where it is said in a trad., fDaraba biyadihi majomaEa bayona EunuqiI wakatifiI, [in which maA seems to have been dropped by the copyist between mjmE and byn,] the meaning is, [And he struck with his hand] the place where my neck and my shoulder-blade meet. (TA.) [Hence also the phrase majaAmiEu AlmaHaAmidi, explained above: see jaAmiEN, near the end of the paragraph. And majaAmiEu AlOumuwri, meaning The concurrences of affairs, or of circumstances, or of events.] ― -b2- A place in which people collect, assemble, or congregate: (Msb, * TA:) and [in like manner,] majomaEapN↓ signifies an assembly-room; a sitting room in which people assemble: (TA:) [pl. of both majaAmiEu.] You say, hecaA AlkalaAmu Oawolaju fiI AlmasaAmiEi waOajowalu fiI AlmajaAmiEi [This language, or discourse, is more, or most, penetrating into the ears, and more, or most, circulating in the places of assembly]. (TA.) ― -b3- See also jamoEN, as syn. with jamaAEapN, in two places; and see 10, first sentence. ― -b4- [The whole of anything, considered as the place in which the several parts thereof are collected: see an instance voce xufRN: and see also mujotamaEN.]

OamorN mujomaEN c
OamorN mujomaEN, (S, K,) and mujomaEN Ealayohi, (TA,) An affair determined, resolved, or decided, upon: (S, K:) an affair agreed upon. (TA.) [The former signification applies to both of the abovementioned phrases: the latter signification, perhaps, only to the latter phrase.] ― -b2- xuTobapN mujomaEapN [A discourse in rhyming prose, or the like,] in which is no flaw, or defect. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.)

EaAmN mujomiEN EAm mjmE
EaAmN mujomiEN A year of dearth, drought, sterility, or unfruitfulness: (Ks, K:) because it is an occasion of people's collecting together in the place where herbage, or plenty, is found. (Ks.) And falaApN mujomiEapN, (S, TA,) like muHosinapN; (TA;) [in Gol. Lex., erroneously, mujomaEapN;] and mujamRiEapN↓, like muHadRivapN; (TA;) A desert in which people collect themselves together, not separating themselves, from fear of losing their way, or perishing, and the like; as though the desert itself collected them. (S, TA.) And OaroDN mujomiEapN, like muHosinapN, A land of dearth, drought, sterility, or unfruitfulness, wherein the camels upon which people journey are not dispersed to pasture. (TA.)

mijomaEN mjmE
mijomaEN: see jamRaAEN.

majomaEapN mjmE mjmEh mjmEp
majomaEapN: see majomaEN: ― -b2- and jamoEN, as syn. with jamaAEapN. ＝ -A2- Also Sands collected together: (K:) pl. majaAmiEu. (TA.) And A vacant, or void, land, destitute of herbage or vegetable produce, and of water. (AA, K.)

falaApN mujamRiEapN flAp mjmEh flAp mjmEp
falaApN mujamRiEapN: see mujomiEN.

majomuwEN mjmwE
majomuwEN Collected; brought, or gathered, together; gathered up; assembled; congregated; mustered; drawn together; [or contracted;] (S, K, TA;) [from several places, or] hence and thence, although not made as one thing. (S, Sgh, L, K.) It is said in the Kur [xi. 105], celika yawomN majomuwEN lahu AlnRaAsi That is a day for which mankind shall be collected. (TA.) ― -b2- See also jamoEN.

mujotamaEN mjtmE
mujotamaEN [A place in which a thing becomes collected, brought together, or the like; or in which things have become so; where they collect themselves, come together, or unite; or in which they are comprised, or contained; a place in which is a collection of things]. You say, AlbayoDapu mujotamaEu Alwaladi [The egg is that which comprises the young bird]. (Mgh in art. byD.) And mujotamaEu Almawoti signifies the same as HawoDu Almawoti, which see, in art. HwD. (TA in that art.) ― -b2- [Also The collective mass, or whole, of the hair of the head: (see jumRapN, in three places:) mujotamaEu XaEori AlrRaOosi meaning the whole head of hair: see also majomaEN.]

mujotamiEN mjtmE
mujotamiEN: see jamiyEN, in five places. ― -b2- A man who has attained to his full state of manly vigour, (S, Mgh, TA,) and whose beard has become fullgrown: (TA:) because at that time his powers have become collected, or because his beard is then full-grown. (Mgh.) [See the verb, 8. And see an ex. in a verse of Suheym Ibn-Wetheel cited in art. dwr, conj. 3.] ― -b3- OaloqaAhu mujotamiEFA [He threw him down gathered together, or in a heap]. (S and Msb and K in art. kwr.) ― -b4- maXaI mujotamiEFA He walked quickly, (K, TA,) with vehemence of motion, and strength of limbs, not languidly. (TA.)

mutajamRaEu AlbayodaMCi mtjmE AlbydMC
mutajamRaEu AlbayodaMCi The main part of the desert; the part in which [as it were] it collects itself; syn. muEaZamuhaA wamuHotafaluhaA. (TA.)

1 jamala jml jmlp
1. jamala, (K,) aor.
jamula
, inf. n. jamolN, (TA,) He collected [a thing, or things]. (K.) [See also 4.] ― -b2- Also, (S, Mgh, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S, Mgh,) He melted fat; (S, Mgh, K;) and so Ajtml↓, and Ajml↓: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) this last was sometimes used: (S:) the best form is jamala: (Fr, TA:) accord. to Z, Ajtml↓ signifies he made the melted grease of fat to drip upon bread, putting it again over the fire. (TA. [See jamiylN.]) jamalaka QllRehu, meaning May God melt thee like as fat is melted, is a form of imprecation mentioned in a trad., as used by a woman. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jamala Aljamala He put the he-camel apart from the she-camel that was fit to be covered. (TA.) ＝ -A3- jamula, aor.
jamula
; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and jamila, aor.
jamala
; (Msb;) inf. n. jamaAlN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, *) originally jamaAlapN; (Msb;) He was, or became, beautiful, goodly, comely, or pleasing, (S, M, Mgh, K,) in person, (M, K,) and good in action, or actions, or behaviour, (M, TA,) or also in moral character: (K:) or elegant, or pretty; i. e., delicately, or minutely, beautiful: (Sb, Msb:) or characterized by much goodness, beauty, goodliness, comeliness, or pleasingness, in his mind, or in his person, or in his actions or behaviour; and also, characterized by much goodness communicated from him to others. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [See jamaAlN, below; and see also jamiylN.]

2 jmRl jml jmlp
2. jmRl, (S, K,) inf. n. tajomiylN, (K,) He, or it, embellished, or adorned, another. (S, K.) Hence the saying, UicaA lamo yujamRiloka maAluka lamo yujodi Ealayoka jamaAluka [If thy wealth do not embellish thee, thy beauty of person, or of moral character, will not suffice thee]. (TA.) And you say, jamRala QllRehu Ealayohi, inf. n. as above, meaning, May God render him beautiful. (TA.) ＝ -A2- He gave a camel to be eaten. (K in art. brqX.) ＝ -A3- He detained an army long [on the frontier of the enemy]; (K, TA;) like jamRara [q. v.]. (TA.)

3 jAmlhu jAmlh jAmlp
3. jAmlhu, (K,) inf. n. mujaAmalapN, (S, TA,) He coaxed him, or wheedled him, with comely behaviour or speech (biAljamiyli), not rendering him pure, or sincere, brotherly affection: (ISd, K:) or he associated with him in a good manner: (K:) or he treated him with comely behaviour. (S, TA.) One says, Ealayoka biAlmudaAraApi waAlmujaAmalapi [Keep thou to blandishment and coaxing, &c.]. (TA.)

4 Ajml Ojml Ajml jml
4. Ajml He collected a thing (Msb, K) without discrimination, or distinction, (Msb,) or from a state of separation, or dispersion. (K.) [See also 1.] And Oujomila It was collected into an aggregate. (TA.) ― -b2- He reduced a calculation to its sum; summed it up: (S, K, TA:) and in like manner, he summed up a speech, or discourse, and then analyzed and explained it. (TA.) ― -b3-
See also 1. ＝ -A2- He made good and large [or liberal]: so in the phrase, Ajml AlSRaniyEapa (S, K) He made the benefit good and large [or liberal] (K) Einoda fulaAnK [to such a one]. (S.) ＝ -A3- [He acted with goodness, or was good and liberal: and he acted with moderation, or was moderate. You say,] Ajml fiI SaniyEihi [He was good and liberal, or, perhaps, moderate, in his benefit]. (S.) And Ajml fiI AlTRalabi He was moderate, not extravagant, in demanding, or desire. (Msb, * K, TA.) It is said in a trad., OajomiluwA fiI Talabi AlrRizoqi faUinRa kulRFA muyasRarN limaA xuliqa lahu [Be ye moderate in demanding, or desiring, the means of subsistence, for every one is accommodated to that which is created for him]. (TA.) ＝ -A4- Ajml Alqawomu The people, or company of men, had many camels; or their camels became many. (S.)

5 tjmRl Ojml jml tjml
5. tjmRl He beautified, embellished, or adorned, himself. (K.) ― -b2- He affected what is jamiyl [or beautiful, goodly, comely, or pleasing, in person, or in action or actions or behaviour, or in moral character, &c.]. (S.) You say, tjmRl biOakovara mimRaA Einodahu [He affected beautiful, goodly, comely, or pleasing, qualities, more than he possessed]. (TA in art. XbE.) ― -b3- He was, or became, patient; or restrained himself from impatience; or constrained himself to be patient: (Mgh, TA:) from jamaAlN meaning "patience." (Mgh.) Hence the saying,
waUicaA tuSiboka xaSaASapN fatajamRali
And when poverty, or straitness, befalls thee, then be patient, or restrain thyself &c. (Mgh in art. xS.) ＝ -A2- He ate what is termed jamiyl, i. e., melted fat. (S, K. *)

8 Ajtml Ajtml
8. Ajtml: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also He anointed himself with fat. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And He ate of a camel. (K in art. brqX.)

10 Astjml Astjml
10. Astjml He (a camel) became a jamal, (S, K,) i. e., such as is termed rabaAEK [or one in his seventh year], (S,) or such as is termed baAzilN [or one in his ninth year], or, accord. to Z, one that had covered. (TA.)

jamolN jml jmlp
jamolN: see jamalN.

jumolN jml jmlp
jumolN: see jumolapN and jumRalN; the latter in two places.

jamalN jml jmlp
jamalN (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and jamolN↓, (K,) which latter is so rare that it is said by some to be used only in poetry, in cases of necessity, (MF,) but it is a correct dial. var., (TA,) a word of well-known meaning; (K;) i. e., [A he-camel; but commonly applied to the camel as a generic term; in like manner as jaAmilN is applied to the males and the females; but properly,] the male of the Uibil; (TA;) the mate of the naAqap; (Fr, S, Mgh;) among camels, corresponding to rajulN among us; (Sh, Msb;) naAqapN corresponding to maroOapN, and bakorN to gulaAmN, and bakorapN to jaAriyapN; (Sh, TA;) [in general] peculiarly applied to the male; (Msb;) exceptionally to the female, as in the saying Xaribotu labana jamaliI, (K,) i. e., I drank the milk of my she-camel; but ISd doubts the correctness of this: (TA:) [as corresponding to rajulN among us, it signifies a full-grown hecamel:] or it signifies such as is termed rabaAEK [or one in his seventh year]: (S, ISd, K:) or such as is termed jacaEN [or one in his fifth year]: (ISd, K:) or such as is termed baAzilN [or one in his ninth year]: (ISd, Mgh, Msb, K:) or such as is termed vaniIRN [or one in his sixth year]: (ISd, K:) or, accord. to Z, one that has covered: (TA:) [see also baEiyrN, and bakorN, and qaEuwdN:] pl. [of pauc.] OajomaAlN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) which may be pl. of jamolN, (TA,) and OajomulN (Msb) and [of mult.] jimaAlN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and jumolN (K) and jimaAlapN (Mgh, Msb, K) and [quasi-pl. n.] jumaAlapN and jamaAlapN and jaAmilN, (K,) which last is disallowed by some, as will be seen below, (TA,) and [pl. pl.] jimaAlaAtN, (S, Msb, K,) which is pl. of jimaAlN, (Msb, TA,) or it may be pl. of jimaAlapN, (TA,) and jumaAlaAtN [which see also voce jumRalN] and jamaAlaAtN (K) and jamaAYilu, (S, K,) pl. of jmAlp and jimAl, (Ham p. 527,) and OajaAmilu. (K.) One says of camels, when they are males, without any female among them, hecihi jimaAlapu baniI fulaAnK [These are the hecamels of the sons of such a one]. (ISk, S. [See also jumaAlapN.]) And they said also jimaAlaAni [meaning Two herds of camels, thus forming a dual from the pl. jimaAlN], like as they said liqaAHaAni. (ISd, in TA voce xayolN.) It is said in a prov., maAQsotatara mano qaAda Aljamala [He does not conceal himself who leads the he-camel]. (TA.) And in another prov., AitRaxaca AllRayola jamalFA (assumed tropical:) He journeyed all the night. (K, TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 230.]) ― -b2- Aljamalu also signifies A certain fish (IAar, K) of the sea, (IAar, TA,) thirty cubits in length: (K:) or, as some say, jamalu AlbaHori is the name of a very great fish, also called the baAl, [i. e., the whale,] thirty cubits in length: accord. to some, this, (TA,) or jamalu AlmaMCi, (Mgh,) is what is called the kawosaj and kubaE (Mgh, TA) and luxom, [i. e., xiphias, or sword-fish,] which passes by nothing without cutting it. (TA.) [In the present day, jamalu AlbaHori is an appellation of The pelican.] ― -b3- Eayonu Aljamali, in the dial. of Egypt, i. q. AlXRaAh balRuwT [The chestnut]. (TA.) ― -b4- jamalN signifies also (assumed tropical:) A woman's husband. (L in arts. Axc and qyd. See 2 in each of those arts.) ― -b5- Also (tropical:) Palm-trees; (K;) as being likened to the he-camel in respect of their tallness and their bigness and their produce: in some of the copies of the K, AlnRaHolu is erroneously put for AlnRaxolu. (TA.) ― -b6- See also jumRalN.

jumalN jml jmlp
jumalN: see jumRalN, in three places.

jumulN jml jmlp
jumulN A company, or congregated body, of men. (ISd, K.) ― -b2- See also jumRalN.

jumolapN jml jmlh jmlp
jumolapN A strand of a thick rope: pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] jumolN↓: or many strands of a rope, put together [to compose a cable: see jumRalN]. (TA, in two places in this art.) ― -b2- Hence, app., (TA,) The aggregate of a thing; (K;) the sum, whole, or total; (KL, PS;) it implies muchness, or numerousness, and means any aggregate unseparated: (Er-Rághib, TA:) pl. jumalN. (S.) [jumolapN mino maAlK generally means A large sum of money; and in a similar sense jumolapN is often used in relation to various things.] It is said in the Kur [xxv. 34], waqaAla QlRaciyna kafaruwA lawo laA nuzRila Ealayohi QloquroMnu jumolapF waAHidapF, i. e., [And those who disbelieved said, Wherefore was not the Kur-án sent down, or revealed, to him] aggregated? (TA:) [or in one aggregate?] or at once? (Bd.) [Hence, biAljumolapi as meaning Upon the whole; to sum up.] ― -b3- And hence, in grammar, (TA,) [A proposition; a clause; a phrase; sometimes, a sentence;] a phrase composed of a subject and an attribute, [i. e., composed of an inchoative and an enunciative, (in which case it is termed jumolapN QsomiyRapN,) or of a verb and its agent, (in which case it is termed jumolapN fiEoliyRapN,)] (KT, TA,) [&c.,] whether affording a complete sense, as zayodN qaAYimN [Zeyd is standing], or not, as Uino yukorimoniI [If he treat me with honour]. (KT.)

jamolaMCu jmlMC
jamolaMCu: see jamiylN.

jamaluwna jmlwn
jamaluwna A building, or structure, in the form of a camel's hump: (TA:) [a ridged roof: so in the present day: pl. jamaAliynu.]

jamaAlN jmAl jml
jamaAlN inf. n. of jamula: (S, Mgh, Msb:) [when used as a simple subst., meaning] Beauty, goodliness, comeliness, or pleasingness, syn. HusonN, (S, M, Mgh, * K,) in person, (M, K,) and goodness in action, or actions, or behaviour, (M, TA,) or also, in moral character: (K:) or elegance, or prettiness; i. e., delicacy, or minuteness, of beauty: (Sb, Msb:) or much goodness, or beauty or goodliness or comeliness, in the mind, or in the person, or in the actions or behaviour; and also, much goodness that is communicated from its possessor to another: (Er-Rághib, TA:) accord. to As, [when relating to the person,] HusonN is in the eyes; and jamaAlN, in the nose. (TA in art. Hsn.) [See also jamiylN.] One says, jamaAlaka Oano laA tafoEala kacaA, (ISd, K,) or Oano tafoEala kacaA, (IDrd, TA,) meaning, Keep to that which is most comely for thee to do, and do not thus. (IDrd, ISd, K. [But see what follows.]) ― -b2- Also Patience. (Mgh in art. xS.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
jamaAlaka OayRuhaA Alqalobu AlqariyHu
sataloqaI mano tuHibRu fatasotariyHu
(S, * TA, the former of which cites only the first hemistich, and the latter substitutes AljariyHu for its syn. AlqariyHu,) meaning, [Keep thy patience, O thou wounded heart: thou wilt find whom thou lovest, and be at rest: or] keep to thy patience, or thy constraint of thyself to be patient, and thy shrinking from what is foul, and be not impatient in an evil manner. (S, TA.)

jumaAlN jmAl jml
jumaAlN: see jamiylN: ＝ -A2- and jumaAlapN.

jamuwlN jmwl
jamuwlN A piece of fat melted. (IAar, TA.) [See also jamiylN.] ― -b2- A fat woman. (IAar, K.) ― -b3- A person, (K,) or woman, (M,) who melts fat. (M, K.)

jamiylN jmyl
jamiylN Melted fat: (S, Mgh:) or melting fat: or fat that is melted and collected: (K, TA:) or fat that is melted, and, whenever it drips, made to drip upon bread, and then replaced over the fire [that it may drip again: see jamala]: (TA:) and jumaAlapN↓, also, signifies [the same; or] melted grease. (Mgh, * TA.) [See also jamuwlN.] ＝ -A2- Hence, accord. to Abu-l-'Alà, because, when a man becomes fat and in good condition, his jamaAl becomes apparent, (Ham p. 155,) as also jumaAlN↓ and jumRaAlN↓, (K,) or this last denotes a higher degree of beauty than jamiylN, (S, Sgh,) and has no broken pl., (TA,) and Oajomalu↓, (TA,) Beautiful, goodly, comely, or pleasing, (S, M, Mgh, K,) in person, (M, K,) and good in action, or actions, or behaviour, (M, TA,) or also in moral character: (K:) [like the Greek καλὸς, the Latin pulcher, the French beau, &c.; and so HasanN:] or elegant, or pretty; i. e., delicately, or minutely, beautiful: (Msb:) [or characterized by much goodness, or beauty or goodliness or comeliness, in his mind, or in his person, or in his actions or behaviour; and also characterized by much goodness communicated from him to others: see jamaAlN:] pl. of the first jamaAlN: (TA:) fem. jamiylapN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) applied to a woman; (S, Mgh, Msb;) as also jamolaMCu↓, (Ks, S, K,) [said to be] an instance of [the measure] faEolaMCu having no [masc. of the measure] OafoEalu; (TA;) [but see above;] or this is applied to any female as signifying perfect, or complete, in body. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) It is said in a trad., UinRa QllReha jamiylN yuHibRu AljimaAla Verily God is comely in deeds, (TA,) or an Abundant Bestower of good things: He loveth those who are of the like character. (Er-Rághib, TA.) And you say, EaAmalahu baAljamiyli [He treated him with comely, or pleasing, behaviour]. (TA.) And maAsaHahu biAljamiyl [He coaxed him, or wheedled him, with comely, or pleasing, behaviour or speech]. (ISd, K. [See 3.]) ― -b2- Oabuw jamiylK [The kind of plants called] Albaqol; because they embellish by their presence, and render good, the seasoning of food; or because they take away the jamiyl, i. e., the grease of the flesh-meat, and dry up the food. (Har p. 227.)

jamaAlapN jmAl jmAlh jmAlp jml
jamaAlapN: see the next paragraph.

jumaAlapa jmAl jmAlh jmAlp jml
jumaAlapa: see jumRalN: ＝ -A2- and jamiylN. ＝ -A3- Also A herd, or distinct number, of camels; (K;) mentioned before as a pl. of jamalN [q. v.]: (TA:) or, of she-camels among which is no he-camel; as also jimaAlapN↓ and jamaAlapN↓; (K;) but this is contradictory to a saying of ISk [respecting jimaAlapN], mentioned above [voce jamalN; where all these three words are said to be pls. of jamalN]: (TA:) and also horses: pl. jumaAlN↓, which is extr. [as a pl.; though, in relation to jumaAlapN, it may be a coll. gen. n., forming its n. un. with p]. (AA, K.)

jimaAlapN jmAl jmAlh jmAlp jml
jimaAlapN: see what next precedes.

jamiylapN jmyl jmylh jmylp
jamiylapN A number of gazelles together: and of pigeons. (Ibn-' Abbád, K.)

jumaAliIRN jmAl jmAlI jmAly jmAlyy jml
jumaAliIRN applied to a man, (S, Msb, K,) Large in make: (S, Msb:) or tall in body: (Msb:) or firm [in make], (K,) or big in limbs, complete in make, (TA,) like a he-camel. (K, TA.) And with p applied to a she-camel, (S, K,) Resembling a he-camel in greatness of make: (S:) or firm (K, TA) in make, (TA,) like a he-camel (K, TA) in greatness of make and in strength. (TA.)

jumRalN jml jmlp
jumRalN (S, K, &c.) and jumalN↓ and jumolN↓ (K) and jumulN↓ and jamalN↓ (IJ, K) [A cable;] the rope of a ship, (S, K,) i. e., the thick rope thereof, (TA,) that is also called qalosN, (S, TA,) consisting of [a number of] ropes put together: (S:) and jumaAlapN↓ also signifies [the same; or] a thick rope, because consisting of many strands put together; pl. jumaAlaAtN; (Zj, TA;) which Mujáhid explains as meaning the ropes of bridges; but I 'Ab, as the ropes of ships, put together so as to be like the waists of men [in thickness]. (TA.) In all the forms mentioned above, except the last (jmAlp), the word is read in the phrase [in the Kur vii. 38], HatRaI yalija AljumRalu fiI samRi AlxiyaATi [Until the cable shall enter into the eye of the needle]: (K, TA:) I 'Ab reads AljumRalu, (S, TA,) and so do 'Alee and many others: jumolN↓ is pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of jumolapN, a strand of a thick rope; or, accord. to IJ, pl. of jamalN [q. v.]: the first is explained by Fr as meaning ropes put together; but Aboo-Tálib thinks that he meant jumalN↓, without tesh-deed. (TA.) ＝ -A2- HisaAbu AljumRali, (S K,) thought by IDrd to be not Arabic, (TA,) and Aljumali↓, (K,) but IDrd doubts its correctness, The calculation by means of the letters d j b A, &c. (TA.)

jamRaAlN jmAl jml
jamRaAlN An owner, or an attendant, of a camel or camels: (KL, TA: * [see also jAmilN:]) and jamRaAlapN owners, or attendants, of camels; (S, K, TA;) similar to xayRaAlapN and HamRaArapN; (S, TA;) as the former is to HamRaArN. (TA.) [See an ex. of the latter in a verse cited voce UicaA.]

jumRaAlN jmAl jml
jumRaAlN: see jamiylN.

jaAmilN jAml
jaAmilN [act. part. n. of jamala. ＝ -A2- And also part. n. of jamula]. The Arabs say, Aujomulo Uino kunota jaAmilFA [Become beautiful, &c., if thou be becoming beautiful, &c.]: but when they mean the quality [alone], they say, UinRahu lajamiylN [Verily he is beautiful, &c.]. (Lh, TA.) ＝ -A3- A man possessing a jamal [or he-camel]. (TA. [See also jamRaAlN.]) ― -b2- A herd, or distinct number, of camels, (S, K, * TA,) males and females, (TA,) with their pastors and their owners: (S, K, TA: [also said in the K to be a pl. of jamalN: in the CK, AljAmiEu is erroneously put for AljaAmilu:]) or a word formed to denote a pl., meaning camels, (Ham pp. 122 and 490,) males and females; (Id p. 122;) derived from jamalN; (Id. p. 490;) like baAqirN (Id. ib. and TA) from baqarN, (Ham p. 490,) and kaAlibN [from kalobN]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also A great tribe. (AHeyth, K.)

Oajomalu c
Oajomalu [More, and most, jamiyl, or beautiful, &c.]. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also jamiylu.

mujomalN mjml
mujomalN [pass. part. n. of 4, q. v. ― -b2- Also, applied to a phrase or the like,] properly, Including, or implying, a number of things, many and unexplained: (Er-Rághib, TA:) as used by the lawyers, [confused, or] requiring explanation. (TA.)

mujaAmilN mjAml
mujaAmilN [act. part. n. of 3, q. v. ― -b2- Also] One who is unable to answer a question put to him by another person, and therefore neglects it, and bears malice against him for some time. (TA.)

jumaAnN jm jmAn
jumaAnN Beads made of silver, like pearls; (S;) things in the form of pearls, of silver; (K;) one of which is called jumaAnapN, (S, K,) pl. jumaAnaAtN: (Har p. 181:) or pearls (K, TA) themselves: (TA:) or the first is the proper meaning, and this is metaphorical: (EM p. 161:) [said to be] a Persian word, arabicized. (TA.) Also A kind of belt (safiyfap) woven of leather, in which are beads of every colour, worn by a woman as a wiXaAH [q. v.]: or silvered beads. (K.)

Q. 1 jamohara jmhr
Q. 1. jamohara, (T, A, K,) inf. n. jamoharapN, (A,) He collected together (T, A, K) a thing, (TA,) or earth, or dust, (T, A, TA,) one part upon another. (T, TA.) ― -b2- jmhr Alqabora, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He collected the earth, or dust, over the grave, (S, Msb, K,) not plastering it with clay, or mud, (S, K,) nor making it even, or level. (TA.) ― -b3- jmhr AlmataAEa He took the main part of the household-goods, or commodities: and in like manner the verb is used in relation to plants, or herbage. (Kitáb el- Addád, TA.) ― -b4- jmhr Ealayohi Alxabara, (Ks, S, K,) or lahu, (Lth, TA,) or Uilayohi, (AZ, TA,) He acquainted him with a part of the news, or story, and concealed what he desired, or meant: (Ks, S, K:) or he acquainted him with a part of the news, or story, incorrectly, or not in the proper manner, and omitted what he desired, or meant: (Lth, TA:) or he acquainted him with a small portion thereof, omitting most of what was necessary for him to know, and relating it in a manner different from the proper way: (AZ, TA:) and accord. to the Kitáb el-Addád of Abu-t-Teiyib the Lexicologist, it seems to have a contr. signification; for he says that jamoharotu laka Alxabara means, I acquainted thee with the main part of the news, or story. (TA.)

Q. 2 tajamohara EalayonaA tjmhr ElynA
Q. 2. tajamohara EalayonaA He held up his head with an assumption of superiority over us; domineered over us; or exalted himself above us. (TA.)

jamoharapN jmhr jmhrh jmhrp
jamoharapN [originally inf. n. of jamohara]: see the next paragraph.

jumohuwrN jmhwr
jumohuwrN (not jamohuwrN, which is a form of the word mentioned by Et-Tilimsánee, MF) A quantity of sand rising above what is around it, (S, Msb, K,) and collected together; (S;) as also ↓with p; (L;) so called from its abundance and height: (Msb:) or a large quantity of sand, heaped up, and extensive: (Lth, TA:) and ↓with p, sand compacted together, and extending in an oblong form upon the surface of the earth. (TA.) ― -b2- The generality, or main part, of men, or people: (S, A, K:) and the eminent, elevated, or noble, of them: (TA:) and a great number of people:
(Msb:) pl. jamaAhiyru; (A, Msb;) which signifies also collective bodies of men. (TA.) You say, hecaA qawolu Aljumohuwri This is the saying of the generality, or main part. (A.) ― -b3- The generality; the greater, main, or chief, part; the main body, main, gross, mass, or bulk; of anything; (K;) as also jamoharapN↓. (W 95.) ― -b4- Also, (K,) or jumohuwrapN↓, (TA,) A noble, or high-born, woman. (K, TA.)

jumohuwrapN jmhwr jmhwrh jmhwrp
jumohuwrapN: see jumohuwrN, in three places.

jumohuwriIRN jmhwr jmhwrI jmhwry
jumohuwriIRN An intoxicating beverage: (AO, K:) or [beverage of the kind called] nabiyc made of grapes, that is three years old: (K:) or i. q. buxotajN; (TA;) which is expressed juice [of grapes] cooked (Mgh voce bxtj, and TA) so as to be reduced to one third, (Mgh,) such as is lawful to be drunk: (TA:) or the beverage called bxtj to which what has gone from it has been restored, and which is then cooked, and put into vessels, and becomes very potent: (AHn, and Mgh ubi suprà, and TA:) or juice of grapes cooked until half of it is gone and half remains: (KL:) called jmhwrIR because used by most men. (TA.)

jumaAhirN jmAhr
jumaAhirN Large, big, bulky, or corpulent. (TA.)

mujamoharapN mjmhrh mjmhrp
mujamoharapN A she-camel compact in make; (K;) as though she were a jumohuwr of sand. (TA.)

1 janRahu 6
1. janRahu, (S, Mgh, K,) aor.
januna
, (Mgh, TA,) inf. n. janRN, (TA,) It veiled, concealed, hid, covered, or protected, him; (S, Mgh, K;) said of the night; (S, K;) as also janRa Ealayohi, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
januna
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. junuwnN, (S,) or janRN, (K,) or both; (TA;) so in the Kur vi. 76, meaning it veiled him, concealed him, or covered him, with its darkness; (Bd;) and AjnRhu↓: (S, Msb, K:) or this last signifies he, or it, made, or prepared, for him, or gave him, that which should veil him, conceal him, &c.: accord. to Er-Rághib, the primary signification of janRN is the veiling, or concealing, &c., from the sense. (TA.) And junRa Eanohu means It (anything) was veiled, concealed, or hidden, from him. (K.) ― -b2- He concealed it; namely, a dead body; as also AjnRhu↓: (S, TA:) or the latter, he wrapped it in grave-clothing: (K:) and he buried it. (TA.) And AlXRaIoCa fiI SadoriI Oajonanotu↓ I concealed the thing in my bosom. (S.) And waladFA OajanRato↓, (S,) or janiynFA, (K,) said of a woman, (S,) or a pregnant female, (K,) She concealed [or enveloped in her womb a child, or an embryo, or a fœtus]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- janRa, aor.
janina
, inf. n. jinRN, It (an embryo, or a fœtus,) was concealed in the womb. (K.) ― -b2- Also, [inf. n., probably, jinRN and junuwnN and janaAnN, explained below,] It (the night) was, or became, dark. (Golius on the authority of Ibn-Maaroof.) ＝ -A3- junRa, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. junuwnN (S, K) and jinRapN (S) and janRN; (K;) and AusotujinRN↓, and tjnRn↓, and tjAnR↓; (K;) He (a man, S) was, or became, majonuwn [originally signifying possessed by a jinRiIR, or by jinR; possessed by a devil or demon; (see Bd li. 39;) and hence meaning bereft of reason; or mad, insane, unsound in mind or intellect, or wanting therein: the verbs may generally be rendered he was, or became, possessed; or mad, or insane]. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- junRa AlcRubaAbu, (S, A, TA,) inf. n. junuwnN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) The flies made much buzzing: (S:) or made a gladsome buzzing in a meadow. (A, TA.) ― -b3- junRa AlnRabotu, inf. n. junuwnN, (tropical:) The herbage became tall, and tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, and put forth its flowers or blossoms: (S, TA:) or became thick and tall and full-grown, and blossomed. (M, TA.) And junRati AlOaroDu, (Fr, K,) inf. n. junuwnN, (K,) (tropical:) The land produced pleasing herbage or plants: (Fr, TA:) or put forth its flowers and blossoms; as also tjnRnt↓. (K, TA.)

2 janRaRa
2: see 4.

4 Oajonana
4: see 1, in four places: ＝ -A2- and see 8. ＝ -A3- Also AjnRhu He (God) caused him to be, or become, majonuwn [originally signifying possessed by a jinRiIR, or by jinR; and hence generally meaning bereft of reason; or mad, insane, unsound in mind or intellect, or wanting therein]. (S, Msb, K.) [And so, vulgarly, jnRnhu↓, whoever, or whatever, be the agent.] ― -b2- mA AjnRhu [How mad, or insane, &c., is he!] is anomalous, (Th, S,) being formed from a verb of the pass. form, namely, junRa; (Th, TA;) for of the maDoruwb one should not say, maA OaDorabahu; nor of the masoluwl should one say, maA OasalRahu: (S:) Sb says that the verb of wonder is used in this case because it denotes want of intellect [which admits of degrees]. (TA.) ＝ -A4- AjnR also signifies waqaEa fiI majanRapK [app. meaning He fell into, or upon, a place containing, or abounding with, jinR]. (TA.)

5 tajanRaRa
5: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- tjnRn Ealayohi, and tajaAnana↓, (S, K,) and tajaAnRa↓, (S,) He feigned himself majonuwn [i. e. possessed by a jinRiIR, or by jinR; and hence generally meaning bereft of reason; or mad, insane, &c.;] to him; (S, K;) not being really so. (TA.)

6 tajaAnRa c and tajaAnana
6. tajaAnRa tajaAnana: see 1: ― -b2- and see also 5.

8 AjtnR jn jnh jnp
8. AjtnR, (accord, to the S,) or AjnR↓, (accord. to the K,) He was, or became, veiled, concealed, hidden, covered, or protected, or he veiled, concealed, hid, covered, or protected, himself, (S, K,) Eanohu from him, or it; (K;) as also Astjn↓. (S, K.) You say, bijunRapK Astjn↓ He was, or became, veiled, &c., or he veiled himself, &c., by a thing whereby he was veiled, &c. (S.)

10 Uisotajonana
10: see 8, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also 1. ＝ -A3- AisotijonaAnN is also syn. with AisotiToraAbN; (S, K;) AstjnRhu meaning AstTrbhu, i. e. He excited him to mirth, joy, gladness, or sport. (TK.)

jinRN jn
jinRN The darkness of night; as also junuwnN↓ and janaAnu↓, (K, TA,) the last [written in the CK junAn, but it is] with fet-h: (TA:) or all signify its intense darkness: (TA:) or all, the confusedness of the darkness of night: (K:) [all, in these senses, are app. inf. ns.: (see 1:)] the last, janaAnN↓, also signifies night [itself]: (K:) or [so in copies of the K, accord. to the TA, but in the CK “ and, ”] the dense black darkness of night: (S, K:) and junuwnN↓, the veiling, or concealing, or protecting, darkness of night. (ISk, S.) ― -b2- Concealment: so in the phrase, laA jinRa bihecaA AlOamori There is no concealment with this thing. (K, * TA.) One of the Hudhalees says,
walaA jinRa biAlbagoDaMCi waAlnRaZari AlXRazori
[And there is no concealment with vehement hatred and the looking with aversion]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [The genii; and sometimes the angels;] accord. to some, the spiritual beings that are concealed from the senses, or that conceal themselves from the senses; all of such beings; (Er-Rághib, TA;) the opposite of UinosN; (S, Mgh, Msb, Er-Rághib, TA;) thus comprising the angels; all of these being jinR; (Er-Rághib, TA;) thus called because they are feared but not seen: (S:) or, accord. to others, certain of the spiritual beings; for the spiritual beings are of three kinds; the good being the angels; and the evil being the devils (XayaATiyn); and the middle kind, among whom are good and evil, being the jinR; as is shown by the first twelve verses of ch. lxxii. of the Kur: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or it here means intelligent invisible bodies, predominantly of the fiery, or of the aerial, quality: or a species of souls, or spirits, divested of bodies: or human souls separate from their bodies: (Bd:) or the jinR are the angels [exclusively]; (K;) these being so called in the Time of Ignorance, because they were concealed, or because they concealed themselves, from the eyes: so, accord. to some, in the Kur [xviii. 48], where it is said that Iblees was of the jinR: and so, as some say, in the Kur [vi. 100], where it is said that they called the jinR partners of God: (TA:) but some reject the explanation in the K, because the angels were created of light, and the jinR of fire; and the former do not propagate their kind, nor are they to be described as males and females; contrary to the case of the jinR; wherefore it is generally said that in the phrase [in the Kur xviii. 48, above mentioned] UilRaA Uiboliysa kaAna mina AljinRi, what is excepted is disunited in kind from that from which the exception is made, or that Iblees had adopted the dispositions of the jinR: (MF, TA:) or, as some say, the jinR were a species of the angels, who were the guardians of the earth and of the gardens of Paradise: (TA:) jinRapN↓, also, signifies the same as jinRN: (S, Msb, K:) so in the last verse of the Kur: (S:) in the Kur xxxvii. 158 meaning the angels, whom certain of the Arabs worshipped; (TA;) and whom they called the daughters of God: (Fr, TA:) a single individual of the jinR is called jinRiIRN↓, [fem. with p:] (S, TA:) and jaAnRN↓, also, is syn. with jinRN: (Msb:) or AljaAnN means the father of the jinR; (S, Mgh, TA;) [i. e. any father of jinR; for] the pl. is jinRaAnN, like HiyTaAnN pl. of HaAYiTN: (S, TA:) so says El-Hasan: it is said in the T, on the authority of
AA, that the jAnR is, or are, of the jinR: (TA:) or jaAnRN is a quasi-pl. n. of jinRN; (M, K;) like jaAmilN and baAqirN: (M, TA:) so in the Kur lv. 56 and 74: in reading the passage in the Kur lv. 39, 'Amr Ibn- 'Obeyd pronounced it jaOanN: (TA:) it is related that there were certain creatures called the jaAnR, who were upon the earth, and who acted corruptly therein, and shed blood, wherefore God sent angels who banished them from the earth; and it is said that these angels became the inhabitants of the earth after them. (Zj, TA.) baAta fulaAnN Dayofa jinRK [Such a one passed the night a guest of jnR] means, in a desolate place, in which was no one that might cheer him by his society or converse. (TA.) The saying of Moosà Ibn-Jábir,
famaA nafarato jinRiI walaA fulRa miboradiI
may mean And my companions, who were like the jinR, did not flee when I came to them and informed them, nor was my tongue, that is like the file, deprived of its sharp edge: or by his jnR he means his familiar jnR, such as were asserted to aid poets when difficulties befell them; and by his mbrd, his tongue: (Ham p. 182 [where other explanations are proposed; but they are far-fetched]:) or by his jnR he means his heart; and by his mbrd, his tongue. (S.) The Arabs liken a man who is sharp and effective in affairs to a jinRiIR and a XayoTaAn: and hence they said, nafarato jinRuhu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He became weak and abject. (Ham ubi suprà.) ― -b2- The greater, main, or chief, part, or the main body, or bulk, of men, or of mankind; as also janaAnN↓; (K;) because he who enters among them becomes concealed by them: (TA:) or the latter means the general assemblage, or collective body, of men: (IAar, S, * TA:) or what veils, conceals, covers, or protects, one, of a thing. (AA, TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) The flowers, or blossoms, of plants or herbage. (K, TA.) ― -b4- (tropical:) The prime, or first part, of youth: (S, K, TA:) or the sharpness, or vigorousness, and briskness, liveliness, or sprightliness, thereof. (TA.) You say, kaAna celik fiI jinRi XabaAbihi (tropical:) That was in the prime, or first part, of his youth. (S, TA.) And OafoEalu celika AlOamora bijinRi celika (tropical:) I will do that thing in the time of the first and fresh state of that. (S, TA.) jinRN may also signify (assumed tropical:) The madness, or insanity, of exultation, or of excessive exultation. (TA.) And one says, AitRqi AlnRAqapa faUinRhaA bijinRi DiraAmihaA, meaning (assumed tropical:) Fear thou the she-camel, for she is in her evil temper on the occasion of her bringing forth. (TA.) ― -b5- Also i. q. jdR [app. jidRN, as meaning (assumed tropical:) Seriousness, or earnestness]; because it is a thing that is an accompaniment of thought, or reflection, and is concealed by the heart. (TA.)

janRapN jn jnh jnp
janRapN A [garden, such as is called] busotaAn: (S, Mgh:) or a garden, or walled garden, (Hadiyqap, Msb, K,) of trees, or of palm-trees, (Msb,) or of palms and other trees: (K:) or only if containing palm-trees and grape-vines; otherwise, if containing trees, called Hdyqp: (Aboo-'Alee in the Tedhkireh, TA:) or any bstAn having trees by which the ground is concealed: and sometimes concealing trees: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and palm-trees: (S:) or tall palm-trees: (Mgh:) or shadowing trees; because of the tangling, or luxuriousness of their branches; as though concealing at once what is beneath them: then a bstAn; because of its dense and shadowing trees: (Bd in ii. 23:) or a bstAn of palms and other trees, dense, and shadowing by the tangling, or luxuriousness, and denseness, of their branches; as though it were originally the inf. n. of un. of janRahu, and meaning “ a single act of veiling ” or “ concealing ” &c.: (Ksh ib.:) then, with the article Al, [Paradise,] the abode of recompense; because of the jinaAn therein; (Ksh and Bd ib.;) or because the various delights prepared therein for mankind are concealed in the present state of existence: (Bd ib.:) [and] hence AljanRaAtu [the gardens of Paradise], (so in a copy of the S,) or janRaAtu EadonK [the gardens of continual abode]: (so in another copy of the S:) [for] the pl. of janRapN is OajinRapN (Mgh, Msb, K) and jinayonap (Msb, TA) and junRapN, but this last is strange. (MF, TA.) [Dim. junayonapN↓, vulgarly pronounced jinayonap, and applied to A garden; as though it were a little Paradise.]

junRapN jn jnh jnp
junRapN A thing by which a person is veiled, concealed, hidden, covered, or protected: an arm, or armour, with which one protects himself: (S:) anything protective: (K:) or coats of mail, and any defensive, or protective, arm or armour: (TA:) pl. junanN. (S.) ― -b2- A piece of cloth which a woman wears, covering the fore and kind parts of her head, but not the middle of it, and covering the face, and the two sides of the bosom, (K,) or, accord. to the M, the ornaments [HuliIR instead of janobaI] of the bosom, (TA,) and having two eyeholes, like the buroquE. (K.)

jinRapN jn jnh jnp
jinRapN: see its syn. jinRN: ＝ -A2- and junuwnN.

jananN jn jnn jnnn
jananN A grave; (S, K;) because it conceals the dead: (TA:) and so janiynN↓, of the measure faEylN in the sense of the measure faAEilN. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b2- Grave-clothing; (K;) for the same reason. (TA.) ― -b3- A garment that conceals the body. (TA.) [See also janaAnN.] ＝ -A2- A dead body; (S, K;) because concealed in the grave; the word being of the measure faEalN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN, like nafaDN in the sense of manofuwDN. (TA.)

janunN jn jnn jnnn
janunN: see junuwnN.

janaAnN jnAn jnp
janaAnN: see jinRN, first sentence, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see the same in the latter part of the paragraph. ― -b2- Also A garment: (K:) or a garment that conceals one; as in the saying, maA EalaIRa janaAnN UilRaA maA taraI [There is not upon me a garment that conceals me save what thou seest]. (S.) [See also jananN.] ― -b3- The Hariym [or surrounding adjuncts, or appertenances and conveniences,] (K, TA) of a house; because concealing the house. (TA.) ― -b4- The interior of a thing that one does not see; (K;) because concealed from the eye. (TA.) ― -b5- The heart; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) because concealed in the bosom; (T, M;) or because it holds things in memory: (M, TA:) or its ruwE [i. e. the heart's core, or the mind, or understanding, or intellect]; (K;) which is more deeply hidden: (TA:) and (sometimes, TA) the soul, or spirit; (IDrd, K;) because the body conceals it: (IDrd, TA:) pl. OajonaAnN. (IJ, K.) You say, maA yasotaqirRu janaAnuhu mina AlfazaEi [His heart does not rest in its place by reason of fright]. (TA.) ― -b6- A secret and bad action. (TA. [Before the word rendered “ secret ” is another epithet, which is illegible.])

junaAnN jnAn jnp
junaAnN: see mijanRN: ＝ -A2- and what here next follows.

junuwnN jnwn
junuwnN: see jinRN, first sentence, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also, inf. n. of junRa; (S, K;) [originally signifying A state of possession by a jinRiIRi, or by jinR; diabolical, or demoniacal, possession; and hence meaning] loss of reason; or madness, insanity, or unsoundness in mind or intellect; (Mgh;) or deficiency of intellect: (Sb, TA:) [it may generally be rendered possession, or insanity:] jununN↓ is a contraction thereof; (S, K;) or accord. to some, an original form: (MF, TA:) and janRapN↓, also, (an inf. n. and a simple subst., S,) signifies the same as junuwnN: (S, Msb, K:) as also majanRapN↓, (S, K,) and junaAnN↓, but this last is vulgar. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Persistence in evil; and pursuance of a headlong, or rash, course. (Ham p. 14.)

janiynN jnI jnyn
janiynN Anything veiled, concealed, hidden, or covered: (K:) applied as an epithet even to rancour, or malice. (TA.) ― -b2- Buried; deposited in a grave. (IDrd, S.) ― -b3- An embryo; a fœtus; the child, or young, in the belly; (S Msb, K;) [i. e.,] in the womb: (Mgh:) pl. OajinRapN (S, Msb, K) and OajonunN. (ISd, K.) ― -b4- And the former of these pls., Waters choked up with earth. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jananN. ― -b2- Also The vulva. (TA.)

junaAnapN jnAnh jnAnp jnp
junaAnapN: see mijanRN.

janiynapN jnI jnyn jnynh jnynp
janiynapN, accord. to the copies of the K, but in the M jinRiyRapN↓, (TA,) A [garment of the kind called] miToraf, (K, TA,) of a round form, (TA,) like the TayolasaAn, (K, TA,) worn by women: (TA:) in the T, said to be certain well-known garments. (TA.)

junayonapN jnI jnyn jnynh jnynp
junayonapN: see jnRapN, last sentence.

jinRiIRN jn jnI jny
jinRiIRN Of, or relating to, the jinR, or jinRap. (K.) ― -b2- See jinRN. In the saying,
wayoHaki yaA jinRiIRa halo badaA laki
Oano turojiEiI EaqoliI faqado OanaI laki
[Mercy on thee! O Jinneeyeh, jinRiIRa being for jinRiyRapu,) doth it appear fit to thee that thou shouldst restore my reason? for the time hath come for thee to do so], a woman resembling a jinRiyRap is meant, either because of her beauty, or in her changeableness. (TA.) ＝ -A2- The tallness, or length and height, of a camel's hump. (TA.)

jinRiyRapN jny jnyh jnyp
jinRiyRapN [fem. of jinRiIRN, q. v.] ＝ -A2- See also janiynapN

jinojinN jnjn
jinojinN and janojanN and jinojinapN↓ (S, K) and jinojanapN↓ (K) and (as some say, TA) junojuwnN↓ (K) are sings. of janaAjinu, which signifies The bones of the breast: (S, K:) or the heads of the ribs of men and of others: (M, TA:) or the extremities of the ribs, next the sternum. (T, TA.)

janojanapN jnjnh jnjnp
janojanapN: see what next precedes.

junojuwnN jnjwn
junojuwnN: see what next precedes.

jaAnRN jAn jAny
jaAnRN: see jinRN. ― -b2- Also A white serpent: (Lth, S, Msb:) or a small white serpent: (Mgh:) or a great serpent: (Zj, TA:) or a species of serpent (AA, M, K) having black-bordered eyes, (M, K,) inclining to yellow, (M, TA,) harmless, and abounding in houses: (M, K:) pl. jawaAnRu, (AA, TA,) or jinRaAnN. (TA.)

OajinRaka kacaA c
OajinRaka kacaA i. q. mino Oajoli OanRaka [Because that thou art thus]; (S, K;) from which it is contracted by suppressing the l and A and transferring the kesreh of the l to the A (S.) A poet says,
OajinRaki EinodiI OaHosanu AlnRaAsi kulRihimo
[Because that thou art in my estimation the goodliest of all mankind]. (S.) The mino is omitted as in the phrase faEalotuhu Oajolaka for mino Oajolika. (Ks, TA.)

tajoniynN Ojn jn jnI tjnI tjnyn
tajoniynN [an inf. n. used as a simple subst.,] What is said by the jinR [or genii]: or, accord. to Es-Sukkaree, strange, uncouth speech or language, difficult to be understood. (TA.)

mujanRN mAj mjn mjnn
mujanRN: see majonuwnN.

mijanRN mAj mjn mjnn
mijanRN A shield; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) because the owner conceals, or protects, himself with it; (Mgh, Msb;) as also mijanRapN↓ (Lh, K) and junaAnN↓ and junaAnapN↓: (K:) pl. majaAnRu. (S, Msb.) Sb held it to be of the measure fiEalRN, from mjn; but his opinion is opposed by the fact that the word is of the form which is significant of an instrument, by the doubling of the n, and by the syns. jnAn and jnAnp. (MF, TA.) It is said in a trad., that the hand [of a thief] shall not be cut off save for the value of a mijanR; which in the time of the Prophet was a deenár, or ten dirhems; for this is the lowest amount for which that punishment is to be inflicted. (Mgh.) You say, qalaba mijanRahu [He turned his shield], meaning (tropical:) He dropped shame, and did what he pleased: or he became absolute master of his affair, or case. (K, TA.) And qalabotu lahu Zahora AlmijanRi [I turned towards him the outer side of the shield], meaning (assumed tropical:) I became hostile to him after reconciliation. (Har p. 265.) ― -b2- Also A [woman's ornament such as is commonly called] wiXaAH (Az, K.)

majanRapN mAj mjn mjnh mjnnh mjnp
majanRapN A place in which one is veiled, concealed, hidden, covered, or protected; or in which one veils, conceals, hides, covers, or protects, himself. (S.) ― -b2- A land having in it jinR: (S:) or abounding with jinR. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also junuwnN.

mijanRapN mAj mjn mjnh mjnnh mjnp
mijanRapN: see mijanRN.

majonuwnN mjnwn
majonuwnN [Possessed by jinRiIR, or by jinR, or by a devil, or demon; a demoniac: (see Bd li. 39:) and hence meaning bereft of reason; or mad, insane, unsound in mind or intellect, or wanting therein: (see junuwnN:) it may generally be rendered possessed; or mad, or insane:] part. n. of junRa: (Msb:) or anomalously used as pass. part. n. of OajanRahu: (S, * K, * TA:) one should not say mujanRN↓: (S, TA:) [pl. majaAniynu.] ― -b2- naxolapN majonuwnapN (tropical:) A tall palm-tree: (S, K, TA:) pl. majaAniynu. (S, TA.) And nabotN majonuwnN (tropical:) A plant, or herbage, that is tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, in part, and strong. (TA.) And OaroDN majonuwnapN (assumed tropical:) Land producing much herbage, that has not been depastured. (TA. [See also what next follows.])

OaroDN matajanRinapN c
OaroDN matajanRinapN (tropical:) Land having much herbage, so that it extends in every way. (K, TA.)

manojanuwnN mnjnwn
manojanuwnN and manojaniynN: see art. mnjn

1 janaOa Ealayohi c
1. janaOa Ealayohi, (As, S, L, K,) aor.
janaAa
, inf. n. junuwoCN, (As, K,) He bent down over, or fell prostrate upon, him, or it; (As, S, L, K;) namely, a man, (Th, L,) as one does in speaking to another [who is sitting], (Th,) or to shield or protect another from blows, (L,) and as a woman does over a child; (TA;) or a horse, said when a man has bent down to preserve himself [from an arrow &c.]; or a thing; (S;) as also janiICa, aor.
janaAa
, inf. n. janaON; (K, TA; [in the CK, erroneously, janAC;]) as also AjnO↓, (As, L, K,) likewise said of a man bending over another to shield or protect the latter; (L, TA;) and jAnO↓, and tjAnO↓, (S, K,) and AjtnO↓ (TA.) ― -b2- janaOa fiI Eadowihi He persevered, or was fatigued and slow, OalaHRa, [which has these two different meanings,]) and bent down, in his running. (T, TA.) ＝ -A2- janiICa, aor.
janaAa
, (Lth, K,) inf. n. janaON, (Lth, S,) said of a man, (S,) He had a bending forward of the upper part of his back over his breast: (Lth, K:) or was humpbacked: (S:) or he had a bent and humped back: but Lth denies that janaON signifies the being humpbacked. (TA.) [See also OajonaOu.]

3 jaAonaAa
3: see 1.

4 OajonaAa
4: see 1.

6 tajaAonaAa
6: see 1.

8 UijotanaAa
8: see 1.

OujonaOu c
OujonaOu, applied to a man, (S,) Having a bending forward of the upper part of the back over the breast: (Lth, K:) or humpbacked: (S:) or having a bent and humped back; but see what Lth says, voce janiICa: (TA:) or i. q. OadonaOu and OaqoEasu, meaning a man having a bending in his breast towards his back: (AA, TA:) accord. to As, applied to him who has been straight in the back and has then been affected with what is termed janaON: it is also applied to an ostrich: fem. janoMCu and janowaMCu (TA.) ― -b2- Also janoMCu A ewe, or a she-goat, having her horns bending backwards; (Esh-Sheybánee, K;) and so janowaMCu (TA in art. jnw.)

mujonaON c
mujonaON A shield: (S, K:) so called because of its being humped, (K, TA, [in some copies of the former of which, for liQHodiydaAbihi, we find laA Hadiydapa bihi, i. e. having no piece of iron in it,]) and on account of its bending form. (TA.)

mujonaOapN c
mujonaOapN A grave. (K.) [App. so called because the grave of an Arab of the desert generally has a small oblong humped mound raised over it.]

1 janabahu jnb jnbh jnbp
1. janabahu He broke his side: (S, K:) or he hit, or hurt, his side. (TA.) [The aor. of the verb in this sense is probably
januba
, and the inf. n., accord. to the TK, is janobN.] ― -b2- He led him by his side; (S, A, * Msb, K;) namely, a horse (S, A, Msb, TA) or the like, (S, A,) and a captive. (S, TA.) In this sense, its aor. is
januba
, (A, Msb, TA,) and the inf. n. janabN (S, A, Msb, K) and majonabN. (K.) Hence, TawoEu Aljanabi: see janabN.jinaAbN which is forbidden (S, A, TA) in a trad., [in which it is said, laA jalaba walaA janaba] (A, TA) relating to horse-racing and to [the collecting of] the poor-rate, (TA,) means [in the former case] A man's leading, by the side of a horse that he rides in a race, another horse, (S, A, K,) without a rider, (TA,) and when the horse that he rides has become languid and weak, (K,) or when he fears that he will not outstrip upon it, (S,) or when he draws near to the goal, (A,) transferring himself to the other, (S, A, K,) in order that he may outstrip: (A:) and in relation to the poorrate, it means the collector's alighting in the most remote of the places whence the portion appointed for the poor-rate is to be collected, and then ordering that the camels or the like [that constitute that portion] shall be led to him: or the going of the owner of the property to a distance, [or aside, or out of the way,] with his property, so that the collector is obliged to go to a distance in quest of it. (K. See more in art. jlb, first paragraph.) ― -b3- He placed, or put, at a distance, or he put, or sent, away, or far away, or far off, or he removed far away, alienated, or estranged, him, or it; (K;) as though he put him, or it, aside, or as though he walked aside; as also jAnbhu↓ (TA.) And He pushed, thrust, or drove, him, or it, away, aside, or to a distance. (K, * TA.) And janabahu AlXRaIoCa (S, K, *) or AlXRarRa (Fr, Zj, Msb,) aor.
januba
; (S, Msb, K;) and jnRbhu↓, (Fr, Zj, S, A, Msb, K,) but this has an intensive signification; (Msb;) and Ajnbhu↓; (Fr, Zj, A, K;) He put aside, or away, or he warded off, from him, (S,) or he removed from him, (S, Msb, K,) or removed far from him, (Msb, K,) the thing, (S, K, *) or evil. (Fr, Zj, A, Msb.) It is said in the Kur [xiv. 38], waQjonuboniI wabaniIRa Oano naEobuda AlOaSonaAma [And put Thou away from me and my sons our worshipping of idols], (S,) or, accord. to one reading, waOajoniboniI↓. (TA.) ― -b4- He yearned towards, longed for, or desired, him, or it. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A2- janaba bihi,
aor.
januba
, [He went aside, apart, out of the way, to a distance, or far away, with him, or it: or, like janabahu, in a sense explained above,] he placed, or put, at a distance, or he put, or sent, away, or far away, or far off, him, or it. (K, TA.) ― -b2- janaba fiI baniI fulaAnK, (S, K, *) aor.
januba
, inf. n. janaAbapN; (S;) and tjnRb↓; (so, app., in the TA;) He alighted, or descended and abode, or settled, as a stranger, among the sons of such a one. (S, K, * TA.) One says, niEoma Alqawomu humo lijaAri AljanaAbapi [Excellent are the people, they,] to the neighbour who is a stranger. (S. [See also junubN.]) And laA taHorimanRiI Eano janaAbapK Do not thou by any means refuse me because of being remote (S, A, TA) in respect of relationship. (A, TA.) [See also janaAbapN mentioned below as a subst.] ― -b3- janabati AlrRiyHu, (S, A, K,) aor.
januba
(TA,) inf. n. junuwbN; (K;) and Ajnbt↓; (TA;) The wind was, or became, such as is termed januwb [i. e. south, or southerly]; (K;) it blew in the direction of the wind thus called: (A, TA:) or the former, (S,) or janibat, (TA,) the wind changed, or veered, so as to become januwb (S, TA.) ― -b4- [And hence, (see januwbN,)] janaba Uilayohi, (IAar, K,) or UilaI liqaAYihi, (TA,) aor.
januba
; (K;) and janiba, aor.
janaba
; (Th, K;) [inf. n., app., janobN, for the verb is said in the K to be like naSara and samiEa;] (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, disquieted by vehement desire to see him, or to meet him. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A3- janiba, aor.
janaba
, (S,) inf. n. janabN, (S, K,) He (a camel) limped, or halted, by reason of [pain in] his side: (S:) or he had an affection resembling ZaloE [i. e. limping, or halting], (K, TA,) but not the same as this: (TA:) and, (K,) or accord. to As, (S,) his lungs clave to his side by reason of vehement thirst: (S, K:) or, accord. to the Arabs of the desert, as ISk says, he became bent, or contorted, by reason of vehemence of thirst: (S:) and he (a camel) had a pain in his side from vehemence of thirst. (TA.) The epithet is janibN↓; which is applied by Dhu-r-Rummeh to an ass. (S, TA.) ― -b2- jnbt AldRalowu [app. janibat] The bucket inclined to one side in consequence of the breaking of one or two of the thongs attacking it to the cross-bars. (L, TA.) ＝ -A4- janiba and januba and janaba are syn. with Oajonaba in a sense explained below: see 4. ＝ -A5- juniba He had, or became affected by, the disease termed caAtu Aljanobi [or pleurisy]: (S, Mgh, Msb:) he had a complaint of his side. (K.) ＝ -A6- junibuwA They were, or became, affected by the [south, or southerly, wind called] junuwb. (S, A, K.) And also, [in allusion to the fertilizing effect attributed to the wind so called,] They were, or became, affected by that wind in their cattle. (L, TA.)

2 jnRbhu jnb jnbh jnbp
2. jnRbhu: see 1: ― -b2- and see also 3. ＝ -A2- jnbR, inf. n. tajoniybN, He did not send the stallion-camel among his she-camels, nor the ram or he-goat among his ewes or she-goats. (K.) ― -b2- jnRb Alqawomu The milk of the people's camels became little: (S:) or the people's milk ceased; (K, TA;) or became little: or the people's camels had no milk: and jnRb said of a man, his camels had no milk, nor had his sheep or goats. (TA.) Hence, EaAmu tajoniybK [A year of little, or no, milk]. (S, TA.) ― -b3- jnRbt AlOibilu The camels, with the exception of one or two, brought forth no young. (AZ, TA.) The camels did not conceive, so as to have milk. (TA.) ＝ -A3- tajoniybN [as an inf. n. of which the verb, if it have one in any of the following senses, is junRiba,] also signifies A bending, or curving, and tension [of the sinews] (tawotiyrN), of the hind leg of a horse; which is a quality approved: (S, K:) or, accord. to AO, a turning aside of his fore legs in raising them and putting them down: but accord. to As, it is in the kind legs, and taHoniybN is in the back-bone and in the fore legs. (TA.) [See also 2 in art Hnb; and see also mujanRabN.]

3 jAnbhu jAnb jAnbh jAnbp
3. jAnbhu, (A, K,) inf. n. mujaAnabapN and jinaAbN, (K,) He was, or became, at, or by, his side: (A, K:) and he walked, or went, by his side. (A.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. baA Eadahu; (A, K;) i. e. He was, or became, [distant, remote, far off, or aloof, from him; or] apart from him; or in a part, quarter, or tract, different from that in which he (the other) was; (TA;) thus bearing two contr. significations. (A, K.) jAnbhu and tjAnbhu↓ and tjnRbuhu↓ and Ajtnbhu↓ all signify the same, (S, K,) i. e. He was, or became, distant, remote, far off, or aloof, or he went, or removed, or retired, or withdrew himself, to a distance, or far away, or far off, or he alienated, or estranged, himself, or he stood, or kept, aloof, from him, or it; he shunned, or avoided, him, or it; as also jinRbh↓ (K) [and minohu tjnRb↓]. You say, jaAnibi AllRiYaAma [Remove thyself far from the mean, or ignoble; stand, or keep, aloof from them; shun, or avoid, them]. (A.) And lajRa fiI jinaAbK qabiyHK He persisted in removing himself to a distance, or estranging himself, from his family. (S, A, K. [In two copies of the S, I find jnAb here written with fet-h to the j; but it is expressly said in the TA to be with kesr.]) ― -b2- See also 1.

4 Ajnbhu Ojnbh Ajnbh Ajnbp jnb
4. Ajnbhu: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph, in two places. ＝ -A2- Ajnb, (S, IAth, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. UijonaAbN; (IAth, TA;) and janiba↓; (IB, K;) but the former is more common than the latter; and the latter, than the next here following; (IB, TA;) and januba↓ (S, Msb, K,) [inf. n. janaAbapN, agreeably with analogy;] and janaba↓, aor.
januba
; (L, TA;) and Oujoniba, and Astjnb↓, (K,) and tjnRb↓; (L, TA;) He was, or became, in the state of one who is termed junub; (S, IAth, Mgh, L, Msb, K;) i. e., under the obligation of performing a total ablution, by reason of sexual intercourse and discharge of the semen. (IAth, TA.) laA yujonibu, said by I' Ab, of a man, and of a garment, and of the ground, (TA,) and of water, (Mgh, TA,) means (tropical:) He, or it, will not become polluted (Mgh, TA) by the touch of him who is junub so that one should need total ablution in consequence of the touching thereof. (TA.) ＝ -A3- AjnbwA They entered upon [a time in which blew] the [south, or southerly,] wind termed Aljunuwb. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- See also 1 in the latter half of the paragraph.

5 tajanRaba
5: see 1: ― -b2- and 3, in two places: ― -b3- and 4.

6 tajaAonaba
6: see 3.

8 Uijotanaba
8: see 3.

10 Uisotajonaba
10: see 4.

janobN jnb
janobN, a word of well-known meaning; (S;) The side, or half, or lateral half, syn. XiqRN, (A, K,) of a man &c.; as also jaAnibN↓ and janabapN↓: (K:) or the part of a man that is beneath the arm-pit, extending to the flank; as also jaAnibN↓, because it is the side of the person: (Msb:) pl. (of the first, Msb) junuwbN (Msb, K) and [of the same, a pl. of pauc.,] OajonaAbN (CK) and [of jaAnibN] jawaAnibu (Lh, ISd, K, but not in the CK) and [app. of janobN (like as layaAYilu is a pl. of layolN) or of janabapN (like as HawaAYiju is pl. of HaAjapN which is originally HawajapN) or of both these] janAYibu↓ (M, K,) which is extr. (M, TA.) [Hence,] qaEadotu UilaI janobi fulaAnK and flAn AlI jaAnibi↓ [I sat by the side of such a one]: both meaning the same. (S.) And UinRahu lamunotafixu AljawaAnibi↓ [Verily he is inflated in the side]: jwAnb being here one of those words which are used in the sing. sense though in the pl. form. (Lh, TA.) And OaEoTaAhu Aljanoba [lit. He gave him the side; meaning] he was, or became, submissive, manageable, easy, or tractable, to him. (A.) And jaAru Aljanobi He who cleaves to one, keeping by one's side. (K. [Differing from jaAru Aljunubi, q. v. infrà.]) And AlSRaAHibu biAljanobi [in the Kur iv. 40] The travelling-companion; the companion in a journey: (S, K:) or he who is near one; or by one's side: or the companion in every good affair: or the husband: or the wife. (TA.) And caAtu Aljanobi, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) with which AljunaAbu↓ is syn., (K,) [and sometimes Aljanobu, as will be seen in what follows,] A well-known disease; (Mgh;) [the pleurisy; called by the first of these three appellations in the present day;] a severe disease, being an inflammatory tumour in the [pleura, or] membrane within the ribs: (Msb:) or an ulcer, or a purulent pustule, that comes within a man's side: (S, TA:) it is a severe disease in the side: accord. to El-Hejeree, it is in either side; and they assert that when it is in the left side, the patient perishes: accord. to ISh, the dubayolap; which is an ulcer that penetrates into the belly: or the ulcer (dubayolap and dumRal) that comes forth within the side, and discharges internally; the sufferer from which seldom recovers: he who suffers from it [and dies in consequence], or, as some say, he who is afflicted by a complaint of the side (absolutely) while warring in the cause of God, is reckoned a martyr: (TA:) [soldiers in a campaign are notoriously more subject to it than persons in most other circumstances; and it is app. for this reason that] it is termed daMCu AlSRanaAdiydi [the disease of the courageous chiefs]. (A, TA.) cuw Aljanobi, of which caAtu Aljunobi is the fem., signifies Having a complaint of his side by reason of [the disease above mentioned, or what is termed] AldRubayolap. (TA. [See also majonuwbN.]) ― -b2- A poet says,
AlnRaAsu janobN waAlOamiyru janobu
[The people are a side and the prince is a side]: (Akh, S, TA:) as though he reckoned the latter equal to all the people. (TA. [This is cited in the S and TA as though it were an ex. of jnb in the sense here next following: but it seems to be rather an ex. of this word in the sense first explained in the present paragraph.]) ― -b3- I. q. naAHiyapN [A side; meaning a lateral, or an outward or adjacent, part or portion, region, quarter, or tract; or a part, region, quarter, or tract, considered with respect to its collocation or juxtaposition or direction, or considered as belonging to a whole; a vicinage, or neighbourhood]; (S, K;) as also jaAnibN↓ (S, Msb, K) and janaAbN↓ and janobapN↓ (S, K) and janabapN↓ (S) and janaAbapN↓. (L, TA.) It is said that the primary signification of janobN is the part of the body mentioned in the beginning of this paragraph, and that its use in the sense of naAHyapN is metaphorical, as is the case of yamiynN and XimaAlN; but naAHiyapN is mentioned in the Msb as the primary signification of jaAnibN↓; (MF, TA;) though its primary signification accord. to the K and ISd seems to be that first mentioned. (TA.) You say, maXawoA jaAnibayohi↓ and janaAbayohi↓ and janobatayohi↓ and janaAbatayohi↓ [They walked, or went on foot, on either side of him]. (A, TA. *) And marRuwA yasiyruwna janaAbayohi↓ (S, L) and janobatayohi↓ and janaAbatayohi↓ (L, TA) They went along journeying on either side of him. (S, L.) And kunRaA Eanohumo janaA bayoni↓ and janaAbFA↓ We were apart from them [on two sides and on one side]. (TA.) And nazaluwA AlwaAdiI fiI janaAbaAti↓ [They alighted in the sides of the valley, or in the tracts beside the valley]. (A.) And fulaAnN laA yaTuwru bijanabatinaA↓ Such a one will not approach our quarter: (S:) thus accord. to AO; with fet-h to the n: IJ, however, says, people are wont to say, OanaA fiI caraAka wajanabatika↓ [meaning I am under thy protection and in thy quarter]; but that the correct expression is janobatika↓, with the n quiescent. (IB, TA.) The Arabs also said, suhayolK AlHarRu jaAnibaIo↓, meaning (assumed tropical:) The heat is on either side of Suheyl [or Canopus: i. e., during the period next before, and that next after, the auroral rising of Canopus; which rising began, in central Arabia, at the commencement of the era of the Flight, about the 4th of August, O. S.]: this is the greatest heat. (TA.) One also says, OaHaATuwA bihi mino jaAnibayohi↓ [meaning They surrounded him on all his sides; lit., on his two sides]; dividing the surrounding parts into two, but not meaning that any of these remained vacant. (Expos. of the exs. cited as testimonies by Sb, TA in art. Hwl.) ― -b4- Also, [and jaAnibN↓, which is thus used in the L in art. jnH, and by many authors,] A part, or portion, of a thing; (L;) the greater, or main, or chief, part or portion thereof; most thereof; (L, K;) or a great part or portion thereof; much thereof. (L.) Hence, [or perhaps from janobN in the second of the senses assigned to it above, conveying the idea of juxtaposition, and thus of comparison,] hecaA qaliylN janobi mawadRatika [This is little in comparison with the magnitude of thy love; or simply, in comparison with thy love]. (TA.) ― -b5- yaA HasorataA EalaI maA farRaTotu fiI jnobi QllRehi [in the Kur xxxix. 57] means fI jaAnibih↓, i. e. (assumed tropical:) [O my grief, or regret, for my negligence, or remissness,] in respect of that which is the right, or due, of God! (A, Bd, TA,) i. e., (Bd,) in respect of obedience to God! (Bd, Jel:) or, in respect of [the means of attaining] nearness to God! (Fr, TA;) or, nearness to God in Paradise! (IAar, TA:) or, in respect of the way of God, to which He hath called me! i. e., the profession of his unity, and the confession of the prophetic office of Mohammad. (Zj, TA.) The saying of the Arabs, AitRaqi QllReha fiI janobihi walaA taqodaHo fiI saAqihi [may be rendered (assumed tropical:) Fear God in respect of his (thy brother's) right, or due, and impugn not his honour, or reputation: or] means, accord. to the copies of the K, laA taqotulohu [slay him not], or, as in the L, and in the original draught of the author [of the K] lA tagotalohu [slay him not clandestinely, or on an occasion of inadvertence], from Algiylapu, and throw him not into trouble, or trial: (TA:) or, accord. to some, fI jnbh means in detracting from his reputation, or reviling him. (K, TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 240.]) A poet, cited by IAar, says,
xaliylaIRa kufRaA waQcokuraA QllReha fiI janobiI
(assumed tropical:) [O my two friends, refrain, and be mindful of God in respect of my reputation; (see also jaAnibN;)] meaning, in detracting from my reputation, or reviling me: or, accord. to MF, in my case. (TA.) And one says, maA faEalota fiI janobi HaAjatiI (assumed tropical:) What didst thou, or what hast thou done, in the case of the thing that I want? (L, TA.)

janabN jnb
janabN: see janiybN. ＝ -A2- TawoEu Aljanabi: see jinaAbN. ＝ -A3- janabN also signifies Short; (K;) applied to a man. (TA.)

janibN jnb
janibN: see janiba. ― -b2- It is also applied as an epithet to a wolf, because he pretends to halt, from guile, or cunning. (L, TA.) ― -b3- Also A man who goes aside, or to a distance, from the beaten way, for fear of guests' coming to him for entertainment. (K, TA.)

junubN jnb
junubN, (El-Fárábee, S, A, Msb, K,) which is sometimes used in the sing. form as pl., and has no fem. form, (TA,) and jaAnibN↓ and OajonabiIRN↓, (El-Fárábee, S, Msb, K,) which is said by Az in art. rwH to be seldom or never used by the Arabs, but is mentioned by him in its proper art., (Msb,) and Oajonabu↓, (Az, S, Msb, K,) are syn., (El-Fárábee, S, Msb, K,) signifying A stranger; (K;) as also janiybN↓: (S:) or a man who is distant, or remote: (Msb:) or distant, or remote, in respect of relationship: (Az and Msb in explanation of the third and fourth:) [or not a relation; as will be seen from what follows:] and jaAnibN↓ [as an act. part. n.] signifies one alighting, or descending and abiding, or settling, as a stranger, among a tribe: (S:) pl. of the first OajonaAbN, (A, TA,) and of the second junRaAbN, (S, TA,) and of the fourth OajaAnibu. (Msb.) AljaAru Aljunubu [occurring in the Kur iv. 40] (T, S, A, Msb, K) and jaAru Aljunubi (TA) The person who is one's neighbour, but who belongs to another people; (T, S, A, Msb, K;) who is not of one's family nor of one's lineage; (A;) who is of another lineage than he of whom he is a neighbour; (T, TA;) who is not a relation: (MF:) or one who is distant, or remote, in an absolute sense: (TA:) or the person who is not a relation to another, and who comes to him, and asks him to protect him, and abides with him: such has the title to respect that belongs to him as neighbour of the other, and to his protection, and as relying upon his safeguard and promise. (TA in art. jwr. [Differing from jaAru Aljanobi, q. v. suprà.]) It is said in a trad., humo OajonaAbu AlnRaAsi They are the strangers of mankind, or of the people. (TA.) And in another trad., qaAla lijaAriyRpK halo mino mugaribapi Alxabaru xabarK qaAlato EalaI jaAnibK↓ [He said to a girl, Is there any news from abroad? She answered,] It is for a stranger coming from a journey [to give such news]. (TA.) And one says, huwa minRiI OajonabiIRN↓ [He is a person not related to me]. (A.) ― -b2- Also, ↓the same four words, (of which only the last is mentioned in this sense in the S,) That will not be led; intractable. (K.) ― -b3- junubN is also an epithet from AljanaAbapu; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) signifying A man under the obligation of performing a total ablution, by reason of sexual intercourse and discharge of the semen: (IAth, TA: [see 4:]) and is used alike as masc. and fem. (S, Mgh, Msb) and sing. (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and dual (Msb, TA) and pl.; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) being regarded as quasi-coordinate to the class of inf. ns.; for the inf. n., when used as an epithet, must remain, in form, sing. and masc.: (MF in art. Eft:) or one may use the dual form junubaAni; (K;) and sometimes they used the pl. OajonaAbN (S, Msb, K *) and junubuwna, (S, Msb,) and the fem. pl. junubaAtN; (Msb;) but not junubapN, (K, TA,) applied to a female. (TA.) It is said in a trad., laA tadoxulu AlmalaAYikapu biyotFA fiyhi junubN, meaning [The angels will not enter a house, or chamber, or tent, in which is] one who usually neglects the total ablution when under an obligation to perform it for the cause above mentioned. (IAth, TA.)

janobapN jnb jnbh jnbp
janobapN: see janobN, in four places: ― -b2- and see jaAnibN. ― -b3- Also Retirement, or secession, from others: (K, TA:) and in a trad., in which it is enjoined, used as meaning retirement from women; avoiding the sitting by them, and the approaching the place that they occupy. (TA.) You say, rajulN cuw janobapK A man of retirement. (TA.) And nazala janobapF He alighted, or descended and abode, or settled, in a place aside, or apart. (S, TA.) And qaEada janobapF He [sat apart, or] retired from others. (A, TA.) ― -b4- The state of being a stranger; as also janaAbapN↓. (K. [Both are there mentioned as simple substs.; but the latter is an inf. n.: see janaba fiI baniI fulaAnK; and what next follows it: and see also 4.]) Both also signify Remoteness in respect of relationship. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, janobapN, A piece of skin from the side of a camel, (S, L, K, *) of which is made a kind of milking vessel (Eulobap), (S, L,) larger than the miEolaq, but smaller than the jawobap. (L.) ＝ -A3- And Every kind of plant, (S,) or
every kind of tree in general, (K,) that produces [new leaves such as are termed] rabol in the season of the Sayof [which may mean either summer or spring]: (S, K:) or every kind of plant that produces leaves in that season without rain: (TA:) or a name given to many plants, all of them Euruwq [perhaps meaning resembling roots, i. e. straggling, or spreading like roots]; so called because less than large trees and higher than those that have no root-stock (Oaruwmap) in the earth; comprising the naSiIR and SilRiyaAn and HamaAT and makor and Hcr [so in the TA, but I do not find it elsewhere, and think it may be a mistranscription for Hazor, of which Hazorap (the name of a certain sour tree) is probably the n. un.,] and dahomaMC; which are smaller than Xajar and superior to buquwl: all this has been heard from the Arabs: (T, TA:) or green and fresh SlRyAn: (TA:) or what is [of a kind] between baqol and Xajar; (AHn, K, TA;) being [in the TA whmA, but this is evidently a mistake for wahiIa,] of the kind of which the root remains in the winter while the branches perish: (AHn, TA:) or herbage of which the root is deep in the earth; such as the naSiIR and the SilRiyaAn. (TA voce xaDirN.)

janabapN jnb jnbh jnbp
janabapN: see janobN, in four places: ― -b2- and see jaAnibN.

junabapN jnb jnbh jnbp
junabapN A thing from which one retires, or withdraws himself, to a distance, or far away, or far off; from which one stands, or keeps, aloof. (K.)

janaAbN jnAb
janaAbN: see janobN, in five places. [Hence,] kunRaA Eanohumo janaAbayoni and janaAbFA We were remote, or retired, from them; or out of their way. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (S, A, Msb, K,) and jaAnibN↓, (Msb, * TA,) A court, or yard, or an open or a wide space in front of a house or extending from its sides: (S, A, K, TA:) and a place of alighting or abode; or a settlement, or place of settling: (A:) a mansion; an abode; a habitation; or a place to which a man betakes himself, or repairs, for lodging, covert, or refuge, in a city or town or village or other place of settled habitations; syn. raHolN: (K:) and a vicinage, neighbourhood, or tract adjacent to the place of abode or settlement, of a people or company of men: pl. OajonibapN. (S.) You say, OanaA fiI janaAbi zayodK I am in the court, or yard, of Zeyd; and in his place of alighting or abode, or settlement. (A, TA.) And fulaAnN raHobu AljanaAbi, (A, TA,) and xaSiybu AljanaAbi, (S, A,) the former meaning Such a one is possessed of an ample raHol [or mansion, &c., as explained above]: (TA:) [and the latter, such a one is surrounded by a plentiful, or fruitful, tract:] or both mean (tropical:) such a one is generous or bountiful [or hospitable]. (A.) And falaAnN jadiybu AljanaAbi (S, TA) [meaning Such a one is environed by a tract affected with drought, or barrenness; as explained in the S in art. jdb: but generally used tropically, as meaning (assumed tropical:) such a one is ungenerous, illiberal, or inhospitable]. And OaxoSaba janaAbu Alqawomi [The neighbourhood of the people, or the tract surrounding them, became plentiful, or fruitful]. (S, TA.) And Oajodaba binaA AljanaAbu [Our neighbourhood, or the tract surrounding us, became affected with drought, or barrenness]. (TA from a trad.) ― -b3- rajulN layRinu AljanaAbi [perhaps a mistranscription for AljaAnibi] (tropical:) A man easy to deal with, compliant, or obsequious.
