(A.) ― -b4- [AljanaAbu is also a title often given by writers of letters and the like to any great man to whom others betake themselves, or repair, for protection; and sometimes to God; meaning (tropical:) The object of recourse; the refuge; the asylum: similar to AlHaDorapu, q. v., and used in the same manner, i. e., alone, and, without the article, prefixed to the name of the person to whom it is applied, or to a pronoun; but the latter is generally considered as implying greater respect than the former.]

AljunaAbu AljnAb jnAb
AljunaAbu i. q. caAtu Aljanobi: see janobu. (K.)

jinaAbN jnAb
jinaAbN A cord tied to the head and neck of a beast, by which he is led, or drawn. (KL.) [Hence,] farasN TawoEu AljanaAbi A horse easily led; or easy to be led; tractable; [obedient to the jnAb;] (S, A, K, TA;) as also TawoEu Aljanabi↓. (TA. [See 1, near the beginning.])

januwbN jnwb
januwbN, of the fem. gender, and, accord. to Sb, both a subst. and an epithet, [so that one says riyHN januwbN, as well as januwbN alone and riyHu Aljanuwbi,] (TA,) [The south wind: or a southerly wind:] the wind that is opposite to that called the XamaAl: (S, K:) [consequently, the wind that blows from the direction of the south pole, accord. to the S;] the wind that blows from the direction of the left hand of a person standing opposite to the kibleh [by which is here meant that corner of the Kaabeh in which is set the Black Stone; which corner is towards the east]: (Th, TA:) or the wind that blows from the quarter between the place where Canopus rises [S. 29? E. in central Arabia] and the place where the same star sets [S. 29? W. in the same latitude]: ('Omárah, TA:) or from the quarter between the place where Canopus rises and the place where the sun sets in winter [W. 26? S. in central Arabia]: (As, TA:) or it is a hot wind, that blows in every season; blowing from that part of the tract between the quarter whence blows the east wind (AlSRabaA) and that whence blows the west wind (AldRabuwr) which is next to the place where Canopus rises: (T, TA:) or the wind that blows from the quarter between the place where Canopus rises and that where the Pleiades set [W. 26? N. in central Arabia]: (IAar, K:) [the points whence it usually blows seem to differ somewhat in different parts:] As says that the jnwb is attended by good, and by fecundating influence; and the XmAl by drying up [of the earth &c.]: (TA:) accord. to IAar, it is hot in every place, except in Nejd, where it is cold, or cool: (MF:) pl. janaAYibu (T, K) and [of pauc.] OajonubN. (T, TA.) ― -b2- One says, of two persons, when they are on terms of sincere friendship, riyHuhumaA januwbN (assumed tropical:) [Their wind is south, or southerly]; and when they are separated, Xamalato riyHuhumaA (assumed tropical:) [Their wind has become north, or northerly]. (TA.)

janiybN jnyb
janiybN, applied to a horse and a captive, (TA,) Led by one's side; as also majonuwbN↓ and mujanRabN↓: (K:) or you say xayolN majanRabapN↓, meaning horses led by the side; the teshdeed denoting application to many objects: (S, TA:) pl. [of the first, and of janiybapN, q. v., or only of this last,] janaAYibu and [quasi-pl. n.] janabN↓. (K.) One walking by the side of another; (A;) [and] so junRaAbN↓. (K.) ― -b2- Any animal or man that is obedient, tractable, or submissive. (S, TA.) You say, OaSobaHa janiybahu He became compliant to him. (A.) ＝ -A2- See also junubN. ＝ -A3- Also, applied to a man, [app. Having a pain in the side; or having the pleurisy; like majonuwbN: and hence, or from janiba, q. v., irregularly formed,] as though walking on one side, bent or crooked, mutaEaqRifFA: so in the L: in the M and K, on the authority of IAar, mutaEaqRibFA [to which I am unable to assign an appropriate meaning, except its modern one of lagging behind]: so in the saying of a poet,
rabaA AljuwEu fiI Oawonayohi HatRaI kaOanRahu
janiybN bihi UinRa Aljaniyba janiybu
[Hunger increased in him (lit. in the two sides of his saddle-bags); so that he seemed as though he walked on one side, bent thereby; for he who has a pain in his side walks on one side, in that manner]. (TA.) ＝ -A4- Also An excellent kind of dates, (K, TA,) well known; (TA;) one of the best kinds of dates. (Mgh in art. jmE, Msb.)

janaAbapN jnAb jnAbh jnAbp
janaAbapN: see janobN, in four places: and see jaAnibN. ＝ -A2- See also janobapN. ― -b2- Accord. to IAth, its primary signification is Distance: and hence it signifies The state of him who is under the obligation of performing a total ablution, by reason of sexual intercourse and discharge of the semen. (TA.) ― -b3- The sperma genitalis [itself]. (K. [But in a marginal note in my copy of that work I find this last signification rejected as erroneous.]) ＝ -A3- See also the next paragraph.

janiybapN jnybh jnybp
janiybapN A led horse or mule or ass; (S, TA;) a horse that is led [by one's side], not ridden: (Msb:) pl. janaAYibu. (A, TA.) ― -b2- janiybataA AlbaEiyri The [two equal] loads on the two sides of the camel. (K.) ― -b3- [Hence, app.,] AitRaqi QllReha AlRaciI laA janybapa lahu (tropical:) Fear thou God, to whom there is no equal. (A, TA.) ― -b4- Also janiybupN, (S,) or janaAbapN↓, (K,) or both, (TA,) A she-camel that one gives [or lends] to people, (S, M, K,) with money, (M, TA,) in order that they may bring corn or other provision for him; (S, M, K;) also called EaliyqapN: pl. janaAYibu. (S.) ＝ -A2- Also, (Kr, M, K,) and xabiybapN, (M, TA,) The wool of a vanRiI [or sheep in its third year]: (Kr, M, K:) it is better and cleaner than what is termed Eaqiyqap, which is the wool of a jacaE [or sheep in or before its second year]. (TA.)

januwbiIRN jnwb jnwbI jnwby
[januwbiIRN Of, or relating to, the quarter of the wind termed the januwb; south, or southerly.]

janaAYibN c
janaAYibN as an extr. pl.: see janobN, first sentence.

junRaAbN jnAb
junRaAbN: see janiybN.

jaAnibN jAnb
jaAnibN; pl. jawaAnibu: see janobN, in eleven places.
[Hence, laAna jaAnibuhu (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, gentle, easy to deal with, compliant, or obsequious. And rajulN layRinu AljaAnibi (assumed tropical:) A man who is gentle, easy to deal with, compliant, or obsequious; contr. of galiyZu AljaAnibi; see art. glZ: and see janaAbN. And] tuzanRu biliyni AljaAnibi (assumed tropical:) [She is suspected of easiness, or compliance], (K in art. lms,) towards him who desires of her that he may lie with her. (TA in that art.) [Hence also,] jaAnibaA AlOanofi (CK) and janaAbataA↓ and janobataA↓ and janabataA↓ (K) The two sides of the nose: (K:) or the two lines that surround the two sides of the nose of a doe-gazelle: (Sb, TA:) pl. [of the second, agreeably with analogy,] janaAYibu. (TA.) ― -b2- See also janaAbN. [It often signifies The vicinage or neighbourhood of a people &c.: and a region or quarter or tract of a people or country: like nAHyp. ― -b3- The bank of a river; and any bank, or steep acclivity. ― -b4- And A limit, bound, or boundary: see a tropical usage of its pl. (jawaAnibu) voce. HinowN. ― -b5- And EalaI jaAnibK means Beside, aside, or apart; and so jaAnibFA, and fiI jaAnibK. ― -b6- jaAnibN mino maAlK, in posi-classical writings, means A portion, and particularly a large portion, of property: and jaAnibN alone, in the same, a sum, and particularly a large sum, of money. ― -b7- The latter, also, in post-classical writings, signifies, like janobN, q. v., (assumed tropical:) A man's honour, or reputation, which should be preserved inviolate; so used in the K voce EiroDN, in an explanation of the latter word taken from IAth; i. q. naAmuwsN and HuromapN, as in the TK in that case.] ＝ -A2- Avoided and despised. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps, daEo kacaA jaAnibFA Let thou, or leave thou, such a thing alone: see an ex. voce OawRN.] ― -b3- See also junubN, in four places. ― -b4- And see mujanRabN.

Oajonabu c
Oajonabu: see junubN, in two places.

OajonabiIRN c
OajonabiIRN: see junubN, in three places ― -b2- You say also, huwa OajonabiIRN mino kacaA, (A,) or Eino kcA, (TA,) (tropical:) He has no concern nor acquaintance with such a thing. (A, TA.)

majonabN mjnb
majonabN (S, AAF, K) and mijonabN↓ (AAF, K) Much (A'Obeyd, S, AAF, K) of good (A'Obeyd, K) and of evil. (K.) You say, UinRa EinodanaA laxayorFA majonabFA Verily with us is much good, and XarRFA majonabFA much evil. (S.) And TaEaAmN majonabN means Much [wheat or food]. (Sh, TA.)

mujonibN mjnb
mujonibN: see what next follows.

mijonabN mjnb
mijonabN A shield; (S, A, K;) because it wards off from its possessor what is displeasing to him; (A, TA;) also with damm to the m [app. mujonibN↓, act. part. n. of 4]. (K.) ― -b2- A thing by which a person or thing is veiled, concealed, or hidden; a veil, curtain, or covering; (K, TA;) for a house, or chamber, or tent. (TA.) ― -b3- A thing like a door, upon which the gatherer of honey stands; (K, TA;) he being let down [upon it] by means of ropes to [the place of] the honey [in the face of a rock or mountain]. (TA.) ― -b4- A thing (XabaHN [app. here meaning a wooden implement]) resembling a comb without teeth (K, TA) and thinedged in its lowest part, (TA,) with which earth is raised upon, or against, the OaEoDaAd and fulojaAn [or raised borders of watering-troughs or the like, and streamlets for irrigation]. (K, TA. [In the CK, AlfilojAni is put for AlfulojAni.]) ― -b5- The extreme part of the territory of the foreigners towards that of the Arabs: (S, K:) and the nearest part of the territory of the Arabs to that of the foreigners. (S) ＝ -A2- See also majonabN.

mujanRabN mjnb
mujanRabN; and its fem., with p: see janiybN. ― -b2- Also, the former, (TA,) or jaAnibN↓, (K, [but this is said in the TA to be a mistake,]) A horse wide in the space between the two kind legs, (K, TA,) without what is termed fajajN [which is an awkward kind of straddling, with the hocks wide apart]: it is a quality approved. (TA. [See also 2; and see muHanRabN.])

mujanRibN mjnb
mujanRibN A man whose sheep or goats [&c.] have few young ones; [and therefore, having little milk;] (TA in art. ysr;) contr. of muyasarN. (S and TA in that art. [See also 2.])

mujanRabapN mjnbh mjnbp
mujanRabapN The van, or fore part, (K, TA,) of an army. (TA.)

AlmujanRibataAni AlmjnbtAn mjnbp
AlmujanRibataAni The right and left wings of an army: (K: [Golius has erroneously written mijonabataAni, and has given J as the authority instead of the K:]) or mujanRabapN signifies a portion of an army (katiybapN) that takes one of the two sides of a way: but the former meaning is the more correct. (IAar, TA.)

majonuwibN mjnwb
majonuwibN pass. part. n. of 1 [q. v.]. ― -b2- See also jniybN. ― -b3- Also Affected by the disease termed caAtu Aljanobi [or pleurisy]: (S, Mgh, Msb, TA:) and said to mean also having a complaint of his side, absolutely. (TA.) ― -b4- And Affected by the [south, or southerly, wind called] januwb. (S, TA.) [And Affected by that wind in one's cattle: see 1, last sentence.] saHaAbapN majonuwbapN A cloud brought by the blowing of that wind. (S, A, K.) The saying of Aboo-Wejzeh,
majonuwbapu AlOunosi maXomuwlN mawaAEiduhaA
means Her familiarity passes away with the januwb [or south-wind], and her promises pass away with the XamaAl [or north wind]. (IAar, TA.)

jinovN jnv
jinovN i. q. OaSolN [as meaning The stock, or stem, or the root, or base, or lowest part, of a tree or plant: and the stock, or origin, of a man]; (S, K;) a dial. var. of jinosN, or a word mispronounced: (S:) or, as some say, a root (of a tree) of which the Oaruwmap [i. e. root-stock] is erect in the ground: or the part of the saAq [i. e. stock, or stem,] of a tree that is in the ground, above the Euruwq [or roots properly so called]: (L, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OajonaAvN and [of mult.] junuwvN. (TA.) One says, fulaAnN mino jinovika and jinosika, meaning mn OaSolika [i. e. Such a one is of thy stock]. (S.) And UinRahu layarojiEu UilaI jinovi SidoqK [Verily he traces back his lineage to an excellent stock, or origin]. (TA.)

1 janaHa jnH jnHp
1. janaHa, (S, A, K, &c.,) aor.
janaHa
, (S, Msb, K,) agreeably with analogy, of the dial. of Temeem, and the most chaste form, (TA,) and
januHa
, (S, Msb, K,) of the dial. of Keys, (TA,) and
janiHa
, (K,) inf. n. junuwHN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He, or it, inclined, leant, or propended, (S, A, Mgh, L, K) Uilayohi (L, Msb) and lahu (L) [to, or towards, it]; as also AjtnH↓, (S, Mgh, K,) and AjnH↓. (K [but, by the omission of a w after it, this is made in some copies of the K to relate to what there follows it].) It is said in the Kur [viii. 63], waUino janaHuwA lilsRalomi faQjonaHo lahaA (Mgh, L) And if they incline to peace, incline thou to it: slm being here made fem. because syn. with muSaAlaHap. (L.) You say, janaHuwA lilsRalomi and Uilayohi. (A.) ― -b2- He (a man) inclined, or leant, on one side; and leant upon his bow: as also AjtnH↓: and Ealayohi AjtnH↓ he leant upon him. (L.) And janaHato She (a camel lying on her breast) leant on one side. (AO, TA.) ― -b3- He (a man) set about a thing, to do it with his hands, his breast leaning over it. (T, TA.) ― -b4- janaHa EalaI mirofaqayohi, inf. n. junuwHN and janoHN, He (a man) rested himself upon his elbows, having set them upon the ground or upon a cushion. (ISh, TA.) ― -b5- janaHa Uilayohimo and lahumo He [inclined to them; or] followed them and submitted to them; namely, a sect. (ISh, TA.) ― -b6- janaHati AlXRamosu liloguruwbi [The sun inclined to setting]. (A.) ― -b7- janaHa, (A, L, Msb,) aor.
janaHa
, (L, Msb,) inf. n. junuwHN, (S, L, K,) said of the night, (S, A, L, Msb, K) and of the evening, (A,) and of the darkness, (L,) It inclined to going, or to coming: (A:) or it came on, or approached. (S, L, Msb, K.) ― -b8- Also, with the same aor. and inf. n., said of a bird, It contracted its wings to descend, or alight, and approached like one falling, and repairing to a place of refuge. (L.) ― -b9- janaHato said of camels, They lowered the fore part of the neck [in running]: or they went quickly, or swiftly. (TA.) ― -b10- And, inf. n. junuwHN, said of a ship (safiynap), She came to shallow water, and stuck to the ground, (A, L,)so as to cease from motion. (L.) ＝ -A2- janaHa, inf. n. junuwHN, He (a man) gave with his [janaAH, or] hand. (TA.) ＝ -A3- janaHahu, (S, L,) aor.
janaHa
, inf. n. janoHN, (L,) He hit, or hurt, its janaAH [or wing]; (S, L;) i. e., the jnAH of the bird. (S.) And janaHa fulaAnFA He hit, or hurt, the arm (janaAH) of such a one. (K. [In some copies of the K, by the omission of a w, this signification is erroneously made to relate to AjnH: so in the copies used by MF and SM, who state that the right verb is janaHa]) ＝ -A4- juniHa, (S, K,) with damm, (S,) like EuniIa, (K,) inf. n. junuwHN, (TA,) He (a camel) had his jawaAniH [the ribs so called] broken by reason of the heaviness of his load: (S, K:) or
he (a camel) had the first of his ribs broken in the part next the breast. (TA.) ＝ -A5- [janaHa also signifies He regarded an act as a crime, or sin. Thus,] UinRI laOajonaHu Oano Mkula minohu, in a trad. respecting the property of the orphan, means Verily I regard as a crime, or sin, (junaAH,) my eating, or devouring, [aught] thereof. (TA.)

2 jnRHhu jnH jnHh jnHp
2. jnRHhu, inf. n. tajoniyHN, He furnished it with wings, or (assumed tropical:) the like: see mujanRaHN.]

4 AjnH OjnH AjnH jnAH jnH
4. AjnH: see 1, first sentence. ＝ -A2- AjnHhu He made him, or it, to incline, lean, or propend. (S, K.)

5 tajanRaHa
5: see 8.

8 AjtnH AjtnH
8. AjtnH: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- Also He (an old man) leant towards the ground, supporting himself with his hands upon his knees, by reason of his weakness. (Mgh.) And He (a man prostrating himself in prayer) rested upon his palms, putting his fore arms apart (from his sides, IAth), not laying them on the ground; (so that they became like the wings of a bird; IAth); as also tjnRH↓. (Sh, IAth, Mgh, K.) ― -b3- AijotinaAHN in a she-camel is The going quickly, or swiftly: (Sh, K:) or the going so that her hinder part as it were leans towards her fore part, by reason of her vehement pressing on, (ISh, K, *) by her pushing forward her kind legs towards her breast: (ISh:) and in a horse, the running with a uniform leaning on one side. (A, O, K.)

10 AstjnH AstjnH
10. AstjnH It (the night) began. (L.)

junoHu AllRayoli jnH Allyl
junoHu AllRayoli (S, A, Msb, K) and jinoHuhu↓ (S, Msb, K) A part, or portion, of the night: (S, A, K:) or a great, or the greater, part thereof: or the first part thereof: or a part thereof, about the half: (L:) or the darkness thereof; and its confusedness. (Msb.) kaOanRahu junoHu layolK [As though it were a portion, &c., of a night] is said of a numerous army heavily encumbered. (L.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce UinRa.]

jinoHN jnH jnHp
jinoHN A side (S, Msb, K) of a road. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- And The vicinage or neighbourhood, or the region or quarter or tract, and the shadow or shelter or protection, syn. naAHiyapN and kanafN, (S, K,) as also janaAHN↓, (K,) of a people, or party, or company of men: (S:) the latter word thus used is tropical. (TA.) You say, baAta bijinoHi Alqawomi He passed the night in the vicinage, &c., of the people. (S, TA.) And OanaA fiI janaAHihi↓ (tropical:) I am in his shadow, shelter, or protection. (TA.) ― -b3- See also the next preceding paragraph.

janaAHN jnAH
janaAHN The yad (S, K) [meaning wing] of a bird or flying thing; (S;) i. e., of a bird or flying thing, the limb that corresponds to the yd of a man: (Msb:) and also the yd [i. e. arm, sometimes also meaning hand, (see a signification of janaHa,)] of a man: (L, TA:) and (K) the upper arm, or arm from the shoulder to the elbow: (Zj, L, K:) each of these is so called because it is on one side of the body: (L:) and the armpit: (K:) pl. OajoniHapN (S, Msb, K) and OajonuHN: (IJ, K:) the sing., though masc., has the latter pl., which properly belongs to a fem. sing. [of this form], because jnAH is assimilated to riyXapN; (IJ;) [or rather, I think, to yadN, which is fem.;] but some assert jnAH to be both masc. and fem. (MF.) [Hence,] huwa maqoSuwSu AljanaAHi [He has the wing clipped; meaning] (tropical:) he is one who lacks strength or power or ability; he is impotent. (A, TA.) And xafaDa lahu janaAHahu (tropical:) [He abased himself to him: lit. he lowered to him his wing: but see an explanation of a similar phrase in the Kur, below]. (A.) And rakibuwA janaAHaIi AlTRaAYiri, (Fr, L, K,) in [some of the copies of] the K, AlTRariyqi, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) They quitted their homes, or accustomed places. (Fr, L, K.) And fulaAnN fiI janaAHaIo TaAYirK Such a one is in a state of disquiet, and confounded, or perplexed, unable to see his right course. (L, A. *) And rakiba fulaAnN janaAHaIi AlnRaEaAmapi (tropical:) Such a one employed himself vigorously, labouriously, sedulously, or diligently, in an affair; (A, K;) managing well. (K.) And naHonu EalaI janaAHi AlsRafari [lit. We are on the wing of travel; meaning] (tropical:) we are about to travel, or journey. (K, TA.) And janaAHu Alfarasi (assumed tropical:) A certain star [ γ] of Pegasus; one of the four bright stars, in Pegasus, which form a square; the other three being that at the extremity of the neck, called Eayonu Alfarasi, [i. e. a of Pegasus,] that called manokibu Alfarasi, [ β of Pegasus,] and the star [a of Andromeda] that belongs to both Pegasus and Andromeda. (Kzw.) [And janaAHu samakapK (assumed tropical:) The fin of a fish.] And janaAHaA naSolK (assumed tropical:) The two wings, or blades, of a spear-head or of an arrow-head. (L.) And janaAHu AlrRaHaI (assumed tropical:) The wing (naAEuwr) of the mill or mill-stone. (L.) And janaAHaA EasokarK (tropical:) The two wings of an army. (A, TA) And janaAHaA AlwaAdiI (tropical:) The two sides of the valley (A, L) down which the water runs, on the right and left. (L.) And variydapN lahaA janaAHaAni mino EuraAqK and biAlEuraAqi mujanRaHapN↓ (tropical:) [A mess of crumbled bread moistened with broth, having two sidegarnishes of bones with some meat remaining upon them]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- See also jinoHN, in two places. ― -b3- Also The side, syn. jaAnibN. (K.) So in the saying in the Kur [xvii. 25], waQxofiDo lahumaA janaAHa AlcRulRi, meaning waOalino lahumaA jaAnibaka AlcRaliyla (tropical:) [And make soft to them [thy two parents) thy submissive side; i. e. treat them with gentleness and submissiveness: or the former words may be literally rendered lower to them the wing of submissiveness; meaning be submissive to them]. (Jel, TA.) ― -b4- And A part, or portion, of a thing; as also junaAHN↓. (K.)

junaAHN jnAH
junaAHN A sin, a crime, or an act of disobedience: (AHeyth, S, A, IAth, L, Msb, K:) or an inclining thereto: (IAth, * L, TA:) and anxiety, and annoyance or molestation or hurt, which one is made to bear. (L, TA.) laA junaAHa Ealayokumo, in the Kur ii. 235, means, accord. to AHeyth, There shall be no sin, or crime, chargeable upon you: or, accord. to others, there shall be no straitening of you. (L.) ＝ -A2- See also janaAHN, last signification.

jaAniHN jAnH
jaAniHN Inclining, leaning, or propending: pl. OajonaAHN, like as OaXohaAdN is pl. of XaAhidN. (L, TA.)

jaAniHapN jAnH jAnHh jAnHp
jaAniHapN sing. of jawaAniHu; (S, K;) which latter signifies The ribs of the breast: (A:) or the ribs that are beneath [those called] the taraAYib, of the part next the breast; (S, K;) like the DuluwE of the part next the back: (S:) or the anterior parts of those ribs; so called because they incline over the heart: or the short ribs that are in the anterior part of the breast: or, of a camel and a horse and the like, the ribs against which lies the shoulder-blade: and of a man, the ribs of the back which are called daOoI, six in number, three on the right and three on the left. (L.)

majonaHapN mjnH mjnHh mjnHp
majonaHapN A piece of leather upon the fore part of the camel's saddle, upon which the rider leans with his hands, thus resting himself. (TA. [See 8.])

mujanRaHN mjnH
mujanRaHN [Furnished with wings, or (assumed tropical:) the like]. ― -b2- [Hence,] variydapN mujanRaHapN biAlEuraAqi: see janaAHN. ― -b3- naAqapN mujanRaHapu Aljabiyni (assumed tropical:) A she-camel wide in the jbyn [app. here meaning the forehead]. (TA.)

2 jnRd junuwdFA jnd jnwdA
2. jnRd junuwdFA (S, A) He collected, or assembled, jnwd [i. e. armies, military forces, &c.]. (A.)

5 tjnRd jnd tjnd
5. tjnRd He took or prepared, for himself, a junod [i. e. an army, a military force, &c.]. (A, TA.)

junodN jnd
junodN [a coll. gen. n.] An army; a military force; a legion; a body of troops or soldiers; (L, K;) a collected body of men prepared for war: (Mgh:) auxiliaries: (S, L, Msb, K:) n. un. junodiIRN↓ [signifying a trooper; a soldier; an auxiliary]; like as ruwmiIRN is n. un. of ruwmN: (Msb:) pl. of the former, junuwdN (S, A, Mgh, Msb) and [pl. of pauc.] OajonaAdN. (Mgh, Msb.) It is said in a trad., AlOarowaAHu junuwdN mujanRadapN↓ (S, A, L) Souls are troops collected together: meaning that they are created of two parties, each party agreeing together, and disagreeing with the other party, like two armies opposed, each to the other. (L.) ― -b2- Also Any kind, or species, of creatures, or created things, regarded as alone, by itself, or apart from others. (K, * TA.) It is said in a prov., UinRa lilRhi junuwdFA minohaA AlEasalu Verily to God belong kinds, or species, of created things [by means of which He effects his purposes as by armies or auxiliaries], of which is honey: (Z, K:) first said by Mo'áwiyeh, when he heard that El-Ashtar had been given to drink some honey containing poison, in consequence of which he died: and used on the occasion of rejoicing at a misfortune that has befallen an enemy: it occurs in the history of El-Mes'oodee thus; UinRa lilRhi junodFA fiI AlEasali. (MF.) ― -b3- Also, [as a term used in Syria, and afterwards by the Arabs from Syria in Spain,] A city [with its territory; i. e. a
province, or district]: (K:) or particularly a city of Syria [with its territory]: (AO, TA:) pl. OajonaAdN. (TA.) Syria consists of five AjnAd; namely, Dimashk [or Damascus], Hims [or Emessa], Kinnesreen, El-Urdunn [or the Jordan], and Filasteen or Falasteen [or Palestine]: (S, M, A:) they were thus called because the military forces were thence collected. (A.) [See mixolaAfN.]

junodiIRN jnd jndI jndy
junodiIRN: see junodN. ― -b2- Also Of, or relating to, a junod of Syria. (A.)

junodN mujanRadN jnd mjnd
junodN mujanRadN An army, or a military force, collected. (TA.) See also junodN.

junodabN jndb
junodabN and junodubN and janodabN: see art. jdb.

janodara jndr
janodara: see Q. Q. 1 in art. jdr.

Q. 1 janodala
Q. 1: [janodalahu He, or it, made him to cleave to the stones. Hence,] taribato yadaAhu wajunodilato [May his arms, or his hands, cleave to the dust, or earth, and the stones, by reason of poverty]. (M in art. trb.)

janodalN jndl
janodalN (S, K) and janodilN (K) Stones; (S in art. jdl;) used in the sense of [the pl.] janaAdilu: (Sb, TA:) n. un. janodalapN: (TA:) or what a man can lift, of stones: (K:) or, as some say, any stone: (TA:) or a mass of stone like a man's head. (T, TA.) [Hence, turobFA lahu wajanodalFA: see turaAbN.]

janadilN jndl
janadilN, (S in art. jdl,) or junadilN, (Kr, K,) A place in which are stones (Kr, S, K) collected together: (Kr, K:) but ISd doubts its correctness. (TA.) And OaroDN junadilapN, (K,) and sometimes with fet-h, (Sgh, K,) i. e., to the j, [janadilapN,] (TK,) A land abounding with stones. (Sgh, K.)

junaAdilN jnAdl jndl
junaAdilN Strong and great. (K.)

1 janazahu jnz jnzh jnzp
1. janazahu, aor.
janiza
, (A, Msb, K,) and
januza
, (A,) inf. n. janozN, (TA,) He veiled, concealed, hid, or covered, it. (A, Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- He collected it; or gathered it together or up; (K;) as also jnRzihu↓, inf. n. tajoniyzN. (Sgh, TA.) You say also, junaza AlrRajulu, part. n. majonuwzN↓, The man was gathered up [app. as a corpse is gathered up in the grave-clothes]: (TA:) or (assumed tropical:) he died. (Har p. 122.)

2 jnRzhu jnz jnzh jnzp
2. jnRzhu, inf. n. tajoniyzN: see 1. ― -b2- It is used by El-Hasan El-Basree as signifying He put it (namely a corpse) upon the bier. (K, * TA.)

jinaAzapN jnAz jnAzh jnAzp
jinaAzapN and janaAzapN signify the same, (Mgh, Msb, K,) namely, A dead person; a corpse: (K:) but the former is the more chaste: (Msb:) or the former signifies the dead person; and the latter, the bier: (As, IAar, Msb, K:) or the former, the bier; and the latter, the dead person: (Mgh, Msb, K:) so accord. to Th, as related by Aboo-'Amr Ez-Záhid: (Msb:) or the former is said by the vulgar to mean the bier: (As, TA:) or the former signifies the bier with the dead person: (K:) or the dead person upon the bier: (S:) and the bier is not so called unless the dead person is upon it: (AAF:) when the dead person is not upon it, it is called sariyrN and naEoXN: (AAF, S:) but the vulgar say janaAzapN, with fet-h; (S;) which is not allowable: (Lth, As, Mgh, TA:) or janaAzapN [so in the TA] signifies the man: or the bier with the man: (En-Nadr, TA:) jnAzp is derived from janazahu, in the first of the senses assigned to it above: (A, Msb, TA:) so some assert: (IDrd, TA:) but ISd says, I know not whether this be correct: (TA:) or a janaAzap is so called because the clothes are gathered together when the man is upon the bier: ('Abd-Allah Ibn-El-Hasan, TA:) some say that it is Nabathean: (TA:) the pl. is janaAYizu. (S.) The Arabs say, tarakotuhu jinaAzapF I left him a corpse, or dead. (As, TA.) And Duriba AlrRajulu HatRaI turika janaAzapF [so in the TA, The man was beaten until he was left a corpse]. (ISh, TA.) And rumiIa fiI jinaAzatihi, meaning, He died: (Lth, Mgh:) or he has been carried, or lifted, and put [into his bier]: this they say when they give information of the death of a man: (TA:) and they say also, TuEina fiI jinaAzatihi, meaning the same. (Lth, Mgh, TA.) ― -b2- Also jinaAzapN [or janaAzapN] (tropical:) A wine-skin [when emptied; as though it were a body without a soul]. (K.) A certain impudent man of the Arabs, 'Amr Ibn- Ki'ás, says,
wakunotu UicaA OaraI ziqRFA SariyEFA
yunaAHu EalaI janaAzatihi bakayotu
[And I used, when I saw a wine-skin laid prostrate, its corpse being wailed over, to weep, or accord. to Th, as is said in the TA in art. bkI, to sing]. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Anything oppressive and grievous, EalaI qawomK to a people. (Lth, K.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) A sick person. (Sgh, K.)

janaAYiziIRN c
janaAYiziIRN, [from janaAYizu, pl. of janaAzapN,] One who recites [or chants the profession of the faith &c.] before the dead [in a funeral-procession]. (TA.)

majonuwzN mjnwz
majonuwzN: see 1.

2 jnRshu bihi jnsh bh jnsh bp
2. jnRshu bihi, (TK,) inf. n. tajoniysN, from Aljinosu, (S, K,) [He made it homogeneous, or congenial, with it; or similar, or conformable, to it: expl. in the TK, not well, by XAklh; but the inf. n., with tolerable correctness, by AykI XyYI brI brynh mXAkl qlmq. The usage of the term tajoniysN in rhetoric, to signify the use of two or more words completely or partly conformable, is post-classical, like jinaAsN, an inf. n. of jaAnasa.]

3 jAnshu jAns jAnsh jAnsp
3. jAnshu, [inf. n. mujaAnasapN and jinaAsN,] It was, or became, homogeneous, or congenial, with it; or similar, or conformable, to it; syn. XaAkalahu: (Mgh, Msb:) AlmujaAnasapu is from Aljinosu. (S, TA.) You say, hecaA yujaAnisu hecaA This is homogeneous with this; syn. yuXaAkiluhu: (Mgh, Msb:) so says Kh. (Msb.) And kayofa yuWaAnisuka mano laA yujaAnisuka [How will he be sociable with thee who will not be congenial with thee?]. (A.) And of a man who has not discrimination nor intelligence, one says, fulaAnN yujaAnisu AlbahaAYima walaA yujaAnisu AlnRaAsa [Such a one resembles the beasts, and does not resemble men]: (Mgh, Msb, * TA:) so says Kh. (Mgh.) But As says that this usage, (Mgh, Msb,) in the first and last of the above-mentioned phrases, (Msb,) is post-classical. (Mgh, Msb.) The usage of the term jinaAsN by rhetoricians [to signify the complete or partial conformity of two or more words] is post-classical [like tajoniysN]. (TA.)

6 tjAns AlXRayoMni c
6. tjAns AlXRayoMni [The two things were, or became homogeneous, congenial, similar, or conformable,] is a phrase of the scholastic theologians, not [classical] Arabic. (TA.)

jinosN jns
jinosN [A genus, kind, or generical class, comprising under it several species, or sorts; or comprised under a superior genus, in relation to which it is a species, or sort;] a Darpb of a thing; (S;) or of anything; (Mgh, Msb;) any Darob of a thing; (A, K;) [as] of men, and of birds, and of the definitions of grammar and of the art of versification, and of things collectively; so accord. to the lexicologists; (ISd, TA;) a term of more common import than nawoE [which is a species, or sort]: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) thus animal is a jns and man is a nwE, (Mgh, Msb,) because the latter is of more particular import than the former, though it is a jns in relation to what is under it; but the scholastic theologians reverse the case, (Mgh,) for with them jns is of more particular import than nwE: (Kull p. 139:) thus also camels are a jns of beasts: (A, K:) pl. OajonaAsN [properly a pl. of pauc. but used also as one of mult.] (Mgh, Msb, K) and junuwsN. (IDrd, K.) You say, AlnRaAsu OajonaAsN waOakovaruhumo OanojaAsN [Men are of several kinds, and most of them are impure]. (A, TA.) And fulaAnN mino jinosika, meaning OaSolika [i. e. Such a one is of thy stock]. (S in art. jnv.) ― -b2- [Hence, Aisomu jinosK A generic noun: and Aisomu jinosK jamoEiIRN a collective generic noun.] ― -b3- OawoSaI lijinosihi signifies He left by will, of his property, to the children of his father, [or his kindred by the father's side,] exclusively of all relations of the mother: and so, liOaholi bayotihi. (Mgh.) ― -b4- The assertion, in the K, that J's saying, on the authority of IDrd, that As used to say Aljinosu as meaning AlmujaAnasapu is a vulgarism, is erroneous, is a matter for consideration; for As said not this, but [what has been cited above, voce jaAnasahu, or] what will be found below, voce mujaAnisN. (TA.)

jinosiIRN jns jnsI jnsy jnsyy
[jinosiIRN Generic; generical.]

jinosiyRapN jns jnsy jnsyh jnsyp
[jinosiyRapN Generical quality.]

1 janafN jnf
1. janafN (T, S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and junuwfN, (K,) the former being inf. n. of janifa and the latter of janafa, (TA,) The act of inclining, or declining (T, S, Mgh, K, TA) in speech and in all affairs: (TA:) and declining, or deviating, from the right course; acting wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically; (T, Msb, * K, TA;) like HayofN, which some erroneously assert to be the act of a judge only. (T, TA.) You say, janifa, (T, S, Mgh, Msb,) aor.
janafa
, inf. n. janafN; (S, Msb;) [and app. janafa, aor.
janifa
, inf. n. junuwfN;] and Ajnf↓; (T, Msb, TA;) He inclined or declined [in speech and in any affair]: (T, S, TA:) and he declined, or deviated, from the right course; acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically; (T, Mgh, Msb, TA;) Ealayohi against him. (Mgh.) Hence, in the Kur [ii. 178], famano xaAfa mino muwSK janafFA (S, TA,) i. e. [And he who feareth, (or, as is said in the K in art. xwf, knoweth,) from, or on the part of, the testator,] an inclining [to a wrong course], or a declining [from the right course]: (TA:) or a manifest inclining or declining. (Er-Rághib, TA.) You say, janifa fiI waSiyRatihi, aor.
janafa
; [He inclined, &c., in his testament;] and so Ajnf↓. (K.) And Ajnf↓ signifies He deviated from that which was right. (K.) And fiI Hukomihi Ajnf↓ [He declined from the right course, or acted wrongfully or unjustly, in his judgment]. (TA.) Or Ajnf↓ relates peculiarly to the case of a testament: and janifa signifies absolutely He declined, or deviated, from that which was right. (K.) And you say, janifa Eano Tariyqihi, aor.
janafa
; and janafa, aor.
janifa
; inf. n. janafN, (K, TA,) which is of the former verb, (TA,) and junuwfN, (K, TA,) which is of the latter verb; He turned away from his course, or way; deviated therefrom. (TA.) ― -b2- Or [app. a mistake for “and ”] janafN signifies Depression (duxuwlN and AinohiDaAmN) in one of the two sides of the breast, or chest, (AlzRawori,) with evenness of the other side: (K:) the verb is janifa: and the part. n. is janifN↓ and Oajonafu↓, fem. [of the latter] janofaMCu. (TA.)

3 jnaAfN jnAf
3. jnaAfN [an inf. n. of which the verb (jAnf) is not mentioned]. You say, lajRa fiI jinaAfK qabiyHK He persisted in removing himself to a distance, or estranging himself, from his family; (Aboo-Sa'eed, K;) like jinaAbK qabiyHK. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA.)

4 Ajnf Ajnf
4. Ajnf He committed an act of inclining [to a wrong course], or declining [from the right course, or acting wrongfully or unjustly or injuriously or tyrannically]; like as you say, OalaAma, meaning “he did a thing for which he should be blamed.” (S.) See also 1, in five places. ＝ -A2- Ajnfhu He found him to be one who deviated from the right way in his judgment; who acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically, therein. (K.) tjAnf fiI miXoyatihi In the text, the characters between ت and ن are unclear. He carried himself in a proud and self-conceited manner, [affecting an inclining of the body from side to side,] in his gait. (TA.) [And He inclined on one side in his gait: said of one who is lame of one leg: see maHoruwqN.] ― -b2- tjAnf Eano Tariyqihi He affected a declining, or deviating, from his course, or way; he purposely declined, or deviated, therefrom; (K, * TA;) syn. tamaAyala. (K.) And in like manner, tjAnf UilaI AlXRaIoCi [He affected an inclining to the thing; intentionally inclined to it]. (TA.) You say, tjAnf liUivomK He inclined to a sin, (S, Mgh,) [or affected an inclining to it, (see the part. n., below,)] intending, or purposing, the commission of an act of disobedience. (Mgh.)

janafa jnf
janafa is [an epithet] like danafa, applying to a sing. and a pl., [being] also an inf. n. [of janifa, q. v.]: Abu-l-'Iyál El-Hudhalee says,
OalRaA daraOota AlxaSoma Hiyna raOayotuhumo
janafFA EalaIRa biOalosunK waEuyuwni
[Wherefore didst not thou repel the adversaries, when thou sawest them inclining, or acting wrongfully, against me with tongues and eyes?]: or, accord. to one reading, junufFA [which is a pl. of jaAnifN↓]: (Skr p. 128:) [or, as some say,] janafFA is a pl. [or rather quasi-pl. n.] of jaAnifN↓, like as rawaHa is of raAYiHN: or it may be for cawiy janafK. (TA.)

janifN jnf
janifN: see Oajonafu, in two places: ― -b2- and see also 1, last sentence.

junaAfiIRN jnAfI jnAfy
junaAfiIRN One who carries himself in a proud and self-conceited manner, (muxotaAl, [for which Golius, here copied by Freytag, appears to have read muHotaAl, with the unpointed H,]) with an inclining [of the body from side to side]: (Sh, K:) or one who affects an inclining [of the body from side to side] (yatajaAnafu) in his gait, and carries himself in a proud and self-conceited manner therein. (TA.)

jaAnifN jAnf
jaAnifN: see Oajonafu; and see also janafN, in two places.

Oajonafu c
Oajonafu [fem. janofaMCu] Inclining [to a wrong course], or declining [from the right course], or acting wrongfully or unjustly, [absolutely, as also janifN↓ and jaAnifN↓ and mijonafN↓, or peculiarly] in his testament. (K.) You say, SaAdafahu fiI Hukomihi janifFA↓ [He found him to be one who deviated from the right way in his judgment; who acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically, therein]. (K.) And xaSomN mijonafN↓ An adversary who inclines [to a wrong course], or declines [from the right course]; (K;) who acts wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically. (TA.) ― -b2- Inclining; [or pendulous;] applied to a penis. (TA.) ― -b3- Having a bending back; (S, K;) applied to a man. (S.) ― -b4- See also 1, last sentence. ― -b5- Big, or large; applied to a bowl (qadaH). (TA.)

mijonafN mjnf
mijonafN: see Oajonafu, in two places.

gayora mutajaAnifK liUivomK gyr mtjAnf lAvm
gayora mutajaAnifK liUivomK, in the Kur [v. 5], means Not affecting an inclining to sin; intending, or purposing, it. (Msb, TA.)

1 janaquwA jnq jnqwA
1. janaquwA, aor.
janiqa
, (IAar, K,) inf. n. janoqN; (IAar, TA;) and jnRqwA↓, inf. n. tajoniyqN; (AZ, K;) They cast stones of [or with] the manojaniyq: (K, * TA:) and majonaquwA↓, (K,) or majonaquwA manojaniyqFA [app. meaning they constructed a mnjnyq], (Lth, TA,) is said by such as hold the m to be radical; (K;) or it may be that the m is augmentative, and that the verb is [denominative,] similar to tamasokana from misokiynN. (TA.) ― -b2- janaquwnaA biAlmanojaniyqi They cast at us with the mnjnyq: mentioned by El-Fárisee on the authority of AZ. (M.) An Arab of the desert, in describing the wars of his people, said, taArapF nujonaqo waOuxoraI nuroXaqo [One time we are cast at with the mnjnyq, and another we are shot at with arrows]: (S, * M:) also mentioned by El-Fárisee. (M.)

2 jnRqwA AlmajaAniyqa jnqwA AlmjAnyq
2. jnRqwA AlmajaAniyqa and majonaquwhaA↓ [app. They constructed the engines of the kind called mnjnyq]. (JK.) See also 1.

Q. Q. 1 majonaquwA mjnqwA
Q. Q. 1. majonaquwA: see 1 and 2.

junuqN jnq
junuqN The stones of the mnjnyq. (M, TA.) [But] IAar says that jnq [app. junuqN] means The people who manage the mnjnyq. (TA.)

mujayniyqN mjynyq
mujayniyqN dim. of manojaniyqN, q. v. (Sb, S.)

manojanuwqN mnjnwq
manojanuwqN: see what next follows.

manojaniyqN mnjnyq
manojaniyqN (S, M, Msb, K) and minojaniyqN (Msb, K) and manojanuwqN↓ (Lth, IAar, Msb, K) [A kind of balista;] an instrument [or engine of war] with which stones are cast (S, M, K, TA) at the enemy; made by binding [in some manner] very tall wooden poles, whereon is placed what is to be cast, which is then struck with a long pole, and so cast to a very distant place: [this imperfect description (the only one that I have found of this engine) seems to show that it was of a very simple and rude construction:] it is an ancient instrument, anterior to the invention [or use] of gunpowder and cannons by the Christians; and was used by Mohammad in the siege of Et-Táïf; but the first [of the Arabs] who used it in the time of paganism is said to have been Jedheemeh El-Abrash, of the Mulook et-Tawáïf: (TA:) pl. manojaniyqaAtN (S, Msb, K) and manojanuwqaAtN (Lth, TA) and majaAniyqu (Sb, S, Msb, K) and majaAniqu: (K:) dim. mujayoniyqN↓: (Sb, S:) it is fem., (Lth, S, Msb, K, *) preferably, (Lth, TA,) and in most instances; (Msb;) and hence it is also called AlOunovaI; (M in art. Anv;) but sometimes it is masc.: (Msb, K:) and is arabicized, (S, Msb, K,) from the Persian (S, K) mano JiI niyko, i. e. “ How excellent am I! ” (S,) or mano Jiho niyko, i. e. “ I, how excellent am I! ” (K;) [Golius asserts it to be from the Greek μάγγανον but this is the original of manojanuwnN, which has a different meaning: its derivation, however, seems to have been unknown to the Arabs in general; for] some say that manojaniyqN is of
the measure mafoEaliylN, [so in copies of the S, but correctly manofaEiylN, as in the Msb and TA,] because of the phrase nujonaqu marRapF [see 1]: (S, Msb: *) or, (Msb,) accord. to Sb, (S,) it is of the measure fanoEaliylN; (S, Msb;) because majaAniyqu is its pl. and the dim. is mujayniyqN; and because, if the m were augmentative as well as the n, there would be two augmentative letters at the beginning of the noun, and this may not be in substs. nor in epithets that are not conformable to augmented verbs; and if the n were made an essential part of the word, the noun would be a quadriliteral-radical, and augmentative letters are not prefixed to words of this class except nouns conformable to their verbs, like mudaHorajN: (S, TA:) but MF says that these disquisitions are unprofitable; for in his opinion, all the letters of the word are radical, since it is a foreign word. (TA.) manojaniyiqIRN [app. A maker of the kind of engine called mnjnyq; being mentioned as a surname:] a rel. n. from mnjnyq. (K.)

janokN jn jnk
janokN [and junokN] A certain [musical] instrument, which is beaten like the Euwd [or lute; namely, the Persian harp; two specimens of which are figured in Note 26 to Chap. iii. of my translation of the “Thousand and One Nights”]; mentioned by El-Khafájee in the Shifá el-Ghaleel; and often spoken of: it is an arabicized word; (MF, TA;) from the Persian JanoG: and applied [also] to the dfR, [dufR or dafR, i. e., tambourine,] with which one plays. (TA.)

janokiIRN jnk jnkI jnky
janokiIRN [and junokiIRN] A player on the jnk above mentioned. (TA.)

janFA jn jnA
janFA i. q. janaON [inf. n. of janiYa, q. v.]. (Sgh, K.)

OajonaA c
OajonaA, applied to a man, i. q. OajonaOu, q. v. (Sgh, K.) And [its fem.] janowaMCu, i. q. janoMCu, (Sgh, K,) applied to a ewe, or a she-goat, meaning Having her horns bending backwards. (TA.)

1 janaI AlvRamarapa jny Alvmrh jny Alvmrp
1. janaI AlvRamarapa, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
janiIa
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. janFI, (S, TA,) or janoIN, (so accord. to one copy of the S, and written in the accus. case jnyA in the Ham p. 355,) and jinaAyapN, (Ham ib., but there without any vowel-signs,) He gathered, plucked, or took from the tree, the fruit; (Mgh, TA;) i. q. AjtnAhA↓ (S, Msb, K) and tjnRAhA↓: (K:) and in like manner one says of a thing similar to fruit. (TA.) One says also, janaAhaA lahu and janaAhu UiyRaAhaA [He gathered it, plucked it, or took it from the tree, for him]. (A'Obeyd, K.) And janayotuka OakomuWFA [I gathered for thee truffles]. (TA.) And janaI cahabFA He collected gold from its mine. (TA.) ― -b2- Aboo-Dhu-eyb uses this verb metaphorically, in the phrase janaI AlEulaI, meaning (tropical:) [He acquired] eminence, or nobility. (TA.) ― -b3- You also say, janaI Ealayohi, (S,) or EalaI qawomihi, (Msb,) inf. n. jinaAyapN, (S, Msb,) (tropical:) He committed, [against him, or] against his people, or party, a crime, or an offence for which he should be punished; (Msb;) as also jAnAhu↓ [or jAnI qawomihi]: (TK in art. jr:) [and (tropical:) he brought an injury upon him, or them:] and janaI AlcRanobi Ealayohi, aor.
janiIa
, inf. n. jinaAyapN, (K,) with kesr, (TA,) (tropical:) He committed the crime, offence, or injurious action, against him; syn. jarRahu Uilayohi: (K: [see art. jr:]) thus used, also, the verb is metaphorical, from janaI AlvRamarapa: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and so in the phrase, janaI XarRFA, meaning (tropical:) He brought to pass an evil thing or action. (Mgh.) [See also jinaAyapN, below.] It is said in a trad., laA yajoniI jaAnK UilRaA EalaI nafosihi (assumed tropical:) [An injurer shall not bring injury save on himself]; meaning that one shall not be prosecuted for an injurious action committed by another, of his relations or of others. (TA.) And a poet says,
jaAniyka mano yajoniI Ealayoka waqado
tuEodiy AlSRijaAHa fatajorabu Aljurobu
[which may be rendered, (assumed tropical:) Thine injurer whom thou shouldst punish is he who brings an injury upon thee: but sometimes the mangy camels infect the sound ones so that these become mangy; and thus a criminal sometimes brings punishment upon his relations: for] A'Obeyd says that jAnyk mn yjnI Elyk is a prov. applied to the case of a man who is punished for an injurious action; because brothers [sometimes] bring injury upon a man [by occasioning his being punished for an injurious action which they have themselves committed], as the latter hemistich of the verse cited above indicates: but AHeyth says that this prov. means AljaAniI laka Alxayora mano yajoniI Ealayoka AlXRarRa [The person bringing thee good is he who brings, or will bring, upon thee evil: perhaps intended as a caution; for the Arabs often suspect that a benefactor has some evil intention]: and he cites the following hemistich:
tuEodiy AlSRiHaAHa mabaAriku Aljurobi
[meaning Sometimes the places where the mangy camels lie down, and which afford benefit to other camels, infect the sound ones]. (TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 298.]) You say also, janayota hecaA EalaI nafosika [Thou hast brought this as an injury upon thyself]. (K in art. jl.)

3 jAnI Ealayohi jAny Elyh jAny Elyp
3. jAnI Ealayohi, inf. n. mujaAnaApN, He accused him of a jinaAyap [or crime, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1.

4 AjnI Oj OjnI Ojny AjnI Ajny jnI jnyn Mjn Mjny Mjnyy
4. AjnI said of a tree, (S, K,) or of a palmtree, (Msb,) It had ripe fruit: (S:) or it attained to the time for the gathering of its fruit: (Msb:) or it attained to maturity: (K:) or, said of a tree, it had fruit to be gathered and eaten: and, said of fruit, it became ripe: (TA:) and, said of grass, or herbage, it became abundant. (KL.) ― -b2- And Ajnti AlOaroDu The land had much janFI, (S, Msb, K,) i. e. herbage, and truffles, and the like. (S.)

5 tajanRaIa
5: see 1. ― -b2- tjnRI Ealayohi, (S, * K,) or tjnRI Elyh canobFA, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He accused him of a crime, an offence, or an injurious action, that he had not committed; (S, K;) i. e. he forged against him the charge of his having committed a crime, &c., he being guiltless [thereof]: (TA:) AlnRajanRiI being like AltRajarRumu. (S.) You say also, yatajanRaI EalayonaA maA lamo najonihi [He accuses us of committing what we did not commit]. (Abu-l-'Abbás, TA in art. jrm.)

8 UijotanaIa
8: see 1. ― -b2- AijotanayonaA maMCi maTarK We came to rainwater, and drank it: (K:) a phrase mentioned with approval by IAar, but not explained by him: thought by ISd to have this meaning. (TA.)

janFI jn jnI jny
janFI [in the CK janiIRN] Whatever is gathered, or plucked; as also janaApN↓: (K:) or whatever is gathered, or plucked, from trees, (S,) &c.; (so in a copy of the S;) as also janaApN↓: (S:) so that these two words are of the same class as HiqRN and HiqRapN: or the latter of them is a n. un.: (TA:) or the former signfies what is gathered from trees while fresh; (Msb;) as also janiIRN↓: (Msb:) or this last is an epithet applied to fruit, signifying just gathered or plucked; (S, K;) or gathered, or plucked, while fresh: (TA:) and majonFI↓, also, pl. majaAnK, signifies fruit gathered or plucked: (Har p. 369:) janFI also signifies fruit [ready to be gathered or plucked]; so in the Kur lv. 54: (Jel:) and is applied to fresh ripe dates: (Fr, K:) and grapes: (TA:) and truffles, and the like: (S:) and even cotton: (TA:) and herbage: (S:) and gold, (K,) which is collected from its mine: (TA:) and cowries, (K,) as though gathered from the sea: (TA:) and honey, (K,) when it is gathered: (TA:) pl. OajonaMCN (K) and OajonK, originally OajonuIN. (TA.) Hence the saying,
hecaA janaAI wa xiyaAruhu fiyhi
UicokulRu jaAnK yaduhu UilaI fiyhi
[This is what I have gathered, and the best of it is in it; when every gatherer but myself has his hand to his mouth]: or, accord. to one reading, wa hijaAnuhu fiyhi (which has the same meaning, TA in art. hjn): a prov., ascribed by Ibn-El-Kelbee to 'Amr Ibn-' Adee El-Lakhmee, the son of the daughter of Jedheemeh: he says that Jedheemeh had ordered the people to gather for him truffles, and some of them ate the best that they found; but ' Amr brought to him the best that he found, and addressed to him these words: and 'Alee is related to have repeated them on an occasion of his entering the government-treasury; meaning that he had not defiled himself with anything of the tribute belonging to the Muslims, but had put it in its places. (TA.)

janaApN jAny jn jnAh jnAp jnI
janaApN: see janFI, in two places.

janiIRN jn jnI jny
janiIRN: see janFI. Also Dates cut from the tree. (TA.)

jinaAyapN jnAyh jnAyp
jinaAyapN, primarily, The act of gathering, plucking, or taking from a tree, fruit: [see 1:] ― -b2- then, (assumed tropical:) The bringing to pass an evil thing, or action: (Mgh, Kull p. 147:) ― -b3- then, (assumed tropical:) Evil, [itself]: ― -b4- then, (assumed tropical:) The doing a forbidden action: (Kull ib.:) specially used in this last sense; though it has a general application: (Mgh:) ― -b5- [as a simple subst., it generally signifies] A crime, an offence, or an injurious action, for which one should be punished:
(Msb:) or an action that a man commits requiring punishment or retaliation to be inflicted upon him in the present world and in the world to come: (TA:) or any forbidden injurious action: (Kull p. 134:) and in the language of the lawyers, especially a wounding: and an amputation, or a maiming: (Msb:) and janiyRapN↓ signifies the same as jinaAyapN: (Ham p. 241:) the pl. of jnAyp is jinaAyaAtN and janaAyaA; but the latter of these pls. is of rare occurrence. (Msb.)

janiyRapN jny jnyh jnyp
janiyRapN: see what next precedes. ＝ -A2- Also A [garment such as is called] ridaMC (K, TA,) of a round form, (TA,) made of [the kind of cloth termed] xazR. (K, TA.)

jaAnK jAn jAny
jaAnK A gatherer of fruit [&c.]: ― -b2- and also (assumed tropical:) A committer of a jinaAyap [or crime, &c.]: (K, * TA:) pl. junaApN (S, K) and junRaMCN (Sb, K) and [of pauc.] OajonaMCN, which last is extr., (S, K,) or doubtful. (S.) Hence the prov., OajonaAWuhaA OabonaAWuhaA, explained in art. bnI. (S, TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] AljaAniI (assumed tropical:) The wolf. (IAar, TA voce jaAbK, q. v.) ＝ -A2- Also i. q. laqRaAHN; (IAar, Az, TA;) i. e. A fecundater of palm-trees. (Az, TA.)

AljawaAniI AljwAnI AljwAny jwAny
AljawaAniI i. q. AljawaAnibu [pl. of AljaAnibu]; (K;) similar to AlvRaEaAliI and AlOaraAniI. (TA.)

majonFI mj mjn mjnI mjny mjnyy
majonFI: see janFI.

mujotanFI mAj mj mjtnI mjtny
mujotanFI A place of gathering, or plucking, fruits, &c. (TA.)

1 jahada jhd
1. jahada, (S, A, L, &c.,) aor.
jahada
, (K,) inf. n. jahodN, (TA,) He strove, laboured, or toiled; exerted himself or his power or efforts or endeavours or ability; employed himself vigorously, strenuously, laboriously, diligently, studiously, sedulously, earnestly, or with energy; was diligent, or studious; took pains, or extraordinary pains; (S, A, L, K;) fiI kacaA in such a thing; (S;) or fiI AlOamori in the affair; (A;) as also Ajthd↓; (A, K;) and so jAhd↓, with respect to speech and actions: (L:) or jahada fiI AlOamori, aor. and inf. n. as above, he did his utmost, or used his utmost power or efforts or endeavours or ability, in prosecuting the affair: (Msb:) and Ajthd↓ and tjAhd↓ he exerted unsparingly his power, or ability: (S, A, K:) or fiI AlOamori Ajthd↓ he exerted unsparingly his power, or ability, in the prosecution of the affair, so as to effect his utmost. (Msb.) You say also, Aijohado jahadaka fiI hcaA AlOamori (tropical:) Do thine utmost in this affair: (Fr, S, K: *) but not juhodaka. (Fr, S.) And raOoyahu Ajthd↓ (tropical:) He took pains, or put himself to trouble or fatigue, to form a right judgment or opinion. (MA.) And raOoyiI wanafosiI HatRaI Aijotahadotu↓ balagotu majohuwdiI (assumed tropical:) I exerted my judgment and my mind so that I attained the utmost of my power, or ability. (T, L.) ― -b2- jahadabihi He tried, proved, or examined, him, (L, K,) Eani Alxayori wa gayorihi [respecting good qualities, &c.]. (L.) ＝ -A2- jahadahu, (Mgh, L, Msb,) aor.
jahada
, (Mgh, L,) inf. n. jahodN, (L, Msb,) It, (an affair, and a disease,) and he, (a man,) affected him severely; harassed, embarrassed, distressed, afflicted, troubled, inconvenienced, fatigued, or wearied, him: (Msb:) it (disease, L and K, and fatigue, and love, L) rendered him lean; emaciated him: (L, K:) he burdened him beyond his power; imposed upon him that which was beyond his power; as also Ajhdhu↓: (Mgh:) and, [as also Ajhdhu↓,] he importuned him, harassed him, or plied him hard, in asking, begging, or petitioning. (A.) [Hence,] juhida, said of a man, He was severely affected, harassed, embarrassed, distressed, afflicted, troubled, inconvenienced, fatigued, or wearied: (S, L:) or was grieved, or made sorry or unhappy. (L.) And OaSaAbahumo quHuwTN mina AlmaTari fajuhiduwA jahodFA XadiydFA Drought befell them, and they consequently became severely distressed. (S.) And juhiduwA They were, or became, afflicted with drought, barrenness, or dearth; or with drought, and dryness of the earth. (L.) And rajulN yajohadu Oano yaHomila silaAHahu mina AlDRaEofi, for yajohadu nafosahu, A man who imposes upon himself a difficulty, or trouble, or fatigue, or a difficult or severe task, or who strains, or strains himself, in the carrying of his weapons, or arms, by reason of weakness. (Mgh.) And jahada daAbRatahu and AjhdhA↓ He jaded, harassed, distressed, fatigued, or wearied, his beast; i. q. balaga jahodahaA↓: (K:) or he tasked, or plied, his beast beyond his power in journeying, or marching, or in respect of pace. (S, Msb.) And Oajohadotuhu EalaI Oano yafoEala kacaA wa kacaA [I importuned him, or harassed him, to do such and such things]. (L.) ― -b2- Also, (S, Msb,) aor. as above, (A,) and so the inf. n., (Msb,) (tropical:) He deprived it (namely, milk,) of its butter, (S, A, K,) entirely: (S, K:) or churned it so as to extract its butter and render it sweet and pleasant: or mixed it with water: (Msb:) or diluted it so that it consisted for the most part of water: and in like manner it is used in relation to broth. (A.) ― -b3- Hence, (Msb,) jahadahaA (assumed tropical:) He lay with her; or compressed her: (L, Msb, from a trad.:) or i. q. dafaEahaA, and HafazahaA [which has a similar meaning]. (L.) ― -b4- jahada AlTRaEaAmi (assumed tropical:) He desired the food eagerly; longed for it; (S, K;) as also Ajhdhu↓. (K.) And juhida AlTRaEaAmu and Oujohida↓ (assumed tropical:) The food was eagerly desired, or longed for. (S.) ― -b5- Also (tropical:) He ate much of the food: (S, K:) he left nothing of it. (A.) You say also, hecaA kalaON yajohaduhu AlmaAlu (assumed tropical:) This is herbage, or pasture, of which the cattle eat perseveringly. (AA, TA.) ＝ -A3- jahida It (a state of life) was, or became, hard, difficult, strait, or distressful. (S, K.)

3 jihaAdN jhAd
3. jihaAdN, inf. n. of jAhd, properly signifies The using, or exerting, one's utmost power, efforts, endeavours, or ability, in contending with an object of disapprobation; and this is of three kinds, namely, a visible enemy, the devil, and one's self; all of which are included in the term as used in the Kur xxii. 77. (Er-Rághib, TA.) See also 1, first sentence. You say, jAhd AlEaduwRa, (JK, A, Mgh,) inf. n. as above (JK, Mgh, K) and mujaAhadapN, (JK, K,) He fought with the enemy: (K:) or he encountered the enemy, imposing upon himself difficulty or distress or fatigue, or exerting his power or efforts or endeavours or ability, [or the utmost thereof,] to repel him, his enemy doing the like: and hence jAhd came to be used by the Muslims to signify generally he fought, warred, or waged war, against unbelievers and the like. (Mgh.) You say also, jAhd fiI sabiyli QllRehi, inf. n. jihaAdN (S, Msb) and mujaAhadapN, (S,) [He fought, &c., in the way of God; i. e., in the cause of religion.]

4 Ajhd Ojhd Ajhd jhd
4. Ajhd, as trans.: see 1, in six places. ― -b2- Also He made, or incited, another, to strive or labour or toil, to exert himself or his power or efforts or endeavours or ability, &c.; trans. of 1 in the first of the senses assigned to it above. (JK.) ― -b3- Oujohida He was thrown into a state of difficulty, distress, affliction, trouble, inconvenience, or fatigue. (L.) ― -b4- Ajhd maAlahu He consumed, or wasted, and dispersed, his property: (K:) or gave it away, and dispersed it, altogether, here and there. (En-Nadr, TA.) ＝ -A2- As intrans., He (an enemy) strove, laboured, or exerted himself, in enmity, (K, TA,) EalayonaA against us. (TA.) ― -b2- He acted with energy, or with the utmost energy: so in the phrases saAra faOajohada He marched, or journeyed, and did so with energy, or with the utmost energy; and Halafa biQllRehi faOajohada He swore by God, and did so with energy, &c.: in which cases one should not say fajahada. (Aboo-' Amr Ibn-El-'Alà, L.) ― -b3- He took the course prescribed by prudence, precaution, and sound judgment, fiI AlOamori in the affair; syn. AiHotaATa. (L, K.) ― -b4- He became in a state of difficulty, embarrassment, distress, affliction, trouble, inconvenience, or fatigue. (L.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) became mixed, or confused. (K.) ＝ -A3- He entered upon land such as is termed jahaAd: he went forth into the desert; and into the plain, or open country. (JK.) ― -b2- It rose up; rose into view; appeared. (JK.) You say, Ajhd liIa Alqawomu The people, or company of men, came within my sight, or view; syn. OaXorafuwA. (AA, K.) And Ajhd fiyhi AlXRayobu Hoariness appeared upon him, and became much: (TA:) or (tropical:) became much, and spread: (A:) or became much, and was quick in its progress, (K, TA,) and spread. (TA.) And Oajohadato lahu AlOaroDu The land became open to him. (L, K. *) And in like manner, Ajhd lh AlTRariyqu, (L,) and AlHaqRu, (L, K, *) The road, and (assumed tropical:) the truth, became open, apparent, and manifest, to him. (L, K. *) And Ajhd laka AlOamoru (assumed tropical:) The thing became, or has become, within thy power, or reach; (Aboo-Sa'eed, K;) and offered, or presented, itself to thee. (Aboo-Sa'eed, TA.)

6 tajaAohada
6: see 1.

8 Uijotahada
8: see 1, in five places. ― -b2- AijotihaAdN as a conventional term means A lawyer's exerting the faculties [of the mind] to the utmost, for the purpose of forming an opinion in a case of law [respecting a doubtful and difficult point]: (KT:) the seeking to form a right opinion: (KL:) [investigation of the law, or the working out a solution of any difficulty in the law, by means of reason and comparison: and] the referring a case proposed to the judge, [respecting a doubtful and difficult
point,] from the method of analogy, to the Kur-Án and the Sunneh. (L, TA. *)

jahodN jhd
jahodN Power; ability; as also juhodN↓; (S, A, IAth, L, Msb, K;) the latter of the dial. of El- Hijáz, and the former of other dials.; (Msb;) and majohuwdN↓: (A:) jhd in the Kur ix. 80 is read both jahod and juhd↓: (S:) and jahodN signifies also labour, toil, exertion, effort, endeavour, energy, diligence, painstaking, or extraordinary painstaking: (L: [see jahada:]) or juhodN↓ has the signification first mentioned above, (Fr, S, IAth, Msb,) and jahodN, with fet-h, is from Aijohado jahodaka fiI hecaA AlOamori, (Fr, S,) or from jahada fiI AlOamori, being an inf. n. from this verb, (Msb,) and signifies, [as also majohuwdN↓,] one's utmost; the utmost of one's power or ability or efforts or endeavours or energy. (Fr, S, IAth, Msb, K.) You say, bacala Aljahoda, (Msb in art. blg, &c.,) and Almajohuwda↓, (S, A,) or jahodahu, (Mgh,) [and majohuwdahu↓,] He exerted unsparingly his power or ability: (Mgh:) [or his utmost power or ability or efforts or endeavours or energy; as shown above.] And balaga jahodahu, (A, L,) and majohuwdahu↓, (A,) He accomplished the utmost of his power or ability; did his utmost. (A, L. [Like jahada jahodahu. See also balaga jahoda daAbRatihi, below.]) And juhayodaI↓ is syn. with jahodN; (K;) as in the saying, laOaboluganRa juhayodaAIa fiI AlOamori (JK, TK,) i. e. I will assuredly accomplish the utmost of my power, or ability, in the affair. (TK. [In a copy of the A, juhayodaAka; and so in the TA, I believe from that same copy.]) [So, too, is juhaAdaI↓; as in the saying,] juhaAdaAka Oano tafoEala The utmost of thy power, or ability, and the utmost of thy case, is, or will be, thy doing [such a thing]; syn. quSaAraAka [q. v.], (JK, K,) and gaAyapu Oamorika. (TA.) AlRaciyna OaqosamuwA biQllRehi jahoda OayomaAnihimo, in the Kur [v. 58, &c.], means Who swore by God with the most energetic of their oaths: (K, * Jel:) or the strongest, or most forcible, of their oaths; jhd being originally an inf. n., and in the accus. as a denotative of state with yajohaduwna understood before it, or as an inf. n. (Bd.) ― -b2- Also Difficulty, or grievousness; embarrassment, distress, affliction, trouble, inconvenience, fatigue, or weariness; (S, A, IAth, Mgh, Msb, K;) so accord. to some who say that juhodN↓, with damm, has the first of the significations assigned to it above; (Msb;) as also majohuwdN↓: (Mgh:) a disease, or difficulty, that distresses or afflicts, a man; as also juhodN↓. (JK.) Hence, jahodu AlbalaMCi, (Msb,) i. e. A state of difficulty, or trouble, to which death is preferred: or largeness of one's family, or household, combined with poverty. (L, K. *) [Hence also,] balaga jahoda daAbRatihi, [i. e. balaga maXaqRatahaA,] i. q. jahadahaA: see 1. (K.) ― -b3- Also Small provision, upon which a man possessing little property can live (JK, L) with difficulty. (L.) And jahodN AlmuqilRi What a man who possesses little property can afford to give in payment of the poor-rate required by the law. (L, from a trad.)

juhodN jhd
juhodN: see jahodN, in five places. ＝ -A2- Also Milk mixed [with water: see majohuwdN]. (JK.)

jahaAdN jhAd
jahaAdN Hard land: (JK, S:) or land in which is no herbage: (TA:) or hard land in which is no herbage: (K:) or level, or even, land: or rugged land: also used as an epithet; so that you say OaroDN jahaAdN: (TA:) or level, smooth land, in which is no hill: (JK:) or the most plain and even of land, whether it have produced herbage or not, not having any mountain or hill near it: and such is what is termed a SaHoraMC: (ISh, TA:) or an open tract of land: (Fr, TA:) or sterile, barren, or unfruitful, land, in which is nothing; as also jamaAdN: pl. juhudN. (AA, L.) ＝ -A2- Also The fruit of the OaraAk; (IAar, K;) and so jahaADN. (IAar, TA.)

maroEFI jahiydN mrEy jhyd
maroEFI jahiydN (tropical:) Pasture much eaten by cattle. (S, A, K.) And OaroDN jahiydapu AlkalaOi (tropical:) Land of which the herbage is much eaten by cattle. (A.)

juhaAdaI jhAd jhAdI jhAdy
juhaAdaI: see jahodN.

juhayodaI jhyd jhydI jhydy
juhayodaI: see jahodN.

jaAhidN jAhd
jaAhidN [Striving, labouring, or toiling; &c.: see 1. Hence,] sayorunaA jaAhidN [Our journeying is laborious]. (TA in art. Axw.) And jahodN jaAhidN [Intense labour or exertion, or the like: or severe difficulty or distress &c.]: an intensive expression, (K, TA,) like XiEorN XaAEirN and layolN laAYilN. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Eagerly desiring [food]; longing for [it]: (JK, S:) pl. OajohaAdN. (JK.) ― -b3- garovaAnu jaAhidN (tropical:) Hungry and greedy, leaving no food. (A.)

mujohadN mjhd
mujohadN A man thrown into a state of difficulty, embarrassment, distress, affliction, inconvenience, trouble, or fatigue. (L.)

huwa mujohadu laka hw mjhd lk
huwa mujohadu laka He is one who takes the course prescribed by prudence, precaution, or sound judgment, for thee; syn. muHotiyTN. (L.) And naSiyHN mujohidN A sincere, or faithful, and careful, adviser, or counsellor. (L.) ― -b2- rajulN mujohidN A man in a state of difficulty, embarrassment, distress, affliction, inconvenience, trouble or fatigue: possessing little property; poor. (L.) ― -b3- And A man whose beast is weak by reason of fatigue. (L.)

majohuwdN mjhwd
majohuwdN Severely affected, harassed, embarrassed, distressed, afflicted, troubled, inconvenienced, fatigued, or wearied: (S, Mgh, L:) distressed, or afflicted, by disease or difficulty: (JK:) afflicted with drought, barrenness, or dearth; or with drought, and dryness of the earth: (L:) and angry. (JK.) ― -b2- A hard, difficult, strait, or distressful, state of life. (TA.) ― -b3- (tropical:) Milk deprived of its butter (S, A) entirely: (S:) or mixed with water: (Msb:) or diluted so as to consist for the most part of water; and in like manner, broth: (A:) or churned so that its butter is extracted and it is rendered sweet and pleasant: and used as meaning eagerly desired, or longed for, and drunk without its occasioning disgust, by reason of its sweetness and pleasantness: (Msb:) or eagerly desired, or longed for; and so food in general: (JK, L:) or eagerly desired, or longed for, and drunk with perseverance, on account of its pleasantness and sweetness. (L.) ＝ -A2- See also jahodN, in six places.

1 jahara jhr
1. jahara, (A, Msb, K,) aor.
jahara
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. jahorN and jihaArN, (Er-Rághib, TA,) It (a thing, A, Msb) was, or became, plain, apparent, conspicuous, open, or public; syn. Zahara, (A, Msb,) and badaA, (TA,) and Ealana: (K:) or the radical signification is, it (a thing) was, or became, exceedingly plain to be perceived, either by the sense of sight or by that of hearing. (Er-Rághib, TA.) [Accord. to some, when relating to what is visible, it is tropical; and when relating to what is audible, proper: but if so, it seems to be so much used in the former sense as to be, in that sense, conventionally regarded as proper. See also jahorapN.] ＝ -A2- jahura, aor.
jahura
, [inf. n., app., jahaArapN and juhuwrapN,] He (a man, TA) was, or became, great, or bulky, (K, TA,) [and therefore a conspicuous object,] before the eyes of the beholder. (TA.) [And He was, or became, pleasing, or goodly, in aspect: see jahaArapN, below.] ― -b2- Also, (A, Msb, K,) inf. n. jahaArapN, (A, Msb,) It (the voice) rose [so as to be plainly heard]; was, or became, high, or loud. (A, Msb, * K.) ― -b3- Also, (S,) inf. n. jahaArapN, (TA,) He, (a man) was, or became, high, or loud, of voice. (S, TA.) ＝ -A3- jibir aor.
jahara
, (Msb,) inf. n. jaharN, (S, Msb,) He (a man) was unable to see in the sun. (S, Msb, TA.) And in like manner said of the eye. (K.) ＝ -A4- jaharahu, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. jahorN; (TA;) and jahara bihi; (A, Msb;) and Ajhrhu↓, (A, Msb, TA,) [and bihi Ajhr↓;] and jahowarahu↓; (TA;) He made it plain, apparent, conspicuous, open, or public. (A, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- jahara AlkalaAma, and jaharabihi; (K;) and Ajhrhu↓, inf. n. UijohaArN; (S;) and bihi Ajhr↓; (K;) and jahowara↓; (TA;) and jahara biAlqawoli, and biduEaAYihi, and biSalaAtihi, (TA,) and biqiraMCatihi, (Sgh, Msb, TA,) aor.
jahara
, inf. n. jahorN and jihaArN; (TA;) and bqrCMth Ajhr↓; (Sgh, Msb, TA;) He uttered the speech, and the saying, and his supplication, and his prayer, and his recitation, with a plain, or an open, voice; openly; publicly: (S, Msb, K, TA:) or jahara bikalaAmihi, (A,) and biAlqawoli, and jahowara↓; (S;) and biqiraMCatihi; (A;) he uttered his speech, and the saying, and his recitation, with a raised, or loud, voice; aloud: (S, A:) and jahara AlSRawota he raised the voice [so as to make it plainly heard]. (K.) ― -b3- jahara biAlmaEaASiI, and Ajhr↓, and jAhr↓, he made known the acts of disobedience that he had committed, by talking of them: he who does so is termed biAlmuEaASiI mujaAhirN↓, and simply mujaAhirN. (TA.) And maA fiI Sadorihi Ajhr↓ He revealed what was in his bosom. (A.) And AlHadiyva baEoda maA hayonamahu jahowara↓ He revealed the story after he had concealed it. (A.) And Ajhr↓ AlOamora He made the case, or affair, notorious. (TA.) ― -b4- Also jaharahu He discovered it (K, TA) ocularly. (TA.) ― -b5- He saw him (a man) without any veil (K, TA) intervening; (TA;) as also Ajthrhu↓: (K:) or he looked towards him, or regarded him. (K.) You say, maA fiI AlHaIRi OaHadN
tajoharahu EayoniI There is not in the tribe any one whom my eye regards as worthy of notice or respect by reason of his greatness therein; syn. taOoxucuhu. (TA.) And Alqawomu fulaAnFA Ajthr↓ The people looked towards such a one without any veil intervening between them and him. (TA.) ― -b6- He treated him, or regarded him, with reverence, veneration, respect, or honour: (K:) or (TA) he regarded him as great in his eyes: (K, TA:) he saw him to be great in aspect, or appearance; (S;) as also Ajthrhu↓ (S, K) and Astjrhu↓: (A:) he was pleased with his beauty, and his form, or appearance, or state of apparel or the like; as also Ajthrhu↓: (Lh, * K:) or he pleased him by his beauty and form or appearance &c.: (A:) or it pleased him by its beauty; as also Ajthrhu↓. (TA.) ― -b7- He saw it (an army, S, A, K, and a people, TA) to be numerous in his eyes; as also Ajthrhu↓. (S A, K.) ＝ -A5- jahara AlbiYora, (S, K,) aor.
jahara
, inf. n. jahorN, (TA,) He cleared out the well, (S, K,) and took forth from it the black fetid mud that it contained; as also AjtrhA↓: (S:) or both signify he entirely, or nearly, exhausted the well of its water: (K:) or the former, he reached the water of the well, (K, TA,) in digging: or so jahara alone: (TA:) and accord. to Akh, jaharotu AlrRakiyRapa signifies I cleared out the mud that the water covered in the well, so that the water appeared and became clear. (S.) 'Áïsheh said, describing her father, dufuna AlrRawaMCi Ajthr↓, lit., He cleared out the filled-up wells of abundant water so as to make the water well forth; alluding to his rectifying affairs that had become disordered. (TA from a trad.) ＝ -A6- jaharonaAhumo We came to them in the morning, at the time called AlSRabaAH, (S, A, K, TA,) when they were inadvertent. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- jahara AlOaroDa He traversed the land (S, K) without knowledge. (S.) ＝ -A7- jahara AlsRiqaMCa He shook the milk-skin to make butter, (Fr, S, K,) and took forth its butter. (Fr, TA.) ＝ -A8- jaharati AlXRamosu AlmusaAfira The sun dazzled the eye, and confused the sight, of the traveller; syn. Oasodarato Eayonahu. (K.)

3 jAhr jAhr
3. jAhr: see 1. ― -b2- [Its inf. n.] mujaAharapN signifies The fighting [with any one] face to face: and the showing open enmity, or hostility, with any one: and the reading, or reciting, a thing aloud: and the speaking loudly. (KL.) You say, jAhr biAlEadaAwapi, (Msb,) inf. n. mujaAharapN (S, Msb) and jihaArN, (Msb,) He showed open enmity or hostility, with another. (S, * Msb.) And jaAharotuhumo biAlOamori I acted openly with them in the affair, or case; syn. EaAlanotuhumo bihi. (JK.) [And jAhrhu He treated him openly with enmity &c.] ― -b3- jaAharahumo biAlOamori, (TA,) inf. n. mujaAharapN and jihaArN, (K,) [is explained as signifying] He vied with them, or strove to overcome or surpass them, in the affair, or case. (K, * TA.) [But gAlbhm, in the TA, and AlmugaAlabapu, in the K, are here evidently mistranscriptions for EaAlanahumo and AlmuEaAlanapu.]

4 Oajohara
4: see 1, in eight places. ― -b2- Ajhr also signifies He begat sons goodly in stature (IAar, K) and in aspect, (IAar, TA,) or in cheeks: (K:) or, a squint-eyed son. (IAar, K.)

6 tajaAohara
6: [tajaAhurN signifies The showing oneself openly: and acting openly, or being open in one's conduct or converse, with others. You say,] tajaAharuwA biAlEadaAwapi They showed open enmity, or hostility, one with another; syn. tabaAdawoAbihaA. (S in art. bdw.) ＝ -A2- [And tjAhr He feigned himself unable to see in the sun: see the part. n., below.]

8 Uijotahara
8: see 1, in eight places.

10 Astjhrhu Astjhrh Astjhrp
10. Astjhrhu: see 1. ― -b2- Also He took it forth. (TA from a trad.)

Q. Q. 1 jahowara jhwr
Q. Q. 1. jahowara: see 1, in four places.

jahorFA jhr jhrA
jahorFA: see jahorapN, in two places.

juhorN jhr
juhorN: see jahaArapN, in six places.

jahirN jhr
jahirN: see jahiyrN, in two places.

jahorapN jhr jhrh jhrp
jahorapN A thing that is plain, apparent, conspicuous, open, or public. (K.) You say, raMhu jahorapF (S, A, &c.) He saw him, or it, [plainly,] without the intervention of any veil: (TA:) and rMh jihaArFA↓ [signifies the same: or] he saw him, or it, with exceeding plainness: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the former signifies he saw him, or it, with his eyes, ocularly, or before his eyes, (S, A, Bd in ii. 52, Msb,) without anything intervening: (S:) so in the Kur. [ii. 52], HatRaI naraI QllReha jahorapF: (S, Bd:) and [some say that] jahorapF is here originally an inf. n. of jaharotu in jaharotu biAlqiraMCapi, [like jahorFA↓,] and metaphorically used in the sense of muEaAyanapF: it is in the accus. case as an inf. n.: or it is thus used as a denotative of state relating to the agent or the object: and some read jaharapF↓, as an inf. n. like galabap, or as pl. of jaAhirN, and as such it is a denotative of state: (Bd:) or jahorapF is here from jaharotu AlrRakiyRapa: (Akh, S:) accord. to Ibn-' Arafeh, it here signifies unconcealed from us: (TA:) and in the Kur. iv. 152, ocularly; not concealed from us by anything. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- You say also, kalRamahu jahorapF [and jahorFA↓ He spoke to him plainly, with an open voice, aloud, or publicly]. (S, TA.) ― -b3- And laqiyahu nahaArFA jihaArFA↓ and jahaArFA↓ [He met him in the daytime, openly, or publicly]. (K.)

juhorapN jhr jhrh jhrp
juhorapN [A blaze covering the face of a horse: or the quality of having such a blaze:] a subst. from Oajoharu applied to a horse. (TA.) ― -b2- A cast in the eye. (AA, TA. [See also Oajoharu.])

jaharapF jhr jhrh jhrp
jaharapF: see jahorapN.

jahaArFA jhAr jhArA
jahaArFA and jihaArFA: see jahorapN, in three places.

jahowarN jhwr
jahowarN: see jahiyrN. ― -b2- Also, and mujotaharN↓, An army seen to be numerous. (A.) ― -b3- And the former, Bold; daring: in the K, erroneously, jawoharN↓. (TA.)

jahiyrN jhyr
jahiyrN (in the TA, here, jahirN↓, but in another place, jahiyrN,) High, loud, or vehement, speech; (Msb, K, TA;) as also mujoharN↓ and jahowariIRN↓: (K:) and so applied to the voice; (Msb, TA;) as also jahowariIRN↓. (A, TA.) Also, and mujoharN↓ (TA) and jahowariIRN↓ (A, TA) and jahowarN↓ (A) and jahiyru AlSRawoti (S, A) and AlSRawoti jahowariIRu↓, (S,) A man having a high, loud, or strong voice. (S, A, TA.) ― -b2- A man (S, A) of pleasing, or goodly, aspect; (S, A, K;) as also jahirN↓: (K:) fem. of the former with p: (S:) beautiful: (K:) of goodly aspect, who pleases the beholder by his beauty: and a face of goodly, or beautiful, fairness: (TA:) and Oajoharu↓ a man (TA) of goodly aspect, (K, TA,) and of goodly and perfect body. (AA, K, TA.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) or jahiyrN liloxayori and lilomaEoruwfi, (A,) Adapted to, or constituted for, goodness: (A, K:) because he who beholds him desires his beneficence: (TA:) pl. juharaMCu. (A, K.) ＝ -A2- Also Milk not mixed with water: (Fr, S, K:) or from which the butter has been taken forth. (TA.)

juhaArapN jhAr jhArh jhArp
juhaArapN [an inf. n. (see jahura)] Pleasingness, or goodliness, of aspect; (S, A, K;) as also juhuwrapN↓ (K) and juhorN↓: (TA:) [and a quality pleasing to behold: for] Abu-n-Nejm says,
waOaraI AlbayaADa EalaI AlnRisaMCi jahaArapF
[And I regard fairness in women as a quality pleasing to behold]: (S:) and juhorN↓ signifies the form, or appearance, or the like, and goodliness of aspect, of a man: (K:) or what pleases by its beauty, of the form or appearance or the like, of a man, and and goodliness of aspect: (S:) [and simply aspect, or outward appearance.] You say, banuwna cawuw jahaArpK Sons goodly in stature and in aspect: (IAar, TA:) or in stature and in cheeks: (K:) but the former is the more agreeable with authority. (TA.) And fulaAnK maA OaHosana juhora↓ How goodly is the form, or appearance, or the like, and the beauty of aspect, of such a one! (S, A: *) [or simply, the aspect; for] you say also, maA OasowaOa juhorahu↓ [How evil is his aspect!]. (A.) And rajulN Hasanu AljahaArapi and Aljuhori↓ A man goodly in aspect. (TA.) And faEarafotu sirRahu raOayotu juhorahu↓ [I saw his aspect, and so knew his mind]. (A.)

juhuwrapN jhwr jhwrh jhwrp
juhuwrapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

fulaAnN Eafiyfu AlsRariyrapi wa Aljahiyrapi flAn Efyf Alsryrp w Aljhyrh flAn Efyf Alsryrp w Aljhyrp
fulaAnN Eafiyfu AlsRariyrapi wa Aljahiyrapi [Such a one is chaste in secret conduct and in public behaviour]. (A.)

jahowariIRN jhwrI jhwry
jahowariIRN: see jahiyrN, in four places.

jawoharN jwhr
jawoharN a word of well-known meaning, (Msb,) [a coll. gen. n., Jewels; precious stones; gems; pearls: any kind of jewel, precious stone, or gem: and also applied (as in the T, M, Mgh, Msb, and K, voce tiborN, q. v.,) to native ore:] any stone from which is extracted, or elicited, anything by which one may profit: (K:) n. un. with p: (S:) [pl. jawaAhiru:] it is of the measure fawoEalu, (Msb,) and is from Aljahoru signifying a thing's “ becoming exceedingly plain to be perceived by the sense of sight: ” (Er-Rághib, TA:) or it is of Persian origin, (TA,) arabicized, (S, TA,) [from Gawoharo,] accord. to most persons. (TA.) ― -b2- jawoharu sayofK The diversified wavy marks, streaks, or grain, of a sword; syn. firinodN. (T and K voce firinodN.] ― -b3- jawoharu XaIoCK [The essence of a thing; or that whereby a thing is what it is; the substance of a thing: the constituent of a thing; the material part thereof;] that upon which the natural con-
stitution of a thing is as it were based; or of which its natural constitution is made to be; [or, as IbrD thinks to be meant in the K, the collective parts and materials of a thing, of which its natural constitution is moulded;] expl. by maAwuDiEato Ealayohi jibilRatuhu, (K,) or, as in some Lexicons, [as the JK and the Msb,] maA xuliqato Ealayohi jibilRatuhu [which is virtually the same]: (TA:) Aljawoharu and AlcRaAtu and AlmaAhiyRapu and AlHaqiyqapu are all syn. terms; and the first has other significations; but in the classical language it signifies AlOaSolu, i. e., OaSolu AlmurakRabaAti [the original of compound things]; and not what subsists by itself. (Kull.) ― -b4- [Hence, Aljawoharu Alfarodu (assumed tropical:) The indivisible atom.] ― -b5- In the conventional language of scholastic theology, jawoharN signifies (tropical:) Substance, as opposed to accident; in which sense, some assert the word to be so much used as to be, in this sense, conventionally regarded as proper. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jahowarN.

jawohariIRN jwhr jwhrI jwhry jwhryy
jawohariIRN A jeweller; a seller of jawohar [or jawaAhir]. (TA.) ― -b2- [In scholastic theology, (assumed tropical:) Of, or relating to, substance, as opposed to accident.]

Oajoharu c
Oajoharu: see jahiyrN. ― -b2- Also A man having the eyeball, or globe of the eye, prominent and apparent, or large and prominent; syn. jaAHiZN: or resembling such as is termed jAHZ: fem. jahoraMCu. (TA.) And this latter, An eye having the ball, or globe, prominent and apparent, or large and prominent; syn. jaAHiZapN: (K:) or resembling what is thus termed. (TA.) ― -b3- Having a pretty cast in the eye: (AA, K:) fem. as above.
