(K.) ― -b4- That cannot see in the sun; (S, A, Msb, K;) applied to a man, (A, Msb,) and to a ram: (S:) fem. as above: (S, A, Msb, K:) or weak-sighted in the sun: (Lh, TA:) or that cannot see in the daytime; OaEoXaI signifying “ that cannot see in the night: ” (TA:) and the fem., a woman who closes her eyes in the sun. (A.) ― -b5- A horse having a blaze that covers his face: fem. as above. (K.) ― -b6- Also the fem., Open, bare, land, not concealed by anything: (A:) or plain land, in which are no trees nor hills (K, TA) nor sands: (TA:) pl. jahoraAwaAtN. (A, TA.) ― -b7- And A company (S, K) consisting of the distinguished part (TA) of a people: (S:) the more, or most, excellent persons of a tribe. (K.) You say, [with reference to distinguished persons,] kayofa jahoraAWukumo How is your company? (S.)

mujoharN mjhr
mujoharN. see majohuwrN: and see also jahiyrN, in two places.

mijoharN mjhr
mijoharN (S, K) and mijohaArN↓ (K) A man accustomed to speak with a plain, or an open, voice; openly; or publicly. (S, K.)

mijohaArN mjhAr
mijohaArN: see what next precedes.

majohuwrN bihi mjhwr bh mjhwr bp
majohuwrN bihi Notorious; applied to a thing: (TA:) and so mujotaharN↓ applied to a man: (A, TA:) and mujoharN↓ plain, apparent, or conspicuous; applied to a thing. (TA.) ― -b2- AlHuruwfu Almajohuwrapu [The letters that are pronounced with the voice, and not with the breath only; the vocal letters;] the letters (nineteen in number, S) that are comprised in the saying ZilRu qawRK rabaDN Uico gazaA junodu muTiyEN: (S, K:) opposed to Almahomuwsapu: (TA:) so called [accord. to some] because there is a full stress in the place where any one of them occurs, and the breath is prevented from passing with it until the stress is ended with the passage of the voice. (Sb, S.) ＝ -A2- maMCN majohuwrN Water which, having been buried in the earth, has been drawn until it has become sweet. (TA.) ― -b2- majohuwrapN A well (biYorN) cleared out, and cleansed from the black fetid mud which it had contained. (S.) ― -b3- And Wells frequented [and in use], (K,) whether their water be sweet or salt. (TA.)

mujaAhirN mjAhr mjhr
mujaAhirN: see, above, jahara biAlmaEaASiI.

mujotaharN mjthr
mujotaharN: see majohuwrN: and see also jahowarN.

mutajaAhirN mtjAhr
mutajaAhirN Feigning himself Oajohar; as in the saying, cited by Th,
kaAlnRaAZiri AlmutajaAhiri
[Like the looker that feigns himself unable to see in the sun]. (TA.)

1 jahaza EalaI AljariyHi jhz Ely AljryH
1. jahaza EalaI AljariyHi: see 4, in two places.

2 jhRz jhz
2. jhRz, inf. n. tajohiyzN, He fitted out, equipped, furnished, or supplied, a bride, and a traveller, and a corpse, (S, Msb, K,) and an army, (S,) with her, or his, or their, jahaAz [i. e. requisites, equipage, furniture, accoutrements, or apparatus]: (S, Msb. K:) he provided a warrior with a beast to ride, and with other requisites for his expedition: (TA:) he prepared him or it. (TA.) You say also, jhaz Ealayohi Alxayola [He fitted out the horsemen and sent them against him]. (S.) ＝ -A2- See also 4.

4 Ajhz EalaI AljariyHi Ajhz Ely AljryH
4. Ajhz EalaI AljariyHi, (As, JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. UijohuAzN; (Msb;) and Ealayoha jahaza↓, aor.
Hahaza
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. jahozN; (TA;) He despatched, or he hastened and completed the slaughter of, the wounded man; (As, S, Mgh, Msb, K;) he made his slaughter sure, or certain: (JK, K:) and jhRz↓, with teshdeed, signifies the same, but denoting muchness, or frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many objects, and intensiveness: (Msb:) or ElI AljryH jahaza↓ signifies he slew the wounded man. (IDrd, TA.) You should not say, Oajazotu ElI AljryH, (S,) or OajaAza Elyh. (ISd, TA.)

5 tjhRz Ojhz jhz tjhz
5. tjhRz He fitted out, equipped, furnished, or supplied, himself; or he or it became fitted out or equipped or furnished or supplied; with his or its jahaAz [or requisites, &c.]: (K:) he prepared himself. (S, K.) You say, tajahRazotu liOamori kacaA, (S, K, *) and AijohaAzazotu↓, (K,) I prepared myself for such a thing. (S, K.)

11 AijohaAzazotu liOamorikacaA c
11. AijohaAzazotu liOamorikacaA: see 5.

jahaAzN jhAz
jahaAzN, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) so accord. to the seven readers in the Kur xii. 59 and 70, (Az, Msb,) and jihaAzN↓, (S, Msb, K,) but the latter is rare, (Msb,) or bad, (Az, TA,) or an erroneous pronunciation of the people of El-Basrah, (Lth, TA,) The requisites, (Msb, K,) equipments, equipage, furniture, accoutrements, or apparatus, (Msb,) of a bride, [i. e. her paraphernalia,] and of a traveller, and of a corpse: (S, Msb, K:) provisions and other requisites for a traveller: (Har p. 104:) pl. [of pauc.] OajohizapN, and pl. pl. OajohizaAtN. (S, K.) ― -b2- Accord. to some, Household goods or furniture and utensils: accord. to 'Alee Ibn- 'Eesà, excellent goods that are conveyed from country to country: and hence the jhAz of the bride: (Har p. 104:) or excellent goods that are conveyed as merchandise. (Mgh.) ― -b3- Also the former, What is upon a camel that is used for riding [consisting of the saddle and its appertenances]. (K.) It is said in a prov., jahaAzihi Daraba fiI , with fet-h [to the j], (As, S, K,) i. e. He took fright and fled or went away at random, and did not return: (K:) or it is said of a thing that goes away and does not return: (As, S:) originally relating to a camel from whose back the saddle with its apparatus tumbles, falling between his legs, in consequence of which he takes fright and flees or runs away at random, so that he goes away into the land: (As, S, K:) Daraba signifies he went; (sAr; for which in the CK is put SAr;) and the meaning of the phrase is, he went stumbling upon his apparatus. (K.) In the T it is said, The Arabs say, Daraba AlbaEiyru fiI jahaAzihi, meaning The camel took fright and ran away at random, beating the ground with his feet so as to throw down the apparatus and load that were upon him. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also the former, The pudendum of a woman. (S K, TA.)

jihaAzN jhAz
jihaAzN: see jahaAzN.

farasN jahiyzN frs jhyz
farasN jahiyzN, (S, K,) or jahiyzu AlXRadRi, (AO, TA,) A horse quick, or swift, in running: (AO, S:) or the former, a horse that is light, or active. (K.) ― -b2- mawotN jahiyzN, and mujohizN↓, A quick death. (K.)

mawotN mujohizN mwt mjhz
mawotN mujohizN: see what next precedes.

mujahRazN mjhz
mujahRazN One for whom are prepared travellingprovisions and equipage, that he may perform the pilgrimage for another. (Mgh.)

mujahRizN mjhz
mujahRizN One who sends forth traders with excellent goods: or who travels with such goods. (Mgh.) Hence, app., the vulgar term mujaAhizN↓, meaning A rich merchant. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And mujahRizuwna Travelling-companions who assist one in the loading of the beasts. (Msb.)

mujaAhizN mjAhz
mujaAhizN: see the next preceding paragraph.

1 jahaXa Uilayohi c
1. jahaXa Uilayohi, (S, K,) and jahiXa, (K,) which latter, accord. to IDrd, is the more common, (TA,) aor.
jahaXa
, inf. n. jahoXN (S, K) and juhuwXN and jahaXaAnN, (K,) He betook himself to him by reason of fright or fear, seeking protection, and being about, or ready, to weep; like as the child betakes himself to his mother by reason of fright or fear, (As, S, K,) and to his father, (As,) being about, or ready, to weep; (As, S;) as also OajohaXa↓. (AO, S, K.) ― -b2- jahaXato nafosuhu, (S, A,) or jahaXato Uilayohi nafosuhu, inf. n. juhuwXN; (TA;) and OajohaXato↓; (S, A, TA;) His soul heaved, (S, A,)
and he was about, or ready, to weep: (A:) or his soul heaved, and quitted him. (TA.) ― -b3- jahaXa lilXRawoqi waAlHuzoni He was ready, or about, to desire, and to mourn: (IDrd:) and biAlbukaMCi OajohaXa↓ He was ready, or about, to weep. (El-Umawee, K.) ― -b4- jahaXa mina AlXRaIpCi, (AA, K,) and jahiXa, (K,) aor.
jahaXa
, inf. n. jahaXaAnN, (AA, K,) He was frightened at the thing, or afraid of it: (AA, K:) or he fled from the thing.. (Sgh, K.) ― -b5- jahaXuwA faziEiyna They came quickly to me, frightened. (A.) ― -b6- yajohaXu mino OaroDK UilaI OaroDK He removes, and goes quickly, from land to land. (K.) ― -b7- jahaXa UilaI Alqawomi, inf. n. jahoXN, He came to the people, or company of men. (TA.)

4 OajohaXa
4: see 1, in three places. ＝ -A2- AjhX fulaAnFA He hastened such a one. (Ibn-'Abbaád, K.)

jahoXapN c
jahoXapN A flow of tears (A, K, TA) falling one after another on the occasion of jahoX [or the betaking oneself to another by reason of fright or fear, &c.]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A company of men; as also jaAhiXapN↓: (K:) or the latter signifies a party, and a multitude, of men. (TA.)

juhuwXN c
juhuwXN Quick; who removes, and goes quickly, from land to land. (K.)

jaAhXapN c
jaAhXapN: see jahoXapN.

1 jahVDa
1: see 4, in two places.

3 jAhDhu jAhDh jAhDp
3. jAhDhu, (K,) inf. n. jihaADN, (TA,) He endeavoured to prevent him, or to turn him away [from a thing]; and strove to be before him; syn. maAnaEahu and EaAjalahu. (K.) Hence the saying, in a trad. of Mohammad Ibn-Meslemeh, relating his endeavouring to attack a man on the day of Ohod, fajaAhaDaniI Eanohu Oabuw sufoyaAna But Aboo-Sufyán endeavoured to turn me away from him (maAnaEaniI Eanohu), and put me away [from him]. (TA.)

4 OajohaDaniI c
4. OajohaDaniI He overcame me in contending for the thing; as also jahaDaniI↓. (S.) You say, AjhDhu Eani AlOamori, He overcame him in contending for the thing, and made him to quit it, or put him away from it; as also Eanohu jahaDahu↓, aor.
jahaDa
. (A, K.) And qutila fulaAnN faOujohiDa Eanohu Alqawomu Such a one was slain, and the people were overcome so that he was taken from them. (S.) And SaAda AljaAriHapu AlSRayoda faOajohaDonaAhu Eanohu The beast, or bird, of prey caught the game, and we removed him, and overcame him in contending for that which he had caught. (S, A, * Msb.) ― -b2- AjhD is also syn. with OaEojala. (A, K.) Thus, sometimes, (S,) OajohaDotuhu Eano kacaA, (S,) or Eani AlOamori, (Mgh, TA,) signifies I hurried him so as to prevent him from doing such a thing, or the thing; (S, Mgh, TA;) and made him to quit it. (Mgh.) ― -b3- You say also, AjhDhu Eano makaAnihi He roused him, or made him to rise, from his place. (A, * TA.) And [elliptically] OajohaDonaA AlEaduwRa We roused the enemy, or made them to rise, from their places; and removed them therefrom, or made them to quit them. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- AjhDt She (a camel, AZ, As, S, A, K) cast her young one: (S, A:) or cast her young one with its fur grown, (As, K,) before it was perfect: (As:) or cast her young one before its form was apparent: (AZ:) or in an imperfect state: (TA:) or AjhDt waladahaA, inf. n. UijohaADN, she (a camel, and a woman,) cast her young one imperfect in form. (Msb.)

jihoDN jhD
jihoDN: see jahiyDN, in two places.

jihaADN jhAD
jihaADN [The act of a camel's, and of a woman's, casting an imperfect fœtus;] a subst. from AjhDt said of a camel and of a woman. (Msb.)

jahiyDN jhyD
jahiyDN, applied to the young one, or fœtus, of a camel, (S, A, Msb,) and of a woman, (Msb,) i. q. mujohaDN↓ [pass. part. n. of OajohaDato, q. v.]: (S, A, Msb: *) or, (K,) as also jihoDN↓, on the authority of Fr, being, as he says, like xidojN, in the K, erroneously, jahiDN, (TA,) an abortion: or a young one perfectly formed, and into which the spirit has been inspired, without its living: (K:) or jihoDN↓ signifies the young one of a camel that is cast before its form is apparent. (TA.)

mujohaDN mjhD
mujohaDN: see the next preceding paragraph.

mujohiDN mjhD
mujohiDN, applied to a she-camel, (S, Msb, K,) and to a woman, (Msb,) act. part. n. of OajohaDato [q. v.]; (S, Msb, K;) as also with majaAhiyDu: (Msb:) pl. mKjohaADN. (K.)

jhl jAhl jhl
jhl A she-camel that is accustomed to cast her young (S, A) in an imperfect state. (TA.)

1 jahila jAhl jhl
1. jahila; (S;) and jahilahu, (Sh, Msb, K,) and jahila bihi (JK) [and minohu (see jaAhilN)]; aor.
jaaaha
, (K,) inf. n. jaholN and jahaAlapN (S, Msb, K) and juhuwliyRahN; (TA;) He was ignorant; (S;) he was characterized by jahol in any of the senses assigned to this word below: (TA:) and he was ignorant of it; he did not know it; (Sh, JK, Msb, K;) contr. of Ealimahu. (Msb, K.) You say, mivoliI laA yajohalu mivolaka The like of me will not be ignorant of the like of thee. (Sh, TA.) And jahila EalaI gayorihi He acted in an ignorant or a silly or foolish manner towards another: and wrongly. (Msb.) And jahila fulaAnN raOoyahu [i. q. safiha raOuyahu, He was ignorant, or silly, or foolish, in his opinion, or judgment]. (Sh, TA.) And jahila AlHaqRa He neglected the truth, or the right, or due; [or he ignored it;] syn. OaDaAEahu. (Msb.) See also 6. ― -b2- jahilati Alqidoru (tropical:) The cooking-pot boiled vehemently; contr. of taHalRamat. (TA.)

2 jhRlhu jAhl jhl jhlh jhlp
2. jhRlhu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. tajohiylN, (S, K,) He attributed to him jahol [or ignorance, &c.]. (S, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And He caused him to fall into jahol. (TA.)

3 mujaAhalapN mjAhlh mjAhlp mjhl
3. mujaAhalapN The acting with levity, and in an ignorant or a silly or foolish manner, with any one. (KL.) [You say, jAhlhu, meaning He so acted with him.]

6 tjAhl tjAhl
6. tjAhl He feigned, or made a false show of, jahol [or ignorance, &c.]. (S, K.) And jahila↓ Ealayohi He feigned ignorance [to him]. (K.)

10 Astjhlhu Ostjhlh Astjhlh Astjhlp Qstjhl Qstjhlh
10. Astjhlhu He reckoned him, or esteemed him, jaAhil [or ignorant, &c.]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- He, or it, excited him to lightness, or levity, and unsteadiness. (S, K.) ― -b3- Aisotjohalati AlrRiyHu AlguSona (tropical:) The wind put the branch into a state of commotion. (K, TA.)

jaholN jAhl jhl
jaholN an inf. n. of 1: Ignorance; contr. of EilomN: (S, Msb, * K: *) [and silliness, or foolishness: and wrong conduct: (see 1:)] it is of two kinds; namely, simple, which is the non-existence of knowledge of that which should be known; and compound, which is a decisive belief not agreeable with the fact, or reality: so accord. to Ibn-El-Kemál: or, accord. to Er-Rághib, it is of three kinds; namely, the mind's voidness of knowledge, which is the primary meaning; and the believing a thing to be different from what it is; and the doing a thing in a manner different from that in which it ought to be done: or, accord. to El-Harállee, the proceeding in dubious affairs without knowledge. (TA.) It is said in a prov., kafiI biAlXRakRi juholFA [Doubt is sufficient ignorance]. (Msb.) And it is said in a trad., UinRa mina AlEilomi jaholFA [Verily there is, among the kinds of knowledge, what is ignorance]: this is one's learning what is not requisite, and neglecting what is requisite; or a learned man's affecting, or pretending, a knowledge of that which he does not know. (TA.)

jahilaOCu c
jahilaOCu: see AljaAhiliyRapu.:jahuwlN see what next follows.

jaAhilN jAhl
jaAhilN and jahuwlN↓, [but the latter has an intensive signification,] Ignorant: (Msb, K:) and silly, or foolish, in conduct: and wrong in conduct: (Msb:) [characterized by jahol in any of the senses assigned to this word above:] pl. juhRaAlN (K, KL) and juholN and juhulN and juhRalN and juhalaMCu: (K:) see jaAhiliIRN. The former epithet is mostly used in dispraise: but sometimes not in dispraise; as in the saying [in the Kur ii. 274], yajosibuhumu AljaAhilu OagoniyaMCa i. e., The ignorant of their [real] state [would reckon them possessed of competence]. (TA.) huwa jaAhilN minohu means hw jAhl bihi, (K, TA,) i. e., He is ignorant [of him, or it, or] of his, or its, state, or condition. (TA.) ― -b2- AljaAhilu The lion (K, TA) that is ignorant of the prey. (TA.) [In the CK, waAljaAhilu AlAasadu is a mistake for waAljaAhilu AlOasadu.]

jayohalu jyhl
jayohalu: see jayohalapN. ＝ -A2- Also Great as an epithet applied to a smooth rock (SafaApN). (K.)

jayohalapN jyhlh jyhlp
jayohalapN (IDrd, JK, K) and jayohalN↓ and mijohalN↓ (IDrd, K) and mijohalapN↓ (K) A piece of wood with which one stirs live, or burning, coals (jamor), (JK, K, TA,) or wine (xamor); (so in some copies of the K;) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

jaAhiliIRN jAhl jAhlI jAhly jAhlyy
jaAhiliIRN [A pagan; a pagan Arab; one of those who are called collectively AljaAhilyRapN↓; and
sometimes muxaDuramuwn↓, pl. of XaAhidN: and particularly, a pagan poet;] a poet of the first, or earliest, of the four classes which are ranked in chronological order; of the class which was succeeded next by the muxaDoramuwn. (Mz, 49th nwE.) [See also XaAhidN.]

AljaAhiliyRapN AljAhlyh AljAhlyp jAhly jAhlyp
AljaAhiliyRapN: see what next precedes. ― -b2- [Also, or] AljaAhiliyRapu AljaholaMCu↓, (JK, S, K,) in which the latter word is a corroborative, (S, K,) as in layolapN layolaMCu &c., (S,) [The time, or state, of ignorance, or paganism; or of intense ignorance;] the time of the fatorap [or cessation of the mission of apostles, and of the effacement of the signs of their religion]. (JK.) One says, kaAna celika fiI AljaAhiliyRapi AljaholaMCi [That was in the time, or state, of paganism, or of intense ignorance]. (S.)

majohalN mjhl
majohalN An affair, or an event, or a case, and a land, and a habit, a property, a quality, a practice, or an action, that induces a man to believe a thing to be different from what it is. (Er-Rághib, TA.) A desert (mafaAzapN) in which are no signs of the way. (S.) And OaroDN majohalN A land in which are no signs of the way: (TA:) or in which one will not go aright (K, TA) unless by means of the [signs of the way called] MraAm: (TA:) pl. majaAhilu, which is the contr. of maEaAlimu: (TA:) accord. to the K, it has neither dual nor pl.; but it has both, as 'Iyád and others have affirmed. (MF, TA.)

mijohalN mjhl
mijohalN: see jayohalapN.

majohalapN mjhl mjhlh mjhlp
majohalapN [A cause of, or an incitement to, ignorant, silly, foolish, or wrong, conduct;] a thing that incites one to Aljahol. (S, K.) Hence the saying, Alwaladu majohalapN [Children are a cause of silly, or foolish, conduct]. (S.)

mijohalapN mjhl mjhlh mjhlp
mijohalapN: see jayohalapN.

mijohaAlN mjhAl
mijohaAlN (tropical:) A she-camel light, brisk, or agile, in her pace, or going. (TA.)

majohuwlN mjhwl
majohuwlN [Unknown]. You say, rakibotu AlmafaAzapN EalaI majohuwlihaA [I ventured upon traversing the desert notwithstanding its unknown character]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- [A man of unknown origin. A book of unknown authorship. ― -b3- In grammar, The passive voice.] ― -b4- naAqapN majohuwlapN (tropical:) A she-camel that has never been milked: or that has no brand upon her: (K, TA:) and (tropical:) a she-camel that has never conceived. (Z, TA.)

musotajohilN mstjhl
musotajohilN Making himself like the jaAhil [or ignorant; feigning himself ignorant]: or reckoning, or esteeming, jaAhil. (Har p. 572.)

1 jahuma jhm
1. jahuma, aor.
jahuma
, inf. n. juhuwmapN (S, K) and jahaAmapN, (K,) He (a man) became frowning, or contracted, in face; or grinning in face, with a frowning, or contraction, or a stern, an austere, or a morose, look: (S:) or he was, or became, coarse, or rough, and contracted, and ugly, in face. (K.) ― -b2- Also, said of the pubes, It was coarse, rough, or big. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jahamahu, (S, K,) and jahimahu, aor.
jahama
, in both instances; (K;) and tjhRmhu↓, (S, K,) and lahu tjhRm↓; (JK, K;) He grinned, frowning, or looking sternly, austerely, or morosely, in his face: (S:) or he met him, or regarded him, with a displeasing, (JK, K, TA,) frowning, or grinning and frowning, (TA,) face: (JK, K, TA:) or tjhRm↓ signifies he showed a sour, a crabbed, or an austere, face. (TK in art. Ebs.) A poet says,
AljahuwmaA↓ wabalodapK tajahRamu↓
zajarotu fiyhaA EayohalFA rasuwmaA
(S, * TA,) i. e. [Many a region] that exhibits to the impotent that which he dislikes, [or that frowns upon the weak, or impotent, I have chidden therein a strong she-camel that leaves the marks of her footsteps upon the ground.] (S.) You say also, AlkiraAma AldRahoru yatajahRamu↓ (tropical:) [Fortune frowns upon the generous]. (TA.) And OamaliI tajahRamaniI↓ (tropical:) [My object of hope frowned upon me] is said when one has not attained his object of hope. (TA.)

4 Oajohamati AlsRamaMCu c
4. Oajohamati AlsRamaMCu The sky had clouds such as are termed jahaAm. (K.)

5 tajahRama
5: see 1, in six places.

8 Ajthm Oj Ojthm Ajthm
8. Ajthm He entered upon, (K,) or journeyed in, (A, TA,) the portion of the night termed juhomap. (A, K, TA.)

jahomN jhm
jahomN A coarse, or rough, and contracted, and ugly, face; as also jahimN↓; (K;) or, as in some of the lexicons, jahiymN↓. (TA.) And jahomu Alwajohi Frowning, or contracted, in face; or grinning in face, with a frowning, or contraction, or a stern, an austere, or a morose, look: (S, Mgh:) or coarse, or rough, in face: (JK, TA:) applied to a man: (JK, S, Mgh, TA:) and to a lion. (JK, TA.) And [hence,] Aljahomu The lion. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also jahuwmN.

jahimN jhm
jahimN: see jahomN.

jahomapN jhm jhmh jhmp
jahomapN: see juhomapN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also A big cooking-pot. (K.)

juhomapN jhm jhmh jhmp
juhomapN and jahomapN↓, (JK, S, K,) both mentioned by Fr, (S,) A portion of the night: (JK:) the first of the last portions of the night, (JK, S, K, TA,) extending [app. from midnight] to near the period a little before daybreak: (TA:) or the remaining portion of the darkness of the last part of the night: (K:) or the former signifies, [or each,] the beginning of the night, extending to a fourth part: or, as some say, the middle of the night: (KL:) pl. of the former juhamN. (JK.) You say, maDaI mina AllRayoli juhomapN and jahomapN↓ [app. meaning A portion, or a portion at the commencement of the latter part, of the night passed]. (A'Obeyd, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also the former, Eighty camels: or the like. (K.)

jahaAmN jhAm
jahaAmN Clouds in which is no water: (JK, S, K:) or that have poured forth their water (K, TA) with the wind. (TA.)

juhuwmN jhwm
juhuwmN, applied to a man, (JK, S,) Impotent; (JK, S, K;) weak; as also jahomN↓. (K.) See an ex. in the first paragraph.

jahiymN jhym
jahiymN: see jahomN.

jahanRamu jhnm
jahanRamu [Hell; or Hell-fire;] (T, S, K, &c.;) a name of the fire with which God will punish, (T, S,) in the life to come, (T,) his [disobedient and unrepentant and unbelieving] servants; (S;) a proper name of the abode of punishment: (Bd, ii. 202:) a word rendered quasi-coordinate to the quinqueliteral-radical class by the doubling of the third letter: (S:) accord. to some, it is an Arabic word, applied to the fire of the world to come because of its depth; [see the last paragraph;] (T, TA;) or originally syn. with AlnRaAru [fire, or the fire]; (Bd in ii. 202;) and imperfectly decl. because determinate and of the fem. gender: (T, S:) accord. to others, it is an arabicized word, (T, S, Bd ubi suprà,) imperfectly decl. because determinate and of foreign origin; (T, TA;) some say, originally Persian; (S;) others, from the Hebrew khnAm, (TA,) [or as Golius says, ??? “ the Valley of Hinnom, ” where children were burned alive as sacrifices to the idol Moloch.] ― -b2- See also jihinRaAmN.

jahanRamiIRN jhnm jhnmI jhnmy
[jahanRamiIRN Of, or relating to, jahanRam, i. e. Hell, or Hell-fire.]

jihinRaAmN jhnAm
jihinRaAmN (S, K, Ham p. 817) and [jahinRaAmN and juhinRaAmN], with each of the three vowels (K, TA) to the j (TA,) [but accord. to the K it would rather seem to be jahanRaAmN and juhunRaAmN,] and jahanRamN↓, (K,) applied to a well (rakiyRapN, S, K, or biYorN, Ham), Deep; (S, K, Ham;) in which he who falls into it perishes. (Ham.)

jawRN jw
jawRN The air: (K:) or [the atmosphere; i. e.] what is between the heaven, or sky, and the earth; (S, Mgh;) the air [or the region] between the heaven, or sky, and the earth: pl. OajowaMCN. (TA.) fiI jawRi AlsRamaMCi, in the Kur [xvi. 81], means In the air between the heaven, or sky, and the earth: (Jel:) or in the middle of the sky: (Katádeh, TA:) or in the air that is remote from the earth. (Bd.) ― -b2- A low, or depressed, part of the ground; (M, K;) as also jawRapN↓: (K:) or a wide part of a valley: (S, Msb:) pl. (in the latter sense, Msb, or in the former, K, TA) jiwaMCN (Msb, K) and [of pauc.] OajowiyapN. (TA.) It has the latter meaning in the saying of Tarafeh, [addressing a lark,]
xalaA laki AljawRu fabiyDiI waQSofiriI
[The wide part of the valley has become vacant for thee; so lay thine eggs, and whistle]. (AA, S.) Az says, I entered, with an Arab of the desert, a [hollow place in which water collected, termed a] daHol, in El-Khalsà, and when we came to the water, he said, hecaA jawRN mina AlmaACi laA yuwqafu EalaI OaqoSaAhu [This is an abyss of water: one knows not the utmost extent of it]. (TA.) ― -b3- A vacant, void, or desolate, place, in which is no one to cheer by his company. (Ham p. 293.) ― -b4- The inside, or interior, of a house or tent; (K;) and of anything; of the dial. of Syria; also termed jawRapN↓, (TA,) and jawRaAniIRN↓; (K; [in the CK
A is erroneously put for n;]) in which last, the A and Ouriydu jawRFA wayuriydu barRFA are augmentatives for the purpose of corroboration. (TA.) ― -b5- [Hence,] jawRapN I desire concealment, or secrecy, and he desires publicity. (A in art. br.)

jawRapN jw jwh jwp
jawRapN: see jawRN, in two places.

jawRaAniIRN jwAnI jwAny
jawRaAniIRN: see jawRN. Hence the saying of Selmán, mano OaSolaHa jawRaAniyRahu OaSolaHa QllRehu barRaAniyRahu [explained in art. br]. (TA.) [It generally signifies Inner, inward, or interior; and secret, or private; opposed to barRaAniIRN; and is now vulgarly pronounced juwRaAniIo.] It is a rel. n. [irregularly formed] from jawRN signifying “ any low, or depressed, part of the ground. ” (T in art. br.)

1 yajuwoCu yj yjwC
1. yajuwoCu is a dial. var. of yajiIoCu [aor. of jaMCa and meaning He comes, or will come]: (K:) mentioned by Sb, who gives as an ex. OanaA OajuwoWuka waOanobuWuka [for AnA OajiyoWuka wOanobaWuka, I will come to thee and inform thee]. (TA.)

juwaAliqN jwAlq
juwaAliqN and juwaAlaqN and jiwaAliqN: see art. jlq.

1 jaAbahu jAb jAbh jAbp
1. jaAbahu, (S, * TA,) aor. yajuwbu, (S, TA,) inf. n. jawobN (S, A, K, TA) and tajowaAbN, (Har p. 336,) He made a hole in it; or rent, or tore, it; (S, A, K, TA;) as also AjtAbhu↓: (K, * TA:) he made a hole through, or in, or into, it; perforated, pierced, or bored, it: (TA:) he cut it: (S, A, K, TA:) he cut it in like manner as one cuts a jayob [or an opening at the neck and bosom of a shirt &c.]: (L, TA:) he made, or cut, a hole in the middle of it; cut a piece out of the middle of it; hollowed it out; or excavated it. (TA.) You say, jAb AlSRaxorapa He made a hole in the rock; (A, TA;) perforated, pierced, or bored, it. (TA.) Hence, in the Kur [lxxxix. 8], wavamuwda AlRaciyna jaAbuwA AlSRaxora biAlwaAdi (Fr, S, TA) And Thamood, who made holes in the rocks, (Fr, TA,) or cut the rocks, (Bd, Jel,) [or hollowed them out,] and made them dwellings, in the valley, (Fr, Bd, Jel, TA,) i. e., in Wádi-l-Kurà. (Bd, Jel.) You say also, jAb AlqamiySa, (S, A, K,) aor. bajuwbu, [inf. n. jawobN;] (S, K, and Msb in art. jyb;) and aor. yajiybu, (S, K,) [inf. n., app., jiybN, originally jawobN; see a verse cited below, and a remark of Sh thereon;] and jwRbhu↓; (A, K;) He hollowed out, or cut out in a round form, the jayob of the shirt: (S, and Msb in art. jyb:) or he cut the jayob of the shirt: (A:) or he made a jayob to the shirt; (K;) as also jayRabahu, (S, and Msb in art. jyb,) inf. n. tajoyiybN. (S.) And jAb AlvRawoba He cut the garment, or piece of cloth; [or cut it out;] as also AjtAbhu↓. (A.) And jAb AlnRaEola, inf. n. jawobN, He cut out the sandal. (TA.) And jAb Alqaronu [i. e. jAb AllRaHoma] The horn cut the flesh and came forth. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, also,] jAb, (S, A, Msb, TA,) aor. yajuwbu (S, Msb, TA) and yajiybu, (S, TA,) inf. n. jawobN; (TA;) and AjtAb↓; (S, A, TA;) (tropical:) He traversed, or crossed, (S, A, * Msb, TA,) or cut through by journeying, (TA,) a country, (S, TA,) or a land, (Msb,) and a desert, and the darkness: (A, * TA:) and jawobN signifies likewise the pouncing down of a bird. (TA.) A rájiz says,
baAtato tajiybu OadoEaja AlZRalaAmi
jiyba AlbiyaTori midoraEa AlhumaAmi
(assumed tropical:) [She passed the night cutting through the black darkness, like as the tailor cuts through the woollen tunic of the valiant chief, making the opening at the neck and bosom]: (S: [but in one copy, instead of jiyba, I here find jayoba; and in art. bTr, XaqRa:]) and Sh remarks that this [verb tjyb, or the inf. n. jyb,] is not from Aljayobu [meaning “ the opening at the neck and bosom ” of a shirt &c.], because its medial radical is w, and that of Aljyb is I: (TA:) [i. e., jAb, aor. yjyb, is originally jawaba, aor. yajowibu.] One says also, of news, yajuwbu AlOaroDa mino baladK UilaI baladK (assumed tropical:) [It traverses the earth from country to country, or the land from town to town]. (S, TA.) And of proverbs, tajuwbu AlbilaAda (assumed tropical:) They are current in the countries, or towns. (TA.) ― -b3- It is said in a trad., jiybati AlEarabu EanRaA kamaA jiybati AlrRaHaA Eano quTobihaA (assumed tropical:) The Arabs were rent from us, like as the mill-stone is rent from its pivot; we being in the midst, and they around us. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jaAbati AldRaEowapu: see Oajowabu.

2 jwRb jwb
2. jwRb: see 1. ― -b2- Also, said of the light of the moon, (assumed tropical:) It illumined, and rendered clear, [by penetrating,] a dark night. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jwRb Ealayohi [from jawobN “ a shield ”] He shielded him. (TA: so accord. to an explanation of the act. part. n.)

3 jaAowaba
3: [jAwbhu, inf. n. mujaAwabapN, He returned him answer for answer, or answers for answers; held a dialogue, colloquy, conference, disputation, or debate, with him; bandied words with him.] See 6, in two places.

4 AjAbhu OjAb OjAbh UjAbp AjAbh AjAbp jAbh
4. AjAbhu, (S, A, Msb, TA,) inf. n. UijaAbapN (S, Msb, K, * TA) and UijaAbN (K, * TA) and jaAbapN↓, (Kr, TA,) or this last is a simple subst., (AHeyth, S, TA,) like TaAEapN and TaAqapN, (S, A,) used in the place of an inf. n.; (AHeyth, TA;) and AstjAbhu↓ (A, K, TA) and Aisotajuwabahu↓ and lahu AistjAb↓; (K, TA;) [for] UijaAbapN and AisotijaAbapN↓ are syn.; (S, TA;) He answered him, replied to him, responded to him, (Msb, TA,) either affirmatively or negatively. (Msb.) And AjAb qawolahu He answered, or replied to, his saying. (Msb.) And AjAb Eano suWaAlihi (S, TA) He answered, or replied to, his question. (TA.) And AjAb duEaMCahu, (Msb, TA, *) and duEaMCahu AstjAb↓, (S, A, TA,) and lahu AstjAb↓, (Msb,) and minohu AstjAb↓, (Har p. 307,) said of God, (S, A, Msb, TA,) [He answered his prayer;;] He accepted his prayer; (Msb;) He recompensed his prayer by gift and acceptance. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 182], Oujiybu daEowpa AldRaAEiI UicaA liI daEaAni faloyasotajiybuwA↓ [I answer the prayer of him who prayeth to me;] therefore let them answer me; (TA;) i. e., let them answer my call by obedience, (Jel,) when I call them to belief and obedience: (Bd:) accord. to Fr, what is here meant [by the last verb] is talobiyap [q. v. in art. lbI]: (TA:) [or let them give me their assent, or consent, to my call; or let them obey my call: for you say, AjAbhu UilaI XaIoCK and EalaI XaIoCK, (for the latter of which there is authority in this art. in the TA, but the former is more common,) and] lh AstjAb↓, He obeyed him, or complied with his desire, in doing a thing, [or consented to do it,] when summoned, or invited, to do it. (Msb.) ― -b2- AjAbt AlOaroDu (assumed tropical:) The land produced plants, or herbage. (Ham p. 94.) ― -b3- damoEN yujiybu (assumed tropical:) Tears running, or flowing; as though called for and answering the call. (Har p. 71.) ＝ -A2- The forms Oajowaba and Oajowibo [as verbs of wonder] are not used: therefore you say, maA Oajowada jawaAbahu and Oajowido bijawaAbihi [How good is his answer, or reply!]; not maA Oajowabahu nor Oajowibo bihi: nor do you say, huwa Oajowabu minoka [meaning He is better in answering, or replying, than thou: but see Oajowabu, below]. (Sb, TA.)

6 tjAwbwA jAwb tjAwb tjAwbwA
6. tjAwbwA i. q. baEoDuhumo baEoDFA jaAwaba↓ [They returned one another answer for answer, or answers for answers; they answered one another; replied, one to another; held a dialogue, colloquy, conference, disputation, or debate, together; bandied words, one with another]: (K:) mujaAwabapN↓ and tajaAwubN both signify i. q. taHaAwurN. (S, TA.) In like manner one says of turtle-doves, (A,) of pigeons, of braying camels, and of neighing horses. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] yatajaAwabu OawRalu kalaAmihi waMxiruhu (tropical:) The first and the last parts of his speech correspond, or are consistent. (A, TA.)

7 AnjAb OnjAb UnjAb AnjAb QnjAb
7. AnjAb [It (a garment) became rent, or slit: see munojaAbN]. ― -b2- Said of a cloud, or a collection of clouds, It cleared away [so as to leave an open space]. (S, Msb.) It is said in a trad., waQnojaAba AlsRaHaAbu Eani Almadiynapi HatRaI SaArakaAlUi koliyli And the clouds became gathered and drawn together, and cleared away from the city [so that they became like a crown]. (TA.) ― -b3- [It (a place) was, or became, clear, open, or unobstructed.] See jawobapN ＝ -A2- AnjAbt She (a camel) stretched forth her neck, to be milked; (K;) as though she complied with the desire of her milker to be restrained [for that purpose]: but Fr says that he had not found a verb of this measure from OajaAba. (TA.)

8 AjtAb AjtAb
8. AjtAb: see 1, in three places. ― -b2- He dug a well. (K.) And AjtAbt, said of a wild cow, She hollowed out, or excavated, a place to shelter herself from the rain. (TA.) ― -b3- He put on, i. e. clad himself with, (T, S, K,) a garment, (T,) or a shirt; (S, K;) he entered into a shirt: and in like manner, (assumed tropical:) the darkness. (TA.)

10 AstjAb 10 and Aisotajowaba
10. AstjAb Aisotajowaba, inf. n. AisotijaAbapN: see 4, nine places.

jaAbN jcAb
jaAbN: see jaOubN, in art. jOb

jawobN jwb
jawobN [an inf. n. (of 1, q. v.,) used in the sense of a pass. part. n. Hence,] a tribe is said to be jawobu OabK as meaning Cut [as it were] from one
father; [sprung from the loins of one father;] occurring in a trad. (TA.) ― -b2- A fire-place; [so called because hollowed out;] syn. kaAnuwnN. (K.) ― -b3- A large dalow [or bucket; because of its hollow form]. (Kr, K.) ― -b4- A shield; (S, K;) as also jawobapN↓ (TA) and mijowabN↓: (K:) [see a verse cited voce yalabN:] pl. of the first OajowaAbN. (TA.) ― -b5- A garment like the baqiyrap: [so called because it has a slit in the middle, through which the head is put:] (S:) or a woman's shift. (K.) ― -b6- See also jawobapN ＝ -A2- [A kind, or sort.] You say, fulaAnN fiyhi jawobaAni mino xuluqK [In such a one are two kinds of temper, or disposition]; i. e., he does not remain in one temper, or disposition. (TA.) And Dhu-Rummeh says,
jawobayoni mino hamaAhimi AlOagowaAli
meaning Thou hearest two kinds of the sounds, or voices, [or mutterings,] of the ghools. (TA.)

jayobN jyb
jayobN meaning The [part called] Tawoq of a shirt, (see art. jyb,) is, accord. to some, from the root jwb, because the middle of it is cut out: accord. to others, from the root jyb. (TA.)

jaAbapN jAb jAbh jAbp
jaAbapN is an inf. n. of OajaAba, (Kr, TA,) or a simple subst. (A Heyth, S, TA) used in the place of an inf. n. (A Heyth, TA. See 4.) Hence, OasaMCa samoEFA faOasaMCa jaAbapF [He heard ill, and therefore answered ill]: (S, A, K:) a prov., and therefore not to be rehearsed otherwise than in the original way, as above: [not to be altered by the substitution of UijaAbapN or UijaAbFA for jaAbapF:] its origin is said to have been this: Sahl [or Suheyl] Ibn-' Amr had an insane son; and a man said to him, Oayona OamRuka, i. e. “ Whither is thy tending? ” to which he (thinking that he said, Oayona OumRuka [“ Where is thy mother! ”],) answered, “ She is gone to buy flour: ” whereupon his father uttered the words of this prov. (TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 603.]) See also jawaAbN ＝ -A2- jaAbapu AlmidoraI is a dial. var. of jaOobapu AlmdrI: (K: [see art. jOb:]) accord. to AO and Sh, it is without C: accord. to the former, it means A doe-gazelle when her horn has come forth; and accord. to the latter, when her horn has cut the skin and come forth: (T, TA:) or it means having smooth horns; and if so, it has no [known] derivation. (TA.) [See also art. drI.]

jawobapN jwb jwbh jwbp
jawobapN A depressed place amid the houses of a people, into which the rain-water flows: (TA:) a pit, an excavation, or a hollow, (T, K, TA,) round and wide: (T, TA:) a gap, or an opening, in the clouds; and in mountains: and a clear space (mawoDiEN yanojaAbu↓) in a [stony tract such as is called] HarRap: (S:) a place (AHn, K) that is clear, (AHn,) plain and smooth, (AHn, K,) such as is termed daArapN, with few trees, like a round gaAYT [or wide and depressed tract], (AHn,) in a tract that is hard, or hard and level, or level but rough, (AHn, K,) and such as is of large extent, not in sands nor in a mountain; so called because [for the most part] clear of trees: (AHn:) and an intervening space between houses; (K;) as also jawobN↓: (TA:) and a wide, or spacious, and smooth tract, between two lands: (K:) any wide gap, or opening: any gap, or opening, without buildings: (TA:) pl. juwabN (S, K) and jawobaAtN (TA.) ― -b2- The former of these pls. also signifies The pudenda of women; syn. furuwjN. (TA.) ― -b3- See also jawobN

jiybapN jyb jybh jybp
jiybapN i. q. jawaAbN, q. v. (S, K.) So in the phrase, UinRahu laHasanu Aljiyabpi [Verily he is good in respect of answer or reply or response: or here it seems rather to signify, agreeably with analogy, the mode, or manner, of answering or replying or responding]. (S.)

jawaAbN jAbyp jwAb
jawaAbN An answer, a reply, or a response, (Msb, TA, *) to a letter, or writing, and to a saying, or question; and this is either affirmative or negative: (Msb:) [accord. to some, it is only after a question or demand; but this is not correct; for it is often a reply to an affirmation:] jiybapN↓ [q. v.] is syn. therewith; (S, K;) and so are jaAbapN↓ [q. v.] and majuwbapN↓: (K:) the pl. of jwAb is OajowibapN and jawaAbaAtN (Msb.) [Hence, in grammar, Harofu jawaAbK A responsive, or replicative, particle. And jawaAbu XaroTK An apodosis; the complement, or correlative, of a condition; as Oakoramotuka in the saying, Uino jiYotaniI Oakoramotuka; also called jazaMCu XaroTK, and jawaAbu jazaMCK. And jawaAbu qasamK The complement of an oath.] ― -b2- Also The sound of a bird pouncing down from the sky. (TA from a trad.)

jawRaAbN jAbyp jwAb
jawRaAbN [An excellent well-digger:] a surname given to Málik Ibn-Kaab El-Kilábee, (AO, ISk, S, K, *) because he dug not a well nor bored a rock without making it to yield water. (AO, ISk, S.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A traverser of countries; one who travels much. (TA.) Hence, jawRaAbu layolK saromadK (assumed tropical:) One who travels all the night without sleeping. (TA.) And jawRaAbN jaORbN (assumed tropical:) One who traverses the countries and gains wealth. (TA.) And jawRaAbu AlfalaApi (assumed tropical:) The guide of the desert. (TA.)

AljaAYibu AlEayoni c
AljaAYibu AlEayoni The lion. (K.)

jaAYibapu xabarK c
jaAYibapu xabarK (tropical:) News that traverses the earth, from country to country, or town to town: (S, A: *) or i. q. Tariyqap xaAriqap [app. a mistranscription for Tiriyfap xArqp, meaning recent news that traverses the land]. (K.) And [the pl.] jawaAYibu (assumed tropical:) Tidings from afar. (K.) And jawaAYibu AlOamovaAli (assumed tropical:) Current proverbs; such as traverse the countries. (TA.)

Oajowabu c
Oajowabu, [see 4,] in the following question, put to Mohammad, (TA,) OaIRuAllRayoli Oajowabu daEowapF is either from jubotu AlOaroDa (K, TA) “ I traversed the land, ” (TA,) and signifies (tropical:) More, or most, penetrating to the places whence the answer is imagined to proceed; (K, TA;) or [it signifies more, or most, quick in being answered,] from AldRaEowapu jaAbati↓, of the measure faEulat, [i. e., originally jawubat,] “ the prayer became answered, ” which, however, is a verb not in use, like as faqiyrN and XadiydN are imagined to be derived from faqura and Xaduda: (Z, TA:) or it signifies more, or most, quick of answer, [from OajaAba,] and is [anomalous, and] similar to OaTowaEu [“ more obedient ”], from AlTRaAEapu, [i. e. from OaTaAEa “ he obeyed, ”] (M, L, TA,) and to OaEoTaI [“ more, or most, excellent in giving, ” from OaEoTaI “ he gave ”], and lawaAqiHa [pl. of laAqiHapN a “ fecundating ” wind, (in the Kur xv. 22,) from OaloqaHa “ he, or it, fecundated ”], (M, L, K, TA,) and the like; (M, L, TA;) and if so, the word is anomalous because a word of the measure OafoEalu of this kind is not derived from a verb of more than three letters, except in certain cases of deviation from the constant course of speech: (L, TA:) the meaning is, (tropical:) What part of the night is that [in which prayer most quickly penetrates? or] in which prayer is most quick in being answered? (Mgh:) or what part of the night is that in which God is most quick in answering prayer? (L, TA.)

majuwbu mjwb
majuwbu [pass. part. n. of 1, q. v.:] Anything cut in the middle, or of which the middle is cut out; as also mujawRabN↓; (T, TA;) and the latter, anything hollowed out in the middle. (TA.)

mijowabN mjwb
mijowabN An iron instrument with which one cuts [or perforates or hollows out]. (S, TA.) ― -b2- See also jawobN

Almujiybu Almjyb mjyb
Almujiybu one of the names of God; The Answerer of prayer; He who recompenses prayer and petition by gift and acceptance. (TA.)

majuwbapN mjwbh mjwbp
majuwbapN: see jawaAbN

mujawRabN mjwb
mujawRabN: see majuwbN ― -b2- [Hence,] OaroDN mujawRabapN (assumed tropical:) A land of which one part has been rained upon (K, TA) and not another. (TA.)

mijowaAbN mjwAb
mijowaAbN An instrument with which palm-sticks and canes &c. are bored by the maker of cages or crates or the like. (TA in art. vTb.)

mutajaAwibN mtjAwb
mutajaAwibN (tropical:) Speech, or language, of which the several parts correspond, or are consistent. (A, TA.)

munojaAbN mnjAb
munojaAbN A garment rent, or slit. (Ham p. 338.)

1 jaAHa jAH
1. jaAHa, (S, A,) aor. yajuwHu, (S,) inf. n. jawoHN, (S, K,) He (a man, S) extirpated, or exterminated, (S, A, K,) a thing: (S:) He (God, S) destroyed (S, A, K) a man's property, or cattle, (S,) by what is termed jaAYiHap: (S, A:) as also AjAH↓, (S, A,) inf. n. UijaAHapN; (K;) and AjtAH↓, (S,) inf. n. AijotiyaAHN. (K.) You say [also], jaAHiti AlMfapu AlmaAla, i. e. AljaAYiHapu, aor. tajuwHuhu, inf. n. as above; and AjAHthu↓; and AjtAHthu↓; The bane, or pest, or the like, destroyed the property, or cattle; as also jaAHatohu, aor. tajiyHuhu, inf. n. jiyaAHapN: (Msb:) and one says of anything, such as drought, or dearth, and civil war, or conflict and faction, &c., jAH AlmaAla and AjtAHhu↓, meaning it extirpated, or exterminated, the property, or cattle. (TA.) And jaAHatohumu AljaAYiHapu, (S,) or AlsRanapu, inf. n. jawoHN and jiyaAHN; and OajaAHatohumo↓; (TA;) and AijotaAHatohumo↓; (S, A, TA;) i. e. [The calamity, bane, pest, or the like, or drought, or dearth, destroyed or] extirpated [them, or] their property, or cattle.
(TA.) And AlEaduwRu maAlahu AjtAH↓ The enemy destroyed, or made an end of, his property, or cattle; syn. OataI Ealayohi. (TA.) ― -b2- Also jAH, aor. yajuwHu, inf. n. jawoHN, He destroyed the property, or cattle, of his relations. (IAar, TA.) ＝ -A2- And, aor. yajuwHu, He deviated from the road, or beaten track. (IAar, K.)

4 OajowaHa
4: see 1, in three places.

8 UijotawaHa
8: see 1, in five places.

jawoHapN jwHh jwHp
jawoHapN: see jaAYiHapN.

jaAYiHN c
jaAYiHN [act. part. n. of 1]. You say MfapN jaAYiHapN A destructive bane or pest or the like: (Msb:) and sanapN jaAYiHapN a year of drought or dearth or sterility: (Mgh:) pl. jawaAYiHu. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- [And hence,] The locust. (IAar, T in art. jHI.)

jaAYiHapN c
jaAYiHapN [fem. of jaAYiHN, q. v.: and hence, as a subst.,] A bane, a pest, (Msb,) a calamity, or the like, (S, Msb, K,) or a great calamity, (Mgh, TA,) that destroys, or extirpates, men's property, or cattle; (S, Mgh, Msb, * K, TA;) as drought, or dearth; or civil war, or conflict and faction, and the like: (S, TA:) drought, or dearth, that destroys, or extirpates, men's property, or cattle; as also jawoHapN↓: (Wásil, TA:) or a calamity that befalls a man, and destroys all his property, or cattle: (A'Obeyd, T:) or severe drought or dearth, that destroys, or extirpates, men's property, or cattle: (ISh:) sometimes it is the effect of large hail; and sometimes, of excessive cold or heat: (T:) or (accord. to Esh-Sháfi'ee, Mgh, Msb) a blast, or blight, or calamity arising from the atmosphere, that destroys the fruits, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) or some thereof; (Mgh;) only relating to fruits: (TA:) pl. jawaAYiHu. (A, Mgh, Msb.) It is said in a trad., Oamara biwaDoEi AljawaAYiHi, which is an elliptical phrase, meaning He commanded to remit the poor-rate in respect of things affected by a blast, or blight, (Mgh, Msb,) namely, property, (Mgh,) or fruits, (Msb,) so affected; (Mgh, Msb;) i. e., that no portion thereof, (Mgh,) or of the remains thereof, (Msb,) should be taken for the poor-rate. (Mgh, Msb.)

mujaAHN mjAH
mujaAHN: see what next follows.

majuwHN mjwH
majuwHN Property, or cattle, destroyed by a bane, or pest, or the like; as also majiyHN [belonging to art. jyH], and mujaAHN↓. (Msb.)

mijowaHN mjwH
mijowaHN [A person or thing] that destroys, or extirpates, everything. (K, TA.)

1 jaAda jAd
1. jaAda, aor. yajuwdu, inf. n. juwdapN and jawodapN, It (a thing, S, or a commodity, an article of household-goods, or the like, Msb, and a work, or performance, TA) was, or became, jayRid [i. e. good, goodly, approvable, or excellent; the verb being the contr. of raduWa, as is implied in the A and K]: (S, A, Msb, K:) in this sense, accord. to some, of the class of qaAla; accord. to others, of the class of qaruba. (Msb.) [Also said of a man, meaning He was, or became, excellent, or egregious, in some quality; sometimes, though very rarely, in a quality that is disapproved.] ― -b2- And jAd, (S, A, Msb, K,) of the class of qAl, (Msb,) aor. as above, (S, Msb,) inf. n. juwdN, (S, A, Msb, K,) with damm, (S, Msb,) He was liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous: (K:) or he affected, or constrained himself, to be generous: (Msb:) or he gave without being asked, to preserve the receiver from the ignominy of asking: (MF:) or he gave what was meet to him to whom it was meet: (El-Karmánee, TA:) or he gave what was meet to him to whom it was meet, not for a compensation; so that it has a more special signification than OaHosana. (MF.) You say, jAd bimaAlihi [He was liberal, &c., with his property]: (S:) or jAd biAlmaAli he affected, or constrained himself, to be generous with the property. (Msb.) ― -b3- Hence, (Msb,) jAd binafosihi, (S, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (S, A,) inf. n. jawodN (TA) and juWuwdN, (S, TA,) (tropical:) He gave up his spirit, (A, Msb, TA,) at death; (S, Msb;) like as one gives away his property; said of one in the agony of death: (TA:) and (tropical:) he gave away his life, in war. (Msb.) And you say also, jaAdato nafosuhu (assumed tropical:) [His soul, or spirit, resigned itself, or departed]. (Msb in art. nfs.) ― -b4- jAd AlmaTaru, inf. n. jawodN, The rain was, or became, copious, or abundant. (S.) And jaAdati AlsRamaMCu, (A, Msb,) inf. n. jawodN, with fet-h, The sky rained. (Msb.) And jaAdati AlEayonu, inf. n. jawodN and juWuwdN, The eye shed many, or abundant, tears. (Lh, K.) ― -b5- jAd said of a horse, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (S,) inf. n. juwdapN (S, L, Msb, K) and jawodapN; (Msb, and some copies of the K;) and jwd↓, (A, L, K,) inf. n. tajowiydN; (TA;) and AjAd↓, (L,) and Oajowada↓; (L, K;) He became fleet, or swift, and excellent, (L,) SaAra raAYiEFA, (S, L, K, *) fiI Eadowihi in his running. (A, L, K.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce daAma, in art. dwm.] ― -b6- See also 4, in two places. ― -b7- jAd Uilayohi He inclined to him, or it. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jAdhu He overcame him in liberality, bounty, munificence, or generosity. (K.) See 3. ― -b2- jaAdahumo, aor. yajuwdu, inf. n. jawodN, It (rain) rained, or descended, upon them copiously, or abundantly. (L.) And jiyduwA They were rained upon with a copious, or an abundant, rain. (L.) And jiydati AlOaroDu, (S, L, K,) inf. n. jawodN; (As, TA;) and Oujiydat↓; (K;) The earth, or land, was rained upon with a copious, or an abundant, rain: (S, L, K:) or, so that the moisture of the rain met that of the soil. (As, TA.) ― -b3- jiyda, (S, A, K,) aor. yujaAdu, (S, K,) inf. n. juwaAdN, (S, * K, * TA,) (assumed tropical:) He (a man, S, A) thirsted, or became affected by thirst: (S, A, K:) or thirsted vehemently: (accord. to an explanation of juwaAdN in the K:) or was at the point of death, or destruction; (K;) as though destruction rained upon him. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence,] UinRiI OujaAdu UilaIliqaAYika (tropical:) Verily I am affected with a longing desire to meet thee: (A:) or UinRiI laOujaAdu Uilayoka (K, TA [in the CK, erroneously, laAajAdu] (tropical:) Verily I am affected with a longing desire for thee, (K, TA,) i. e., to meet thee, (TA,) and am impelled towards thee: (K:) and yujaAduUilaI fulaAnapa (tropical:) He is affected with longing desire for such a female; like as you say yaZomaOu. (A.) One says also, jAdhu AlahawI (tropical:) Love affected him with longing desire, (XaAqahu, L, K, in the CK XAqRahu,) and overcame him. (K.) ― -b5- [Also, app., jyda, aor. yujaAdu, inf. n. juwaAdN, (as in a sense explained above,) (assumed tropical:) He became affected, or overcome, or distressed, (see majuwdN,) by drowsiness, or slumber: for] juwaAdN is syn. with nuEaAsN: (L, TA:) and you say, jAdhu AlnRuEaAsu (assumed tropical:) Drowsiness, or slumber, overcame him; (L;) as though sleep rained upon him. (TA.)

2 jawRada
2: see 4: ― -b2- and see also 1.

3 jAwdhu jAwdh jAwdp
3. jAwdhu He vied with him, or contended with him for superiority, in liberality, bounty, munificence, or generosity. (S, TA.) You say, jAwdhu fajaAdahu↓ He vied with him, or contended &c., in liberality, &c., and overcame him therein. (TA.)

4 AjAdhu OjAd OjAdh UjAdp AjAdh AjAdp
4. AjAdhu He made it good, goodly, approvable, or excellent; (S, A, * K;) as also Oajowadahu, (S, * K,) like as they said ATAl and ATwl, and AHAl and AHwl, and ATAb and ATyb, and AlAn and Alyn; (S;) and jwRdhu↓, (S, * A,) inf. n. tajowiydN. (S.) [Hence,] AjAdhu AlnRaqoda He gave him the cash, or ready money, good. (S, K.) And Oajadotuka vawobFA I gave thee a garment, or piece of cloth, that was good, goodly, or excellent; or in a good state. (A, TA.) ― -b2- He gave him a dirhem, or piece of silver. (K.) ― -b3- Oujiydati AlOaroDu: see 1. ＝ -A2- He, or it, slew him, or killed him. (L.) ＝ -A3- AjAd, (inf. n. UijaAdapN, Msb,) He said, gave utterance to, uttered, or expressed, what was good, approvable, or excellent; he said, or did, well, or excellently; OataI biAljayRidi (L, Msb, K) mino qawoli Oawo fiEolK; (Msb;) as also Oajowada; (L;) and jAd↓, inf. n. jawodapN. (L.) [You say, qaAla faOajaAda He said, and said well: and faEala faOajaAda He did, and did well.] And AjAd fiI Eamalihi, and Ajwd, He did well, or excellently, in his work. (L.) ― -b2- Said of a horse, and Ajwd likewise: see 1. ― -b3- Also He had with him a horse such as is termed jawaAd [i. e. fleet, or swift, and excellent]: (S:) or he became possessed of such a horse; (A, K;) as also Ajwd. (K.) ― -b4- OajaAdato She brought forth a child, or children, of liberal, bountiful, or generous, disposition. (A.) And AjAd biAlwaladi He begot the child, or children, of liberal, bountiful, or generous, disposition; (K;) and in like manner, bihi OabawaAhu jAd↓ [His two parents so engendered him]. (TA.)

5 tjwRd jAd tjwd
5. tjwRd He chose what was good, goodly, approvable, or excellent, among all things. (Ham p. 299.) He affected nicety, or refinement; he was, or became, nice, exquisite, refined, or scrupulously nice and exact; or he chose what was excellent, or best, to be done; and exceeded the usual bounds; fiI SanoEatihi in his work of art, or his manufacture; syn. tanawRaqa. (A, TA.) And tjwRd wabaAlaga fiI maToEamihi wamalobasihi [He was dainty, nice, exquisite, refined, or scrupulously nice and exact; or he chose what was excellent, or best; and exceeded the usual bounds; in his food and his
apparel]; (JK and K in art. nwq;) he was studious of his diet and apparel, always eating exquisite food and wearing sumptuous clothing. (TK in that art.) ＝ -A2- tjwRdhu: see 10. tajawRadotuhaA laka I chose, or selected, the best, or most excellent, (AlOajowada↓,) thereof for thee. (TA.)

6 tjAwdwA tjAwdwA
6. tjAwdwA They considered [or tried] which of them had the best argument, or plea, or allegation: (K, TA:) so says Aboo-Sa'eed on the authority of an Arab of the desert. (TA.) And yatajaAwaduwna AlHadiyva They consider, or see, [or try,] which of them will be best in narration, or talk, or discourse. (A.) ― -b2- [Also They vied, or contended together for superiority, in liberality, bounty, munificence, or generosity.]

10 AstjAdhu AstjAdh AstjAdp QstjAd QstjAdh
10. AstjAdhu He reckoned it, or esteemed it, good, goodly, approvable, or excellent: (S:) or he found it to be so: (K:) or he desired, or sought, that it might be so, (A, K,) and chose it, or selected it; (A;) as also tjwRdhu↓. (A.) You say also, Aisotajowada raOoyahu [He esteemed his judgment, or opinion, good: or found it to be so]. (TA in art. jzl.) ― -b2- He desired, or sought, or demanded, his liberality, bounty, munificence, or generosity. (K.) ― -b3- He desired, or sought, that he (a horse) might be such as is termed jawaAd [i. e. fleet, or swift, and excellent]. (K.) ＝ -A2- AstjAd It came or happened, well. (KL.)

jawodN jwd
jawodN Copious, or abundant, rain; (S, L, K;) as also jaAYidN↓: (S:) or rain that thoroughly irrigates everything: (M:) or rain that is not exceeded: (M, L, K:) accord. to some, who observe that the phrase, mentioned by Sb, OaxacotanaA biAljawodiwafawoqhaA [Thou hast assailed us with a storm of reproach or the like not to be exceeded, and with that which is above it,] is one of hyperbole and reproach. (M, L.) It is an inf. n. thus used as an epithet [and therefore applicable without variation to a fem. as to a masc. n., and to a dual and a pl. as to a sing. n.]: (L:) and is also pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of jaAYidN, (S, L, K,) like as SaHobN is of SaAHibN. (S, L.) You say maTarN jawodN [A copious, or an abundant, rain; &c.]: (L:) and saHaAbapN jawodN [A cloud yielding a copious, or an abundant, rain; &c.]: (IAar, L:) and haAjato lanaA samaMCN jawodN [A copious, or an abundant, rain, &c., became stirred up for us]: (S, K: *) and you also say, [contr. to the usage mentioned above, or as though jawodN were an epithet from jaAda, and this originally jawoda, like DaxomN from Daxuma, but used as a subst.,] maTorataAni jawodaAni [Two showers of rain, copious, or abundant, &c.]. (S, K.) tajaAwiydu↓, [app. signifying the same as jawodN used as a pl.,] occurring in the following verse of Sakhr El-Ghei,
yulaAEibu AlrRiyHa biAlEaSorayoni qaSoTaluhu
waAlwaAbiluwna watahotaAnu AltRajaAwiydi
[Its dust makes sport with the wind in the morning and evening, or night and day, and so do the violent showers of big drops, and the pouring of copious, or abundant, rains, &c.], (L, K, *) is a pl. having no sing.; (K;) or it may be so, like taEaAjiybu and taEaAXiybu and tabaAXiyru; or it may be pl. of tajowaAdN [an inf. n.]. (L.) You say also, AmaTari OaSaAbatohu tajaAwiydu↓ [Copious showers of rain fell upon him, or it]. (A.) ― -b2- See also jawaAdN.

jawodapN jwdh jwdp
jawodapN [an inf. n. of 1, (q. v.,) in two senses; as also juwdapN: and an inf. n. of un., signifying] A single affection of thirst; a thirsting. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also juwaAdN.

jaAdiIRN jAd jAdI jAdy jAdyy
jaAdiIRN Saffron. (S, K.)

jawaAdN jwAd
jawaAdN, used alike as masc. and fem., (S, K,) Liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous: (S, * K:) or one who affects, or constrains himself, to be generous: (Msb:) or who gives without being asked, to preserve the receiver from the ignominy of asking: (MF:) or who gives what is meet to him to whom it is meet: (El-Karmánee, TA:) or who gives what is meet to him to whom it is meet, not for a compensation; so that it has a more special signification than muHosinN: (MF:) pl. [of pauc., masc.,] OajowaAdN and (of mult., TA) juwodN, (S, A, K,) like as quculN is pl. of qacaAlN, but the w is made quiescent because it is an unsound letter, (S,) [in some copies of the K juwudN,] and OajaAwidu, (S, K,) contr. to analogy, (TA,) or OajaAwiydu, [reg., as pl. of OajowaAdN,] (A,) and juwadaMCu (S, K) and juwadapN, (CK, [in some copies of the K omitted,]) or juwodapN, or juwudapN, [written in the latter manner in a MS. copy of the K,] with p added to the [proper] pl. form [juwodN or juwudN], accord. to the doctrine of Sb: (TA:) juwodN is used as a fem. pl., (S, Msb,) and is like nuworN pl. of nawaArN. (S.) ― -b2- Also, applied alike to the male and the female, (S,) A courser; a fleet, or swift, and excellent, horse; (L;) a horse fleet, or swift, in running; or excellent in running, or in the motion of his legs; as also jawodN↓: (Bd in xxxviii. 30:) or that outstrips others: (Jel ib.:) i. q. raAYiEN: (S, L, K:) pl. jiyaAdN, (S, A, Bd, L, Msb, K,) which by rule should be jiwaAdN, like TiwaAlN, but this latter form has not been heard from the Arabs; (L;) or jiyaAdN is pl. of jawodN, or of jayRidN; (Bd ubi suprá;) and jawaAdN has also for its pl. OajoyaAdN, [a pl. of pauc., and irregular, or this is pl. of jayRdN, and therefore, though irregularly, retains the I substituted for w] (S, L,) and OajowaAdN, [also a pl. of pauc., but agreeable with rule, or this is pl. of jawodN,] (L,) and OajaAwiydu (S, L) is pl. of OajowaAdN. (L.) Hence, Oaqobala jawaAdFA (assumed tropical:) He came on, or advanced, like a horse that is termed jwAd: and sirotu Uilayohi jawaAdFA (assumed tropical:) I went to him, or it, like a horse that is so termed. (Mgh in art. gc.) You say also, EadaA EadowFA jawaAdFA He ran a long run. (A, TA.) And sironaA EuqobapF jawaAdFA, and Euqobatayoni jawaAdayoni, and EuqabFA jiyaAdFA (S, A) and OajowaAdFA, (A, TA,) We journeyed a long march or stage, and two long marches or stages, and long marches or stages. (S, A, TA.)

juwaAdN jwAd
juwaAdN [accord. to the TA inf. n. of jiyda, which see in two places,] (assumed tropical:) Thirst: (S, K:) or vehemence of thirst. (K.) ― -b2- Also, [accord. to the K jawodapN↓, but this is corrected in the TA,] (assumed tropical:) Drowsiness, or slumber. (TA.)

jaAYidN c
jaAYidN: see jawodN.

jayRidN jyd
jayRidN, originally of the measure fayoEilN, (S, Msb,) as the Basrees say, i. e. jayowidN, (Msb, TA,) the w being changed into I because of its being meksoor and preceded by I, and the augmentative I being then incorporated into it; (TA;) or, as the Koofees say, of the measure fayoEalN, like EayoTalN &c., because there is found no sound word of the measure fayoEilN except SayoqilN, a woman's name, and the unsound is accorded to the sound; or, as others say, of the measure faEiylN, [and so I find in one copy of the S,] originally jawiydN, the kesreh of the w being, accord. to them, suppressed because difficult of pronunciation, and the quiescent w and I thus coming together, [the latter receives the rejected kesreh, and] the w is changed into I and incorporated into the [augmentative] I; (Msb;) Good, goodly, approvable, or excellent; contr. of radi Io; (A, K;) applied to a thing, (S,) or a commodity, an article of household-goods, or the like, (A, Msb,) and a work, or performance: (TA:) pl. jiyaAdN (S, A, Msb, K) and jiyaAdaAtN, (K,) the latter a pl. pl., [i. e. pl. of jiyaAdN,] (TA,) and jayaAYidu, (S, K,) with hemz, [and, accord. to some,] contr. to analogy. (S.) [It is also applied to a man, meaning Excellent, or egregious, in some quality; sometimes, though very rarely, in a quality that is disapproved.]

Oajowadu c
Oajowadu [Better, and best; more, and most, goodly or approvable or excellent]: see 5. ― -b2- [More, and most, liberal, bountiful, munificent, or generous. Hence,] Oajowadu mino HaAtimK [More liberal, &c., than Hátim]: a prov. (Meyd.) ― -b3- [More, and most, fleet, or swift, and excellent; relating to a horse. Hence,] Oajowadu mina AljawaAdi AlmubirRi [More fleet, &c., than the courser that surpasses others]: a prov. (Meyd.)

tajaAwydu tjAwyd
tajaAwydu: see jawodN, in two places.

majuwdN mjwd
majuwdN A field, or garden, rained upon: (A:) [or rained upon copiously, or abundantly.] And OaroDN majowdapN Land rained upon with a copious, or an abundant, rain. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A man (S, A) affected with thirst: (S, A, K:) [or, with vehement thirst: (see juwaAdN:)] or at the point of death, or destruction. (K.) ― -b3- And [hence,] (tropical:) Affected with longing desire. (L.) ― -b4- Also (assumed tropical:) Overcome by drowsiness, or slumber: (TA:) or distressed by drowsiness, or slumber, &c. (Lh, L.)

mujiydN mjyd
mujiydN: see mijowaAdN. ― -b2- Also A man possessing a horse such as is termed jawaAdi [i. e. fleet, or swift, and excellent]: pl. majaAwiydu [by rule pl. of mijowaAdN, q. v.]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- HatofN mujiydN (tropical:) Present death. (K, TA.)

mijowaAdN mjwAd
mijowaAdN One who says, utters, or expresses, or who does, (K, TA,) much, or often, (TA,) what is good, goodly, approvable, or excellent; (K, TA;) as also mujiydN↓: (TA:) [or rather the latter is a simple, not an intensive, epithet:] the former is applied to a poet, (S, A, K,) as syn. with the latter, (K,) or as meaning who says, or utters, much, or often, what is good, or excellent:
(S:) and both are applied to a workman, or an artificer: pl. of the former majaAwiydu. (A.)

juwcaAbN c
juwcaAbN: see art. jcb.

1 jaAra jAr jAry
1. jaAra, aor. yajuwru, (TA,) inf. n. jaworN, (S, A, K,) He declined, or deviated, from the right course; (S, A;) and so jArEani AlqaSodi: (A:) he wandered from the right way: (TA:) he pursued a wrong course: (K:) or he left the right way in journeying: and it (anything) declined. (TA.) You say also, jAr Eani AlTRiriyqi He declined, or deviated, from the road, or way. (S, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- And jAr, (S, Mgh, Msb,) aor. as above, (Msb,) and so the inf. n., (Mgh, Msb, K,) He acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically, (S, * Mgh, Msb, K,) Ealayohi against him, (S, TA,) fiI Hukomihi in his judgment, (Msb,) or fiI AlHukomi in judgment. (S, TA.) ― -b3- jArti AlOaroDu (tropical:) The plants, or herbage, of the land grew tall: (A, TA:) and so jaOarat. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 10.

2 jwRrhu jwr jwrh jwrp
2. jwRrhu, (S, A, K,) inf. n. tajowiyrN, (S,) He attributed, or imputed, to him, or charged him with, or accused him of, wrongful, unjust, injurious, or tyrannical, conduct; (S, K;) contr. of EadRalahu. (A.) ＝ -A2- He prostrated him (S, K) by a blow, (S,) or by a thrust of a spear or the like; from jAr “he, or it, declined;”; (A;) like kawRarahu. (S.) ― -b2- He threw it down, (TA,) and overturned it; (K, TA;) namely, a building, and a tent, &c.: (TA:) he took it to pieces; namely, a tent. (A.)

3 jAwirhu jAwrh jAwrp
3. jAwirhu, inf. n. mujaAwarapN and jiwaArN (S, Msb, K) and juwaArN↓, (S, M, and some copies of the K,) or the last is a simple subst., (Msb,) and jawaArN↓, (M, and so in some copies of the K instead of juwaArN,) of which forms the second (jiwaArN) is more chaste than the third (S, TA) and than the fourth, as relating to the verb in the sense here following, though some disapprove of it, and assert the third and the fourth to be more chaste; (TA;) He became his jAr [or neighbour]; (K;) he lived in his neighbourhood, or near to him: (Msb, TA:) or he lived in a dwelling contiguous to his. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also jAwrhu, (TA,) inf. n. jiwaArN, (K,) and juwaArN↓ is said to be a quasi-inf. n., and more chaste than jiwaArN as relating to the verb in the sense here following; (TA;) He bound himself to him by a covenant to protect him. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And jAwr banRI fulaAnK, and fiI bnI flAn, inf. n. majaAwarapN and jiwaArN, He protected himself by a covenant with the sons of such a one; from mujaAwarapN signifying the “ living near. ” (TA.) ― -b4- And jAwr, inf. n. mujaAwarapN, i. q. AiEotakafa fiI masojidK [He confined himself in a mosque, or place of worship, during a period of days and nights, or at least during one whole day, fasting from daybreak to sunset, and occupying himself in prayer and religious meditation, without any interruption by affairs distracting the mind from devotion and not pressing]. (S, K.) But jAwr bimakRapa, and biAlmadiynapi, signifies absolutely He abode in Mekkeh, and El-Medeeneh; not necessarily implying conformity with the conditions of AiEotikaAf required by the law [though generally meaning for the purpose of study: and so in the neighbourhood of the great collegiate mosque called the Azhar, in Cairo: so that the term mujaAwirN↓ means a student of Mekkeh &c.]. (TA.)

4 AjArhu OjAr OjArh OjArp UjArp AjArh AjArp jArI
4. AjArhu, (S, A, &c.,) inf. n. UijaArapN (Mgh, K) and jaArapN↓, (Kr, K,) [or the latter is rather a quasi-inf. n., like TaAEapN from OaTaAEahu,] He protected him; granted him refuge; (K;) preserved, saved, rescued, or liberated, him; (S, A, Msb, K;) from (mino) wrongful, unjust, injurious, or tyrannical, treatment; (S, K;) from punishment; (S, A;) or from what he feared: (Msb:) he aided him; succoured him; delivered him from evil: the Oa having a privative effect. (Mgh.) It is said of God, yujiyru walaA yujaAru Ealayohi He protects, but none is protected against him. (TA.) And in the Kur [lxxii. 22], qulo UinRiI lano yujiyraniI mina QllRehi OaHadN Verily none will protect me against God. (TA.) ― -b2- AjAr AlmataAEa He put the household-goods, or commodities, into the repository, (K, TA,) and so preserved them from being lost. (TA.) ― -b3- It is said [of God] in a trad., yujiyru bayona AlbuHuwri He makes a division between the seas, and prevents one from mixing with another and encroaching upon it. (TA.)

5 tjwRr jAr tjwr
5. tjwRr He became prostrated; (S;) he fell down; (K;) by reason of a blow. (S, TA.) ― -b2- It (a building, TA) became thrown down, or demolished. (K.) ― -b3- He (a man, TA) laid himself down on his side (K) upon his bed. (TA.)

6 tajaAwaruwA jAwr tjAwr tjAwrwA
6. tajaAwaruwA and AijotawaruwA↓ (S, K) are syn., (S,) signifying They became mutual neighbours; they lived near together: (K, * TA:) the [radical] w in the latter verb remaining unaltered because this verb is syn. with one in which the w must preserve its original form on account of the quiescence of the preceding letter, namely, tjAwrwA, (S, TA,) and to show that it is syn. therewith: but AijotaAruwA also occurs. (TA.) ― -b2- [Also They bound themselves by a covenant to protect one another.]

8 Uijotawara
8: see 6.

10 AstjAr AstjAr QstjAr
10. AstjAr and jaAra↓, (K,) the latter like jaArN as syn. with musotajiyrN, (TA,) He sought, desired, or asked, to be protected; to be granted refuge; to be preserved, saved, rescued, or liberated. (K.) And AstjArhu He desired him, or asked him, to preserve, save, rescue, or deliver, him, (S, A, Msb,) mino fulaAnK from such a one. (S.) And AstjAr bihi He had recourse to him for refuge, protection, or preservation; he sought his protection. (TA.)

jaArN jAr jAry
jaArN A neighbour; one who lives near to another; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) one who lives in the next tent or house: (IAar, Th, T, Msb:) pl. [of mult.] jiyraAnN (Msb, K) [and jiwaArN (a pl. not of unfrequent occurrence, and mentioned by Freytag as used by El-Mutanebbee,)] and [of pauc.] jiyrapN and OajowaArN; (K;) like qaAEN, pl. qiyEaAnN and qiyEapN and OaqowaAEN, the only similar instance: (TA:) fem. with p. (Mgh.) AljaAru cuw AlqurobaI [in the Kur iv. 40] is The relation, or kinsman, who is abiding in one's neighbourhood: or who is abiding in one town or district or the like while thou art in another, and who has that title to respect which belongs to nearness of relationship: (TA:) or the near neighbour: (Bd, Jel:) or the near relation: (Jel:) or he who is near, and connected, by relationship or religion. (Bd.) jaAru Aljanobi: and AljaAru Aljunubu and jaAru Aljunubi: see art. jnb. jaArN nifRiyjN A stranger [who has become one's neighbour]. (TA.) ― -b2- A person whom one protects from wrongful, unjust, injurious, or tyrannical, treatment. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) ― -b3- One who seeks, or asks, protection (Msb, K) of another: jaAruka signifying he who seeks thy protection. (TA.) ― -b4- A protector; (A, Mgh, Msb, K;) one who protects another from that which he fears; (Msb;) one who grants refuge, or protects, or preserves. (AHeyth.) mino celika AlOamori humo jaArapN↓ They are protectors from that thing, is a phrase mentioned by Th, respecting which ISd says, I know not how this is, unless the sing. be supposed to be originally jaAYirN, so as to have a pl. of the measure faEalapN [as jaArapN is originally jawarapN]. (TA.) ― -b5- An aider, or assister. (IAar, Msb, K.) ― -b6- A confederate. (IAar, Msb, K.) ― -b7- A woman's husband. (Msb, K.) ― -b8- A man's wife; (Msb;) as also jaArapN↓: (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) or the latter, the object of his love: (M:) and the latter also, a woman's fellow-wife; (Mgh, Msb, TA;) so called because the term DarRapN is disliked, (Mgh, Msb,) as being of evil omen. (Mgh.) ― -b9- A partner who has not divided with his partner: so in the trad. AljaAru OaHaqRu biSaqabihi [explained in art. Sqb]; as is shown by another trad. (Az, Msb.) ― -b10- A partner, or sharer, (Msb, K,) in immoveable property, such as land and houses, (Msb, TA,) and in merchandise, (K, TA,) whether he divide the property with the other or not, (Msb,) or whether he be partner in the whole or only in part. (TA.) ― -b11- One who divides with another. (IAar, K.) ― -b12- (tropical:) The froj [or pudendum] of a woman: and (tropical:) The anus; as also jaArapN↓. (IAar, K, TA.) ― -b13- The part (IAar, K) of the sea-shore (IAar) that is near to the places where people have alighted and taken up their abode. (IAar, K.)

jaworN jwr jwrp
jaworN, an inf. n. used as an epithet, (TA,) i. q. jaAYirN↓; (K, TA;) i. e. Declining, or deviating, from the right course: and acting wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically: (TA:) pl. [of the latter], applied to men, jawarapN↓, (K,) in which the w remains unaltered contr. to rule, (TA,) and jaArapN↓, (A, K,) as in all the copies of the K, but some substitute for it, as a correction, juwarapN↓, [found in a copy of the A,] which, however, requires consideration, (TA,) and jaAYiruwna. (K.) You say TariyqN jaworN A road, or way, deviating from the right course. (TA.) And huwa jaworN Eano TariyqinaA He is declining, or deviating, from our way. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, for cuw jawor, meaning Wronged, or unjustly treated, by the judge.
(Mgh from a trad.) ― -b3- Einodahu mina AlmaAli Aljaworu (tropical:) He possesses, of property, an extraordinary abundance. (A, TA.) See also jiwarRN.

jaArapN jAr jArh jArp
jaArapN: see jaArN, in three places: ＝ -A2- and jaworN: ＝ -A3- and see also 4.

jawarapN jwr jwrh jwrp
jawarapN and juwarapN: see jaworN.

UinRahu laHasanu Aljiyrapi Anh lHsn Aljyrh Anh lHsn Aljyrp
UinRahu laHasanu Aljiyrapi Verily he is good in respect of the mode, or manner, of jiwaAr [i. e. living as a neighbour, or binding himself by covenant to protect others]. (TA.)

jiwarRN jwr jwrp
jiwarRN A rain accompanied by vehement thunder: (K:) or by a vehement sound of thunder: (S:) or a copious rain; as also jaOorN and juWarN; (K in art. jOr;) and, accord. to As, juWaArN: (TA:) and an exceedingly great torrent. (TA. [In this last sense written in a copy of the A jaworN↓, and there said to be tropical.]) See jawaArN: and see also art. jr. ― -b2- You say also baAzilN jiwarRN (S) [app. meaning A camel nine years old that brays loudly: or] hard and strong: and baEiyrN jiwarRN a bulky camel. (TA.)

jawaArN jAryp jwAr
jawaArN: see 3. ＝ -A2- Also The part of the exterior court or yard of a house that is coextensive with the house. (K, * TA.) ＝ -A3- Abundant and deep water. (K.) Whence jiwarRN↓ applied to rain. (TA.) ＝ -A4- Ships: a dial. var. of jawaArK; on the authority of Sá'id, (K,) surnamed Abu-l-'Alà: (TA:) said in the K to be strange; but similar instances are well known. (MF.)

juwaArN jAryp jwAr
juwaArN: see 3, in two places. ― -b2- Also, and jiwaArN↓, or the latter is only an inf. n., The covenant between two parties by which either is bound to protect the other. (TA.)

jiwaArN jAryp jwAr
jiwaArN: see what next precedes. ＝ -A2- [Also a pl. of jaArN.]

jaAYirN c
jaAYirN: see jaworN. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) Wide and big; applied to a [bucket of the kind called] garob: and so, with p, applied to a [skin of the kind called] qirobap. (A, TA.)

mujawRarN mjwr
mujawRarN [as meaning Thrown down, or overturned,] occurs in the following prov.:
yawomN biyawomi AlHafaDi AlmujawRari
[A day for a day of the household-goods (or, accord. to the TA, the hair-cloth tent) thrown down, or overturned]: applied in the case of rejoicing at a calamity befalling another: a man had an aged paternal uncle, and used continually to go into the latter's tent, or house, and throw down his household-goods, one upon another; and when he himself grew old, sons of a brother of his did to him as he had done to his paternal uncle; wherefore he said thus, meaning, this is for what I did to my paternal uncle. (K.)

mujaAwirN mjAwr
mujaAwirN: see 3, last sentence.

1 jaAza AlmawoDiEa
3 4
1. jaAza AlmawoDiEa, (S, K,) or AlmakaAna, (A, Mgh, Msb,) aor. yajuwzu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. jawaAzN (S, Msb, K) and jawozN and juWuwzN and majaAzN, (K,) He went, or passed, in, or along, the place, and left it behind; (Mgh, K;) [whether this be meant for one signification or two, does not appear; but in either case it is evident that one signification is he passed through, or over, or along, and beyond, the place; and this signification is of frequent occurrence;] as also jAz bihi; (K;) and AjAzhu↓; (Mgh;) and jAwzhu↓, (Mgh, K,) inf. n. jiwaAzN; (K, TA; in the CK jawaAzN;) and tjAwzhu↓; (Mgh;) lit., he traversed, or crossed, its jawoz, i. e., middle, and passed through it: (Mgh:) or he went, or passed, in, or along, the place; (As, S, A, Msb, TA;) as also jAz bihi, and jAwzhu↓, (TA,) and AjAzhu↓, (A,) and AjtAzhu↓: (S: [so it appears from its being said that AijotiyaAzN is syn. with suluwkN:]) and in like manner, AlTRariyaqa the road: (TA:) AlmwDEa jAwz↓ and jAzhu signify the same: (TA:) or AjAzhu↓ (As, S, Msb, K) and jAwzhu↓ and tjAwzhu↓ (A) signify he left it behind him, (As, S, A, K,) and traversed, or crossed, it; (As, S, A, Msb;) and jAwzhu↓ and bihi jAwz↓ also signify he left it behind. (TA.) You say, juzotu xilaAla AldRiyaAri, which is like jusotu [I passed amid, or among, the houses: (see the remarks on the letter z:) or I went to and fro amid, or among, the houses, in a hostile attack upon them: or went round about them]. (Ibn-Umm-Kásim, TA.) And juzotu bikacaA, i. e., bihi Aijotazotu↓ [I passed by, and beyond, such a thing]. (TA.) And jAz Ealayohi He passed by him, or it; syn. marRa bihi, and AimotarRa bihi and Ealayohi. (M and K in art. mr.) And jaAzahu He passed, or crossed, over it. (L.) jAz and AjAz↓ are syn. [in this last sense]. (TA.) You say, AlSRiraATi OaEaAnaka QllRehu EalaI UijaAzapi↓ (A, TA) May God aid thee [to pass, or cross, over, or] to pass along, and to leave behind thee, the Sirát. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. respecting the Sirát, faOakuwnu OanaA Ealayohi waOumRatiI OawRala mano yujiyzu↓ [And I, with my people, shall be the first who will pass over it]: yjyz being here syn. with yajuwzu. (TA.) ― -b2- juzotu AlXRaIoCa UilaI gayorihi: see 3. ― -b3- jAz AldRirohamu fatajawRazahu↓ [The piece of money passed, or was current, and he accepted it as current: in the TA written jAz Aldrhm ktjwzh, and without any syll. signs; but that the reading which I have adopted is right appears from what immediately follows:] a poet says,
wazuyRafu
[Pieces of money whereof there are current and bad]: and Lh mentions the saying, lamo Oara AlnRafaqapa tajuwzu bimakaAnK kamaA tajuwzu bimakRapa [I have not seen money for expenses pass away in a place as it passes away in Mekkeh]: ISd says, He has not explained it, but I think that the meaning is tanofuqu. (TA.) ― -b4- jAz AlXRaIoCu, inf. n. jawaAzN, The thing was, or became, allowable; it passed for lawful: as though it kept the middle (jawoz) of the road. (TA.) You say, jaAza AlbayoEu, and AlnRikaAHu, (A, Mgh,) and AlEaqodu wagayoruhu, (Msb,) [The sale, and the marriage, and the contract, or other thing, was, or became, allowable; or] passed as right, sound, valid, or good [in law:] (Msb:) or had effect. (Mgh.) [And jAz lahu Oano yafoEala kacaA It was allowable to him to do so. And yajuwzu Oano yakuwna kacaA It may be so; or such a thing may be.] ＝ -A2- jaAzahu in the sense of AjAzhu: see 4, second sentence, in two places.

2 jawRaza
2: see 4, in nine places.

3 jAwzhu c and jAwz bihi
3. jAwzhu jAwz bihi, inf. n. jiwaAzN: see 1, in six places. ― -b2- jAwz AlHadRa, and Alqadora, inf. n. mujaAwazapN; and so tjAwz↓, alone; He exceeded, or transgressed, the proper bound, or limit, or measure; acted extravagantly, exorbitantly, or immoderately: he, or it, was, or became, excessive, extravagant, exorbitant, or immoderate. (The Lexicons &c. passim.) ― -b3- jaAwazotu AlXRaIoCi OilaI gayorihi (S, Msb *) I passed from the thing [to another thing]; (Msb;) as also tajaAwazotuhu↓; (S, Msb;) i. q. juzotuhu↓. (S.) ― -b4- jAwz Eano canobihi: see 6. ― -b5- [Hence, app.,] kaAna mino xuluqiI AljiwaAzu It was of my disposition to be easy, or facile, in selling and demanding. (TA from a trad.) ＝ -A2- jAwz bihi: see 4, in two places.

4 AjAz c and AjAzhu
4. AjAz AjAzhu: see 1, in six places. ＝ -A2- AjAzhu He made him to go, or pass along; as also jaAzahu↓: (TA:) he made him to pass through, or over, or along and beyond: (S, IF, Msb, K;) as also [bihi jAwz↓, as will be shown by an ex. below, and jwRzhu↓, and] jaAzahu↓, for which we find jAwzhu incorrectly substituted in the K. (TA.) A rájiz says,
xalRuwA AlTRariyqa Eano OabiI sayRaAraho
HatRaI yujiyza saAlimFA HimaAraho
[Leave ye the road to Aboo-Seiyárah until he make his ass to pass through, or over, safely]. (S.) And it is said in the Kur [vii. 134, and x. 90], bibaniI UisoraAYiyla AlbaHora wajaAwazonaA↓ [And we made the Children of Israel to pass through the sea]. (TA.) You say also lahumo Uibilahumo jawRaza↓, inf. n. tajowiyzN, He led for them their camels one by one until they passed. (K.) ― -b2- [He made it to pass, or be current; as also jwRzhu↓: as in the following phrases.] Oajazotu EalaI Qsomihi i. q. jaEalotuhu jaAYizFA [I made his name to pass, or be current, by stamping money with it]: (ISk, S, TA:) and Darabotu [I coined, or minted, money in his name]. (ISd, TA.) And AlDRarRaAbu AldRaraAhima jwRz↓, inf. n. tajowiyzN, [The coiner, or minter,] made the dirhems, or pieces of money, to pass, or be current. (Mgh.) ― -b3- He made it, or held it, to be allowable, or to pass for lawful; he allowed it, or permitted it; (S, K, TA;) as also jwRzhu↓: (S, TA:) syn. sawRaga: (S, K:) and syn. of UijaAzapN, [the inf. n. of the former verb,] UiconN. (K, TA: omitted in the CK.) You say, AjAz lahu maA SanaEa, (S, K, *) and lh jwRz↓, (S,) He made, or held, what he did to be allowable, &c. (S, K.) And AlEaqolu hecaA mimRaA laA yujuwRizuhu↓ [This is of the things which reason will not allow]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- [He granted him the authority or degree of a licentiate in some one or more of the various departments of learning, for the instruction of others therein;] he
granted him a license with respect to the matters that he had related and heard [from other learned men, to teach the same]. (TA.) You say also, AjAz lifulaAnK jamiyEa masomuwEaAtihi mino maXaAYixihi [He ters which he had heard from his sheykhs, to teach the same to others]. (TA.) The licentiate is termed mujaAzN↓: and the matters which he relates are termed mujaAzaAtN↓.
