(TA.) ― -b5- AjAz AlbayoEa, (A, Mgh, K,) and AlnRikaAHa, (A, Mgh,) and AlEaqoda, (Msb,) He (the judge, A, Mgh) made the sale, (A, Mgh, K,) and the marriage, (A, Mgh,) and the contract, (Msb,) to have effect; he executed or performed it; (Mgh, Msb K;) lahu for him: (K:) he decreed it. (Mgh.) And [in like manner] AjAz raOoyahu, and jwRzhu↓, He made his judgment, or opinion, to have effect; he executed or performed it. (K.) Hence the saying, in a trad. of Aboo-Dharr, qabola Oano yujayzuwA EalaIRa, i. e., Before they slay me, and execute your order upon me. (TA.) ＝ -A3- OajaAzaniI (S, K *) (tropical:) He gave me water for, (S,) or he watered [for me], (K,) my land, or my beasts. (S, K.) And Uibilahu jwRz↓, (K,) inf. n. tajowiyzN, (TA,) He watered his camels. (K.) And AjAz Alwafoda He gave to the party who came as envoys, or the like, the quantity of water sufficient to pass therewith from one watering-place to another. (TA.) And OajaAzahu maMCF yajuwzu bihi AlTRariyqa (assumed tropical:) He gave him water wherewith to travel the road. (A.) And OajizoniI maMCF Give thou me some water that I may go my way, and pass from thee. (Aboo-Bekr, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (Aboo-Bekr, TA,) AjAzhu bijaAYizapK, (Aboo-Bekr, TA,) and AjAzhu bijaAYizapK saniyRapK, (S, A,) (assumed tropical:) He (the Sultán) gave him a gift, or present, (Aboo-Bekr, TA,) and he gave him a gift, or present, of high estimation. (S, A. *) Or the origin of the expression was this: Katan the son of 'Owf, of the tribe of Benoo-Hilál-Ibn-'Ámir-Ibn-Saasa'ah, gave the government of Fáris to 'Abd-Allah Ibn- 'Abbás; and El-Ahnaf passing by him with his army on an expedition to Khurásán, he waited for them upon a bridge, and said, Oajiyzuwhumo [Make ye them to pass over]; and he began to mention the lineage of each man and to give him according to his rank: (S:) or from the fact that a certain commander, having a river between him and an opposing force, said, mano jaAza hecaA AlnRahora falahu kacaA [Whoso passeth this river shall have such a thing]; and whenever one passed over, he received a jaAYizap. (TA.) You say also, OajaAzahu, meaning (assumed tropical:) He gave him. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., OajiyzuwA Alwafoda binaHowi maA kunotu Oujiyzuhumo bihi Give ye to the party who come as envoys, or the like, a similar jaAYizap to that which I used to give them. (TA.)

5 tjwRz AllRayolu jAz AlmwDE
5. tjwRz AllRayolu The darkness of the night cleared away. (A.) ＝ -A2- tjwRz fiI SalaAtihi He relaxed, or remitted, in his prayer; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) and so in other things; (A;) and abridged it; and was quick in it: said to be from Aljawozu “the act of traversing, and going, or passing along:” (TA:) or did less than was sufficient in it. (Msb.) ― -b2- Hence, tjwRz fiI Oaxoci AldRaraAhimi, (A, Mgh,) or tjwRz AldRaraAhima, (K,) He accepted the dirhems, or pieces of money, as current; did not reject them: (A, Mgh:) see 1: or he accepted them as they were, or notwithstanding what was in them: (Lth, TA:) or he accepted them notwithstanding what was intermixed with them, (K, TA,) [of bad money,] concealed therein, and notwithstanding their fewness. (TA.) In the phrase AltRajawRuzu biduwni AlHaqRi [The accepting less than what was due], the inf. n. is made trans. by means of bi because it implies the meaning of AlrRiDaA [which is made trans. by the same means]. (Mgh.) tajaAwazo↓ also occurs in the sense of tajawRazo in a trad. of Ibn-Rawáhah: hecaA laka watajaAwazo fiI Alqasomi This is thine, or for thee, and be thou remiss, or not extreme, in, or with respect to, the division: and is allowable, though we have not heard it. (Mgh.) You say also, tajawRaza fiI hecaA AlOamori maA lamo yatajawRazo fiI gayorihi He bore patiently, or with silence and forgiveness, and with feigned neglect, or connivance, in this affair, or case, what he did not so bear in another. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- See also 6, in three places. ＝ -A3- tjwRz fiI kalaAmihi He made use of a trope, or tropes, in his speech. (S, K.) [See majaAzN, below.]

6 tjAwzhu jAwz tjAwz tjAwzh tjAwzp
6. tjAwzhu: see 1, first sentence: and see also 3. ＝ -A2- tjAwz i. q. OaforaTa, [i.e., jAwz AlHadRa, explained above,] fiyhi in it, or with respect to it. (K. See 3.) ― -b2- tjAwz Eanohu, (S, A, Mgh, Msb,) and tjwRz↓; (S, A, Mgh;) and tjAwzEano canobihi, (A, K,) and tjwRz↓, and jAwz↓; (K;) He (God, S, A, or a man, Msb) passed him by, or over, without punishing him; or forgave him; (S, A, Mgh, Msb;) namely, an evil-doer; (A, Mgh, Msb;) and He passed by, or over, without punishing, or forgave, his sin or offence. (A, K. *) You say, AallRehumRa tajaAwazo EanRiI, and EanRiI tajawRazo↓, O God, pass me by, or over, without punishing me; or forgive me. (S, A.) tjAwz Eanohu, followed by a noun in the accus. case, also signifies He forgave him a thing. (L.) And the same alone, He feigned himself neglectful of it; he connived at it. (K.) ― -b3- [Also, this last phrase alone, He transcended it.] ― -b4- tajaAwazo fiI Alqasomi: see 5.

8 AjtAzhu OjtAzh AjtAzh AjtAzp QjtAz QjtAzh
8. AjtAzhu: and AjtAz bihi: see 1.

10 AstjAzhu AstjAzh AstjAzp QstjAz QstjAzh
10. AstjAzhu He asked, or demanded, of him permission. (K, * TA.) ― -b2- He asked, or demanded, of him [the authority or degree of a licentiate; i. e.,] a license with respect to the matters that he had related and heard [from other learned men, to teach the same]. (TA.) [See 4.] ＝ -A2- (tropical:) He asked, or demanded, of him (S, K) water for, (S,) or to water [for him], (K,) his land, or his beasts. (S, K.) ＝ -A3- He approved it. (Har p. 326.)

jawozN jwz
jawozN The middle (S, K) of a thing, (K,) or of anything; (S;) [as, for instance,] of a desert, (A,) and of a camel, (TA,) and of the night: (A, TA:) and the main part of a thing, (K,) or of the night: (TA:) pl. OajowaAzN; (Sb, S, A;) beside which it has no other. (Sb.) ＝ -A2- [The walnut; or walnuts;] a well-known fruit, (K,) which is eaten: (Msb:) a Persian word, (S,) arabicized; (S, Msb, K;) originally Gawozo: (Mgh, Msb, K:) n. un. jawozapN: (S, TA:) pl. jawozaAtN: (S, K, TA: in the CK jawozaAnN:) the tree thereof abounds in the land of the Arabs, in the province of El-Yemen, where it bears fruit and is cultivated; and in the Sarawát (AlsRarawaAt) are trees thereof, which are not cultivated: the wood thereof is characterized by hardness and strength. (AHn. TA.) ― -b2- jawozu bawRay, (K,) or jawozu bawRaA, with the short alif, as heard from the physicians, in Persian Gawozi buwyaA, (Mgh, under the letter b,) [vulgarly called jawozu AlTRiybi, The nutmeg;] a certain medicine; (K;) it is of the size of the gall-nut (EafoS), easily broken, with a thin coat, (Mgh, TA,) having a pleasant odour, (Mgh,) or a pleasant and sharp odour; and the best kind is the red, with a black coat, and heavy: (TA:) it is good for the [affection of the face termed] laqowap, strengthens the stomach and heart, and removes cold. (Mgh.) ― -b3- jawozu maAvilK [The datura stramonium, or thorn-apple;] also a certain medicine; (K;) having the property of producing torpor; resembling the jawozu AlqaIoCi (see what follows); having upon it small, thick thorns; and its seed is like that of the OutorujR [or citror.]. (TA.) ― -b4- jawozu AlqRIoCi [Nux vomica;] also a certain medicine, (K,) having a power similar to that of the white xarobaq [or hellebore]. (TA.) ― -b5- jawozu Alhinodi [The cocoa-nut;] what is commonly called the naArajiyl. (TA.)

jawozapN jwz jwzh jwzp
jawozapN: see jaAYizapN, in four places. ＝ -A2- Also n. un. of jawozN [q. v.].

jiyzapN jyzh jyzp
jiyzapN: see jaAYizapN.

AljawozaMCu AljwzMC
AljawozaMCu A certain constellation (najomN); (S;) a certain sign of the Zodiac; (K;) [namely, Gemini;] said to cross the jawoz (i. e. the middle, TA) of the sky; (S, TA;) for which reason it is [asserted to be] thus called. (TA.) ― -b2- Also i. q. AljabRaAru [The constellation Orion]: (A and K in art. jbr:) it has three very bright stars disposed obliquely in the midst thereof, called by the Arabs AlnRaZomu, and niTaAqu AljawozaMCi, and faqaAru AljawozaMCi. (Har p. 456.)

jawaAzN jwAz
jawaAzN (assumed tropical:) The act of watering, or giving to drink: (S:) or a single watering of, or giving drink to, camels. (TA.) [See also jaAYizapN.] A rájiz says,
yaA SaAHiba QlomaMCi fadatoka nafosiI
EajRilo jawaAziy waOaqilRa HabosiI
[O master of the water (may my soul be thy ransom) hasten the watering of my camels, and make my detention little]. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The water with which beasts are watered, or with which seed-produce is watered: (AA, S, K:) [and] water which is given one that he may travel with it the road. (A, Mgh.) [See also jaAYizapN.] ― -b3- Hence, (Mgh,) (assumed tropical:) The traveller's pass, (A, Mgh, K,) given him to prevent any one's offering opposition to him: (A, Mgh:) pl. OajowizapN. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- The office, or authority, of a guardian and affiancer. (TA.)

jaAYizN c
jaAYizN [act. part. n. of jaAza, in all its senses]. ― -b2- Passing, or current, money. (Mgh.) See an ex. above, voce jaAza. [And hence,] jawaAYizu AlOaXoEaAri, and AlOamovaAli, (K, TA,) for the former of which we find, in some copies of the K, AlXRiEori, which is incorrect, (TA,) Verses, or poems, and proverbs, current from country to country, or from town to town. (K, TA.) ― -b3- Applied to a contract, [and a sale and a marriage, Allowable; passing for lawful;] passing as right, sound, valid, or good [in law]; having effect. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- [The beam of a house, or chamber, upon which rest the EawaAriD, or rafters;] that upon which are placed the extremities of the pieces of wood in the roof of a house or chamber; (AO, TA;) the palm-trunk, (S,) or piece of wood, which passes across between two walls, (K,) called in Persian tiyor, (S, K,) which is the sahom of the house or chamber: (S:) pl. [of pauc.] OajowizapN, (S, CK, TA,) in [some of] the copies of the K, incorrectly, OjowuzN, (TA,) [and both these are given in the CK,] and [of mult.] juwzaAnN (S, K) and jiyzaAnN (CK, but omitted in my MS. copy of the K and in the TA,) and jawaAYizu. (Seer, K.)

jaAYizapN c
jaAYizapN (assumed tropical:) A draught of water; (S, K;) as also jawozapN↓: (K:) or ↓the latter signifies a single watering, or giving of water to drink; (S, K; [see an ex. in art. Acn, conj. 2;]) or such as a man passes with from one person to another: and ↓both signify the quantity of water with which the traveller passes from one watering-place to another; as also jiyzapN↓. (TA.) It is said in a prov., vumRa yuWucRanu likulRi jaAbihK jawozapN↓, i. e., (assumed tropical:) For every one that comes to us for water is a single water-ing, or giving of water to drink; then he is repelled from the water: or, as in the M, then his ear is struck, to indicate to him that he has nothing more than that to receive from us. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (A, Mgh,) accord. to Aboo-Bekr, (TA,) [but see 4,] (assumed tropical:) A gift, or present: (Aboo-Bekr, S, Mgh, K:) pl. jawaAYizu. (S, A, Mgh.) ― -b3- Hence also, (Mgh,) (tropical:) Kindness and courtesy: (K:) or kindnesses and courtesy shown to those who come to one as envoys or the like: (Mgh:) or provisions for a day and a night given to a guest at his departure after entertainment for three days. (Mgh, TA.) It is said in a trad., AlDRiyaAfapu valaAvapu OayRaAmK wajaAYizatuhu yawomN walayolapN wamaA zaAda fahuwa SadaqapN, meaning, [The period of] the entertainment of a guest is three days, during the first of which the host shall take trouble to show him large kindness and courtesy, and on the second and third of which he shall offer him what he has at hand, not exceeding his usual custom; then he shall give him that wherewith to journey for the space of a day and a night; and what is after that shall be as an alms and an act of favour, which he may do if he please of neglect if he please. (TA.)

majaAzN mjAz mjAzy
majaAzN A way, road, or path, (S, K, TA,) which one travels from one side [or end] to the other; (K, TA;) as also majaAzapN↓. (TA.) You say, jaEala fulaAnN celika AlOamora majaAzFA UilaI HaAjatihi (assumed tropical:) Such a one made that thing a way to the attainment of his want. (S, TA.) nahorK majaAzapu↓ signifies A bridge. (A.) And majaAzapN↓ alone [also] signifies A road (TariyqapN) in a saboxap [or salt tract]. (K.) ― -b2- A privy, or place where one performs ablution; syn. mutabarRazN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A trope; a word, or phrase, used in a sense different from that which it was originally applied to denote, by reason of some analogy, or connexion, between the two senses; as, for instance, OasadN, properly signifying “ a lion, ” applied to “ a courageous man; ” (KT, &c.;) what passes beyond the meaning to which it is originally applied; (TA;) [being of the measure mafoEalN in the sense of the measure faAEilN;] contr. of HaqiyqapN. (K.) [This is also called majaAzN lugawiIRN, and majaAzN lugapF; to distinguish it from what is termed majaAzN EurofiIRN, and majaAzN EurofFA, which is A word, or phrase, so little used in a particular proper sense as to be, in that sense, conventionally regarded as tropical; as, for instance, daAbRapN in the sense of “ a man, ” or “ a human being; ” it being commonly applied to “ a beast, ” and especially to “ a horse ” or “ a mule ” or “ an ass. ”] A Haqiyqap, when little used, becomes what is termed majaAzN EurofFA. (Mz, 24th nwE.) The majaAz is either what is termed AisotiEaArapN [i. e. a metaphor] (as OasadN used as meaning “ a courageous man ”), or majaAzN murosalN [a loose trope] (as yadN used as meaning “ a benefit, ” “ benefaction, ” “ favour, ” or “ boon ”). (KT, &c.) [majaAzN also signifies A tropical meaning.]

mujaAzN mjAz mjAzy
mujaAzN: and mujaAzaAtN: see 4, in the middle of the paragraph.

mujiyzN mjyz
mujiyzN A commissioned agent of another; an executor appointed by a will; syn. wakiylN, and waSiIR; because he executes what he is ordered to do: so in the conventional language of the people of El-Koofeh: (Mgh:) or a slave who has received permission to traffic. (Mgh, K.) ― -b2- The guardian and affiancer [of a woman]; syn. waliIRN. (K.) You say, hecihi QmoraOapN layosa lahaA mujiyzN [This is a woman who has no guardian and affiancer]: and Shureyh is related to have said, UicaA OanokaHa QlomujiyzaAni faAlnRikaAHu liloOawRali [When the two guardians and affiancers give a woman in marriage, the marriage is the former's]. (TA.) ― -b3- The manager of the affairs of an orphan. (K.)

majaAzapN mjAz mjAzh mjAzp
majaAzapN: see majaAzN, in three places. ＝ -A2- OaroDN majaAzapN (S, A) A land containing trees of the jawoz [or walnut]: (S:) or a land (in the K, makaAn [a place], which is wrong, TA) abounding with jawoz. (A, K.)

majaAziIRN mjAz mjAzI mjAzy mjAzyy
[majaAziIRN Tropical.]

mujataAzN mjtAz
mujataAzN Going, or passing along. (K.) ― -b2- One who travels, or penetrates, along a road. (K.) ― -b3- One who loves to hasten, or outstrip. (K, TA.)

1 jaAsa jAs
1. jaAsa, aor. yajuwsu, (S, TA,) inf. n. jawosN, (A, K,) He sought for, or after, (Zj, S, A, K,) a thing, (Zj, A, K,) or news, or tidings, (S,) with the utmost of his endeavour. (Zj, A, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] jaAsuwA xilaAla AldRiyaAri, (S, A,) in the Kur [xvii. 5], (TA,) inf. n. as above, (S, A, K,) They went through the midst of the houses (taxalRaluwhaA), and sought for what was in them, as a man seeks for news, or tidings; as also AjtAswA↓: (S:) or they went to and fro among the houses, in a sudden attack: (A, K:) or the meaning in the Kur is, they slew you amid your houses; and HaAsuwA signifies the same; going and coming: (Fr, TA:) and, inf. n. as above, (K,) and jawasaAnN, (S, K,) they went round about (Zj, S, A, K) by night, (S,) among the houses, (Zj, A, K,) looking if any remained whom they had not slain, (Zj, TA,) or doing mischief: (A:) and AijotiyaAsN↓ signifies the same as jawasaAnN, (K, TA,) the going round about by night. (TA.) ― -b3- jiysa also signifies It (anything) was trodden: jawosN is said to be like dawosN: (TA:) and you say, jaMCa fulaAnN yajuwsu AlnRaAsa Such a one came stepping over the people; syn. yataxaTRaAhumo. (A, TA. *) And accord. to A' Obeyd, jusotuhu and Husotuhu both signify I came into it, and trod it; (xaAlaTotuhu wawaTiYotuhu;) meaning, any place. (TA.) You say also, jaAsahumu AlOasadu The lion trod upon them: or came into the midst of them, and did mischief among them. (TA; [in which the inf. n. of the verb in this sense is said to be jawosN and jawosaMCu: but the latter is probably a mistranscription for jawasaAnNu.])

8 Uijotawasa
8: see 1, in two places.

jawRaAsN jwAs
jawRaAsN One who treads upon everything: or who comes into the midst of a people, and does mischief among them. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) The lion. (K, TA.) And in like manner it is applied to a man. (TA.)

jawosaqN jwsq
jawosaqN i. q. qaSorN [A palace: or a pavilion, or kind of building wholly or for the most. part isolated, sometimes on the top of a larger building, i. e., a belvedere, and sometimes projecting from a larger building, and generally consisting of one room if forming a part of a larger building]: (S, K, and Ham p. 823:) or a fortress; syn. HiSonN: (M, IB, TA:) or [a building] resembling a HiSon: (M:) an arabicized word, (Lth, JK, S, M,) from the Persian kuwXok: (TA:) its primary meaning is a HiSon in a state of demolition; and a ruined qaSor: pl. jawaAsiqu and jawaAsiyqu; the latter formed by giving fulness of sound to the kesreh, or by poetic license. (Ham ubi suprà.) There were, in the Karáfeh, [the great burial-ground of the Egyptian metropolis,] numerous quSuwr, i. e., what are called jwAsq, having belvederes (manaAZir) and gardens: but most of the jwAsq were without gardens and without a well; being lofty belvederes: all of them were called quSuwr. (El-Makreezee's “ Khitat, ” ii. 453.)

jawoXN c
jawoXN The breast; (S, A, K;) as also juWoXuwXN (S) and jawoXN: (S, A:) and [particularly] that
of a man; as also juwXN↓: (K:) and the middle of a man. (K.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) The fore part (Sador) of the night; like jaroXN; (S;) and so juwXN↓: (TA:) or the middle thereof; (K;) as also jawozN: (AA:) and a great portion thereof: or of the latter part thereof: (K:) or a portion of the latter part thereof: (TA:) or from the time of a quarter to a third thereof. (T, TA.) You say, maDaI jawoXN mina AllRayoli (assumed tropical:) [A portion of the fore part, &c., of the night passed]. (S.)

juwXN c
juwXN: see above, in two places.

jawoXanN c
jawoXanN The breast: (IDrd, S, Mgh, K:) or the broad part of the middle of the breast: and the fore part of the body of a locust. (TA.) ― -b2- A coat of mail: (S, Mgh, K:) or mail with which the breast and the Hayozuwm [or parts adjoining the breast] are clad. (M, TA.) ― -b3- The middle of the night: (S, K:) and (so in the S, but in the K “ or ”) the fore part thereof: (S, K:) pl. jawaAXinu. (S.) You say, maDaI jawoXanN mina AllRayoli An early portion of the night passed: (S:) or [simply] a portion of the night. (M, TA.) It is a dial. var. of jawoXN, [in the first of the meanings explained above, and also as relating to the night,] although augmented. (TA.)

jawoXaniIRN c
jawoXaniIRN A manufacturer of coats of mail. (K.)

1 jaAEa jAE
1. jaAEa, (S, Msb, K,) aor. yajuwEu, (S,) inf. n. jawoEN, (Msb, K,) or juwEN, (S, so in two copies,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb, TA,) and majaAEapN, (S, K,) He was, or became, hungry; or empty in the belly; (TA;) contr. of XabiEa. (S, K, TA.) [See also juwEN below.] ― -b2- [Hence,] jaAEa Uilayohi, (K,) or jaAEa UilaI liqaAYihi, (M, TA,) (tropical:) He desired, (M, K, *) and longed, (K,) [as though hungering,] to meet with him; like EaTiXa. (M, K. *) And jaAEa UilaI maAlihi (tropical:) He longed for his property. (AZ.)

2 jawRaEa
2: see 4, in two places.

4 AjAEhu OjAE OjAEh UjAEp AjAEh AjAEp
4. AjAEhu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. UijaAEapN; (Msb;) and jwREhu↓, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. tajowiyEN; (Msb;) He constrained him to be hungry, or empty in the belly: (S, * K, TA:) or he debarred him from food and drink. (Msb.) It is said in a prov., OajiEo kalobaka yatobaEoka [Make thy dog to be hungry and he will follow thee]; (S, K;) meaning (assumed tropical:) constrain thou the ignoble to have recourse to thee, by want, in order that he may continue by thee; (K, * TA;) for if he be in no need of thee, he will leave thee: and for OajiEo, some say jawRiEo↓. (TA.)

5 tjwRE jAE jwE tjwE
5. tjwRE He made himself hungry, or empty in the belly, intentionally, or purposely. (S, K.) You say, tawaHRaXo lildRawaMCi and tajawRaEo lildRawaMCi, [Make thyself hungry, or make thy stomach empty of food and beverage, (see art. wHX,) or] abstain thou from eating the full quantity of food, for the purpose of taking medicine. (TA.)

10 AstjAE AstjAE
10. AstjAE He showed hunger. (KL, PS.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AisotijaAEapu AlEilomi (assumed tropical:) The being insatiable of knowledge. (TA.)

juwEN jwE
juwEN, a subst., (Msb, TA,) signifying Hunger; or emptiness of the belly; (TA;) contr. of XibaEN; (S, K, TA;) as also majaAEapN↓, [properly an inf. n.,] and majowaEapN↓, (K, TA,) and majuwEapN↓. (TA.) You say, juwEFA lahu wanuwEFA [May God decree hunger to him]: accord. to Sb, an instance of inf. ns. in the accus. case by reason of a verb understood: it is a form of imprecation: and the latter noun may not be put before the former, because it is a corroborative to it: (TA:) or, accord. to some, nuwEN means “ thirst. ” (S, &c., in art. nwE.) And EaAmu majaAEapK↓ and majowaEapK↓ (S, K) and majuwEapK↓ (TA) A year in which is hunger, or emptiness of the belly: (K, TA:) and EaAmu AlmajaAEapi↓ and AlmajuwEapi↓ [the year of hunger, &c.]: (Msb:) pl. majaAYiEu (K) and majaAwihu: as in the phrases OaSaAbatohumu AlmajaAwiEu [Cases of hunger, &c., befell them] and waqaEuwAfiI AlmajaAwiEi [They fell into cases of hunger, &c.]. (TA.) And AlrRaDaAEapu mina AlmajaAEapi↓, meaning The sucking which occasions interdiction [of marriage with the woman whose milk is sucked and certain of her relations] is that consequent upon hunger which is stopped by the milk in the time of infancy of the child; not when the child's hunger is only to be stopped by solid food. (Mgh.) [See also 1 in art. rDE.] And it is said in a prov., samanu kalobK bijuwEi Oaholihi, i. e. [The dog's becoming fat is] by reason of [the hunger of his owners occasioned by] murrain befalling the camels; (K, * TA;) his owners falling into hunger and distress and leanness: (TA:) or klb was the name of a certain man, who was an object of fear, wherefore he was asked for a pledge, and he pledged his family: then obtaining possession of the camels, or cattle, of the people to whom he had pledged his family, he drove them away, and left his family: (K, TA:) some relate this prov. differently, saying [samina kalobN “ a dog, ” or “ Kelb, ” “ became fat, ” and] bibuWosi Oaholihi [“ by reason of the distress of his owners, ” or “ his family ”]. (TA.) [See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 615.]

jawoEapN jwE jwEh jwEp
jawoEapN A single temporary affection of hunger. (S, TA.) A state of destitution and hunger of a tribe. (TA.)

jawoEaAnu jwEAn
jawoEaAnu: see the next paragraph.

jaAYiEN c
jaAYiEN and jawoEaAnu↓, (Msb, K, TA,) but not jayoEaAnu, [as the vulgar say,] for this a mistake, (TA,) Hungry; or empty in the belly: (K, * TA:) or debarred from food and drink: (Msb:) the fem. [of the former] is jaAYiEapN and [of the latter] jawoEaI: (Msb, K:) and the pl. [of the former] is juwRaEN (S, Msb, K) and juyRaEN, with the w changed into I, (L,) and [of the latter, or perhaps of both,] jiyaAEN (S, K) and jaAEapN (K * in art. swE) and jayaAEaI [with the w changed into I contr. to rule, if this be not a mistake for jiyaAEN, in which the w is changed into I by rule]. (Msb.) You say jaAYiEN naAYiEN; the latter word being an imitative sequent; (TA;) or, accord. to some, signifying “ thirsty. ” (S, &c., in art. nwE.) ― -b2- rajulN jaAYiEu Alqidori (tropical:) A man whose cookingpot is not full. (TA.) ― -b3- AimoraOapN jaAYiEapu AlwiXaAHi (tropical:) A woman slender in the [waist, or] belly. (K, * TA.) [See art. wXH.]

majaAEN mjAE
majaAEN [The space in which one becomes hungry]. You say, huwa minRiI EalaI qadori majaAEi AlXRaboEaAni, i. e., EalaI qadori maA yajuwEu AlXRaboEaAnu [He, or it, is distant from me as far as the space in which he who is satiated with food becomes hungry]: (O, K: *) and in like manner, EalaI qadori maEoTaXi AlrRayRaAni [as far as the space in which he who is satisfied with drink becomes thirsty]. (Z, TA.)

majaAEapN mjAEh mjAEp
majaAEapN: see juwEN, in four places.

majowaEapN mjwEh mjwEp
majowaEapN and majuwEapN: see juwEN, in five places.

musotajiyEN mstjyE
musotajiyEN A man (S) who always shows himself, or is seen, to be hungry: (S, A, O, K:) or, accord. to Aboo-Sa'eed, who is always eating one thing after another. (Sgh, L.)

1 jawafN Ojwf jwf
1. jawafN The being [hollow, or] wide and hollow within: (PS:) or the being empty, vacant, or void: an inf. n. of which the verb is of the class of taEiba [i. e. jaAfa, originally jawifa, like xaAfa, sec. pers. jifota, aor. yajaAfu]: (Msb:) the being wide, spacious, or ample: (K:) the inf. n., or source, whence XaIoCN Oajowafu. (S.) [See also 10.] ＝ -A2- jaAfahu, [aor. yajuwfu,] inf. n. jawofN, It reached his jawof [or inside, or interior, &c.]. (TA.) It (medicine) entered his jawof. (TA. [See also 8.]) And jaAfatohu AljiraAHapu The wound reached his jawof. (Msb.) ― -b2- TaEanahu fajaAfahu, and AjAfhu↓, He pierced him and pierced his jawof: (Mgh, Msb:) and jwRfhu↓, inf. n. tajowiyfN, he pierced him in his jawof. (TA.) jufotuhu biAlTRaEonapi, and AlTRaEonapa Oajafotuhu↓, I made the spear-wound, or the like, to reach his jawof. (Ks, A 'Obeyd, S, K.) jaAfa AlSRayoda He made the arrow to enter the jawof of the object of the chase. (TA.)

2 tajowiyfN tjwyf
2. tajowiyfN The making [a thing] hollow, or empty in the middle. (KL, PS.) You say, jwRfhu, inf. n. tajowiyfN, [He made it hollow; hollowed it out;] he made it to have a jawof. (Msb.) And of a thing that is mujawRaf, (S, K,) i. e. Ojowaf, (S,) you say, fiyhi tajowiyfN [In it is a hollowing out; meaning a hollow, in which sense tjwyf has a pl., namely, tajaAwiyfu]. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also 1.

4 Oajowafa
4: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- AjAf AlbaAba (tropical:) He shut, or closed, the door. (S, K, TA.) Hence, in a trad., waOajiyfuwA AlOabowaAa waOaTofiYuwA AlmaSaAbiyHa [And shut ye the doors, and extinguish the lamps]. (TA.)

5 tjwRf jwf tjwf
5. tjwRf It was, or became, hollow, or empty within. (KL.) ＝ -A2- tjwRfhu: see 8. ― -b2- tajawRafati AlxuwSapu
AlEarofaja The leaf was in the jawof [or inside] of the [plant called] Erfj, not having yet come forth. (S.)

8 AjtAfhu AjtAfh AjtAfp
8. AjtAfhu He entered its jawof [or inside, or interior; he entered into the midst of it]; as also tjwRfhu↓. (S, K.) [See an ex. in a verse of Lebeed, voce OaSolN: and see also 1.]

10 AstjAf 10 and Aisotajowafa
10. AstjAf Aisotajowafa It (a thing) became wide, spacious, or ample. (S, K.) [See also 1, first sentence.] ＝ -A2- AstjAfhu He found it (a place) to be Oajowaf [i. e. hollow, or empty within; or wide, spacious, or ample]. (O, L, K.)

jawofN Ojwf jwf
jawofN [A hollow; an interior empty, vacant, or void, space;] a vacancy: pl. OajowaAfN: this is the primary signification: then it was used in relation to a thing capable of being occupied and of being unoccupied; so as to be applied in the sense next following. (Msb.) ― -b2- The inside, or interior, (Msb, KL,) of a house [&c.]. (Msb.) ― -b3- [The midst, or middle, of a thing.] ― -b4- A low, or depressed, (S, K, TA,) and wide, (TA,) tract, or portion, of land, or ground: (S, K, TA:) what is wider than the XiEob; the [water-courses termed] tilaAE, and the valleys, flow into it; and it has jirafap [or abrupt, water-worn, banks]: sometimes it is wider than a valley, and deeper: and sometimes it is a plain, or soft, tract, that retains water: and sometimes it is completely round, so that it retains water: accord. to IAar, it signifies a valley: or, as some say, the interior (baTon) of a valley. (TA.) ― -b5- The belly, or abdomen, of a man: (S, K:) or, accord. to ISd, the interior of the belly: and the part upon which close the shoulder-blades and the upper arms and the ribs and the two flanks (AlSRuqolaAni): (TA:) the chest, or thorax; i. e., the part of the body that is separated from the baTon [or belly, or abdomen,] by the HijaAb [or diaphragm, or midriff]; containing the heart and its appertenances: (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán: ”) pl. as above. (TA.) See also jaAYifN. It is one of the words that are not used adverbially except with prepositions. (Sb, TA.) It is said in a trad., laA tanosawuA Aljawofa wamaA waEaI [Forget not ye the jwf and what it hath collected]; meaning what enters into it, of food and beverage: but some say that Aljwf here means the belly and the faroj [or vulva, or pudendum muliebre], together, which are also called AlOajowafaAni↓: and some say that the meaning is, the heart and what it hath retained, and kept in memory, of the knowledge of God. (A 'Obeyd, TA.) ― -b6- AlOajowaAfu is also applied by the people of El-Ghowr (K) and of El-Yemen (TA) to The tents (fasaATiyT) of their EumRaAl [or governors, or collectors of the poor-rates]. (K.) ― -b7- jawofu AllRayoli AlMxiru, occurring in a trad., means (assumed tropical:) The last third of the night: [or] the fifth of the sixths of the night: (K:) not the half, as some assert. (TA.)

jawofiIRN Ojwf jwf jwfI jwfy jwfyy
jawofiIRN: see Oajowafu.

juwfiIRN Ojwf jwf jwfI jwfy jwfyy
juwfiIRN: see Oajowafu. ＝ -A2- Also, and without tesh-deed, (S, K,) [app. meaning, when with the article Al, written and pronounced AljuwfiI,] in the accus. case juwfiyFA, by poetic license, (S,) A species of fish; and so juwaAfN↓. (S, K.)

juwfaAnN jwf jwfAn
juwfaAnN The penis of an ass: (El-Muärrij, K:) and of a man. (TA.)

juwaAfN jwAf
juwaAfN: see juwfiIRN.

jaAYifN c
jaAYifN Reaching the jawof. (Msb.) [Hence,] TaEonapN jaAYifapN, (S, Mgh, K, &c.,) or jiraAHapN jaAYifapN, (Msb,) A spear-wound, or the like, that reaches the jawof↓, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) by which is here meant [the interior of the body or head, or], accord. to IAth, any vital part, as the belly and the brain: (TA:) and sometimes, that penetrates into the jwf: (A 'Obeyd, S, Mgh:) and that passes through also: (A 'Obeyd, S:) and said to be such as is in the pit between the collarbones, and in the pubes; but not in the neck, nor in the throat, nor in the thigh, nor in the leg: (Mgh:) not if it reaches the interior of the bone of the thigh: (Msb:) opposed to jaAlifapN. (S in art. jlf.) ― -b2- Hence, jaAYifapN is applied to (tropical:) A great fault or imperfection or vice. (TA from a trad.) ― -b3- taloEapN jaAYifapN A deep [water-course, &c.: see tlEh]: pl. jawaAYifu. (K, TA. [In the CK, qaSiyrapN is erroneously put for qaEiyrapN.]) ― -b4- jawaAYifu AlnRafosi The deep recesses of the jawofa [or chest] in the places where the soul has its seat; expl. by maA taqaERara mina Aljawofi fiI maqaArRi AlrRuwHi. (L, K.) So in the phrase, used by El-Farezdak, waradRa AlnRafosa bayona AljawaAYifi [And he drove back the soul into the midst of the deep recesses of the chest]: (L, TA:) but some read byn AlXRaraAsifi. (TA.) ― -b5- AljaAYifu [The cephalic vein;] a vein that runs along the upper arm to the [cartilage called] nagoD of the shoulder-blade; it is the faliyq. (TA.)

Oajowafu c
Oajowafu Having a jawof; (TA;) [i. e.,] hollow, or empty within; (KL, PS;) having in it a tajowiyf [or hollowing out, meaning a hollow], (S,) and so mujawRafN↓: (S, K: [but the latter is more properly rendered hollowed, or hollowed out:]) empty, vacant, or void: (Msb:) wide, spacious, or ample; (S, K;) as also musotajaAfN↓, (S, TA,) and juwfiIRN↓, with damm, (K,) thus correctly written, being a rel. n. altered from the original form, like suholiIRN and duhoriIRN, (Sgh, TA,) but meaning wide in the jawof [or belly, &c.], written by J [in the S] jawofiIRN↓, with fet-h: (TA:) great in the jawof; (TA;) as also majuwfN↓; (AO, S, K;) each applied to a man: (TA:) [fem. jawofaMCu:] pl. juwfN. (TA.) You say luWoluWN Oajowafu, and mujawRafN↓, [Hollow, and hollowed, pearls; or] both signify the same. (TA.) And qanaApN jawofaMCu An empty [or a hollow] cane, or reed: (K:) and in like manner, XajarapN [a tree]; (S, K;) having a jawof. (S.) And dalowN jawofaMCu A wide, or an ample, bucket: (K:) and dilaMCN jawfN wide, or ample, buckets: (S:) and qidorN jawofaMCu a wide, capacious, cooking-pot. (Ham p. 719.) And AlOajowafu The lion that is great in the jawof [or belly, &c.]. (K.) And AlOajowafaAni The belly and the faroj [or vulva, or pudendum muliebre]; (S, K;) because of their width. (TA.) See also jawofN. Hence the trad., UinRa Oaxowafa maA OaxaAfu Ealayokumu AlOajowafaAni [Verily what I most fear for you are the belly and the vulva]. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A cowardly man; as also mijowafN↓, and mujawRafN↓; the last explained in the K as meaning having no heart: pl. [of the first] juwfN. (TA.) ― -b3- A horse white in the jawof [or belly] as far as the part where the sides terminate, whatever be the colour of the rest of him; (AO, TA;) as also mijowafN↓. (TA.) [See also mujawRafN.] ― -b4- In the conventional language of the science of inflection, (assumed tropical:) [A hollow word; i. e.] a word having an infirm letter for its medial radical; (K, TA;) as qaAla and baAEa. (TA.)

mujaAfN mjAf
mujaAfN (tropical:) A shut, or closed, door. (TA.)

majuwfN mjcwf
majuwfN: see Oajowafu.

mijowafN mjwf
mijowafN: see Oajowafu, in two places.

mujawRafN mjwf
mujawRafN: see Oajowafu, in three places. ― -b2- Also A beast whose balaq [q. v.] reaches up to his belly: (As, S, K:) or a horse whose balaq reaches to his sides is said to be mujawRafN balaqFA. (AA, TA.) [See also Oajowafu, last meaning but one.] ― -b3- And an epithet applied to the bird called Surad, because it is white in the belly. (Mgh and Msb in art. Srd.)

musotajaAfN mstjAf
musotajaAfN: see Oajowafu.

1 jaAla jAl
1. jaAla, (S, K, &c.,) aor. yajuwlu, (S,) inf. n. jawolN (S, K) and juwlN (K) and jawalaAnN (Az, S, ISd, Z, Sgh) and juWuwlN (ISd, K) and jiylaAlN, (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA,) in some copies of the K jiylaAn; (TA;) and in like manner, AjtAl↓ and AnjAl↓; (S, K;) He went round or about, or or round about; as also jwRl↓, inf. n. tajowaAlN: (K:) or jwRl signifies he went round, or about, or round about, much, or often; agreeably with what Sb says of the measure tafoEaAlN; but accord. to the O, tajowaAlN is an inf. n. of jAl. (TA.) You say, jAl fiI AlbilaAdi He went about, or round about, in the countries, or districts, not remaining fixed, or settled: (Msb:) and AlbilaAda jwRl↓, (T, TA,) or jwRl fiI AlbilaAdi, (S,) inf. n. tajowiylN, (T, TA,) or tajowaAlN, (S,) he went about, or round about, much, or often, in the countries, or districts. (T, S, TA.) And jAl fiI AlmayodaAni, aor. as above, inf. n. jawolapN and jawalaAnN, He (a horse) traversed the sides, or lateral parts or tracts, of the horse-course; which are termed OajowaAlN, pl. of juwlN. (Msb.) And jAl fiI AlHarobi, inf. n. jawolapN, He wheeled round, or about, in battle. (K.) And farRa lilojawalaAni vumRa EaAda liloqitaAli [He fled, to wheel round, or about, and then returned to the fight]. (Msb in art. kr.) And jAluwA, (Msb,) or tajaAwaluwA↓, (S, K,) means jAl baEoDuhumo EalaI baEoDK, (S, Msb,
K,) i. e., They assailed, or assaulted, one another, (TA,) fiI AlHarobi [in battle]; (S, Msb, K;) [and so, app., jaAwaluwA↓, inf. n. mujaAwalapN:] and kaAnato bayonahumo mujaAwalaAtN↓ (S, K *) There were between them mutual [assailings, or assaults, and] defendings. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) And jAl Alqawomu, inf. n. jawolapN, The company of men were routed, defeated, or put to flight, (AinokaXafuwA,) and then returned to the fight, or charged, or assaulted. (K.) And OaSaAba Almusolimiyna jawolapN Defeat befell the Muslims: a metonymy; used only in relation to the favourites of God; from AljawalaAnu. (Mgh.) ― -b2- jAlwuA fiI AlDRalaAlapi, (Sgh, TA,) or UilaI AlDRalaAlapi, (A, TA,) (assumed tropical:) They became excited to lightness, or levity, and unsteadiness, and carried away, and driven, (Sgh, TA,) or they became fascinated, and turned away, (A, TA,) by the influence of devils, (A, Sgh, TA,) from their religion, (Sgh, TA,) or from the right course, (A, TA,) to error. (A, Sgh, TA.) ― -b3- jAl AltRuraAbu, (ISd, K,) inf. n. jawolN, (TA,) The dust went away, and rose; as also AnjAl↓: (ISd, K:) or the latter signifies became removed, or cleared away [by the wind]; syn. AinokaXaTa. (T, TA.) ― -b4- yajuwlu fiI SadoriI Oano OafoEalahu (tropical:) [It is revolved in my bosom, or mind, that I should do it]. (TA.) ― -b5- See also 4, in two places. ＝ -A2- jAl AlXRaIoCa, (K,) inf. n. jawolN, (TA,) He chose, or selected, the thing. (K.) You say, julotu hecaA mino hecaA I chose, or selected, this from this. (AA, S.) And manohumo jawolFA Aijotalotu↓ I chose, or selected, from them [a choice portion]; (S, K, * TA;) and separated some of them from others. (TA.) And mino maAlihi jawolFA AjtAl↓, and jawaAlapF, He chose, or selected, from his property, or cattle, a choice portion. (TA.)

2 jawRala
2: see 1, in two places.

3 jaAwaluwA jAwlwA
3. jaAwaluwA, inf. n. mujaAwalapN: and kaAnato bayonahumo mujaAwalaAtN: see 1.

4 AHAlhu AHAlh AHAlp OHAl OHAlh UHAlp
4. AHAlhu, (Msb, K,) and AjAl bihi, (K,) inf. n. UijaAlapN, (S,) He, or it, made, or caused, him, or it, to go, move, or turn round, or about, or round about; to circle, or revolve; (S, Msb, K;) as also bihi jAl↓. (Zj, K.) One says in the game called Almayosir, [see this word,] Oajili AlsRihaAma [Turn thou round about, i. e., shuffle, the arrows in the ribaAbap]. (S, TA.) And AjAl AlsRihaAma bayona Alqawomi He moved about the arrows, [i. e., shuffled them in the ribaAbap,] (Az, ISd, TA,) and then distributed them among the people, or party. (Az, TA.) And AjAl sayofahu He brandished, flourished, or played with, his sword, turning it round about. (Msb.) And baAltRuraAbi AlrRiyHu tajuwlu↓, (Lth, TA,) and biAlHaSaI, (K, TA,) [The wind makes the dust, and the pebbles, to turn round about, to circle, or to revolve.] ― -b2- OajaAluwA AlrRaOoIa fiymaA bayonahumo (tropical:) They turned about, or revolved, [in their minds, the idea, or opinion, respecting the matter that was between them.] (TA.) And AjAlwA Alfikari (assumed tropical:) [They turned about, or revolved, thoughts, ideas, schemes, or contrivances, in their minds]. (Jel in ix. 48.) ― -b3- [AjAl xamosahu fiI wiEaAYihi, in the 7th Makámeh of Har, (p. 76 of the sec. ed.,) is explained in a MS. of that work as meaning Adxl, (De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., p. 185,) i. e., He inserted: but the proper meaning is, he turned about, or round about, his five fingers in his bag.] ― -b4- Oajilo jaAYilataka↓ (tropical:) Accomplish, or finish, the affair in which thou art engaged. (M, K, TA.)

6 tajaAowala
6: see 1.

7 Uinojawala
7: see 1, in two places.

8 Uijotawala
8: see 1, first sentence. ＝ -A2- AjtAlhumo He turned them from their course. (K.) He (the devil) caused them to leave, or forsake, the right way. (T, TA.) AijotaAlatohumu AlXRayaATiynu Eano diynihimo The devils excited them to lightness, or levity, and unsteadiness, so that they turned away from their religion, to error; i. e., they carried them away and drove them [from their religion]. (Sgh, TA.) [See also 10.] ＝ -A3- See also 1, last two sentences.

10 AisotajaAlatohumu AlXRayaATiynu c
10. AisotajaAlatohumu AlXRayaATiynu The devils turned them from the right course, to error; fascinated them so that they turned with them. (A, TA.) And AstjAlhu AlXRaIoCu The thing excited him to lightness, or levity, and unsteadiness. (TA.) [See also 8.] ― -b2- AstjAlti Alxayolu maA marRato bihi The horses removed, or displaced, that by which they passed. (O, TA.) ― -b3- Ausotujiyla AlrRabaAbu The rbAb [or white clouds] were driven together after a state of dispersion, and became ready to rain: (M, TA:) or it means jaMCatohu AlrRiyHu faQsotajaAlatohu, i. e., the wind came to them, and removed them, or displaced them, and dissundered them, and drove them away. (TA.) ― -b4- AisotajalonaA AljahaAma (tropical:) We saw the rainless clouds going about, or round about, in the horizon, (A, TA,) or in the sky. (TA.)

jaAlN jAl
jaAlN: see juwlN, in five places: ― -b2- and mijowalN.

jaAlK jAl
jaAlK: see jaAYilN.

jawolN jwl
jawolN: see jawolaAnN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also A large army, or military force, or troop of horse: (Sgh, K:) pl. juwlN. (Sgh, TA.) A herd of camels: and a troop of xayol [meaning horses or horsemen]: as also juwlN↓ in both these senses: (K:) or the latter, which is also explained in the K as signifying a herd of camels, and a flock of ostriches and of sheep or goats, is pl. of the former: (TA:) or the former signifies thirty [horses or horsemen]: or forty: (K:) or less: or more: (TA:) or the choice, or best, of camels: and [in like manner] jawaAlapN↓ signifies the choice and best; as in the saying, Oaxaca jawaAlapa maAlihi [He took the choice and best of his cattle, or property]. (K. [See also 1, last two sentences: and see jawalaAn.]) And Many great sheep or goats. (K.) ― -b2- Also A male mountain-goat that is old, or advanced in age: (M, K:) pl. OajowaAlN. (M, TA.)

juwlN jwl
juwlN The wall [that surrounds the interior] of a well: accord. to A 'Obeyd, every side of a well, from its top to its bottom: and jaAlN↓ signifies the same: (S:) or the former, the side, or lateral part, (M, Msb, K,) of a well, and of a grave, and of the sea, and of a mountain; as also jaAlN↓ (M, K) and jiylN↓: (K, TA; in the CK jayol:) or the surrounding parts [or sides] of a grave: (M, TA:) and AlwaAdiI jaAlaA↓ the two sides of the water of the valley: and AlbaHori jaAlaA↓ the two shores of the sea, or great river: (T, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OajowaAlN, (Az, S, Msb, K,) pl. of juwlN and jaAlN, (TA,) and [of mult.] jiwaAlN and jiwaAlapN; (so in copies of the K, and in the M, but in some copies of the K juwaAlN and juwaAlapN;) and OajaAwilu is pl. of OajowaAlN. (TA.) Also, as in the T and the Moheet, (TA,) The portion of rock that is at the bottom of the water, (K, TA.) upon which is the casing of the well; so that if it quit its place, the well falls to ruin: this is [said to be] the primary meaning of the word: and hence the saying, hecaA maMCN laA yudoraku juwluhu [This is water of which the rock beneath it is not to be reached]. (TA.) ― -b2- [And from this word as signifying the casing of a well, or the portion of rock above mentioned,] (tropical:) Intelligence; (S, K, TA;) judgment, and intelligence, or full intelligence, or intelligence to which one has recourse; (T, TA;) understanding of the heart; (TA;) and resolution, or fixed purpose of mind; (S, M;) and prudence: (T, TA:) AlEazomu in the K is erroneously put for AlHazomu. (TA.) You say, of a man, maAlahu juwlN (tropical:) He has not intelligence and judgment, or fixed purpose of mind, to withhold him, or protect him; like the jwl of a well; (S, M, * TA; *) because a well, when cased with stone or the like, is stronger. (TA.) And rajulN lahu zaborN wajuwlN (tropical:) A man having judgment and intelligence, or full intelligence, or intelligence to which recourse is had; whose jwl does not become demolished: and in like manner, huwa mazobuwrN maAfawqa Aljuwli minohu waSulobN maAtaHota AlzRabori mina Aljuwli: and in the contr. case, layosa lifulaAnK juwlN (tropical:) Such a one has not intelligence nor prudence; i. e., his jwl is demolished, therefore one is not sure that the zbr [that rests upon it] may not also fall: and layosa lahu juwlN, and jaAlN↓, (tropical:) He has not prudence. (T, TA.) ― -b3- faEalotuhu mino juwlihi I did it on account, or for the sake, or because, of him, or it. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also jawolN: ＝ -A3- and jawolaAnN.

jiylN jyl
jiylN: see juwlN.

jawolaAnN jwlAn
jawolaAnN Dust; as also jawolN↓ and juwlN↓, (K,) both mentioned by Az, (TA,) and jayolaAnN↓, (K,) mentioned by ISd: [or] all signify dust which the wind makes to turn about or round about, to circle, or to revolve, upon, or from, the surface of the earth. (TA.) And Small pebbles which the wind makes to turn about or round about, to circle, or to revolve; (K, TA;) as also jawolN↓ and jayolaAnN↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jawolaAnu: see Oajowalu.

jawalaAnu Alhumuwmi jwlAn Alhmwm
jawalaAnu Alhumuwmi (tropical:) The first, or beginning, [lit. the revolving, (see 1,)] of anxieties. (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, jawolAnu.]) You say, fiI qalobihi jawalaAnu Alhumuwmi (tropical:) In his heart are revolving anxieties. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- jawalaAnu AlmaAli The small, or young, and bad, of cattle: (Fr, S, K:) so in the M and O; but in a copy of the M, written jawolAn; which is app. a mistake. (TA.) Accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, The choice, or
best, of cattle: the contr. of what is said by Fr. (TA. [See also jawolN.])

jayolaAnN jyl jylAn
jayolaAnN: see jawolaAnN, in two places. ＝ -A2- jyolaAnu: see Oajowalu.

jawolaAniIRN jwl jwlAn jwlAnI jwlAny
jawolaAniIRN: see Oajowalu. ― -b2- Also (tropical:) A man whose benefits are common to the near and the distant; (K, TA;) whose benefits go round to every one. (Sgh, TA.)

jayolaAniIRN jylAnI jylAny
jayolaAniIRN: see Oajowalu.

jawiylN jwyl
jawiylN What the winds sweep away (AHn, M, K) and round about, (AHn, M,) of fragments of plants and of the fallen leaves of trees; (AHn, M, K;) as also jaAYilN↓. (M, TA.)

jawaAlapN jwAl jwAlh jwAlp
jawaAlapN: see jawolN.

jawaAYilu OamorK c
jawaAYilu OamorK (assumed tropical:) The turns (dawaAYir) of an affair, or event. (TA.)

jawRaAlN jAlyp jwAl
jawRaAlN One who goes about, or round about, much, or often, in the countries, or districts, (Msb,) TA,) not remaining fixed, or settled; (Msb;) as also jawRaAlapN↓ [but in a more intensive sense, meaning who does so very much, or very often]. (TA.) ― -b2- A horse having a flexible head: (TA:) and OajowaliIRN↓ a swift horse, that turns about howsoever one turns him. (K, * TA.)

jawRaAlapN jwAl jwAlh jwAlp
jawRaAlapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

jaAYilN c
jaAYilN: see jawiylN. ― -b2- Also Rainless clouds going round about. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And, applied to a [woman's ornament of the kind termed] wiXaAH, and to a camel's belly-girth, Loose; not tight; unsteady; as also jaAlK↓. (T, TA.) [Hence,] AimoraOapN jaAYilapu AlwiXaAHayoni (tropical:) A woman slender in the waist. (Z, TA.)

jaAYilapN c
jaAYilapN An affair in which one is engaged. (M, K.) See 4, last sentence.

Oajowalu c
Oajowalu [More, and most, wont to go round, or about, or round about; to circle, or revolve;] is from the first of the verbs in this art.: and hence the prov., Oajowalu mino quTorubK [More wont to go about, or round about, or more restless, than a qTrb; a certain animalcule, or insect, that is constantly moving about: see art. qTrb]. (Har p. 661.) ― -b2- Also, [as meaning (assumed tropical:) More, and most, circulating,] applied to language, or discourse. (TA in art. jmE.) [See an ex. voce majomaEN.] ― -b3- yawomN Oajowalu, and jayolaAniIRN↓, and jawolaAniIRN↓, (Lh, M, K,) and jawolaAnu↓, and jayolaAnu↓, (M, K,) A day of much dust (T, M, K) and wind: (T, TA:) from jawolN signifying “ dust.” (TA.)

OajowaliIRN c
OajowaliIRN: see jawRaAlN.

majaAlN mjAl mjAly
majaAlN A place in which one goes round, or about, or round about: (TA:) [a field of battle: a circus:] a place of exercise for horses. (Har p. 16.) ― -b2- [Hence] one says, lamo yaboqa majaAlN fiI AlOamori (tropical:) [There remained not any scope in the affair, or case]. (TA.)

mijowalN mjwl
mijowalN A certain garment for women, (M, K,) doubled, and sewed together at one of its two sides, and having an opening made to it at the neck and bosom; in which a woman goes about: (M, TA:) or for a young girl; (K;) the diroE being for a woman: (TA:) a small garment in which a girl goes about: (S:) or a garment which a girl wears before she is made to keep herself behind, or within, the curtain, and in which she goes about: (Z, TA:) accord. to IAar, i. q. SudorapN. (TA.) Imra-el-Keys says,
UilaI mivolihaAyaronuw AlHaliymu SabaAbapF
UicaA maA QsobakarRato bayona diroEK wamijowali
[At the like of her the staid would fixedly gaze with tenderness of desire, when she has become of erect and justly-proportioned stature, between such as wears a woman's shirt and such as wears a young girl's garment]. (S, * TA.) ― -b2- A woman's anklet. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) ― -b3- An amulet, a phylactery, or charm of the kind termed Euwcap. (IAar, K.) ― -b4- A crescent of silver in the middle of the necklace termed qilaAdap. (IAar, K.) ― -b5- Silver [itself]. (Th, K.) ― -b6- A good, or sound, diroham [or silver coin]. (IAar, K.) ― -b7- A shield; (S, O, K;) sometimes used in this sense; (S, O;) as also jaAlN↓. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) ― -b8- A large wooden bowl. (IAar, TA.) ― -b9- A white vawob [or piece of cloth] that is put upon the hand of him to whom the players at the game called Almayosir commit the arrows [to be shuffled and distributed, in order that he may not be able to distinguish them by the feel,] when they have collected themselves. (ISd, K, * TA.) [For the same purpose, a piece of thin skin was also used: see ribaAbapN.] ＝ -A2- A pool of water left by a torrent; because the water goes round about in it. (IF, TA.) ＝ -A3- A wild ass. (IAar, K.)

musotajaAlN mstjAl
musotajaAlN [pass. part. n. of 10, Turned from the right course, &c.:] excited to lightness, or levity, and unsteadiness: (TA:) being bereft of his reason, or intellect. (AA, TA.)

jaAmN jAm
jaAmN A vessel, (K,) or faAvuwr [i. e. a basin, or a table, or a tray used as a table], (IAar, TA,) of silver: (IAar, K, TA:) or a white dish or tray, of glass or of silver: (Mgh:) or a vessel (Zarof) of glass: (Har p. 200:) [a Persian word, i. e. jaAmo, arabicized; or] a genuine Arabic word: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OajoWumN, with C, (IAar, K,) and OajowaAmN, and (as some say, IAar, TA, [of mult.,]) juwmN, (K,) with damm, (TA, in the CK jawomN,) and [of pauc. or mult.] jaAmaAtN: (IAar, K:) but IB says that jaAmN is pl. of jaAmapN↓, as is also jaAmaAtN: [instead of which he should rather have said that jAm is a coll. gen. n. of which the n. un. is jAmp, (though this requires consideration, as the former is commonly used as a sing.,) and that the pl. of the latter is jAmAt:] that its dim. is juwayomapN↓: and that it, i. e. jAm, is of the fem. gender. (TA.)

jaAmapN jcAm jcAmh jcAmp
jaAmapN: see above.

juwayomapN jwymh jwymp
juwayomapN: see above.

1 jaAna jAn jAny
1. jaAna, (K, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, jAnRa,]) inf. n. jawonN, (TA,) It (the face) became black. (K.)

jawonN jwn
jawonN White: and black: (S, Msb, K:) thus bearing two contr. significations: (S:) and juwniIRN↓, also, has the latter signification: (IAth, TA in art. Hwt:) or jawonN signifies black tinged over with red: (T, M, TA:) and black intermixed with red; the colour of the qaTaA: (T, TA:) and also red: (K:) or of a pure red colour: (TA:) and, applied to a horse and a camel, of the colour termed Oadoham, (S, K,) intensely black: (S:) every camel, and every wild ass, seen from a distance, is of this colour: fem. with p: (T, TA:) and, applied to a plant, or herbage, green, (K,) or intensely green, (TA,) inclining to blackness: (K, TA:) pl. juwnN; (S, TA;) like as SutomN is of SatomN, (S,) and wurodN of warodN. (M, TA.) You say also, AlXRamosu jawonapN The sun is characterized by what is termed juwnapN: (S:) or is intensely glistening and clear. (Az, TA.) [See also jawonapN below.] See also juwniIRN. Accord. to ISk, Oabuw Aljawoni means The white man: opposed to OabuwAlbayoDaMCi meaning the negro. (TA in art. byD.) ― -b2- Also (assumed tropical:) Day: (AO, S, K:) pl. as above. (K.) So in the saying,
gayRara yaA binota AlHulayosi lawoniI
marRu AllRayaAliI waQxotilaAfu Aljuwoni
[The passing of the nights, and the alternating of the day, have changed, O daughter of El-Holeys, my colour]. (AO, S.) ― -b3- And, accord. to certain of the lawyers, metaphorically, (tropical:) The light: and the darkness. (Msb.) ― -b4- And accord. to IAar, (assumed tropical:) The frq [app. faraq, meaning day-break]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AljawonaAni The two extremities of the bow. (Fr, Az, K.)

jawonapN jwn jwnh jwnp
jawonapN The sun; (K;) [i. e.] the sun's disc; because it becomes black [or of a blackish colour tinged with red] at setting; (S;) or it may be because of its whiteness and clearness; but it is said to be only applied to the sun when it is setting; opposed to gazaAlapN; as observed by MF: (TA:) [see also jawonN:] the sun is also called jawonaMCu↓, (K,) because of its becoming black [or of a blackish colour tinged with red] at setting. (TA.) ― -b2- A [jar such as is called] xaAbiyap: (IAar, TA:) or a xAbyp smeared with tar, or pitch. (S.) [See an ex. in a verse of Lebeed cited in art. dkn.] See also juwnapN. ― -b3- And A bucket (dalow) that has become black. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- And i. q. faHomapN [which may here mean either A piece of charcoal, or the blackness of night or the like]. (IAar, K.) ― -b5- And i. q. OaHomaru [perhaps as a subst., meaning A red thing]. (K.) ― -b6- See also jawniIRN.

juwnapN jwn jwnh jwnp
juwnapN The quality [i. e. colour], in horses, denoted by [the epithet] jawonN; like gubospN and duhomapN; (S;) in horses, i. q. jawonapN: (K:) and in the sun, also, the quality denoted by jawonapN [as fem. of jawonN, q. v.]: and blackness; as in the saying, laA OafoEaluhu HatRaI taboyaDRa juwnapu AlqaAri [I will not
do it until the blackness of pitch, or tar, become white]: but if you say AlqaAri jawonapu↓, the meaning is the xaAbiyp [smeared with tar, or pitch]. (S.) ＝ -A2- A small basket (sulayolap), (K,) or safaT, (K in art. jOn,) of a round form, (TA,) that is with the sellers of perfumes, (S, K,) used for containing their perfumes: (K in art. jOn:) called in Persian XiyXaho daAnN [a receptacle for bottles or the like]: (KL:) originally with C: (K:) or sometimes pronounced with C: (S:) El-Fárisee approved the suppression of the C: (M, TA:) pl. juwanN. (S, M, K.) [See also raboEapN.] ＝ -A3- A small mountain. (K.)

jawonaMCu jwnMC
jawonaMCu: see jawonapN. ― -b2- Also A cooking-pot; (K;) because it is black. (TA.) ― -b3- And A she-camel such as is termed dahomaMCu [of an intense, or a dark, gray colour, without any admixture of white]; from jaAna said of the face. (K.)

juwniIRN jwn jwnI jwny
juwniIRN: see jawonN. ― -b2- Also A species of the kind of bird called qaTFA, (S, K,) black in the belly and wings, larger than the [species called] kudoriIR, one of the former species being equal to two of the latter: (S, TA:) or, accord. to ISk, the qTA compose two species; one called juwniIRN and kudoriIRN; and the other, gaTaATN; and the former is dusky, or dingy, or of a hue inclining to black and dust-colour, (Oakodar,) in the back, black in the inner side of the wing, yellow in the throat, short in the legs, having in the tail two feathers longer than the rest of the tail: (T, TA:) or, as some say, the kudoriyRap and juwniyRap are one of the two species of the qTA, and the other is the gTAT; and the former are short in the legs, yellow in the necks, black in the primary feathers of the wings, of a white hue tinged with red (Suhob) in the tertials: (TA voce gTAT, q. v.:) [but see kudoriIRN: the jwnIR is described by De Sacy, on the authority of the book entitled drRp AlmntqAp mn EjAYb AlmxlwqAt wgrAYb AlmwjwdAt, thus: “ le djouni a les barbes internes des ailes et les pennes primaires noires; il a la gorge blanche, ornée de deux colliers, l'un jaune et l'autre noir; son dos est d'un gris cendré, moucheté, mêlé d'un peu de jaune: on appelle cette espèce djouni, parce que sa voix ne rend pas un son clair et sonore, mais qu'elle fait entendre seulement une sorte de gargouillement dans le gosier: ” (Chrest. Arabe, 2nd ed., ii. 369:)] it is stated in the handwriting of As, on the authority of the Arabs, that jwnIR, applied to the qTA, is with C; app. meaning that it was pronounced juWuniIRN: (M, TA:) a single bird of this species is termed juwniyRapN: (S:) and you say also qaTaApN jawonapN↓, with fet-h: (TA:) [but juwniIRN seems to be also used as a n. un., like ruwmiIRN: for it is said that] juwnN is pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of juwnIRN, like as tamorN is of tamorapN. (Ham p. 605.)

1 jaAhahu biAlmakoruwhi jAhh bAlmkrwh jAhh bAlmkrwp
1. jaAhahu biAlmakoruwhi, (S,) or bimakoruwhK, (K,) [aor. yajuwhu,] inf. n. jawohN, (S,) i. q. jabahahu bihi [He met him, or encountered him, with, or he said to him, or did to him, or he accused him, to his face, of, that which was, or a thing that was, disliked, or hated]. (S, K.) And [in like manner,] jAhhu biXarRK He encountered him with evil [speech or conduct]; or confronted him therewith: whence laA jihota, i. e. Mayest thou not be encountered with evil; said in chiding a he-camel: see jaAhi below. (TA.) A woman of Ghatafán, being chidden by her son, and being asked why she did not reply against him, said, OaxaAfu Oano yajuwhaniI biOakovara mino hecaA, meaning I fear that he would encounter me with more than this. (JK.)

2 jwRh jw jwh jwp
2. jwRh and AjAh↓ are rendered by Golius Ad dignitatem evexit: spectabilem reddidit: as on the authority of the S: but in my copies of the S the two verbs are Awjh and wjRh; and belong to art. wjh, though mentioned in the present art.]

4 Oajowaha
4: see 2.]

5 tjwRh jwy tjwh tjwp
5. tjwRh He magnified himself; or was, or became, proud, haughty, or disdainful: or he affected rank, station, or dignity, not possessing it. (TA.)

jaAhN jAh jAp
jaAhN Rank, station, or dignity, (S, K, TA, and JK in art. wjh,) with, or in the estimation of, the Sultán; (JK, TA;) as also jaAhapN↓, (K,) on the authority of Lh, (TA, as from the K, [but not in my copies,]) or, accord. to Sgh, of Ks.: the former word [probably arabicized from the Persian jaAho; but] said to be formed by transposition from wajohN; this being first changed to jawohN; then, to jawahN; and then, to jaAhN: or, accord. to Lh, it is not from wajohN, but from juhot [app. juhotu, first pers. sing. of jaAha, q. v.]; though he does not explain what is juhot. (TA.) You say, fulaAnN cuw jaAhK [Such a one is possessed of rank, station, or dignity]. (S.) And lifulaAnK jaAhN fiyhimo To such a one belongs rank, station, or dignity, among them. (Aboo-Bekr, TA.) The dim. of jaAhN [or of jaAhapN] is juwayohapN↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- jaAhi, indecl., with kesr for its termination; and, accord. to As, sometimes, jaAhK, with tenween; (S;) or jaAhi jaAhi, (JK, K,) and jaAhK jaAhK, and jaAho jaAho, (Lh, K,) and juwh juwh↓, or jawoh jawoh, (accord. to different copies of the K, but) indecl., with kesr for the termination, [i. e. juwhi juwhi, or jawohi jawohi,] mentioned in the M, (TA,) and jaAhi laA jihota↓, (IDrd, TA, [see 1,]) ejaculations used for chiding a he-camel, not a she-camel: (As, JK, IDrd, S, K:) or one says to a she-camel, EaAjK and jaAhK. (A 'Obeyd, TA in art. Ewj: [or perhaps there is an omission here: I think it more likely that what A 'Obeyd said was that one says to a she-camel EaAjK, and to a he-camel jaAhK.])

juwhN jw jwh jwp
juwhN The face, or countenance: syn. wajohN; as also jiyhN: (Lh, K:) the latter with kesr: (TA:) so in the saying, naZara bijuwhi sawoCK and bijiyhi sawoCK [He looked with an evil face or countenance]. (Lh, K.) ＝ -A2- juwhi juwhi, or jawohi jawohi: see the next preceding paragraph.

jaAhapN jAh jAhh jAhp
jaAhapN: see jaAhN.

juwayohapN jwyhh jwyhp
juwayohapN: see jaAhN.

tujaAha tjAh tjAp
tujaAha and tijaAha and tajaAha: see art. wjh.

jawoharN jwhr
jawoharN: see art. jhr.

jawohariIRN jwhr jwhrI jwhry jwhryy
jawohariIRN: see art. jhr.

1 jawiIa jw jwI jwy
1. jawiIa, (S, K,) aor.
jawaIa
, (TA,) inf. n. jawFI, (K,) He (a man, S) was, or became, affected with what is termed jawFI↓, (S, K,) meaning ardour: and violence of amorous desire; or of grief, or sorrow: (S:) or inward love: (M, K:) and grief, or sorrow: (K, and so in a copy of the S:) and ardour: and violence of love: or of grief, or sorrow: (K:) [see HubRN:] ― -b2- and also as meaning consumption; or an ulcer in the lungs: and long continuance, or oppressiveness, of disease: and a disease in the chest: (K:) or any inward disease during which one does not find food to be wholesome: (TA:) part. n. jawK↓; (S, K;) fem. jawiyapN. (TA.) ― -b3- You say also, jawiyato nafosiI, meaning I found the country, or town, to disagree with me. (S.) And jawiyato nafosuhu minohu and Eanohu [He found it to disagree with him: a meaning indicated, but not expressed]. (K.) See also 8. ― -b4- And jawiyati AlOaroDu The land stank. (TA.)

8 AjtwAhu AjtwAh AjtwAp QjtwAh QjtwI
8. AjtwAhu He disliked residing in it, namely, a country, or town, even if in the enjoyment of ease and plenty: (S:) or he disliked it, (K, TA,) and found it to disagree with him; (TA;) as also jawiyahu↓: (K, TA:) or he disliked it, namely, a city, and found it to be insalubrious: or, as AZ says, he disliked it, namely, a country, even if it agreed with him in respect of his body: and he says, in his Nawádir, that AijotiwaMCN signifies the yearning towards, or longing for, home, and disliking a place, even if in the enjoyment of ease and plenty: and disliking it without yearning towards, or longing for, home: and also the not finding the food nor the beverage in a land to be wholesome: but not when one likes the residing in it but its food and beverage do not agree with him. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And AjtwI His heart was burnt by the fire of enmity. (Ham p. 219.)

jawFI jw jwI jwy
jawFI: see 1: ― -b2- and see what next follows, in two places.

jawK jw
jawK part. n. of 1, q. v.; (S, K;) and jawFI↓ signifies the same, being an inf. n. used as an epithet. (K.) ― -b2- Hence, (S,) the former, (S, K,) as also ↓the latter, (K, and so in a copy of the S,) signifies Stinking water; (K;) or water that has become altered and stinking. (S, TA.) ― -b3- OaroDN jawiyapN and jawiyRapN↓ A land that disagrees with one. (K.)

jawiIRN jw jwI jwy
jawiIRN Contracted in the bosom, (K, TA,) by reason of disease therein, (TA,) so that his tongue cannot explain for him, (K,) or so that his tongue can hardly, or not at all, explain for him. (TA.) ― -b2- OaroDN jawiyRapN: see jawK.

3 jaAyaAhu jAyAh jAyAp
3. jaAyaAhu, inf. n. mujaAyaApN, He faced him, fronted him, was opposite to him, or was over against him: a dial. var. of jaAyaOahu. (IAar, K.) You say also, marRa biI mujaAyaApF He passed by me being in front, or opposite. (TA.)

1 jaMCa jMC
1. jaMCa, aor. yajiIoCu, inf. n. majiIoCN (S, Msb, K, &c., [the most common form, but] deviating from the general rule [respecting inf. ns. of this class], for the inf. n. of a verb of the form faEala having its aor. of the form yafoEilu is [accord. to the general rule, if commencing with an augmentative m,] mafoEalN, though some words, beside majiIoCN, deviate from this rule by being of the measure mafoEilN, [for majiIoCN is originally majoyiYN,] as maEiyXN and makiylN and maSiyrN and masiyrN and maHiydN and mamiylN and maqiylN and maziydN and maEiylN and mabiyEN and maHiySN and maHiyDN, S, * TA) and jayoYapN (S, K, of the form of an inf. n. of un., but used as an inf. n. in an absolute sense, like rajofapN and raHomapN, S, TA) and jaIoCN, (K,) He, or it, came; or was, or became, present; syn. OataI; (S, K;) or HaDara, said of a man [&c.]; (Msb;) or HaSala [meaning it came, came to pass, happened, took place, betided, befell, or occurred; it resulted; it ensued; &c.]; and it is used in relation to ideal, as well as real, substantives; so that UicaA jaMCa naSoru QllRehi [When the assistance of God shall come (in the Kur ex. 1)] is [not a figurative but] a proper phrase. (Er-Rághib, TA.) Sb mentions, on the authority of certain of the Arabs, huwa yajiyka [for hw yajiyoWuka He comes, or will come, to thee], with the hemzeh suppressed: (TA:) and he also mentions yajuwoCu as a dial. var. of yajiIoCu. (Id. in art. jwO, q. v.) [As shown above,] jaMCa is used intransitively and transitively. (Msb, MF.) say, jaMCa zayodN Zeyd came; or was, or became, present. (Msb.) And jiYotu majiyoYFA HasanFA [I came with a good coming; or in a good manner]. (S.) And jiYotu zayodFA I came to Zeyd. (Msb.) And sometimes one says, jiYotu Uilayohi meaning I went [as well as I came] to him, or it. (Msb.) And jiYotu mina Albaladi [I came from the town, or country]: and mina Alqawomi, meaning mino Einodi Alqawomi [from the presence of the people, or company of men]. (Msb.) And jaMCa Algayovu The rain [came, or] descended. (Msb.) And jaMCa Oamoru AlsRuloTaAni The order, or command, of the Sultán came, or arrived. (Msb.) And jiYotu bihi (S, Msb, K) and OajaOotuhu↓, both signifying the same, (S, K,) [I came with him, or it;] I brought him, or it, with me. (Msb.) And AlHamodu llRehi AlRaciI jaMCa bika [Praise be to God who brought thee]; and AlHamodu llRehi Uico jiYota [Praise be to God because, or that, thou camest, or hast come]; but not AlHamodu llRehi AlRaciI jiYota: (S, TA:) and [in like manner] you say, AlHamodu llRehi Uico kaAna kacaA; but not AlHamodu llRehi AlRaciI kaAna kacaA unless you say bihi or minohu or Eanohu [after AlcI]. (ISk, TA.) [Hence, jaMCa biwaladK He begot a child, or children; like OataI biwaladK. And jaMCto bihi She brought him forth; gave birth to him; like Oatato bihi. And jaMCa bimaEonFI It (a word) conveyed, or imported, a meaning.] ― -b2- [jaMCa biXaIoCK also signifies He brought to pass, did, executed, performed, or effected, a thing: and he said, gave utterance to, or uttered, a thing: like OataI bihi in both these senses.] And jaMCa kacaA He did thus, or such a thing. (TA.) Hence, [in the Kur xix. 28,] laqado jiYoti XayoYFA fariyRFA (TA) [Verily, O Mary, thou hast done] a thing hitherto unknown; a thing deemed strange. (Bd. [See another ex. voce UimorN, likewise from the Kur.]) And jiYotu XayoYFA HasanFA I did a good thing. (Msb.) And jaMCa biAlbadiyEi He produced a new saying, or new poetry, not after the similitude of anything preceding. (TA in art. bdE.) And jaMCa jaroyFA baEoda jaroIK (K in art. tOm) or [more commonly] jAC bijaroIK baEoda jaroIK (M in that art.) [He (a horse) performed, or fetched, run after run]. ― -b3- jaMC is also syn. with SaAra, like OataI; as in the saying, jaMCa AlbinaMCu muHokamFA The building became, or came to be, firm, strong, or compact. (Kull p. 11.) [And hence the phrase,] maA jaMCato HaAjataka, (M, K,) thus in all the copies of the K, with the noun in the accus. case; i. e. What became, or has become, thy want? syn. maA SaArato; (M, K;) or What was thy want? syn. maA kaAnato: (Er-Radee, TA:) mA being here an interrogative, and the [implied] pronoun [in the verb] being made fem. because its predicate is fem.: but some say HaAjatuka, in the nom. case, [as it is in the CK, meaning What did, or has, thy want become?] regarding HAjtk as the subject of jACt, and mA as the predicate of this verb. (TA.) ― -b4- See also 3.

3 mujaAyaOapN c
3. mujaAyaOapN [inf. n. of jaAyaOa] signifies The act of facing, or fronting; being opposite, or over against: (IAar, K:) and the act of coinciding; as also jiyaMCN. (AZ, K.) You say of a man, jaAyaOaniI mino qurobK He faced me, fronted me, was opposite to me, or was over against me, at a short distance. (TA.) And marRa biI mujaAyaOapF He passed by me being in front, or opposite. (TA.) And jaAyaOotu fulaAnFA I coincided with such a one in his coming. (TA.) And lawo jaAwazota hecaA AlmakaAna lajaAyaOota Algayova Hadst thou passed beyond this place, thou hadst met with rain, or coincided with rain in its coming. (TA.) ― -b2- jaAMniI fajiYotuhu↓, [so in copies of the S, and in copies of the K, as from the S, but in the TA, as from the S, jaMCaOaniI, and said to be with two hemzehs, though this is evidently wrong,] aor. OajiyoWuhu, the former verb of the measure faAEalaniI, (S,) is [said to be] a mistake for jaAyaOaniI fjYth, since the former verb has an infirm letter [I] for its medial radical and C for its final, not the reverse, (Sgh, K,) [therefore] what J says is not allowable unless it be an instance of transposition; (IB, TA;) but what is given by F [and Sgh as the correct form] is that which is accord. to rule, and what J says is that which has been heard from the Arabs, as ISd has pointed out; (TA;) [and rule is not to be regarded when it is contr. to classical usage;] the meaning is, He vied with me, or strove to surpass me, in frequency of coming, and I surpassed him therein. (S, K.)

4 OajaACahu c
4. OajaACahu He made him, or it, to come. (Kull p. 11.) ― -b2- [Hence,] OajaOotuhu i. q. jiYotu bihi: see 1. (S, K.) ― -b3- OajaOotuhu Uilayohi I compelled him, constrained him, or necessitated him, to have recourse, or betake himself, to it; (Fr, S, K;) or made him to want it, or be in need of it: (S:) in the dial. of Temeem, OaXaOotuhu. (TA in art. XyO.) It is said in a prov., XarRN maA yujiyoWuka UilaI muxRapi EuroquwbK [It is an evil thing that compels thee to have recourse to the marrow of a hock]; for, as As says, the Erqwb contains no marrow, and only he who cannot obtain any [other] thing is made to want it. (S.) And it is said in the Kur xix. 23, faOajaMCahaA AlmaxaADu UilaI jicoEi AlnRaxolapi And the motion of the child in her womb compelled her to betake herself to the trunk of the palm-tree. (Bd.)

jiyoYapN c
jiyoYapN [A coming;] a subst. from jaMCa, (S, K,) of the measure fiEolapN, with kesr to the j. (S.)

jaYiYN c
jaYiYN and jaORLCN: see what next follows.

jayRaMCN jyMC
jayRaMCN, (K,) mentioned by Sb as an extr. word, (TA,) [but regularly formed, of the measure faERaAlN,] and jaORLCN↓, also written jaORaACN, (K,) with the I changed into hemzeh, (TA,) and jaYiYN↓, (K,) [originally jayiYN, of the measure faEilN, denoting intensiveness, in the CK written jaAyiYN,] mentioned by IJ as anomalous, A frequent comer. (TA.) One says, UinRahu lajayRaMCN bixayorK Verily he is a frequent bringer of good. (TA.)

jaMCK jMC
[jaMCK, originally jaAyiYN, then jaAYiYN, then jaAYiIN, and then jaMCK, Coming; act. part. n. of 1.]

1 jaAba jAb jAby
1. jaAba, aor. yajiybu: see 1 in art. jwb, in two places.

2 jyRb jyb
2. jyRb, inf. n. tajoyiybN: see 1 in art. jwb.

jayobN jyb
jayobN The Tawoq [or opening at the neck and bosom] (K) of a shirt (S, K) and the like; (K;) as, for instance, of a coat of mail: (TA:) or the opening of a shirt at the uppermost part of the breast: (Msb, MF:) or the opening in a garment for the head to be put through: or such an opening as a sleeve and a Tawoq: (MF:) pl. [of mult.] juyuwbN, (Msb, K,) also pronounced jiyuwbN, (TA,) [like biyuwtN for buyuwtN,] and [of pauc.] OajoyaAbN: (Msb:) this is said to be its proper art., (K, TA,) not jwb, because its pl. is juyuwbN. (TA.) [The Arabs often carry things within the bosom of the shirt &c.; and hence the word is now applied by them to A pocket.] ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The heart; the bosom. (K.) So in the saying, huwa naASiHu Aljayobi (assumed tropical:) [He is pure, or sincere, of heart or bosom]: (K:) or trusty, trustworthy, or faithful. (S. [See also art. nSH.]) A poet says,
waxaXRanota SadorFA jayobuhu laka naASiHu
(assumed tropical:) [And thou hast exasperated a bosom the heart of which was faithful to thee]. (TA.) You say also, huwa danisu Aljayobi (assumed tropical:) [He is a person of foul heart]. (A in art. dns.) And radaEa jayobahu Eanohu (assumed tropical:) He cleared his heart, or bosom, of it. (K in art. rdE q. v.) ― -b3- jayobu AlOaroDi (assumed tropical:) The place of entrance of the land, or country: (K:) pl. juyuwbN. (TA.)

jiybapN jyb jybh jybp
jiybapN: see art. jwb.

yaAquwtN mujayRabN yAqwt mjyb
yaAquwtN mujayRabN Hollowed [sapphires]: occurring in a trad. describing the banks of the river of Paradise: but accord. to one reading, it is luWoluWN mujawRabN; accord. to another, mujayRabN or majawRafN; and accord. to another, mujayRabN or mujawRabN. (TA.)

1 jaAHati AlMfapu AlmaAla jAHt AlMfp AlmAl
1. jaAHati AlMfapu AlmaAla, aor. tajiyHuhu, inf. n. jiyaAHapN, [perhaps a mistranscription for jaAYiHapN,] i. q. jaAHatohu of which the aor. is tajuwHuhu: see art. jwH. (Msb.) And jaAHahumu QllRehu, inf. n. jayoHN and jaAYiHapN, the latter an inf. n. like EaAfiyapN, God afflicted them with a calamity. (TA.)

majiyHN mjyH
majiyHN i. q. majuwHN: see art. jwH. (Msb.)

1 jayida jyd
1. jayida, (Lh, L,) or jaAda, of the same class as taEiba, aor. yajaAdu, (Msb,) inf. n. jayadN, (Lh, S, A, L, Msb, K,) He had a long neck: (A, Msb, K:) or a long and beautiful neck: (S, L:) or a slender and long neck. (L, K.)

jiydN jyd
jiydN, of the measure fiEolN, (Sb, Akh,) or it may be originally of the measure fuEolN, (Sb, TA,) The neck: (S, L, Msb, K:) said by Sh to be used only in praise; and EunuqN, in dispraise; the use of the former in the Kur exi. being ironical; (TA;) but accord. to Esh-Shiháb, the contr. is often the case: (MF:) generally applied to that of a woman: (L:) or the part of the neck upon which the necklace lies: or its fore part: (L, K:) pl. [of pauc.] OajoyaAdN (S, L, Msb, K) and [of mult.] juyuwdN. (L, K.) layRinapu AlOajoyaAdi means A female soft in respect of the neck; as though the term jiydN applied to each distinct part of the neck, and the pl. denoted the whole neck. (L.)

jayodaAnapN jydAnh jydAnp
jayodaAnapN: see Oajoyadu.

jayRidN jyd
jayRidN: see art. jwd.

Oajoyadu c
Oajoyadu Having a long neck: (A, Msb, K:) or having a long and beautiful neck: (S, L:) or having a slender and long neck: (L, K:) or it is not applied to a man: (T, TA:) fem. jayodaMCu, (S, L, Msb, K,) with which jayodaAnapN↓ is syn.; (K;) or this signifies having a beautiful neck: (L:) pl. juwdN [originally juyodN]. (S, A, K.) And EunuqN Oajoyadu A long and beautiful, or slender and long, neck. (L.)

2 jyRr jyr
2. jyRr He plastered a watering-trough or tank with jayRaAr. (TA.)

jayori jyr
jayori, with kesr to the r, (S, Mughnee, K, &c.,) like Oamosi; (Mughnee;) and jayora, like Oayona; and sometimes jayorK; (Mughnee, K;) or this, where it occurs, is for jayori UinRa, and is properly written jayorino, UinRa in the sense of naEamo being a corroborative of jayori, and its hemzeh and sheddeh and final vowel being here suppressed: (Mughnee:) a form of oath, (S, K,) or put in the place of an oath, (IAmb, TA,) meaning Verily, or truly; syn. HaqRFA: (S, K:) or a responsive particle, (Mughnee,) meaning yes; syn. naEamo [which is most approved as responsive to an interrogation], (Mughnee, K,) or Oajalo [which is most approved as responsive to an affirmation]; (Sharh et-Tesheel, K;) not a noun in the sense of HaqRFA, for were it so it would be an inf. n.; nor in the sense of OabadFA, for were it so it would be an adv. n. of time; and if it were a noun it would be decl., and would admit the article Al, and would not have UinRa for a corroborative, nor have laA opposed to it, as it has in the saying,
UicaA taquwlu laA Qbonapu AlEujayori
taSoduqu laA UicaA taquwlu jayori
[When the daughter of El-'Ojeyr says lA, she speaks truly: not when she says jyr]: (Mughnee:) or it is a verbal noun, meaning I know; syn. OaEorifu; as is mentioned by Ibn-Abi-r-Rabeea, and by Er-Radee on the authority of 'Abd-El- Káhir. (MF.) You say, jayori laA Mtiyka Verily, or truly, [&c.,] I will not come to thee. (S.) And jayori laA OafoEalu celika Verily, or truly, [&c.,] I will not do that. (K, * TA.) And laA jayori laA OafoEalu No, verily, or truly, [&c.,] I will not do [that]. (K.)

jiyrN jyr
jiyrN Gypsum; syn. jiSRN. (IAar, TA.) [In modern Arabic, Lime: see also what next follows.]

jayRaArN jyAr
jayRaArN Quick lime, and the mixtures thereof, with which are plastered watering-troughs or tanks, and baths; syn. SaAruwjN: (S, K:) quick lime and gypsum mixed with ashes: (IAar TA:) or quick lime alone. (TA. [See also jiyrN.]) ＝ -A2- [A limeburner: so in the present day: see OatuwnN.] ＝ -A3- Heat in the chest, by reason of rage or hunger; as also jaAYirN↓: (S, K:) or cough, or the like. (Ham p. 56.) It is app. of the measure faERaAlN; or it may be of the measure fayoEaAlN; or fawoEaAlN [originally jawoyaArN]. (IJ, TA.) ― -b2- Strength, or vehemence. (TA.)

jaAYirN c
jaAYirN: see jayRaArN.

mujayRarN mjyr
mujayRarN A watering-trough or tank made small: or made deep: or plastered with gypsum. (K.)

1 jaAXa c
1. jaAXa, (S, A, Msb, K,) aor. yajiyXu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. jayoXN (Msb, K) and jayaXaAnN (T, K) and juyuwXN, (K,) said of a cooking-pot (T, S, A, Msb, K) &c., (T, A, K,) It boiled, or estuated: (T, S, A, Msb, K:) or began to do so, not yet boiling or estuating; this latter being said by some to be the correct meaning. (Ib, L, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) It (the sea) estuated (A, * K, TA) with the waves, (A, TA,) so that it was unnavigable. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) It (a valley) flowed with much water, its water, or waves, rising high. (S, K. *) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) It (a water-spout, or pipe,) poured forth water: (TA:) and [in like manner] you say of the eye, jaAXato, meaning, (assumed tropical:) it flowed, or overflowed, with tears. (K.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) He (a horse) reared, and became excited. (TA.) ― -b6- jaAXato nafosuhu, (S, K,) or jaAXato Uilayohi nafosuhu, (A,) (tropical:) His soul [or stomach] heaved; or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; syn. gavato; (S, K, TA;) or faArato; (T in art. vwr; see vaArato nafosuhu in that art.;) as though what was in his belly rose to his fauces: (TA:) or his soul [as it were] turned round, [i. e., he became giddy,] with the tendency to vomit: (S, K:) as also tjyRXt↓; (K;) which occurs in the former of these senses in a trad.: (TA:) and jaAXato nafosuhu also signifies his soul [or stomach] heaved, by reason of grief or fright; (K;) [as also jaOaXato;] or when this last signification is meant, you say jaXaOato: (S:) and his (a coward's) soul purposed flight: or was frightened: as also jaOaXato, in either of these two senses: (TA:) and jaAXato Uilayohi AlnRafosu his heart quitted its place by reason of fear. (EM p. 79.) ― -b7- jaAXa Sadoruhu (tropical:) His bosom boiled with wrath, or rage. (TA.) You say also, Sadoruhu yajiyXu EalaIRa biAlgilRi (tropical:) [His bosom boils against me with rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite; or with latent rancour, &c.]. (A.) ― -b8- jaAXa AlhamRu fiI AlSRadori Anxiety boiled in the bosom: and in like manner, jaAXati AlguSRapu fiI AlSRadori (assumed tropical:) [Choking wrath or rage boiled in the bosom]. (T, TA.) ― -b9- jaAXat AlHarobu bayonahumo (A, L) (tropical:) War, or the war, [boiled, or raged, or] began to boil [or rage,] between them. (L, TA.) ― -b10- In the following words of a poet, cited by IAar,
qaAmato tabadRaI laka fiI jayoXaAnihaA
(assumed tropical:) [She arose, showing herself to thee] in her strength and youth, [tabadRaI being for tatabadRaI,] jyXAn, [the inf. n.,] meaning as rendered above, is with sukoon [to the I] by poetic license. (ISd, TA.)

2 jyRX c
2. jyRX, [from jayoXN,] He collected, or assembled, armies, or military forces. (S.) And jyRX jayoXFA [He collected, or assembled, an army, or a military force]. (A.)

5 tjyRXt nafosuhu c
5. tjyRXt nafosuhu: see 1. ＝ -A2- [tjyRXwA, from jayoXN, They became collected, or assembled, as an army, or a military force: or they formed themselves into an army, or a military force.]

10 AstjAX c
10. AstjAX, [from jayoXN,] He demanded, or summoned, armies, or military forces, mino maHalRi kacaA from such a place. (A.) And AstjAXhu He demanded of him an army, or a military force. (S.)

jaAXN c
jaAXN: see jaOoXN, in art. jOX, in two places; and see AljaAYiXapu, below.

jayoXN c
jayoXN An army; a military force: (A, K:) or a body of men in war: (TA:) or men going to war or for some other purpose: (T, K, TA:) pl. juyuwXN. (S, A Msb, K.)

jayoXapN c
jayoXapN A single rising, or heaving, or the like: pl. jayoXaAtN: hence the phrase jayoXaAtu AlOabaATiyli [app. meaning The risings of false or vain things in the mind, or the like]. (TA.)

mirojalN jayRaAXN c
mirojalN jayRaAXN [A cooking-pot boiling, or boiling much]. (A.) ― -b2- farasN jiyRaAXN (assumed tropical:) A horse that rears and is excited when thou puttest him in motion with thy heel. (K * TA.)

AljaAYiXapu c
AljaAYiXapu The soul; syn. AlnRafosu; (K;) [as also AljaOoXu, sometimes written AljaAXu↓, without C;] mentioned by some in art. jOX. (TA.) Quasi

jayaAEaI jwEAn jyAEI jyAEy
jayaAEaI and juyRaEN: see jaAYiEN, in art. jwE.

1 jaAfati Aljiyfapu jAft Aljyfh jAft Aljyfp
1. jaAfati Aljiyfapu, aor. tajiyfu; (K;) and jyRft↓, (S, * K,) inf. n. tajoyiyfN; (S;) and AjtAft↓, (K,) [and tjyRft↓, Golius, as from the K, but not found by me in any copy thereof,] and AnjAft↓; (TA;) The dead body stank, or became stinking. (S, * K, TA.)

2 jyRf jyf jyfp
2. jyRf He became a stinking dead body. (Mgh, KL.) ― -b2- See also 1.

5 tajayRafa
5: see 1.

7 Uinojayafa
7: see 1.

8 Uijotayafa
8: see 1.

jiyfapN jyfh jyfp
jiyfapN [A carcass, or corpse, i. e.] a dead body [of a beast or a man], that has become stinking; (S, Mgh, K;) or, as some say, in a general sense; [whether stinking or not:] (TA:) or, of beasts and cattle, an animal that has died a natural death, or been killed otherwise than in the manner prescribed by the law, and has become stinking: (Msb:) [and the corpse of a man: (see jayRaAfN:)] pl. [of mult.] jiyafN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and [of pauc.] OajoyaAfN. (S K.) [Hence,] jiyfapu layolK quTorubu nahaArK One who sleeps all the night, and labours all the day. (TA from a trad. [See also art. qTrb.]) IDrd mentions this word in art. jwf, holding the I to be originally w. (TA.)

jayRaAfN jyAf
jayRaAfN A rifler, or ransacker, of graves; (K, TA;) because he removes the [grave-] clothes from the corpses, and takes them; or, as some say, because of the stinking nature of his act. (TA.)

jiylN jyl
jiylN A nation, people, race, tribe, or family of mankind; (S, Msb, K;) such as the Turks, and the Greeks, (S. TA,) and the Chinese: (TA:) pl. OajoyaAlN (M, Msb, TA) and jiylaAnN. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And A generation of men. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also juwlN.

jayalu jyl
jayalu: see jayoOalu, in art. jOl.

jayolaAnu AlHaSaI jylAn AlHSI jylAn AlHSy
jayolaAnu AlHaSaI Small pebbles which the wind makes to turn about or round about, to circle, or to revolve: (S, K:) but this belongs to art. jwl. (TA.) ＝ -A2- yawomN jayolaAnu: see Oajowalu, in art. jwl.

yawomN jayolaAniIRN ywm jylAnI ywm jylAny
yawomN jayolaAniIRN: see Oajowalu, in art. jwl.

2 jyRm jiymFA jym jymA
2. jyRm jiymFA He wrote a j. (K.)

jiymN jym
jiymN The letter j: masc. and fem.: (T, K, * TA:) pl. OajoyaAmN and jiymaAtN. (TA.) Quasi

jiyhN jyh jyp
jiyhN: see juwhN, in art. jwh.
